If you can take a visual arts course with David Antin or Jean-Pierre Gorin, do it... they will open your eyes to the world around you!

To me, an east-coaster who has also lived in the midwest, and seen other California campuses like Berkely, UCSD doesn't look like a real college or university campus.  It gets bigger and better each year, but it's still a commuter school and it's going to stay that way until it has a sustainable, well-laid-out campus in a walkable setting.  There is no character, no college area.  You can't walk anywhere from here; you can hardly walk across the campus it's so spread out.  Because of the high land values, the surrounding housing is mostly luxury condos.  Seeing the few students who do live nearby walk to class is almost as absurd as watching people walk in pirate costumes or Star Trek TNG uniforms down a city street, they look so out of place.

UCSD is just a maze of suburban sprawl in the middle of more suburban sprawl.  I think the academics of this college are an afterthought.  People come to UCSD because they want to be in San Diego and they also want to go to a decent college with a decent reputation.  This college is riding on the fact that it is the largest and most prestigious higher educational institution in San Diego.  As San Diego is a major city that has experienced rapid population growth, sustained economic prosperity, and a continued influx of wealthy and intelligent people, it would simply be impossible for this university to do anything other than thrive.

Ecologically, the campus is rather fake.  Lots of Eucalyptus groves, ice plant, artificial-looking grassy lawns, everything maintained by sprinkler systems.  Everything treated with chemicals.  They even spray chemicals right around the kid's playground in daycare in the grad student housing.  You can watch the kids come out the next day crawling around in the grass, probably getting all different kinds of cancer.  Reminds me of the cancer of suburban sprawl emanating from UCSD to the south, east, and north.

I loved my time at UC San Diego. The professors are first rate and the quarter system makes it very easy to track your success. 

The students are really intelligent and ambitious but unpretentious. Casual beach culture reigns high. 

Living in San Diego was like being on vacation everyday. There are so many beautiful parts of San Diego to explore: La Jolla, Del Mar, Pacific Beach, Balboa Park, Downtown...

Contrary to popular belief, UCSD is a very social campus. But if you sit in your dorm and wait for someone to dig you out, you probably will feel pretty alone and bored. The key is getting involved. At UCSD,  social kids join the greek system, a club sports team, Associated Students, or a cultural organization. It's too big of a school for everyone to just "be your friend" automatically. 

If you're outgoing, enjoy intellectual conversation as well as a good beer with your toes in the sand, you'll never want to leave UCSD.
A UC school, in a great city, with amazing weather. What more could you want? :)

Thumbs up for the quality of education, Old Student Center, and Art of Espresso. And like every review has said, hey the social life isn't that great, but it's really what you make of it. Join clubs, go to events, etc.

Thumbs down for the sh*tty administration.. I really believe that UCSD does not care about its students, no matter what they say. Me and many of my friends have had frequent bad encounters with various offices, such as advisors who never show up for appointments, rude and surly office assistants and other staff who are always "too busy" to serve you, and even counselors who give you incorrect advice on what classes to take, subsequently screwing up your schedule and wasting your time.
While I've appreciated my education and the friends I've made, I definitely don't love UCSD.

I have so many dichotomous feelings about UCSD. In certain areas, I could give it a single star; on others, a 5. The campus is absolutely magnificent and truly makes up for any downfalls the university may have. 

The students are quiet intellectuals who you cannot bribe for notes, no matter what. It's competitive as hell. Want or need notes? Well, you better kiss someones butt because no one wants you getting a better grade than themselves. Once, I remember a girl asking me for two weeks worth of notes and I questioned her like a PI. While I'm sitting in class typing 90 WPM, trying to pick up everything the instructor is saying so that I can actually pass the course, you put in zero effort. I think not.

I went to UCSD twice. Once to obtain my BA and the second to get my minor, When I went back to finish my minor in 2011, there were a lot of changes. The Rady School of Business was completed. So was the parking structure near the Social Sciences building (finally!). I feel that UCSD truly wants to be the best, and you can tell by the way they take care of the campus. 

Back in 2007, I had the fortunate experience of living in the dorms (Warren Apartments-Black Hall). Apparently, only graduate students can reside there now. Living on campus was one of the most amazing experiences of my life because everyday I took advantage of the opportunities and amenities. I went to watch movies in the price center. I rode my bicycle to class everyday. I took 2 hour runs around the campus; even at 11 at night. I tried the food at every college. If I wanted to study at Geisel at one in the morning during finals week, I could just walk there. I will never forget my stay on campus. If you at all have the opportunity to live in the dorms, please do so.

The downfall of UCSD, however, is its liberal arts. You will learn theory; tons and tons of theory. You will learn history. You will write a lot. You will have to and want to prove yourself to students and professors, often. You will read more than you have ever read in your life (I just started leisure reading after years of putting it off because UCSD knocked the enjoyment of reading out of me). Finally, you will not make many friends because the school is competitive and frankly, you will not have much time to socialize.

Moreover, you will rarely learn to implement your knowledge. I fought hard sifting through hundreds of courses trying to find one that had a more hands on approach. Even when I thought I found one that was more practical, the classes were sometimes boring and consisted mostly of theory and history on the subject matter.

If you want to be intellectually stimulated and surround yourself with some extremely intelligent peers, then this is a great school for you. However, be very careful when selecting the courses you take. READ THE CAPE AND GO BY IT. The cape has rarely done me wrong. Make sure you are willing to put in the effort. UCSD is not necessarily hard, but you do have to be extremely dedicated to your education.

In terms of the people, I find that if you are not a science major, you will see plenty of attractive young guys and girls. They may not be stereotypically good looking but who wants ordinary? Trust me, people who have personality and intelligence will keep your interest much longer than those who are good looking but shallow.

There you go. This is my summation for UCSD being a Sociology major with an emphasis in science and medicine. The hard sciences, I know to be much, much worse. Trust me when I say, I feel bad for the kids who have to endure years of tough classes and competition. Especially since in the hard sciences, professors often grade on a curve.

There is so much more to write but I don't have time; I will have to save my additions for another day.

OMG!!!  How I miss being at UCSD!!

I started at Revelle (for four years) only to end-up at Muir.  Those requirements are killer when you're so burnt out!!  Probably because I commuted the whole time I was there!  I seriously wished I had dormed in the Revelle Mudhuts!!  And speaking about Revelle...the highlights were "The Watermelon Drop" and "The Renaissance Fair".  How I miss this school!!!

I remember rowing crew in freshman year, HAW (Honors Achievement Workshop), MOD (Methods of Inquiry) class taught by Quincy Troupe, hanging-out at THE GROVE Cafe and going to the record store at The Price Center.  The Library was used in the movie "Close Encounters", 3rd and 5th colleges did not have names yet and have you heard the singing trees?

If you're thinking about going to UCSD, even to visit, PLEASE GO!  It has so much history, it's amazing.  Too bad we all have to grow up.  I may just take some classes at the UCSD Extension, just so I can be around all that once again!!

1. Urban Studies & Planning program/dept. -- 5 stars.

great professors, curriculum, well-planned program.
In a few of the USP classes I've taken, the profs have brought in guest speakers from the field, such as from SANDAG, environmental, transportation agencies, etc. And a couple profs are really liberal and real--makes me feel if I were at Berkeley.

2. administrative stuff -- 3

USP faculty were very friendly and helpful when I added it as my second major. But the head lady (Valorie) retired and now there's a new guy, who although is still super-friendly, doesn't know as much.

Sixth College advising is good with walk-ins. But it's been more than a whole quarter since I've turned in my double major forms and gotten approved, but STILL not on my student info stuff or whatever.. which made me unable to register for upper-div classes, until I went back to the USP office to get pre-authorized, and by then the class was full.

3. parking -- 4

EVERYONE complains about parking.
Well, you know what?? JUST DON'T DRIVE to school.
UCSD is obviously trying to incentivize students to drive less by incurring high parking permit costs and sky-high tickets. There are free shuttles. If you don't want to park (and pay) at Regents, do what my friend does and park at Vons and then hop on the Arriba shuttle to campus.
UCSD already has like 3 parking structures, and a decent amount of surface parking. If you really want more parking, imagine how %@$& ugly the campus will be with more eyesore concrete parking. (just view the campus from google.maps satellite.)

Everything else someone's probably already mentioned.

btw, an update: UCSD websites have finally been revamped. Tritonlink is under students.ucsd.edu, and webct is now ted.ucsd.edu.

This review will be about the Chancellor's Associates benefit, which unfortunately the rate per annum jumps from $350 to $2500 starting this year (wtf!). 

For the time being, it's an awesome program. You get the holiest of holies parking permit - the purple chancellor's permit, which allows you to park in any available spot (A, B, S). You also get a Passport card, which gives you buy 1 get 1 free at over 100 local restaurants from $ to $$$$. Also includes RIMAC and faculty club access. You also get a gratis Sungod ticket. Also whenever you go to campus, you can call into the Alumni office and ask for a day pass parking code, gratis. 

That's a whole lot for $350!! I even kind of feel bad because out of that $350, how much is actually donated to the school? Seems like a LOT is spent on developing benefits to attract new people. Sadly this program will be prohibitively expensive now.

As my premier review, I decided to review the place with which I identify the most. I spent the past five years of my educational life here. Last year, I completed the first year of my graduate work in the Education Studies (EDS) program. I also worked as a staff for the TRIO Outreach Programs. Currently, I am in the second (and last) year of the EDS program.

I was introduced to the university by an outreach officer from San Diego. He pulled me out of class and helped me fill out the application. Soon after, I was admitted to the UCSD Eleanor Roosevelt College Class of 2007. Later, I got an early start to college by participating in the Summer Bridge program ran by OASIS. Since then, my life as been going full speed.

Being a math major and a part of the (EDS) program as an undergrad, I felt the best thing I got out of college was the practical experience. The faculty at UCSD is dedicated to their research work. Fortunately for me, the research performed by EDS involves training better teachers. For others, you have to seek out the support. 

People say that the staff and faculty at UCSD do not care. You really must be pro-active in getting the help. It's true: no one is going to knock on your dorm room door and explain to you how to graduate in four years. You have to make an effort see a academic counselor and have them walk you through a four-year plan. Trust me, they are nice. There are many resources on-campus to help with whatever you need. Other programs like the Office of Academic Support and Instructional Services (OASIS) offer free tutoring and job opportunities for qualified undergraduates.

Now that I have graduated and got into grad school, I can see that the standards for admission have gone up. Like hundreds of students now, I can say that I am one of those that probably would not have gotten in had I applied now.

For my 100th review, I thought I'd write about the very reason why I came to San Diego: UCSD.

I really really liked the school when I checked it out as a high school student.  I liked it so much, that I turned down UCLA, Berkeley, and Stanford, to go to the campus down by the sea, and see what trouble I could get into and what adventures I could have.  

First off, what attracted me as an undergraduate in 2001 was the college system.  While having over 20,000 students, UCSD's undergraduate college system--which breaks the population down into six smaller, liberal arts colleges, tries to build a spirit of community while giving you the access to a big school's resources.  I was really impressed with my college, Eleanor Roosevelt, when I showed up as a senior and the dean of students came out and talked to me for nearly an hour, something I'm sure wouldn't happen at most other UCs.

The college system can be a trifle tricky, but it's comforting to know that your major isn't affected significantly by your college choice--however, there are certain prerequisites that fit in with the philosophy of each college--i.e., Thurgood Marshall emphasizes civil rights and American citizenship, Roger Revelle places heavy stress on taking math and science regardless of discipline, etc--so keep that in mind.

The campus itself is really nicely laid out, it's a bit big, but the center of the campus is a walkway called library walk, that connects the library (named after Dr. Seuss and shaped like an enormous Broccoli of Knowledge).  During a regular school day, look for library walk to be crowded with everything from fraternity pledges, to Korean barbecue sales, to Christian groups singing songs, to the occasional renaissance fair production.  It's crazy.

I loved my classes, my departments, and the choices I had there.  I was a double major in history and religious studies, and took enough classes to be a theatre minor although I didn't declare it.

Now, as for diversity, all I can is simply thus:  UCSD tries hard.  And doesn't succeed entirely well.  For people of color, particularly Latinos, African-Americans, Filipinos, and Native Americans, the campus can feel a bit unfriendly, particularly if you're used to people looking like you, or feeling like you're not the 'only one.'  There are amazing resource centers at UCSD, however, for people wanting to connect with larger community--UCSD boasts a Women's Center, LGBT Resource Center, and a Cross Cultural Center, all of which provide safe spaces for discussion, dialog, and community forming.  Join them!

If I had some suggestions to make, in all honesty, they would be:

* get involved:  Getting involved is ESSENTIAL to being at UCSD.  UCSD lacks some of the traditional 'social structures' of other schools, but there is no end to a sense of community if you seek one out.  There are clubs/organizations/groups for anything from French films to Hinduism to playing magic the gathering.  Find your niche.  Do it.

* Take advantage: From scholarships, to study abroad, to job opportunities, TAKE THEM.  you won't regret it.  I feel that perhaps doing a little of everything (like i did) may not be the best, but as a former: Resident Advisor, Orientation Leader, Tour Guide, Course Grader, and Study Abroad participant (in South Africa), I must say that it is SO VERY WORTH IT to take advantage of whatever opportunities are available.

*Explore San Diego:  There's so much more to UCSD than La Jolla; if only I'd known that my first two years here.  Go to Balboa Park.  The Zoo.  Scout around.  Find new places.  The farther from LJ, the better.

--because I'm crazy, I then went back to UCSD for a one year masters in history.  It was intense, but very worth it, and for you potential UCSD graduate students out there, please definitely take advantages of grad student socials, things put on by the GSA (Grad Student Association), and meet people outside of your department.  It will do you nearly as much good as a pint at porters after six hours of reading for a seminar the next day.

All in all, UCSD has been plenty good to me.  A great campus, high rated faculty, super involvement opportunities, and so much more.  While diversity is a bit lacking, and one does have to find opportunities on ones own initiative, it's an amazing campus, and I'm glad to have my two degrees from there.

If you are a social animal, going to UCSD shouldn't be a problem regardless. In retrospect, I really liked UCSD. Its pretty, right by La Jolla Shores. Our apartment and dorm had ocean views (Muir!) The biggest thing people complained about was the social life. Solution: Go Greek, join a club, leave your dorm room. UCSD was a fun college experience. 

You can ride a longboard to class and the dorm food isn't bad. You can always hit up the beach. Being a communications major was pretty fun and interesting too. Oh. And you'll get a pretty degree.

Amazing science programs. Honestly, one of the best schools for science on the West coast. If you're planning on majoring in something like literature, then maybe you should look elsewhere, because the literature department here is fairly small. Or, if you're going to major in international studies maybe do a little more research because the department here is not as well known as other places. Some of the better programs here are: chem, bio, poli sci, engineering, physics, music and theater.

Pros:
Great quality of education
World renown Professors who are masters in their field
TA's are extraordinarily helpful if you get right one
Campus is very clean and well-kept
The Student Centers are great
You learn a lot if you apply yourself

Cons:
Administration doesn't seem to care too much for their students
Social events are too far and few in between
Everything is pretty expensive (but this is to be expected)
Super old lecture halls (ex: Solis)
Some Professors care only about their research and not their students (but, fear not, there are some really great Professors too)
Can be difficult to meet people if you're not willing to put yourself out there (but college is what you make of it)

So yeah, I enjoy it here. I don't regret coming here, not anymore at least. :]
I would definitely consider going to college here again.

UCSD... great buy for your money especially if you're majoring in the engineering/science fields. Well known for their political science and psychology programs in their respective fields. The campus architecture is really modern and the food at the dining commons were pretty good (at least when I was there!)

I like to give back to my Alma mater.  I don't respond to the donation letters they send me, but every time I set foot on campus I get a parking ticket.  The fines have doubled since 2005 to an outrageous $65, though, so I don't visit very often.

As previous Yelper Eddie P. suggested: this is a truly beautiful campus- situated on top of Torrey Pines Mesa and with a fantastic view of the blue waters of La Jolla Shores down below.The hundreds of eucalyptus trees that dot the campus offered lush and pungent shade. The intriguing designs and architecture of the various Schools and especially that Space-Age library would trip anybody out.

Why 5 Stars? This is where you will get a mind-expanding education that will truly separate the student wheat from the chaff. And cost you a pretty penny too! It's all true that the campus has a very sterile, business-like atmosphere that-while not made for heavy-duty partying is still conducive to the intense learning atmosphere that exists there.

With all the super-bright Asian students, you really have to be on your toes at UCSD. If the classes you take have professors who grade on a curve-it's time to break out  the coffee and get to  the unending study jams! I remember coming home from school, grabbing some more books and grub, and then heading right back to the school library to pull almost all-nighters. Go to UCSD and BET ON being in-the-books all the time!

When I was a student in the 1980's, there wasn't too much sports stuff going on. To get my activity fix on, I had to join a number of dance classes and also the College Jogging Club--where daily runs on Black's Beach were a common occurrence!  (Clothed!)

Most of my classes were in those huge, cavern-like halls where you feel like you're just a number. To the professor's eternal credit, many were able to personalize and make these behemoths  intellectually manageable.

UCSD is NOT the place to go and try and score a hot guy or girl. Mostly the students may have a lot between their ears but they ain't so great in the looks department! I remember meeting a really cute, hippie-looking guy in a political science class and thinking how lucky I was to have a hottie finally! It was shocking!

So, despite the cost and financial expense, the hard classes with lots of homework, the lack of good-looking students on campus, and the sometimes impersonal classroom experiences, I believe that UCSD is a great choice and selection for someone looking for a excellent education in a positive learning environment.

I went home at the end of September to parade my boyfriend around San Diego.  Needless to say, I felt the need to show-off my alma mater.  Unfortunately, we went during Welcome Week, and not only was the place a zoo, but we almost got ran over by a bunch of Sixth College freshmen, complete with face paint, running around in a fashion similar to that of a flock of birds (minus that whole flying thing).  And I hate to be a superficial space cadet, but the "campus faces" really are getting uglier and shorter.  I guess that's what happens when the school starts becoming more competitive and the "smarter" kids are overtaking the campus by a storm (or flock).  

Despite my shallowness though, I have nothing but love for my college campus.  

First of all, what other college campus do you know has a talking tree?  And the Sun God (which, by the way, was missing on our visit - does anyone know what happened to it)?  Or a building that the flashes the 7 Vices/Virtues as you're stumbling home drunk?  The Stuart Art Collection definitely adds points to campus "flair."  The buildings and structures really do make UCSD more unique that some of the other campuses I've visited.  Despite its appearance, the Che Cafe, is much to my delight, still standing.  

Your college experience is definitely what you make of it.  While the school lacks (for the most part) in spirit (I think it's because we don't have a football team) and partying, you can find groups and activities for you with a little hard work and some luck.  The school is large enough and diverse enough for everyone to find something of interest.

As far as education goes (the part that I've been told should matter the most), the degree (mine is in Computer Engineering) is a great buy.  The rest of the programs are pretty amazing too - all my friends in various disciplines have faired really well since graduation.  UCSD's reputation will, supplemented by a grammatically correct resume, at least buy yourself into an interview (you just have to do the rest as far as that whole "getting a job" goes.).  Thanks to the less than average looking freshmen, the college's reputation will continue to rise - which really helps to give that degree an extra boost.

P.S.  Don't fool yourself into thinking that you'll be going surfing between classes - that's what I thought and let me tell you, I was very, very wrong...  And no, hot nude girls do not hang out on Black's Beach between classes either.

Wow, no love for girls on this campus.
It's okay, I take no offense. I embrace my rainbow flip-flops, am not ashamed of my attachment to sweat pants, and take pride in the battle scars that I have gained from recklessly walking through UCSD's hilly slopes and forests.

Seriously, though. I'm quite thankful for the way this school:
1) mellowed me out, even if it has had eye-sore consequences (hey, beauty is fleeting, but  the art of enjoying life pairs well with wrinkles!).

2) piled essay assignments on me (compliments of MMW, and the Sociology Department), so that I could apply my writing-skills to significant and meaningful things... like Yelp reviews.

3) committed itself to keeping students healthy by: (a) offering a sad-selection of food at outrageous prices,(b) distancing lecture halls half-a-mile apart, and (c) providing an amazing gym that required a workout just getting to.

4) gave me an excuse to live in arguably one of the best locations on the Continental-U.S. for three glorious years.

I love San Diego. Thus, I love UCSD.

Specifially I write in order to recommend to the cultured and mature. If you are from where the cultural life is more rich than ol Sunny Daygo, check out the concert series at the Mandeville Auditorium. Truly WORLD CLASS international musical acts, look it up , check it out and enjoy deeply.

Also, the campus is a nice place to go for a leisurely stroll, you can easily hoof it over to the Glider Port and Blacks Beach. The architecture may not be to your liking but if nothing else it IS interesting and provocative.

I'll start by disclosing my bias: I got my degree and currently teach here. It's actually a great institution. A little overboard on the bureaucracy: Just try addressing a specific issue or anything that falls any tiny bit beyond what the nameless bureaucrats there are trained to do. Still, that's as a much a problem of contemporary life, as it is with this specific university, so it's hard to fault them too much for it. 

In the meantime, the academics truly are outstanding ... and let's face it, that's what it's there for in the first place.

As a transfer student, I can say that I blossomed like a flat-chested girl when puberty is achieved.  I was on the trillion-year program at community college and had forgotten what it was like (with few exceptions- Bouscaren and Christenson, both of whom I ended up working for)  to think critically.  

I felt like a dumb-ass in some of my classes &  had a few dumb-ass classes while there.  Sadly they were my anthropology core classes.  Useless.  But all was not lost as I participated on a dig abroad and was exposed to so many peer-reviewed journals that I feel like an expert myself!

pros...oh what can i say about my alma mater?  well it is one darn good school.  ranked #1 for research, great funding from the NIH too.  beautiful campus, located on the bluffs of la jolla.  that means cool ocean breezes and a warm sun too.  mist, fog in the morning, burning off to sunny days.  interesting architecture on the campus.  love the book store too.  

cons...well not much in the social development department.  studying is not a sport!  studying is not a hobby either!  studying is all that seems to get done here.  so if you find yourself with too much time and the want, no, take that back, the NEED to study.  ucsd is the place for you.  don't go here to party, don't come here to make friends, don't come here to find HOT, or HAWT, or super fine, this is not the meat market, go to sdsu for that.  but solidly constructed, average types to downright charity, as Brian said, the UGLY stick was working overtime here. yeah, i'm one.  it didn't miss me.

depressing school. 
always cloudy. 
no one is friendly.  
17 hours of homework per day if you get stuck in ERC. 
so busy with GEs that there is no time for your major. 
you are taught how to BS through papers and make them sound legit.
there isn't time to learn at this school. 

go to community college FIRST, then transfer:
those people seemed happier.

good things:

there is a talking tree and also a singing tree in the woods.

find them at night when you are alone.

As someone whose attended UCI and UCSD, I must say SD has a uniqueness of its own.  True, you are pretty much on your own island down in San Diego, but don't let that put you down.   Throughout the year, the school holds engaging activities for their student body.  Also, the Price Center (which has just been expanded) is located conveniently in the middle, accessible from any of the six colleges.  Dining halls are pretty much scattered throughout  campus so you're not likely to starve.  Unless, of course, it's after midnight then your best hope is to head to Ocean View Terrace.

Speaking of the ocean, that alone is worth TEN stars =D

Unfortunately, SD doesn't have much in the way of sports.  Although, I hear their water-based sports (rowing, water polo) etc. are pretty good.  There is a lack of a football team.  Also, the malls around here aren't all that great.  You only get University Town Center and Fashion Valley.  But if you're sociable and approachable, you'll find other ways to pass the time.  If you know what I mean.

A lot can be said about UCSD.  People generally tend to say the following about UCSD: 

1. It is a very anti-social campus 
2.  Yeah  people at UCSD are lame but I made my own fun 
3.  People are very ugly here

Its hard for me to say how I feel about UCSD.  During my freshman year, I thought I made a mistake.  Now that I have graduated, I am really glad I went to UCSD.   I made some really great friends and had a great time.   After a semi-crappy first year, I decided to take advantage of being a college student and tried to do as much as possible.  I went to many free concerts on campus and joined a couple of clubs/orgs.  I studied abroad and participated in the UCDC program (I highly recommend doing this program).   When I turned 21, I explored PB, downtown and other random bars.   

For me, UCSD holds a special place in my heart because at the beginning of spring quarter of my sophomore year, my dad passed away.  I was very surprised at the amount of support I received at UCSD.   I was an ERC student and the assisant res dean was very helpful and encouraged me to take time off if needed.  All of my professors were supportive and let me make up my work at my own pace.   People may say that students here are anti-social but during this rough time for me, my friends and other kids living in the dorms around me were so nice.  People  I hardly knew were giving me class notes or buying me a meal with their meal points.   

I cant really comment on what classes were like because I dont remember them.  I was a communication major and its a good major a UCSD.   I had some pretty hot comm professors and TAs. Science classes suck unless you like the sort of thing.  Take as many film classes as possible, they are easy and fun.

Took my girlfriend's sister here to check it out to see if it is a choice for going to school. The campus is big. You will probably have to drive or bike to your classes since it is so spread out. It is awesome that it is by the ocean, so it's nice and cool and pretty. If I tried to study there, I might not get work done because I would just stare out into the ocean.

They have lots of cool architecture around since it was last donated. There is a house on top of a building. That was interesting. The library has an interesting design. It almost looks like a space ship.

There are 6 areas to live, called colleges. The confusing thing is that your GE requirements depends on what college you live at. So if 2 people have the same major but live in different colleges, they have different GE requirements.

Don't get me wrong. I am very grateful to be here. It's a reputable school with many research opportunities for undergrads. It plays host to some amazing intellectuals, and some of the top scientific minds the world has to offer.

With that said, I also have a fair number of gripes with this place. UCSD served me well when I was studying biochemistry. I got a legit position in a lab, and learned so much doing hands-on work. I felt like my courses sufficiently supplemented my work, and everything was just fine. But when I switched majors to pursue my love of music, everything changed.

Granted, the music department is not a big one. However, the curriculum is embarrassingly rudimentary... as in "I could have passed this upper division course when I was 10." I do not feel that the courses required of me for graduation will sufficiently prepare me for graduate work, or even graduate school applications. In light of statewide budget cuts, UCSD's music program was hit particularly hard. I was recently told that my major, vocal performance, may even be nixed, and turned into an even more generalized BA. That... is just sad.

In addition, the administration is downright incompetent. Recent events (the highly publicized racial tensions) have exemplified the University bureaucracy's flaws.

Taking the fee hikes into consideration, I truly believe that UCSD is no longer one of the best bangs for your buck in education. The 32% increase puts our tuition right up there, next to the average private school. And for all that mollycoddling, alumni networking, job placement, smaller class sizes, better faculty:student ratio, and superior facilities, I say go ahead and splurge on USC or Claremont. 

Bottom line: the tuition has risen to the point where the costs outweigh the benefits.

UCSD has wonderful professors that make you feel like you're getting a truly elite college education at a public school (albeit still expensive...but public school) price. But it also has awful ones that make you want to crawl into a hole and cry at the injustice of it all.

Socially, the school is huge, but it also can be terribly small. If you have an unpopular major, you'll see the same kids again and again. Same goes for living on campus, or joining a group of some sort.

The college system makes certain things particularly easy, while other schoolwide tasks, like signing up for a doctor's appointment, can require weeks of waiting.

What I will give UCSD credit for is trying. They acknowledge the problems on campus, and try to change them. Sometimes it helps, sometimes it hurts, but they try. They expanded the main student center to accommodate a growing student population. They are working on opening up an on-campus nightclub to create a more social atmosphere. They're building on campus housing for transfers. At least our rising tuition costs are going somewhere.

Enjoyed my time in Grad school at UCSD, but the undergrads seem to have no enthusiasm for anything other than studying. This was great for me as a TA but come on, live it up a little! 
Obviously UCSD is an excellent school; The Economist ranked it 18th in the world at one point which shows what truly elite scholarship is achieved at UCSD, but as far as engaged student bodies go...well, lets just say that it's lacking, big time.

Other cons: on campus food options, the Price center, such a large sprawling campus with no central square, the architecture (my friends and I refered to the AP&M concrete monstrosity as the "suicide building" do to the fact that if you had to spend any amount of time in there you'd try to defenestrate yourself through one of the tiny slot windows). Oh, and worst of all is the surrounding area. La Jolla and UTC is a cultural wasteland devoid of anything resembling a decent bar, music venue or restaurant.

Some Pros: The campus is practically perched on the ocean, Giesel library can be cool up on the 8th floor if it's not crowded, the grove cafe and co-op, Porters Pub (which absorbed a good deal of my money over the years) and of course the quality of education that you'll receive which I suppose is fairly important.

Along with my acceptance letter to UCSD was an invitation to check out the campus and meet with UCSD students to ask questions about campus life and what the school is really like.  I knew UCSD was ranked 3rd (after Berkley and UCLA) in the UC system so I figured it'd be a good school.  But while touring the campus I fell in love.  So many odd and interesting art pieces scattered across the campus, the spaceship of a library, RIMAC, Price Center...it was all great.  Plus, it's within walking distance to the beach.  

When I first heard that didn't have housing for transfer students, I was bummed.  But La Jolla had plenty of housing surrounding the campus and it worked out better for me that way.  I got to get off of campus because while it's beautiful, after a day full of classes all you want to do is get the hell away from it.  

One of my highlights was seeing John Kerry speak here on a campaign stop.  I was a part of the UCSD College Democrats and they set the whole thing up.  It was awesome.  

SunGod.  The only time of the whole year that all of UCSD parties.  The one day that you get on the shuttle that picks up students at several different spots in the neighborhoods surrounding the campus and actually talk to them!  SunGod is this crazy all-day festival/carnival/concert.  When I was there I saw Busta Rhymes, Ludacris, Phantom Planet, Pretty Girls Make Graves...and the others...well, I was too drunk to remember.  

Ah yes, classes.  I'd recommend taking Wayne Cornelius' Politics of Immigration class.  Most of his research has been on Mexican immigration to the U.S. but this class also looks at immigration to and from other countries.  I took an amazing class on the History of Los Angeles.  I can't remember the professor's name but he was great.  

The psychology department (my major) offered many classes, Abnormal Psych, Clinical Psych,  Psych of Emotion, Adolescence, Drugs and Behavior, Impulse Control and everyone's favorite Human Sexuality.  Plus all the basic intro psych classes.  And besides having great professors, the psych dept (at least while I was there) had great T.A.s that were very helpful.

As for the non-existent social life of the campus, I wouldn't know about it.  I lived off campus and made friends with people who were just as social as me if not more.  And they were transfer students as well, so we were all in the same boat.  Get in where you fit in.

College is what you make it.  Everyone complains that UCSD is boring and consists only of nerdy, bio majors...

I went to UCSD and I had fun, got crazy, partied, etc.  If you want to have fun, you will.  I think the bad rap is just an excuse for wall flowers and people who refuse to leave their comfort zone and make friends to justify why they are sitting at home on Saturday night playing WOW.

***ammendment:  I cannot believe I forgot to mention my absolute favorite part of UCSD; Professor Michael Hanson....mmm mmm mmm .

OVERRATED

Too many coddled, anit-social spoiled nerds

Horrible administration and professors do not care about students

Overpriced and not worth it. Stay away.

UC San Diego is located near Blacks Beach (a nudist beach) so how any students study is beyond comprehension (I'd be snooping and taking pictures/video of nudists all day)... Other than that, UC San Diego is a great place to study for students interested in majoring in any field related to: Oceanography, Marine Biology, Environmental Science, etc. Here are the brief positives of UCSD:

1. Located next to the beach/ocean
2. Located next to Blacks Beach (a nudist beach)
3. Mellow, surfer vibe

Here are the brief negatives of UCSD:

1. Located near the border with mexico (illegal, mexican aliens sporadically wash ashore on small boats, surprisingly with no rocks to throw at you). Don't respond with troglodyte letters. Read and think.
2. Located next to Blacks Beach (a nudist beach). You can't focus on studying while people are walking around naked with saggy/floppy or perky/luscious breasts hanging out.

Bottom line: Visit and/or reside in San Diego/La Jolla for only 2 reasons: 1. Blacks Beach. 2. An Oceanography/Marine Biology/Environmental Science degree from UCSD. Other than that, stay away from San Diego/La Jolla and the embarrassments: Chargers, Padres, clubs, overpriced gas stations ($4.59! What the f***** hell?!)...

This is my school so of course I love it.

Naturally it has it's ups-and-downs, which I don't need to go into as the UC system's failings are well noted in the media, but on the whole this is a fantastic campus.

It's extremely scenic and the hilly terrain gives you a damn good workout as you stroll from class to class. There's food conveniently located at every college and the center for all the action at PC is literally located in the center of the campus for convenience. 

It definitely has a place in my heart. I love my school so if you want a tour or if you want me to give you some more personal information regarding this school just give me a shout!

Cheers!

good ol' sd...one of the best gyms in the uc system..the REMAC...awesome.....the shield's library was oddly shaped but the basements was the place place to quietly study...the price center was entertaining to watch the students....the walk around campus was horrible...hilly and large..and i ended up overflowing to the pepper canyon apartment dorms in the corner of no-where land on campus..this is in la jolla, so apartments didn't come cheap here....

i never understood the whole different colleges thing...but oh well...i met some good chill people here...

I love this campus. It's right next to the beach, in the heart of La Jolla, close to the shopping centers, and great access to the freeways. The freshman dorms also remind me of 6th grade camp...cabins, bunk beds, and the great outdoors. I even witnessed two huge raccoons on my way home. 

It's also a great place for running, walking, and hiking. There are a ton of trees and the buildings are nice to look at. The drive to the beach isn't bad either.

2 stars for location. -1 for price -1 for parking, -1 for crappy food.

Graduated here this summer with a bachelors of science in biochemistry. love the scenery, although its too big and impossible to get to your next class in 10 minutes if you're walking. 

the campus is extremely beautiful but please UCSD staff, can you quit painting over student spots with teacher/grad student spots? you guys make it extremely difficult for us to find parking. either create a new parking structure for under grad students or lower the cost for a parking permit, geez.

oh yeah, stop building useless structures with our raised tuiton money were forced to pay you.

i guess im pretty bitter after leaving, heh

I'm in finals week of my second quarter as a transfer student. The professors are great so far. Very good educational lectures and open to two way communication in class, during office hours, and via e-mail. Scenery is great and the buildings are incredible architecture statements. There are many art pieces scattered throughout the campuses. Wish I was a campus resident so I could enjoy more of the social activities.

Welcome to San Diego.

UCSD is a beautiful campus just minutes from the shoreline, and close to many eateries and places of amusement. The parking situation may suck, and I've received numerous citations, but that doesn't matter because my parents will pay for it.

UCSD is where a pretentious kid can be a pretentious kid. And that's okay by me. Hipsters, republicans, and environmentalists all incubate their pre-pubescent thoughts and plans for world domination. Many people have come to this establishment to find themselves, but instead find that there's a ton of homework and Asians.

It's cool though because UCSD is on the quarter system. Lots of downtime and lots of driving off campus to places like Pokez downtown or chillin in PB will do us good. And if we don't feel like going far, there's always the Che Cafe.

I taught at computer graphics and film editing UCSD last year.  You know the most valuable thing I learned there?

The phrase "fail" and "lolz."

Kids at UCSD are square man, but as Hewie Lewis said, "It's hip to be square."

I love it here and never want to leave, ever. 

The campus is beautiful, the views are gorgeous. I love the library, and the stuart art collection. The campus is *huge* but that can be a good thing, I actually lost a ton of weight just walking around it. I especially love the old student center, it's got this hippie feel to it and makes me want to debate communism. 

There is *so* much to do. Some of the dorms have ocean views as well. I love living down here and being part of the campus. I'm going to miss it so much!

I took my family friends to have a mini campus tour!  They told me that compare to many campuses, UCSD has the best of the best campus in CA!  They said UCSD is beautiful and the building is unique!  

GO TRITON!!!

Of course UCSD is great!  Beautiful campus, cheap rec classes, relaxing on library walk, library that looks like a UFO, weird pieces of artwork all over the place, my alma mater!  Also, if you live in Muir dorms (which I didn't unfortunately) you can see the ocean.  Doesn't get any better.  Watch for rolling fog...the weather on campus is always weird.

(a couple negative things...1. parking is terrible and expensive, you should shuttle in - shuttle pick ups are all over la jolla, a luxury I didn't really have when I was there -  or park in regents lot and shuttle in from there 2. everything is spread out...have fun walking up hills)

When I think of UCSD/San Diego a few things come to mind. Amazin' Mexican Food, Phil's BBQ, Theodore Geisel A.K.A. Dr. Seuss motherfucka!!!! And of course the Chinese three-some video makin' nice guys known as Wong Fu Productions. 

Let's be honest. People who go to UCSD are the ones who didn't get into UCLA or CAL. People who go to Riverside are the ones who didn't get into Irvine or SD?  make sense? Hope it does. Though, that isn't to knock the students here. Gettin' into college is so competitive these days! There is definitely some smart and talented kids who go here to UCSD who could have gone to CAL or UCLA but just had some bad luck.  

Location: San Deezy. You know.. That place that is really close to Mexico! The home of the Padres, Blink 182, good Carne Asada, The Real World SD, 

Campus: It's nice. 

Students: I always feel like there is a very wholesome feel to the students here at UCSD. I don't know. Maybe it's cause I'm used to seein' SC, Irvine, Riverside, and all the other So cal UC's ever so often. Though, the guys are super dorky and the girls are like you're Joey Potter girl next door look which I'm a fan of. 

Athletics: UCSD FOOTBALL TEAM UNDEFEATED! Nuff' Said 

Notable Alumni: 

Wong Fu Productions: If you're not familiar with them it's probably because you're not Asian, between the ages of 10-28, frequent Youtube, and have a life. Good bunch of fellas who really set the standard for making super emo, heartfelt, videos about relationships, Asian stereotypes, and parodying music videos.

*Yellow Fever* 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vC_ycDO66bw
If you are looking to LEARN something, and learn it WELL, this is the place for you.

UCSD sucks. 

I've been going here almost 2 years now. I transferred here from UC Santa Barbara so you multiply normal agony experienced by UCSD students and multiply that by 50. Transferred because UCSD had a good political science program. I'm not even a political science major anymore. The area around it sucks too. La Jolla is nothing like college towns by all other colleges. It blows and I don't understand how it is kept so nice and snobby. The area around UCSD should be dingy and dirty, full of bars, pubs, pizza places, open late restaurants, liquor stores, laughter. Nope. Full of old snobby rich people and everything shuts down at 6 pm. Hillcrest (by SDSU) is better but it's like a 30 minute drive. Lamest university + university area in existence. I knew UCSD was known as UC Socially Dead but I thought that was an overexaggeration. Nope. Oh yeah and the campus is really ugly and annoying too, with the WORST student art EVER. It's so freaking ugly. It looks like trash and it's all over the place. Not even joking. One of the exhibits is 3 big rusty pipes with rusty bolts and wires. On campus food selection also sucks. Everything closes too early and is priced too high. God this sucks. Can't wait to graduate. If you like to have fun, please don't choose UCSD.

I'm not writing from the student viewpoint.  I didn't go to school at UCSD... but I work there now.  I'm from San Diego originally, left for college, realized the error of my ways and came back as soon as I graduated.  Got a job in research at UCSD and love the campus.  Obviously, paying for parking is a drag, but it's really nice to be able to take walks around campus at lunch.  It's true that the campus is spread out and it'll take you at least half-an-hour to walk from one side of campus to the other.  This is why I watch skaters and bikers race by me all of the time.
UCSD is a nice place to work.  Heck, San Diego is a pretty fantastic place to work.  But to be specific, the bene's are good and the ability to network and focus on research is wonderful.  There's a lot of bureaucracy & hierarchical politics, but that's present in any university system.  There is a lot of modern art around campus to check out, and if you get bored with that, you can drive to the beach in 5 minutes.

If you would have asked me to review UCSD my freshmen year I would have given it 5 stars... oh ignorant me, now that I've been here longer it obvious the administration doesn't give a damn about its students, yes they always are like "OMFG WE'RE TRYING TO MAKE THE SCHOOL BETTER FOR YOU" oh really? how so? so far all the administration has done is try to raise parking prices, tuition prices, food prices, and on top of raising prices they also have horrible administered class/webreg options and counselors that know less about classes than my 14 year old sister who doesn't even go here. I went to talk to my counselor about a class i was taking, he said yes NO PROBLEM! your schedule is perfect, ok so woot woot.. i take the class... few weeks later i'm notified that one of the classes I'm taking overlaps with another that i took in the past, and what do you know? it's past the drop date.. so i'm forced to take the class and take the finals all for....

nothing
thanks ucsd, please take this splintery piece of wood and shove it up yours. thanks!

I wish I could give this place negative stars. I transferred from another UC and have attended two community colleges and a CSU  so I can say without a doubt that this is the worst decision I have ever made in my life and will regret it forever. I would never wish harm upon anyone, but, the staff, especially the ones that work in the Registrar's, Student Business Services, Financial Aid, and Sixth College offices, deserve to DIAF. 

In order from hell-ish to tolerable:

1. HORRIBLE ADMINISTRATION: Inefficient, incompetent, ineffective, inept, etc, etc, etc. Expect to call or visit at least 5 different offices to resolve your problems. Not helpful at all. They have no compassion and no understanding how their stupidity NEGATIVELY affects our lives. I started SOBBING uncontrollably while talking to the dean of Sixth College. All she said was she'll ask around and call me back. She has yet to call me back. They make mistakes and they literally make you pay $$$$ for it (I currently owe over $2000 because of their mistakes. I'm sure I'll be able to pay it back in no time, seeing as how my mom is on unemployment and I have a kick-ass part-time job!).

2. Academic Advising: is non-existent. They don't advise. They smile and nod their heads and pretend like they care. The "virtual advising center" is a joke. No one ever fully answers your questions. They regurgitate shit already posted on the website. 
When I went to see the counselors at community college (PCC), they would make the appropriate phone calls, ask their superiors and Google info for me. The ones here told me to either ask a different department or do my own research. Um, why would I even bother coming to you if I could find the answer on the Internet? Again, they make mistakes and you will pay for it.

3. Sixth College: 
a. CAT 125, the upper division writing requirement for Sixth college is clusterfuck of a course. Useless. Fun for people who have large enough egos to fill 10-15 pages.
b. Art-making requirement: 8 units (2-3 courses) in an "art" course. 

4. The Students: There's something very strange about UCSD students. They seem to have a knack for finding nice people and asking for help over and over again and then never ever returning the favour. They love to take but they never give any back. I admit I'm guilty of this.

5. La Jolla: Awful place to be if you don't have a car. Everything is spread out and far away. Downtown San Diego is "accessible" by public transportation if you have 2-3 hours to spare. No good food in La Jolla. All the fruits seem to taste like rubber erasers. Trader Joe's might be the safest option. Because SD is so close to the Mexican border where there are a bunch of factories and home to military bases, there is a lot of water pollution. Buy bottled water (and recycle it) or bring a water filter and change the filter often!

6. UGLY ASS CAMPUS: Biomedical Library is the only building I like and the only place I can actually study.

7. Housing: Tolerable, but much too expensive for the shit place you're renting. Live near Hillcrest. It's cheaper and the Hillcrest shuttle is really convenient. Better food and "life" there as well. If you do choose to live near campus, choose an apartment complex that offers free printing. There are several of them like La Scala and International Gardens (I prefer La Scala. The staff is much nicer and more helpful).

My suggestions: 
-DO NOT APPLY! If you do, don't apply for Sixth College or Eleanor Roosevelt. And apply as a transfer student. Lower-division courses and GE courses here are insufferable and a excruciating prolonged cockblock. 
-Do well at community college and transfer to a small, private school where you exist as a real person. Being at a large school makes you a statistic. 
-Attend a private school. Public schools, especially ones in CA are subject to frequent budget cuts. Your fees go up by 30%, your favorite professors get cut, and the administration and the UC Regents chillax in their $20 million dollar mansions. 
-Attend a school with a large budget.
-Do not attend a school where certain majors (sciences) are HEAVILY favoured over other majors, unless you are majoring in the sciences. Social sciences, humanities and arts are the first things to get cut when there are budget cuts (I had a condescending graduate students teach an UPPER DIVISION course. Didn't learn a thing.)
-If you want to attend a school with a college system, I recommend UC Santa Cruz (or you can look across the pond). Their college system is significantly better and the college requirements are more reasonable, just a writing requirement. SD's GE requirement vary greatly depending on your college (Eleanor Roosevelt has an infamous 6-quarter writing requirement. If you have two years to spare on writing research papers, go for it!)
-If you're choosing SD because of the nice weather and beaches, FYI: this is California. Every other school is by the beach and has nice weather

As I near my departure from this great campus at UCSD, I'll always wonder what would have been?  

If I were a terrible surfer - Would I have never come here?

If I didn't like the Sun, Beach, Sand, Surf, Cali - Would I have come here?

If I didn't like babes - Would I have come here?

If I didn't break my leg and decided not to go into medicine - Would I have come here?

Boy I'm glad none of those things ever happened!  Nothing but a 5-star rating from the best campus in California!

there was once a time I respected UCSD for its caliber, research antiquities, and all around academic experience.  Since I have graduated, the reverence I held for this joke of a "university" has dwindled down to next to null.  I had the harsh reality thrown in my face that UCSD is fun when you are giving them $30k a year.  They fail epically when it comes to hiring their own alumni, employment politics, and parking situations.  UCSD temp services fails to even provide parking passes for their staff that is necessary to do their job.  The $100 a month is somehow supposed to come out of their own non-permanent, no benefits' pockets.  Then add on the numerous parking tickets that are nothing but revenue makers, it has become abundantly clear that this university is part of a bigger system that could give a lesser crap about the people.  Add this on to the nepotism, elitism and favoritism in the office politics along with the heavy animal testing that goes on in its research facilities....

 I am ashamed to have ever been a UCSD student.

Yes, it's a good school if you're interested in the engineering disciplines, biological sciences, and political science.  Every other field is decently rated at best... only 10% of the campus is actually traversed on by students because of the horrible la
This is also a beautiful school.  It was a great sight everytime I came down.  The air, the scenery, and the beach.

This is my alma mater! I graduated many years ago (actually not that many) and I enjoyed my time here. I come back every few years to get some alumni gear and am impressed by the progression of this university. Wow, it's really huge now.

Er... if you're going to rate a University on its parking, shouldn't they all get one star?

I received my degree from UCSD and I now work for UCSD, so obviously I love it here. 

It's a great location- walking distance to the beach, right off the freeway, central to everything. It's beautiful, and I love getting my exercise walking across campus every day. 

The education is second to none and continues to rival the best universities in the country, even the uber-costly private ones.  

The students here are awesome- smart and fun. I see plenty of students having a great time and yes, partying. And 40% of the students here live on campus, how is that a commuter school?

Wow, I'm such an old timer, I graduated from UCSD way back in 1998. Sounds like things are pretty much the same. If I had it to do over, I'd do all the things that the other reviews recommend, like getting involved and studying more!

It's a good thing th

5 years of my life was spent going to this school and it was totally worth it.  Now I am visiting friends and every time I am here the school just gets bigger and bigger.  Don't believe anyone that says this school is socially dead.  If you really want to have fun you will find it. It's definitely there!

So much has changed at UCSD from 2005! I'm scared how a post-graduation interval of only four years has done an incredible job making me feel uber old. But I must say that these changes are great! I haven't been able to walk through most of it, but from what I saw, the current tritoners are very fortunate. 

I attended Warren college for 4 years back from 2001-05 and graduated with a cognitive science degree. I have to say my experience was really great. I'm from orange county, and although it took me a few months to warm up to the super-chill vibe, my experience was guided by the stunning beaches and amazing mexican food. 

UCSD has a weak greek life, as there is no football team that encourages parties, or other major sporting events. So my pride for UCSD was definitely limited in comparison to other football-driven schools. The way to really enjoy your experience @ UCSD, as with other schools I would assume, is to get involved in something. Whether its greek life, service organizations, ethnic groups, religious groups, whatever group, get involved! You aren't in high school where cliques come easy. Becoming involved in something you are interested in and surrounding yourself with people that share commonality is important, and I believe UCSD does have strong student life opportunities. 

San Diego is a hidden gem, and for many students, its easy to go through your 4 years thinking its a hard rock. There are so many great areas filled with good eats, things to do, and places to hang out so don't miss out! Research on yelp! Surround yourself with good company, and go exploring because you wont be disappointed. Also the mexican food is amazing, and mexico is just a short drive away! Go grub it up on some dollar tacos and cheap lobsters at puerto nuevo. 

UCSD is filled with bright students who often know how to have fun while taking care of their business. It caters to great student life, and many professors, like Magagna or Ramachandrom (sp?) are NOT to be missed...even if you dont have to take them. GO Tritons!

Pros:

The professors are wonderful. Okay, here's the tip: go to office hours and ask questions. Put a name on your face. A lot of times, professors are much different outside of lecture. They are friendlier, more down to earth, open and honest. Only a couple of times, I encountered an arrogant one, but they were arrogant in lecture too, so I wasn't surprised. This is especially important down the line when you need letters of recommendation for grad school, law school, etc. You want a professor to know who YOU are and not write a generic statement about you. So get to know them and you'll understand why I love most of the professors here.

The environment is absolutely beautiful. Its located minutes away from the beach. La Jolla has plenty to offer, UTC is not far from the school, and you are located very close to the freeway so easy access.

Cons:

Parking. UCSD is illogical when it comes to parking. During my senior year here, they decided to add MORE faculty parking spaces by eliminating undergraduate spaces...even in the most distant parking lots. The stupid part is, the faculty spaces rarely fill up. Heck, it never did unless it was after hours when it was free for all. 

Student activity/social atmosphere is pretty dull here. It takes one to know one though and I admit, I am one of those stereotypical UCSD student that doesn't like to say much in class, plays Wordscraper on Facebook, watches anime, and prefers spending their weekends writing reviews on Yelp instead. ~winks~ Its just not the most sociable atmosphere and it doesn't help that many times, your classmates are just as quiet as you are. Sometimes, i think the fraternities should be renamed the Anime Otaku Club instead. UCSD fraternities? Hahaha! I'm making myself laugh!

Conclusion: My best years were spent at UCSD. Despite its flaws, no place is perfect and I wouldn't trade my education and experience at UCSD for anything.....except a couple of million dollars and Cristiano Ronaldo.....yum......

RIMAC stadium!!  Where are the signs to this place after you get off the 5 Freeway?  NO WHERE! Signs were only on Torrey Pines Road.  Please get some signs--we were on our way to a concert there and had to ask many students where it was.  UCSD committee folks--get to workin' on the RIMAC signage --ok??  Thanks :)

I could write a book on UCSD. I feel like I've been at this school for... well... ever. I have done my undergraduate here, I have done my master's here, and now I am doing my Ph.D. here. 

I've been writing reviews of the food here, so I'll leave that to my other reviews. But as for a school, its an amazing research and science school. For graduate school it is amazing and you are exposed to so many opportunities. Now onto the social life... well.. wait... what social life? 

I kid, I kid. I shouldn't be so rough on the ol' UCSD. It just seems like UCSD attracts those study-a-holic, overachieving type of student. This makes the academics shine, but the social lack. 

But with any school, it's what you make of it. Don't focus on the negative. I say a school should be that: a school. Go to UCSD to learn, not to party. If you want to party, go to SDSU and do that. Its the same with your house, you don't want to live somewhere that's a constant raging party; rather, you'd want to go mess up someone else's house on the weekend! 

So don't worry too much about the social aspect here, you will find plenty to do. And with girls, psh, there are pretty ones here, you just need to know where to look. And if you can't find any here, then go look at Whole Foods, go to SDSU, or even join an online dating profile. 

Stop focusing on the negative and starting finding solutions! Be positive, young ones!

This is a really, really good university. If you're a jock and/or want to party all the time, this isn't for you and please go somewhere else so you don't ruin this really good university. If you want to go to college to meet hot chicks/guys and get ten kinds of laid, this isn't for you and please go somewhere else so you don't ruin this really good university. If you want to study something you don't care about and score an impressive degree that will get you a job that you don't care about, please go somewhere else and don't ruin this really good university.

The educational program is really amazing, if you have an interest in that. The social life is also really amazing, if your definition of social life is anything other than completely shallow. This is the kind of school you should go to if you want to see yourself, the world, and the people around you in a deeper, more nuanced, more interesting way. If you want to binge drink your way to orgasms between tests that get you jobs that pay money, find a different school.
The ramen was good, but the service could've been better.
cheap summer school classes open to the general public!  even if you're an out of state student, the summer tuition rates are probably cheaper than if you attend summer session at a private school.
Good ed-u-ma-cation, interesting campus with lots of art, and some good foooods. But seriously, eff the parking. They definitely need to build a few 500 story parking garages.

UCSD has a good science program.. Professors are eh. Some are really good, others, not so much. Honestly though, you're going to find that anywhere and everywhere. And for those that are constantly saying that we don't have a social life, dude, just go out and find some parties to go to. There ARE parties; you just don't know about them (there's probably a reason for that).

There's not a lot of school spirit, but that doesn't really matter to me because I'm not a very spirited person to begin with. Just because we're not known to have parties 24/7 like other schools, doesn't mean that they don't exist. There's a reason why UCSD is high in the UC system and if you want to go to a party school, then stop complaining and GTFO. It really pisses me off when I hear people talking shit about having nothing to do here and that we're socially dead. There's something called going out and actively looking for parties or just go to the party school SDSU like 15mins away; I'm sure you can get tons of STDs over there (no offense to anyone).

I transferred to UCSD and completed the 3rd and 4th year of my undergrad degree. I truly LOVED the brief 2 years I spent at this university, probably why I stuck around to complete a certification through extension, and chose to stay on campus to work. 

For starters, the campus is beautiful, simply breathtaking! There are views of the ocean from some of the buildings, including certain dorm rooms! There are hiking/running trails located right behind our very cool, futuristic looking library. UCSD is in La Jolla, minutes from La Jolla Shores. Not even the most spoiled of spoiled brats could complain in that respect. 

I love the fact that UCSD has a green/sustainability energy program. It includes biogas fuel cells, wind energy, and solar panels! Being so involved at this university, I'm ashamed I don't ride my bike more, and even more ashamed that I still (shhhhh) drive a SUV - which, in my defense, I am desperately trying to get out of! Really though, UCSD is one of the greenest universities nationwide, and that in itself is just awesome.

I also appreciate the level of education they provide. It is a very good academic institution - nobody can deny that.

I do have one major complaint about this school though. It's not a whole lot of fun, especially for a transfer student. Even for someone who went there all 4 years, I could see it being somewhat boring. The students can be pretty antisocial. The Price Center, which is the central part of campus with the food court and bookstore, etc, clears out pretty much when the sun goes down. It seems like most everyone attends class and that's it. There are frats and sororities that attempt to make the best out of a setting that doesn't even provide a frat row (no frat houses). It's definitely not a "party school." For instance, Sun God (a concert on campus where the whole school gets plastered) is known for being the only day out of the year when UCSD kids party.

obviously the best university in SD for learnin'. the social scene sucks, i hear. i graduated from here and am on the faculty so i'm biased. many world class departments, although beware... it's a research intensive place so, although your prof will be brilliant, he/she may not be the greatest teacher and he/she may be utterly inaccessible. hot tip: eat a bunch of acid and check out the stuart collection of VERY interesting modern art all over campus. if the cops hassle you, try not to laugh and call them rent-a-cops. apparently they are not. also a good experimental music department (with which i am not affiliated) that provides lots of free and good performances.

I recently went back to visit UCSD after 4 years. I missed UCSD dearly and was really jealous of all the new additions (especially the new Price Center with TapEx and Yogurt World!) made after I graduated. That's how it always is, huh? =P

I had an amazing experience at UCSD. Not only is it a beautiful campus with interesting (to say the least) art and buildings, especially the signature building of Geisel Library, most of the professors I had were of extremely high caliber. I had some of the best teachers and mentors here ever.

A little background on me: I attended 6th College (second class, w00t!) and graduated in 2007 with a BS in Biochemistry/Cell Biology and a minor in Health Care Social Issues. I lived on campus all 4 years, with 2 years in Pepper Canyon (now called Sixth College Apartments), 1 year in Marshall Lowers, and 1 year in International House - Kathmandu. I'd have to say my last year in I-House was the best year of my life and the most fun and culturally rewarding. I highly recommend everyone try to get in at least a semester there.

I also studied abroad in Korea at Yonsei University via EAP. Studying abroad is another thing I'd highly recommend everyone do while still a student. It's NOT the same as traveling for vacay! It's way better!

The food is pretty good once you feel your way around. I loved the breakfast burritos and smoothies at OVT, the stirfry and cornbread at Muir, the salad bar at Warren, and spending my extra mealpoints on appliances and other junk at Earl's Place (could shop some Costco products via the website too). I understand that there are even more places you can shop and spend your mealpoints at now...*jealous*

I got involved in a lot of clubs, most actively in InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, Golden Key International Honor Society, and InSight Pre-Optometry Club. I did some fun stuff for credit like Teams in Engineering Service. I think it was really these extracurricular activities that enriched my time at UCSD so much.

San Diego and La Jolla are such a great place to live. There's endless things to do! And even without a car, you could still walk to the beach in 15 min or go to the cliffs in less. Nothing like watching the sunset after class. =)

I'm really proud of UCSD and my education there, and I could say a lot more...but words would never encompass everything. My only complaint is that some of the writing requirements at Sixth College are pretty horrible. I wonder if it's changed...

If you're a biology, medical, engineering, or any science major for that matter at UCSD, then congratulations - you are attending one of the best research universities in the country, if not the world, and you're chances of getting a well-paying job after graduation are pretty damn good. It's time to make a lot of money, bling it up, and head on over to your high school reunion and make those jocks-turned-losers who made fun of you back then feel like complete shit. Don't forget to wow that highscool crush who denied you before by whisking him/her away in your private helicopter.
Unfortunately i won't be doing any of this myself because i am a literature major...bwaa bwaa. I'll be the guy at the bar getting wasted off of vodka and tonics. Oops. 
If you're an average person like me, UCSD can be somewhat overwhelming. I transferred from a community college one year ago (after spending five years there because i pretty much slacked the whole time) and had a hard time adjusting. Here's are a few reasons why: 

Classes - So, that 18-week semester is pretty crazy, huh? You're pulling your hairs because you want this nightmare to be over, right? Well, here's what would happen if you complained about this to any of the 110 pound, scrawny little guys or girls buzzing around UCSD  - roundhouse kick right to the face. You're bitchin about eighteen week semesters? Well, we have to deal with ten week QUARTERS, with TWICE as much work. So there. 
People get so worked up about their classes at UCSD that, on average, quite a number of students commit SUICIDE every year. I typically read about at least one every other quarter, that's how hardcore it is (although i would attribute it to stupidity more than anything). But as gnarly as these cons may be, the pros of the quarter system are also apparent. There is no time to screw around. You can't take breaks. So what happens? You actually become disciplined, and therefore you end up getting the most out of the classes. I'll admit that i'm still not keen about the quarter system, but the quality of the education as a result of it is top notch. 

Social Life - I don't have to dwell too much on this subject. Everybody knows that your likely to find more better looking, more amicable people at a Starwars enthusiasts meeting rather than at UCSD. Yes, i'm a shallow prick, and therefore looks are important to me, but personality is also important, if not more, and i'll have to admit that the Tritonettes fail to impress in either regards. Sigh. 
People are so socially akward at UCSD that they even stiffen up when working in class groups. Out of most of them you wont hear a peep throughout the course of the entire class. 

Mascot - This conversation has actually happened:
Inquirer- "So, what's a Triton?"
Me - "...um, have you seen the little mermaid?"
Inquirer - "yeah"
Me - "(clear throat) Yeah, well, uh, its pretty much the guy from the little mermaid"
Inquirer - "Which guy?"
Me - "You know, the dad...the merman."
Inquirer - "Oh"
Me - "Yeah"
Akward silence, followed by the soothing sounds of crickets. Fuck.

Sports - Word on the street is that we have a pretty decent baseball team. That's nice, and i maybe i would appreciate it more if it wasn't for the fact that i consider baseball to be the most boring sport on the planet. Maybe i'm just pissy because we don't have a football team. Give me a football team, and then we'll talk about sports at UCSD.

But as much as i've complained about UCSD, i think it's only fair to mention that nonetheless, it really is a good school. Students can't weasel their way doing the bare minimum, because they are actually challenged, and this translates to developing more effective life skills for later. If you can transcend the socially inept students, the drab imagery of endless eucalyptus forests riddled with big, ugly crows and lifeless concrete buildings, and the pressures of academia, then i think you'll find something special.

I swear I've reviewed UC San Diego before...  In any case, I only have positive things to say of former university.  When I set foot on campus as a sophomore in high school, I was immediately in love with it.  The location is excellent, including weather.  There is a lot to do all the time, whether university provided or otherwise.  The faculty is outstanding and the students are brilliant.  It's a great place to live and play if you like the outdoors.  Living on campus in Revelle was probably the best experience of my life (which is why I did it for 4 years....).  

As others have said, it's pretty tough to review the ENTIRE university...and I can't sit around and say they have everything perfect: parking, for example, definitely leaves something to be desired.  Still, as a former student and active alumni, UC San Diego has given me so much since I started there 6 years ago.  It's a great place to live, play, work, and study.

If you're hoping for a constant party, this is not the place to go. People who go here will always describe it as "chill" - which is exactly what it is... just very laidback in all aspects. Personally, I love living in sunny San Diego! There are six different colleges in UCSD, which actually makes what would be a big and impersonal school feel more homey. Each college has its own Academic Advising office, cafeteria, dorms and apartments, etc. They actually do have their own "personalities" - Eleanor Roosevelt, for example, has more liberal arts/humanities type people, while Earl Warren is known for being less social with a lot of engineering majors.

Sports are a minor thing, besides say, water polo. We don't have a football team, so that kills any hope for school spirit. Plus, Greek life is weak at best. A lot of SoCal people go home on the weekends, so it generally turns into a dead campus. The thing about the party scene is that you have to look to find it - there are always going to be some people down to party, it's just not campus-wide. The campus security officers are a pain to deal with, since they're very uptight about drinking. It's best to go off campus so you won't get caught. There are also pretty much weekly shuttles to Tijuana, which always makes a fun night. UCSD is by no means a wild campus, but trips to TJ almost always are. Among other things, I've passed out on the lawn at the border and walked back with no shoes. (BE SAFE!) Other things we do on the weekend include beach trips, bussing to Pacific Beach/downtown, going to the casino, etc. There's a mall and a movie theater, both about 10 minutes away. Usually we party on Friday, recover from all the damage done on Saturday, and do something mellow on Sunday.

UCSD is a highly ranked and respected school. However, we're really considered a research school - there's a good amount of professors who are famous researchers but are mind-numbingly boring in the lecture hall.
