But there are a handful of simply amazing professors who make up for the rest. I had to seriously convince myself not to sign up for a Latin language class, for which I had absolutely zero interest in and no use for, but I more or less in love with Professor Charles Chamberlain, also known as Greek God. If only all professors were as wonderful/brilliant/humble/charming/wise, I think I would be in love with school. I've also had my fair share of good and bad TAs - so there's no way to really judge them as a whole. The workload is not bad at all; compared to my friends at other UCs, I get away with doing relatively little.

I'm not gonna lie; we aren't know for being an attractive student body. Thus they say that people develop "triton eye" - in which your standards are lowered the longer you're a student here. Kind of like beer goggles, but without the alcohol. It's a very friendly and inviting campus - people are always playing football or frisbee on the lawn, and on warm days people will study or tan on the grass. At night there'll sometimes be groups smoking hookah on the green. I'm personally not in any clubs because I find I have enough to do... but if you're interested in something there are pretty much clubs for everything from cars to community service to cultural associations.

Basically, you have to seek out fun to have it, but if you find the right people, you'll have a good time - so don't let those "UC Socially Dead" rumors scare you too much. La Jolla is a beautiful place to go to college, and overall it's been a positive experience.

So one acquaintance of mine referred to the architecture of this place as something along the lines of Disneyland.  You've got your Revelle-Land, your Muir-Land, your Marshall-Land, Warren-Land, Roosevelt-Land, and of course Sixth-Land.  Each one looks like its own thing independent and oblivious to the styles of its neighbor.

If you didn't know, I'm an Eleanor Roosevelt College alum.  Finished up in 2007.  Good times.

Sarah M., who is finishing up at John Muir College, is the love of my life, and I thank UCSD for bringing the two of us together.

I have zero gripes about this place.  The UC system is honestly the best bang for your buck when it comes to upper education, and the climate and people in the San Diego area make this such a perfect place to be.  I wish I could be in college forever.

Be a smartie in high school.  Apply here.  Go here.  Learn some science.  Be successful.

Oh yeah, if you want an easy A, take a class with Victor Magagna.  And if you want a challenge, be a science/engineering major at Eleanor Roosevelt College.

well, folks.  for my 100th review, i figure i should write about a place that is really really special.  the only place that comes to mind deserving both five stars and the spot as my 100th review is my favorite place in the whole wide world, UCSD.  i just started going to ucsd in january of this year (it is june 2007 in case someone reads this way way in the future.. and don't get me started on how cool that will be) to finish my undergraduate degree as a transfer student to the communication department.  first off, let's get things straight.  as you may have heard, this is not a party school.  if you're looking to drink your way through your college years and not have to crack a book, turn around, and run as fast as you can in the other direction.  however, there are a lot of cool people that love to have a good time.  you just have to find them.  the professors here are, by far, amazing.  for the first time in my life, i really enjoy going to class.  i've always really liked school and had a drive to want to learn, but just setting foot on this campus reassures me there are others like this too.  
 
things are well-orgainzed, the campus is gorgeous - to say the least, the library is huge, and there are a zillion programs and groups to join if you're into that kind of thing.  the teachings are progressive, and i  have had professors on more than one occassion suggest that it is the student who should be choosing the learning, and that if you are not happy with the education you're receiving, you should stand up and do something about it.  this is not a place that is out to force-feed you your education.  it is a research campus, where the teachers themselves are still indulged in their own education and always moving forward.  
 
i haven't had the experience of living in the dorms since i am a transfer student, so i can't really assist in a review of that.  the campus is amazing in every way, and if you have some agency in your own being, you're sure to find something here that suits you.  
 
UCSD is on the quarter system, which means if you are diligent, you can finish sooner.  it also means it is significantly harder than a lot of other universities because you're always in a time crunch, but i find that i work best under pressure anyway.  
 
a few things to do if you ever get the chance at ucsd:
- lay on the grass in the sun on a break b/w classes and be thankful you live somewhere you are able to do so.
- take a class taught by professor patrick anderson in the comm. department.  he will change your life.  
- take a class taught by professor mike cole.  he knows everything.
- go to a "last lecture".

anyway, there are too many amazing things about ucsd that you just have to experience for yourself, but take my word for it - it is five stars all around.

MOST BEAUTIFUL CAMPUS EVER!

i know i am biased; you don't have to believe me.
But I really like the environment of this campus. Having spent almost 4 years here, I will definitely miss it after I graduate!

WARNING:

This school is terrible.  Go somewhere else, you'll thank me for this advice.

P.S. "School is what you make of it"  Why does this come up so much when people talk about this place.  Trust me you don't want to know.  Also this quote makes it sound like you just lost a job and your making due with what you got or you got some disease but your hanging on.  College shouldn't feel like that.  It should feel like "You went here and it was fucking awesome!"  which ucsd absolutely is not.

Ah, my Alma Mater!

I graduated here from John Muir College in December of 2002 with a BS in molecular biology (no, I don't work with moles...well, not the animal but the chemistry kind).

The research here is definitely one of the best in the UC system and in the nation. I had the opportunity to use my workstudy to do research with a professor in the School of Medicine at the VA hospital. Several projects and published papers later, I was off to graduate school, for teaching nevertheless, from the opportunities that he had given me here. 

The teaching quality, at least at the undergraduate level, can vary widely depending on dept to dept. I felt that the biology, chem, and physics depts could have done a better job to engage the students in practical uses of concepts learned in lectures. The lab courses were definitely more interesting and challenging for me. The lower division calculus and differential equations classes were equally interesting and challenging. Do take the time to take classes outside of your major. I took an upper division music course devoted entirely on analysis of Bach's work and loved it even though it required me to read many scores during the weekends and see how Bach thinks in his music. The best courses I took was from the Teacher Education Program (TEP). They were more organized and higher quality than the ones I had for my MAT at Cornell. As you might expect from a public school, the lectures can be as large as 300 students, but the labs and TEP courses are small in the 30-40s. 

Like many science majors, I once considered medicine as a option and still think it is a very noble profession to pursue, but it is not for me. As for advice, do it because you enjoy working and help people and the knowledge and not because it having a lab coat makes you above others. Definitely consider NOT majoring in a science and pursue other practical interests during your undergraduate years (though I would stay away from majoring in communications...you CAN actually find and pursue an legitimate major in four years, can't you?). In medical school, you will have learned all the science you need to practice medicine. 

Try to stay away from the "food" served at the cafeteria as much as possible, although the High Price Center doesn't help except for the Jamba Juice. 

Be sure to live life by balancing your fun and studies! And play some ultimate Frisbee; we're the #1 at it for a reason!

I'm very happy that I went here for my undergrad degree. I look back on my days at UCSD fondly, with no regrets.

The Computer Science department is top notch and quickly gaining the reputation for it. It has a lot of interesting and challenging courses, especially in the upper divs.

The campus is really beautiful. There's always somewhere pretty to wander off to when you're bored or just need to clear your mind.

Geisel Library is a good place to nap... I mean study. Just bring a jacket because the air conditioning can get cold. And hide your food/drinks or they'll make you throw it away!

Even though it's a nerd school filled with pre-meds and engineers, it wasn't scary cut-throat competitive. People actually helped each other out and were generally pretty laid back.

If you're into partying, you'd have to look harder for that kind of stuff (than if you went to... say... STDSU :P), but it's there. 

Campus housing is pretty limited, which sucks, but oh well.

Oh, and if you like music and want an easy A, take concert choir. :)

Attended UCSD for 4 years, studied communications and photography, graduated Warren college...and loved my time here. Lived on campus for 2 years, off campus at the Southpointe condos (behind Ralphs, Via Mallorca) the last 2 years. Met a lot of wonderful people, slept late, woke up late, ditched class, attended class, stayed up late to cram for finals...all that good stuff! And...Little did I know I would be finding the man of my dreams, here...only to be "just friends" with him during college and end up dating him years later. It's funny how things work out, but I definitely have great memories of UCSD...5 stars for that! I guess I would take off a star because they don't have a football team...but that's what I have USC for! =)

First, all the stuff in the "Lilly S." review is accurate and perhaps too kind; I will avoid restating her observations although they bear repeating.  
   Be Aware: 
A)  Among the UC campuses, UCSD has a unique group of 6-'Colleges' that each paint different requirements regarding the undergraduate G.Ed undertakings. One requires 'U.S. History', one requires almost a year more of G.Ed, one requires foreign language, one 'artsy', two allow 'dual-major' courses to substitute for what other Colleges call a 'well rounded' education (and yeah, the students coming out of this are dumb as stones outside of their Major's).
   This '6-college' system means there are double and triple the number of 'advisers' on this campus relative to other UC campuses of equal or larger size. Each 'College' is a self-preserving entity on it's own, and some are much better than others. You would think, from the literature, you can CHOOSE which college suits you... not so; the Catalog tells you less about them then this paragraph. (When you figure out you've been hosed, it may be too late; they don't allow easy transfer to another College). As a 'dorm-mother' function, these Colleges rate better; why the serve a dual role is beyond comprehension. 
B)  Transfer students (largely from J.C.'s) can benefit from 'Reciprocity' for eliminating the G.Ed requirement  IF  they have completed ALL the J.C.'s G.Ed. requirements and have a 'letter' stating same. Inter-UC transfers MUST do the same, but other UC's DO NOT create a curriculum for 'transfers' that the JC's do, so good luck with a 'letter.'
C)   Item B does NOTHING for transfer' students Major (the department that accepts you), but that all varies from Major to Major. IF your Major is classic (and historically established, such as English, Communication, languages, Psych, etc. and other areas that lead to being a fun Barista) then you may matriculate just fine; you are 'another brick in the wall'. Note:  you must 'Petition' for each undergrad class in your major in which you seek equivalence.
  BUT (a big Butt): in the Sciences, esp. Engineering, there are extremely FEW equivalence that can be easily approximated;  so you'll find yourself REPEATING concepts/classes yet again. Worse: many departments stack the courses on Tuesdays and Thursdays (esp. at Jacob's school of Engineering), so there is NO WAY to take both upper division and lower division classes at the same time.  All transfer students to Jacob's, even those from Stanford or other U.C.'s should expect to add TWO YEARS because of inability to provide  line-by-line equivalent class syllabuses.  The advisers at Jacob's have NO JUICE; all  they can do is poorly advise you, and tell you they have been working for YEARS to pressure the faculty to spread classes into Mondays and Fridays, so that conflicting courses aren't such a problem. Neither the Chancellor, various Deans have any influence on the abysmal system portrayed above; and most just keep their head in the sand. 
   Similar to almost all U.C. engineering schools, MANY students are angry and self-serving, with a Cantonese-Kalifornian background. Students outside of the Engineering Majors tend to have much more free-time, and are happier here, and jobless after graduation. The Bio-sciences future has also dimmed considerably, unless your goals are MUCH MORE education after a B.S. 

   La Jolla, and the 'University City' area has criminal rings that prey on the off-campus housing/apartment areas. Sport motorcycle theft is the highest in the U.S., even parking them on Campus is not safe at all. (stolen bikes can be found with a new number in front of the old, and sold as new in Mexico City I'm told). There are no street lights in La Jolla.  The UCSD campus, located on an otherwise un-buildable hill, is surrounded by 6-lane Freeways; Fraternity and Sorority houses are illegal; bottom line: "there is no there, there."

Okay, let's be honest.. 
Academics wise, yes, UCSD is a great school.  You will get an exemplary education, especially in any form of science.  I've never really had a professor that has let me down, although I probably have been pretty lucky.  Classes are HARD, but managable if you keep up and actually put an effort in (in the sciences at least). 
The location is amazzzzing. La Jolla is in an incredibly beautiful place and I'm convinced that San Diego is definitely one of the best cities in the world.  The campus itself has some interesting architecture, some good, some obviously outdated, but overall a nice place to be.
If you're looking for a social life, this is NOT THE PLACE TO LOOK. People, in general, are not very friendly. Or attractive. Although, if you look in the right places, you'll find the right people. It's a rough adjustment if you're not used to such anti social people, but you'll probably find your way.
The beach is down the street, which makes it a dream college for me. And although the down sides to UCSD made me absolutely despise the place my first year, you figure out whats really great and learn to love that and find the good things in this socially inept school. It might not be as bad as I'm making it sound, but you have to figure that out for yourself, because that's what college is for, isn't it?

I don't LOVE UCSD but I don't regret coming here either. I mean, 88% of the girls are in the closet freaks who pretend they're totally innocent, and 98.2% of the guys have never touched a girl before. 

Academics:
There are some really amazing professors here that make class fun. But there are also not so great ones. This is definitely a study school! so be prepared to study study study!
AIP (academic internship program) is VERY helpful and useful in helping you secure an internship and gain experience in a field you're interested in. I think AIP is one of the biggest PROS about UCSD. the AIP office workers are super nice and helpful. so go and take advantage of that! 

Social life: 
Don't expect one. You have to really search hard to find people you can click with. I've never met so many socially awkward people in my life. I think a lot of the students here were just SO smart in high school they didn't get a chance to develop socially. 

the GIRLS- there are definitely some very attractive girls here. Maybe not ALL OVER campus, but here and there. like 2 out of 40 girls. There are also a handful of ugly ones too who think they're super hot and walk around with their noses in the air. But don't worry, with time you'll develop Triton goggles and everyone's ugliness will seem very normal.

the GUYS- so. awkward. so so so. awkward. physically, 98% of them look the same. UCSD sweatshirt, high water pants, and tennis shoes. Personality-wise, there are some SUPER funny ones and A LOT of immature ones. They will talk about porn and butts and boobs like it's the COOLEST THING EVER. I think they just need to get laid and move on with life. Girls, don't expect to meet your Romeo here. 

Parking:
You can get ticketed for ANYTHING. UCSD wants to make their students poorer than ever. I've never gotten a parking ticket here, BUT I've known a lot of people who have for things like not "turning your wheels" when you're parked on a flat surface. Oh wait, they claimed it was a "hill". Also, they're constantly reducing the number of student parking spots and raising the prices as well! Some of the apartments around campus give really stupid parking tickets too. Even to people who DO have the right to park where they're parked. Anyway, I know it's your job and all, but GET A LIFE and stop ticketing people for STUPID little things that even YOU wouldn't know you're doing wrong if it were YOU. 

La Jolla:
It's a rich conservative little town. The beach is nice and peaceful, but that's really the only interesting thing there. If you want to have fun, GET OUT OF THERE. It only takes about 5-20 minutes to drive outta there and into some other places of San Diego like Hillcrest, PB, downtown SD, Mira Mesa, Clairemont, La Mesa, El Cajon, Carlsbad, etc etc etc. 
I'm from San Diego and it BUGS me when people complain about how "boring" it is in SD. Well, DUH. you're on campus like 24/7. and NO, Convoy does NOT count as the ENTIRE San Diego. get a map and go somewhere.

Although I will not be reviewing UCSD for its academic accolades, I will note that had I not attended and graduated from UCSD I would likely not be the successful well-rounded individual with a smattering of narcissistic traits that I am today. Most classes, in the day and I am sure currently, were not easy especially the upper level ones.  I also recall that, although I lived off campus and not in an on campus dorm, that UCSD was definitely not the "party" school that say, SDSU or Chico is/was. Also, I do know that it is very difficult to attend UCSD as the standards for admission are much more difficult. 

Now the true purpose for my review. I needed to meet a friend at the Cognitive Science Building. No problem I thought, I went to UCSD and how much could it have changed. Well, as I ended up wandering around the campus muttering to myself that I was indeed lost, I came upon a familiar building and thought, "yes! The third college administration building. I went to Third College. I will go in and ask directions."  As I approached the building I say a large sign, "Thurgood Marshall" with a smaller plaque that indicated it was formerly known as Third College. WTF ... was it like The Artist formerly known as Prince? Why the name change? Likely a donation ... So feeling a bit fatigued from my 20 mile hike and feeling old as I remembered that my mom said the hospital I was born in no longer existed and now my college was renamed, I decided to buck up and ask someone where the Cognitive Science Building was.  Wandering in and out of buildings and past numerous lecture halls, I could NOT find anyone who was not busy chattering on a cell phone or listening to an iPod.  Finally, I came upon a sweet unsuspecting girl who nicely guided me to the building.  After visiting my friend, I left and realized I had walked past the fkn building 45 minutes earlier. Sigh ... Walking back through UCSD and down the pathway near the library, one will always encounter one or more of the following: religious pamphlets being handed out, invites to bars and bands, rantings and political posters about the demise of Israel, Africa, amongst other countries, pro abortion advocates, anti abortion advocates, in addition to a variety of fraternities and sororities selling food to help their houses (e.g., Korean BBQ, pancakes, hotdogs, etc ..). There cannot be any starving students at $3-5 a healthy plate for those causes.  Wandering down the pathway, I also admire that although UCSD is still filled with students from many different cultures, the attire has drastically changed. Yes, there are those who wear traditional clothing from their country of origin, but shirtless males, women and men in board shorts, jeans, layered clothes, and lastly the attire akin to El Cajon Blvd. and I don't mean the johns. UCSD people watching is always a treat.  I know what the cliché "the more things change, the more they remain the same" means.  Although this campus is quite a bit larger than I recall, the cultural diversity of the campus is definitely still in existence.  Take a walk through. It is a must.

The undergraduate population, overall, is pretty pathetic. It really seems like half the school has declared themselves pre-med while only a small proportion of them will actually gain admission into a medical school (not counting osteopathic or Puerto Rican schools).

The schools offers an exorbitant amount of resources and research opportunities for people to excel in their chosen disciplines, but it seems that most students are too self-interested in bashing the school for being socially dead. If you're complaining the campus is boring, you're probably the common denominator in your life of monotony.

The school is lacking in a few things--i.e., football/D1 sports, Greek Row, a college system that makes sense, etc.--but it was a great place to finish my undergrad. I was involved in a frat and many social organizations, met friends whom I basically consider family now, gotten published as an undergraduate researcher, and just had a blast for four years.

If you're checking out colleges in California, UCSD would definitely be on my recommendation list, but a quick caveat: figure out what your goals are during and after college and actually make an effort to accomplish them.

Way overrated. As a former faculty member (now at Berkeley) the ongoing joke among the UCSD faculty is that the "the whole does not equal the sum."  In other words, there are some really good individual faculty (and students), but the majority (both students and faculty) are quite mediocre. In no way, shape, or form is this university even in the same league as Berkeley or Stanford.

I guess I should be thankful I got a degree from this place, considering its one of the best research instituions in the country, if not the world. Here's my impressions of the 2 1/2 years I spent there...

Social Scene - Like many people say, the social scene here is pretty blah. Someone joked UCSD stands for "University that is Completely Socially Dead". For some people, a good Friday night is playing Tekken with some dorm-mates. But I'd be lying if I said that socializing is improssible, but I didn't really get much mileage by socializing within the VERY cliquish clubs like NSU, KSA, etc. You just have to work harder here to find fun people than at other schools.

Campus - Parking near the core of campus is neigh impossible, even at 7 in the morning! Forget about Gillman! Regents is probably the best place to park, the shuttles there come at reasonably brisk pace. If you're a commuter, rushing to class late is going to be a PITA. This school is huge!
However some parts of the campus are very nice. I used to like to study in the Grove Cafe, or in one of the lounges near the top of Tioga Hall in Muir where you can see the cliff-studded Pacific Coast while hang-gliders coast along the waves. The top of the Geisel isn't too bad as well.

Food - Like most campus food, it ranges from mediocre to putrid. Some of my better dining experiences were in Muir's cafeteria and "El Mercado." Price Center, or Pricey Center as everyone likes to call it, is nothing but chain junk, and crowded to boot. I did enjoy "The Art of Espresso", a coffee cart next to Mandeville. AoE has a very funny and cool staff, and some awesome espresso drinks too. Even if you live on the other side of campus, they're worth a trip.

Classes - Lower Divison classes, like in other UC schools, suck hard. You feel like you're in high school and the teachers are really patronizing. I've had ups and downs with the upper divison classes, but the Poli Sci department at UC definately had some good variety. If you're a UCSD student you have to take a Victor Magagna class, even if you're not a Poli-Sci major. The man was one of the best lecturers I've seen.
The language programs at UC however are lame. I just gave up on them and did tutoring with a student who did private Japanese lessons.
Also, class sizes are LARGE. You need to be very motivated to meet with your professor because they'll likely be hard to catch. Most of the times you'll be talking to a Teacher's Assistant (TA). Some of them can be real stuck-up and snooty. I can only think of two TA's who I actually liked at UC.

I'd also like to note that the International Center is really great and that Bill Clabby is a super guy. If you want to do some study abroad, he's an awesome fellow to talk to.

Overall: It can be sometimes daunting and isolating at UCSD, but you can get a lot out of this school if you apply yourself and are motivated, no matter what field you are in. Being a lower divison student here is very tough and I personally think UCSD is a good school to transfer into, but I might be biased since that is how I went to this school. Since UCSD is a big name in research, the worst thing you could do is not take advantage of this place's reputation.

YUCK! The WORST 4 years of my life. I went against all instinct to go here just so I could stay at home and not pay for housing. NEVER take engineering here. They don't teach you to become engineers. They teach you how to derive formulas that you can easily find in text books. Physics has multiple choice questions. Fill in each answer on a scantron. REALLY???? Because 300 people are taking the same class??? This school (although really nice in the sense that has great facilities, library, etc) is for students who are pre-med or something else. DO NOT DO ENGINEERING HERE. I finished off my degree at SDSU because I learned more there than I ever did here. Especially for Mechanical Engineering and Aerospace Engineering, UCSD takes their curriculum from SDSU. I can't really blame the school, but my experience was so horrid, I might as well.

I actually like SD's rather obscure location. It's located in safe little La Jolla where you don't have to worry too much about being held at gun point and robbed, and you know raped and what not, but if you ever feel like getting out it's only a quick drive out to the city/urban sprawl.

Everyone's heard about how infamously impassive the UC system and staff can be, so I came into SD not really expecting much from my counselors or teachers. But I've learned that if you take the time to reach out to them for help, they WILL really help you. Yeah, color me surprised. 

I'm not exactly fond of waking up with a hangover every day, so I can't really complain about the lack of parties here. Since making friends through playing beer pong isn't quite my thing, I've found that if you actually take the effort to join some clubs, organizations, you're bound to meet some amazing people.

Top tier school, walking distance to the beach, 65-70 degree weather year round - I've got nothing to complain about.

edit - I'm using my sister's account.

Out of all the universities in San Diego, this is the best one to earn a degree from.  Also has the best location; not a minute too far from the beach.

Sure, lots of people whine that it's an anti-social school and that "San Diego" (you're in La Jolla, not SD) sucks because there's nothing to do..  But the social life and the city are what you make of it.  Find your own fun.  Get out of Giesel.

For my 50th Yelp review, I decided to write a review of the institution from which I will be an alumna come June (that is, if I stop procrastinating on Yelp and pass all my classes..). 

Not to mention, it's UCSD's 50th Anniversary, which they're making a pretty big deal about (so big, that the Chancellor in fact dressed up in camouflage for a volunteer campaign: http://a4.sphotos.ak.fbcdn.net/hphotos-ak-snc4/163268_156988644348187_128136397233412_287984_7602067_n.jpg).

As a fifth year (I'm a double major + minor -- I have an excuse for taking this long!), it's hard to decide where to start! In general, the university has improved in many arenas since I first stepped foot onto campus in 2006. The University Center/Student Services Center has doubled in size and resources, the shuttle system has become a bit more streamlined, and they've built housing for transfer students, with a new sports bar and coffee shop nearby. I lived on campus in my freshmen year and all I can say is that all the new on-campus residents are so spoiled with all their amenities and better food! 

As for student life itself, I'd say that this is a great institution to attend if you love studying or if you love student organizations/clubs. 

We have top-notch academic resources on campus, from science labs to social science field research. The university is also well connected in San Diego, so there are many opportunities for some really great internships (I was able to secure one with the American Heart Association as I am going into public health). There are also cool novelty classes ranging from "Anatomy of a Rockstar" to "Psychology of Human Sexuality." There really isn't much guidance when it comes to choosing a field of study, but once you do a little self searching and discover what you want to do with your life, there are plenty of academic resources available for you to utilize. 

But as for me, I love the latter. My experience at UCSD has been shaped by my involvement with various student organizations, as opposed to my academic studies (sorry, parents..). While I'd agree that the campus as a whole doesn't quite scream "partaay!" there are many opportunities to pursue your non-academic interests, and make some great friends along the way. We have hundreds of organizations on campus, and if you don't like any of them, you can even start your own. I'd have to say that I met about 90% of my friends through being involved in student organizations. I've also gained invaluable life skills and experience that you simply can't learn in the classroom (and that I can't possibly express here on Yelp). 

Of course, like many students, I could go on for days about injustices in the school system - bureaucratic agendas, endless red tape, fee hikes, etc. I got over my frustrations by pursuing ways to change what I can for the better (read: Alternative Breaks & UCSD Cares).   

In summary, UCSD is a great place for proactive individuals, be it for your academic success or your social satisfaction. Your experience here is really what you make of it.
The perfect place to do a PhD in biomedical sciences. Or you can freeze your butt off in Boston for the same quality of labs.

I don't think UCSD is for everyone, but if you find your niche, you can get one of the most satisfying educational experiences at this university. 

I loved UCSD. I got involved in a lot of the arts programs at the college and I met loads of friends. Plus, UCSD has one of the most beautiful college campuses in California. 

If you go the college I have a few recommendations and here they are:

1) Get involved - Not necessarily with a sorority, but get involved in cool creative clubs or organizations like the UCSD Guardian or Muir Movie. The theatre department at UCSD is one of the best in the country and taking a couple of theatre classes is a great way to meet friendly peeps because the classes are so small. 

2) Skateboard on campus - I so miss skating on campus while listening to my I-Pod. Do you know how many college kiddies would love to skate on campus? Not only is skating allowed at UCSD, but it is the BEST way to get around. The campus is so big, you need to get some sort transportation and lugging a bike around is no fun. 

3) Eat Hare Krishna - The food is amazing and oh, do I miss it!

4) Take classes by JP Gorrin - He is a genius. He is crazy and and he can be mean, but he really has to something say.  His lecturers are powerful and highly, highly entertaining. 

5) Get a parking pass - Yeah, they are expensive, but I spent too much on parking tickets at UCSD. The parking Nazis are good at what they do, so just park legally because money spent on UCSD parking tickets is money wasted. 

Other than that, I say enjoy the campus. There are plenty of spots with great views so enjoy.

I fully agree with other reviewers that UCSD is what you make of it. Here are my recommendations for potential or current students: Use ratemyprofessor.com and take interesting and/or easy professors. Join some of the university's many clubs and meet people with the same interests as you. I can't emphasize the importance of this enough. There are social people at UCSD, but you may have to make an effort to find them. If you're struggling in a class go to office hours. Many professors are really helpful and friendly one on one. If you're really scared to talk to a professor, or you need help with an essay or assignment go to your TA's office hours since they'll be grading your work in most cases. Use the career services center (and Port Triton) to get a job when you're in school or when you graduate. Also, attend some of the career services center programs about interviewing, writing resumes, etc. If you're applying to graduate school they'll read your personal statement for you and give you recommendations to improve it. They'll also help you with your resume. Overall, they're really helpful. 

UCSD has six different colleges, all with different GE's. If you are thinking about applying here DON'T put Revelle or ERC as your first choice of college on your application. They have the most GEs and they're hard. Muir has the least GEs. I was in Revelle and loved it anyway, but my GPA would have been higher if I didn't have to take a year of both calculus and chemistry, and five quarters of fascinating but ridiculously hard humanities. 

Overall though, I have much love for my alma mater and had an amazing four years here.

Its really hard to rate a unversity on a yelp review.  So many things encompasses a university education that a yelp review is not really legit at all...

I went here for 4 years and they were amazing.  
Even after going to graduate school, UCSD still feels like my real alma mater and "home".

I miss it and when I visited last week, I felt nostalgic with all the memories that came back from it.   Its a part of my past that I can't go back to but always remember! 

Go Tritons!

It was not my first choice; I actually wanted to go to UCLA but got rejected. I don't know how many UCLA-rejectees like me came to UCSD, but I would venture to guess that there were a few. 

The years I had spent here both as an undergraduate and a gradua

I love UCSD. It was my number one choice when I was applying to colleges because of its great reputation in the biological sciences. The campus is huge and has lots to see. It is in my opinion, in one of the best locations-- 5 minutes away from the beach, and a short drive away from downtown San Diego. You have everything you could possibly want in La Jolla/ San Diego. Since I have been attending UCSD I have learned so much. Professors are among the most intelligent in their fields and so easy to approach. They may seem intimidating but they are so eager to have students go talk to them during office hours and make you feel very welcome. It IS a VERY competitive school so be prepared for that. As for all those people who complain about the UCSD social life, it is because they are the ones who choose it to be that way. College is what you make of it, if you are looking to party and have a good time, trust me, you wouldn't have any difficulty at UCSD. If I ever had the choice to go back in time and apply to college again, I would apply to UCSD without a doubt.

Really difficult to write a review of an ENTIRE university on a yelp page so I'm going to summarize by saying:

UCSD gives you essentially ALL the tools to get a really great education, make a lot of friends, and develop yourself for a great future...if you REALLY go out and search for all these things yourself.  Nothing is handed to you, by anybody.

Great weather is something that most people that come from California take for granted.  As an out-of-stater, this is a HUGE HUGE benefit to going to school here.  It makes everything is just more comfortable and easy to deal with.  No rummaging through the snow freezing my ass off, buying new "all weather" tires, searching for winter coats, replacing windshield wipers all the time, new umbrella every few months, hundreds of dollars a month in utilities for AC on a 110F day...etc etc, so much hassle that I've put out of my life by coming to school here!

business.full_address:
Parking Garage Near Kendall St
Kendall Square/MIT
Cambridge, MA 02142
business.name: Toscanini & Sons

reviews.text: This is a branch of the Toscanini & Sons on Washington Street in Somerville. They are not elated to Toscanini's ice cream even thought they do sell Toscanini's ice cream and their logo is nearly identical. You can take away delicious baked goods and $6 sandwiches, plus the full assortment of coffee shop beverages. There are tables with umbrellas outside.

The address for this listing is odd - they're basically on the SE corner (more or less, it's not like streets in Cambridge/Somerville actually run straight!!) of Beacon and Washington, right on the edge of Cambridge and Somerville.

We used to live right in the area and ate their scones almost every day! The fresh fruit scones are the best, although the savory scones (yum, cheddar cheese and onion) are also quite lovely. Not at all dry or hard like most scones you get.

Their coffee is hit-or-miss - there is/was this one guy there who makes the worst coffee - we would actively avoid ordering coffee there if he was working. 

The cafe has got a wonderful, local, family feeling to it - the employees are really nice. If you buy the Toscanini's ice cream by the pint (as you well should!), the pre-packed cartons give you slightly more for your money than the hand-packed ones you buy there. But, of course, then you're subject to fewer choices.

business.full_address:
50 Broadway
2 Cambridge Ctr
Kendall Square/MIT
Cambridge, MA 02142
business.name: Starbucks

reviews.text:
They won me over.

This review is for the Starbucks inside the Marriott Hotel at  Kendall Square in Cambridge. 

I experienced a completely frustrating SNAFU when I tried to order a traveller and miscellaneous other items from this Starbucks ahead of time by phone for a work event. When I arrived to pick up my purchase, there was massive confusion. Once they realized that the person who took my order mysteriously disappeared without mentioning it to anyone else, the four staffers present at this location totally rallied to get the order ready and didn't make me pay for it. As an added bonus, the utter darling-sweetheart who always remembers me prepared the signature beverage that I usually order for me to enjoy while I waited.

Apart from this singular occurence, the staff is normally friendly and pretty efficient. I have a higher percentage chance of receiving my order to spec here than at the other nearby Starbucks (Broadway and Ames). 

Keep up the good work, Kendall Marriott Starbucks staffers!!

This tiny Starbucks-in-a-hotel does not have the full Starbucks menu.  However, you can still give them money in exchange for coffee, so it achieves the bare minimum that needs to be achieved by a Starbucks.

yes, this is a starbucks.  it is in a hotel.  i like this particular location for getting work done.  it's small, and the employees are relatively nice.  it's also good for getting a frappuccino on the way to the t.  there are also couch-like seats immediately outside of the starbucks itself.

Its Starbucks... so... it's pretty much like the others.

Pros: Easy access. Quick service. 

Cons: No skinny caramel macchiato (ok, ok you may be able to order it but it is not on the menu as it is in the Harvard Square one and many others). Staff that sighs a lot when you order (oh I'm sorry, am I making you work?!!?)

This is my favorite starbucks of all time. I always sit at the bar like a loser reading my nook drinking my latte and the fabulous staff are always so friendly and talkative even when they're busy. I see them moving so fast and nailing every drink. They are extremely informative also. I see them constantly getting asked questions and they never fail to give an accurate detailed answer. They are all so great!

For a Starbucks, it's spacious, the employees are on par with other Starbucks locations I approve of, and at almost every table there is a nearby socket! (if you like doing work in cafes).

Big pro is that the half the walls are windows, so if you happen to be here on a weekend in late September, you may catch the Oktoberfest 5K as you sip your Sunday coffee!

I normally enjoy a Starbucks, and I always give good reviews.  However this past Sunday 8/5/12 the girl behind the counter needed a serious attitude adjustment.  I paid for my order with six (6) $1 coins.  She told me she couldn't taken "Subway tokens" as she rides the subway and this is the change they give.  True, that's where I obtained said coins, however if she paid attention they're $1 coins.  It took the other girl behind the counter to explain it to her.  This will not prevent me from going back as I enjoy a Starbucks and I understand they were busy, but don't automatically give somebody an attitude that early in the morning.   This should be a 4-star.

Every time I go in the staff is always friendly.  Once or twice there was a goof up in the afternoon but the morning commuters rush is always on point- and if it isn't they will give you free drink tickets every time.  Thanks Starbucks team Cambridge!

I

This starbucks is okay but the one right up the street at the Marriot Inn is wayyyy better.  They always have a bigger and fresher selection of food and there are more baristas working the counter so you end up getting your coffee or latte a lot faster.  This place is good for the convenience since it's right off the Kendall T station but if you can afford to walk up the street, it will be worth your time.

I'm going to throw out some love for my local Starbucks, okay? 

I realize that it's more fun to point out the hilarity that this company brings out. All those skinny hipsters in their Buddy Holly specks with their Macbooks and their..faces. But what makes this location awesome is a great staff--I've had the pleasure of getting to know several of them, and I gotta say, they'll take care of people with patience and an obvious care. This is probably why they have so many regulars. 

Also. Sitting at the bar is the tits.
Have been there multiple times, moderately crowded but more spacious than other Starbucks in the area, has good service. I wish they were open later though. And free wi-fi is always convenient :)
great drip coffee.  love the hot chocolate if i already had my caffeine.
There is no Starbucks wi-fi that I could find in this location despite starbucks.com saying otherwise. There is paid wifi available form the hotel however.

business.full_address:
4340 University Way NE
University District
Seattle, WA 98105
business.name: Soap Box the

reviews.text:
Anything you could imagine that has to do with soaping up the body is here in this store.  The overpowering scent of the shampoo, soap, creams, perfumes and everything else can almost knock you down so hold your breath and plunge right in. 
They also have bulk products if you are in the mood to create your own signature bath gel.

business.full_address:
Alewife Brook Parkway and Cambridge Park Drive
Harvard Square
Cambridge, MA
business.name: Alewife Station

reviews.text:
What a beautifully building. 

This is a very good choice for people coming from the north to get into Boston. you can drive in to exactly where traffic starts to become crazy and drop off your car in the lot that holds 2700 cars and even take you clothes to the cleaners in the lower level so that on the way home it will be ready and you take the red line to where you want to go, it passes Harvard Sq. into South station.

I don't mind Alewife Station, it's A-OK.  That's probably because I've never had to drive and park there.  It doesn't seem to matter if it's 1 in the morning and every other street's deserted, Alewife Brook Parkway always manages to be packed right by the T station with cars driven by irate people just itching to give you the finger.  Here's the solution to this: Forget driving there.  Take the 79 or the 350 or one of the other handful of buses that come through there.  Problem solved!

As to the station itself, it's big and sorta clean.  They've got a Dunkin' Donuts, though I've never eaten anything from it so I can't speak to the freshness of that muffin or bagel you just purchased.

I have never seen more disgusting bathrooms in my life, though.  I was having a serious bathroom attack when I walked in, but upon further inspection, I realized I just didn't have to go anymore.  But on the plus side, most other T stations don't even have bathrooms to begin with.  Kudos to Alewife for that.

The Alewife station is great! It is for MANY MANY reasons! 

Let me just start by saying I use this station just about every other weekend this year when I go to Boston! 

Its location is GREAT! Because you dont need to drive into Boston to get here! HUGE plus for me! I hate the traffic Boston sometimes offers. The station also has a lot of parking. I find it best to park up on the 3rd level and just park in a corner! This way its easy to find your car and the 3rd level all most always seems empty to me. So if you worry about your car getting hit or bumped. This is some advice for you! 

Parking here is very cheap! $7 a day or $8 a night! I dont think there is a better deal than this in the area. I know in Boston the cheapest I could find it was $15 a night. So being at about half the price you dont really need to think about it! 

The tickets for the train are also very reasonable! You can do it a few different ways! One you could get a card and load up some money and pay $1.75 a scan. Not to bad! The second choice you can do and get a 7 day pass for a cheap $15. The monthly card goes for around $60 if I remember right. I always end up getting the 7 day pass. I can easily use over $15 in one weekend just going back and worth in the city! So if your there for a weekend that's probably your best bet. Then you dont need to keep refilling the card! Also keep in mind all of the options are also good for the bus lines as well and ANY color train route! 

The only thing about this station that gets to me as I'm sure you can read in other reviews. The bathrooms are bad! I dont think they are ever cleaned. Even the sink is nasty. Stay clear of this. Just go down and get on your train! Wait it out until your next stop! 

So over all the station is very helpful for parking and tickets for public transportation. Its not over prices and I have never ran into a problem on the T. Trains always seem to be on time and one is always sitting there when I get down there! So if your going to Boston or anywhere the T can bring you, go here! Just make sure you can hold your self if you need a rest room!

Very very solid 4/5!

Alewife is a great station. Let me elaborate:

-It's easy to get to from Route 2(my preferred approach), or the Minuteman bike trail.

-It's simple to navigate around the station itself, as it has two tracks which are both on the same platform.

-It also has plenty of inexpensive parking(I've never had trouble finding a space).

-It's fairly modern and well kept(except for the restrooms, as others have pointed out!).

I go here all the time, and will continue to do so

Spotted dead center in the confluence of several apocalyptically horrendous traffic patterns, Alewife is pretty much DOA straight out of the gate. It's a bitch to get to, it's an even worse bitch to get out of, and it generally smells of piss (when it doesn't actually just smell of straight up raw sewage, as it did for much of the summer of 2011, when I'm assuming all the pipes got backed up) and exhaust. 

It also must serve as a reform school for the recalcitrant of MBTA employees, as everyone always seems to be in a foul mood, and they all sequester themselves in their little glass encased bunker refusing to acknowledge that every single bus coming to or out of the station is over 30 minutes late. I see you in there!! Just tell me if if I'm better off just walking the three miles home instead of waiting (and waiting and waiting) for the goddamn 79!

One star, plus one star because it is actually rather cozily heated in the winter, waiting for all those buses that never come.

I parked at Alewife and took the train for the first time at the end of February (2012) and had no issues.  Getting in and out was fine (I consider myself a good driver and I had my navigator with me so I knew where go).

The signs to the trains are not as visible as they could be.  I wasn't sure which direction to go in when I got out of my car.  Finding a place around 12:30 p.m. on a Thursday was a little bit of a search but I did find a place within 5 minutes of arriving and it was close to the stairs.  

The $7 is reasonable but if it goes up, I won't be able to afford to take advantage of this great convenience.  I t is more affordable than taking the T and transfering to the Redline (I live in Waltham).
Plenty of parking, lots of space, great location, trains run on time in general. A pretty nice station in general.

Talk about end of the line!  This place is built up for one purpose... to store the vehicles of commuters.  There's tons of bike racks, and a huge a** parking garage.  The garage is open 24 hours, and takes cash only ($9 bucks a day i think).

It's easily accessible from Route 2 if you are going East (from 95).  I have found it to prefer it over the orange line for that reason.  You never know which of the 2 trains docked there will leave first, so just hop on one and wait.  

The bathrooms are so dirty they'll magically give you the ability to 'hold it' ... i'm talking even at urinals people.  I washed my hands in there, and i think they actually got dirtier. 

There is also a maze of escalators going to specific floors in the parking garage, so remember where you parked.  However if you don't like walking down stairs, take the elevator... it's the easiest way to go down. 

but yeah, if you are living in suburbia, and are trying to get to a T line, this place is wicked easy to get to... unlike that infamous station 'oak grove' which I have only heard legends about but never been able to find (I always wind up in Malden Center, trying to get there, wtf!)
I find it generally clean and well-lit. Benches are cleaner than those of Green or Orange. Not sure what others are referring to!

Say you have designated Alewife as the meeting point for a group of friends. You are taking off for the weekend on a whitewater rafting trip and this is where you carless folk are meeting the designated driver. You live half a mile from Alewife so you figure you'll just walk... Except.

There are no sidewalks on portions of Route 16 leading to Alewife, leaving you to drag your wheelie duffel bag, bouncey bounce bounce, over the rough terrain of rocks and dirt and maybe some hypodermic needles. So instead you just walk to Davis and take the train one stop.

I have had actual train-taking experiences at Alewife. It has a nice circle where cars can stop for pickup (not the case with other Red Line stations). It is close to such fine institutions as Bertucci's and Lanes 'n Games. It has a garage where you can park for cheap(ish) rates and head into Boston.

But the traffic circle outside gets horribly, awfully, catastrophically clogged. Seriously, don't EVER drive near here between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m. on weekdays (and probably not on weekends, either). So, it really isn't all that convenient for cars. And as we've seen, not really for pedestrians, either... Would it be so hard to put in sidewalks?

Meh.  It's the end of the line, and the station is generally pretty clean and safe. The downside is the public bathrooms, which are schnasty, but at least there is ample parking and a DD for when you're in need of caffeine before work.

Convenient to route 2 in Cambridge, this station is frequently very crowded being the northern most point on the Red Line through Boston's MBTA.  The part that gets everyone is trying to leave the parking garage during rush hour is pure punishment.  Avoid that time and it's not too bad at all.   Could be cleaner at times.

Which train? WHICH TRAIN? There are two... and they are both going the same direction... and they both have their doors open... and people are boarding both.... AAAAAH... I'm in a hurry... which is departing first??? Oh good lord!  Tell me which train to get on!  I don't want to get on the wrong train and end up late!  It's the beginning/end of the red line... either one could be the next one out... can I just use a life-line?  I have no final answer!  Okay... i choose the one on the right... phew... sit down... relax... and... DAG NABBIT... boop boop... the other train left first.  Jeeze louise... just my effin luck.

This is a Historical Building?  No, this place is a Historical Dump!   The red line is easily a close contender for worst line in the MBTA subway system.  If the orange line didn't have so much vomit on it's trains and used syringes...............the red line would be on top...........and  Alewife would be it's disasterpeice.

In addition to being a great parking place for commuters coming into Boston/Cambridge from west or north of Boston, the garage is also a great alternative for local residents to park their cars during a snowstorm!  Most residences in the immediate area only have outdoor parking options (driveway or street).  So if you live in the area and don't want to have to shovel out your car after a snowstorm, you can't beat the price of $7 or $8 (overnight) to park your car during the storm, then drive it out after all the snowplowing is done.

Ah yes, Alewife, everyone's favorite historical landmark. Over there, the famous battle site where in 1998 two JNCO-wearing teens fought over whether the new Insane Clown Posse album came out this week or next. And here, on the top floor of this very parking lot, marks the spot where in late February 2010, Lindsay "The Rock Johnson" B. found her car battery dead at 4 AM, and wishing to inform/bother no one, spent the most boring/freezing/unfoundedly terrifying 45 minutes of her life waiting for AAA.

Yelp miscategorization aside, Alewife actually isn't too bad of a place if you're in the burbs north of Boston and need to get into the city. The garage houses 2700 cars and 175 bikes, and parking is $7 for 24 hours. Good place to leave your car and disappear from your parents' house for a few days when you're home for the summer from college. I wouldn't know, just guessing.

Alewife Station also connects to the Minuteman bike path, which you can ride all the damn way to Bedford, if you really want to get somewhere where there's absolutely nothing to do.

And, since no one has mentioned it yet:
The alewife is a species of herring. The front of the body is deep and larger than other fish found in the same waters, and its common name is said to come from comparison with a corpulent female tavernkeeper ("ale-wife").

Source: Wikipedia.

The more you know.
It's the end of the red line, easy to get to and parking is usually great. Getting out, however, sucks.  SUCKS.  It could be 10am or 11pm - expect to wait from 5 to 20 minutes to leave.

This is the station I drive to when I want to access Boston.  Whether it's to pickup/drop off a person or actually traveling to Boston myself, I'd rather park and ride than to navigate the busy streets of the inner city.

Positives:
- Easy to get to as it's right off of Route 2 eastbound.
- Usually enough temporary parking spaces to wait for people
- No one harasses you in the temporary parking spaces even if you've been there for hours waiting.
- Dunkin Donuts right before the turnstiles if you're hungry
- Usually but not always plenty of parking in the garage
- Escalator and elevator

Negatives:
- Navigating the turns of the garage may be hazardous
- Escalator sometimes break down
- I've been seeing the parking fee rise over the years.
- Sometimes the garage gets really full and you worry about not finding parking even at the top level.
- Getting out of the station and back on to Route 2 can be hazardous due to the timing of the traffic lights.
Great place for flowers.

business.full_address:
2505 Telegraph Ave
Telegraph Ave
Berkeley, CA 94704
business.name: Sockshop Telegraph

reviews.text: As a sock lover I was thrilled to stumble across Sockshop Telegraph. Awesome selection, good prices, friendly staff.   Will certainly return.

A second location for the Sockshop (Haight being the other one), I stumbled across the Berkeley location this past weekend while out exploring and shopping. I headed on in for some replacement tights.

The stock and prices are similar to the store on Haight. Spacious interior, colourful socks of all shapes and sizes, tights everywhere, I was able to find what I was looking for quickly and get served fast. The girl behind the counter was super nice and I left much happier than I was before going in.

You can't go wrong with the Sockshop for everything about your feet. Or legs.

I stumbled into this place by accident while wandering around Berkeley this past weekend with friends.  This is the shop you go when you have a sock fetish, a fun sense of humor, or need to find a gift for the person who already has 'everything'.  I bought some 'puzzled' socks, 'derby' socks and 'high top Converse' socks----all very fun.  My friend bought some skull-decorated socks. Reasonably priced for a boutique store and the staff was very friendly.  They also have hose, kids socks, hiking socks.

business.full_address:
3801 Chestnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Chili's Grill & Bar

reviews.text:
Go ahead and think I'm lame for going to chain restaurants when I live in the Big Love. We had a gift card.

We went for lunch and I got the bottomless salad and soup for 6.95. If you have the guts and want to try lots of soups, ask for it to come in cups so you get less full and can try more! The salad is boring, but the soups are spicy and exciting! I think I got something like chicken enchilada as my favorite.

Margarita specials are banging. I like strawberry. They have $3 top shelf margaritas on monday, and sometimes $3 classic ones on Tuesday and Thursday depending on their supply. Maybe call ahead. I really like their Pomegranate special margarita.

Now, I got this coupon for signing up for salsa and queso... the queso is awesome! We got whatever sounded the spiciest and went to town on it's sizzling pan of goodness! But the salsa... HOW IS THEIR SALSA SUPPOSED TO STAY ON A CHIP? IT'S LIKE GAZPACHO.
And sometimes you get a wowza over-salted chip. Turns you off the chip bowl for a while.

I LOVE THEIR LITTLE SOUTHWESTERN EGGROLLS THOUGH. Corn and blackbeans in a tiny baby burrito that is fried up like an eggroll. I could eat it for hours. I tried them as part of the happy hour food special, and it was definitely worth it.

I would particularly like to compliment my recurring waitress Asia, who has tips for the girl who really doesn't know anything about cocktails, and can accommodate special preferences when ordering things like wings and sauces. :)

I will, without shame, go there someday for the 2 for $20 dinner special. See if you can stop me.

I don't care what anyone says...Chili's is great and I would take their Baby Back Ribs over a lot of meals at high-end restaurants anytime.  Chili's is my favorite of the chains, as personally I feel it is far superior to TGI Fridays, Ruby Tuesdays or the rest of the field.

I'd say about once every two months you should find yourself in a booth drinking a 22 once mug of beer, munching on bottomless chips and salsa and waiting for your "baby back baby back baby back..."

One evening, I was with a co-worker in UniCity looking for some eats.  We went to White Dog but with the mortgage crunch in full effect, we found it unlikely that we could secure a home loan in order to afford food there.  

Then we tried Mad-Mex.  The wait was something like an hour.  

In our hunger-based stupor, we just settled on Chili's.  After nearly a year of living in the city, I had forgotten what a chain store like this was like.  

Our waiter, although really friendly, kept screwing things up.  Like repeatedly.  Wrong dish.  Wrong side.  Wrong check.  Wrong items on the check.  Kept screwing up.  It was pretty humorous but I could see it being a problem if I needed to get somewhere.  

As for the food, they were out of my first and second choice (?).  But once my third choice was approved, it arrived and tasted like it was reheated in a microwave.  Mmmmm...

As we left, I checked "eat at chain restaurant" off of my year checklist and relaxed knowing that I won't have to do that again until next year.

Wow, quick heads up on the homemade chips (all you can eat), if you get the bottom of the barrel (or wherever they store them), they will be -salty-.  

The service is swift, good for large groups of students wandering in, and the drinks are large and usually decent. Food is in good supply, and at decent prices, and the dessert of choice is the molten chocolate cake.

Mango iced tea here is a mix of sugar, tea, and flavoring, but at least the waitstaff is generally good about getting plenty of refills and is pretty helpful when it comes to boxing up leftovers.

Overall, food is not bad. If you get the queso, get the meat one, it makes it that much better with the chips.  Birthdays are celebrated with gusto here, too, nicely.

Only gripes are the wait time (not unusual near a university), and the inability to split checks for one-table parties (they tend to do more than one table okay, though, oddly enough, might just be the waitstaff on each day).

Every time my friend and I go out to eat she usually makes the suggestion, "I think there's a Chili's around here!"  Which I will always roll my eyes and say "No, let's not talk about it either."  Back in the day, my friend, her boyfriend, and I went to this Chili's (I have no idea why, looking back on it), we were poor or at least, I was poor.  I ended up getting some crappy appetizer, probably cheese quesadillas or something along those lines.  It was all fun and games while we were there and then.....then my friends were dropping me off at the 34th St. El stop, my stomach and all it's contents quickly dropped.  Let's just be blunt, I made it all the way to Delaware County on SEPTA without crapping my pants.
I never really understood the appeal to this place.  Even when I was older, people at my work would go here for cheap margaritas.  No thanks, I'll definitely pass.

Chilli's is good for what it's good for, and you don't go there expecting something high end. It's a chain restaurant that's good for things like burgers, sandwiches, salads, and some okay apps. Their prices are decent, service okay, and generally the place is clean. It can be a little load at times, but it's a hangout type of restaurant, not one for a dinner date.

We chose Chilli's because it was close, service is typically quick, prices are good, and we felt it was a spot that would work for us having our 7 month old baby. And, it did all of this for us.

We enjoyed the chips and queso app. My sandwhich and fries were tasty too. Nothing too fancy, but not much to complain about.

It is what it is, and you should not expect it to be more.

somehow, shockingly, exactly like every chili's ive ever been in before!!!

except, in philadephia, there's really no excuse to actually go here. unlike, say phoenix, where the only choices are chili's, applebees and...hm. that's it.

I'm with Russ on this, 110%. I know they're considered "Tex Mex", but Chili's has better Mexican food than most of this city, I'm sorry to say. If it wasn't for Mad Mex's excellent drink and food specials, Chili's would be my place (though their margaritas are so, so powdery).

My favorite thing is the salsa. Chili's has great chips and salsa, and they serve drinks in big frosty mugs. I feel when I'm drinking beer/coke out of those big mugs, and crunching on corn chips, I feel like pure and absolute dude... like a caveman.

Then my Quesidilla Explosion Salad comes, and I'm pulled back to reality.
Friendly staff

Only reason to go to Chili's?  Fajita Rita Mondays.  Who doesn't love a fajita every so often?  These will satisfy that craving and with iced margaritas, especially on a hot summer night, this is a great once in a while dinner.

Yuck.  I really loather chain restaurants and Chili's is no exception.  The one nice this about this Chili's is it's proximity to the Penn Campus and the universally cheap and greasy burgers and other fried foods are the same at any Chili's nation wide.

It's kinda dirty in here - and the place is run by teenagers.

I guess it beats TGI Friday's - but not by much.

Food was  delicious as usual, ok waiter. Dining room area was freezing. Waiter served us water with dingy plastic mugs. That was the only disgrace. I scratched of some of the caked mildew of the plastic mugs. Mugs need to be scrubbed, or better yet they need to be thrown away. Make sure your mugs are clean before you drink. This review very generous.

This Chili's location really sucks... You would think since its in University City area it would be better but its not.. Its really horrible. 

Its not too clean and just the whole ambience is soooo dreary....
Hey! THIS place has GREAT food at reasonable price. Two thumbs up!
My first try to american style restaurant....good service, good food

I work here but I am far from biased. I never was a fan of Chili's food. I feel that it's menu lacks the variety and depth of Fridays. Even so, this restaurant is pretty good. The Quesadilla Explosion Salad is AMAZING and who can turn up $2.50 margaritas on Mondays?
The best molten chocolate cake in the whole world! Nothing beats that.

I had nothing but the utmost respect for Chillis in Center City. However, the franchise in University City is just plain wrong. We just happen to have a gift card for $50, so we decided to take a trip to the nearest Chillis. Our party waited for 15 minutes for signs of life; waiter, staff, anyone. Our un-appetizers took another 20 minutes to show on our table. Having bland chips with salsa that tasted two-weeks old is far from a siesta. 

Contemplating to leave was in all of our minds, but we somehow managed to stay for the full meal. BIG MISTAKE! Our waiter took forever, even getting refills on water. Usually in any restaurant, they would come to your table and pour water into your glass. NOOOO, not Chillis! The staff  takes your glass, hide in the kitchen for a half hour, and if you are lucky, return your glass with less ice than before. 

Our entrees were decent, with some minor issues. The bacon cheeseburger looked overcooked, and tasted salty. My friend's fajita was very sloppy, and tasted as if the chefs (LMAO CHEFS) never added   salt or pepper. Overall, our food looked rushed. Never come to Chillis during a game.

At the last minute, friends and I decided to take another friend to dinner and Chili's was it. I don't recall ever going to that one before.

Half way through the meal a mouse ran around the floor. The server acknowledged it and said "What can I do about?". 

That should be enough for you to make any future decisions.

The food would have been okay, had it not been obviously sitting in the kitchen for quite some time. This happens EVERYTIME, I'm at this specific Chili's. Seriously, this just makes the food look even more unappetizing. Service is terrible on multiple occ

This Chili's is in sort of an awkward location....situated above a strip club. Stopped here two times for some take out and left utterly unimpressed. When you arrive (and I did around 9:30pm), it is like a time warp. The place is not very inviting or clean for that matter. The help is no where to be found. I stood at the bar both times waiting for someone to recognize me and offer their assistance. I'm sure a few strippers on break were enjoying a cocktail at the bar (had to be cheaper drinks than what were offered downstairs, not that I've ever been there...). The food was passable (this is a Chili's, you know). Why I went twice within a week is beyond me.

I went in to this location for lunch a few weeks ago.  The food was great, nice portions, served hot, very tasty.  The service was exceptional.  We had a really terrific server named Dani.  She was the best!  She was very courteous and attentive.  She really took great care of us.  We had a great meal and a great time!  Thanks, Dani!

The food is great and the drinks are okay.  Service may be a little slow, but they'll bring your food.  They have great burgers and awesome queso dip (especially the 'wild' version currently on special) and I've eaten there enough to believe their food is consistently good.

Go during lunch (when they have great lunch deals) or when they're having drink specials.

business.full_address:
470 N Greenbush Rd
Rensselaer, NY 12144
business.name: Hennessy Homebrew Emporium

reviews.text:
I've been shopping at the Homebrew Emporium in Cambridge for a few months now, and decided to stop by to the Rensselaer location while I was in town to pick up a few things. 

The store is SO HUGE compared to the one in Cambridge, but this comes as no surprise considering the cost of real estate in both locations. While the Rensselaer location has the disadvantage of being in a weird strip mall on a heavily trafficked road (it's hard to take a left turn into this place), that all doesn't matter once you step inside.

The selection of stock on the shelves is huge, there's almost an entire room dedicated to wine kits, unlike the single shelf at Cambridge. You could easily lose yourself browsing around at bottles, wine kits, corkers, presses, beer brewing ingredients, books, and miscellaneous accessories.

The employees were very helpful and were able to find me the things I needed very quickly, and they were also quite friendly. I was in and out quick because I was in a rush, but in the future I'd like to spend more time checking this place out.

I walked in here to pick up a few missing items from an old homebrew kit. The salesman (store person? clerk?) sensed I had no idea what I was doing and walked me through the process. He told me if I had any questions as I was brewing to just call the store and they'll help me out. Good service is good.

Wide selection of pretty much anything you could want to brew beer, make cheese, or make wine. And probably some other stuff I missed.

A few years ago my husband expressed an interest in brewing beer so I decided to buy him the setup as a Christmas present.  While I knew nothing about beer brewing the staff at Hennessy was extremely helpful.  I purchased a starter kit and we were brewing.  

In addition to a ton of stuff for beer making they also stock wine kits and cheese making ingredients.  The store is jam packed and the counter area is a little crowded. Checking out can take a little while if the person in front of you wants to get into a long winded discussion but the staff is pretty good about making sure everyone is helped. 

The one bad feature to the store is getting in and out of the parking lot - you take your life in your hands getting out on Rt. 4.

They have a helpful and knowledgeable staff, and will help you over the phone. They also carry a wide selection of grains, hops, yeasts, and kits. For ingredients, they are one of the best homebrew shops I've heard of. They also sell the intro homebrewing kits for around $80, a very good price. 
    However, they charge a hefty markup for simple hardware, like thorns and tubing, that would be dirt cheap at a hardware store. I understand that profits have to come from somewhere, but it can be a little silly. I've taken to buying the equipment I need from Wal-Mart, and ingredients there because of cost, but I would like to be able to support them more with my dollar.
    Overall, they provide an excellent value for most things, and are very helpful. If you live in the Capital Region and are interested in homebrewing, I would start here and upgrade my equipment on the internet later.

business.full_address:
85 4th St
Troy, NY 12180
business.name: Lo Porto's

reviews.text:
I don't understand the appeal.

The food is relatively average as Italian goes in this area. It's not bad, but it's definitely not great. It's also quite expensive... and easy to walk by without even knowing it's a restaurant. 

Also, sometimes the waiter

One of the best home-style restaurants I have been to in a while.  My favorite is Consiglios in New Haven, CT.  I just graduated from RPI this semester (Dec. '11) and finally tried this restaurant.  It is the last white tablecloth restaurant left in Troy and it really shines.  The place doesn't look like much from the outside and it is no in the best area of Troy, but it is great.  The inside feels a Manhattan restaurant.  It feels like the restaurant in the movie "Dinner Rush."  

On to the food.  I have had the Bolognese which was I was completely unimpressed with (hence the four stars instead of five).  It was chopped up meatballs in their house marinara instead of a stewed beef, veal, pork, and/or sausage sauce with a couple of cans of tomato sauce like I grew up with and found at other top-notch Italian restaurants.  I would not recommend this dish.

The two times succeeding my first visit I ordered the chicken parmigiana.  It was thick for what I am used to, very thick in fact.  However, it was properly cooked and the most tender breaded chicken I have had.  The breading was good Italian bread crumbs cooked in good olive oil.  The house sauce is quite good.  

The portions are huge, really huge.  Most restaurants give you one chicken breast filleted into two pieces and then breaded and fried.  They give you two full chicken breasts and pasta.  If you order a pasta dish, it comes with an entire pound of pasta.  The prices are high, but you get a lot of food.  

The atmosphere has a local elegant feel.  It is a mix between my local pizza place and an elegant restaurant.  Actually, when I was there last, there were two wedding proposals (The guy hid the ring under a pile of fried calamari).  Service was fine.  It is a relaxed dining experience (i.e. slow).  If you are with family or friends it goes by quickly.  Delicious bread comes to the table upon arrival and the wine list is extensive (for Troy at least, Spago had a text book for a wine list, so not quite that long).  

I liked this restaurant a lot.  It is traditional Italian fare that I love.  It is not the nuvo-Italian restaurants folks like in NYC (such as Babbo or Circo), but I like traditional better anyway.   It is a must for RPI families, a business lunch, and perhaps a proposal.

Ok, so I'm comparing Lo Porto's to my favorites such as Cafe Capriccio, Cafe Italia and Lombardo's.  But good Italian is Good Italian regardless of location.  Lo Porto's was OK but  really not that great.

The first thing that turned me off was the salad included with the meal.  Ok, so it was included BUT...I asked if their house vinaigrette was home made and I was told yes.  My salad came out and it was standard iceburg with a bit of romaine and BOTTLED Italian dressing!  There's no confusing home made for the bottled crap that I hate so...much!

The pasta...over cooked and literally about 2 lbs of the stuff per dish. I think that's a huge waste of food.  If it and the sauce was really good I might consider taking the remaining 1.75 lbs of it home.  But it was only standard fare that would have sat in my fridge festering until the next time I cleaned out the fridge...

The Veal Parm..super flat paper thin piece of meat pounded so much it actually hung over the plate.  It looked inpressive when it came out with it's 2 lbs of pasta but it was all breading and the veal was indistinguishable from anything  that could have been pounded that flat and thin.   I know it was veal but mystery meat comes to mind when you really can't tell! 

That's my experience.  salad dressing from a bottle on iceburg lettuce and highly breaded  "paper" veal with no flavor and too much over cooked pasta.

And the place is chopped up into very small, odd dinning areas.  Just not impressed.  I know many people love this place but I just don't get it.  Although I love some high end Italian places, I also appreciate a great mom and pop red sauce joint.  This just didn't fit into either catagory as far as flavor, quality or ambiance,.

This place is without a doubt the best italian place in the area. I've been a number of times -service has never been bad and the food is always great, but expensive. You know an Italian joint's going to be good when it shares a name with a disgraced, indicted politician.

I truly don't understand how anyone can say Lombardo's in Albany even comes close to this place...

If you're thinking about going - Go.

I've driven down 4th street dozens of times and I've never noticed this place existed until we went for dinner. It just blends in with all the storefronts and closed businesses. Upon entering it appears small and old fashioned but there is much more seating in the back. 

The restaurant is very casual yet the menu is quite expensive for the area. But like others have said, portions are huge. Some of the biggest I've ever seen. Since it was my birthday dinner and my parents were paying I ordered the Seafood Fra Diavolo which was $41. I'm not kidding when I say this was so big it was served on a platter rather than a plate and had more seafood than pasta. 

Unfortunately I didn't find the food itself as impressive as the portion sizes. Bigger is not always better. The sauce was thin and the seafood was just mediocre. I also tried some of the fried calamari which looked great but just tasted kinda bland.  I did however enjoy the leftovers slightly more than my original meal.
