This place screwed up our reservations and were refusing to  seat us even though there was 4 empty tables and no one else was coming in until 7. (it was 5:15) I feel the hostess miss treated us because we looked young. the same feeling I got last time we ate here. First she said she couldn't find us on the list, then the bartender did and asked her to just seat us now and she was really rude about it. Needless to say we will not be returning here.

This was my first experience with Lo Porto's and it was great. There are a few things to note about this place. First: make a reservation. It's not a large restaurant and it fills very quickly. Especially during peak times, you'll be waiting for quite a while for a table, largely because of my next point:

Don't go here if you're in a hurry. Lo Porto's makes it very clear right on their menu that they don't rush the kitchen. They take their time and they do it right. I've never been one to care so much about these sorts of places as long as the food that results from it is good. That's certainly the case here. We waited about 45 minutes for our food after ordering, and when it came out, it certainly wasn't a disappointment. Well worth the wait.

Serving sizes are hefty. If you're not hungry, be prepared to take an assload of leftovers home. I was really hungry, however, so I destroyed (most of) what they brought to me. Of course I couldn't really move afterward, but hey, it was worth it.

Parking, as is typical in Troy, can be a bit challenging. I parked in the small garage over on River and State streets since I had some things to do in that area before heading over to the restaurant. 

The outside appearance may turn you off. It's not in the nicest or prettiest of areas, but I assure you it's a great place. If you like Italian food, this is one of those local places that you have to check out.

2nd time here. We arrived at 5:15 and were the only people in the place. It was like a private dinner. We sat at the "prime table" at the top of the stairs overlooking the bar area. The bread was hot & fresh, the romaine salad with the home made Italian dressing was tasty. I had the chicken cordon bleu. It was very good. A bit too much Prosciutto but very good. Once again we will definitely be back!

Lo Porto's never gets it wrong. I have been there many times with many different people (some very finicky!) and everyone has always been blown away. The food is amazing. The service is amazing. The prices are amazing. The steak au poivre is TO DIE FOR as are any of the parms. Oh, and don't you dare skip dessert. 
 
Ohhhh, Lo Porto's!!!! I would love to curl up in your culinary arms.... 

Go. Just go.

LO PORTO WAS SO-SO

Let me start by saying that my first visit to Lo Porto was in Fall 1994 when I was just a freshman at RPI. I asked my Residence Director to recommend a place that would impress my uncle that was coming up for Family Weekend.  Well, it sure did the job. I still remember what my uncle said after dinner was over: "He's been to Italian places all over the world, but the food here was PHENOMENAL!" And so the bar was set. For the last 17 years Lo Porto's which is hidden away in upstate New York on a small street in downtown Troy would forever be against what all restaurants would be compared. And I've been coming back up here for the last 17 years even though I have lived near New York City since the late 90's.  My usual table is the one over-looking the balcony (ask for Table #7 when reserving a table for 2).

So, my wife and a friend decided to go there after heading up to RPI for alumni weekend.  On Saturdays, the restaurant opens at 5:00 PM, so we made a reservation for that time.  When we arrived we told the hostess that we had a reservation and she began to lead us upstairs past my usual table on the balcony and into their backroom. We had a reservation for 3, so I can understand why they couldn't seat us at Table #7, but there were plenty of other tables on the second level and couldn't understand why they were hiding us all the way in the back. When I asked the hostess why she was seating us all the way in the back, at first she told me that the tables had been reserved. I then reminded her that WE had a reservation ourselves and that we had driven about 3 hours up there from NYC and could have anywhere but in advance we had chosen to go there.

I should probably make mention, that this was not the first time that I had gone up there with my wife. About 3 years ago I went up there with my wife for another alumni weekend event and I was very excited to show her my "hidden secret" in Troy. Unfortunately, that night was less than spectacular and my wife could not understand why I always carried on making such a big thing about this place. I assured her that it must have been an off night and could only hope that she'd give this place another try.

Fast forward to the present day. We ordered the Escargot Maison ($12.95) - Escargot Stuffed Mushrooms Caps in a Zesty Cream Sauce with Garlic. However, the description fails to mentions the fresh diced tomatoes and capers interspersed throughout the dish. The 3 of us devoured the appetizer and it was every bit as good as I remembered.

For my entree I ordered the restaurant's signature dish, Veal Scorsese ($24.95). My wife was indecisive of what she wanted to order and did not see Penne Vodka on the menu, so the waitress suggested that she could have my side pasta which was included with the veal and that the chef could prepare it with their cognac sauce which is similar to vodka sauce. How could anyone turn down an offer like that?

When the meals came, my veal was as excellent as I had always remembered it to be. Even my wife admitted that her Ziti in Cognac Sauce with mushrooms and prosciutto was as well prepared as any Penne Vodka she had anywhere else.  As other reviewers have mentioned, the portions here are insane and you will definitely be wrapping up part of your entree to bring home.

The big surprise for us came when we received our check. The menu lists the Veal Scorsese ($24.95), but the check showed the charge for that portion of the meal as $32.90. When I asked the waitress how much extra it cost for the Cognac Sauce she confirmed that it was $7.95 and said that it was because it was cooked to order. At that price I probably would have just asked her if she could prepare a 1/2 order of pasta for my wife and still give me the side of pasta that was included with my meal. The problem I have is that she did not tell me about that the additional charge was so exorbitant.

To close this up, on this visit the food was much better than our last visit. Good enough to convince my wife that we should come back here again on our next trip to RPI.  The biggest problem that I had was with the service. I have seen prices increase by over 60% in the time that I have been coming here. This is not the fault of the chef/owner as price changes can be attributed to inflation and the increase of his materials. Unfortunately, I can't find any reason for the consistent drop in service. I did appreciate that our waitress asked us if we had tickets to a show and were in a hurry. However, I could not understand why the hostess tried to hide us away in the back when nobody else was in there. We stayed there long enough to see her put a few couples that were 40 years older than us in our surrounding seats on the balcony. It would have been nice if she mentioned about the near $8 surcharge on the pasta, there should never be surprises when the check arrives. A bad start and a bad finish to what could have otherwise have been a better rated evening.

Look, I am sad to post that Lo Porto's probably won't be an Italian restaurant I'm coming back any time soon. Sad because for so long it had been on our list of places to try in Troy, a place that everyone said we simply must try - and it didn't live up to my expectations.

I don't really have any complaints about the food. It's flavourful, hearty Italian fare. The salads were great, and the bread was delicious (though I should have read Ticia's review more carefully - I didn't realize you had to special request oil, so we just got butter). I had an eggplant parm that was lovely but could have held off on the cheese, and my husband had a seafood dish that was loaded very generously with scallops.

Here comes the '.... but.' When we walked in to the somewhat empty room without a reservation, I was surprised at the instantly frosty reaction from the hostess. Like lullabylove x, we got shafted in this table by the kitchen, where there was huge amounts of traffic from the staff.  I felt uncomfortable the whole night as it was difficult to relax with someone brushing by every five seconds. It sucked. I also had the distinct impression if I was thirty years older I would have been treated better. A place has to be really special for me to ignore such bad service.

They get 2 stars because I'd enjoyed my previous two dinners so much. They were 4 stars until tonight. 

We were seated promptly and in a cozy corner. 

The bread was good and our salads perfectly dressed, as they've always been.

My boyfriend enjoyed his seafood dish quite a bit. His linguine seemed homemade.  Cooked perfectly; slippery and soaking up the sauce from his dish.

My dish was the deal breaker. Tonight I deviated and ordered Carbonara. It was separated and inedible. I sent it back, very politely, and got an explanation from our waitress about what goes into Carbonara.  I make it at home and know what goes into it.  No cream, yet it should be creamy, with proper treatment of the eggs. Not chewy pasta and a pool of oil at the bottom. The kitchen's second offering was also inedible. Pretty sure it was the same pasta drained and plated again. I took it home and paid for it without complaint. It went into the trash when we returned home.

It really took a lot for me to send the dish back. I cringe to send anything back, ever. I don't blame our waitress, but I don't need a lesson.

I just have two questions.....where have you been all our life and why has no one told us about this place before now?  

Hubby and I have been there twice now and both times had our socks literally knocked off by the food!  I am now dreaming of the fried calamari.  

Both times we started with the fried calamari, which is WAY too much for two people to finish.  It's more like an appetizer for four.  The cocktail sauce is fantastic too - I'm not usually a fan of cocktail sauce.  Salads are fresh and the homemade dressings are delicious.

For dinners we have tried the Veal Giuseppe, Veal Scorcese, Shrimp Michael and the Chicken Parm.  Hubby advised against ordering the chicken parm as it is a standard everywhere, but I went against his suggestion and got it anyway.  Even HE was surprised at how good it was!  Best chicken parm I've ever had and the portions are HUGE!  I would be happy with just a bowl of pasta and their red sauce.  The pasta is obviously not the cheap stuff served everywhere else.  It's SO good.  Hubby says it reminds him of when he was a child and his grandmother cooked all day (and THAT is quite a compliment).

It's a little pricey, probably best saved for special occasions or when you want a REALLY good meal but it's definitely worth the price.  We can't wait to go back!

I'm torn between a 3 and 4.  The food was really really good, but the service was strange and I didn't like the vibe of the place.  

I got scallops fra diavolo and it was amazing .  It wasn't on the menu, but they had shrimp fra diavolo and broiled scallops so I asked if they could make it and there was no problem.  The portion was very generous at about $22.  I could be wrong, but I do not think the pasta was made in house.  The side salad that it came with was mixed greens (I'm always happen when the salad is not iceberg)

The house merlot was blah.  I've never really had a wine that tasted like nothing, but....it happened.  

My friends enjoyed their dinners and for 3 entrees and 6 glasses of wine the tab was about $120 and everyone went home with a lot of leftovers.  

The services was weird.  There was a little chaos in getting seated when we first came in.  Then our server disappeared for a long time before taking out drink order and then an even longer time before taking our dinner orders.  She was pleasant, just absent.  

The food came out in a timely manner.  

I'll go back again so long as it stays open, with considering the state of "politics" and the owners, who knows how long that will be.

i was astounded that there were no reviews. i hope this changes soon. i don't know where to start - other than at the beginning i guess. 

brit took me out last night to celebrate the new job and as she recently moved to troy she had looked around at some places in the local paper and found an ad for lo porto's. it sounded fine so we decided to check it out.

we drove right by it on 4th as the sign isn't big and the old Proctor's was on the opposite side distracting us.  as we approached we were perhaps a bit unsure but still interested. they have some outdoor seating and several nice potted plants to separate you from the street/sidewalk.  when we entered, we first got the impression that it was very small, only 4 or 5 tables on the left and a nice, well-lit bar on the right with a big round table in the front window. 

we were greeted right away and asked if we had reservations (there were several in the book and it was only a tuesday so the question was legit). we didn't but no problem. they sat us Upstairs at a wonderful table overlooking the downstairs dining area. there were 5 or 6 tables up here and then in a back room there is room for larger parties.

our waitress was very friendly and brought us fresh crusty bread and water while we chose a lovely (primativo) red zin for dinner. we requested olive oil and holy crap. we got it. the bread dipping oil has fresh garlic, fresh ground pepper, salt, fresh basil bits and freshly grated romano. i say it again. holy crap. i wanted to bathe in it.

the fried calamari were a surprise for me, i don't usually dig them too much and only have a few (david loves them) but these were Very fresh, lightly breaded with a very tasty breading. the cocktail sauce too was surprising (i usually hate it) the horseradish was incredible and not to overuse the word, it was obviously fresh. YUM!! we ate a ton of it but as they give Huge portions we had to get the rest wrapped.

brit ordered the chicken parm - organic and free range with a side of ziti. the portion was enormous. she only was able to eat a little bit. it too was lightly breaded, the sauce was delicious and not chunky and the mozz was very tasty and not at all greasy.  i ordered the tortellini ala panna. oh my god. every single bite made me moan. the prosciutto was totally unnecessary (usually i want a piece with every bite, it is what makes the dish). the sauce was absolute perfection. oh, and the salads that preceded the dinners were with arugula and other lovely greens served with the house italian (i poured some of the dipping oil on it too. because i could not help myself.)

the deserts were also tempting and brit had a yummy canoli. i couldn't fit another bite so i just looked on smiling.

the owner also came to our table and was gracious and complimentary. we had a chance to chat with him and some of the other staff later and they were all very friendly.

the bill with the bottle of wine came to $86 but with the amount of food we had and how incredible it was i think that was a fine price. we will most definitely be going back. soon. and i may have to rethink the whole new wardrobe option.

I have only been here once but it made a major impression on me. 

It was Mother's Day and after a day of intra-family fighting, my mother decided she just wanted to have a light dinner on the deck at Brown's Brew Pub. I called to make reservations and got an answering service. However, the service listed their hours for Sunday but neglected to mention that on Mother's Day Sunday, they would not be opening.  

We get there and it's closed. In fact, so are most of the places in Troy. We drive around and find LoPorto's. They told us that they weren't normally open on Sundays but had made an exception for Mother's Day lunch/early dinner. And although they were originally scheduled to have closed 15 minutes before we showed up there, they told us to come right in and have dinner. The wait staff saved the day from being a complete disaster and turned it around completely.

I'm a little wary of italian because I'm allergic to wheat (yes, I'm "gluten-free.) The staff was very helpful and assisted me in figuring out what I could have. I ended up with a delicious scallop dish. What's especially great is that their meals come with potatoes and/or pasta (which I don't eat.) 

This place is pricey, yes, but the portions were pretty big and everything was delicious. And the restaurant itself made me feel like I was in some old mob family. Supposedly Scorcese himself is a big fan of this place too. 

To paraphrase the tagline of certain unnamed Italian chain restaurants, they really did make us feel like family here.
Great little place! Excellent food, decent price, huge portions! Can't wait to come back!!

Like Skye, this was long on our list of places to try. And finally, when we went, I tried to love it.....but it fell short of high expectations. First of all, when you walk into the bar/downstairs seating area, your olfactory senses are accosted by years of stale tobacco smoke, rather than the garlic and wine you might wish to inhale when entering a good Italian restaurant.
The upstairs seating area feels cramped and dank. The menu options are very good, so I took heart. The bread is okay, but the way salty butter is the pits, and I did not feel like troubling our busy server for olive oil. The fried calamari app is indeed gynormous, but not really great. It bothered me that when I asked for marinara instead of cocktail or tarter, our server informed us that they charge extra for it.  Hmm- their prices aren't high enough?  But it was worth it, because their marinara is good. The calamari was underdone- that is to say, the flour coating was white and limp rather than a crispy golden brown. I really missed the crunch factor. HUGE portion - 'could feed 4 for an app - but I would rather have less and better tasting.
Husband's ziti and meatballs was good and again, HUGE- but my white clam sauce inedible because the clams were way tough and impossible to chew and swallow. I do not understand why chef would not choose smaller, more tender clams - such as manila. The flavors were good and the pasta al dente. To their credit the dish was removed from our bill. That guarantees that I will not write them off.
We were too full for dessert. I do hope to return because I like the menu and many dishes going by looked superb. I think this is a place where you need to find YOUR DISH. And I sure wish that they had more windows!

business.full_address:
2501 Pearl St
Ste 101
West Campus
Austin, TX 78705
business.name: The Block On Campus

reviews.text: This place has terrible maintenance. The elevator stops working once a week, no joke. Don't even get me started about the parking garage. The spaces are extremely narrow and your car is bound to get scratched on at least once. When it rains, there is a huge puddle of water all over the floor. In the summer, the lights are off and people break into cars. It's not like the office will do much about it. They answer their phones like 30% of the time and they never get back to you if you leave a voicemail. They will only listen if you are a parent ....maybe. The elevator is always extremely dirty and gross on the weekends because no one is there to clean. However, I like how the hallway is quiet and the building isn't too high because it's not as bad to use the stairs since the elevator is always broken anyways.

I wanted to get a one bedroom apartment this year as a transfer student because I brought my dog and cat and all of my own furniture. I chose the block on 28th. The only real downfall is that you can't see your individual unit before moving in, but that's to be expected with 12 month leases by students, as your unit wont be vacated before that time. However, I thoroughly enjoy my little home at the block on 28th. The balcony ended up being bigger than I thought it would be, and gets a nice breeze and shade throughout the day. The only complaint I have is that the a/c was broken when i moved in so I had to stay in a hotel until it was fixed, but after calling in and emailing it was fixed and has been at a happy 72 degrees since. If you fill out a work request it may take a week or so at first unless its a really bad problem, and the office will call you to check up on how satisfactory the fix was. For instance if a lock is not working, you have a priority. It isn't perfect,  but its a cozy place. I love the granite countertops, and this was a big plus. Also, my unit has a remote controled fan and lighting in the living room, which I find very neat. I will say that although the internet is free, make sure you come with a router. The modem is free, definitely pick it up from TWC, because the wait to have it installed would take a few weeks, and make sure you bring a copy of your lease just in case the last resident didn't return their modem. The router is a one time buy, so its definitely worth it for wireless. The only thing I wish they would replace is the carpet in the bedrooms, perhaps with something lower pile or a hardwood floor... but its clean and looks nice so its not a big deal. Remember that college students live in these units, so stuff will always be broken on move in that no one will have noticed, but the work staff is pretty decent in fixing things.

My roommate and I currently live at the 22.5 and Pearl Block and although the location is perfect in terms of campus and being in the midst of the central hub of west campus, the building and staff are beyond unsatisfactory. 

For most of our time here the front door has been broken and at one point broken to the point where no one could get in or out. For some reason our garage is the worst lit garage (or so they say) of all the buildings, which is true if you compare our building (Pearl North) the the south building or the pearl building because those are the only ones i've been in, which makes it seem very unsafe. I know of at least 3 or 4 cars that have been broken into this year, one that has been broken into twice and parks across from me. 

The staff here is ridiculous as well. Turn in a request form and they either "don't receive" it or it takes them weeks to get around to it. When we moved in our fridge, and two lights were broken, and there was some kind of mold growing on the vents in my room. When we go and talk to them in their main office a few of the workers (mostly the girls) seem to not understand what they are doing or what we are asking them. They do not return e-mails like they say they would, and their online payment system is always malfunctioning in some way or another. 

Also over the Christmas break they were changing filters and left our front door unlocked for God knows how long, which infuriated my roommate and I because we still had valuable things in our apartment that we thought would be ok to leave here over the break. When we reported it all they had to say was "Oh, we'll let them know"

Well I'll let you know I'm happy to leave at the end of my lease.

business.full_address:
1101 Welch Rd
Ste A-8
Palo Alto, CA 94304
business.name: Kathy Lannin, MD

reviews.text: This wonderful woman literally saved my life. I had been in the Kaiser health system for more than 20 years and started having problems with abdominal pain. I ended up in the Kaiser emergency room twice, had all kinds of tests and was sent home, told it was all in my head. Had a doctor friend  [ he's at Stanford] refer me to her and to make a long story short, had surgery to remove something that turned out to be pre-cancerous. She not only figured this out relatively quickly, but was honest, straight-forward and kind beyond anything I had ever experienced from a physician. Was wonderful throughout the surgical process, insisted on the best for me when I was in the hospital and took care of me afterwards like I was her family. I've been with her some time now, and she might as well be a primary care, she cares so much about everything to do with my health. She gave me my life back by listening to me, believing what I was saying and taking action on my behalf. The best doctor you'll ever meet in your life!

Dr. Lannin is my favorite doctor on the planet!  If you're lucky enough to be able to get into her overly busy practice, she will care for you like you're her sister (who is the other doctor in her office).  If you know anything about doctors, you know that most of the offices have a high staff turnover.  Dr. Lannin's staff has been with her for over twenty years!  If that doesn't speak volumes for her character, nothing does.  And she really knows medicine.  She's up on all the latest treatments and will never prescribe medicine for you unless you need it.  She listens and really cares about your well-being.  The woman is simply off the hook as a premium care giver!  I've been going to her for almost 18 years and now my daughter is her patient too.  Nothing but the best for my family!!

Seriously, Dr. Lannin is amazing in so many ways. I highly recommend her as an obgyn and surgeon, hormone expert and therapist in disguise. I cannot imagine having anyone better to take care of my female needs.

business.full_address:
520 W. 1st St.
Claremont, CA 91711
business.name: zpizza

reviews.text: Best pizza ever! Love the organic ingredients and that they deliver!

I'm sure I will have to be changing this review to more stars in the future.  I've been here twice and liked the pizza and ambiance.  The service can be a little slow for now because of the restaurants newness factor.  

The food was good and will probably improve with time.  

Looking forward to eating late night snacks from this place with my treacherous bike rides home.

I consumed too much Mountain Dew here and shat my pants a few steps out the door after wrongfully mistaken diarrhea spray for a fart. As I ran to the bathroom and stripped myself of my soiled skinny jeans, I looked down and to my surprise, my shit looked like pure Mountain Dew. I'm not going to point any fingers here and accuse any kind of foul play, but it was a bit too coincidental for my liking. That being said, this place is great and I'd highly recommended their vegan pizza to any idiots like myself that don't be animal. I look forward to returning here again, but next time I'll be fully prepared with any extra set of trousers.

I was so excited to find out about Zpizza coming to Claremont!  I tried a gluten free pizza for the very first time.  I have to admit I really liked it and will definately have it again.  The staff was very friendly and the restaurant (and ladies room) was very clean.
Tuscan Pizza!  The best ever!  So was the Parmesan Flat bread. Trying new pizzas every time but nothing has beat the Tuscan yet.
Really nice thin crust pizza, one vegan option, very veggie friendly.

I had lunch at zpizza for the first time after a friend recommend this place and I can honestly say it is really good.  The employees are really nice and the owner is a really nice lady.  I truly recommend this place for those who want to try pizza with a different tast.

Really clean inside, nice waitress, fancy pizza options, yummy tasting. That's all there is to it, I've only been once since it's new, but I'm glad I tried it. Pizza can be boring but they sure know how to spice it up!

I came here a week ago and got the Vegan pizza with a Vegan friend of mine and it was Amazing. They put a vegan sausage on it that makes it taste just like a supreme pizza. And I must say if I didnt know it was vegan I would have thought it was a normal thin crust pizza. The prices are reasonable and the environment is like a swagged out throwback pizza joint. I loved it. Definitely going back!

I've Had Their Salads, Sandwiches, & Calzones...Oh And Finally Their Pizza.

Based On The Items I Have Eaten Here I Would Suggest You Go And Eat.

The ZBQ Salad Is Delicious!!!  ZBQ Chicken, Roasted Peppers, Red Onions, Tomatoes, Cilantro , Sweet Corn & Chipotle Ranch Dressing, You Just Gotta Try This!!!  The Dressing Is Served ON The Side But They Give You More Than Enough For Your Salad.

The Pear & Gorgonzola Salad s Refreshing And Delicious. It Has Pears, Candied Walnuts, Gorgonzola With A Balsamic Vinaigrette.

The Meatball Sandwich Was Good But I Didn't Think It Was As Good As The One I Get From The Old World Delicatesan In Upland.

The Meat Calzone Is Delicious And Is Made For 2 People.  Some People Have Eaten It By Themselves, So If You Have A Big Appetite Don't Share It.

The Veggie Calzone Is Delicious, If You Can't Stomach The Thought Of Veggies Wrapped And Baked In Bread This Isn't For You.

I Like The Pollo Latino, It Had Me At Avocado.  I Can't Get Enough Avocado In Anything!!!  Chicken Breast, Salsa And Avocado.

The Parmesan Flatbread Sticks Are Delicious, I Don't Usually Order Them But I Got Them For Free Because I Ordered A Large Salad.  They Have A Promotion Going On, Buy A Large Pizza Or Large Salad And Get A Free Order Of Flatbread.

The Mediterranean Plate, Well You ad me At Mediterranean. I'm A Sucker For Hummus.

I Had The Pizza Americano And Added Pili Pili Oil & Ref Pepper Flakes To It.  Yeah I Like My Foods Hot & Spicy When Possible.  The Pizza Is Delicious, My Son Had A Slice & Preferred Without The Extra Spice.

OK. I promise, I will try it again and maybe try something less conventional. Because last night, the over-all impression of the food, was...eh, ok. I'll head to Pizza n Such next, as usual, thanks. But hey, some places deserve at least two rounds and this is one of them. I promise, I *will* try again. 

We had a cheese pizza - my kids loved it! To impress my 9 year old son is quite a job when it comes to pizza. He likes Ledo's, the REAL one, in College Park, MD and Pizza n Such. Well, he also likes Domino's Cheese Pizza, double cheese, but he knows as well as I do, that may as well be "McPizza" (anyone actually remember that, lol?). Anyway, it was under cooked, floppy. Now I always reheat pizza in my cast iron skillet anyway, but this was a NEED, in order to get it fully done and crispy. The dough was cooked, but it was white still, under-side and the edges. And VERY little sauce. I wasn't sure there *was* sauce at first, there was so little. But once crisped up, re cooked and doused with Italian seasoning, lol, it was pretty good. I must try other types there. Maybe the gluten-free is good! I WILL find out. 

Now if any one of you follow me, you know I am a huge meatball sub fan. I consider myself a connoisseur, lol. I LOVE a good meatball sub with cheese - and have been in serious mourning since Federico's in Claremont closed, what, 25 years ago? Seriously, people. I can imagine that taste still, to this day. Sorry, I will wax nostalgic elsewhere! But I have yet to find a replacement. This is not one that even comes close. This reminded me of Subway's meatball sub. The rolls are so...prefab. And chewy - like underdone dough can be. Like par-cooked! That's' it! It was like it was par-cooked. Meh. The meatballs - too few of them, though the taste was decent, I admit. Not enough sauce either. Nope. No more meatballs there at least for me. Boo. Maybe on the pizza, since they were slices. Thinly. 

I also sampled the turkey sandwich that has cranberry sauce on it. That was good! Now the bread was still an issue, but the sauce was full of fruit, the Dijon mustard was a nice kick to the break up the sweetness of the cranberry sauce and it all went together well. But pardon me for being a snobette, but it was a SANDWICH and not particularly unique in style. In fact, Vons used to have one at their deli counter that was GREAT! This? Was good, yes. I took the stuff out of the bread and ate it separately. I'll indulge in bread - I love good bread - but I can leave the calories behind when the bread is just a way to hold ingredients together. 

The best thing was the garlic bread! Still, underdone, but the flavor was great, my kids loved it to bits and I admit to snagging a half piece...just for the sake of the review, you know. Really. Yup ;) It comes with a little cup of their red sauce - which I have to say, IS good. Just use more on the pizza, folks! I mean, sure *my* sauce is better. Ahem. But this was a good, strong flavor and the texture was thick, but not gloppy. I hate too thick or too thin sauce...this sauce was juuuuust right! I give it my Goldilocks seal of approval. 

The Greek salad...oh MY when will restaurants actually make a real Greek salad, and not Greek-inspired? Just call it Greek-inspired, people! You are giving a false impression as to what a real Greek salad is! And not just Zpizza...oh, no! Some places are better than others, but Zpizza is pretty much took inaccurate to higher level than other places that make good "Greek" salads (but still are not autherntic). This was a bunch of Spring mix greens, with some slicked up Kalamata olives, here and there...some feta...I found some, I found some! Then few slices of red onion and a balsamic vinagarette. It's not that it was a bad salad - it wasn't. But I think there should at least be more of the items that would help Greek it up a bit. Oh, some cucumbers and tomatoes, too, to be fair. 


It's just an ok pizza place. but I LOVE what they are attempting wiht the ingredients. The organics, the grass fed cows from Wisconsin, and the meats with out garbage in them and the different crust option? Excellent! But they even say, "If it doesn't crunch, it's not a pizza!" Well, I guess I didn't have a pizza then, huh, folks? Ah, well...  

I, like I said, will indeed try it again at some point...perhaps after their beer and wine license comes through ;) (it's on the way, btw, all, so sit tight!)

We ordered the gluten free California version with chicken sausage. I was 
hesitant since the California is all veggies, hence the side of chicken sausage. 
My five year old son loved it and is on his third piece as I type. The crust is 
very thin and crisp, almost cracker like consistency. Although I liked a charred 
crust, it made it hard for my son to eat, especially as he's missing two 
incisors. The taste was great, though, fresh yet the veggie flavors melded well 
together. I found it cheaper to order a large gluten free pizza and freeze the 
extras vs. buying frozen gluten free pizza from the grocery store. This will be 
a regular eatery for us.

OPENING SOON!! I am so excited about Zpizza coming to the old Claremont packing house! This is my favorite pizza. They make pizza with traditional toppings to vegan pizza and everything in between. They also have great salads and sandwiches. Cannot wait!

I originally went to Zpizza because my dining companion was looking for somewhere that made gluten-free pizza; this was the spot. The gluten-free crust was really good: we got the pizza with artichoke hearts, garlic, and a few other topics: flavorful and fresh. 

On another visit, I tried a slice of the veggie pizza, which was equally good. All in all, not the most filling slices in the world but fresh ingredients and friendly staff keep me coming back.

This is a GREAT new pizza spot!  My husband and I took a stroll through Claremont and found this jewel!  We shared the Mediterranean Plate ($7.50) and the small Greek pizza ($9.95).  It was FABULOUS!  The pizza wasnt heavy or greasy and was made with fresh ingredients!  Many of the food items are great to share because the portions are good. The service was fast and friendly!

I tried Zpizza for take-out last night. I'm not a big pizza fan but was having a casual dinner with my husband and another couple, and so decided to try it. The pizza was very, very good! We had ham and pineapple, which I didn't try, but which was completely gone by the end of the meal. We also had sausage and mushroom--only 1 piece left, and I got a wheat crust, basil pesto sauce, chicken sausage with vegetables. It was terrific!
I will definitely be back. It reminds me of when I first tried Chipotle for mexican food--the difference was notable and I could feel good about patronizing them. Now I have a place for high quality pizza that is reasonable priced. Thank you Zpizza!
Best pizza ever. The Pear & Gorgonzola pizza is one of my favorite along with others.

business.full_address:
540 W Baseline Rd
Ste 15
Claremont, CA 91711
business.name: Smith and Bellows Dental Practice

reviews.text: I have been going to Smith and Bellows for the last few years now and I have to say they have been the most professional and up to date office I have ever had my dentistry done. Not only do they have a fantastic staff who are attentive and great at what they do, but they use all the latest technology as well! I can see my pictures and X-Rays immediately on a computer screen! Thats awesome!!  I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS OFFICE! Also I had taken my son to two different dentists to have a 2 teeth removed for his orthodonist. These two other Dentists could not remove the teeth and told me the roots were too long. To have Oral Surgery. Dr. Smith had them both out within 20 minutes and my son said he didnt feel any pain.. Thanks Dr. Smith!!

Dr. Brian Smith is an amazing dentist.  He has a great chair side manor and is very gentle.  I had my first Root Canal today and was scared to death.  He did a great job with nearly no pain at all.  He also followed up a couple hours later to make sure I was ok.  

His office staff is equally professional, they are always happy and laughing and make you feel right at home.  I wouldn't go anywhere else.  I live in Redlands and drive 40 minutes to get to his office.  To me it's hard to find a great dentist and one that you can trust. 

Dr. Smith also treats my son and has for a couple years now.  My son really likes him as well and that is important.

I highly recommend Dr. Smith and his staff..

Do not use this dentist. 
Twice work he performed very quickly failed and had to be redone. 
Once he billed again for the correction work on his failed work. 
Twice he billed in excess of written estimates. 
Numerous billings errors took months to correct. 
Some billing errors were never corrected. 
He sued me in small claims court instead of making billing corrections. 
He raises his rates without notification. 
He misrepresented that he was a preferred provider under our insurance. 
He's not very good at administering pain medications.

business.full_address:
1035 Mt. Carmel Church Rd
Chapel Hill, NC 27517
business.name: Bill Hester Fine Art

reviews.text: This gallery adds high level of culture to the community with the pieces that are brought in.  They awaken your appreciation for the arts, breathe art life into those who may not necessarily care for the arts.  You'll find paintings, metal pieces, busts and many other items to beautify your home or office.  Two of the artist they are currently featuring are Arlene LaDell Hayes (painter) and Walter Horak (metal artist).  The owner is exceptionally wonderful and a joy to chat with about the artists he features and many other events taking place in the area.

This place is... not so much.  It's an art gallery, so it contains art.  Some of the art is quite good.  That's the best I can say for it.  If you're looking for some really fine art, this is the place to come in the area.  Hear that?  Right here!  Art!

On the other hand, the prices are ridiculous.  Can people around here pay $24,000 for a painting?  If so, I'd like to meet them.  Perhaps they can pay me that much, and I will spent months to LEARN to paint, then paint a piece to their exact specifications.  Sound good?

The staff was not very friendly to me, which is to say that the man working did not acknowledge my presence as I browsed.  I feel like that's kind of a no-no.

business.full_address:
9 Jfk St
Harvard Square
Cambridge, MA 02138
business.name: Penti

reviews.text:
I was looking for some fun, unique white hosiery to wear under my wedding dress and being new to Boston, didn't know where to go.  I ended up at Forty Winks down the street in Cambridge, and while they have lovely lingerie there wasn't much of a selection of stockings.

As I was shuffling back towards the Harvard Street T station I spied through the construction on JFK a storefront showcasing hosiery and tights galore. Bingo!  

Penti has a small selection of bras, undies, kids tights, and mens socks, but where they really shine is women's hosiery.  When I was there I spotted basic cold weather tights, sexy fishnets and lacy stockings, and funky fashion forward leggings and tights in lots of different colors and patterns.  I practiced some restraint and limited myself to two pairs, but I was really pleased with the selection and could have dropped a pretty penny in there.  The prices are reasonable, about what you would pay in a department store.  Note that Penti is a Turkish brand of hosiery, so you won't see other brands (Hue and so on) in this store.

The store is staffed by some very kind ladies who are happy to help if needed, but otherwise will leave you alone if you would like to browse in peace.  I'll definitely be back to stock up on some basics once the temperatures dip!

Penti is the ultimate source for tights in Boston. As Lisa P. says in her review, they have a huge selection of beautiful leggings--I even saw some for pregnant ladies! A saleswoman will be happy to fill you in on things like weave and sizing (they use a European system). Prices for a pair of tights start around $16 and go to about $34.

A couple minor reservations: The tights are mostly synthetic, so if you're looking for cotton, you have fewer choices. Also, the sheer number of leggings in the store completely overwhelmed me, so I wound up running away without buying anything! I will be back with a more focused shopping list.

business.full_address:
782 Higuera St
San Luis Obispo, CA 93401
business.name: Creeky Tiki Bar & Island Grill

reviews.text:
There was an interesting crowd at this bar on a Friday afternoon. There were families, college kids, old men... and to top it all off, there was tacky tiki decor. 

Despite all that, the drinks were good, and the bartender was friendly. He struck up a conversation with us four girls. We had several of those margarita drinks with a trio of citrus: lemons, lime, oranges. The citrus-ness helped cut down the sweetness of the usual margarita. They were also only $4 each!

came to SLO for the first time with diana c. on our roadtrip back from santa barbara beach camping and stopped here for lunch. i know this is going to sound weird, but i LOVE their bathrooms. i can't speak for the men's room, but the women's restroom is painted blue and filled with handwritten quotes. i may or may not have spent a good amount of time in the restroom just reading them.

the food was a-ok, just like the review says. i got nachos because, i always get nachos and i picked off the best parts and left a lot of chips - also like i always do. :P we got to sit outdoors and because we were one of only two groups of people due to the time of day, we got waited on very efficiently and the servers were exceptionally friendly, not to mention cute :)

The Creeky has reasonably priced food, and the service has been great to me on all the visits I can remember.  The drink prices are all comparable to other bars in the vicinity.  The Chicken Sicilian Pizza, a cold beer, and creekside seating during the day are a good combo try!  Also, there's a fabulous drink special I only tell my friends about.   Sorry readers this one has to stay under cover, otherwise the price will likely climb and it won't be so special.

The Creeky Tiki Bar & Grill (attached to the Creeky Tiki Restaurant, sharing the same awesome patio) just opened the week of Thanksgiving!  This place is fantastic!  It has amazing glass front doors and windows that look out on Higuera Street, so it's a great place to go people watch or meet up with friends.  The bar also has any drink you could imagine....the drink options they offer are endless!  The bar has a caribbean, beachy feel inside and is very relaxed and chill...everyone working there seemed really friendly, professional, and attentive to our needs.  We went in there a couple nights ago and the place was PACKED!  I think it's definitely going to become a major hotspot on the SLO scene :) 

We tried the pizza and it was amazing.....great sauce, just enough spiciness!  We also had the sweet potato fries, which are always a favorite.  Overall we had a great time just eating and people watching there, and are looking forward to all this place will have in store.  It looks like they're going to have specials every night from 7 PM - close (in addition to their daily Happy Hour specials), so I'm sure we'll be going back to take advantage of those!  This is definitely a place we're going to hit every time we're in town.

Beware of the Happiest Happy Hour

Stopped in to the Creeky Tiki last night, hadn't been there since right after they opened.  They offer the "Happiest" of happy hours, including $3 drafts.   My friend and I both ordered draft beer, even from the same brewery.  I ordered Union Jack, she ordered 805.  When the bill came, my beer was somehow $6 while hers was $3.  No where on the menu, or in our discussions with the waitress was a distinction ever mentioned.  It wasn't the money, it was the principle.

My husband, son and I ate here for the second time today and I must say the service is not good at all and takes away from the positives of the restaurant, hence the two stars. 

Our first visit was at 5PM on a week night two weeks after they opened. The service wasn't great but I just let it go since they were still trying to find their groove due to being new. I ordered a mushroom veggie burger, and the patty is basically made of black beans and mushrooms....a huge disappointment since the menu doesn't give a description or warning. If I would have known I wouldn't have ordered the burger. I typically order veggie burgers when I eat out and I would have to say their burger wasn't good and the taste was very odd. My son ordered chicken strips and fries. The chicken was DRY and had a hint of fish taste, I can only assume fish was fried in the same fryer prior to the chicken? The fries were excellent and they were definitely the highlight of the meal. 

Our second visit (today) was really not a a good experience as far as service goes. We arrived for a late lunch around 2:30. Since it is a seat yourself establishment we sat at one of the 2 available tables toward the front of the restaurant. 10 minutes after we arrived another family walked in and sat at the table next to us...they were waited on immediately while we just sat and hoped someone would notice we were sitting there with no drinks or food. A few minutes later a man (who didn't look like a server) walked over and asked if we had been helped. My husband asked if they had Stella on tap and he said no and named the beers they have on tap, in addition to saying we have a whole bunch of bottle beers so go over to the bar and take a look at what we have. Have they ever heard of a beer list??? I ordered a Belvedere and 7-up, to my surprise they do not have belvedere so I went with Kettle One. After a very LONG wait he walked back to the table with my son's soda and husband's beer, um were was my drink? Oh I'm sorry he said but I forgot what you ordered. Terrible! He returned with my drink and a young lady came out and we ordered our food. 

While we waited for our food we had the pleasure (or not) of watching and listening to the most obnoxious drunk I have ever witnessed. I was actually embarrassed for him for being so drunk and loud and for the bar tender that continued to serve him while he was offending the other customers in the restaurant. 

When our food arrived our server brought out my garden salad (no dressing or fork), margarita pizza, in addition to my husband and son's french fries (no hamburger). I understand she only has two hands and can only carry so much at one time, but the amount of time we had to wait for the remainder of our order was ridiculous. I didn't want to start eating my pizza until the guys got their burgers so by the time the burgers came out my pizza was cold and I couldn't eat my salad because I didn't have a fork or salad dressing. 

The food was actually very good! I can honestly say when we finally had the chance to eat we couldn't complain about the quality. However, I will think twice about returning because the service was extremely poor.

As it's name suggests, this bar and grill is situated on the San Luis Obispo Creek and offers up some delicious island fare. One of Creeky Tiki's big selling points is cheap drinks for those boozing on a budget. An ice-cold pina colada, margarita or long island will cost you only $3.50 a pop during Happy Hour (3-7p.m. Monday - Friday). 

Sample the endless flavor of their signature SLO fish tacos ($6.95) made with pan-seared mahi mahi, shredded cabbage, cilantro and a house-made creamy cilantro sauce (served with lime wedges and a side of black beans) or indulge in one of their beloved burgers. I had the burly Sunset Burger, which comes with bacon, onion rings, cheddar cheese and a killer BBQ sauce ($6.75). We also threw in a cheese pizza and a basket of sweet potato fries for only $3.50 each. All this food, along with a couple of refreshing pina coladas, came to $35.00 (tip included). 

Creeky Tiki offers a nice array of menu items. Gourmet salads (salmon, raspberry, seared scallop, cobb, ceasar), seafood items (coconut shrimp, crab cakes, fish and chips and fish tacos), burgers, sandwiches, pizzas, sides and more. 

They have specials every night of the week, including Tiki Twosdays -- $2 tacos, pizzas, 2 for 1 well drinks and drafts. Head to Creeky's if you're looking to score some great food and drink specials.

I came here twice and both times it was loud and annoying to be inside. The bartending staff is obviously new. It looks like they hired the prettiest girls willing to work here, and didn't care if they knew how to tend the bar correctly. The food is the same food they had at the old Creeky Tiki, back in the Network, which was average at best. I get that they're trying to be a cheesy sports bar, but it doesn't have to be so cliche. The whole island theme just seems so 1985 to me. I would recommend Firestone's for a better place to grab a drink and watch a game.
wasn't good before.... isn't good now. Blew their wad on decorations and nothing on training staff or food quality.

This is my new favorite hangout downtown! Not only is the atmosphere fun, relaxing, and friendly, the food is extra tasty. I went to the Tiki on football Sunday and will be coming back for every football event. There are 6 TV's around the bar/lounge so you can see the games from any seat. 
 The decor is fabulous featuring original surf posters, brilliant artwork (seriously incredible), surboards, and real tiki men. It backs up to the downtown creek which is beautiful to lounge and socialize by. There is also an outside tiki bar that allows easy access to drinks while hanging outside enjoying the fresh air.  The staff definitely knows their stuff providing great service and the bartenders make killer signiture drinks.
 The menu is very affordable and every night there is a unique happy hour. On some evenings the customers par-take in determining what the happy hour will be, which is pretty fun. So far I've had the mushroom veggie burger that was full of flavor, jerk chicken and sweet potato fries that I easily could have had seconds of, veggie pizza, and clam chowder, yummy.  This place just opened so I cant wait to see where they are down the road!!

So my wife and I are showing my Dad the sights in SLO. We come upon the Creeky Tiki and since my wife and I haven't tried this establishment yet, we decide to chance it. 

The bar had a few empty seats left, but we had our choice of tables so we sat right away. The server greeted us in pretty short order and informed us he had someone he was training that evening. We've all been the "new guy/girl" so we joked with her to put her at ease. 

The lead guy took our drink orders and she came back with them right away. My dad's a "wine guy" and he commented that the red wine hadn't been "aerated". Hmmm. Ok. My beer was good and cold as was my wifes water. For dinner I opted for the SLO Fish Tacos. I've had fish tacos all over the county and I would put these at a 7. The tasty salsa that came with them was a bit spicy for me (I'm a wuss when it comes to that anyway so...) but very good none the less. My wife had the Chicken Pesto sandwich and the only complaint she has was the bread was a little tough due to the toasting of it. Other than that she compared it to the ones she's had at Lombardi's in Cambria and that's saying something. My dad had the fish and chips and, since our area is fairly well known for it's seafood, his expectations were rightfully high. Well the fish came out and looked like it was a step above the Fillet o Fish Patties. Dad's review reflected the same. Chewy. 

By the time we were ready for the check the place had filled up and the wait staff was busy so it took a little while but eventually we got it. Other than the issues mentioned previously we had a decent experience. Overall I'd say come by and have a drink, some laughs, but the food could use a little help.

First visit = 2 stars. I went here with my wife and a friend for a late lunch on a weekday. The service was average but the food disappointing. I ordered the fish and chips and my wife ordered the crab cakes entree. The fish and chips were OK. However, my wife was really disappointed with the crab cakes. The menu describes the crab cakes as "three large carribean-spiced crab cakes." However, they were about the size of a chips a hoy cookie. They were more like what you would expect to get as an appetizer, not an entree. So my wife left very disappointed. 

Second visit = zero stars. We thought the price was OK so we decided to give the Creeky Tiki another try. We returned on a Thursday night, which is farmer's market night. Understandably, they were busy, but we were completely ignored by the staff. We stood just inside the entrance for a few minutes waiting to be seated. As we waited and waited, it grew more awkard just standing there. Other patrons lined up behind us, equally dumbfounded. Several of the wait staff made eye contact with us but never indicated that someone would assist us. We would have seated ourselves but the only open seats had not yet been cleared. After about ten minutes of trying and failing to get someone to acknowledge us, we left and ate somewhere else. Really frustrating.

Does a Creeky Tiki make creaking noises?

Apparently not... It's just a beach-themed restaurant located next to a creek. (According to other Yelp reviews, that is.)

Came here on my way down to Santa Barbara.

Fish Tacos. Ahi tuna with lettuce, cilantro, guacamole and lime wrapped in a flour tortilla. Reminded me of the sisig tacos from yummy food trucks in SF that I'm so very fond of. LOVES! They were really yummy though, I would come back all the way from NorCal just for these if those food trucks didn't exist, but maybe the next time I'm on my way to Santa Barbara.

Kitchen Sink Pizza. Small Pizza with Pepperoni, Sausage, Onions, Peppers, Mushrooms and Olives. YUMS! One of the best pizzas I've ever had! The toppings were super fresh and really yummy. Too bad I was so full, otherwise I would have eaten another slice. I want to try another one of their pizzas!

Mushroom Veggie Burger. My sis ordered this but I had a bite of the patty. It was pretty good, tasted like a homemade patty and not one of those frozen ones you get at the store. It actually tasted a bit like a potato cake too, but I don't know if my taste buds were being weird since I just had a tiny bit of it.

Tiki Burger. House beef burger. My dad ordered this so I had a tiny bite of it as well. The beef patty was pretty good, a little on the dry side though but I could easily tell that it was charcoal grilled because it had that distinct fragrance of charcoal on it. I wish there was a choice to have it grilled to medium rather than well done because it would have made for a juicier more fragrant burger, but I do understand that it could have been a health standard issue. Sadly though I must admit that I have had not necessarily better tasting but juicier burgers. 

See photos of food, http://potbellypanda.tumblr.com

We stopped on a Sunday afternoon to watch the game and grab some lunch. I was immediately impressed with the ambience of the place. A relaxed atmosphere with six TVs positioned around the bar.  It was the opening week of the new location and someone I assume was the owner was going around making sure everyone was happy.

 I ordered the ahi tacos and my wife ordered the cheeseburger. We decided to share an order of fries. While waiting for our food, we watched SLO from our table while six games played at once. Now this is nirvana!

 ... which is a good thing because it took forever for our food to come. We were very easy going about it and didn't complain. Our waitress came up to us twice to apologize and assure us our food was coming. I  didn't mind because it was  the second day it had been open and the bugs were still being worked out. Besides, like I said, it's a great place to hang out.

 When our food did come, I was immediately disappointed in my fish tacos. We're talking two flour tortillas with a very small amount of ahi, guacamole and cilantro. I ate both in minutes and was still hungry.  Not worth the price. The cheeseburger was good but the fries were undercooked. All in all, a so so experience.

 I'll cut them slack for still working the kinks out. We'll give them another try soon.

I ran across this cute little place one day i was with a friend of mine. We just needed a place to sit and chill and enjoy the day. We went to the patio area it was such a nice day, sun was shining. It was so nice out back sitting overlooking the creek. It was calming. Our waiter was a really nice guy as well. He came and checked on us pretty often to make sure we didn't need anything. The food was great. The other people there seemed to enjoy themselves as well. We even had a nice little chat with the ladies sitting next to us. They wanted to know what we had ordered. They wanted the same thing. They have a nice size bar also. Plenty of space to sit inside and out. Guys were at the bar hanging out watching a game. The place is also really clean, that was a plus for me. I would definitely go again!
The food is horrible.  The service was really slow!  Bring back Cisco's by the creek.  Beware to parents, only one high chair.

Food is ok, steak nachos were not what we expected at all. Happy hour has great prices on beer and "marquezaritas", atmosphere is nice with a view of the mission and creek. Service was slow but we were here on a farmers market night. I'd love to go back for drinks, but not for food.

The server was nice. The grilled cheese my daughter ordered was the worst grilled cheese I have ever had. It was like two pieces of dry toast with one piece of that dry toast that had the one slice of cheese on it had been melted under the salamander untill the cheese was void of any moisture. Not sure if that made any sense, but it was awful none the less.

After drinking in the SLO wineries all day long, this was a great stop to just chill out at and keep drinking. Wasn't sure how well Cadillac margaritas would mix with all the wine I had been consuming all day, but surprisingly it went well. The drinks were good, I was only drinking Cadillacs so I have no idea how well made their other drinks are. 

The staff was friendly, and I never waited too long for a drink. The atmosphere is great, plenty of room and tables inside, and a large patio overlooking the creek in the back outside with another bar. They had live music too which was great; I always enjoy that. It's also fun to watch all the Cal Poly kids drink and fall off the stools.

Fun atmosphere and decent food. The service was a bit on the slow side but my friend and I didn't mind because we weren't really in a rush. Its not very organized so I can see why some have had issues with service, especially on a busy night like Farmers. But for us, our order was taken and our food was brought out relatively fast. They forgot my order of sweet potato fries but they apologized and brought it out soon after and thank god because it was delicious. My raspberry salad was 8 out of 10 ten stars.
Those MARQUEZARITAS, SLOBONGOS and SHOTSKI'S sure are special!!!!!!!!!

I love the vibe of this bar and the happy hour beer specials. I have ate here twice now and the food was not good at all. I ordered the fish tacos and it was like they had a can of albacore tuna in the back and used that! My little brother can make better tacos then that! My friend ordered the pesto sandwich and he said it was really dry! So if your looking for a place with just good drink specials and good looking girls...go here :) but skip dinner and appetizers!
So so food, slow, but nice patio in the back... No restrooms available?

Good happy hour, always okay when drinks are cheap.  The food is okay, i liked the nachos, except we asked for no sour cream and had to send them back once (after it took forever to get them) because there was a sheet of sour cream covering the top.  
The next time I was here, I ordered fish and chips expecting some delicious fish fried up next to my fries.  What came out was an extreme embarrassment to fish.  It was tiny little shapes of fish which obviously came out of a freezer.  I expect being so close to the coast, they could make some descent fish and chips.  The fries were just okay, obviously frozen as well.  It was a much to small serving, at least if they're going to feed you that crap they should give you enough to fill you up.
Obviously a place for the college crowd.  But if you want anything besides good happy hour, I'd go elsewhere for some edible food.
Not open when they say they are, closed before 11 when they said they were open until Midnight

I visited Creeky Tiki this evening with some friends. It was pretty crowded, but I expected this since since SLO Farmer's Market was in full swing and there was some sort of wine festival at the Mission. 

The prices are pretty typical for a bar/grill joint, just under $10 for a decent size burger [avocado bacon cheese burger] and a basket of seasoned fries. The fries were pretty good. The burger wasn't bad, but it certainly left something to be desired...

The burger showed up astonishingly quick. The meat was a little dry and the veggies (tomatoes and lettuce) seemed sorta cheap. I have a sneaking suspicion the patty had been grilled long before we arrived/ordered and had been waiting under a heat lamp or something. It sorta reminded me of the frozen patties you buy at Costco and use for a company BBQ.

So the food was average, but the atmosphere is really nice. It was a little noisy, but that's expected for this sort of place. The patio area is large with lots of seating and a nice view of the Mission and the "SLO riverwalk." They have a bunch of those gas heaters which make it pleasant even on a cold evening. There are several bars, including one out on the patio--never waited long for drinks even though there seemed like a lot of people.

All in all, I'd recommend this place for its atmosphere if not its food.

I love the creeky tiki! This is by far one of my new fav places downtown. They have friendly staff, good service and great drinks & grub! 

They have a theme for every night with drink and food specials & entertainment (7-10pm). 
Maholo Mondays
Tiki Tuesdays
Wine Down Wednesdays
Country/Classic Rock Thursdays
Freaky Tiki Fridays
8 Trax Saturdays
Industry & Salon Sunday Nights

& Build your own Saturday & Sunday Breakfast (burritos and bloody mary's)

With so much happening, its fun every night!

Beastly Burrito, so much so it couldn't be wrapped.
Beautiful Seating.
Arcade Machine in the back.
Umm how many bars?

It's a cool new bar to the main drag of SLO.  Good atmosphere, nicely poured drinks and very reasonably priced!  They have a huge wheel on the wall, kind of like wheel of fortune, that has price specials for that hour.  Entertaining.

Popped in here on a Friday evening. It's like being on a Carnival Cruise Ship after a late sail from Mexico. Lots of middle aged drunk honkies in brightly coloured clothing, singing or stumbling around while clutching an exotic beverage.

I fit right in.

I had the best time at the Creeky Tiki Friday night. Brad and the staff went out of their way to make sure we had a good time. We got there around 6:00 pm and the outdoor seating was full. They actually moved a table outside for us so we could enjoy the music and good weather. The margaritas were delicious. We ordered them by the pitcher. The pizza was really good too! I didn't try the nachos, but I saw other people eating them and they looked amazing... I'm definitely ordering nachos next time! 

I've always gone to Frog and Peach when I want to go to a casual downtown bar. I'm so glad I found a friendlier and cleaner downtown bar. I'm sure we will be back often!

This place automatically gets a thumbs up for being a tiki bar because I'm obsessed with them! I hit them up wherever I travel. The decor is super cool and love the surfboards that are on the wall. I really also liked that they had TVs to watch sports (although they are a little high and gave me a crick in my neck). 

However, what I did not enjoy was the customer service. The bartenders were not very attentive and sincerely did not seem like they enjoyed their jobs. I felt like I was putting them out whenever I asked for a drink. 

The only thing we ordered to eat was french fries and they were decent.

Had lunch on the outdoor patio facing the creek. They had a great local jazz band playing. Had the veggie burger with fries! The best.
Service was good.
Recommend for lunch .

Have you ever had one of those restaurant experiences that was just so bad that you're scared to come back to see if they've improved? Well Creeky Tiki was that experience for me. I went here a while ago with a large group of family and friends. It was a Sunday, so it wasn't very busy, yet it took almost 20 minutes to get drinks and even longer for us to order our food! When we finally did get to order, our food also took a ridiculous amount of time to make it to our tables, and when it did, half of our orders we wrong (twice). (If you don't have any spanish rice made, don't think that it is safe to assume that cilantro-lime would be ok!) Now I wouldn't have minded if maybe one or two orders were wrong, but we're talking about 6 mistakes! Not to mention, my vegetarian friend was served a burrito with meat in it. AND the food wasn't even that good. I'm going to try to muster up the courage to come back but I just hope that my money won't go to waste. Two stars because the atmosphere was cool and I like the whole vibe of the place.
Slooooooow service and mediocre food. I'd pass on this place unless you just get drinks and enjoy waiting forever to flag down your waiter/bartender.

Food is surprisingly good (didn't expect much from a Tiki Bar) even if they don't offer much in the way of "island" fare. The drink s were a bit high, even at happy hour, but it's also likely a high-rent area. The place was clean, service was good and we had a great view of the active street. All-in-all this one makes the list of places to return to.

business.full_address:
Amherst College
11 Barrett Hill Rd
Amherst, MA 01002
business.name: Amherst College Museum of Natural History

reviews.text:
Sheer terror.  That was the feeling I always associated with my childhood visits to the Amherst College Museum of Natural History.  Enormous skeletons of mastodons and saber-tooth tigers, gigantic fossils of brutish-looking fish creatures, and the faint smell of death that hung about the old building all worked together to strike fear in my little heart.  And then there were these tiny, sinister-looking ceiling fans buzzing around the whole place, imminently ready to descend and cut me to pieces--ironically, these bothered me most of all.

These visits formed such a deep impression that I did not return until almost two decades later, when a friend needed to turn in a final lab report for a geology class at Amherst.  There I was astounded to find all my old nemeses disarmed of their former powers and housed in a gorgeous new building alongside oodles of geological specimens, all accompanied by informative labels.  I think being literate and about three feet taller made a huge difference here. If you are a child in the area who is not easily frightened and enjoys encountering the remains of massive, fearsome creatures, I highly recommend you ask the tall person (or people) you know best to take you here.

The museum is three levels. The mineralogy and meteorite collections are behind some doors, so don't miss those. 

Some impressive dinosaur bones, including a triceratops skull, a tyrannosaurus skull, and a dunkleostreus (monster fish) skull. 

They also have some meteorites, including the Canyon Diablo meteorite from Arizona. And they have an impressive collection of minerals.  

The museum also has some informational panels that describe things such as what the Pioneer Valley looked like when it was covered with glaciers. This was very interesting. I learned a lot here. I'm glad they did this.

I would have liked more information about the fossils though. There were some large fossils hanging on the wall, and I had no idea what they were. But they do have a fossil room. You might find more information there.

The museum is on Barrett Hill Road which runs parallel to Route 9. They're closed on Mondays. On most days they close at 4 PM, so get there early.

My daughter is a camp counselor K-1 for the town of Amherst. In fact she grew up going to the former Pratt History Museum on campus. She knows the collection very well.  She recently brought her group of 19 kids to the Museum. She gave it such high reviews I had to post it. 

The tour guide was so informative, and age appropriate, keeping all 19 children actively engaged. The space is of course amazing. All of the children had a wonderful experience and want to go back. 

Many thanks to Amherst College for making such a wonderful resource available to the public. You have done much to inspire young minds.

business.full_address:
1012 Amsterdam Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Suds Laundromat

reviews.text:
Start by saying that I come from a country where you almost always have a laundry machine in your apartment, even if you rent. So I'll never be happy having to lug my dirty clothes beyond the kitchen. And the front loading European machines really work their magic and take time to do so. Laundromat machines always seem fast and never seem to really clean your clothes so I'm probably never going to give more than 3/5 stars because I'm never satisfied.
Having said that, I deduct at least one star from suds because:

1) They screwed up a service wash once which left ink on my clothes. They claimed I'd left a pen in my clothes but that wasn't true. They were nice about it and did offer to help remove the stains.

2) Recently cleaning my whites by myself I found tiny black spots all over them. The black spots must have come from the washing machine. They have never come out even with subsequent washes and I think it looks like an oily substance. The lady told me it was because I didn't clean the drier filter but I don't know what black oil has to do with filters. 

It can get crazy busy and there are not enough driers for washing machines so tension often mounts. 

The staff are nice and helpful, and the place is clean. The equipment is fairly modern.

I still use suds because it's my closest laundromat and until I hit it rich and buy my loft I just have to deal with it.

Bad, bad, bad. Not only is management unprofessional but their machines don't leave your clothes smelling or feeling clean. I had to run the dryer for 75 minutes on high vac to get them dry, seriously? Because I had clothing that needed to be dry cleaned, I asked if they could be delivered, and the women at the front said yes.  I was charged an additional fee for one hour service and delivery was at no additional charge ....6 hours later no deliver. I called asking when my clothing would be ready. Not only did it take 10 minutes to communicate the problem to the non-english speaking attendant, I was then told there is no delivery on weekends and that I needed to pick it up myself.
 
I strongly urge you to take your business somewhere else and avoid this place all together.

Busy fast laundramat what do you expect. It's not going to entertain you unless you like mexican soap operas. Univsion available. 

$2 for wash 25 cents for 8 minute dry. last wash on weekdays at 7:30 so unless you want to get hassled arrive before

I will get my positive biases out of the way.  Suds is a thirty second walk from my apartment and it is located next to a really decent coffee shop.

The price was fine, and I took care of more than a week's worth of laundry for $4.50.  The dryers were fair @ 42 minutes, but the condition of all of the equipment seemed superb.

There was a serious lack of seats for waiting, but it seemed like the other users felt comfortable to step away next door for coffee without worry.

Management is nice, and they offer full laundry service too.

business.full_address:
1566 Win Hentschel Blvd
West Lafayette, IN 47906
business.name: Route 66 Diner

reviews.text: Terrible. Put our name on the list and they started skipping around on the list and skipped over us.
One of my favorite places to eat :)

It was my first time at the Diner, along with the whole fam...
We should of  had "Breakfast"..Good waiter and great tasty yummie shakes for the kids!! I will go back for breakfast  next time! "Oh my wife won't let me eat at the other place  (xxx)  ha ha."

The Route 66 diner is the "G-rated" cousin of it's sister diner, The "Triple XXX" on the campus of beautiful Purdue University in West Lafayette, IN. Don't get me wrong. Both Route 66 and Triple XXX are family establishments (not strip clubs) and you will likely have a great experience at either location. The difference is the regular clientele. 

The menu at both the Triple XXX and Route 66 are similar if not identical. The lunch/dinner food is fine, but if you're going to either location for the first time, you should be going for breakfast regardless of the time of day.  For mostly sentimental reasons, I highly recommend the Drew Brees Favorite (2 eggs, 1/3 lb. burger, potatoes covered with sausage gravy & 2 grilled buttermilk biscuits W/ jelly). 

Back to the clientele:

As you might imagine, the Triple XXX has a strong following among the local university students, and the atmosphere reflects that. It's fun and at times extremely entertaining if that's what you're looking for, but if Granny is in town to watch her baby girl walk for graduation, you're likely better off taking her to Route 66 for a more family friendly atmosphere. 

Let's just say that people don't get arrested for public intox after falling off of their stool and through the plate glass window at Route 66, where this might be a more probable occurrence at Triple XXX. 

Again, both establishments are great, just pick your location with the desired experience in mind.
was 'ok'. just dont get the waffles or pancakes, they are routinely over done. While not quite burnt, i do not think pancakes should have a crunchy crust,

My friends and I were in town for a wedding over this past weekend and we just happened to fall in to this cute little diner tucked away in a strip mall!  Like most hometown diners, the decor (and clientel) scream "wholesome plain-jane country"...assorted knick-knacks, the required amount of junky memorabilia related to Route 66. This is the type of place  you expect to find exactly what you expect: pancakes all day, hamburgers and fries, nothing particularly "special".

Except for the part where they serve PEANUT BUTTER HAMBURGERS. Yes, you read that right. Peanut butter. On a hamburger.

Now, I confess I am adventurous, but pb on a burger?  Being the macho foodie that I am, I instantly decided we must try it so we could see just how bad this idea was.  We ordered and I proceeded to watch with gleeful horror as the cook pulled out this industrial size can of JIF (one of the sugariest, crappiest peanut butters out there) and adds it to the mix on the grill. We got the burgers (on plain ol' grocery-store sesame buns) and were fully ready to blast the heck out of this joint...when a miracle occurred. Yes, that burger was in fact a miracle. Somewhere along the way, the Jif had turned into pure magic and light, and my meal was now amazing. Holy crap. 

So, while on the whole this place remains an average hometown diner - certainly wouldn't drive two hours for it alone - if I am back this way, I will be honored to take on the PBB once more :)

Good, friendly, quick service.  Have had about half of the breakfast menu so far and the biscuits and gravy along with the Albuquerque omelet are my favorites. Wife loves the biscuits with jam.  One of only a few non-chain restaurants in town and by far my favorite of any breakfast place.

Route 66 (and the same-owner Triple XXX on campus) is a Lafayette/West Lafayette institution, even featured on Food Network.

My wife and I have been to '66 numerous times - usually for lunch/dinner food, but a few times for breakfast as well.  

The food's always good.  We usually get burgers, and they've got an interesting assortment, including one with peanut butter on it - which is surprisingly popular.  Of course, you can also just build a burger any way you like in true diner fashion.

Basically, it's old-school "American diner" type stuff; good enough, but not "super awesome."

Personally, I think it would be cool if they advertised "... with locally made D&R Market bacon" instead of "... with OSCAR MAYER bacon."  Local is better than hardcore-mass-produced, every day of the week, in my book.  Ditto if they used local meat, hand-cut potatoes for fries, and so on.

But, they're obviously doing something right to be such an institution in the area.  The food IS good, it's just not "awesome" - and the ingredients used are very industrial/mass-produced.
A little piece of "The Mother Road" in Indiana! We've eaten here a couple of times after returning from an Illinois Route 66 trip and have enjoyed the decor and food.

Even though this place is suppose to be just as good as XXX in my opinion the food in here doesn't taste as good as in there. It's good enough and they have some more items on the menu so it's worth a visit to try something different or if you don't want

business.full_address:
116 E Liberty St
Downtown Ann Arbor
Ann Arbor, MI 48104
business.name: Cupcake Station

reviews.text:
