Very rarely does anything bakery related open in the Ann Arbor area without my knowledge - my spidey sense for all things sweet is impeccable - so when I saw Cupcake Station across the street from Kilwins I was taken aback.  I knew I was in for something at least mildly interesting!

While the cupcakes here are a little bit pricey (makes sense - they're a specialty shop) all the ones I've tried so far have been moist & scrumptious.  Good frosting to cupcake ratio.  There are some inventive varieties too: I strongly suggest the german chocolate.  I try to stop by for a little treat whenever I'm in that part of downtown.

Credit card minimum of $5, so if you want just one then bring cash.

the raspberry cupcake with cream cheese frosting and angel cake is amazing! the mocha chocolate is also great for coffee/dark chocolate lovers like yours truly. got lucky today with a fresh batch that just came out. i've had dry/stale cupcakes from here before presumably that have been sitting out for too long. 

the good: 2 for 1 cupcakes from march 15-21!!! double your waistline for half the $$$.  i stumbled upon this deal coming here to buy cupcakes for a friends bday. 

the bad: they got rid of their 4-pack so that they can sell more 6-packs. annoying. 

can't give this place 5 stars, which is reserved for the likes of sprinkles cupcakes in LA and sugar sweet sunshine in NY, but for ann arbor cupcake station will be my station for cupcakes.  (wayyyy better than that fancy foodnetwork place cake nouveau's cupcakes.)
Tuesdays are the day to get your cheap cupcake fix - $2 regulars and $1 minis! You can't beat the cupcake station for a quick and delicious fix for your sweet tooth!

Y-U-M
I bought a half dozen on Sunday and they are already gone. Consistently, the cake was perfectly moist and the buttercream whip (?) frosting was a nice sweetness. My favorite tho was the waffle cone. Followed closely by the vegan chocolate w/vanilla frosting. If I'm in town again, I'd definitely get a full dozen to take home.

Got hooked on this place awhile ago.  Now, every time im in Ann Arbor, I go.  I got there for $2 Tuesday and bought half a dozen cupcakes.   It was a lovely variety that consisted of Banana Cream, Egg Nog, Bump Cake, Peppermint.  The people have always be

I'm from Grand Rapids and ran into this place during this years Art Fair. So glad I did because the Party Time cupcake i got was excellent!I wish I would have gotten a cookie for $1 too.I thought $3 was a little high for a cupcake but it was worth it.

Cupcakes YUM!  and these are Super-YUM!  So happy we stumbled upon Cupcake Station on our recent trip to Ann Arbor.  We bought a dozen minis because it was too difficult to choose just one.  As we sat in a parking lot devouring our dozen (plus one free) mini's the standouts were definitely the carrot cake, the red velvet (this one is worth a return trip to Ann Arbor alone!), pineapple, coconut, station's samoa, and the heavenly banana split.  Now mind you, there were some that didn't make it since we ONLY got 13 - so we have decided that is also another reason for a return trip to Ann Arbor!  

Prices were reasonable, in my opinion, given that in Chicago these kinds of cupcakes generally go for more $$, so to me, they were actually on the inexpensive side.  I did notice that they had Jumbo cupcakes on the menu...wish I would have noticed when I was there, sounds tempting....

Aaaaah cupcakes...

The moment I walked through the doors of The Cupcake Station, I was hit by a cakey, battery, frosty aroma that almost knocked me off of my feet. I was immediately greeted, but there was a line, so I was not serviced right away. The wait did not bother me, because I was too busy looking at the beautiful cupcakes in the display case, the catchy t-shirts for sell, and the fun yet elegant cupcake artwork that hung on the wall. And when it was my turn to order, it was my lucky day. They were having a sell: buy two, get one free. So, I bought two, and got one free of course. Overall, the atmosphere was great, the aroma even better, and the service was excellent. The only downfall was that they did not have enough vegan variety in the store. They have more variety for order, but not in the store. They only had Chocolate Vegan Cupcakes with vanilla or mocha frosting. I would have loved to try their Red Velvet Cupcake. Yum!


Talk about rich. Talk about flavor. Talk about Vabulous. When I entered The Cupcake Station, I was greeted with two options. The chocolate cupcake with vegan buttercream frosting or the chocolate cupcake with vegan mocha frosting. Who was I to choose? I tried both. Now, I am usually not a fan of chocolate, because it can go really wrong, really fast. Chocolate done right deserves the utmost position in the flavor hierarchy. But chocolate done fast, cheap, and wrong does not even deserve a place on the table. The Cupcake Station's Chocolate Vegan Cupcake, my friends, is chocolate done right. Moist, rich, savory. For those of you who do not enjoy a powerful flavor punch, keep a glass of milk nearby.

The Buttercream frosting tasted very vanilla, and I thought I saw vanilla bean seeds throughout. It complimented the chocolate at all the right moments, like the perfect gentlemen on a perfect first date. Love at first . . . taste. I will be back for more.

The Mocha frosting was not my favorite. I will not be purchasing it again. It packed a powerful coffee taste and aroma with a pinch of caramel, which would be great if I liked that type of thing. I am the type of girl who likes a little coffee with my cream. It over powered me. Not only was it too strong for my taste, but it also had a scorched overtone. It was like burnt toast when you scrap off the black, but you can still taste it.

Addendum: I attempted the mocha frosting again and it was actually tasty the second time around. Before I said that it had a scorched overtone. I believe firmly that something was scorched in the batch. This tasting everything was fresh, flavorful, but not overwhelming. I would actually buy it again! Rating for the mocha frosting up from a 1 to a 3. The only reason I tried it again with a 1 rating is because the vegan selection in the store for individual retail is limited.

Overall, I love The Cupcake Station. There is no doubt that I will be returning and I can not wait to try more of their vegan flavors.

I have to say, I could live at The Cupcake Station. Boosting great customer service, It is like a friend's house that is always filled with the aroma of baked goods. Where there are always cookies in the jar, a cake on the stand, and a pie in the oven. That is why it saddens me to say that I did not like the Red Velvet cupcake. I was expecting so much, and it left much to be desired.

The first bite, I tasted nothing but the vanilla buttercream frosting. Which taste great, but as cute as frosting is, I am not a fan of it. I started to get scared, because if the flavor of the cupcake could not shine through a little frosting, that said something. On the second bite, without frosting, I could taste a little bit of cocoa. Then, I was distracted by the texture of the cupcake. Moist, but a little too moist, mushy if you will. It had no structure, no "chew". On the third bite, I tasted nothing at all. : (

These cupcakes are the absolute best in Ann Arbor! Moist and fluffy with the right amount of creamy frosting!
I don't like the frosting to be too sweet, the way it often is in supermarket bakeries, but this stuff was just the right amount of sweetness. I tried Chocolate Salted Caramel, Samoa and Pumpkin. My favorite was the Chocolate Salted Caramel. I definitely recommend this place to anyone going to eat downtown. I think it is cheaper than getting dessert at most of the Main Street restaurants.

I might be a bit biased since I got my wedding cupcakes from here but I chose them because they have amazing cupcakes and the people are super friendly. :)  For my wedding day, I got pineapple cupcakes with pineapple icing,  carrot cake with cream cheese icing, and lemon cupcake with raspberry filling.  We also got a red velvet cake with raspberry filling and white chocolate cream cheese icing.  In case you didn't know, they make cakes to order and big batches of cupcakes to order.  This was over a year ago and people are still talking about how awesome the cupcakes were at my wedding.
  
This place always has a BIG selection of unique yummy cupcakes that are moist and addictive.  What's nice is that they have regular sized cupcakes, mini bite size ones, and then huge big ones.  I tend to get a bunch of the mini ones so that I can try multiple kinds.  You get a discount for getting batches of 6 or a dozen.  Speaking of discounts, they have a different  special for each day of the week so there's always a reason to go.  

The people there are extremely friendly and helpful.  They are always patient with people who are indecisive like me.  With all the different yummy choices, sometimes it takes a few minutes to decide.

It's a small store so I wouldn't recommend going with a crowd but I did go once with about 8 people as part of a birthday food run and it worked out fine.  

This is great casual place to go for dessert!

Admittedly, I'm not one to be impressed by cupcakes.  I feel they're just a bit insignificant in terms of dessert.  But if you like cupcakes, you'll like the cupcakes here.  Rich frosting, nice cake batter.  The downside?  You basically have to take out a mortgage to afford them.

Another good thing to know about this place, and the reason I was interested in reviewing it: their chocolate-dipped cheesecake on a stick is dangerously good (and I mean *dangerously*). 

A couple other notes:  their 8 calorie ice cream is tasty and the place has a sweet atmosphere... you can sit and play little games with friends, or just bask in the cool air and bright colors of the walls.

Quirky: they're open until the posted closing our... or sold out.  So you might not plan on stopping in at 9:59 for a cupcake, because this place actually sells out of their product.

I've not had any problems with Cupcake Station not having flavors I want...currently I'm addicted to the Red Velvet, Boston Cream, and most of all: the White Chocolate Bumpy-Cake. 

This is not a french patisserie, this is Americana: as such, many of the frostings have a charmingly 1980's home-made taste and texture and the cake is a bit heavy/chewy instead of light -n- foamy. Staff are great, it's a comfy-cute place with lots of little gift items on walls/shelves.

OK...after a repeat visit, I'll boost my original rating by a star. 

The trick to a successful Cupcake Station experience is good planning.  Is there a special deal today?  Is it early enough in the day that the cupcakes will be fresh, and they'll be stocked up  with a wide variety of flavors? 

Late in the day, when there's no special (or rather, the special that's on doesn't fit your order), you could wind up with a last choice, dryish, $3 cupcake. 

Or, like this time, you could get 2 minis, in delicious flavors (chocolate snowball and German chocolate cake, if you must know), for $1.38.  Yum!

In sum...I see what people like about this place...but getting it "right" takes a bit of effort, and for me a cupcake run is nearly always  a spontaneous affair.

This is the establishment that sparked my interest in baking. PB&C & Cookies & Cream are staples, but they continue to experiment and offer new cupcakes every month.

Current recommendation: the Station Samoa!

But their cupcakes are not the only reason they receive 5 stars. They are the most Social Media Savvy business in all of Ann Arbor. Giving away free cupcakes for "Fan Days"  (every 500 more fans that "Like" them on Facebook.com), "Mystery Mondays" (sampling different flavors and reporting back on Facebook what they were) & other great promotions/deals (Elvis' Bday) the Cupcake Station is contributing to the Ann Arbor community by having a presence where their customers socialize.

This is what every company should be doing! 

On top of all of this praise, the people that work here are the ideal employees & the people that visit the cupcake station are extremely friendly and nice. It is impossible to not smile when I walk by this fine establishment.

So if you're looking to sweeten up a date, dinner or your day you don't have to look past Liberty St.

Great Cupcakes and great service. I had a great experience. I wanted a specialty cupcake make 2 minutes after they closed and the server happily created it for me. Sasha is the best cupcake make ever!

They never have their red velvet when I come in....
The place itself is pretty cutesy but always outta the stuff i want!

I'll edit my review once I've tasted it!

Cupcakes are supposed to be about happiness, and I assume cupcake stores are supposed to be happy too. But it really kills the mood when the girl behind the counter has an attitude problem. And the cupcakes are definitely not good enough to compensate for bad service.

After many trips to Cake Nouveau, we finally tried Cupcake station.  I was very much impressed, and I think this will be our new cupcake destination.  I tried 4 flavors, and I liked them all (lets see if I can remember--carrot cake, bumpy cake, banana pudding, and german chocolate).  I especially like the mini cupcakes, which allows you try more flavors.  I thought there was a good balance between cake and frosting, both of which were flavorful and fresh.  Definitely will return here!

The fiance and I drove to this place after hitting up Just Baked. We were on vacation and they were close to each other so we thought, "why not?" I didn't love this place, I didn't hate it, but it definitely wasn't my favorite. When we walked in we were told that all mini's were $1. Yay. We got six so we could take a bite of each and decide what we liked. Well the guy behind that counter wasn't that friendly so we hurried and made out choices. When he boxed them they were already falling over and sticking to each other. We took them to the car and by that point they were a mess. The only reason I'm giving this place three stars is because the Vanilla Latte cupcake was really tasty and the cake part of the cupcakes I could piece together and try was baked really well. I might try them again if I go back for vacation, but then again, I could very easily forget about this place.

HUGE selection and I love how they have most flavors in mini so that you can taste alot and not go broke.
$3 for a regular and $1.40 for a mini is of course still steep but now I am getting used to and just dealing with how expensive cupcakes are.
The mini really is just one bite so the regular is a better value but I knew I would be eating the whole dozen so I went with the "lighter" option.
The staff is great and very patient since it took me awhile to figure out what all I "needed" to try.
I went with whats up doc, samoa, pb&c, strawberry, german chocolate, coconut,vegan chocolate peanut butter, salted caramel,  red velvet, banana cream pie, alaskan moose and original.
All were good, my favorite being the ones with peanut butter and the samoa.
Least favorite the banana which tasted pretty artificial.
In all a nice place but there are so many others in Ann Arbour, I have to confess Just baked was better.

Stop in and grab a mini red velvet cupcake - TRUST ME!

Yes, I may be a bit obsessed with anything red velvet (to the point where I won't order anything else - no way - so long as red velvet is present), but that just makes me so much more qualified to let you in on the little secret Cupcake Station holds behind their glass display.  The mini, not full sized, red velvet cupcakes are a great size (two bites and done!  Thank you!) and really pack a punch!  Just another example of how good things come in small packages, and the price is hard to beat at a buck and a half.  

My taste buds and waist line thank you, Cupcake Station!

Wait, what? I haven't reviewed this place yet?

Best cupcakes I've tried in Ann Arbor so far, and the minis are too cute. I love the weekly deals ($2 cupcakes on Tuesday, buy 2 get 1 free cupcakes on Wednesday), and the service has always been friendly... even during super busy times like Restaurant Week!

They hold up well after being refrigerated for a couple of days, as long as you let the cupcake sit on the counter for a little, to reach room temperature. Still as moist as day one! This lets me take advantage of the B2G1 deal on Wednesday for cheaper than, say, caving into my sugar craving Wednesday, Thursday, AND Friday.......................................................................


Can't say anything nearly as nice about Cake Nouveau, where I've only ever felt like a nuisance to the person behind the counter and the cupcakes are DRY DRY DRY DRY DRY.



Carry cash unless you plan on spending at least $5 here though.

Pricey, because hello you're buying cupcakes for over $2.50/per, but if you're only going on occasion for a special treat who cares? It's all about indulging every now and then and I think the cupcakes are delicious, satisfying and worth every penny. 

I wish they had more inventive flavours and better packaging, like the other reviewers, but considering how often I go and buy cupcakes it's not a dealbreaker.

I may have also bought their "pupcakes" for my dogs. They both agree they were pawsitivly delicious (I can't believe I just typed that... That's a lie, I totally believe it).

I've visited Ann Arbor twice and both times I've brought back a dozen mini cupcakes back to san diego as my carry on luggage. Their mini cupcakes are the perfect indulgence - two satisfying bites, the right amount of sugar intake, you get to try all their flavors w/o feeling too guilty of eating too much sweets, and it's only $1.40 (i think) :) Get a baker's dozen for $16, which comes out to be $1.25. They last pretty well in the frig for 2 days. I haven't tried their cookies, regular sized cupcakes, or pies, but I'm too satisfied with their minis to go further. 

I wish cupcake station was in san diego. yes i know we have sprinkles, but cupcake station's minis found the way to my sweet tooth. why doesnt EVERY SINGLE CUPCAKE STORE HAVE MINIS????

After the manager apologized for my experience and offered me a coupon so I could stop by and try their cupcakes again, I made a second trip to The Cupcake Station with a few friends. Despite writing a negative review previously I was really pleased to see the management taking such an active role in their service. Way to go!

When we went in it was later in the day, and most of the cupcakes were sold out, but the girl working there offered that she could make any cupcakes "on request" with the few that had just finished baking. She could have just told us that they were sold out for the day, and I really appreciated that they were so accommodating.

Just for good measure I tried the Cream Francaise again, and found that the cupcakes are best enjoyed when you balance cake and frosting in the same bite. By itself, the Cream Francaise tastes pretty much like whipped butter, but if you balance it with a bite of cake its has a very nice, bread-and-butter sort of feel to it.

With that said, most of the frosting that I tried after stealing a bite of my friend's choices was *way* too rich or sweet for my liking, but that's just a matter of personal taste. Some people really enjoy an indulgent cupcake. And the cake base itself (I had chocolate) was fluffy and sweet and tasted very fresh.

Because of personal cake-preferences, I can't say that I would choose The Cupcake Station for my own cupcake experience, but I really appreciate how devoted the company is to creating a good customer experience, and I imagine that I'll pop in again on occasion.

*Note; I still think that 2.75 is too expensive for a cupcake that's just frosting and cake, but I can imagine that would be a fair price for some of the more elaborate flavors. And they have deals on occasion for the cupcakes, so overall I can't say that its unfair.

Normally I would give The Cupcake Station 3/5 on account that they're not my favorite cupcakes, but their customer service here bumps them up to a 4.

The Cupcake Station is one of the best around.  We stop at the shop every time we visit Ann Arbor and they never disappoint.  My personal favorites are the Boston Cream and the Creme Francaise.  

I do agree with the reviewer who said that the packaging is not great-clear plastic container where the cupcakes frequently tip over... but it is not any different than the boxes that other stores use which allows the frostings from different cupcakes to stick together.

When I say best around, I mean it.  We have been to cupcake shops in Chicago, Cleveland, Boston, New York, Atlanta and just about every city we visit and Cupcake Station's are still tops!

We got three cupcakes last week; Chocolate peanut butter, chocolate cheesecake, and carrot cake with walnuts. 

The chocolate cupcakes were so perfectly cooked! They were moist but had a delicately thin crispy crust. I'm still confused about the "cheesecake" part of the chocolate cheesecake cupcake, but it was too delicious for me to care. 

The carrot cake was equally good and supremely moist, just as advertised. I assume the carrot cake batter is wetter than the chocolate batter, and it didn't have that awesome crispy outside the of the chocolate cupcakes. If they could get that crust on the carrot cake cupcake it would be perfect!

The ratio of frosting to cake is spot on.  Their cupcakes aren't simply platforms for frosting. You get the full flavor of the cake and a compliment of frosting to go with it. 

Personally, I think the price tag per cupcake is perfectly adequate. One cupcake is plenty for dessert, and you'd pay just as much or more for a scoop of ice cream, piece of pie, etc.  We went on a Wednesday and it was "buy 2 get 1 free". Totally cost $5.50. Totally fair for two cupcakes and a deal for three.  

Keep up the good work, Cupcake Station!

Went in just before closing one night and got three mini cupcakes for the price of two.  The best was the Cream Francaise, which they refrosted for us just because the employee thought it had gotten smushed.  The Vabulous Vegan was was okay, but didn't have the same outstanding flavor burst as the Carrot Cake or Cream Francaise.  I'll have to get there earlier some day to dry out the Boston Cream variety.

Got buy 2 get 1 free-- makes slightly overpriced cupcakes a little more worth it.  

I love the S'mores flavor, Samoa is also tasty.  A little less opulent but still tasty is the Boston Cream.  The carrot cake is super moist and has a good cream cheese icing.

Cupcakes are a little icing-heavy, but so darn cute I don't even mind.

I wanted so badly to LOVE the Cupcake Station.  Cupcakes within walking distance from my apartment, work and school?  YES PLZ.  Oh, I wish I hadn't wanted it so badly because it ended up being a severe disappointment for this cupcake lover.

It may have been an off day when I went in, but it was off enough that I never went back.  They only had a very small selection of cupcakes, when I was expecting a plethora.  The cupcakes they did have were small and over-priced.  I played it safe and went basic with a vanilla and a chocolate, both of which were underwhelming.  One of which (chocolate) was dry and obviously NOT fresh.  A BIG no-no for any bakery, much less one that "specializes" in selling cupcakes.  

I would say this place is good for kids, but for adults with refined palettes that know what good flavor is beyond a sugar buzz, I would look elsewhere for your mini cake fix.

Pros: best cupcakes in town, made fresh every morning. 
Also, variety -- take a look on their website and you can see all they offer. Mmmmm.

Cons: they only make them fresh in the morning, so get there early if you want specific varieties, because they are nearly sold out in the evening!
And...price -- at $2.50 to $3 a cupcake, bringing dessert for a large party gets a bit expensive.

The German Chocolate cupcake has been my favorite thus far (and their dark chocolate one is very tasty too).

The cupcakes are okay...nothing like sprinkles, crumbs, or anything else they are trying to be posing off it. The price is standard but the cupcakes aren't great. My favorite one would be the carrot cake one.
You need to luck out on the right time to get

I love cupcake bakeries! I think these are so adorable!! Back in 2009, when I was OBSESSED with cupcakes, I used to frequent this place about once a week. I loved coming on Tuesdays ($2 tuesdays) or Wednesdays (buy 2 get 1 free). I loved thier red velvet and carrotcake cupcakes!

Sadly/luckily, my excessive sugar cravings are now under control. I haven't really come back to cupcake station as often as i did before, but I will stop by if I have sweet tooth attacks

Overall, cute cupcake bakery. Come on Tues or Wed for the best deals. Try to come early too (before ~5pm) before they sell out of the most popular flavors!

I have ordered cupcakes from the Cupcake Station quite frequently.  I first ordered from them in October, 2008 and have ordered several times since for meetings and other occasions.  The cupcakes have been a hit with everyone who has had them.

I am somewhat mystified by the other reviewers who have found the cupcakes dry or the frosting hard.  I am not sure why my experience has been so different, but let me try to puzzle it out.

Whenever I order cupcakes, I pre-order online or call and I order a  variety of cupcakes at 1-2 dozen.  I typically order the mini-cupcakes because I find that people really like the variety and feel better about eating smaller portions of cupcakes.  Not all the cupcake varieties are available in the minis, but all of the minis have been moist, and people have really liked them.

I am a chocolate fan, so I love the chocolate cupcakes and I really liked the crème franchaise which has a buttery icing, but it is perfect on a mini-size cupcake.

If you are new to the shop, I recommend trying the mini-cupcakes first where you can try a variety of flavors.  Call in a day before to make sure you get the varieties you like.

The pros: big selection of cupcakes, my hubby says my cupcakes are better (yay, me!); I will say they are better than Cake Nouveau
The cons: overpriced for what you get, didn't give a napkin.  =(

Spending nearly $5 for a regular size cupcake and a bite size cupcake: ridiculous!

Great place for a cupcake! In town for a wedding, we happened to walk past CS with our daughter and nieces in tow and decided to stop in. It's a nice little shop, the woman working was friendly and helpful, and the cupcakes were great! The selection is quite diverse; there was something for everyone in our group, from "classic" flavors to unique combinations that we hadn't seen before. I recommend the "bumpy cake", the dark chocolate melted over the buttercream icing was fantastic. Cakes were moist and tasty, we didn't run into any of the quality issues mentioned in other reviews here.

The best flavor I've tried was Red Velvet. The buttercream frosting melted in my mouth. Second best is the Original. 

That said, I've found that most of what I've tried (which includes Vanilla Latte, German Chocolate, and Cookies & Cream) were too sweet, at least for my taste buds. The frosting made my mouth all tingly and not in a good way. And don't expect the name to match the actual flavor. The Vanilla "Latte" tasted simply like a over-sweetened, plasticky vanilla frosting. 

The mini sizes are good for trying new flavors, but they are overpriced. The best deal is on Wednesday, when they have the buy 2 get 1 free deal. The first time I went was on that day, so I got a pleasant surprise. However, one cupcake was sweet enough that I did not want to follow up with another one, so either save it for later or share with a friend!

Wow!  What a gem.  We were just walking around taking in the scene in downtown Ann Arbor and saw a sign fir key lime lemonade for a buck.  Well that was good enough for me to go in.  In, short the drink was one of the best lemonades  I have had in a ling time.  Tangy and sweet with a front end taste of the key lime yet finishes with smooth lemon.  Tasty.  But the real treat were the cupcakes.  We tried the mini version cupcakes and they were moist, full of flavor and the variety prove to cause us to really think hard what to try.  Oh, and they even have frosting shots so you can try out a frosting flavor!  How cool is that?  Place deserves to be visited bt Antonella in the area.

Maybe it's just because I'm cheap, but I don't get what all the hoopla is about.  $2.50 for a PB & C cupcake that was decent, but the cake was dry and hard on top, and the frosting was overly sweet.  I think I have made better, moister cupcakes with Meijer brand cake mix.  And, sure, $1.30 for a mini-cupcake sounds like a deal, but it's literally gone in 2 bites. One if you have a big mouth.  Maybe I just don't get the cupcake craze?

The cupcakes are awesome! There is definitely nowhere around that offers so many choices.  And everything I have had so far has been fantastic! And it's pretty rare to find anything made from scratch nowadays:-)

Definitely hit them up during the week for the great specials.

The staff is fantastic and very accommodating.

Great experience and great cupcakes.

I guess it's about time I write a review for the Cupcake Station.. I'm a freak for cupcakes. I make them, I buy them, I eat them &make other people eat them.. love them. So after getting tattooed at Name Brand Tattoo, I thought I owed myself a cupcake (he

Stopped by one day while walking around downtown and got a few cupcakes.  They were amazing, at first I couldn't decide on what I wanted to get since there were so many to choose from.  The staff was very helpful and didn't mind my indecisiveness.  I ended up getting a german chocolate cake, honey lavender, and chocolate lovers.  They were to die for, so moist and flavorful.  The honey lavender was different and so good.  I love the smell of lavender and never thought I would like the taste, but it's really delicious.  I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a good dessert or a special treat.  

Tip: the honey lavender is only offered in april, they rotate special cupcakes each month, check out their website for details.  also, they have a great deal on tues: regular cupcakes for $2 and minis for $1 AND wed: it's buy 2 get one free!

Cupcake Station. You are such a great concept. Homemade, fresh, tasty cupcakes in flavors that everyone wants to try. But you failed when it came to pricing. 

Michigan Bumpy Cake - Who doesn't remember Bumpy Cake. It's perfectly reproduced here.  Rich ch

Just not worth it.
Not worth the price or the calories.
As a cupcake aficionado, I had high hopes when this cupcake place opened in Ann Arbor. But all I've ever really had are dry, crumbly, sometimes stale cupcakes with usually overly sweet and not fluffy frosting. The vanilla is just not good, tastes too artificial. Ditto for the red velvet, that queen of cupcakes, which should not taste like the one here does. The real thing is a moist, soft cupcake covered in creamy (key word: creamy) cream cheese frosting. You won't get that here. The chocolate is mediocre too. I really wish I could say great things about this place, because the staff are nice and it's overall pretty cute. But the product is just not up to par. Especially not for about $3 a pop. Sorry.

Disclaimer: I have never had any of their bars, such as the peanut butter bar, which a friend recently raved about.

Only been a handful of times, but I appreciate it for what it is - an indulgence, and a darn good one! The daily specials every week are wonderful, and they always have a wide variety of cupcake choices. 

What matters to me, though, is that they make sure to always offer at least one (generally two) vegan cupcakes. Those have all been delicious, as far as I've experienced as of now. I'll continue experimenting for future data, though, rest assured!
One of my favorite dessert places. I love the mini cupcakes which allow you to indulge without going too far. My favorite is the Creme Francaise.

I have tried cupcakes all over the country, hungry or not I'm a sucker for a cupcake shop. This is by far my favorite in the state of MI, overall fave is Baked by Melissa in NYC. I ordered an assortment of 40 cupcakes for my bridal shower and they were a hit. The girls couldn't believe how good they were. My faves: bumpalicious and the original!

in a moment of excessive depression and low blood sugar (after hours of failed house hunting) we decided to medicate with cupcakes. the lemon cupcake was gone in seconds. the cake was fluffy, the frosting tangy and light. not greasy, just the right ratio. immediately got back in line and ordered a second - cookies and cream.. with a marshmallow filling and cookies and cream frosting on top. it was the only thing keeping me from total heartbreak. the frosting seems to be the perfect compromise between a traditional heavy buttercream and the light whipped cream frostings, which really speaks to my needs. eat more cupcakes.

Worst cupcake experience ever! First time there, my friend and I ordered a banana cream and a red velvet cupcake. First of all, the banana cream taste like artificial banana, similar to a banana flavored laffy taffy. Disgusting! Secondly, the red velvet was just a chocolate cupcake. I recognize that red velvet has cocoa power in it, but this was a bona fide chocolate cake. When I asked about it, the staff was immediately defensive and rude, offering no remedy to my complaint. I never complain about food, but this was the worst experience I have ever had. I will never return and do not recommend any one to go there.

Sweet cuppin' cakes!!

Lots of interesting flavors lie behind the glass. All are moist, decadent and definitely worth savoring. 

I adore the Red Velvet with real cream cheese frosting!  Trailing not too far behind that is the Michigan Bumpy.  The bumps are nearly as tall as the cake itself.  

They make wee bite-sized cakes for those of you who don't want an express ride on the Sugar Train.  This is moot if you purchase more than 2-3. Just buy a regular one and stuff your face already! 

I have noticed sometimes that a cupcake will be not-so-moist, the frosting not-so-soft...I'm guessing the cakes weren't shifted around as they should have been.  Or bagged up with a sign emblazoned in red marker: "Day-Old Cupcakes, Half Off!" 

$2.75 per cuppycake is a bit pricey, given the regular size of these babies.  I'm fine with the size, I'd just rather pay less.

The place itself is pretty cute and they sell other cupcake related merchandise like cute mini cupcake ornaments!

With that said, I was a little disappointed with their packaging of the cupcakes. They just put them in a generic clear to- go box so by the time you get home, the cupcakes are all tipped over and ugly. Not good if you were planning on giving the cupcakes as a gift. They really should invest in a box with cupcake holders in it.  

As for the cupcakes, they were either hit or miss.
These were the ones I tried:
Carrot cake: The cake part itself was dry. The frosting was a regular cream cheese type frosting. Overall, subpar.

Strawberry delight: i didnt expect much from this one and almost didnt choose it. But it was surprisingly delish! It was very moist and the frosting complimented it well.

Chocolate lovers: This sounds delicious but was very  disappointing. I don't know what part of this cupcake would satisfy a chocolate lover since it was dry and tasted like it was made from boxed cake food mix. The frosting was also very hard.

Vanilla latte: The best part of this one was the frosting. I'm not much of a frosting person, but this frosting had a yummy coffee taste and was very silky and creamy! I don't even remember what the cake part was like because the frosting was so good!
 
All in all, not one of the better cupcake places I've been too. The cupcakes may as well have been made from boxed mixes (not that I have a prob with good ole Betty Crocker mixes. But if you're selling gourmet cupcakes, you better step up your game.)

It's a good thing that I don't live close to this store. I would be down here buying cupcakes all of the time. It wouldn't be good for my waist. Though I suppose at 2 dollars on Tuesdays it's not that bad on my wallet. 

The store is a nice little store tucked away in downtown anne arbor, the people working here are helpful and patient with my indecisiveness in the face of so many choices. The cupcakes were good. They weren't too battery but they had the right about of softness. The icing was good, not too sugary but sugary enough.

The cupcakes here are good, but nothing super special. However, if you're a college student living without an oven (or the time to bake...), the homemade quality can actually be kind of nice. I wouldn't recommend coming during the last few hours they're open, because they're often running low. And when I saw running low, I mean they'll have, like, two kinds of cupcakes left. Any other time, though, I would recommend the carrot cake cupcakes (available with or without nuts!). The frosting is the best part :).

UPDATE:

*Idea*
DATE NIGHT! 
Instead of that bland, boring "Want to get a cup of coffee" first sort-of date with someone, take them to Cupcake Station and jazz it up a bit.  They have a few intimate tables there and a small couch area as well that's cool, casual, safe and well-lit, as well as being a better idea that the usual snore with caffeine. 

You can still have coffee or hot cider and still get into deep conversation, but get your sweet treats on as well, which is always a plus. For those watching their weight they even have mini cupcakes, so come on there is NO more excuse for the boring coffee date. Go grab a cupcake!

business.full_address:
Congdon St at Bowen St
College Hill
Providence, RI 02906
business.name: Prospect Park

reviews.text: This well-kept Providence treasure is the perfect spot to enjoy a "Crunchy Leaf Day" all of your own in Fall's kaleidoscopic splendor. Well-established trees offer generous piles of leaves for hours of crunching and jumping!  The majestic view of downtown Providence is a treat in itself in the light of day, or in the twinkling night.

Hands down one of the best views of Downtown Providence!

Super convenient located right off Thayer and is a great spot just to take in the views or have a picnic at. 

Definitely someplace you have to go to at least once while your in Providence!

Not all that big but a must-see if you're living in Providence, just for the view. Good spot to walk through for a date, sit back and enjoy looking out over the city. Does tend to be overrun at times by wannabe intellectuals, pot smokers, and hipsters from the surrounding neighborhood.

It's impossible to live in the Renaissance city of Providence or in RI as a whole without coming to this wonderful, beautiful park. 

Prospect Park is a Providence icon -- well, one of them anyway. With a fantastic view of the city, benches for everyone to sit and take a load off, and a statue of our founder: Roger Williams. 

What better way to spend the day? I'd love to see another park view as marvelous as this little baby...oh right, there isn't one. 

Prospect all the way!

A wonderful and surprisingly overlooked gem of a park. Providence actually has precious few nice parks (and this one isn't all that well maintained) but this is definitely one of the good ones. Great for a summer picnic or a spring/fall stroll (I am not saying its bad in the winter but its not its best season).

If there are 5 Top picnic spots downtown, this is one of them. 

The view is great up here. 

Great place to bring your brown bag lunch. Relax and feed the squirrels and filthy pigeons. Stare out over the city, or lie in the grass away from the dog poo and stare at the sky. 
Not sure about after sunset. Haven't seen any punks, but there is some evidence of beer bottles. (cheap, crappy beer)

NOTE: The park has a statue of Roger Williams, but this is a FAKE Roger Williams park. There are several Roger Williams parks scattered throughout Providence to make it difficult for you to find the buried pirate treasure.

Can't argue, it really is a great spot.  The best view of downtown and a nice place to have a city picnic. Relative to other parks in Providence, it's 5 (maybe 10) stars, but I think the reality is that there aren't too many fantastic outdoor places in the city.

Prospect Park offers one of the best views of Downcity Providence.  A couple of park benches are lined up for seating and there is plenty of groomed grass to throw a blanket down as well.  Sit next to the massive statue of Roger Williams and reflect on H.P. Lovecraft who used to frequently visit Prospect Park.  If possible, grab a bottle of wine and kick back to the lovely sights and sounds of the city.  The only downfall of this park, is that it's shut down at at dusk and cops do patrol the area and don't have a problem kicking people out.

We really should have picnicked up here. 

After a walk through town, we made our way here and sat on a bench overlooking the city like a cute little elderly couple. We passed some people on a lunch date, a young family out with their baby, and some guy attempting to read a book. 

Come, stay, sit, and chill out for a while like that little boy in, "The Giving Tree."
Best park in providence I've been to. Beautiful view of the city scape year round.

Morning, noon, or night, Prospect Park is a great place to get a gorgeous view of the Providence skyline. My favorite time to come here is at night.  It is breathtaking as the lights of downtown Providence twinkle like the stars in the sky and you can enjoy a relaxing chat with your friend or significant other.  Meanwhile, you will probably be trying to avoid staring at the kids making out in the bench next to yours.  This park is relatively small, so it tends to mostly attract young lovers and the occasional dog walker.  This is also where the Providence Ghost Tour meets (for those that are not of the faint of heart).  In my opinion, this is one of the great landmarks to visit while you are in PVD, as it has a mix of history (with the giant statue of Roger Williams looming over the city), mystery and makes a great place for a romantic evening picnic.
This is a great little park, situated closely to the college hill area. Small but worth the trip, this is the home to Roger Williams' grave, which jets out overlooking the city. You should stop by.
Very nice, clean and not completely packed. It has a great view of the city and seems to be taken care of pretty well. Easily a good park to go to and enjoy the weather.
First stop by Thayer street for some to-go food and head to Prospect Park for a picnic, awesome views!

SCENIC VISTA ALERT - if you make it here, you'll probably spend a minimum of ten solid minutes just ogling the skyline of our small, fair city.  And with good reason - you can pick all the landmarks out, watch the blood of the city pump through arteries such as I-95 and Memorial Boulevard, and snap a "wish you were here" style photo to show off to others.  Added bonus - no one will be jockeying with you to get the view described.  You'll likely be joined by about 20 or so people on the whole grounds, so you can take your time, stroll or sit or lie down, kick a soccer ball, throw a frisbee, read a book, have an intimate chat, share a laugh, or just collect your thoughts a while...overlooking the Renaissance City.

Missing our nap-time homages to Roger William's tomb! Just a few weeks into San Francisco's chilly summer and I'm already longing for last year's summer sublet at Prospect Park... The property is modest, but boasts magnificent views of the city, shady trees and wild flower hedges. Simple and perfect for lazy lounging.

This park is glorious. It offers panoramic views of our fair city, has lovely park benches, green grass and is on a pretty, quiet, quaint street tucked away in College Hill. Oh, and there's a gigantic statue of Roger Williams. What's not to love?

It isn'
small park with a nice view of the city

H.P. Lovecraft, an incorrigible corresponder, frequently wrote letters from this park while lamenting the marring of the view by the construction of ultra-modern monstrosities.

This park has an illimitable view and would be a fantastic place to read a book, have a picnic, or correspond with friends.

It's really hard not to give Prospect Park five stars. Even though the great view is being marred by the condo buildings popping up every other week, it's still a great place to bring an out-of-towner for a view of Providence. The somewhat constant patrolling of cops is a downer but the park does have a curfew so technically, we're not even supposed to be there late at night. But we keep going back even when the cops kick us out because it's a great place to chill. I've met some cool people up there that I'll probably never see again but will always remember all the good times I've had at the park. Also, a good place to watch the fireworks (if Providence ever haves them again).
Far and away my favorite place to go in the entire city. Any time of the year. It's just serene and beautiful,I absolutely love that park!

Good view of Providence, a few very worn wooden benches (fits in with the historic naure of providence). Good place to take visitors, but just remember it's a small park. Good size for a picnic. Nice view, but I don't think it's worth a particular detour.

This'll be my first review where I get to say "I thought about not reviewing this place because I want to keep it all to myself," so.... there it was.

At my school's orientation, our group leader told us that the statue of Roger Williams, Rhode Island's venerated state founder, has an interesting secret past.  The statue depicts Williams pointing out over a vista of the city -- but with his whole hand.  That's weird, right?  The rumor is that he used to be patting a Native American boy on the head, but it was deemed politically incorrect and the boy was removed.

Fact or fiction?  Who cares?  If you're trying to convince anyone that Providence is the shit, take them here at sunset with a themos of hot cocoa, and sit on one of the benches.  Also, this is the best make-out spot in Providence.  Especially in winter!  Get to it!
The best view in Providence. Kind of dark and gloomy, but in a cute way, like an Edward Gorey book.

Fantastic view of the city, beautiful little park.
The statue of Roger Williams looks like he's scratching. We call him DJ Rog.

business.full_address:
The Courtyard Of Chapel Hill
431 W Franklin St
Chapel Hill, NC 27516
business.name: Bliss Boutique Bakery

reviews.text:
Cute location in the Courtyard that actually has a coffee shop feel to it with some leather chairs and nice, slightly dimmer lighting. I'd go here to read or do work inside or outside. You can watch them do the baking, which is cool.

The coffee here has been good, and I enjoyed my cupcake, though I personally prefer the ones at Sugarland, which I think are a little more unique. The Bliss cupcakes are very light and airy. Another plus is that they offer vegan cupcakes, which if I was a vegan, I'd be ecstatic over. They change cupcake specials daily (with some regular weekly rotations) so if you have a favorite that isn't standard vanilla or chocolate, check the website to see what days they have it.

What can I say that hasn't been said?

Bliss has a comfortable little shop next to Sandwhich in the Courtyard (note: FREE PARKING) with a lovely little outdoor area to eat and it's staffed by the nicest guys.

This place is amazing. The ganache, the butter cream, the brownies, the brownie cupcakes, the carrot cupcakes, the coffee, the tea. Oh, and the vegan cupcake du jour, is also AMAZING, especially when it's the cherry chocolate one, and no, I'm not vegan.

A couple of notables: There are no day-old cupcakes. You will only get cupcakes that were freshly mixed and baked that day, in an unrefrigerated state. There are no cases drying out your cupcakes. Be sure to pick up a schedule so you know the day to get your favorites!

It's a good cupcake/brownie, I've tasted better but I don't think you'll find anywhere much better in Chapel Hill.  I'm not sure if their cupcakes are worth the $2.50 premium, but they do have some interesting flavors for you to find one that you might really like.  Unfortunately they rotate flavors everyday of the week so you may have to go in a certain day each week or call in a large order.   

Overall it's a good spot if you're looking for a gourmet brownie or cupcake though it's on the pricier side.

Dear Mad Hatter Bake Shop in Durham, please be aware that Bliss allowed me and my date to grab a cupcake and a cup of coffee ten minutes before closing time AND the dude behind the counter -- as we scurried to pay and get out of his way -- even encouraged us to sit down in the store and enjoy the cupcake so long as we didn't mind him cleaning up in the background (please reference my Mad Hatter Yelp for additional disgruntled info on trying to order a to-go cupcake from them ten minutes before closing time). ANYway. Aforementioned dude-behind-counter could not have been nicer. The shop is cute, small, but still plenty of seating for a cozy cafe. You can see the kitchen where all the cupcake magic happens. They do offer vegan options, which is great. I sampled the ganache chocolate cupcake with chocolate buttercream filling. :salivate: Can't believe they're open till 10 on a Friday -- so awesome for that after-a-late-dinner dessert hankering.  Because I was rushing, can't fully remember the coffee options. I went with a latte, which was a tasty brew but a little tepid. They switch featured cupcakes out daily so I'm totally enticed to keep visiting -- and taste testing!

Awesome space, fantastic staff and management, great and inexpensive food,... Just plain bad luck. Or maybe bad location. I don't know. Fact is, one of my favorite places in a town that has a lot to offer (food-wise) has recently reduced its hours of operation and modified its business model in a direction that preoccupies me. We'll see. "Allez Madame, hang in there!".
The sitting/dining area is between the counter and the open kitchen, where you can witness magic happen. Comfy, cozy, clean, yummy, relaxed, hip and simply a gem.

I went to Bliss 1.5 hours after their website said they opened.  They told me that their cupcakes weren't baked for the day and asked me if I'd like to place an order.  I told them what I wanted and the guy, who was very very uninterested in being polite, said, "let me check... those might be ready."  While I waited for them to finish, I asked for an iced coffee.  They told me they'd have to go get the ice.  How about a hot coffee.. they didn't have any.  So he handed me an iced coffee, filled to the brim, and didn't offer me any milk, cream or sugar.  Gee... thanks?  After a 15 minute wait, they handed me the cupcakes without eye contact or a smile.  The cupcakes are decent but nothing to write home about and certainly not worth the awful customer service.

Yay!

This place is pretty awesome! 
First, located in the court yard, there is a little fountain outside which is extremely nice for a summer and nice fall day!  I would definitely take advantage of this in the future.
Second, the decor is extremely cute and interesting.  The brick walls give you a rustic feeling but modern and cute art decoration upgrade it a notch.  Give you kind of a mixture of both the old and new.
Third:  Service is very good.  The owner is extremely attentive and very responsive as well.  It's a slow night and one of the customers ask for a change in music, he would do that!!!  
And last but not least, the cupcake is actually pretty good!!!  I love the chocolate ganache.  IT is definitely my favorite.
They also have a vegan carrot walnut cupcake.  I know it's a long name... however I have to say... some people go vegan because they allergic to certain ingredients.  Walnut is one of a very common allergen.  So maybe next time they could cut the walnut and try some other things like raisins.  

Overall experience, very good!! I would definitely take some friends to come back and try more stuffs.

Not a coffee drinker so I can't say anything about the coffee. :)

Half off from 5:30 to 7:30 is a great plus as well!!!

I went to Chapel Hill for a visit in January and was super excited to stumble upon this place. The cupcakes here are amazing, they melt in your mouth and are super buttery and sweet (but not obnoxiously sweet). The selection is great too. I wanted to hit this place up everyday I was in town, but on Sunday they were closed, so I ventured up the street to Sugarland for my cupcake fix. Not the same...not even close! So, if you need some sugah and coffee, go here. Loved it! The owner is really nice too, I'm sure all the staff are as well :)

Coming from Boston, we kind of have, um, controversy among our cupcakes.  This will explain: http://www.kickasscupcakes.com/Flash/episode2/episode2.html 

That being said, I've noticed that Chapel Hill cupcakes are much more laid back, bringing me to Bliss Boutique.  Hidden within the Courtyard on the western side of Franklin Street, BBB is a nice little bakery with a patio area outside.  It's also just away from the hustle and bustle of Franklin Street, giving it a more intimate feel.

The cupcakes themselves are quite good, and a nice little treat at $2.50 a pop.  I ended up with the Vegan Cookies and Cream one (I'm not vegan, but it had an Oreo sticking out of it, and I thought that was fun :) ).  The cupcake had great frosting and good cake area, and wonderful consistency.

They're decently sized considering, and if you get there between 5:30 and 7:30, it's CUPCAKE HAPPY HOUR! :D  (1/2 price for cupcakes).  So cupcakes are about $1.35 after taxes during that time.  A great deal for a nice end of day treat.

Service is also excellent, so overall it's a very good little hidden gem off to the side of Franklin Street.

Bliss...the clouds' envy--the other side of sweetness in heaven.   

Yes, indeed there are various eating lifestyle cupcakes here, like vegan as the other reviewer mentioned.  Perhaps their vegan cupcake didn't hit the spot for them, but let me tell you I am NOT a vegan honey and I unintentionally bought the option of that day (which unfortunately I don't recall at the moment--yikes I know!), but it ROCKED my world--I was blown away!! Honestly, when I think of vegan-- I think dry, boring and bland...but  not this vegalicious cup cake blissfulness!  My mouth is watering just thinking about it...

The coffee is from the local Counter Culture folks and is simply lovely, and these guys whip up some good cappuccinos, lattes, espressos and americanos, as well as, multiple tea options.  

 This is the previous location of 3 cups, for those of you who frequented the location as did I.  This is a great location for the kids to play outside a bit after having their sweets and burn off some of that energy.  It's getting warm and the beautiful fountain and outdoor seating is there waiting for you so go ahead and sashay on over there for your tasty treat.  

I must say one of my favorite managers/customer service people there is Rickey, he has excellent customer service, he's highly knowledgeable about their product line and extremely professional; not to mention friendly and hospitable.

I can't get over how adorable this place is and how friendly and helpful the staff are.  I absolutely adored my vegan chocolate pecan coconut fudge cupcake and my husband loved his vanilla with vanilla buttercream.  Also, the hot chocolate is out of this world.   We sat for nearly an hour, playing cards and writing in the book of bliss---where you anonymously fill in personal answers to various questions about your past, present, and future---and it was just the perfect stop on a chilly winter afternoon!

My friend and I are visiting from Rhode Island and I have never tasted a more delicious cup cake in my life! I got the vanilla buttercream cupcake and it was absolutely amazing. We met the owner, who is an extremely sweet guy as well. The place is really cute and modern inside and feels very comfortable. I would definitely recommend this place if you're looking to cure your sweet tooth!

business.full_address:
1 Providence Pl
Downtown
Providence, RI 02903
business.name: Providence Place Cinema

reviews.text: Watching Bridesmaids, which was a fantastic movie...but the soundproofing sucks. I have no idea what movie was next door, but I could constantly hear the bass rattling through the walls which was annoying and unacceptable.

This venue is clean with nice seats, a nifty ticket machine that allows one to bypass human interaction with the folks selling tickets if one so desires, and Icees behind the concessions counter. I just want to know why, with the temperature outside a mere fifteen degrees, the theater was kept so cold that I had to wear my coat, scarf, and hat for the entire duration of the film. We watched "Letters From Iwo Jima" and I almost found myself longing for the heat and humidity of Japan's southern islands. Almost. Couldn't some of that exorbitant ticket price be put toward proper heating? Yeesh.

I don't love that the theatre is in the mall.  There can be chatterboxes sitting in the seats with you and it can be a pain to navigate the crowds in the food court to get to it.  Parking, for anything at Prov Place, is a pain.  

The seats, however, are

Like any other big movie place, the snack prices are ridiculous. I hate that there's a food court right outside, but you can't bring any of that food in. Instead your options are horrible pizza, nachos, or hot dog.  Stick with the basic popcorn and you'll be fine.  

The best part of Providence Place Cinema is that they have $6 movie night on Tuesdays.  Still more expensive than when I was a kid, but better than paying $10 dollars.

It would be great if everyone got off their phone.... I seriously saw someone pull out an ipad! The girl next to me was on facebook.  Ridiculous and distracting, it's obnoxious that the cinema doesn't do more to prevent it.
Other than that....  It's convenient and the pricing is typical.

This is your typical humongoid mall movie theater. The theaters all have stadium seating and larger comfy seats with plenty of leg room. For someone to walk by all you need is to sit up and stop slouching and you don't get a bunch of butt in your face. I appreciate this because I always seem to sit in the row where everyone needs to get up. They have many showings of all the recent big name movies. With a student ID it's only $8 and all movies are $6 on Tuesdays. They also have a military discount. The snack bar is large if you plan on grabbing a movie snack (please chew with your mouth closed.) They have a new area in there with a full bar, not sure if you can take the alcohol into the movie or not though.

The only reason I head over to the cinema at Providence Place is because there are pretty much no other theaters in Providence. 

Like other major/newer theaters, the only true plus is that you can purchase your tickets at a kiosk rather than wait in line. The seats aren't terrible but the seats were state of the art probably about 10 years ago when the mall opened. This might come off as a bit snobby or asking for too much, but for the price I am paying for a ticket, they really have to update the seats. Newer captains style chairs might be nice along with having the cup holders to retract so you can be comfy. 

Food choices there are a little strange along with the "loungey" type area. You guys do know there is a food court right outside. They actually might benefit by having some food court style choices within the movie theater that might lure others away from the food court. I have seen this at some theaters near my old house. 

Like others have said the cleanliness of the bathrooms is a little suspect. They rarely stagger the movie times so the bathroom before and after is pretty busy. 

I have to go to this theater because of the lack of choices in the area but they do need to work just a little bit more on updating it since it has opened.

Nothing extremely negative or positive to say about this theater.

It's your usual, run-of-the-mill, mall movie theater.  The theaters are rather large, stadium seating, and usually pretty clean.  You have your usual annoying teenagers now and then but for the most part I enjoy my movie-going experience.  

They offer discounts for students, veterans, and on Tuesdays all movies for everyone is only six bucks! Not too shabby of a deal.  There is also a an IMAX theater, if that floats you boat.  It pains me to pay full price for a movie nowadays (I mean come on, 11$ for a movie. WTF).  You will usually find me here on Tuesdays for the awesome deal.  Most likely for a horror flick or indie film because most blockbusters bore me.  

See you at the movies!

Here is yet another place that is difficult to rate.  When I was 17/18 this theater just opened and I was here every weekend catching a midnight show.  I loved this place.  Now I'm older, it's different.  Same theater as I remember, comfortable seats, great acoustics, everything you'd expect from a movie theater.

My problem:  it's in Providence Place Mall.  I was once that 17-18 year old, and now they annoy me.  The chatter, the cell phone, the rudeness (not all, but a good portion) and the staff don't really seem to mind.  

In RI we don't have many options.  I usually try and go to the theater in Lincoln, however this one once and a while is ideal and I end up here.  I don't mind it, but now I find myself going during the afternoon than evening showings.  I wouldn't not come here, but I'd prefer to go elsewhere given the option.

It is just a movie theater. Props for being clean, and running films on time without too many commercials. It seems a little more expensive because there is no student discount, so I took a star off. Once, the screen projection was a bit shitty, so minus another.
Also, they have the audacity to post large, multiple NO OUTSIDE FOOD OR DRINK signs when there is a food court right there. And of course it is $5 for a hot dog. 
There is a large number of arcade machines here, and a photo strip booth, which i adore. Points for that. 
If you want to see a movie, come here, bring a bag to smuggle food in, and some quarters if you need to kill time before.

My only complaint about this movie theater is that it's in a mall, so the annoying chatterbox teenagers that talk through the movies get my goat. Other than that, this place is fantastic.

Not only is the seating ample, it's comfey - they have those larger, loungey-type seats that move when you stretch. Also, the leg room between the seats is gorgeous - these are the things that make or break public seating when you're 5'10" with a 34" inseam, and it doesn't go unnoticed or unappreciated here. The bathrooms are fine (if a little untidy when movie-goers are there en-mass), the space manageable and the movie options are more often than not copious. The only food I'd every consider getting at the movies is popcorn, and it's pretty good here. 

I can't complain about the ticket prices, either - they're on par with other cinemas, and for what you get it's worth the parking fee of $2. Again, the annoying teenagers I could do without (I mean, why pay money to talk through a movie you aren't even wathing?!), but I don't mind giving the stink-eye in exchange for my legroom.

Every time I come to this theater I have a bad experience. It came down to the last straw last week and I've decided never to return, even though it is the closest Showcase Cinema to where I live.

First of all, they never open the screen curtain all the way. Ever. That is a major pet peeve of mine (you miss 1/4 of the film!) and they just don't seem to care enough about user experience to open that curtain.

One time I came to see a film and the aspect ratio was completely off. The characters' faces were squished - the reel was obviously not correctly aligned. No one seemed to be doing anything about it, and I wasn't about to watch the movie like that so I had to leave the film (with all my stuff) and go find a manager and tell him about it. I missed about 10 minutes of the movie, but at least the picture was fixed.

The very last time I went to this cinema, when my movie was over I stayed to see the credits, but about 2 minutes into them, the lights went up and about 7 theater staff came in to clean, but instead gathered around the exit (blocking it) and engaged in loud, screamy conversation and laughter until I couldn't deal with it anymore and had to squeeze my way through the group to leave.

I find the staff at this cinema very unprofessional, the theaters untidy, and a complete and utter disregard for audience experience. Which is especially bad now that ticket prices have skyrocketed yet again to $10.50 for non-3D, non-IMAX shows.

A truly horrible cinema, whose doors I will never darken again.

Providence Place Cinemas has a gorgeous setup with a great snack bar.  Which can really make or break a movie cinema for me.  However, not only ave the Tuesday Bargain Deal gone from $6 to $7, but parking has also risen from $1 to $2.  It's really a shame, because the theater and its staff are great, but I have a feeling that business will be declining as people can easily opt for Warwick or Seekonk.

Just your average theater, great location for those who live in Providence. 
 
They do have IMAX here and show just about every movie, and it's right in the mall which dosn't make for a bad way to end a day of shopping or perfect for dinner and a movie.

If your a student be sure to show your id for $8 tickets, and on Tuesdays all movies are $6 for everyone and includes IMAX which is a pretty spiffy deal.

Been reading through the reviews for this place and I just gotta ask, What are you ladies doing in the bathroom?  The mens rooms are at least adequately clean. They're never unuseably gross anyway.  The other thing is that I almost never run into rude/inconsiderate crowds here, and I go see lots of movies.  Don't get me wrong it has happened to me here but it is the exception rather than the rule. The best advice I can give you is don't go see the biggest movies on the biggest nights. And ladies, don't trash the bathroom, other ladies need to use it as well. And aren't you aware that it's someone's job to clean up that shit? And also, shut the fuck up, turn off your cell phone and leave your goddamned kid at home.  Seriously, people are trying to watch the f'ing movie

I try and avoid this cinema like the plague! Honestly every time I come here, it's like Yo! MTV Raps come to life. One time I came here, it was for a 9:40 show on a Saturday night. And there were not one couple but TWO couples in the theater with new born babies! Through out the whole movie all you could hear was crying and the usual new born sounds. This is the exact kind of trash this place attracts. I'm sorry if I come off as offensive or ignorant, but any night of the week, a new born baby should be at home in it's crib, not in a freakin movie theater! Ignorant kids that talk through the whole movie. Cell phones going off, giggling with each other..and it's not even a comedy flick! 

Sorry but I am a firm believer in wearing your pants at your waist, removing the stickers from your hat and wearing it straight.

I would rather take the drive to Patriots Place and hit the De Lux.

You probably won't have many options when it comes to movie theatres if you're in Providence - that is, if you want to see a first-run, non-arthouse film (though there are plenty of independent, local places that do those well!). This will basically be your only option, and it's not a great one.

The layout is decent but slightly confusing. The chairs are above-average and give you tons of room, not that I have long legs and would need it. :) The sound quality is abysmal, though. You know that squeaky/muffled noise when the speakers can't handle the volume (I know how non-technical that is BTW)? It was basically that throughout the whole movie. Thank goodness I was wearing a hooded sweatshirt, since I pulled up my hood and saved myself a bit of ear ache. Still, if it's a movie theatre and they have a few set objectives, you'd think they wouldn't blow this one.

During this time of the year, I end up at the movie theatre a whole heck of a lot more than during the other eleven months. Perhaps it is the end-of-the-year Oscar push, perhaps it is the holidays, or perhaps it is because of the nasty weather and my inability to do anything remotely close to outdoors unless I am wearing a liquid blanket. Whatever it may be, I'm at the cinema a lot in December. 

There are many choices thirty-minute drive from Providence, but the closest (and I would think most convenient) to my pad is the cinema at Providence Place. However, after my experience last week, I'm thinking I will always plan ahead and either hoof it east to Seekonk or Swansea or north to Foxboro. 

I mean, it's a movie theatre. It's not that deep: ticket services, concession stand, the theatre itself, movie presentation, bathrooms. If the theatre itself looks like the popcorn monster puked and the bathroom looks like the ghost of poopers past is still lingering, that's a big fat fail in my book. This is what Providence Place had to offer me. Yes, I appreciated the fact that their pre-purchase ticket machine worked. The sound was good, the movie quality was good, the seats reclined. (For $11 a pop, I'd better get those things!) However, if I can't perform a lightning pee during a movie because of how nasty the ladies' room is - and I certainly couldn't - then I just can't show any love.

The theaters are very large with nice stadium seating.  While I've been there several times I wish more than the IMAX had seats you could reserve.  This just makes the movie experience so much smoother and less of a hassle with getting there early since you know your seat will be there.

They have a very large selection of concessions besides the normal popcorn and candy affair.  Chicken strips, burgers, pizza, funnel cake fries, and a few other items.  Most will take 5-10 minutes as they are made fresh so take that into account if you're cutting it close for the movie.

I've experienced the chatty kids once before but they were asked to leave by management after a warning.  The usher stayed in the theater to keep an eye on them and when they acted up by talking loudly security showed up to escort them out which was nice.

Overall it's a very large theater and if you want to see an IMAX movie it's THE place to go.  The Regal Cinemas in Lisbon is nicer in my opinion and if you don't mind the drive Lux De Lux at Foxborough is very nice with adult beverages and service during the movie.

I have no issues with this theatre itself. The staff is friendly and the place is clean. The movies start on time and the line at the refreshment stand goes pretty fast. The bathrooms are not too bad, usually pretty clean.

All of my downsides for this place are about the fact that it is in a mall. The parking is abundant, but if you go to a midnight showing, you might as well bring a sleeping bag because it takes hours to get out. When the mall closes, trying to get to the lower levels to get to your car is like an evil video game.
This is my movie theater of choice. Mind you, I almost exclusively attend a weekday matinee. Sound and picture quality is excellent and the seats are super comfortable. Also has iMax.

I somewhat enjoy/hate going to this cinema.  The bathrooms are usually trashed and I hate that you have to pay to park to even go to this place.  
I can understand a dollar for 1 to 3 hours, but if you are even over a second, it jumps to five dollars.  WTF mate!  I just paid some serious cheddar to see the movie and get a soda and now I am seriously going to get slapped again when I leave.  It would be great to at least get a voucher or a stamp to get some dollars shaved off of your parking fee.  I am not even asking for free parking!  Just something!

The only thing this place has going for it is $6 movie nights on Tuesday.  That is just about the only reason why I go back.  I just make sure to use the bathroom before I leave to go to the show.  Seriously, it can look like the day after a major party in a frat house and can smell like a porta pot too.  YUCK!

The best thing about this theatre is the automated ticket machines.  This is a pretty big confession on a yelp review, but I look like a child, so can't I buy a child ticket? 

I'm not sure what the reviews below were referring to, but our screen (for Bridesmaids) was fine, the seats were fine, the people were fine, and as for the snacks- they're pretty irrelevant to me.

Providence Place used to be happening.  Now it's getting trashier by the minute, and the movie theater is no exception.  The bathrooms are easily the grossest I've encountered in any movie theater (come on, people, bathroom cleanliness DOES matter).  Also, the fact that the theater is at Providence Place means its patrons must abide by Providence Place's extremely overpriced parking prices for anything over 3 hours.  Why should the price jump from $1 for up to 3 hours to $5 for a minute over 3 hours (and after that it only gets higher... I paid $10 for my parking today!)?  If someone goes to see a longer movie, they may end up spending $5 easily to park their car, in addition to their ticket price.  LAME.  Showcase Cinemas in Warwick and at Warwick Mall have free parking lots.  That's where I usually go, but stupidly decided to go here today since I was already in Providence.  I won't make that mistake again.

business.full_address:
84 Nassau St
Princeton, NJ 08542
business.name: Twist - Yogurt Without Limits

reviews.text: Such a cute, funky spot with delicious dessert.  I love picking my own toppings, it makes me feel 6 years old again!
The frozen yogurt is pretty average but they have a number of flavors.  I liked all of the topping selections - fruits were fresh.  It was a bit pricey but the toppings made it a nice treat!

A lot of people were excited about this place when it first came out, but they have just ok yogurt.  Maybe less than Ok.  They are just not tasty.  However, it is pretty comfortable to sit and talk (if there's space).  Overall, I would say this is a good place to have some dessert and sit and talk.

I just took a trip to the west coast where froyo is everywhere--and cheap! Twist is a highly welcome and opportune (for me!) addition to Princeton. It's considerably healthier than ice cream or gelato; no fat and has all that pro-biotic goodness added. Of course, this doesn't mean I'll be giving up my Bent Spoon or Halo any time soon, but Twist offers a relatively guilt-free product at a great location.

 I've since sampled all of the flavors except for vanilla. My favorite is the EuroTart, followed by Green Tea and then the Original. The topping selection is superb. There is a great assortment of fresh fruits, nuts, granola, mochi**! (and it's good too), and then the unhealthy stuff. Prices were definitely resonable; more expensive than Cali, but muchhhh cheaper than what they rip me off with in DC. 

Twist is open late--midnight on weeknights even! It seems like a great hangout place for students who are looking for somewhere a little different somewhat off campus that's not Starbucks or Panera Bread. Twist also offers free wi-fi, comfy chairs and there's a tv on that always seems to be playing CNN...that seems a bit more DC to me than Princeton, but that's not a bad thing. Oh! And this week they were offering 25% any purchase after 10pm for students. Sweet deal! I went twice :) 

I dock one star because it's simply not as cheap as the froyo I had last week, even with a 25% discount. Also, it's cash only, which is kind of annoying since my bank doesn't have an ATM anywhere in NJ and I have to pay a service fee :P

If I was in the area for more of the year, I would definitely be a regular. Alas, DC beckons tonight. BUT for those who will be sticking around, check Twist out! You will not be disappointed!

I just went for the first time, despite living outside princeton for 2.5 years.  I have been missing out!  I thought the froyo was tasty, but even though others have said it's not the greatest, who cares?  I'm there for the toppings!!  I loved that I could put just 3 gummy bears or 4 m&m's.  Definitely cheaper than cold stone and other places where they charge for each mix-in.  I will definitely be back.  I kind of wish I didn't go there two days ago because it's still all I can think about.

Twist, located in Princeton and Fruity Yogurt, located in New Brunswick, NJ are definitely well placed in ideal locations to tap the huge number of students in their respective areas.  Sadly, they don't taste as good as Yo Mon or Wicked Twist.  Twist does have smoothies and frappes that you can order.  Red Mango, though, also has a wide variety of smoothies, shakes, juices, and teas that you can order from the counter.

Pretty good! Great selections of yogurts. Their tart is one of the best and I definitely recommend the pumpkin (it's fall, it's a crime not to get it). The only odd thing is that they don't let you get your samples yourself. This causes the line to back up and to make you feel like a baby. But whatev good yogurt none the less.

A night in Princeton isn't complete without a visit to Twist. And they constantly change their flavors and toppings so you can always try something new. If you are in the area for dinner do yourself a favor and stop here afterwards for desert!

So I should just say right off the bat that I work here, but with that being said, I absolutely love this place.  I am officially addicted to their frozen yogurt.  They have 8 different flavors.. and they change it up every other week.  Right now they have original tart (my favorite- its creamier than the euro tart), euro tart, raspberry tart, no sugar added strawberry, vanilla, chocolate, mixed berry sorbet and pistachio.   

They now have two sizes of cups.  Large and small.  They are very responsive to customer comments.  The owners are very friendly and at the store almost all the time.  They love their store just as much as their customers, so take a second and say hello to them.  

Their toppings are amazing.  They have tons of fruit... here goes... pineapple, mango, banana, strawberries, kiwi, blueberries, blackberries and peaches.  Sometimes they have raspberries and pomegranate.  The mochi, fruity pebbles and mini gummi bears are for sure my favorite.  But I do mix it up with capn crunch and peanut butter cookie dough.

Most people spend from $3-$5 on yogurt, but so far the least expensive was 47 cents and the most was over $14.   and you get 10% off if you go back for seconds.
