its always a clean and friendly environment. a worker was cleaning the glass door when I showed up and later she was using a tiny handheld mini vac to clean the crumbs and toppings from the counter. their green tea yogurt is pretty good but they don't have it often. service was moving pretty fast which was nice. this is one of my favorite froyo places because it's self serve :) if you go enough, you might even find a picture of yourself mounted on one of the many picture boards. there are artworks mounted throughout the place that are for sale.

The yogurt dispensers are somewhat limited in variety but are pretty tasty. The topping selection is extremely wide. Variations with toppings are exciting and there are endless combinations. The space is sort of awkward but nonetheless a cool hang in Princeton. Great to stop by for a quick treat.

As a Pton student with a big sweet tooth, I used to be a huge Twist fan, at least until Fruity Yogurt (on Nassau beside CVS) came along.  Of all the places I've reviewed on Yelp, Fruity Yogurt is by far my favorite!!  

COST:
Twist is way too expensive, so I used to go less often for froyo but now that I've tried the lower prices at Fruity Yogurt, I get to satisfy my froyo cravings every week!! :) Ahhh I'm so happy haha.

VARIETY:
Twist only has eight types of fro-yo, and I only like two of them consistently, which was good enough for me at the time until I realized the possibilities haha.  There's something for everyone at Fruity Yogurt... it's like Twist but better, more types of fro-yo, more creative flavors, and more depth to the flavors too, and that's just talking about the frozen yogurt (they also serve the best bubble teas I've had here on the East Coast... it's so hard to do well). Just try it and you'll know... it's hard to explain.

TASTE:
This is where Fruity Yogurt beats out Twist most of all, hands down.  Fruity Yogurt uses majority yogurt in its recipes, and it's milk-free in all but two flavors (Cookies n' Cream and Green Tea)... this is great and healthier than froyo that is majority milk-based.  Less preservatives and natural food coloring too! 

I used to be a big fan of Twist but now that I know what the flavors can be like in froyo, I'll never go back unless they change their recipes.

ATMOSPHERE:
This is where Twist has an advantage over Fruity Yogurt, because it's a much larger place with more seating.  On the other hand, at Twist I've sometimes had the displeasure of having to sit near really loud and annoying high schoolers (I guess it's a popular place for them?!).  I like the music at Fruity Yogurt more, and I've never had trouble finding a seat.  I like how Twist has board games and cool art on the walls, but it doesn't overcome the other cons for me.

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
Fruity Yogurt wins hand down.  Twist stole the former cashier at Fruity Yogurt by offering her a manager position.  I saw her working at Twist after being at Fruity Yogurt as the cashier weeks earlier; and that was the last time I went to Twist (I used to go just for the Eurotart flavor).  That's really lame, and one of the main reasons why I would refuse to go to Twist even if Fruity Yogurt somehow moved elsewhere.  

THE VERDICT?
Save your money and go to Fruity Yogurt for more froyo variety, better taste, more for your money, and greater dessert and beverage options!  

Check out my other reviews of places in and around Pton! :)
This place is good. The yogurt is great. The atmousphere is fun and hip. The prices are resonable but you can just sit there and eat till your stomach explodes. Otherwise its great!!

Pinkberry wanna be. The yogurt are not nearly as flavorful and thick as Pinkberry.  The mango flavor yogurt tasted somewhat fake. Everything tasted artificial and watered down

only if there's a Pinkberry or Red Mango in Princeton

Great flavors and fun toppings. This place has a great feel with couches and games. Fill your cup with a great yogurt and add all the toppings you could hope for. Just watch out the cup can get heavy quickly.

This place set up shop before Pinkberry could get here. It's basically the same thing, although it's self serve so you can add whatever toppings you want. (pinkberry charges per topping) Since the price is based on weight, the ability to add whatever toppings you want beats out pinkberry's fixed choices. However, the toppings are tart yogurt aren't as good quality as pinkberry.

All in all, it's a great light snack stop where you can fully customize how much you want to eat and/or spend.

This place is great. I especially like it because they serve frozen yogurt and offer so many healthy toppings. To me - it's guilt free.  Love the pomegranate seeds, fresh blue berries, and flax seed options! But don't be put off by the healthy choices - they have everything else imaginable available if you have a sweet tooth. It's fun too - a sundae bar - so you add what you want - including how much yogurt you want.
Kid love this place.

heaven in a big green paper cup : ) you've read it right- fix your own fro yo and help yourself toppings. some genious thought of this! i mean, really... red velvet fro yo?!?! omg, amazing. 

plus great seating, whimsical enviroment... local artists on display... a real treasure of princeton.

GO HERE... now.
$7.00 for a cup of frozen yogurt? No thanks!  I'll stick to Thomas Sweet!  Went here today for the first time. Liked the whole self-service thing, but there is NO WAY yogurt is worth that much money.

I'm from California so I'm a froyo snob - Twist is mediocre, at best.  If it were good yogurt, I would put up with the expensive price (it is Princeton after all).  However the yogurt is watery and melts in 30 seconds, and I can't stand watery yogurt.  The consistency is much better at Fruity Yogurt, so I avoid Twist as much as I can.

I've gone to twist a few times. Their toppings are choco-licious and since I love getting sugar comas, their toppings are perfect for me. 

However their yogurt isn't so consistent. Once or twice I was blown away by how good the yogurt was. I believe it was strawberry cheesecake and dulce de leche. But most other times, it left a nasty after-taste in my mouth. Example: peppermint candy cane from winter 2010. The yogurt is both watery and creamy, which means they melt fast and lead me to believe the "healthy" yogurt really isn't that healthy. If I was going for creamy, I'd go with Ice Cream. And Princeton has many ice cream places in town that is better tasting and cheaper than twist (like Halo Pub).

They do have some nice games in the sitting area though. Mainly monopoly and sorry. But I never usually stay that long because its dark and unwelcoming.

LOVE IT. Never crowded, the yogurt flavors are always amazing. Red velvet, ghirardelli chocolate, white choc-mint, Mom's PB cookies, etc. 

The toppings bar is AMAZING, all sorts of fruits (kiwi, banana, lychee), cereal (cinnamon toast crunch!), brownies, syrups, caramelized pecans, reese's chunks, etc. 

though it can be expensive.... paid $15 for two huge filled-to-the-brim cups, its so so worth it.

I'm not going to explain how it's setup, as every review basically explains that.

CASH ONLY!

I tried 3 different flavors - Georgia Peach, Cookies and Cream, Ghiradelli chocolate. I found all 3 to be weak in terms of flavor and texture. Georgia peach tasted peachy but not necessarily ZOMG TASTY NOMS! It was more of a "hrm...this isn't bad." The other two tasted plain. Not a hit of cookies or cream, and chocolate was about as chocolately as plain yogurt - not very.

The saving grace is the do it yourself - you get as much or as little yogurt as you want. I think that's awesome when you're wanting just a ~little~ something sweet but don't have anyone to share with and don't want to buy a full serving at say Thomas Sweet.

Do-it-yourself toppings are a nice touch as well. They had a huge variety of fresh and canned fruits along with all the traditional toppings, plus a few unique ones (cinnamon toast crunch cereal, mochi, cheesecake bites [which were kinda icky, but still unique]).

3.5 starsss.

  I mean, the yogurt itself isn't that good compared to a lot of other Froyo places but hey, this town could use a trendy little thing like Twist.   Their frozen yogurt is kinda watery rather than creamy but  their sheer selection of toppings makes up for it.  I love their original tart flavors as well as the chocolate and cheesecake.  As I said before, the toppings choices are endless - there's every kind of fruit imaginable (including some exotic ones like longyan), nuts, cookies, mochi, granola, seeds, cake, the list goes on and on and on.  The greatest thing is that it's all self serve so you can put as much froyo and toppings as you want!

The place is nicely decorated and personal, with lots of photos of customers, and they've recently added a bunch of colorful paintings by a local artist.  The only downside is they're cash only, which is a little inconvenient sometimes but then again, a lot of businesses in Princeton are like that so it's not a big deal.

One of my favorite froyo spots! I feel like Koreans are really into it, so there was an explosion of froyo places up north, but none compare to Twist.

I love how Twist offers so many non-fat flavors/seasonal flavors, and they have a huge fixing bar. I recently tried their popping bobas from their fixing bar which I liked. Their Ghiradelli chocolate froyo is excellent if you're craving chocolate. I also loved their pumpkin flavor froyo. Their regular euro-tart is good - just the right amount of tanginess.

The best part is that at the end, I end up having this huge cup full of toppings, but the price doesn't reflect that at all! You could never get this much at any place up in north Jersey.

*TIP: It's cash only so be prepared to bring the greens!

Okay, so I've been back like, COUNTLESS times this summer since getting home. 
I'm addicted. I go with vanilla yogurt, strawberries, oreo crumbs, lots of mocchi bits (adds a grew chewiness without the sugary blast of gummis), hot fudge and Reese's cup bits. Nom nom nom...

And considering how much I pile on, their prices are super reasonable. Plus refills are reduced price, so if you think you'll want more, split with a pal and then go back for seconds!

I very rarely write updates because honestly -- when you have 100 more places to write reviews about, why bother writing a review about the same place twice? But I think Twist merits an update, because I reviewed it when it first opened, and it has definitely made plenty of improvements since then.

Without ever meeting the owners of Twist, I can tell that they care. They have suggestion boxes and almost everything I nitpicked on back in December has been improved or completely revamped. Fruit offerings are wide and varied, even more so than pinkberry. This is not to say that some of it isn't frozen -- some strawberries i've tried have been on the hard side -- but they offer canned longan, pineapple, blackberries, peaches, blueberries, pomegranate etc... more types of fruit than I can stuff in my little cup. They also now offer 2 cup sizes so you don't feel like an absolute glutton when you bring your $7 cup to the register; I can happily fill up on the small size and have it total under $5.

But more so than anything else, Twist has improved on the previously mundane decor by having paintings by a local artist all over the store. The art is cheery, eclectic and quite interesting to look at. It doesn't have the commercial hip, trendy feel of Pinkberry, but it is warm, inviting, and they actually WANT you to sit and stay! Pinkberry's decor for sure is very chic, but those wire chairs aren't exactly intended for comfort. There have been times when I've felt that the chairs are designed so you don't linger too long, so the next customers can sit too. It's not that way at Twist at all. People linger and hang out because the leather chairs are comfortable and no one will ever bother you. While I said in my first review that Twist lacks a lot of the charm of Pinkberry and Red Mango, I can safely say that this isn't true anymore. I find that there's something slightly boring now about the decor and feel of the millions of froyo places that dot the city. If anything, Twist brings a fresh perspective (or twist you could say) of what it means to be a small business reinterpreted on the back of a raging fad.

You know this kind of place- Self-serve FroYo by the ounce. The question is, is it good and not overpriced?

Answer: Twist's yogurt is in the top 20% of FroYos out there. Their specialty is non-fat, live culture, tart yogurt. This forms their base yogurt to which they add flavours. The flavours are actually tasty and resemble their names and the yogurt tastes like something you couldn't get at the grocery store. As for cost, 45 cents an ounce isn't too steep. A pretty big half-pound serving adds up to about $6 then, which isn't that bad in comparison to any other ice cream place. Their topping selection is also varied and the cut fruits are fresh. 

For Princeton, it's definitely the best yogurt out there.

They call themselves a "frozen yogurt lounge" which makes me picture rich, skinny women in red spandex laying back on chaise lounges with their pursed lips only slightly open as the frozen yogurt drips from the spigot. Broad-shouldered frat boys fan them as the women snap their fingers to have them stop the spigots. But no, Twist just looks like a Starbucks with eight flavors of self-serve yogurt instead of lattes and electric yellow walls that are anything but soothing.

So who cares? It's a major college hangout with big sitting areas, all occupied of course, like the annex to a campus study hall. I was relegated to a side counter where I had a combination mix of Mom's Peanut Cookie and Raspberry Cheesecake with berries and shredded toasted coconut on top, all for about 44-cents per ounce (see photo). It was definitely on the creamy end of the tartness spectrum, probably the sugar rush these students needed to get through finals. It was definitely the sugar rush I needed before heading back to the hotel to write work emails that night.

FROYO - 3 stars...pretty creamy stuff for the sweeter tooth
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...it's a lounge, dude
SERVICE - 3 stars...it's self-serve, dude
TOTAL - 3 stars...a study hall with calories

Great addition to Princeton. I tried several of the other flavors through sample cups that you can get from them (a very nice benefit), but stuck with the eurotart original, the classic flavor most likely what you'll find at red mango/pinkberry/other chains.

fruit toppings were generously big and the mango slices were ripe. .49/oz is a little bit more expensive than i've seen in other serve yourself yogurt shops, but since you choose how much you want to put in you can adjust accordingly. 

and the free samples and service is great - local college students work here and were very helpful. 

also, i enjoyed the pictures hanging on the walls and the games/books in the lounge area - great place to hang out, and i wish this was here when i was a student! but then i'd have spent all my $$ here, so that might not have been so good for my budget.

I've been to Twist a couple of times and I adore the store's atmosphere. The comfy couches, board games, and stools are what make Twist different than any other yogurt place. Other yogurt places appear modern, whereas Twist is more traditional, casual, and laid-back. In the back of the store is where the yogurt is. All of the yogurt is self-served with flavors like chocolate, eurotart, mango, pomegranate, etc. There are also a lot of toppings to choose from. My favorites are longan, lychee cubes, and mochi. After that, a worker will weigh your yogurt and it's 44 cents per ounce. I'm not a giant fan of frozen yogurt but I prefer Pinkberry over Twist. Pinkberry's yogurt has a richer taste and more flavor than Twist's. This is a good place to go to with friends and family but I'll stick to my Pinkberry in NYC :P

I am crazy for F.Y. And I love this place The atmosphere, the bright walls and quirky paintings. Self-serve is awesome -it really is. And the variety is pretty good for the toppings. I had pumpkin cheescake, with cheesecake crumbs, gingersnaps and bananas on top. 

Its real refreshing and comfortable!

I'm kind of surprised that there is only one "$" for the price range. Twist is expensive and the quality of frozen yogurt isn't deserving of the price tag in my opinion. I go back here because they don't have much competition, and their seating area is plentiful. I really like that they sell art there to support local artists, which at one point served as very colorful, beautiful decor. Often times the frozen yogurt is runny and there really isn't THAT much variety since the flavors don't change very often. 

This place got a third star for their seating and dog treats, and I just thought, what the hell. Princeton needs to step it up
A healthier option than ice cream with lots of great toppings

Froyo by the ounce!  Visited with the wife and kids after dinner.  The boys loved it.  One loved plain choc/vanilla twist and the other loved the myriad of toppings.  I enjoyed it more than I thought would.  The coconut and red velvet froyo was very good

I love this place. I'm not a big fan of frozen yogurt but I really like this place. The selection of toppings is amazing. My favorite is cookie dough chunks and these pink liquid balls that are some type of fruit (Bubba?) They are SO COOL. So far my favor

Frozen Yogurt, or "Froyo" as I like to call it, has really been making it big in this area. I had never heard of Cups, which is a big chain of frozen yogurt stores, but a friend of mine was a huge fan so we decided to see if Twist compared.

I want to say there are about 10 flavors to choose from, and they change often. You can try any flavor you like in a small sample cup, so if you arent sure, ask! Then you won't be dissatisfied later. 

You then get a big cup and put whateverrrrr you like in it. I like the option to mix and match, and not have to be limited like if you were ordering from a normal ice cream place.

I love the peanut butter/chocolate swirl combo. By love, I mean I would kill for it right about now. They have a TON of toppings. You can go healthy and choose granola, nuts, and fresh fruit for your yogurt, or you can be like me and throw cookie dough, cheesecake bites, and nutella on it. To each his own! 

Then you weigh it and pay. It's 53 cents an ounce I believe, which trust me adds up fast. Things can get pricey here. It is tempting to completely fill the huge cup they give you, but trust me you won't eat that much anyway. 

There's cute sitting area inside and out and it's kid friendly. What more could you want? I'm a new froyo convert now, and I see many trips to twist in my future.

Between Bent Spoon, Thomas Sweet, and Halo Pub, the ice cream market in Princeton is getting pretty crowded. That said, Twist is a pretty unique and tasty alternative if you want healthier frozen yogurt instead. Flavors change here pretty regularly, although the traditional, tart yogurts are always available. Both the mango and the strawberry yogurts were quite good; my wife also tried and very much liked the green tea. Lots of mixers are available, including more exotic fruits and nuts than are typically available in this kind of place. Price is by the ounce depending on the size of your bowl and payment is cash only.
Pay by the ounce - several base flavors to pick from & then you add your own toppings. Good selection of fruit, chocolate, candy & baked goods to top your yogurt with. Super yummy!

Anyone familiar with the frozen yogurt episode of Seinfeld? You should expect similar enthusiasm at this place. The yogurt is VERY milky (as opposed to yogurty/fruity). They've got about 8 flavors, with a few of them in rotation, and a pretty extensive bar of toppings. I recommend the Eurotart.

Kind of pricey for a cup of yogurt, but otherwise really great. Plenty of seating all the time, open late.

Twist is a good alternative to all the ice cream places around Princeton. It's no Bent Spoon, but I made several trips here during my last months at Princeton. Sometimes froyo is a nice alternative to ice cream. 

You would never think this place was so large by the outside, but there is plenty of room to sit inside as well as a TV and paintings throughout the seating area. 

It's self-serve so you can mix flavors and toppings at your discretion. But the pricing is by weight, so just keep that in mind! 

Tips: 
1) If you go near closing time, sometimes they will let you take containers of certain flavors home for free! 
2) CASH ONLY, like a lot of places in Princeton.

Not as good as fruity yogurt or halo. The yogurt is def watered down...They did have tons of great toppings and there was room to sit. This is an okay place but def other places are better if you just want it due to the taste. The price was reasonable and they do have a whole wide range of flavors. Some of the yogurts were just too sweet to get anything besides a sample of. The tart/eurotart was the one i thought was too watered down. You can atleast grab the yogurt, pay in cash (cash only), and sit outside on a nice day since they have chairs outside.

With all of the Frozen Yogurt franchises (Pink Berry, Red Mango, Fro Yo) it's refreshing to find an independent, place that does frozen yogurt with it's own a "twist".  

You walk into the store and are greeted by a dimly lit, inviting, lounge feel. As your eyes adjust to the darker room, you will see books on the shelves, art work,  assorted board games, semi plush sofas, chairs/tables and leather lounges adorning the walls and seating area.  They even have a piano if you feel so inclined.    

You walk to the back of the store where you will find 6 frozen yogurt machines stocked with creative and ever changing flavors.  A friendly staff is there to answer your questions and offer a samples of the yogurt. Once your done filling your cup with Fro Yo, you can shuffle over to the toppings bar.  The toppings section  is large and host a large variety of fix ins (cookie dough, Kit Kat's, Resses, Pineapple, Mangos etc). Load up with as much stuff as you would like.  Don't forget save room in your cup for the caramel, whip cream and the sprinkles.  

Place your Frozen Yogurt masterpiece it on the scale and you will be charged a very reasonable price by weight.  I always try to support, small and local business.

Twist has great frozen yogurt that is delicious.  My daughter loves the Cheesecake flavor, and my son loves the Peanut Butter Cup flavor.  Both of my kids love the games and reading the Yogurt Timeline.  Maraschino cherries are AMAZING!!!!!
We stop by here anytime we are in or around Princeton.  Their Eurotart yogurt is great, and a with some fresh fruits and nuts... it makes for a low sugar treat!

i am a bossy person. i like things done my way. and i'd always rather do everything myself.
so i love self-serve fro yo. 

i got the euro-tart and loaded it up with mochi, raspberries & strawberries. the fruits were nice and fresh but GOOD GOD that mochi is terrible! ick!!!!!!!

the yogurt itself was okay. nothing special, but just alright.

the atmosphere inside is kinda weird so do yourself a favor and sit outside on nassau street!

Tonight when I went to Twist, I was given a plastic Twist cup for free and told that whenever I use the cup, I will get 10% off my purchase. A great idea to get people to reduce waste! Just make sure they tare the weight of the plastic cup - it weighs $1 more than the paper cup.

Flavors change weekly.
I love the eurotart! I'm also a fan of the green tea and taro.
I am usually disappointed in the fruit flavors.
The strawberry tastes like strawberry quick.
Some flavors are very sweet - especially many of the fruit flavors and sorbets.

Oh, and for whatever reason, this yogurt seems to be addictive.

It's average, at best. Though they have a large variety of flavors and toppings (cherries, nuts, raspberries, etc.), the frozen yogurt is not really that "frozen" after all. It melts in a matter of seconds and leaves you with a sickeningly sugary soup.

The best frozen yogurt in Princeton.
They have a wide varity toppings, you name it, they have it, from fruit, cereal, candy, and one of my favorites , mochi (rice balls). Their frozen yogurt is cool and refreshing, and you help yourself, so you can have as much as you want! I wish I could go there everyday...I highly recomend it !  But if you don't want to be around a bunch of teenagers, I recommend not going during the weekend.

business.full_address:
333 S. Main Street
Downtown Ann Arbor
Ann Arbor, MI 48104
business.name: La Belle Maison

reviews.text:
La Belle Maison just opened in this location early this year. This store has one of the best selections of gifts I have ever seen. They have the cutest baby clothes and this skincare for babies called "noodle and boo". The diaper bags are so cute too!

I also love that they have my favorite Diptyque candles. Which are usually a bit harder to find than the average brand. They also have the amazing Antica home scents. I love all the home accessories. I want to mention that they have very high end antiques here that are beautiful!

It's definitely one of the more interesting and worthwhile stores to stop into on Main Street.

Found some Diptyque candles here as the perfect gift the other day. and i have to say i really like this store!! quite a bit of the store is dedicated to children's items which i have no interest in, but they have a lot of other great gift ideas like french soaps and pillow and things.... and my favorite Louis Ghost Chairs. This store is a bit pricey$$, but only because the items they are selling are luxury goods like Sferra bedding.....and that would make a nice gift....to receive :D

I can't believe I just stumbled upon this place!  Such cute stuff for the little man.  Boutiques with baby stuff kind of freak me out.  I feel like I should be finger painting with him instead of touring boutiques, but it is worth a look, especially for gift shopping.

They have accessories for your home as well, but since I have a son I paid more attention to the baby section.  I'll admit, it was very bousgie-cute.  It is definitely a place you'd want to hit if you want to stray from someone's Baby's R Us gift registry.

For around a year I've been wondering what's in this store. Finally, I checked: not one thing that I would buy for myself or for a gift. 

The imported French baby clothes don't appeal to me much -- not even for my new-born niece. The antiques are uninteresting. The overall selection is really small considering that it's a very large store. 

I guess I don't have any idea about what's popular: I wouldn't have expected this place to last for a year. I'm clueless: who would want this fake-antique pretentious stuff?

business.full_address:
2799 Broadway 108th St
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Cascabel Taqueria

reviews.text:
The tacos are great, if a bit expensive. Certainly not the most authentic you can get, but very tasty. 

The service is mediocre, and delivery can be ridiculously slow (more than an hour on more than one occassion). I'll echo other people's comments about repeatedly having to flag down waiters/waitresses even when the place isn't that busy, and being rushed. 

Overall, maybe worth a try if you're nearby, but it's really not worth all the trouble in terms of slow delivery/poor service just for good tacos, especially when there are comparable options nearby (e.g., Taqueria y Fonda).

Maybe it was the heat.  Maybe it was $4 + per taco it costs for a small taco.  Maybe it was the tiny tables...too tiny for not such cheap food.  And I know this sounds petty, but it was definitely the fact that you couldn't "mix and match" your two tacos for $8.50...they had to be the same flavor.  

I know other reviewers loved the "early luchador style," but I was not as impressed.

Having said that, the food wasn't bad.  so the third star for that. But because of the relative expense and small, cramped tables, I am not running back.

Picked a good day to come- Monday, Taco flight day. So I was able to order four different tacos to try-chicken, carne asada, chorizo, and carnitas for $12. They also had a beer flight, but im not into beer so I skipped. They had a good selection of margaritas-but no specials on them :( They also had negra modelo on tap which my bf loves. The decor is cute and colorful with images of La Loteria, Luchadores, etc. 

The taco I liked best was the carne asada but did not LOVE it. They also offer three tacos for $11.75 for LUNCH. I dont think I could order 2tacos for $8.50- that's $4.25 per taco, yikes! I would return for a snack but not a complete meal. I would like to see some drink specials that would entice me to come back. Not my favorite taco place but somewhere I can return to if the mood strikes.

Been there twice and ordered from them.  I have no problem with the food.  The corn with the cheese and the spices is amazing.  I've tried the chorizo tacos and the pork butt (don't ask) tacos which were also tasty.  Additionally, their house margarita is
Tacos are delish, but a little pricey, although not by UWS standards. Good beer choices.

Tasty tortilla soup, blankets for protection from the chilly night air, and guac with a healthy zip of garlic. Woo hoo, I can't wait to go back!!! 

Lots of yelp complaints about the service, but luckily, that wasn't the case for us, despite the fact that we dined on a busy Friday night. 

Fab menu: a nice mix of entrees and sides and smaller plates. Great for someone like me, who wants to try everything! 

The food was beautifully presented: my tortilla soup looked like a work of art, topped with a giant pepper and sprinkled with cheese. Corn on the cob, drizzled with cheese and spices. Adorable little gorditas filled with tender pork. My friend and I stuffed ourselves to the point of embarrassment, all the while discussing what we wanted to try the NEXT time we visited! 

I was a bit bummed by the "quesadilla" which was about three inches in diameter, deep fried, and served in a wax paper bag. Hmmmm, not at all what i was hoping for. 

A WORD OF WARNING: On seamless web, the prices are a $1 higher per item than to eat in.  That's a pretty steep increase when you consider that many items on the eat-in menu are $6 $7 or $8. 

Overall, a great meal and a gem of an addition to the UWS.

We love this place for the happy hour. $6 delicious fresh margaritas - the regular one has a great smoky-cayenne-salt rim, and the watermelon basil and cucumber ones are both delish too. The apps are interesting, petite, yummy, and not super expensive. Don't expect free chips. The guacamole was not impressive for the price - clearly made ahead of time and refridgerated, which for $8.50 seems like cheating in a city of amazing made-to-order guac (Picante in Harlem does this exceptionally well for $6). Nice outdoor seating, though the building's scaffolding takes away from the atmosphere, but even indoors is great in good weather because the front of the restaurant is all open. Really this place is about the margaritas and tacos and that corn on the cob appetizer thingy, and that's enough to keep me coming back for happy hour.

Dining near Columbia involves either:
1. Hordes of Columbia students so thick that you have to wait ages for food and then can't get a seat...and the food is mediocre anyway
2. Ridiculously high prices for tiny amounts of food

Pick two. Yes, you can get better food elsewhere in Manhattan, but obviously you are in the area for reasons other than food. Cascabel Taqueria is a good choice. It's pretty expensive, but the ingredients are very good. The street is lined with restaurants that are expensive and use crap ingredients. The upside to the price is that there aren't hoards of people here like there are at nearby Chipotle, which is quite a bit cheaper and also uses good ingredients. The service is also much better and I love the variety and the hot sauce. 

So yeah, I'd rather be eating at Tortilleria Nixtamal in Queens (where I could get 10 tacos for the price of 3 here), but I work in the neighborhood and this is a very satisfying option.

When this place opened I was excited, the atmosphere looked fun, inviting, and it was always packed. My boyfriend and I made it a point to come and try this place before we moved out of the neighborhood. 

we ordered the blue crab appetizer, which was decent, but overpriced for the serving size (3 ping pong ball sized). We then ordered shrimp tacos and carnitas. They all came on the same plate, which was really annoying as they are messy to separate. Another reviewer had the same complaint. The tacos were about 1/4th the size of a normal taco and truly flavorless. My shrimp tacos had a few baby shrimp and about 6 black beans sprinkled on top. The carnitas were bland, and again VERY tiny. The only thing that saved the meal was drowning the flavorless doll sized tacos with the 3 types of salsa they had on the table. We skipped dessert, and left hungry, pissed, and out $30.

A bit on the pricey side, but good food.  Tried a beef burrito, which was very tasty and just the right size so I didn't feel grossly overstuffed.  Also tried beef tacos which were topped with very thinly sliced fried crunchy onions.  Delish! 

People at the next table had fish tacos which looked very good - that's what I'll be trying next time!

I have been waiting for this place to open since they took over the vacant Thai restaurant on the corner. Being from Southern California, I have been in search for some good Mexican style food to satisfy my hungry tummy. When they posted their menu to their store front window, I would stop by weekly, teasing my taste buds with their delicious sounding menu. 

Today was their grand opening and believe me, I rushed there as soon as I could. Walking in, the place reminded me of a LA Pink Taco with a friendly taqueria set up. As I walked up to the bar to place my take out order, I was greeted by the bartender who kindly handed me over to a server. I ordered the two tacos, one pescado and one camaron. The server sweetly corrected me that I cannot mix tacos for one order, so I asked him which was better? He genuinely told me the shrimp was better, and with that, I trusted my first order with him. Also, because I am the kind of person who loves to go BIG when I eat, I added the pricey guacamole with tostadas. Just couldn't resist. 

As I waited, I strolled through the menu once more and made mental notes of what I was going to order next. What can I say, food really excites me. They have Elote Asado, Mexican style street corn, which shoots me back to childhood memories of the friendly street vendors with grocery carts by my house. 

The best part however was when the cute bartender came over to me and offered a homemade specialty organic margarita on the house to celebrate their grand opening. My eyes lit up!!! Free alcohol in the middle of day, OF COURSE!!! The margarita was rimmed with smokey paprica and a wedge of lime. However, the best part, the margarita itself. Not too overwhelming with the tequila flavor and believe me, I love the taste of tequila. Instead it was well balanced and exactly what a first margarita should taste like. 

When my order arrived from the kitchen, I rushed home to devour my meal. The camaron tacos hit a good spot. A good amount of shrimp, black beans, pickled red onion, a charred jalapeno and lime wedges within 2 warm corn tortillas, perfect. The guacamole did not disappoint as well. I ordered it high medium spicy and it was really delicious. I am a fan of lime and the guac had a nice little tang. The tostado chips were still warm and just complemented the guacamole. 

All in all, I will be coming back and I hope that the service continues to stay up to par. The one thing holding me back from a 5 star rating is the high prices. I would never pay this much back home in CA but to satisfy my craving out here in NY, so close to my apartment, not to mention the good quality ingredients, yes... I will save my monies just to make a weekly trip here.

I had been hearing about Cascabel from friends who had been to the UES location.  My husband and I rushed out to check it out and left disappointed.
The steak was amazing.  So were the radishes side dish.  The chorizo, which is apparently house-made, was delicious.  The space is fun - the best part is that they have arranged the outdoor seating area into like a porch.  It looked like a charming place to sit.  
And now, on to the minuses.  And there are plenty.
Margaritas.  The classic flavor tasted like it had been made with RealLime juice.  The stuff that comes out of a plastic lime.  It was sour and bitter, but not in a good way.  I ordered a rum and coke, and the server had to "check" with the bar to see if they could make it.  They did, but it was warm and flat.  
Special requests to ask to leave something off of a dish -- say, if you have a food allergy, or you're just picky -- will not be accommodated.  When asked if it was possible to leave a sauce off of the steak, the server said "Well, the kitchen is really picky about special requests because we're so busy."  One special request was accommodated; the other was ignored.
The tacos: the chorizo tacos, while delicious, were just plops of chorizo in tortillas (with the big pile of onions that I hadn't wanted).  Could have used some crunch or some green - or something.  My husband's tuna tacos were bland.
I am sure the metal trays are intended to be cute or quaint.  They bummed my husband out.  Moving the tacos (which could be messy) from tray to tray was really a messy.
Then, petty squabbles: Not enough room on the tables because the space is being taken up by napkin dispensers.  No air conditioning.  Stuff like that.
Frankly, with Noche Mexicana and Cafe Frida in the neighborhood, I won't bother to go back.

Went here as part of a group and the food was all very good. We had a bunch of the appetizers including the guacamole, the queso, crab/corn cakes, and gorditas - those were hard to eat. I wouldn't order the green onions again, nobody really ate that and there was so much food, I don't think we touched the black beans and quinoa. Only a few people ordered tacos, but those were all good.

The setup was a big awkward for our group as we were split between a bunch of smaller tables and some of us were stuck at a hightop table on stools. There wasn't much room on the tables for all the food.

Service was pretty good, but there were definitely times where you'd need to go up and interrupt the waiter who was talking to other waiters in the corner - a bit hard to get their attention. He also didn't go out of his way to keep checking in on us. You are given these little trays as plates and then there was silverware at the end of the table. Midway through though, a busboy came and cleaned up all our plates and silverware and then more food came out so we had to ask for everything again.

i gave this 4 stars because the food itself is good. I'm not sure this is the best place for a large group (20 people), but I'd definitely go back with just one or a few others.

Great decor.  Fresh food and ingredients. I usually find Mexican greasy and heavy but this is true, simple Mexican taqueria food.  The salad was fresh.  The meat (both carne asada and carnitas) juicy and delicious.  The agua fresca was so refreshing.  Some new opening growing pains but I have a feeling all will be ironed out over time.

Tasty tacos!  Mucho picante for all who are not afraid of the heat.  Place is always packed.  They squeeze everyone into tiny tables.  Small price to pay for some well needed Mexican flair in the UPW hood.  Margheritas pack a punch.  So many types of tequilas.  Only sip the best.  Fun vibe with the lucha libre pics throughout.  Outdoor space if you don't want the cramped style inside.  Will mos def go back and explore more of the menu.  Buen provecho!

I really want to give Cascabel four stars. But I can't. 

At it's best, Cascabel is truly excellent. But it's uneven and pricing as if it is hitting the high notes with everything. 

This is fresh, flavorful Mexican that is authentic and a definite step above street food in Mexico. They want to be La Esquina for Uptown. But they haven't got it quite right. Make a few more trips downtown and study La Esquina closely!

Some of the tacos (esp. carnitas) are really excellent. The margaritas are blended perfectly. But the elote callejera (grilled corn), which in the right hands is a revelation, is here a disappointing mess. 

Cascabel is still much better than Papasito's a few blocks down Broadway. And better, as well, than the faux Mexican at Mama Mexico even further down Broadway.

I will try them from time to time. Still hoping to fall in love.

Such a great addition to the neighborhood! 

Delicious margaritas that don't make you feel the need for a nap but do take you to your happy place. Cute waiters. Tasty tacos. What could be better? Oh, wait, a place with AC during a heat wave! Holy cats it was hot in there tonight! 

That said, I will definitely be back for more of their delicious drinks and small plates. We loved the guacamole. The fish tacos were super good (shrimp, not as much).
Tacos! Tacos! Tacos! Any kind. They're all good. What else is there to say?

This rating and review is strictly about the service. Wow, Cascabel. Whyyyyy? No one loves authentic Mexican tacos more than me, and this is how you treat me? The server who tended to us tonight (brunette waitress in her late 30s to early 40s) was the sam

To begin- I really enjoyed my meal here and I have no idea why this place has such lackluster reviews overall!
My girlfriend and I ate lunch here this week and it was a nice experience!  

Our waiter was friendly and efficient and the food was delicious.  
The atmosphere is also quite nice- they have a Mexican wrestling theme about the place.  Little Mexican wrestler figurines adorn the walls, as do paintings representing Mexican wrestling.  This might sound tacky and weird, but it's a tastefully decorated restaurant.

We shared a small bowl of guacamole with accompanying crispy whole tortillas for an appetizer.  The guacamole seemed freshly made and was really good.  It could have used some red onion chunks in it for some diversity of its consistency, but I have no complaints about it overall.  

We also each ordered tacos for our mains and shared them with each other.  I got the chorizo tacos and my girlfriend got the chicken tacos.  The chorizo tacos were certainly the better of the two (the chicken tacos were tasty but could have had a bit more spice in them to make them interesting).  The chorizo tacos were a bit greasy, but were very flavorful and had a nice spice-level to them- not spicy hot, just tasty.  
All of the tacos were served with lime wedges and a whole chili pepper on the side.
The tortillas were authentic Mexican style (or at least, seemed to be much more authentic than your usual gringo-style tortillas).  
You can either order two or three tacos for a lunch meal.

Our lunch- appetizer, mains and drinks (iced tea and soda)- came to around $37 for the both of us.  That's not bad at all considering we ate a lot of food, and again, ordered an appetizer and drinks.

I never heard of this place before, but the bright shining lights were intriguing to me.  
It's a small, quaint place.  Cozy but no frills.  But overall, a nice place.

The food is good and typical mexican food fare.  I would come here more often, except...it's expensive.  I came here with my friend and we both ordered food an no alcohol (thus I can't comment on the alcohol).  But, it was like, $47 dollars for two entrees and an appetizer.  

At some places, I expect that but this was a bit too expensive for me, especially given what we got.  Also, given it's proximity to Columbia, I would think they'd be less expensive.

Just as a side note, any side order you want, you need to pay extra for.  I found that slightly annoying.  At least give me beans on the side without having to pay $5.00 for them, (although they were good - but $5.00 good....I am not sure).  

So, do I recommend this place?  Yes.  The service is good and the food is good.  However, this will not be a regular place for me, as I just feel it nickel and dimed.  However, there is a hole-in-the-wall taqueria just round the corner from me that serves food that's a smidge more authentic and less expensive. Come here for the decor.

I may be hooked. Sitting outside in flip-flops enjoying ice-cold, generously-sized, not-too-sweet margaritas and mojitos on a summer evening, with a steady stream of delectable tacos coming my way - such a great way to banish all memory of the winter months. The food is prepared with a lot of fresh veg. The pomelo salad is a *must*. The tacos come loaded down with all manner of tangy, juicy, tender, crisp deliciousness. Although the three bite-sized churros that come in a little brown paper-bag (for a buck!!) always make the meal for me. If you can't go to Cabo, go here!

This is by far the most crazily priced Mexican I have ever seen. Two tacos (must be of the same flavor!) will cost you $8.5. Not bad perhaps till you know that the size of the two tacos together is less than a quarter of a single normal taco. So if you want to have a taste of two kinds of tacos it will cost you $17 and the quantity still wont satisfy you.

This could all be forgiven if the taste was actually good. I ordered two carne asada tacos and they came with a bizarre twist: deep fried onion rings and not much carne to be seen. The strange combination is not mentioned in the menu ("crispy onions" could mean fresh onions as is normal in carne asada!) so I was shocked and turned the sweet+greasy dish down. They would not change the order but rather asked me to leave because I "couldn't appreciate the food". But maybe that's a good thing.

So make sure you don't complain or you will be treated violently.

I don't often review but I had to this time. While the tacos were decent, I received terrible sevice here! Our waitress was so unbelievably rude to us, I couldn't believe it. :-(  
Sooo we tipped her well although she was  totally inattentive and rushing us throughout the meal. Then once we'd paid and immediately after the busboy removed my friend's desert dish, she came over and stood behind our table and mumbled "people are waiting." A few seconds later, she walked around to us to and asked us to leave because she needed to seat someone else! My friends and I were so shocked, we didn't even know how to respond (it was like a reallyy good episode of punk'd, except it was real-and bad!). To make it even worse, we only saw one couple waiting and there were other open tables of 2 and 3 just like ours!  I was beyond appalled that she would treat paying customers this way.   
I have never received such offensive service.

I would give this a 3.5.

Let me start off by saying that I am used to a taqueria back home where I get delicious explosions of flavor in my mouth for 99 cents per taco. So, even in NY, when I pay $8.50 for 2 chicken tacos, I have high expectations. And I thought it was...fine, but nothing special. My meat didn't have that smoky, charred flavor.

I'll probably go back and try their other options though...I give props for a creative menu and a cute, hip atmosphere

Pretty average Mexican food. They have lunch specials and you can order ahead!  Pretty satisfying.  Friendly people that work there. I want to come back to try their drinks and other food besides tacos.  I

It was a scorcher when I stopped here with some friends on the way to bringing our boyfriends food at Columbia- yes, they were working on a Sunday...busy bee's... We decided to stop into Cascabel Taqueria for a few tacos and a nice refreshing margarita.  && we definitely picked right! We sat outside on the little tables and benches and people watched as our medium guac came out speedy!  The guac was great.  The flat chips that they served were great as well, just enough salty but not too much that it was overcompensating for the lack of flavor in the chip.

I ordered the cucumber basil Margarita and it was refreshing, delicious, and hit the spot on the hot hot humid day.  Two of my girlfriends ordered the shrimp tacos and I ordered the cirspy tuna tacos.  My tacos were great.  They had the double tortilla's and fresh olives and sauces to top it all off.  To add a little extra flavor I added some extra tomatillo sauce and a few squirts of super hot sauce as well.   Two tacos per person was just the right amount of food for a light dinner out :)... also! GREAT PRICES!! I was incredible happy... =) yum yum...

I really love Mexican food, and hoped this place would be awesome. But it isn't--it's not horrible either. It's just that the fish taco was undercooked, and without any crunch. Also, the guacamole, while it was fine, was not anything to brag about and it cost 8 dollars. At least, at Mama Mexico, the guacamole is worth the price.  Also, Cascabel does not give you very many chips to go with your expensive guacamole. 

In my opinion, the margaritas (and we only had one each) were exceptionally good, but very expensive. $10? Not strong enough for that price, although I still recommend them.

Anyway, I hoped Cascabel would be better than Chipotle or Taqueria Y Fonda, but it isn't.

A much-needed addition to the UWS in terms of funky, fun decor and relaxed, friendly taqueria vibe. Interesting twists on the margarita like watermelon basil, cucumber cilantro. Food is pretty good, too, for this South Texan turned New Yorker. Cascabel gets the job done when taco cravings arise. (As other reviewers have noted, tacos do sometimes include gourmet flair, which may or may not be your style.)

The bone I have to pick with this place is pricing. For this I have detracted a star...$8.50 for TWO LITTLE TACOS??!! I'm talking the little ones, with the maybe 4-inch diameter tortillas. Where I come from (an area of the country in which tacos abound) that's highway robbery, and laughable. These are tacos, which, by definition, are riffs on Mexican street food! A clever sprinkling of crispy fried onions does not a $4 price difference make. I have to say, $4.25 per taco feels insulting. For an appetizer (which you need because the tacos are little), tacos, a margarita, you're walking out of there having dropped $26 before tax and tip. That's for one person...yikes! This South Texan can't quite get her head around that.

I would frequent the place more if the value was better. I rationalize my discomfort with the pricing with the fact that this is NYC, space is at a premium, and I'm paying to be in a fun, lively space with decent food that's convenient to home.

I keep going back here, even though I hate cilantro, and--fair warning--there's cilantro on EVERYTHING here.  if you ask, they'll avoid putting a handful on the top of everything as it leaves the kitchen, but most things also have cilantro incorporated into them in some way.  but the dishes that are good are simply good enough for me to bother picking cilantro out.

the best meal is brunch--there, basically everything is fantastic.  the Mexican French Toast is unbelievable; the breakfast burrito comes a close second; pretty much anything with the ancho chile maple syrup is fabulous.   the guacamole is excellent, and the drinks are all amazing.

I think that the service is probably pretty inconsistent; I've had friendly and fairly quick service there almost every time, but I've seen tables nearby be pretty neglected.  go with friends and when you're not in a rush, and you'll likely love it.

A new place opens up a block away from my apartment and I'm the eighth reviewer? Jeez, I'm getting old :P

I'm usually wary of nice Mexican places - the cheap stuff usually tastes better - but it turned out I had no reason to be on guard with Cascabel.

I came here with a friend and we started by splitting a couple appetizers. The blue crab and corn were more or less decent crab cakes, but the gorditas played a nice little trick on me. Served between two two-inch-wide thin fried masa cakes, the combination of pork belly, cucumber, cilantro and glaze reminded me more of a David Chang-esque pork belly bun than a traditional gordita. The pork, however, was kind of dry. Both were good, but neither was great.

We then split two orders of tacos: carne asada and carnitas. These were both very good. The meat was on the dryer side - the correct way to prepare a taco - and the toppings matched well, even if they were non-traditional. Their two hot sauces are worth applying - the roasted tomato for flavor and the diablo for scorching heat if you desire. 

My one bone to pick with Cascabel, and the reason that I'm not giving it four stars, is that it's on the pricier side. $8.50 for a pair of tacos - you have to get two of the same in every order - is expensive no matter how you look at it. They're really good tacos, but there are many other places in the city that make better ones. At $7 it would still be more expensive than you could get elsewhere, but understandable. Not so at $8.50, especially since two tacos alone aren't going to fill you up. If it hadn't been for the appetizers I would have been apologizing to my stomach for the rest of the night.

I'm glad to have Cascabel as an addition to the neighborhood. It has a good vibe and the food is pretty good. However, the main factors that would draw me back are if I'm feeling too lazy to go to the taco truck on 96th or Tehuitzingo in Hell's Kitchen, or if I were looking for a trendy Mexican restaurant, like a date place, close by. I'll probably drop in again to try the large plates. Will keep you posted, Yelp.

These are tacos that had the flavor volume turned up to 11; we had the carne asada, chorizo, and carnitas tacos, and they were all very good.  $8.50 for 2 tacos isn't too bad; the tortillas are small but they certainly loaded our tacos up with lots of high quality goodies.  The churros are a must at 3 for $1.  R summed it up best when she said it was a 'New York-style taqueria;' the tacos are a far cry from the ones I've had in BC, Mexico or San Diego, both in price and quality.  Whether or not that's a good thing is debatable.

This place is excellent.  I have been here a number of times and they are a great Mexican place in the UES (possibly the entire city).  I highly recommend their tacos, the elote, the roast chicken, and their agua frescas.  A great place for a low price.

Venturing into my new neighborhood I came here for a friend on a Saturday afternoon looking to get my grub on BUT a few things got in the way:

-the ridiculously small portions
-food that was not very warm.. cold almost
-price is pretty ny standard, but I would expect more for the lack of quality 

We had the tortilla chips with the eggs on top (soggy weh) and the veggie burrito which I would recommend. It was nice and crispy but I just wish it had more fresh veggies in it.

Staff was pretty awesome which made a mediocre experience better!! Our waiter was on his second shift at the restaurant and was a little flustered, but was very personable!
 
Drinks were pretty strong! But our table neighbors had ordered some delicious looking shrimp salads which I think I will be back to try. Also really nice outdoor seating which makes for excellent people watching!

Expensive and bad are not a great combo.  I had the fish and shrimp tacos and my wife had the chicken. The chicken smelled and tasted "off". The shrimp and the fish were no better. The "seasonal" drink was good (I can't remember the name).  The waiters were very nice and the restaurant is very open; in a good way. Ultimately, we left the place disappointed and promising not to go back. Go to Mama's instead

Have been to this location a handful of times and it is consistently enjoyable. Had the carne asada tacos, guacamole and rabanos last night and was totally satisfied.  When the taco meat falls out of the taco, just break off some of the hard shell tortillas, served with the guacamole, smear in a little guac and scoop up the meat, adding a little dash of one of their three little sauces, I preferred the smokey diablo, though the tomatillo and roasted tomato were fine.  

The rabanos are really a highlight as the salt, cilantro, dressing perfectly marry with the radishes.  They are totally refreshing as is writing about a vegetable normally ignored.  The guacamole could have a little more bite (next time upgrade from medium to hot, I guess) and could have had more acid.  I wanted to like their margaritias more but they were made a little too limey, maybe that is where the guacamole acid went? Why can't we mix and match tacos?  I wanted one carne asada and one carnitas and was refused.   Nitpicking a bit here, overall a nice meal and the outside seating area is always a treat.

After walking past this place for the first time about a week ago, I figured it was time to give it a try. Luckily my apartment is right on the edge of the delivery range, so i didn't have venture out in the rain to try this new neighborhood spot.

I agree with some of the other reviewers that say that the taco (2 tacos for $8.50) is a little pricy and not that huge of a plate, BUT that along with a side (like the quinoa and black beans) is a nice meal and not that pricy. 

Sure cafe frida still rules the area w/ the best mexican food (5 stars), this place is a great addition to the area as it is a sort of middle ground between taqueria y fonda and cafe frida. Delivery was pretty fast and the food was still nice and hot.  The lengua tacos were very good and the meat was not tough at all. The grilled corn was a sure winner, as was the quinoa and black beans, though I think I'd rather pay a little more and get a side of each to get more when sharing. 

Id definitely order delivery again and maybe stop in for a margarita.

If I could give 3.5 stars, that is what this place is.

The good:  its local, the food is flavorful (we had fresh guac, fish tacos, carne asada tacos, corn-on-the-cob and quinoa with black beans) and their three homemade hot sauces are all delicious.

The not so good:  compared to other similar restaurant, the portions are small for the price, and they also will not allow you to mix-and-match your tacos.  I also told the server that it was my girlfriend's birthday, and not only did he not ask whether I wanted a dessert/candle, he did not even look up to say happy birthday to her.  

I will probably come back when I have a hankering for Mexican flavors, but not if I am starving or craving good waiter service.
Probably the best Mexican in the area. Crowded, and pricier than it should be, but worth it. The vegetable taco--with oyster mushrooms, fingerling potatoes, poblanos and queso fresco--is outstanding.

Very, very good. I went here with a friend, after being curious about the decor from months of walking by and also for the craving of authentic, unique soft tacos. OMG, deliciousness. My friend and I both had a the roasted pork ones and it was AMAZING. It is a little on the expensive side, but they both were filling. 

apparently, they have certain nights with $1 churros. must. get. that.

I wanted to love Cascabel Taqueria, but it was not to be.

First of all, this place (a small chain) is definitely better Mexican than many New York establishments. If I was judging on food alone, they would get 3 stars. The value is just so poor that I'm left giving 2 stars.

Cascabel is trying to upscale their "street-style" tacos with ingredients like tuna belly instead of white fish, hearts of palm instead of I'm not sure what, veal tongue instead of lengua, Amish chicken instead of the poor non Amish chicken. I'm all for it so far. I got excited to try the food when I read the menu. So you only get 2 tiny tacos for $8.50? That's OK - they have tuna belly in them.

I split the tuna belly tacos and carnitas tacos, as well as guacamole con tostada, with a friend. The pieces or tuna belly were dipped in so much batter I literally could not see or taste any fish inside. They were not crispy or freshly out of the frier, but room temp and slightly soggy. That was a big disappointment. The tortillas were fine but the rest of the fillings were unremarkable. The taco badly needed some crunchy texture (usually from crunchy cabbage and crispy fried fish).

Carnitas tacos were an improvement - the carnitas were nicely cooked and slightly crispy on the edges, although too salty. This was the most traditional sounding taco on the menu, with pickled onions and chili de arbol. You can get this exact taco in Arizona for $2.

Guacamole was fine but a bit too acidic for my taste (too much lime). It was fresh, though, and I liked that we could order it spicy. The whole freshly fried tortillas looked nice but were kind of awkward to eat. There is something more appealing about a friendly little chip you can pop in your mouth.

Others have complained that the drinks were watery, but ours were not and I could definitely taste the tequila in my grapefruit juice and tequila. The accompanying hot salsa was good, but I didn't try the one marked "marinara." Really? Food is served on stainless trays like at Brooklyn BBQ, where it makes more sense because they are serving large juicy chunks of meat to share on picnic tables. 

Our waiter was a really nice guy and a very skilled waiter and sported an excellent turquoise jacket. Total cost was $47 with tip for 2 tacos each, 1 drink each, and a few bites of shared guacamole. I left still hungry. I could easily have eaten 4 tiny tacos myself but didn't want to spend $75 on tacos for 2.

All in all, Cascabel is just trying too hard and it shows. They need to learn the basics before they can riff off of classics...and rip off the masses.

This place is garbage.

It certainly looks the part of hip taqueria, but the execution is dismal at best.  The wait staff was comprised of hipsters who seemed to have little or no interest in taking an order.  We ordered our tacos separately and then received them on one single tray and were tasked with parsing them out ourselves.  I'm fairly sure they do this to conceal the miserable portion sizes.

The food itself was no better.  While my carnitas tacos were decent, my date's fish tacos were an abomination.  Corn meal battered and fried they somehow arrived cold, leading us to believe they had been returned by another customer and then re-served. Unfortunately, the place is also overpriced, especially in light of its other flaws.  

Go to Taco Bell; go to Blockheads; go to Chipotle; go to Qdoba.  Go anywehere.  Just don't go here.

I give the 2 stars for the food which was delicious.  Not ensconced in the Mexican spices (which I prefer), but for a watered-down Mexican joint, it was really good. 

I take away the 3 stars for the terrible host (the Asian guy in the ponytail) with the

This is definitely one of the nicer spots in the neighborhood for tasty food in a casual atmosphere. I've whiled away a weekend afternoon with friends here unrushed but comfortable. Monday night taco flight is the best, though, because otherwise you're stuck with just one type of taco. All of the flavors are good, but be warned that chorizo especially is very greasy. The downside to this place is that the prices are not great, especially when you get your food on metal trays (to me, this kinda gives off a prison-cafeteria vibe). Drink a margarita or two ($12) and you'll start to care less about the high prices, though.

I have to go back sometime.  I went for lunch on a work day so no alcohol was involved.  What was involved were two carnitas tacos with pickled onions, crispy rice, and cilantro.  I added hot sauce.  Yummy.  Perfectly sized for lunch and flavorful.  

Highly recommended for a lunch with friends.

Echoing other reviewers, the food was tasty (we had tacos - camarones, pollo chipotle, and carnitas) but pricy. $8.50 for two teeny tacos. We were there for lunch on MLK Monday and there were very few customers. It might get crowded on a typical day and the tables are also teeny. On the upside, it's got a good vibe and the server was cool. If it were 60 degrees warmer outside, the outdoor seating would've been great as well.

Oh my gosh, I can't be effusive enough about how happy I am that Cascabel opened a 2nd location in Morningside Heights!! I've been going to the UES since they first opened! And then I was super psyched when they expanded. And now they are even closer to my neighborhood!! So happy!

Just as the UES location the food is incredible and reasonably priced. I love the shrimp tacos, the chorizo tacos, as well as the lengua! For sides definitely go with the quinoa y frijoles. And for starters the gorditas or the crab abs corn cakes are superb! For drinks, either go with agua frescas or the pomegranate hibiscus margarita. Awesome! And try the ancho spiced hot chocolate. So good!

The service is friendly and the atmosphere is nice. The UWS location has a nice outdoor area and a decent amount of space.

Yet another restaurant that's completely underrated on Yelp.

I've been to both Cascabel locations several times and had food and drinks every time I've been to this one. By the way, they have a great happy hour from 4-7 - $6 margaritas! I've had them all, but my favorite is the pomegranate hibiscus. The watermelon basil margarita is kind of yucky. 

The food is also great. I haven't found anything that beats this place in Upper Manhattan. Their tacos are small, but you get three, and it's a good portion size. If you want to eat a disgusting amount of "Mexican" food, go to Taco Bell. I've had most things on the menu, but the chorizo tacos -- though greasy -- and the shrimp ones are my favorites. 

At times the service can be slow and forgetful, but I usually hang out for a couple of hours so it's not really bothersome. It's really low-key, and I really like the music they play, too - Radiohead, Phoenix, Arcade Fire, etc.

Don't forget to ask about their margarita snow cones in the summer. Technically, it's street-legal alcohol because it's classified as a food item.

I love when new places open up in my neck of the woods, especially Mexican places, but sadly, Cascabel left me a bit unenthusiastic.

At the bar, they have a cool selection of 4 types of margaritas (I had the cucumber-cilantro, which was not much of a margarita but was very refreshing).  They also have Negra Modelo on tap, which apparently is rare, but the pour is pretty weak.

Food-wise, the guacamole was lacking, and they charged us a dollar for extra chips.  The tacos (shrimp and fish) were really delicious, but they were nothing I couldn't make at home.  I'm just that talented ;)

Overall, the food is good and the atmosphere is really, really fun, but it's just not a good value for the small portions and okay flavors.
Nice vibe, friendly staff, will have to come here a few more times to give a full review.

We came here per my friend's recommendation. She described it as "gourmet" tacos, similar to how CA goes overboard with our "gourmet" pizzas that's filled with ass crazy topping and artisan cheeses.  This place goes ape shit with the fillings. Fried onions, pickled onions, and all sorts of sauces. 

In CA, the tacos are just some meat, a little bit of diced onions, and cilantro and maybe a little bit of salsa. Here they go a little overboard.  We tried the carne asada and the carnitas tacos. The carme asada came with fried onions, which was actually pretty good. The carnitas had a lot of sauce and came with sweet pickled onions which made the whole thing taste like sweet meat taco.

Each order comes with 2 of the same tacos. So no mix and matching, which kind of sucks when you want to try different meats.

Drinks here are pretty good. This wouldn't be a place I would crave but I wouldn't mind meeting up here again for some tacos.

Love this place. 

Had the Watermelon- Basil Margarita (which was BANGIN') and the Pomegranate- Hibiscus Margarita (too floral for my personal taste but better for those who like that much Hibiscus flavor in a drink).

Love the casual but polished lay out and design of the joint. LOVE the daily specials. Friends with meat entrees seemed to enjoy them. I, however, built my own burrito per the daily special and got a Veggie burrito... Which ended up just being rice & beans in a tortilla smothered in verde sauce. Not exactly what I asked for OR had in mind but it was edible. I'd like to encourage this place to offer a LITTLE more variety in the vegetarian arena. Especially since Vegetarianism/ Veganism are at an all-time high. 

Our server was friendly and open which, as a fellow server, is ALWAYS a plus. I HATE robotic service and she definitely didn't do that. She was very nice.

Overall, I will be back MANY times- in fact, I'm going in TODAY for lunch and their AWESOME Happy Hour. This place is definitely worth a try!

I liked the vibe of this place on both our visits--the dining room is small, but it opens up to a large outdoor seating area when the weather is nice. The drinks are good to. Unfortunately, the tacos themselves just aren't that good. The flavors are too complicated by half--I wish they would get the basics of the fillings right before they went for some of the more inventive ingredients.

In sum, I'd go back for drinks with a shared bite or two among friends, but I'm not heading there again for a meal out.

Cascabel looks very promising from the outside, but falls a bit flat. 

The coffee was much too bitter for my taste, that I didn't end up taking advantage of the "bottomless $2 cup". 

I had the pescado tacos and the Rabano (breakfast radishes). The Pescado tacos were fried fish with an olive and hearts of palm, which were both pickled. The combined flavors were good, but the hearts of palm and olives were a bit too intense together and ultimately caused the dish to be overwhelmed. The rabano were whole radishes marinated in olive oil with salt and pepper and were absolutely delicious, but a very large portion of radishes for a side dish (probably be best to share). 

The provided table salsas were alright, but everything seemed to lack any element of heat. 

The atmosphere is nice and a pleasant place to sit outside for Sunday brunch.

Perhaps it's still the margaritas talking a full 18 hours after I first started drinking them, but I am in love with this little place!

First off, let's talk 'ritas, because I tried three out of the four, much to the dismay of my liver and wallet. (I'm sorry, but I was a bit peeved at too much ice in my $11 'ritas...) However, the flavor combinations were fantastic! From traditional to fruity to refreshing, there is a 'rita for everyone. I partook in the Pomegranate Hibiscus, the Cucumber Cilantro, and the Watermelon Basil. The Pom-Hi (...yes, I invented my own name for the sake of not typing "pomegranate" too many times...) was the most flavorful, but almost to a fault. It was a tad too rich for me, tasting strongly of Pom Juice. The Watermelon Basil and Cucumber Cilantro were both refreshing and light, but I think the latter takes the cake as my personal favorite. (Then again, I'm in the section of people that says, "Cilantro! I love you! I don't know why so many people hate you!")

As for food, my friend and I split and shared the Carne Asada and the Pollo Chipotle tacos. Both were extremely flavorful; the chicken had the slight chipotle heat to it, but I enjoyed the Carne Asada ones infinitely more. I hate mushrooms, but I could not even tell if they were in my taco. It was just meat on meat on meat, juices dripping down my fingers and hands and off of my wrists...it was almost hedonistic. 

The staff is friendly. (...what's up, Javier?) The little churros are hot, fresh, and almost creamy. The music is...well, it switches up from Franz Ferdinand at 8 p.m. to Al Green by closing. Oh, and can we talk about the bright blue fleece blanket Javier gave me because it was a bit chilly in the outdoor seating area? If that isn't great customer service...

A bit pricy for what is served, admittedly, but...I'm hooked. It's just a good and solid restaurant. Muy bien!

I like the spot. The whole front opens and the tables are placed on the edge of the open area so that you feel like you're outside. There is also a whole picket fenced outside area. Maybe they are waiting for some kind of permit because no one was eating

Went in lastnight just for drinks and I must say that I wasnt really impressed with the drinks. We did not eat but we did see the way someone of the dishes looked when the group next to us ordered. It did look delicious so next time I will attempt to try the food there.

Tried this place tonight for delivery. It was fast and tasty. It isn't your run of the mill Mexican. It is creative and upscale.

I had the fish tacos, which were delicious and unique. They tasted great with more guacamole added on top. 

I also had the vegetable tacos which were very flavorful and robust. I highly recommend trying these for something different and delicious.

2 Tacos come per order and they are the normal corn tortilla size, with a double tortilla.

Portions are small but adequate for the price & quality.  I really enjoyed the pork belly appetizer- it was well balanced with salty, sweet, & savory flavors.  The pork belly itself was delicious.  

The margarita could use more tequila & agave, and less lime juice. It pretty much tasted like unsweetened limeade.  I didn't get a buzz & I'm a lightweight. Also, I'm a bartender. 

I will definitely bring some friends back because I enjoyed the experience. It's nice to have a more foodie-friendly Mexican restaurant in my neighborhood.

My husband and I went to Cascabel yesterday for brunch and it was delicious.  My husband had the pancakes with goat cheese and bacon and I had the eggs with chorizo-both dishes were delicious!  We noticed that they have a cute bar area that will be perfect for watching a sports gave while having a yummy drink.  Will definitely be back!

The best thing to come to the neighborhood in ages! Walking in we were offered margaritas on the house; obviously this was an opening night thing but the drinks themselves were great: not too sweet or overwhelmingly strong.
The tacos are incredible especially for $8.50 for two ($11.75 for three). I had the Carnitas (succulent as hell), given how small the tacos apear it's amazing how much they can pack in--my girlfriend came in famished and couldn't even finish her second taco. 
The guacamole was good; I would have liked a little more for the price though. We got medium which struck me more as mild, luckily they supply many and various sauces to augment it to your heart's delight.
We finished with the Churros. They are heavenly and...3 for $1. It's really more like one long churro cut in three but it's still pretty awesome for a dollar. Comes in a bag like you bought it on the street.

Great service and amazing ambiance (we sat half outside). My new go to place.

After waiting anxiously for cascabel to open, I was excited to try it out Saturday night with 2 friends. We were promptly seated at one of their high bar tables, allowing us to enjoy the nice outdoor breeze (drinks only at the seating outside unfortunately). We started off with the guacamole and chips - tasty, but definitely a small portion for the price. Our margaritas were underwhelming - my traditional margarita was acceptable, not the best I've had, but my friends' pomegranate hibiscus margaritas were a bit too sweet and skimpy on the tequila. Not worth $10 each. However, the tacos were awesome! We had the shrimp, carne asada, and yellowfin tuna. I liked the fish tacos best, but all were sufficiently stuffed with fresh and well-seasoned ingredients. The service was fast and friendly, so that's always nice.

All in all, I'll definitely be back for more tacos, but I'll save my margarita money for later...

Expensive for glammed-up Mexican street food yes- but if you order the right things it can be a great lunch or dinner. 

The drinks are fantastic- the watermelon basil margarita is seriously delish. The sopa de tortilla is tasty and hearty and comes with a roasted chili that you can break into the soup. I also love the Ensalada Luchador.

The tacos are a bit bland in my opinion, and require lots of their sauces to make them interesting, but that being said, the best ones I've had are the carne asada. I really want to like the tuna but always find them to be just ok. I've also tried the chicken dish with corn and found it to be lacking flavor. 

The space is festive- bright colors, open inside/outside feel, great patio. Compared to other options in the neighborhood, this place is pretty cool.

I really want to like this place. And there are aspects of this restaurant that I do like. For starters, the staff here is very friendly and the food does come out quick. It's a hip place that pulls of this cool look while seeming very low maintenance. I like that their window doors (or are they just called glass doors?) can open up on a beautiful, warm, sunny day. And their bathroom was immaculate. Small, with a very tiny sink, but very very clean. I definitely appreciated that.

The only thing I did not love and is sadly, a very big thing, was the food. My boyfriend and I came here for lunch the first time and ordered the Baja Fish Tacos and Carnitas Tacos. We were really excited to try this place out and we had lucked out as it was a beautiful day so we sat on the inside by the window doors to enjoy the sunshine and warmth. We didn't love the fish taco but the carnitas were tasty. But the overall atmosphere with the sun and all left us with a more positive than negative opinion of the place.

Fast forward to my boyfriend's birthday. We had eaten a late lunch earlier in the day so we didn't feel hungry again until around 11pm. But by then a majority of the restaurants in this area are closed. Doing a quick yelp search for restaurants currently open, Cascabel Taqueria popped up. We decided to give this place another try as we weren't 100% sure whether we liked it.

Again, nice service, food came out quick, and very nice facilities. But the food was definitely not to our liking. We ordered the Pescado Tacos and the Puerco en Adobo. Again, didn't love the fish taco. (We had kind of forgotten we didn't love it the first time but we both love fish tacos, so any time we see it on the menu, we have to order it!) There was a very fishy aftertaste that even the lime could not hide. We were piqued by the hearts of palm and thought that was such an interesting item to add, but in the end it was kind of blah and left us underwhelmed. The Puerco en Adobo was sooo salty. My boyfriend didn't think it was too salty but did think the flavor was a bit off. I generally love salt but this was just too much. I ended up adding a ton of hot sauce to both items to hide the taste of the food.

To drink, we ordered a Watermelon Agua Fresca and a Fruit Punch Agua Fresca. My boyfriend didn't love his Watermelon Agua Fresca.. he thought the flavor was too subtle. The Fruit Punch Agua Fresca is tasty though.

Overall, we do have a pleasant experience as far as the atmosphere is concerned. But we just can't bring ourselves to do that to our taste buds again.
