I was going to opt out of fries with my sandwich and she strongly suggested to do half salad half fries, because the fries are awesome. The woman was right-they were some of the best french fries I've ever had in my life. My mouth is watering just thinking about them. 

Good for groups, family brunches, fancy dinners, and dates. Easy to get to and reasonably priced-really good quality food.

I said I'd be back after the awesome Elite event here a few months ago, and dammit, I keep my promises!

I assumed that there wouldn't be a wait on a rainy Wednesday evening.  Whoops.  It was a half-hour wait for the three of us.  Luckily, there were three spots at the downstairs bar, so we sat down to enjoy a drink while we waited.  I had the Jacobin Club, a cocktail with St. Germain and grapefruit juice (and some fancy-sounding shit I don't remember).  Good, but perhaps a little too sweet.  My boyfriend was excited that they sold Goose Island Matilda (we haven't seen it much around the Boston area, since it's a Chicago beer).  Overall, we were impressed with their liquor selection.

After some seating confusion with the hostesses (are you seating us upstairs or downstairs??  JUST TELL US), we finally got a table in a cozy corner downstairs.  I was adamant that we start with the Creamy Spinach Gratin appetizer, which I fell in love with at the Elite event.  Yep, still amazing.  I never realized that spinach and bleu cheese were soulmates.  Now I know.  I probably could have eaten a whole meal of just the spinach, but I grudgingly allowed my companions to share.

For the meal itself, I was hoping we could order a bunch of small plates, but no one else wanted to do that, so I ordered two for myself: the Crispy Soft Poached Chip-In Farm Egg and the Chicken Liver Crostini.  The poached egg was, for lack of a better word, AMAZEBALLS.  The second I punctured it with my fork and the delightfully runny yolk oozed out, I knew I was in for a treat.  (Sorry to all you runny yolk haters - I probably just grossed you out big time.)  The crispy egg sat atop a piece of toasted brioche, with pancetta and pecorino aioli.  All the flavors and textures worked perfectly together; this dish was basically flawless.  The Chicken Liver Crostini was very good as well, but I think it came with too much prune and honey jam - the sweetness was in danger of overpowering the pate.  I had to scrape some off.

We decided go elsewhere for dessert, but I was definitely tempted by a few things on the menu.  I've since moved out of state, but I have a feeling I'll be back to Russell House Tavern.  Heck, let's make it a promise.

Went here on a Sunday morning and the place was hopping. It was a nice atmosphere. Everyone gets water to start, and a pitcher for the table. I'm not sure if this is by design, but you don't get ice and the water was room temperature. 

We started off with coffees all around. It was strong but smooth, and I HIGHLY recommend it. 

Though I cannot complain about the service, our waiter acted awkwardly around his tables, and was softspoken. For awhile, we weren't even sure if he was our waiter, or just a helpful bus boy bringing us water and coffee.

Anyway, the food here was delicious and tasted fresh. My only complain, and it is a big one, is that the hash browns that came with my meal were not hot. Same with the fries that came with the other meal. Otherwise, everything was outstanding.

This place is hot hash browns and a friendly server away from being 5 stars, and I recommend it!

They have oysters and their bar manager is Aaron, formerly of Drink! Try his housemade spiced rum. And a great beer list... what more could you ask for? (I haven't tried any of their food so can't comment on that). 

Go at off hours, like 2pm.

Wow, what a perfect place right in the heart of harvard square.  This is a nice classy place with an excellent drink selection and awesome food.  I had a burger that was juicy and perfect.  The people I was with were raving about how good their pizza, chicken, and perogis were.  This is a nice clean and classy place to grab dinner and get some drinks.  They have a late night menu too, making this the perfect harvard square destination.

A perfectly fine gastropub in a very convenient location in Harvard Square (literally cater corner to the T). Portions on the main dishes are generous, and the dishes we tried (steak frittes and pan roasted chicken) were well seasoned. Good beer selection and a nice looking variety of pretty bottles behind the bar (for what it's worth--we're no experts on mixed drinks). While the place looks small from the street, it is actually ginormous with a second large bar and dining area downstairs.
Most gigantic glasses of wine ever.  The bar is downstairs.  Not crowded after work.

It was what it was. I would return knowing what I could expect. Service was professional, food was predictable. The Caesar salad was dressed while the lettuce was wet (and overdressed) and so the flavors were completely diluted (or again, it was overdressed and the dressing has no flavor) but the deviled eggs passed muster (without being thrilling), a burger was decent though the fries need work (blanch them first please!). In word, middle of the road somewhat upscale beer, wine, and burger place that does a little extra.

UGH I really wanted to like this place, but it fell short, way short!  So, we were dying to eat here as we had heard great things about this place.  The only AMAZING thing about it was my cocktail which was called the Battle of Trafalgar, and it was awesome.  The waitress told me that they are known for this drink and have won awards for it, and yes it was awesome!  The food was not so awesome.  We decided to order a few of the small plates, so that we could try a variety of dishes.  We ordered the Jonah Crab Cakes (very small portion, tons of mayo which overpowered the actual crab meat, so all in all very disappointing), Short Rib Wellington (this was definitely not a short rib wellington, it was more like short rib stew with a topping of pastry puff.  The pastry puff was dry and the short rib stew was very watery, again disappointed), House Charcuterie Board (ugh, bread that came with it was dry, no mustard provided, the duck ham was sliced ridiculously thin and there were about three tiny slices of it, the chicken liver pate was good but I have had better, basically this does not even compare to Ten Tables charcuterie plate which is plentiful with tons of extras); we then ordered the Smoked Lamb Belly Toast (not kidding there was no lamb belly on the toast and this was just doused in butter and really terrible, I would have returned it but by that point the disappointment and disgust was overwhelming), the final thing we ordered was the Crispy Soft Poached Chip-In Farm Egg (this was AWESOME, very different, filled with flavor and my husband wanted another one, definitely worth ordering).  All in all I would come back here for a drink but not the food.  It is very overpriced for the quality of food that you get.  So disappointing!

My fiance and I were in Harvard for the day and were looking to grab some lunch and cocktails. We came across Russell House Tavern, and decided to give it a shot. We walked in to find only two patrons in the entire restaurant, and they were sitting at the bar. We asked the hostess for a table for two, to which she responded "For what?" My fiance responded "some drinks... and maybe some food" she then berated us and decided to speak to he and I as though we were children. She said that the tables were only for those who wished to eat food, and that if we decided to sit at a table, we would be encouraged to have something to eat as only patrons eating were allowed to sit at the tables. There was NO ONE in the restaurant. We had every intention of eating there, but this woman's attitude was just too much. We finally did sit at a table, and quickly realized the reason she was pushing the food, it's because their menu is TERRIBLE. We walked out quickly after we saw our poor food options. I do not recommend this restaurant, if the food looked even remotely appetizing we gladly would have stayed, but due to poor atmosphere and waitstaff we made the proper decision and brought our business across the street to a lovely restaurant called Tory Row.
Having been in the restaurant business I know the appropriate way to greet and seat guests, and this woman was the polar opposite of the correct way to do her job. Do not waste your time with this place unless you like to be treated like garbage.

Not too long ago, there was an article (or was it a review?) that I enjoyed reading that named a certain establishment as the author's "local," defining "local" as a pub near one's home, where you can stumble from drunk, a place where they know you. Because you are there. A lot. This undoubtedly makes Russell House Tavern my local. And for that, I am thankful. 

I've stumbled in, stumbled out, tried nearly everything on the menu, sipped wine from the tap, beer from the bottle, knocked back more Fernet than I should admit, met up with friends, ran into some more, sat at the upstairs bar with the windows open, sat downstairs in the lounge and even brunched on the patio. It's just one of those places where you can do all of those things and they are all so well done.

Points that separate Russell House from the pack? The editing process of their bar, for starters. There's hardly anything more exciting than the opportunity to be introduced to a new beer/wine/spirit of which I was previously unfamiliar. Nope, you just won't find the same old selection here. And if that's what you're looking for, then there's plenty of other bars to hit up in Boston. If you're curious, ask about their wine on tap, their extensive craft beer selection or their scotch list.

For lunch, dinner, brunch or late-night snacks, the Russell House menu features dishes in a wide range of proteins, flavors and price points. You'll find pizzas are big enough to share, while small plates are perfectly sized to enjoy 2-3 per person. Traditional entrees range from $10 - $28, and you'd be a fool not to find something to love: lamb shank, an Ozark pork trio (belly, shoulder and loin) two steaks and a really bad-ass burger served on an English muffin. The fries, with their crispy, salty perfection of texture, make it hard for me to eat them any where else. Among my favorites: the egg, the charcuterie and the pork trio.

Whether at the bar or a table, I've found the service to be pretty on point, with the food generally arriving in the right amount of time, the staff smiling and helpful, and water glasses, shot glasses, beer glasses and cocktails are always full. And despite the busy summer season, getting a seat here is a relatively smooth and swift process. The only night I absolutely couldn't get a table was during Harvard graduation. Fair enough.

A melding of creative, well-priced food, a welcoming and warm atmosphere (the decor improvements from the previous inhabitant are tremendous), finely crafted cocktails and a beer and wine list that will both educate and satisfy you, Russell House is the piece that's been missing from Harvard Square; a bar/lounge/restaurant that lacks pretension, caters to the curious with being too obscure and never fails to make for me a difficult time of narrowing down just what exactly I am going to eat and drink each time I go.

After a fun-filled night of karoke near BU, we wanted to cruise back over to Harvard for a night cap. Since we are Virginians, the cold got the best of us and we agreed to go to the first bar that we saw. We spotted Russell House across the street and noticed on their sign that they have $1 oysters from 11-midnight...yes..11:12 pm! The whisky and beer selection was extensive and descently priced. I ordered the Belgian Abbey Ale; beware, this is a heavy one but full bodied and 9.4%. We also ordered 2 dozen oysters. They came from somewhere on the west coast, so they were small but tasted good. It was a bit of a teaser; you can't win 'em all! To top it off, our waitress, Karen, was super nice and helpful! Thanks Russell House for a good time :)

Overall, I enjoyed Russell House Tavern. The service was very good, the wine was excellent, and it's a comfortable, conveniently-located venue. The reason I gave it 3 stars rather than 4 was because I had quite a mediocre meal. For an entree I got the "Berkshire Blue Cheese Wedge" salad, which was listed on the menu as coming with blue cheese, pears, grilled onions, and crispy pig's ear. But you could barely detect anything other than lettuce in the salad I got -- I literally got tiny specks, about 1/4 the size of an M&M,  of each add-in. For dessert I ordered the molten dark chocolate torte, which was way too sweet and didn't have much chocolate flavor. The only saving grace was that I then traded dessert with a friend, and my new dessert, carrot cake bread pudding, was delicious. 

I can only hope that this was an off night and not business as usual.

A classic in Harvard Square, usually full of Harvard students. Overall a great quality and atmosphere for a very reasonable price. The market fish is usually great, the steak frites (at night) is also wonderful with a great aioli sauce. Brunches are great as well, and it's usually easier to get a table... A little bit noisy, but that's a part of the experience!

Remember when the Lonely Island said Mr. Pibb + Red Vines = Crazy Delicious? 
I have a new equation: Pimm's No.1 + St. Germain = Crazy Drinklicious.

The best thing in Russell House Tavern is its Battle of Trafalgar drink. Add a little honey simple, batavia arrack (no idea what that is), and honey simple and you have the perfect drink. Not too sweet, not too strong, and not too pretentious...it's just right. Every friend who tries it likes it. It should be called the Goldilocks drink. But I guess Battle of Trafalgar is a more badass name.

Russell House also has great pizzas and fries, but the Battle of Trafalgar is what keeps me coming back for more.

My family from out of town and myself dined at this restaurant on 5/21/11.  We had to wait about an hour for a table but that was fine as everyone was off looking around the nearby shops.  We had no idea this place was a "gastropub" so when we were seated and took a look at the menus we were kind of confused.  My family is from western new york and didn't even know what aioli was, but the waitress was very helpful in explaining some of the dishes.  Even with the explanations, we all stuck to the safe side of things (no one would eat beef heart).  

We started with the deviled eggs and the melted cambaloze cheese appetizer.  They were both delicious and highly recommended!  For entrees, people had the grassfed burger which they seemed to enjoy, the crabcakes which had a different consistency from crabcakes I've had anywhere else, but were good, the chicken sandwich, which I thought was delicious.  So, all in all, it was a very interesting and delicious meal.  I would definitely recommend the restaurant to anyone looking to try new types of food, or foodies, but if you wander in thinking it is a traditional tavern with the traditional fare, you are out of luck.

What's all the fuss with Russell House? I came in for a solo lunch and had a pleasant enough experience. I mean, it's a gastro pub in Harvard Square, a needed thing by all means, but not sure if it's worth writing to Mom and Dad about. Maybe I'm wrong. I dunno. A few things that caught my attention as I sat at the upstairs bar for lunch on a Thursday afternoon on a warm August day:

-There is a downstairs bar? Huh. I would have sat in these shady depths had I known that to be an option. The sun hurts me. Hurts I say. 

-Crab cakes are my enemy. They look so good and I want them, but they hurt me deeply. Like literally every time I have them, I suffer. So why do I order them? Russell House is no exception. That's my fault for ordering, but their fault for making them look so good on my neighbors plate. Damn you both. 

-Excellent little beer list. Loved the Bengali Tiger IPA on tap. A perfect cold beer for a warm day. Would have loved to have a few more but life was calling and I for once was listening. 

-Bar staff was nice enough. Prompt. Seemed to be mixing up some interesting drinks. Made with the water. Cleared the mess. Charged the credit card. Did not harass. 

-Interior is modern. Clean. A little too clean maybe. I like a few stuffed deer heads on the walls. 

-View of pedestrian traffic in Harvard Square is both fun and daunting. How many faux goth Harvard freshmen can I look at while smashing a mediocre crab cake down my gullet?

All in all. Not bad at all. I'm sure I'll be back to hurt myself again with something else off the menu that is known to cause me gastrointestinal stress.

I really liked all the food at Russell House Tavern, but I feel the need to drop 2 stars because of the immensely slow service. 

All of the food on the menu is exactly what a gastropub promises - every dish is thoughtful, tasty, complex, and just perfectly delicious in your mouth - presentation is gorgeous as well.

But then you get to the waiter service - after ordering our drinks, it probably took over 30 minutes for them to arrive.  Of course during this time, they did bring over the wine glasses for us to stare at - but not the actual bottle to fill them up.

Then when we asked for more bread to go with one of the dishes - this took another 30 minutes, at which point we already finished the dish.

The finale - getting the bill took just as long... it honestly all exhausted and overwhelmed my experience.

The waiter was extremely friendly, but I can't tell if they just don't have enough waiters or he would forget about us when he left - but it's a good enough reason for me not to want to come back.

A friend of mine has managed to build a bit of a relationship with the staff at Russell House, and when he brought us there tonight, we were treated like straight-up royalty. I think it says a lot about the hospitality of the staff that just because a manager knew my friend's face, our party of four was greeted with a jump to the front of the waitlist on a busy night--to a nice table, nonetheless--and drinks on the house. The waitstaff was incredibly attentive and helpful throughout the night, checking on us frequently. Also, the ambiance is really perfect--chatty but with a lot of quiet corners, and there's a sort of understated classiness about the place that's really nice.

I might be bringing people back here in future for this alone, but everything about the food and drink was similarly wonderful. Russell House serves up a really nice mix of comforting and innovative gastropub-type fare, and everything was luscious. I especially liked the Crispy Pig's Head Cake, which is everything good about pork, deep-fried and served with a poached egg and a mapley reduction of some sort. It was sweet and unctuous and decadent.

The raw bar is a huge plus. If you're looking for a place in Cambridge to stop for a round of oysters, this is your ticket: Island Creek seems to always be a good bet 'round these parts, and Russell stocks them. I had two friends with me who had never had oysters before, and I knew this would be a good place to initiate them--they came away oyster-lovers. Totally fresh, briny, and perfect.

Gotta give a nod to the extensive drinks lists, as well. I haven't tried out their cocktails yet, but the house list is the sort of mixology-type experimentation I've come to enjoy--lots of St. Germaine and rye. When I was uncertain about which beer to order (they have a nice assortment of craft brews, many local), the waitstaff was amazingly attentive and knowledgeable in helping me pick, asking about my preferences before making recommendations. So fun!

Seriously good stuff. Thanks for the wonderful evening, Russell House--I'll be back!

This is a great location for this place. You walk into a cafe-style bar area and as you realize you are not in the main dining room you descend down the stairs to a pantheon of flavors and spirits (too much? No? Probably but it did feel like the Bat Cave). 

I refused to go to this place on a weekend night because I fore-casted a mobbed bar, unappreciative diners and hey, restaurants just are not as good on the weekends. 

I started with one of the cocktails, a rye based "Harvard Yard" while the lady had a very respectable and punchy white. We decided to to some sharing of small plates and had the soft shell crab pizza (of which I could have simply ate the soft shell crab off the top and been happy), the deep fried egg (an epicure's delight) and what I thought was the highlight: the smoked pork shoulder terrine with mustard seed and honey gelee. Yeah it really is as good as it sounds and probably better. Words do not do the terrine justice as it brought me to provincial France, a British public house and to my hometown Jawjah in a single bite. 

Reeling but unfazed, we split the obligatory roast chicken. It was perfectly cooked and the carrots were wonderfully shaped and roasted. I guarantee that there was no butter in the mashed potatoes. None (HA!). At some point during the meal I had a Wachusett Belgian that I was not to fond of as the server, though cheery, was not as knowledgeable about beer as should could have been working at a place to this caliber. I wanted something with bright hops, aromatics and a touch of bitterness and I got a syrupy, viscousy, amber Belgian. 

Desert was an afterthought after my food baby started knocking at my ribcage but they had carrot cake bread pudding. That's right, beloved carrot cake with beloved bread pudding coupled together like the Olson twins (although of course, they would not partake). With a mini-scoop of ice cream I was induced into a mini-food coma. 

It was worth the trip to Harvard square on the oft dreaded 66 and I'll be back. 

Three things of note: 

The bartender is always changing up the cocktails and is of good pedigree as he was formally at Drink. 

This place will fill up so definitely make reservations to eat downstairs. Summers are great at university proximate places like this because many of the students are gone.

This a a place for seasonal ingredients and orgainic/biodynamic wines. If it is not in season, they don't have it. Thank you RHT.

So exciting to find a place like this. The crispy egg was incredible, better than Eastern Standard's sweetbread frisee salad, which is similar. Chicken liver crostinis were guuuud, short rib Wellington a good hearty stew. My cocktail was perfect also, exactly what I was looking for. Nice job, and great atmosphere
Comfortable, lively yet quiet atmosphere. Good comfort food.

The food at Russell House Tavern is delicious. They accomplished what Green Street did not - a crispy fried poached egg that was oozy and amazing in the middle. Oozing over the toasted brioche and the pancetta and the (!!!) amazing aioli. (The same aioli that was scraped clean off my plate with an extra piece of bread.) If plate-licking was socially acceptable, I would have.

The Andria (burrata, mission figs and garlic) was the perfect combo of sweet and savory. Perfect for sharing. Figs on a pizza, a revelation. This was my first experience with figs (aside from jam) - the verdict? Figs! Figs! Figs! Delicious. 

Rounding out the eats, spiced ginger cake. It didn't look like much - but layered with coffee buttercream it was heavenly. A great texture and a really delicate flavor. Yum.

The bevvies are in a class of their own. I had been planning on drinking beer, but after perusing the cocktails I changed my mind (quickly). I had the Battle of Trafalgar - Pimms + St. Germain = delightful. Sweet and so so good. I had a quick sip of the Wigglesworth. So so nice.

Loved the atmosphere (we sat at some high-tops in the upstairs bar area). The service was great (our server was super adorable). Can't wait to go back!

After hearing a bunch of people say how good Russell House was, i picked it a bit at random as a place to meet someone for dinner the other night, because this is how one learns new things.

Walking up, i was wondering if i might've screwed up, since it looked busy, but actually we were seated nearly instantaneously.  Earlier in the week, i was pretty psyched to eat something awesome and delicious, but i was fighting off a cold by the time Thursday rolled around, which sorta sucked.  

Anyway, other reviews have questioned the service, but i didn't really have reason to; it was prompt and courteous without being exceedingly friendly.  

The beer list is very well-considered, and though they were out of Harpoon's imperial red, the locally brewed double IPA they had replaced it with was smooth, delicious, and strong.  i can only assume that the wine list is also good.  

The food was merely good, and i was a bit underwhelmed.  Like i said, i was looking forward to a good meal, but i was feeling pretty crummy, so i just ordered a pizza.  Despite being thin-crusted, it retained heat like crazy and was scorching hot pretty much the whole time.  It was clearly made with some care from good ingredients, but it just didn't taste very good.

Other than that, though, it's a nice place to eat outside-ish in a brick alcove just off of Harvard Square, and that alone is enough for me to give it another try.

I still dig this place.
The food has gotten better
and Lou is still cute. 

--Haiku Review

To start, a 30-minute wait became an hour wait. Not the staff's fault for the wait (it was Saturday night) but kind of their fault for not guesstimating correctly.

Remember, it's all about underpromising and overdelivering in the service industry!

Once we were seated our waitress was a doll, the bar we sat at had hooks under the table (as all bars should have) and the food was good if overpriced. Note, if you get the greens with your burger you will get a LOT of greens. It was like a full salad! On the other hand, if you order the "small place" brussel sprout salad it will be so small you'll wonder if they messed up. 

Overall, delicious. Overpriced, but ok given the area. Beers were also wonderful with a wide assortment! 

Lively atmosphere - could be good for drinks or a casual date out.

The food (including creative small plates like deviled eggs with shrimp and avocado), cocktails and craft beer are three reasons to get excited about Russell Tavern. Plates are well-presented and the kitchen does a fantastic job of layering flavors and textures. My wife and I were there twice yesterday: once to check the place out and see if we wanted to return for dinner with our son. We had a friendly knowledgeable bartender. The first thing he did after greeting us was to pour a couple of glasses of water. We washed down aforementioned deviled eggs with pints of Harpoon Belgian Ale and a dark German wheat beer. Both were excellent. We liked the menu and reserved a table for dinner in the bar. 

Fast forward and we're back with our 10-year-old after his hockey game ended. Dinner was Pt. Judith "Trace & Trust" Bluefish w/ Creamed Verrill Farms Corn, Roasted Pink Eggplant, Radish Salad ($23); Ozark Heritage Pork Trio: Loin, Belly, Shoulder with Anson Mills Grits and Sauce Vinegar ($23); and Steak Frites at $24. All were delicious. The bluefish portion could have been a little more generous. 

Service is where Russell Tavern really needs to improve. It took 10 minutes for our server to arrive, then another 15 to get bread and 45 minutes to get our entrees after ordering. The restaurant was busy, but it was only 6:15 and that's far too long to wait. The server should have come by to let us know what the situation was. Instead, I had to flag her down and ask when the meals would arrive. Also, the tables in the bar are much too close; uncomfortably so. There were six inches between our table and the one next to us. 

I'd give Russell Tavern another shot, but I'd take more control of the meal by insisting on better service. 

Please let me know what you think of this review by clicking a button below. Thanks.

I was a bit skeptical about coming here based on the mixed reviews, but boy I am sure glad I did!

It was warm out yesterday so the front windows were open, and the whole atmosphere of the place was airy and relaxed. Ahhh... sigh... Based on what my friend had said, I expected the food to be overpriced and portions small and the service to be kinda shitty.

NOT what I experienced at all! Quite the opposite in fact! I ordered a Harpoon specialty Belgian beer (can't remember exactly what it's called) while my friend got a Southside cocktail to start. Beer is beer (I mean I love beer but it's hard to fuck up) but holy shit that cocktail was amazing. 

I was hungry so I ordered the burger. Again, another pleasant surprise!! Delicious and juicy with crispy bacon served on an English muffin! Yes! An English muffin! Geniusss. 

Service was good, atmosphere was great and food and drinks were fantastic! I will be back.

Pros:
Really good atmosphere, 
very good variety of drinks, not too expensive either. 
Good food not just the regular bar food, especially the pizzas.
Couldn't ask for a better location.

Cons:
Food portions were a little small and coz of that somewhat pricey. But worth it.
Ask for seating downstairs, much better, they didn't give us the option so we didn't know we could sit there.

Great for late night food at Harvard Square. I got the burger and it was really good. It was wrapped in an english muffin bun and the burger patty itself was really juicy. The burger is topped with bacon and chedder. Delicious.

The pizza was just okay and nothing too memorable. 

The salad was wayyyyyyyyyyy too salty. Felt like I was just eating salt.

The service was good and the waiter gave us recommendations on the food and beer choices. Speaking of beer choices, they have a pretty good selection to choose from.

The best thing about this place is $1 Oysters after 11pm everyday. I'm no oyster connoisseur, but the oysters were delicious in my opinion. They didn't have a fishy aftertaste and tasted very fresh, while going down easily. Definitely get the oysters if you happen to be here after 11.

I don't know that I'm into the Gastro-pub thing.  I didn't try anything fancy or the specials here which might've been my mistake.  I had the roast chicken dinner, comes with mashed taters and i subbed creamed spinach for carrots (sadly I'm allergic). It was good, but nothing special especially for the price.  If you can't or don't cook I'm sure it's heavenly.

It is a nice little spot, and I like that the hostess said sit where you want.  The staff were all very nice and helpful, even tho I was dressed like a bum (seriously, i just didn't smell bad), and hacking up internal organs from bronchitis.   I did get the nice little corner spot by the window all to myself... I wonder why :)

Think $6 beers in 14.75 oz water glasses, minus out the head and you get about 13oz of beer. Other beers were a bit more expensive to a little outrageous. But that is what you can expect from an up-scale bistro in the Harvard SQ area.

The upstairs bar di

I've never had something I didn't like at Russell House

Brunch - Amazing
Beer Selection - Awesome
Fresh oysters - OMG I WANT TO EAT THEM ALL
Charcuterie Board - Give it to me

Favorite items that I have to get EVERY.TIME?!

Bone Marrow
Crispy Poached egg

Please. If you haven't tried these two items you should probably go to Russell House and DEMAND them

Heaven. It is Russell House Tavern.

On a recent visit to Cambridge I yelped this restaurant, and was not disappointed!  It was a great menu, and the service was top notch.  I had the pork trio entree, which was incredible!  Also the beer selection is local and fresh.  Great ambiance as well - all around, highly recommended!

This was my second visit to Russell House Tavern (RHT). The food here is quite good, though not of the Craigie on Main sort. I'd give it a B to B+ grade for price-to-quality ratio -- 3.2 stars.

Atmosphere is nice here -- not too loud, not too quiet. And the tables are spaced far enough apart for comfort. But I was never a big fan of eating in windowless basements, and that's what RHT is: a windowless basement.

RHT serves bread and olive oil to start. The bread isn't very good -- too dry, tough, and relatively flavorless. It's sort of peasant bread but taken to the extreme. Ask your server for salt & pepper to flavor the olive oil a bit (there won't be any salt and pepper on your table).

Tonight I started by splitting the House Charcuterie Board app with my dining companion. She loved the chicken liver pate, which I didn't like at all. But I never liked chicken liver very much, so that's no fault of RHT's. My favorite charcuterie item was the Smoked Berkshire Pork Rillette (which my DC hated). So all in all, it worked out well -- she ate all the chicken liver pate, I ate all the rillette, and we split the other (very very tiny) items on the charcuterie board. The prune & honey jam that comes with the charcuterie board is worth its weight in gold. Oddly, there's no mustard, though. It was a good app, but I'd bet you can do better here -- I would've rather gotten the "3 sides for $15" deal (ALL their sides looked appealing -- the brussel sprouts, the grits, the potato & cheddar gratin).  I also got a Caesar salad, which was tasty enough, though it was not especially unique or different in presentation or taste (anchovy-flavored croutons were an attempt at that, I guess). I was in a burger mood, so I just got their R. House Grass Fed Burger. I ordered it medium rare and they nailed it -- perfectly cooked. The meat was flavorful. Although it was cute that they served it on an English muffin, the English muffin was dry and not very tasty. It didn't add value; I would've rather had a good bun or roll. It also came with fairly nondescript bacon and cheese (i.e., good enough, but nothing uniquely flavorful or mindblowing). It's definitely not anywhere near what you'd get at Craigie on Main, but it's only $12. And at $12, a bacon cheeseburger with fries at a mostly high-end Harvard Square restaurant ain't bad. The fries were medium thickness and tasty but again, not mind-blowing. Oh -- the mayo that comes w/the burger plate was really good and tasted homemade. That mayo was another high point.  We were in a rush, so we skipped dessert there. I should mention that my DC had the market fish (striped bass, perhaps?) and really liked it.

Service was wonderful. Our server was attentive without hovering. The only screw-up -- and it was pretty major -- was that they brought the entrees WAY too early. We were about 3/4 done w/the charcuterie plate when they came out with the entrees. So my burger and fries sat on the other end of the table getting cold for 10 minutes. I dunno why they did that.

Would I go back to RHT? Yes, but I wouldn't go out of my way. Although the food is different from what you'd get at say Henrietta's Table, I'd rate it similarly as far as food quality goes (though Henrietta's has much nicer ambiance due to copious natural light) -- i.e., very good quality, okay prices for Harvard Square, but you won't rave about the food to your friends the next day.
Great burger, great fries.  Easy to find a seat at the bar downstairs.  I'll be back.
Good price point for Harvard Square. Had a really corteous waitor. I am going back for sure. Downstairs is much nicer with faster service.

Love RHT.  Every time I come I feel welcome, I leave full and I enjoy myself thoroughly the whole time I'm there.

Came to meet my sister on a Monday and only had to wait 10 mins (half a beer at the bar) till a table was ready.
Great beer list, to compliment anyone's meal and to fit anyone's taste.  

Started with oysters, then shared the pork trio (awesome and interesting) and the mkt fish of the day (bluefish, a healthy sized piece and also quite good).

Service was friendly an attentive.  

One of my top 5 restaurants in Boston.

Yelp led my family and I here. I had the steak frites and it was very good. Tender, flavorful meat with a delicious demi sauce. The wine and beer selection is very extensive, and the specialty cocktail menu looked good too. Service and ambience was great...I'd recommend the place!

Wonderful things happen at Russell House Tavern.  And I'm not just talking about in your mouth.  It just has a magical vibe to it.  Like Disneyworld, but for drunks.

Brilliantly crafted cocktails, a menu you're not embarrassed to order from when drunk, and a staff and management that exude enthusiasm.

So come on a slow night (you'll never be able to fully appreciate RHT on a crazy busy Friday night).  Sit at or near the bar and make friends with the staff.  Order specials and off the small plates menu, and ask the bartender to make you a drink you've never heard of (as a whiskey drunker, I love the Scottish Play).  

Rinse and repeat.

I went to Russell House for the first time last night. I absolutely love what they've done with the place (I remember when it was Finagle Bagel). We sat downstairs, and the atmosphere is divine. I especially love the photographs and comfy plush seating.

The waitstaff (there are tons of them) must have a position for everything - waitress, bus boy, drink-deliverer. It was "uppity" and it was a little chaotic as a patron. A moment or two after the bread was delivered, so were our oysters. The person delivering the oysters moved the bread plate away while one person in my party was trying to dunk their bread. The servers also jam-packed our table with lots of plates (we did order a lot of food) and overall just asked a lot of questions. The mood from the ambiance wants you to have a relaxing calm experience and I hope they calm down as the staff gets more comfortable with the restaurant.

The food and drinks were pretty great. I got two Moscow Mules and they were delicious and strong. It's nice getting a strong drink while you're dining out. To start we had some oysters and the Painted Hills Steak Tartare which were really good. For entrees I ordered the R.House Burger (was debating getting the Hearth Baked Pasta). It was pretty good but kind of sloppy. We also ordered three sides - creamy spinach, creamy grits (are you seeing a trend here?), and the roasted vegetables. All were really good, but clearly we ordered too much food for three people and ended up taking most of the sides home.

We were with someone who always insists on ordering dessert, otherwise I wouldn't have really bothered. Their dessert menu is sort of limited. We ended up getting the yogurt cake with honey, ice cream, and basil sauce. It was okay, but really small and not worth $8.

I'm willing to come back to Russell House to try out the small plates or maybe order a different entree.

A very stellar dining experience. 

My friend and I each got the Crispy Poached Egg, and split the Steak Tartare and Pork Trio. Drink: She got the Crimson Crow, I got the Battle of Trafalgar (I love me some UK history!).

The egg lived up to the hype. Perfectly crisp, perfectly gooey, perfectly runny, all in one. It's the flavor, stupid. And this is the shiznit. Steak tartare was very well-done. Not meant to be mind-blowing, I guess, nor especially creative (unlike at Jean-George's Market), so you get a good, solid circle of tartare. The Pork Trio was rich and meaty with cheesy grits and a bed of salad greens for accompaniment. Also very well done, with the various parts of the pig perfectly cooked.

I had quite a bit of my friend's Crimson Crow and it's definitely my cup of cocktail. Sweet, fruity, slightly sour and gorgeous to look at in its regal martini glass. My Battle was much stronger and less sweet, but not without its stoic charm. Service was flawless with an extremely friendly waiter and the dining space is dark, sleek and lovely. Will definitely be back.
Superb.  Had brussel sprout pizza (one of the best ever) & oxtail perogi (small serving size, but delicious).  Affordable at $19/ea. w/ no liquor.

I invited friends to Russell House last night to celebrate my 28th birthday over drinks downstairs.  RHT certainly has the look, feel and taste of my favorite Boston watering hole - Drink in Fort Point.  I had three sazerac old fashioneds, compliments of my friends and was a very happy birthday boy.  Definitely my favorite bar in Harvard Square and will have to come back soon to try the food.

We had a table of eight people for a birthday celebration. 

Appetizer- B
The Melted Cambazola Cheese - Too much mushrooms and not enough cheese
Loose Leaf Salad- Too much salad not enough walnuts and figs

Entree- D
Seared Gloucester Cod Loin - Bland. Three of us ordered the cod. It was a decent meal, nothing to rave about until another one of my friends found a worm in her cod! Suffice to say, we did not have an appetite anymore.  

Service- A
The waitress took our three cod dishes and offered us something else to eat. They comped the 3 cod dishes. The manager apologized. They sent us three entrees to make up for it. 

Overall- 2 stars
This restaurant was packed and it seems liked the staff was overwhelmed. Our waitress was wonderful. However, it is not a place that I would seek out again. The food is just mediocre.

I've been anticipating the opening of this place since my boyfriend was hired (later declined for a more immediate job elsewhere) as a line cook back in February. I have to say, I'm not disappointed! The newest of the Grafton Groups endeavors (owners of Temple Bar, Grafton Street, etc...to correct Clayton's review) has proven to be in great taste!

Having gone twice in the past 10 days I can say this is quickly becoming a new favorite spot. I was pleased my first visit by my cocktail choice (Jacobin's Club) and even my boyfriend, who is a self proclaimed anti-cocktail imbiber, was impressed enough to order a second round of his whiskey based cocktail (the name of which escapes me right now...Hanger something?).  I was also intrigued with the St. Germain cocktail available by the pitcher. So much so, that after ordering it on our second visit I've decided it will be my go-too summer cookout beverage. Light and refreshing. Despite the current trend in the bar world of using elderflower liquor whenever possible, it was simple and impressive. A great use of the medium.

Moving on to the food. I was insanely impressed with the charcuterie plate. The amount and selection was generous for the price point but lets hope it stays that way! My friends and I (4 of us) ran out of toast points and were desperate for vehicles, thank goodness they brought us more. I enjoyed my steak frite as the potatoes were actually crisp and were a great compliment to the perfectly cooked meat. The one thing I will say though is that the pizza my friend got was lacking in spice/flavor. But if thats the only thing wrong I can't fault them.

The service was great, just attentive enough and definitely well versed in the menu offerings.
Two thumbs up! I'll certainly be spending some QT here in the near future!

Need more vegetarian options!

This restaurant was an awesome addition to the Harvard Square area, and I quickly grew to love the bartenders and servers and overall attitude of the place.  The service is fantastic (our waiter was adorable and super nice and attentive), the drinks are amazing.  And if you're a carnivore I hear the food is excellent.  But since when does a nice restaurant in Cambridge not offer even a single vegetarian entree?  This is ridiculous -- they used to have one on the menu (and it was delicious) and now it's gone.  A choice between salad and pizza, however delicious they may be, means I won't be back.  There's no reason to return if you know exactly what you'll have.   Furthermore, if they source their veggies from Verrill Farm, they clearly have excellent produce -- why not add a single entree to showcase that produce?  Every other meat-heavy restaurant in the area (Craigie on Main comes to mind) has a separate section of vegetarian food, or dishes that could be made vegetarian via substitutions.  To me, this just speaks to the limitations or lack of imagination on the part of the chef.  Vegetarian food can be delicious and amazing (see Craigie on Main, West Side Lounge, Chez Henri, any other similar restaurant in the area).  Please think of this as a challenge -- ***more vegetarian options please***!

Oh, and there were two girls throwing up in the bathroom.  So if you see a lot of undergrads around... beware!

Young crowd. Fun atmosphere.  They have an array of fancy appetizer's and side dishes and beer too. 
It is a great place to come with a couple of friends to pick on food and taste their array of drinks. 
When i came here I sat down for a meal. I ordered the Market Fish, which at the time was Bass. It was heavenly. 
If you are going for just the small dishes I recommend the steak tartar. 
Besides the complementary bread being stale and having to yell across the table to speak to one another- I'd suggest coming here for just the bar scene and small bites.
Love the dollar oyster after 11pm. Good beer, although not listed on the menu when we arrive

In 3 visits:
Appetizers: Foie gras and laphroig terrine (1 star), Melted carbozola cheese (4.5 stars), Jonah crab cakes (4 stars), Deviled local farm eggs (4.5 stars). 
Entrees: Local Berkshire pork trio (5 stars), Panroasted arctic char (5 stars). 

Solid place for dinner and drinks. The atmosphere is vibrant and classy - perfect for young professionals. There's dark wood throughout with modern lighting, fresh flowers, and young dapper bartenders mixing drinks behind the bar. The food is bold and innovative. The service is nice and relatively quick. There's even outdoor seating near the entrance weather permitting. What's not to love?!

Well the foie gras. It was soft, bland, and slightly gamey, like bad liver. It melted in my mouth...in a bad way. The upside is that everything else was phenomenal! The melted carbozola cheese spread was plentiful and amazing. The cheese had great flavor and was of the perfect gooey consistency to spoon onto the thyme-garlic flatbread. The crab cakes were run of the mill, good and fresh but not outstanding in terms of texture or spices.  The deviled eggs were awesome! The cooked yolks are mixed with fresh seasoned olive oil and anchovies. The eggs sit on a layer of asian hot oil which makes each component of the egg pop. Mmmm! 

The pork trio was great! I got this 2 out of 3 visits and it was great both times. The loin, belly, and shoulder easily cut apart with a fork and were packed with flavor.  Its bed of greenery, grits, and dark sauce were a perfect complement to the meat. The arctic char was flakey and also packed with flavor. Its bed of pickled parsnips were also a perfect complement to the fish. You can tell each ingredient was carefully selected for its quality and flavor.  In addition, the head chef is clearly a genius at complementing the different tastes of these ingredients. Wow!

Hands down the best bar/restaurant in Harvard Square!

Over the past 30 years, I've watched the conveyor belt of retail establishments churn their way through our beloved Harvard Square ... many of which didn't deserve to stay - and far too many cherished institutions that should have been spared ... so it is with some caution that I declare Russel House Tavern as having that "special something" that SHOULD garner it a coveted place in the Harvard Square Hall of Fame.   EVERYTHING - from the service (ask for James the Bartender) to the exquisitely prepared & presented food (Steak Tartar, Deviled Eggs, Beet Salad, So-Not-Ordinary Cheeseburger, and the Dreamy-Perfect-Comfort-Food Chicken Pot Pie) ... made for a 100% verifiable, perfect lunch.  After too many disappointing experiences in the modern Square .... Russel's Tavern is a place that SHOULD be here 50 years from now.   P.S. After being turned away from several posh & hip restaurants that couldn't accommodate  some AC for a computer, the Russell's Tavern crew threw their arms open - and went searching tor a plug-in-able place for us.  Luckily for us ... we found James and his Most Amazing Bar right here - in the snug and comfy underground hide out - RUSSELL'S HOUSE TAVERN.  BTW, did I mention James the Bartender was AWESOME?

I really want to give this place a higher rating but their service is just horrendous. Went there for a birthday party last night and ran into perhaps the worst service in the restaurant business.  Some examples:
1. We ordered a bottle of wine for a few people - the waitress had me taste the wine, went away to pour it for others, and completely forgot to fill my glass while finishing the bottle.  She did not apologize at all but rather had the gall to suggest I order another bottle.
2.  I declined on ordering another bottle and decided to go for a beer instead. Oops - the beer I order off the 4 day old menu is not available. Why have it on your menu if u dint have it?
3.  Giving up on beer, I decided to order a Tom Collins. The waitress asks me what kind of vodka I want in my drink. One small problem - Tom Collins is not made with vodka at all. Why ask me something u have no idea about - just tell the bartender what I want.
4.  Before my drink saga ended, I had been served somebody else's drink and had a different waitress try to take my order. The Tom Collins was actually quite excellent - pity it was ruined by the service.
5.  The food was also brought out haphazardly - see some of the other reviews on this. Appetizers came out as main courses, the waitress could not remember who had ordered what and would randomly place the dishes in front of us. We had to rearrange on our own.
6. The worst came at the end when we wanted to split on 6 cards - not a very unreasonable request I think for a bill that was around 50 dollars per person. The waitress flat out stated that she could not split on more than 5 cards. Why??? No idea.  Even when we put it on 5 cards and the rest in cash, she had a tough time charging the cards.  Before our nightmare ended, she had charged 2 of the cards for wrong amounts and wasted more than 20 mins.

Even despite all our troubles, the manager did not apologize or offer to make it better. My advice is to wait a couple of months before they sort out their service or go to the bar.  And don't forget to tell the bartender to stiffen up the drinks - they seem to be on alcohol saving mode at the moment.

I went on a Friday night for dinner and drinks with a friend and there was little to no wait for a table. After we were sat we were immediately approached by our server who told us the specials and seasonal beers on draught. 

My friend and I ordered a combination of small plates and appetizers and the server was smart enough to stagger them so that our small table could accommodate all the plates. Before our beer ran dry the server was by out table side asking if we might like another. 

The crispy soft poached chip-in egg was amazing! Highly recommended! We also tried the House Smoked Maine Mussel Salad, the House Charcuterie Board, the Melted Cambozola Cheese, and for dessert, the Milk Chocolate Cheesecake. 

I didn't want to leave.

I've been back to Russell House a couple times since and I'm sad to say I wasn't as wowed. Brunch was fine...nothing to write home about...barely even memorable.

I also went one evening just for drinks and the bartenders were extremely icy...dudes, it's Friday night in the summer in Harvard Square and your bar is packed...crack a smile, hmm? Or at least make some sort of facial expression. I also didn't happen to like my cocktail at all (it was almost undrinkable actually) but that may have been less about them and more of a matter of taste.

Meh. I doubt I'll be back, but I wouldn't discourage others from trying it (hence the fact that I'm still giving it 3 stars). I just happen to be over it.

The problem with this place is that the DINNER is great, but the BRUNCH is horrible. So I would give the dinner 4 stars and the brunch 1 star. Since they have good drinks, I settled on 3 stars. 

We had high hopes for the brunch. The menu looked awesome, and we'd had good dinners there in the past. We were incredibly disappointed by what we were served there. 

My boyfriend had the American Egg Plate. He ordered it with the "House Ginger Sage Breakfast Sausage". It came with the bacon by mistake, so he asked for the sausage. They brought it. The sausage was burned and not worth eating. Maybe they cooked it too fast once they realized the mistake. The bacon was awful (I know, right? how do you ruin BACON, for pete's sake? the texture was horrible, and it had practically no flavor). The eggs were runny, and the toast came completely dry with nothing to put on it. It was pathetic, and he sent it back having eaten only a few bites. I have never seen this man send food back before--and he loves eggs and bacon! It was just inedible. It made no sense to us that the Russell House can't manage eggs, bacon, sausage, toast... ???

I had the Anti-Benedict--eggs benedict with the egg poached and then fried. It was okay, but--the hollandaise sauce was just nasty. Thin, runny, tasteless...I have had so many much better hollandaise sauces, I just couldn't believe Russell House can't manage a hollandaise. The lame sauce pretty much ruined that meal for me, because that's the best part of eggs benedict. I ate it anyway, but would not order it (or their regular Benedict) again. The best eggs benedict I've had lately was at Uncommon Grounds in Watertown. They're just a little diner. Russell House thinks pretty smart of itself, but in this case, they were badly beaten by a little diner in Watertown. 

We will never go back to Russell House for brunch. HOWEVER, will surely go back for drinks and apps after work sometime again. I really like their stuff in general, but that brunch was so disappointing that it really surprised us.

P.S. My bf wants me to add that they have a cask line, which is really awesome. That alone would keep us coming back.

"This place isn't as cool as it looks" says another yelper. I couldn't agree more. We walked in on the 4th of July at midnight to a completely empty bar, two bartenders and one server. As I have worked in food service before, I asked if they were about to close or if they were still serving drinks - there is nothing worse than being five minutes from going home and getting new customers, especially on the 4th. The bartender assured me they were still open and to sit anywhere. We parked ourselves at one of the tall center tables and it pretty much all went downhill from there. The bartender was so sarcastic and rude it was ridiculous - first telling us to order from our server, who then told us (within earshot of the bartender) to order from the bartender, who then looked at me with an obnoxious smirk, and replied "he's new," referring to the server. 

It took 20 minutes to get in an order and have it delivered, despite the fact that I could reach the bar from where I was sitting, the room is so small, and the bartender knew that we had been waiting. Two of our party ordered two beers at once to avoid having to wait again. It would have been absolutely fine if just one of the three staff members had made even the tiniest effort to be nice. Nope. Just dicks. To be fair, the server was trying his best, he was just inept. The bartender was a straight up asshole.  

The second star is only because the beer was perfectly ice cold and delicious (great selection). But I think I'd rather drink warm natty lite from a can on my couch than suffer the attitude of the assholes running this place again.

I've been here frequently since they opened, most recently yesterday for lunch and before that on July 4th at dinner. I've eaten every meal here.

Pluses:
+ You can almost always get a table because the place is much, MUCH larger than it looks from the street.
+ Good beer list and nice cocktail bar--they started out with a real mixologist, and I don't know if he's still there, but they've more or less kept up what they're doing. Try a Harvey Goes to Amsterdam!
+ Dinner and lunch food is great, especially the small plates. Nice raw bar too--and it's nice that they sell most items on the raw bar by the piece, not just "dozen oysters" at once.
+ Friendly bartenders who are quite kind. When I eat there as a woman sitting alone, I feel confident that the bartender would take my part in asking a guy to leave if he made me uncomfortable. This may sound silly, but it's a big plus to my mind!

Minuses:
- Inconsistent service. On July 4th, for instance, our server was so slow that we nearly left at one point. Generally, service in the bar is better than in the dining room, and service sitting at the bar is by far the best.
- Brunch food is not so good. When they opened it was fantastic, but they changed their menu and now brunch is overpriced and nothing to write home about.
- The crowd at the bar can be pretty loud and irritating on weekend nights--it's not as bad as Grafton St. (owned by the same group) but I wouldn't go there on a weekend.

Overall, I go to Russell House regularly--it's one of my neighborhood restaurants--but if you want a great gastropub experience, there are better ones in Cambridge.

Went here for lunch while wandering around Cambridge and really enjoyed it! Sat outside in their beautiful patio garden and loved the kale salad.  The pizzas and sandwiches also looked amazing, as did the drinks.  I would love to come back and try other meals here, and it definitely felt like a neighborhood hit.  I felt like a Harvard student grabbing lunch between classes :)

I just spent a few minutes debating whether to give Russell House 4 or 5 stars and came to the conclusion that there's really no reason for me to give it less than 5. So, kudos to you, Russell House. This place is typically hopping with, whom I would assume to be, Harvard kids and grads - some spending, others beginning, their evening either at the upstairs bar area or darker, and larger downstairs dining room and bar.

The beer selection is decent - there's always something tasty to be had. They typically have a BBC on tap (at least the seasonal) and so far they're the only place I've seen that serves the Harpoon Belgian Ale. Well, at least they used to (maybe someone can correct me on this?). Their cocktails are also thoroughly enjoyable. My favorite is the Battle of Trafalgar, but if you ask nicely the bartender may concoct something special for you.

For food, people have raved about the burger, and I have to agree that it is amazing. It's not the best of all time (seriously, try the one at jm Curley) and I could go either way with the English muffin, but it's just so juicy and you can't go wrong with bacon. Other than that, I really like the local leaf salad (with figs!); the oyster selection is great; and the pizza is decent as well. Also this is the first place where I've tried bone marrow, which I enjoyed. Possibly my favorite dish though is the plate of jumbo shrimp. Well it says cocktail shrimp, but they're always JUMBO. You get 3 and they come atop of this cylinder of chopped up honeydew mixed up with some sort of spice. Just ask for some cocktail sauce and you're all set.

I wanted to love Russell House Tavern, but I'll say that the burger is only ok. I've had a good burger at a gastropub, and RHT's wasn't up to par. That being said it certainly was a nice dining environment and more upscale than what I would expect of a gastropub, but along the same lines the prices are also in line. At $12, the burger wasn't a bad value, but nothing to warrant a pass on a cheaper alternative. The beer I got was also a lot more bitter than I had expected when the description by our server led me to think it would be lighter with more hops like a pilsner. I can still see myself return, perhaps with some beef snobs or out of town friends, but for the time being I'll be giving other places a fair shot at my dining out budget.

Went here on a snowy evening, after tramping around Cambridge trying and failing to find the correct movie theatre. The food was your fairly typical posh pub fare - tasty but not memorable. I'm no cocktail connoisseur but our drinks went down a treat. I'd go there again but when I'm feeling richer.

Ok, I'm going to try not to get too excited but I have to say something that's extremely important and I'm going to need you to trust me; to close your eyes and say "Heather, I know I'm afraid. I know I don't know who I can trust on Yelp in Boston because it's obvious people out here give out stars like free candy. But, even in my fear, Heather, I trust you."  
Did you say it? 

Good. 

Now listen young one. If you are looking for the best damn burger in the history of Cambridge time, IT IS LOCATED HERE. For a mere $11 you can get the BEST DAMN BURGER I've ever gotten my gluttonous hands on. And that includes delicious fries. Why is the burger so good? How can I explain... the english muffin bun is perfect. Not too dense. Not all puffy and airy and worthless. The meat is seriously top notch. The cheese is all melted with these onions and sauce of the gods. The gods!!! 

Just trust me. For $11 it is 100% worth it. And, best part, you can get it at brunch too. Why waste your time with some morning sausage bull shiat when you can go with the big boys and get a hamburger that will have your tastebuds holding hands and swaying back and forth as they get washed over with beefy goodness? Point made. 

Other pro- they have epic drinks. Epic. A million cocktails with this whole pre and post Prohibition theme going on and enough beer and wine to keep anybody satisfied. Oh, and cordials. How cool is that? Just saying it reminds me of Marry Poppins. I don't know why... 

So what are the only issues I have with my new go-to hamburger joint? 

- Their "carrot cake bread pudding" isn't really bread pudding. It's like carrot cake without frosting (well, there's some frosting-esque thing going on down on the bottom but it's not right) 

- Their brunch yogurt and honey and banana thing is the size of my pinkie finger. Seriously. I ate it and was basically hungry by the time I left. 


Other than that, I had a great waitress at dinner (so so waitress at brunch) and the place has a great atmosphere. 

Trust me. Go.

A little overhyped by the time I got myself here...

The staff were awesome, very nice. Our waitress helped me with a great local beer recommendations. Kudos on that.

We got the creamy spinach gratin for an appetizer. It wasn't gratin-y or creamy enough for me, kind of just chunks of spinach sprinkled with parmesan cheese. The flatbread it was served with was good but pretty hard and not soft like it looked. This app was good but you can't maintain any semblance of ladylike while eating it.

For dinner I got the grilled chicken baguette. It was good, very creamy though! I couldn't even tell it was grilled chicken. Also, it was definitely not served on a baguette it was more like a flatbread. Good nonetheless and came with delicious fries.

The prices were very good, entire restaurant was clean, and the service was great. Just not too sure about the mislabeled menu items? Ah well.

After hearing rave reviews of RHT, I took The Lady out for dinner before a show at Passim thinking that a great dinner before some awesome music would be a nice way to set the tone for the evening. I was sadly disappointed. 

We started with the Cambozola Cheese appetizer in which cheese is the least of the ingredients. Honestly, there is barely any cheese. You are paying $9 for sauteed onions and mushrooms. It's shameful. 

After being very knowledgeable about the beer and wine selection, I asked our server which of the Woodchuck ciders they carried (The Lady drinks beer/wine, but I prefer hard cider). She replied, "Apple". I explained that there are a number of varieties of Woodchuck apple ciders (Amber, 802, Granny Smith) and asked that she check for me. She came back and said, "Yeah, I was right, we only have apple." Needless to say, I had a soda.

I ordered the grass-fed burger, medium-rare. It came out rare and fell apart while I was eating it, drippping blood everywhere. The Lady ordered the scallops. Two of the three scallops she received were raw in the middle. 

The best part of the meal was dessert. We shared the Molten Dark Chocolate Torte. It was delicious.

Russell House? More like Robot House. And I say "robot" because all of the staff there pretty much act like robots. For real. These shameless automatons go about their Soviet-like work with little appreciation for human life. My life and the lives of my friends were worsened by at least 8% when we went there (temporarily just for the night, our lives all got better afterward.)

We put our name in for a table and the hipster hostess said "40 minutes." After 75 minutes, we asked what was up and the hipster hostess tried to seat our party of 5 people at a 4 person table. Not possible. It's just not! This isn't Ikea. Then they said OK we can put you at a real table, but it would be another 40 minute wait. We bailed because we're not idiots.

With all of the time we WASTED, we could have held a charity benefit racquetball tournament, collected and disbursed funds for needy children in Dorchester, thus improving the quality of some young lives by 8%, and also shower because we got sweaty from the racquetball tournament. Instead, thanks to Robot House, these children are continuing to suffer.

Yo, seriously, this place is just horrible.

I seriously can't get enough of this place.
I had the special which was chicken fried pork chop with gravy and biscuits. Yummmmm. 
The person I was with had the brioche french toast with strawberries and blackberries. 
This is definitely my go-to brunch spot.

Came in for a late lunch on Monday and the place was pretty slow, as to be expected at this time of the day. Better for us! The bar and dining area upstairs is pretty small, but the area downstairs is much larger. The space seems well used and very clean. We sat at the bar and enjoyed some cocktails and some food. The barkeep was friendly and attentive. 

The drink list is excellent. My group of four sampled several different cocktails and they were all quite good. I especially enjoyed the $4 shots of Fernet and homemade ginger beer. 

The food was good. We ordered some oysters, which were delicious. also got a smoked brisket version of a Reuben with cole slaw on it instead of sauerkraut. This was an excellent sandwich. Came w a choice of fries or field greens. 

Overall, an excellent place. I could definitely see myself frequenting this establishment if I lived near the square.

First Disclosure:  I am friends with Aaron, the bar manager.
Second Disclosure:  I stopped in for a quick afternoon drink, and thus all 5 stars refer to the bar area - haven't had a chance to sample the food as of yet.

Now that we've got that out of the way - The bar at Russell House is outstanding.  Not your ordinary, run of the mill setup, they've made sure that when you belly up you're going to have a chance to experience something that you don't find at your usual drinking establishment.  I noticed that the rotating tap was featuring Dead Guy, something i usually jump on when i see it on tap, but since i had never heard of most of the other taps, i decided to sample something new (following Aaron's suggestion based on my particular tastes).  Can't recall the name of the beer, but it was actually similar to Dead guy - a bit more hoppy and with tighter flavors.

They also have wine on tap (the nerd in me enjoyed the explanation of what goes into getting wine on tap) and as an Alumnus of Barbara Lynch's 'Drink' - Aaron is always rediscovering the obscure cocktail or inventing his own delicious concoctions.

The credit card machine went down while i was there, and watching the interactions with other customers, the staff handled it with a sense of humor and really made a good experience out of something that could have been potentially disruptive.

RHT is highly recommended for a quick mid-afternoon drink (or any other time of day).

I showed up to Russel House with a date early in the evening on a friday night. We had a reservation and were seated immediately upon arrival. Good idea - because over the course of dinner it definitely got packed.

I ordered braised lamb and parsley gnocchi and I was simply not a fan of the gnocchi. It was a little too firm and crumbly. We had also ordered a crab cake appetizer between the two of us which was very good - nice crispy exterior, shredded crab throughout. However, between the crab appetizer, finishing my lamb, and not really liking my gnocchi (but eating it all anyways) I still found myself picking off my date's plate and I'm not that big of an eater. That being said, portion sizes (for my dish at least) perhaps leave something to be desired. My date didnt finish his burger, but I think he was just nervous ;-)

I commend our waitress for not rushing us out of there. She came over and was attentive, also had a lot of fun banter with us, but despite the fact that we saw two sets of people completely rotate out of the table next to us (time to sit, order, eat, pay, repeat) we didn't feel rushed to get out.

I can't remember the last time I gave 1 star.  But, this visit to Rusell deserves it.

First, we arrived at 8pm tonight, were told the wait was 30 minutes for the 4 of us and we waited an hour.  But, this happens, so no huge deal.

After waiting an hour, we were seated upstairs at a table in the corner.  It was fine, but upstairs is extremely loud for eating.  When I went downstairs to use the bathroom a few minutes later, I noticed that there were at least 2 4-tops ready for seating... why hadn't we been seated there?  This is where the real 1-star part begins.

How many minutes to get water?  10.
How many minutes to get our first round of drinks?  About 15.
The pig's head appetizer?  Tasted like grease and that's it.
The complementary bread on the table was stale and the garlic/evoo dip tastes nearly rancid if you dipped your bread in far enough to get the garlic.
The sausage pizza?  Salt.  Bread, sausage and cheese are all salty on their own.  WHY would you add a bunch of salt on top of the pizza??
Burger ordered medium?  It came out barely rare and also overly salted.

We're not a tough going crowd when it comes to restaurants, but all 4 of us had exactly the same strong reaction: come for drinks, leave for food and service.  It's too bad.

Russell House Taverns vs. Grafton Street. Russell House will win every time.

As one of my favorite restaurants in Harvard Square, they have the most delicious BRUNCH. Literally every thing on their brunch menu is absolutely yummy, you can't go wrong. BRUNCH BRUNCH BRUNCH BRUNCH BRUNCH. If you didn't get it, that's how much I love it. 

I have been there for drinks with friends, and the bartenders are friendly and classy. I have never had a bad experience here and therefore, anytime you decide to show up, you're bound to have a wonderful experience! GREAT beer/wine selection, and the bartenders even surprise you with their own concoctions.

Lunch, and dinner at Russell House are both good, nothing out of the ordinary, but still delicious. I am not a huge fan of seafood, but I do believe that they do have a sizzling seafood menu, but if you're not a fan, there is plenty to choose from! 

As the summer approaches, they even have a little outside patio which is adorable when the weather is nice!

Don't miss out on this gem!

I knew of the pricing before I went in, I was just hoping to be blown away by the food.

First, the service, awesome service. I went with my girlfriend and one of my friends and our waitress did a good job making sure we had everything that was needed, and was knowledgeable about the menu for the questions we had. I almost ordered something I wouldn't have liked because my friend asked what certain things on it ment.

We had the Melted Cambazola Cheese for an appetizer. I personally did not like it. It was mostly the flavor profile. My girlfriend thought it was fine and so did my friend. It was basically determined that I don't like Cambazola cheese, at least melted.

The Grass Fed Burger was good. Was it worth the price? Not really, but it wasn't a bad burger. My friend got the grilled chicken sandwich and he found that it was excellent.

So, overall I give it 3 stars. Would I go again, probably, I wouldn't get the same things, so we'll see what happens.

A friend and I found ourselves quite hungry while wandering around Harvard Square. We wanted a quick bite but at a sit-down restaurant. We happened upon Russell House Tavern and boy, am I glad!

I love the ambiance of the place - it's spacious and has a great bar area. Our waiter was fast and happily offered us menu suggestions. As I said, we only wanted a quick bite so my friend and I shared the brisket reuben and it. Was. Heavenly. Their french fries are super crispy and salty goodness - definitely order those! 

This is definitely on my list of places to try for dinner - can't wait to go back.

Over the summer I sat on the patio and enjoyed a bunch of their small plates and their supremely awesome cocktail menu. A standout was their seasonal tomato salad and the deviled eggs; we also had the tartare and the cambozola cheese. The tartare was decent, and I was a little disappointed in the cheese, as I was expecting something a bit, well, cheesier, than a thin layer of cheese in a small pan. Tasty but underwhelming.

Fast forward to more recent times, when my boyfriend had a hankering for oysters on his birthday. A last minute decision so I didn't make reservations, thinking how busy could any place be on Monday? Well clearly if you're the Russell House Tavern in Harvard Square,  you're going to be busy. There was a good wait for a table but we opted for some seats at the not-too-crowded bar for better people-watching anyways. We ordered up cocktails and a bunch of small plates, including the tartare, the burrata and brussel sprouts, and some oysters for the birthday boy. I'm still on the fence about the tartare, because I wish they'd go easy on the sauce -mustard? Horseradish? - and let the flavor of the meat shine though, but the brussel sprouts were fan-flippin-tastic. Great combination of flavors with the creamy cheese, the crisp of apples, and the kick of chili oil. We finished off with the pizza with housemade sausage and ricotta - crispy thin crust that was perfect for sharing. Service at the bar was attentive but not instrusive, which I appreciated. I could tell, though, that the bartenders were smiling and engaging with various people around the bar, confirming that this would be a great place to enjoy a meal alone as well.

I always come here after 11pm for their 1$ oysters.....yummm  the bartenders are douche bags EVERY TIME! There's this one guy, he works downstairs at the bar, he looks exactly like Collin Ferrel....but he is so rude lol I don't know what it is with these men here but if you have good or bad service it doesn't matter what you tip, they ALL share the tips and split them up at the end of the night, so good ol' Collin will  get his whether you tip good or not lol 

ALL of their cocktails are great, the food is amazing and very hearty, like the as if you were sitting at a wooden table in an old castle on the British countryside, with homemade jams and freshly killed game, roasted with goose fat...vivid i know but thats exactly what their menu is like. so for that 5 stars F Collin lol

If this had been in the Square when I lived in Cambridge, I know I'd be in trouble. RHT fills an important, hip, boozy spot for Harvard Square and Harvard students -- and, boy, are they everywhere.

The beer list is one of the best I've seen in Cambridge, and the cocktails were extensive -- at NYC prices.

The bartenders weren't very friendly, which was odd. Nonetheless, I sat the bar for two hours and had a good time.

I was sad to see zsquare go - I really liked their brunch. But anyway, they are gone.. and now Russell House Tavern fills the space.

We ate there last Friday night and it was really, realy busy. We took one side of a high table up on the main floor. Our waitress was very nice and brought the drinks over pretty quickly - though it's a bit odd: depending on what you order the drinks either come from the bar on the main floor or the one downstairs - so any drink ordered that needs to come from downstairs takes a lot longer. 

The apps were quite good - though timing was very off - we ordered 2 orders of the shrimp, a salad, and 2 other apps. We got 1 shrimp and the other 2 apps, then the salad like a half hour later, then the 2nd shrimp like 45 minutes later. The main course was decent - not bad, but not amazing either. I would agree with most of the reviewers that service seemed kind of slow (but they are new and probably trying to figure it out).

The other odd thing - the night we were there - a busy Friday in which the Celtics were playing an important game - they were showing the food network. We asked several times to put on the game and no one changed the channel - then maybe other people asked , or we asked the right person - and finally the tv was switched to the game. 

i think this is a fun place for a drink with friends after work and maybe a few apps.

4.75 stars

After waiting until I had visited six times, I think I can now write the review. The first two visits it was RHT as Wine Bar and then RHT as Beer Pub. Both times I sat at the upstairs bar and got better than decent recommendations from the bar tenders. The beer and wine lists are loaded with value that any beer aficionado or oenophile can cherry pick from.  Both list feature domestic offerings with a few local/regional choices. 

The upstairs provides you a view of the Harvard Square car and foot traffic; it makes for mildly amusing diversion if you are on your own. I prefer the bar although the high top tables are a good option you might consider if it's crowded.
The down stairs room is what I prefer over all, I like subterranean venues. The bar is a large rectangle with a welcoming open atmosphere.  The rest of the room has booths and tables that are just slightly more densely packed than I would like, yet seating is somewhat intimate.

The food here is more towards the hearty side. It is rich and flavorful, and quite filling. Ingredients are fresh local products used in inventive ways. Without a doubt my favorite item is the oft spoken of poached egg, if you are an egg person you must try this. The beef choices here are all excellent, the burger is superlative. I myself am partial to the short ribs (Braised and the Wellington). The Charcuterie, and the salads are a nice lighter choice.  Pizzas are of high quality served piping hot. The only sandwich apart form the burger I've sampled was the Grilled Chicken, which is also a lighter choice.  

I've yet to try the lamb, chicken, or duck, which I will soon remedy. The Raw Bar has been untouched mostly because I was not dining with people who like it as much as I do. I will certainly be back and update this review.

The service has been quite good with the only soft spot being the sometimes less than helpful hostesses (2/6 visits). The bartenders are very knowledgeable, the servers less so but they never failed to find an answer for me if they didn't know off the top of their head.

* Truly a "Tavern" experience, albeit an upscale one.
* On the expensive side but not without value for your dollar.
