* Try eating downstairs to get the full experience, and bring your appetite.

Really good creative cocktails, and a menu that made me feel like I was back home in San Francisco -- full of well crafted small plates, giving credit to the ingredients.  Very nice raw bar of lots of different types of seafood.  

I ate at the downstairs bar -- which has a full menu -- on my own, and the staff was incredibly friendly.  

It's a bit loud for a date, but a fun energetic atmosphere.  Try going with a group of friends who don't mind spending a bunch of money on food and great drinks, or treating yourself (or being on an expense account).  

Very large restaurant, with two levels and lots of tables and bar space, but crowded.

Ok, so I'm a little biased.  I mean, I suppose any time you go on a first "date" (what is a date, anyway?) with the person you will ultimately marry, the locale tends to have a positive lasting impression.  But the happenstance of fate isn't all RHT has going for it!

Rainy days require comfort food, it is a simple fact of life.  After trapsing through the slushy streets and over-heated boutiques of Harvard Square in search of the elusive, and often non-existent ________ of your dreams, there is simply nothing better than tender, saucy short ribs and buttery mashed potatoes to remind you of life's little pleasures.  Of course, that is if your entree selection isn't derailed by a particularly yummy sounding 3-cheese pasta or some other star winning special.  Portions are generous, and pairings are classic (even expected) but delicious.

RHT doesn't offer five star dining, but the food is consistantly tasty, the staff adorable, and the cozy basement dining room a wonderful locale for a lunch date, dinner with friends, or simply an escape for the New England cold.

We got there early on a Saturday night, so we sat down immediately without a reservation.  Upstairs has a small space with a great looking bar.  Drinks are fair at 10 bucks a pop and tasty.  The service was friendly enough, but sparse in actual face time.  The entrees did not live up to the price.  I think smart folks stick to the sandwiches or burgers.  Dessert was awful; the cake was a brick, being pulled directly from the freezer and served immediately without proper time to get to room temperature.  Overall it was fun to check this place out, but the chic gastro pub ambiance created does not match the price tag.

Wow, this place was good. I had the bone marrow, charcuterie plate, and the pork trio. All were excellent. Service was excellent. Atmosphere was excellent. 

Better than No. 9 especially for the price.

Oh, I also had the Moscow Mule, very good.

Go here

I'm really confused by all the reviews that mention off service - I had an amazingly attentive server here. She hustled her bum off and bent over backwards to ensure that there was something on the menu that would work for my dietary and allergy restrictions.

I do agree with Brian D. that it doesn't seem like a place to immediately write home about - but I have to offer up an extra star for the wine list. I love that they have biodynamic and organic wines called out. The cocktails are also lovely. 

Obviously I like this place because I'm a lush. If you are too and you want to hide it, hit the downstairs bar. If you're out in the open with your foibles sit upstairs and enjoy the people watching in the square.

Somehow, in my nearly two years of adventures in Cambridge and Boston, I'd neglected ever to eat at Russell House.  But the other day, in the course of a sunshiny jaunt through Harvard Square, the BF and I stopped here for lunch.

We started off with the

The mood is of a loud upish scale American restaurant.  The food is just plan tasty!  Crab cakes to start, Chicken Caesar for main, and anything for desert.  The entries are creative at times, but comfortable.  The bar is great.  I am glad this spot is in my hood.

A few years ago, if you'd asked me what sort of restaurant I'd want to open if I were to ever go down that path, I'd have probably said something along these lines: good, comfort-esque food without an air of snootiness, but a nice enough atmosphere that you actually feel like you're capital-G Going Out. 

Apparently, everyone else in Boston had the same idea: it seems like it's impossible to consider dining options around Boston these days without running into the fact that a surprising majority of venues bill themselves as New American gastropubs. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it can lead to a severe case of restaurant fatigue: on a recent Friday evening, when I asked a recommendation from the lady friend on where we should go for dinner, she responded, "Seriously, anything that isn't New American or a gastropub," and I was worried that the whole cuisine had run its course.

Okay, now that the depressing bit's over with, I will get right to the point: Russell House Tavern saved, for me, the concept of the New American gastropub, by honoring the roots of upscale bar fare with solid takes on a variety of categories of ingredients. 

Starting at the beginning, the house charcuterie board is an early standout. The increasingly-popular duck ham is wonderfully deep and gamey, the chicken liver paté is perfectly seasoned, and the Berkshire rillette converted even the most mousseline-phobic of my dining companions, but the real winner here are the paper-thin, ghostly pale, wait-what-is-this-even-meat slices of guanciale: these shavings of cured pork jowl will floor you with their surprisingly strong flavor given their slight appearance. (Also worth mentioning: if you find yourself running out of crostini upon which to place the quite substantial contents of this board, don't worry: the wait staff is on point and will provide you with additional supplies almost instinctively.)

More entree-esque options are, for lack of a better phrase, pretty amazing, and do a pretty nice job at illustrating why New American is still okay. As far as the New, the raw yellowfin tuna off the fairly deep raw bar menu yields a beautiful, well-stated tuna flavor; the cube of seaweed gelee and and slice of yam with a panko-esque crust on the side fill in nicely on either side of the spectrum of taste. If you're looking for the American, look no further than the R. House grass fed burger: large without being ridiculous, served on a toasted English muffin with cheddar, bacon and grilled onions, this is the essence of burger. (Pro-tip: If you've got any leftover spreadable components of the charcuterie board, save 'em for the fries. You'll thank me later.)

Additionally, as should be the case with any restaurant that puts "-pub" anywhere in its moniker, the beverages are certainly not forgotten here: Russell House Tavern offers an impressive list of bottled and draught beers (including Golden Monkey on-tap, always a welcome sight) all priced under $7. If you feel like getting fancy, they've also got larger bottles of stronger beers, as well as a rotating selection of cask ales. Also, the cocktail/liquor list is wonderful, especially where darker spirits are concerned: it's a pretty good call to set aside time for a 14-year-old Balvenie at the end of your meal.

Furthermore, the atmosphere is exactly what you want from a gastropub: appropriately-dim lighting, deep brown leather banquettes, and centrally-located bars, all tucked away in two lower floors down an alley entrance off Harvard Square. Cozy without being lackadaisical, sharp without being intimidating: the perfect balance every establishment that calls itself a gastropub should strive for.

So, don't despair. New American is clearly alive in greater Boston, but it's definitely well at Russell House Tavern.

This review is solely on their brunch service. I had drinks at their upstairs bar and had a great experience. 

This past Sunday me and a couple of friends went to RHT for brunch, without a reservation. It was no problem, we were seated promptly. I was excited to try their sticky buns (as recommended by a friend) but the waitress advised that they had already sold out (it was 1pm on a Sunday). The menu really wasn't anything special. I had a large breakfast so I decided to order a few side dishes. My friends ordered sandwiches. The Egg BTL was good, but not great. The pork sandwich was large but not well seasoned. 

I ordered a biscuit, it arrived with a side of mint berry jelly. I cut the biscuit in half and noticed that the inside was a solid cold piece of dough. 
$3 for a cold biscuit? Nahhhhhh-- not worth it. 
You can get better, FREE, table bread at Olive Garden. Seriously. 

The waitress talked to the chef, who said the dough was made that morning and refrigerated and that's why it was cold. But the outside was totally cooked. Either way, they made a new one for me that was still not  great. I don't want to turn this whole review into a biscuit investigation but.. I have a suspicion that their bread is frozen. 

We were also not impressed with the hash browns. They were soggy and not crisp. They were also a orange color, not sure if they were sweet potato? It was confusing. Nothing like the amazing hash browns at Max and Dylan's (seriously go their for brunch if you haven't) !

I would/will still go here for their drinks, they are well crafted and strong, but I won't be back for the brunch.

After a random Sunday morning spent at the Harvard Natural History Museum, we ended up here for oysters and beer.  I'm sure we ended up deciding that was the best thing to order at noon on a Sunday.... but it was good.  They had a good selection of both!  It was pretty quiet in there as we sat at the downstairs bar and so we started talking to the bartender.  Turns out you can also reserve one or both of the curtained off tables downstairs for private parties.  You can even organize a fixed menu with the chef ahead of time.  Cool idea for get togethers!

RHT, you're growing on me.  

Food, service, atmosphere, oh my!  RHT has improved drastically on all fronts since it's opening.  They've learned to deal with the demanding HSQ residents, and that's no small task.  And, uh, RHT has now become a HSQ favored spot for my girlfriends . . . maybe even THE favorite place.

Wine on tap + oysters + great friends = lovely night out

Now, please keep those addictive fries away from me, and this may be the beginning of a beautiful relationship.

Really cool atmosphere. Loved the bar downstairs. Ordered the Oysters and chocolate cheese cake, both good. $2 per oyster is pretty standard out at restaurants and $8 for a delish dessert isn't bad either. DO NOT; however, order the Scottish Play cocktail. It taste like someone poured liquid smoke in it. I'm not a hater either, I love me some Scotch, but this was just awful. Waiter was super nice, but service was slow (opening weekend, so they were busy and working out kinks). Pear dessert was really gross, another no-no, but sorbet was nice. Friend ordered the Char and said it was mediocre. Presentation was really nice though.

I'd re-visit for drinks and apps.
Awesome place! We ate at the bar that gave the food a casual approach to elegant dining. Cool atmosphere. Order a flatbread and a side of brussels (seriously- the brussel sprouts were delish!)

I ate lunch at Russell House Tavern with a friend from out-of-town. We were seated quickly at a corner table in the basement. The atmosphere was very lively, with students, faculty and businesspeople chatting all around. I was able to use Yelp to check-in, which earned me a free iced tea when I showed this to our waitress. My friend ordered a crab cake sandwich with fries, and I ordered the fish fry. The serving sizes for our meals were enormous, and the chips and fries were delicious. My only complaint is that the fish fry was not all that tasty. It was too oily and limp, and the breading lacked flavor. Next time, I will try something new, making sure to get some fries on the side.

It's too bad our waitress was so attentive and awesome because other than her and the fact that this place is WAY bigger than it looks outside and has a really super extensive beer list, this place looks cooler than it really is.

We got one of their flatbread pizzas which everyone told us was supposed to be one of their specialties, but it was pretty much flavorless. I had to ask for red pepper chili flakes and even that just made it spicy. That crust was so flat, and the cheese was blah which is hard for anyone to say I think since cheese is so amazing ha ha And all of the seasonal fresh veggies on top also had not an ounce of life in them. Basically that pizza was a waste of money and I don't think I would ever come here for food again.

The decor is nice though, and there is a whole downstairs to this place making it way way bigger than I imagined it being. Coming here just for a drink is really the only way this place should be used I think. Their drink list is pretty much awesome and it may take you a while to figure out what you want to order, but I say come here for a drink and leave before you get hungry.

I love this place! I have to ration my visits here, though, or I will begin to look like Mr. Creosote. I am addicted to the caesar salad-luscious anchovy goodness-yum-and the Ozark pork trio is fantastic.  The downstairs seating area is airy and relaxed, with subdued, semi-dim lighting. It's perfect if you're not up to the chaos of upstairs, though there is a beautiful horseshoe bar down there that is plenty lively-nice if you want to have a relaxed dinner, then belly up to the bar and join your fellow humans. Honestly, downstairs is so perfect I really have no desire to ever sit upstairs. Every time I've been here, the service has been attentive and really friendly, neither hovering nor neglectful. HUGE bonus for zero pretentiousness. It feels like home. Always have to fight the urge to curl up and nap in the booth after dinner.

Great place overall.  I go there regularly for the bar and tend to have dinner with my liquor.  Have the Toronto (read 0 to Drunk in 2 drinks) or enjoy a simple Dark and Stormy that will have you asking for at least 3 since the ginger beer is made in house.  Food is definitely worth a shot (they had a rabbit special which complimented my drink superbly and definitely stood out of the rest of the dishes I have had there over time).  You can use this as a start up point for your evening, or it can be your entire evening, this place can suit both needs.  Biggest downside, as it is popular, getting seats can be a real hassle. Plan accordingly

I had brunch here, and it was great. The service was good, the food was good, there wasn't a wait (10:45am on a Sunday, holiday weekend). My only complaint is that the jelly that came with the toast was not particularly gourmet. The bathrooms were nice. The brunch menu includes sandwiches and other lunch-type items, not just eggs.

I've been to this tavern twice now and both times were AMAZING!  The food is so good, entrees are bit pricy but so delicious. The whole set up of the place is really welcoming,cozy and yet elegant. The waiter that we had last time was unbelievable -Steve B.- the way he described each dish was unreal! I would definitely go back even if ti's just for a drink, it's my new favorite spot!

Harvard Square is full of places like this, and this is actually better than most.
- High price
- High quality
- Low creativity
The super-ideal location in the exact center of Harvard Square justifies the prices, and the food is very good.  It's just not special.  Don't go out of your way to go here, but if you're choosing between here and Grafton Street for a Harvard Square "resto-bar" type place, this is better.

This place is way classier than I expected for a place where the name is Russell House Tavern.  I thought I'd be walking into something like the John Harvard Restaurant.. but it was a lot nicer.

We went at 11 pm on a Monday night.. didn't seem too busy.  I think it's because it got cold again.  It is pretty busy on warm nights.

We seated ourselves right away.  They have cafeteria style seating but it's ample on the top floor.  I didn't go to the basement.  The wait staff took forever to bring us menus, etc.

I tried one of the drinks.. it was okay.. too much ice.  It was like 75% ice.  

I ordered one clam.. it is not the regular ones they sell at Skipjack's but it was decent.  I liked they served with ketchup and wasabi.  

I also ordered the pig's head cake appetizer.  I don't even know what was in it.. the sauce was good and I liked the perfectly poached egg.  I did not care for the cake though which means this place misses the point.

Waitress did seem very familiar with the menu so that's good.  I'll have to come again to make a full assessment of the place.

I have had many steaks in my life and my girlfriend normally is not the biggest steak person either, but when we ordered their steaks in just melted in your mouth like butter.

Definitely one of the best steakhouse in town if you do not want to pay Capital Grille prices.

I recommend RHT as the go-to in harvard square, among all the overpriced and mediocre restaurants. The menu is quite innovative and the cooking is quite precise and stable. The pizzas are a great deal - they are large and yummy. The only problem is that the cooking is also quite consistently *salty*. I love salt, soy sauce, oyster sauce, herbs, cracked pepper, etc but man their shit is Saaaaaalllty!!!! Be careful. As long as the exaggerated presence of salt (and the following extreme thirst afterward) is expected, I think any diner will be fine.

I wanted to like this place but the menu for being a pub was very limited. 80% of the menu was breakfast type foods and I was looking for a classic beer and burger pub lunch. I ended up with the gem salad which was a wedge salad, slightly overdressed with creamy dressing, figi apples and cashews. The beer and atmosphere were the highlights of this pub.

To describe their crispy egg in one word: BEAUTIFUL. 

I would happily eat this perfect egg all day, and die at age 22 of some sort of artery congestion ailment, if I had unlimited funds. Alas, I do not and am limited to eating this delectably crispy, crunchy, velvety, smooth and rich egg but once or twice a month. 

Seriously, whoever thought of slow poaching an egg, then coating it in a layer of Panko crumbs, then deep frying without losing the runniness of the egg is a genius. Whatever you do, you have to get the egg. Just do it. GET THE EGG. 

Other dishes I've tried and liked/loved:
BURGER- also mighty tasty (and a steal of an entree at $11, considering most other entrees are $20+). The beef is loosely packed and cooked to order (medium-rare for me) and the fries are a crunchy golden brown. 
STEAK TARTARE - the quail yolk on top just makes this dish, but I'm not a big fan of the overly buttered toasts they serve it with. The butter overpowers the beef. 
CRABCAKES- solid, but with a similar crumb topping as the egg, this  tasted like a less amazing version of the egg. A good basic for less adventurous eaters.
RILLETTE- decent  but with other interesting things to order I probably won't get it again. And I know duck fat is in, blah blah, and I love duck fat fries, but I don't exactly want to see a half centimeter thick layer of congealed fat on top of my food. 
OYSTERS- oysters were good, decently fresh and tasty. 

Oh yeah, and they have lots of interesting drinks and beers too. But remember to get the egg. THE EGG.
Went here for brunch the other day. Portions were generous but the menu was limited, the staff was inattentive and our order got messed up. The Mimosa was overpriced and undersized.

I liken my Russell House dining experience to watching a disappointing movie at an awesome cineplex.

The food was surprisingly mediocre:

1) The 'R. House' burger is served with a twist, using English muffins instead of traditional buns. For something that is a supposed favorite, I expected more. It was like driving a base-model Toyota without any of the optional bells and whistles. Very boring.

2) The 'Salt & Pepper shrimp' was a soggy mess. Disappointing. And the only thing 'salt & peppa' about it was that I wanted to "push it" away from me.

3) The 'House Made Cotechino Sausage pizza' is another supposed favorite. I did love the thin crust, but considering the number of ingredients and toppings on it, found it underwhelming at best. 

It then dawned on me that the last time I had food this bland was during my stint in London, so if it is authenticity you are looking for, then 5-stars for the immersive experience. On future visits, I'll order food here strictly as an add-on to drinking with friends.

Outside the food, Russell House does have one of the best ambiences I've experienced in a while. The beer is great, and the fact that they have a huge downstairs bar (perfect for group functions) as well as outside patio dining option gets major points. 

The service was also top-shelf. We had Brenda the host, and Scott the waiter, who were just fabulous. Loved them. Never enjoyed coming to a new place as much as this visit, and we'll be sure to come again.

I've been here enough times to try an incredible amount on the menu. I can honestly say, they have some GREAT choices.

First off-You can't go wrong with their burger. They keep the bacon thick and the english muffin bun holds it together awesomely. 

The beef heart ravioli was surprisingly good! I wasn't sure about this one, but it won my heart (see what I did there?) with its spices.

My favorite so far is the seasonal scallops. Get over there soon so you can try them out!

The prices are a bit steep, but if you want something DELICIOUS with a great atmosphere, you can't lose.

They really know how to take a reservation. We were seated on time. Upon entry, we were told our reservation was for a table downstairs and that we were to see the hostess down there. When we came down the stairs, we didn't even have to check in again; the hostess was ready to seat us.
The service was decent and the food was good. I am only giving them 3 stars because the food wasn't so good that I remember what I ate.

Went here twice in two days. First time had smoked pork sandwich- literally best sandwich I had in my entire life. Next time I went it was just ok. Otherwise great menu selection. Clean. Fun to people watch in Harvard square.

UPDATE:
I have been hesitant to go back to Russell House since my last visit was so bad.  Tonight, some friends (3 total) convinced me to give it another try.  Wednesday night around 7, we walk in.  Place is busy and we don't have a reservation.  No problem.  We put our name in, they say ~20 minute wait, so we grab a beer in the upstairs bar.  

Fast forward 1 hour.  We are now at the downstairs bar, having checked in with the hostess before that to see how we were doing.  "20 minutes" was the reply.  Well, we know that's not true, but no big deal. 

Fast forward 20 more minutes.  The hostess tells us that "a table is going to be ready soon" and she is sorry for how long we've waited.

Fast forward 20 more minutes (a total of one hour and forty minutes).  We walk out with another terrible experience at Russell House.  We walked around the corner and got a delicious Felipe's Burrito for $5 in less than 2 minutes!

Now having to wait for a table is not a big deal.  What is a big deal is how you are told repeatedly the same BS line of "20 minutes."  If they were upfront with how long the wait was we probably would have just gone somewhere else.  I guess they lose business for that night, but it certainly would not have left such a terrible taste in my mouth.  Honesty is the best policy. 

This place has lost my business for good.  It's too bad since it has so much promise, but it just appears to be managed by buffoons with no idea of how to run a restaurant or train a staff.  Great location, great beers, great ambiance, interesting menu, but just flat out terrible service from start to finish really is a deal breaker for me at this place.  

No more.

Original Review:

My first experience with Russell House was fine. I checked it out because it was a new spot in Harvard Square that thankfully wasn't trying too hard to be a high-end, pretentious place (i.e. Om) and it wasn't a complete dive bar (i.e. Tommy Doyle's).  It is a nice middle to upper range pub with a decent menu and a great space.

THEN I went a second time for a planned event to celebrate my friends graduating from grad school.  IT WAS A COMPLETE DISASTER.  I actually signed up for Yelp to write the review since it was such a terrible experience.

First, it was a pre-fixe menu and we had to order ahead of time, which was fine. $45 seemed like a reasonable price.  When we get there they seated us almost immediately.  It was a large group of roughly 30 people.  We were told there would be two large tables set up in the basement so people could socialize and talk with each others families.  Once we sat down, the disaster began.  

We were broken into six small tables of 5 per person, not the two tables we were promised.  This basically meant that each family had to sit together without the ability to interact with others in the group over dinner.  Except, of course, the one family that had to disperse amongst the other tables because of the poor seating arrangement.  They didn't even get to sit with one another!  

The service was horrendous.  We didn't get bread or water for over an hour after sitting down.  First course salad came out an hour and a half after sitting.  Main course roughly two hours.  This was for a pre-fixe 3 course dinner where the order had been placed the day before!  

Once the food finally came, it did little to salvage the night.  One member of the party who was in from out of town and who claims to have never returned a dish before returned his fish entree because it was so bad.  I had steak frites, which should have been more appropriately named plate of french fries, as there were three meager pieces of poorly cooked steak.  Others seemed to have decent food, but nobody was blown away.

Then, to top off the night, we get the bill and it averages $75 per person.  Where did the additional $30 per person come from.  Maybe half of the group ordered 1-2 cocktails and the others did not.  How does that math work out?  After asking the waitress how it all worked out she did not have much of an answer.  Then after speaking with the manager they reluctantly informed us (as if they were going to "slide it by us") that they added a 10% service charge on top of the 18% gratuity that they had already tacked on (the tip is totally reasonable).  The additional service charge was not disclosed to us prior to getting the bill.  After an hour of dealing with this nonsense we were able to walk out of that place with a disgusting feeling of a terrible experience.  

I cannot recommend the Russell House in good conscious to any of my friends.  Maybe if you're just going to grab a quick beer and a bite to eat, but certainly not for anything more than that.  Like I said, I have always read Yelp but never contributed.  This experience was so poor that I finally felt compelled to Yelp about it and let people know to avoid planning any sort of event at this place.  But, if you do, you've been warned..

Looking for a good place for lunch in Harvard Square, two of us walked into Russell House Tavern, an upscale pub.  Like other reviewers have mentioned there's both the small upstairs bar and patio area and a much larger downstairs bar and restaurant, where we ate.  The decor was very nice, although the one downside was the smell - there was something stale about the smell downstairs that definitely bothered us.  

Fortunately, the food impressed us - we'll definitely be back!  I got the arctic char nicoise, a very light, fresh salad with greens, olives, green beans, crispy potatoes, a large portion of perfectly cooked arctic char, and a light olive oil dressing.  I was in the mood for something light and simple, and this definitely fit the bill.  

The other entree was the burger with cheese, garlic aioli, and caramelized onions on an English muffin.  At first I was really concerned by the muffin - it makes a regular burger look much smaller, and I'm much more used to brioche or some other oversized bun - but both of us loved the burger, and in fact said it was the best we've ever had.  Now I know I've had amazing burgers all over the country, and I'm not sure I'm ready to say it's the best burger ever, but I will definitely put it in the top few I've had.  And the English muffin was perfect on it - just enough bread to hold everything together without overwhelming the rest of the burger.  

Also - check in on Yelp and get a free non-alcoholic beverage!  

In the end our tab was $25, which is more than we can afford to spend on a daily basis for lunch, but when you want something nicer than a quick bite it's definitely a good value for what you get.  We'll be back for more!

Just an OK experience here. I really thought I would like this place more. 

I had family in town and they wanted to walk around Harvard Square. I chose this place for brunch since I've been wanting to try it for a while and have read mostly good things. 

The atmosphere of the place was cool. When I walked in I thought it was tiny, then we were lead downstairs which was HUGE! 

Service was SLOW and unenthusiastic. The vibe from most of the people in the place was cold. The first table we were offered wasn't great but they looked at us like it was an inconvenience to offer another. We ordered a couple brunch drinks and they sat at the bar for 10 minutes within view of us. I was surprised the bartender couldn't just bring them over since our girl was out of sight.  

We had various items on the menu, I got a burger which was delicious and topped with bacon and onions. When ordering she asked if I wanted a salad or fries. I asked how the fries were, expecting to hear the cut/style of them and she replied they are just salty. That turned me off so I had the side salad which had a tasty vinaigrette. 3 items out of 4 arrived at once and the 4th was another wait but the busboy who brought it was very friendly and nicely apologized for the delay. At the end we waited a while to cash out the check. We left not impressed with the place. The food was good so it may warrant a future visit.

This place has the best burger in Harvard square, I swear. Ridiculous portions, too! I say order a salad with it and then mooch off of your girlfriend's or boyfriend's fries since this place puts enough on your plate to feed a small army. The prices here in general are great as well, so hard to come by. My boyfriend and I came here on our first date, and when we both had to leave after graduation it was a great place to revisit.

Went here on a whim some months back for brunch, and have been coming back consistently since. Russell House Tavern falls into that odd "gastropub" category - a pub environment and feel, with top notch quality food. While I didn't try any of the mixed drinks, they had a decent selection of bottle and draft. I've gone for both brunch and dinner, both were excellent. Food was served quickly, and everything tasted great. One of my favorite spots in Cambridge for a nice night out.

OK, I've been here three times and still haven't written a review.  I'm losing it.  Someone get me some some gingko biloba or something. 

First two visits were great (Ozark pork three ways=WIN.)  The third was a well but with a curious side note.  We went last night during Boston's restaurant week and got to see first-hand why so many restaurants despise restaurant week.  

The couple next to us was older and looked like they hadn't been to a restaurant in years.  The female orders a steak rare and it comes rare.  she eats almost half of it, then complains that it's to rare.  Without hesitation the waitress apologizes and presents another that is slightly more cooked.  She eats almost all of that and then declares that it also, is not prepared the way she asked.  

She is then brought a third entirely different entree and demolishes that as well, before having dessert.  My guess is that the saint-like waitress (who was also our waitress and did an overall excellent job) got solidly stiffed on the tip from these two clowns too.  It was like a Harvard business case on "why restaurant week sucks." 

For the record though:

Chip-In Egg is fantastic.  It's an egg that they use some sort of magic on to allow them to poach and then batter and fry it.  Yet it's still runny when you break it open.  Delicious, tasty magic I say.   

18oz cowboy ribeye.  This is no joke.  I got it rare, it came rare and delicious.  The potatoes had some sort of funky salt on them that was almost citrusy.  I liked it quite a bit.  And spinach, garlic and blue cheese is always tasty.  

Russell House is one of my favorite places in the Boston area.  Three visits and I've never had a bad meal.

This is a review for the brunch, which I thought was great!

We called ahead to make a reservation for our group of seven and were pleased when they actually saved a table for us!  I feel like this is increasingly rare in Boston, so major props to Russell House Tavern.

I got the eggs benedict (which includes sauteed spinach on the english muffin, so consider it more of an eggs florentine).  Great taste, good texture.  My mimosa was tasty, albeit very weak.

The rest of the group seemed happy as well, so four stars for Russell House.
Fancy pants pub.

I really really wanted to write a good review for this place. This Harvard Square hot spot had come highly recommended by a food warrior friend of mine that has sadly relocated to Brooklyn. She told me that if I was looking for a phenomenal burger, that I needed to get my derriere to RHT. So, before heading to the Brattle Theater for some classic Alfred Hitchcock flicks, I grabbed my boyfriend and headed toward JFK St. To my chagrin, I was so unfortunately let down. 

The atmosphere, I have to admit, is lovely. And if I was rating this place for decor and feel alone, it would certainly get 5 stars. It had a sleek interior with a high class pub feeling with throwbacks to a happier time. There is a smallish upstairs and additional seating downstairs. They had a patio in the alleyway next to the restaurant that reminded me of one of those random sidestreet cafe's in Europe. I was sold immediately and started thinking of the fabulous review I was about to write. Alas, man cannot live on decor alone. 

We were seated in the lovely cafe area outside and were promptly forgotten. No worries, it was a beautiful day, and we were enjoying the shade. The menu was extensive and looked exotic with things like Crispy Pigs Head Cake and Smoked Lamb Belly Toast. I was super excited about the Short Rib Wellington. And my boyfriend got the highly recommended grass fed Burger. We intended on splitting both because we couldn't decide. To their credit, they split the plates for us. (I always give brownie points for this. It's such an easy thing to do and makes life MONUMENTALLY easier for us.)

We ordered the burger medium rare and it came out so rare that the inside of the burger came spilling out in a gloopy mess. We mentioned this fact to the server, and while at first she seemed to understand the extent to which this was unappetizing, she then asked if we wanted to wrap it to go. No, no we would not. The fries were ok, mostly overdone, but the ones that didn't snap in half were quite tasty. The Wellington was actually pretty good and a decent size for an appetizer. There was a lot of fat to the meat, but that's a hazard one takes when ordering beef. The pastry puff tasted like plastic. The apples were a pleasant and delicious surprise. However, as rich as the food was, it was missing that kick that would have made it delicious.

The food was just a tad overpriced. We didn't eat the burger and received no apology, no visit from a manager, no adjustment on our bill. I was a little disappointed. The server was very friendly and once she got to our table, she was attentive. The beer selection was decent. Not too many draughts but a healthy bottle selection. However, I don't think I'll be coming back. With the wealth of gastro options in Harvard Square, I'll probably choose elsewhere next time.

WHAT THE HELLLLL TOOK ME YEARS TO GET HERE?!

Literal.

YEARRRS.

I work a stones throw away and I would walk by Russell House only eleventy billion times a week.

My fiance wanted to meet me for a cocktail after work and I told him that we should try Russell House Taven.

I made the right decision.

I left work at 5:00 and stepped into Russell House minutes later.

It was a nasty, rainy, windy, raw winters night and I was glad to find shelter in this wonderful establishment.

I was pleasantly greeted by a hostess and I asked her if I could have a seat a the bar.  Downstairs.  It was quieter than upstairs and seemed kinda cool being all downstairs and all.

I made the right decision.

My bartender was Lou and he was quick with the cocktail menu and a nice glass of water for me.  I ordered Moscow Mule, which was delicious.  Vodka isn't really my drink of choice but I wanted to try their house-made ginger beer.

I made the right decision.

I perused the food menu and my had my eyes and salivary glands on their grassfed burger.  I was not here for dinner though, so made a mental note come back soon.

My fiance showed up a few minutes later when I was happily sipping my drink.

He ordered a Manhattan, on the rocks, with rye.

He loved it.

He had another.  I decided to try their St. Germain Cocktail.  This cocktail will now rival all other cocktails, yes, even my beloved Gin Gin Mule.  It tasted like a liquid floral garden.  Made with St. Germain, sparkling white wine and soda water.

It was delicious.

I made the right decision.

We paid our bill and went off into the cold weather, happily buzzed compliments of Lou at Russell House.

I returned yesterday for lunch.  Sat at the bar.  Downstairs.  Got the grassfed burger.  HOT DAMN ON A TUESDAY NIGHT WAS IT GOOD!

I made the right decision.

I also got their fries.  Which were honestly, the BEST FRIES I've ever had.  Golden brown, handcut, perfectly cooked -- just like my medium well burger.

I ordered it well done because I am a crazy old lady who thinks meat should be burnt.  But, god bless his heart, the bartender told me to order it another way.

I listened to him.

I made the right decision.

Make the right decision and get to Russell House Tavern.

Second time here, first for food.

The menu is... well... eclectic.  I didn't have a lot to choose from as I didn't recognize what most of the dishes were on the menu.  The service was slow to me, as it felt like it took forever to get a food order put in or a refill on my drink.  I ordered a pizza that they had on special here, which was a garlic and fennel base, onion, roasted tomato, smoked pork, and mozzarella cheese.  Amazing.  The signature cocktails were equally as eclectic as most of us at the table couldn't recognize most of the ingredients.  I ordered a local brew to start and switched over to a mojito.  Both were equally good,

It seems like the Russell House Tavern would be a fantastic place for a foodie that has some innate knowledge of eclectic food and drink but for the mainstream crowd, I'd choose somewhere else.

This is half of a two-parter! Try not to fall off the edge of your seat.

Someone suggested Russell House Tavern. I went. There were stools available at the bar. I sat. The menu was placed in front of me. I ordered.

If I had instructed the bartender (who had all the personality of my Torched Tuna plate) to whip up a cocktail that tasted like a Ricola cough drop, he couldn't have done better than the Battle of Trafalgar that he handed me. It kind of made me feel like I was sick every time I sipped it. I've had the same thing happen at 2Amy's with a prosecco/fruit concoction that tasted exactly like Pink Grapefruit Airborne. So unfortunate.

My tuna was three tiny slivers drizzled with oil and pepper. For $13 I was expecting something... more. In contrast, the side of mashed potatoes I got were way too much for one person.

So, we've got a cough remedy drink, flavored air and a carb overload for the low, low price of $29. I'm only adding the third star because my companion requested a rum suggestion, and the resulting Old Monk 7 year was delightful. Onward and outward...

I'm a fan of going out to dinner during the holidays.  Everything is lit up and decorated, and people are in festive moods. The Russel House Tavern was no different, and played nothing but Christmas music (annoying for some, but welcome for me!)

They sat portions of our party of 5 and allowed them to wait at the table for the rest of us, which was great considering one person was stuck on the Red Line at a few stops, and I had to wait extra long for a bus after one broke down.

Our waiter was attentive and not overly friendly.  There was always a full water bottle (tap) at our table once we ran out.

The drink menu is extensive and creative.  I was excited to see all the different drinks with St. Germain, but stuck with my old standby, the St. Germain cocktail (St Germain and bubbles), rather than getting it with something stronger.  It was a school night, after all.  The wines come in low ball glasses, which other reviewers scoff at, but I liked the glasses, and appreciated them not wanting gesticulators (me) to knock a full glass over too easily.  

Apps were small, except the one I ordered.  Yellowfin tuna looked great but had 3 small slices with a tiny cube of seaweed gelee (only tasted the seaweed, which was very good.)  Fried oysters come with 5 breaded morsels on top of a spicey orange sauce.  My mother responded "I guess we aren't in Essex anymore"! referring to the fried food restaurants near the beach that pile breaded bivalves on an enormous platter.  The fois gras was a normal-sized portion of this dish that I've seen elsewhere, but I didn't taste it.  I got the melted cheese appetizer, that comes with mushrooms and carmelized onions and entirely too many toasted pita wedges to justify with the small-ish tray of cheese and veggies.  But oh-so-delicious.

I went out on a limb and ordered the Char, a fish I don't think I have ever had before.  Very impressive.  Cooked to perfection, it resembles salmon in color and somewhat in taste.  It was served over a white sauce that seemed buttery and garlicky, more mushrooms, cooked apples (decent, but didn't really belong), with a pine nut mix on top.  SO good.  I practically licked my plate clean.

The table split sides of grits (SUPER) and french fries, which weren't crispy enough for me.  My sister got brussel sprouts and they were awesome.

For dessert, we all split the molten chocolate cake and the trio of sorbets.  Apple Cider Sorbet tasted like the real thing, fresh from the orchard.  The cake was unappealing to the eye (it kind of resembled a chocolate desert, as in sand and dry air, not sweet post-dinner course.)  However, it was indeed molten, the ice cream scoop on top was good, and the ginger-caramel sauce was a wonderful accompaniment.

I definitely recommend Russel House.

I went here on a date recently, and fell in lovee with this place!! What a hidden gem (well i'm not sure about hidden as it is in the center of harvard square), but it was hidden to me as I never venture out to cambridge. Massive place, extensive seating downstairs, bar seating upstairs, and tables outside. It was a thursday night and was pretty packed, probably because it was the first 80 degree day of spring in the arctic tundra of mass. However, we prevailed on the battlefield and managed to get seated outside. The cocktail menu is EXTENSIVE. Pitchers of St. Germain Cocktail? awesome. Wine on tap, awesome. Crowd? Awesome. It was not full of cambridge snobs or hipsters, which let's face it, some cambridge bars can be.

Great service, interesting drinks, very good food (especially the Arctic Char), a little pricey, and the menu is unusual - which is good, but it isn't unusual in an "all these are awesome" way; it's unusual in a "I'm not sure about any of these, but I'll try it."  I'd be skeptical, but the food is actually really good.

After hearing me rave about the burger here for the past week, my boyfriend wanted to check this place out.  We went with two of his friends this past weekend and had the opportunity to check out more items off the menu.  This time was even better than the last. 

We started with their deviled eggs, which had a kick of heat to them (spicy, but tasty).  We also ordered a dozen oysters, which were very good (fresh).   We slurped them up quickly.  On to the entrees.  One of our friends had actually already eaten dinner a couple of hours earlier, so he wanted something light.  He ordered the Beet Salad with the crispy poached egg (from the small plates menu).  He said the Beet Salad and egg was really good.  He actually went on and on  about the Beet Salad  (and I don't think it was just the bourbon talking).  He seemed to really enjoy it.  Our other friend ordered the pork trio, which had pork belly, pork shoulder and some other pork (I forget which).  I tried a portion of each type of pork and damn, I think I will order this next time I go.  It was really good. 

As for my boyfriend and I....  he tried (and loved) the burger.  I also ordered the burger, this time with a side salad instead of fries.  I also got an order of the honey brussells sprouts to share with the table - - everyone was shocked that brussells sprouts could taste this good.  I think next time I'll pass on the side salad and just stick to the sprouts - they are really that good.  Weird, I know.  

The service was just OK - my boyfriend's burger was brought out with a side salad instead of the fries he had ordered, but that was quickly remedied (they left the salad, but brought out a large bowl of fries for the table....all the better for me to steal some.)   My only real gripe about the service was that it was slow and surley.   Our waitress seemed put out by our drink requests; she just seemed unhappy.  At one point, later in the evening when we were enjoying after dinner cocktails, I asked her, "are you trying to get out of here and are we keeping you?", thinking perhaps we were her last table and that would explain why she was so annoyed.  She said no, but didn't seem to change her attitude.  We still tipped her well, but honestly, after a $400 tab for dinner and many (many) drinks, would it kill you to smile? 

I won't ding the restaurant for one sourpuss waitress. The food was just too damn good.  It's funny, because we live in Somerville and all of us were saying "this place is what Foundry could have been, if only their food didn't suck..." (If you are local, you'll probably understand that statement).  The food here is just excellent.  Not pretentious, just tasty and varied.  I'm going to have to keep bringing friends here so I can try their entrees while still enjoying that amazing burger.   DAMN, that burger calls to me every time I come here.

I'm not easy with my 5 star yelp reviews for restaurants, but this place deserves it.  Daring menu, executed well, with great beers on tap.  I constantly look for reasons to complain at restaurants, and struggle here.  Try the small plates.

Pathetic and excellent, so I'm torn with my rating. I really want to like this place because I go to Harvard Square all the time, but had the best and the worst service in the same visit. 

I went there with my friend and my boyfriend. This was our second attempt since we tried to get at the downstairs bar the previous Sunday and it was a full house with no one budging. We waited and two seats opened. My friend and I took the seats and we waited for a third to open. Our first bartender was awesome. My friend, being a typical martini lover, asked for a martini in a special way. The bartender served it right up, was very friendly and answered our questions.

A group of three chairs opened on the other side of the bar, so we moved over there. Another bartender was doing most of the service over there, but there were three bartenders taking care of everything. 

The bartender completely ignored us for the entire visit. It was busy, but not insane and she helped every person around us. She was just kind of hanging around at a couple of points. We had to ask her to put in an order for an appetizer and her demeanor was very unwelcoming.

Our glasses were empty while we were eating. I called over the nice bartender and told him we were waiting 20 minutes with no service and she was just standing there. He remembered my friend's martini order and he asked the other bartender to make it. She made it and put it down with a bit of an attitude. We had to go through the same thing again to put in our dinner order and again, we sat there with empty glasses. The good bartender came over again and helped us out.

My boyfriend later flagged her down for a shot of very expensive shot of scotch and she spaced it. 

The food was awesome. We had salads, pizza and burgers. One bartender was awesome, but the other bartender made me really annoyed spending my money there. We did give a good tip because we assume they pool the tips and wanted to give the first guy his due, but honestly, I wanted to put the money in his pocket directly.

Really good place!  My co-worker suggested this place saying it had the best burgers in the city.  I wasn't in the mood for a hamburger so I got the BLT.  Delicious!  Salad was fresh.  The cocktails were delicious as well.  Nice ambiance and location. 
Definitely would love to go back.

Met some friends for a late dinner here last night. I'd been to RHT for lunch before and was generally happy with both the food and the atmosphere. It's got a casual but classy vibe going on, and they have a nice selection of beer/wine and some interesting cocktails (try the "Always Sunny"). 

Most at my table got the burger, which they all raved about- except for the pickle, which tasted "like death" and was panned by everyone (I did not try it myself). Fries were plentiful and tasty (skin-ons, score). 

I had eaten earlier so just wanted a small bite and ordered the tiny lobster slider ($6), nothing to rave about but nothing to really complain about either. I also ordered a side of grits ($6) which at first bite were really tasty and cheesy, but the more I ate the less I liked it... the entire thing was riddled with parsley, and although I'm indifferent to parsley generally, that's literally all I could taste. It was fully incorporated in it too, making it really difficult to pick out. These would have been a win if there had been no parsley (or at least less). 

Service is professional but friendly. RHT has some clear wins and some missteps, but overall I think it's a decent, comfortable spot for dining or drinks in the area.

Last night, I enjoyed braised beef tongue, chicken liver confit, and lamb belly pizza, in the course of a single meal. So long as Russell House Tavern continues to serve the stranger portions of meats, and to serve them well, they have a regular (and wild

Very unexpected in Harvard Square but definitely worth a visit. Me and my niece visited on a Sunday afternoon. We were
 sat promptly-they have plenty of seating. The atmosphere downstairs was very "old school cigar bar". Lots of wood paneling and dim lighting. Started with a Moscow Mule to drink-fabulous. To eat i had the burger. It was very tasty but not life changing. The portion size of the burger was perfect, not too big not too small. I was served a ton of fries with it. Do not go here expecting ur typical bar food-the burger was served on an english muffin. The menu selection is small but very "foodie" appealing. I will def go back.

oh, the Roosell Hoose! i do enjoy you. 

had dinner there last week, which i scored thusly:

Appetizers: 10/10
we ordered two dishes from the small plates menu (serrano ham w/ manchego cheese and pickled pears, and the maine mussel salad) and, honestly, there was not a thing i would change about either of them. the pickled pears were a bright complement to the ham and cheese, and the bacony vinaigrette on the salad was just the right kind of salty and very yum. both were served with buttery crostinis, all the better to scoop up every last morsel, my dear....

Entrees: 8/10 
i ordered the braised lamb shoulder with gnocchi and poached egg. now, this is not an attractive plate of food. but what it lacks in looks it makes up for in personality, because i would definitely date this dinner. it is maybe a touch unsubtle -- it kinda hits you over the head with flavor at every bite, which could get a little overwhelming but is enough to make your eyes roll back in your head at the first bite. my boyfriend ordered the duck confit dish, the true star of which was the "fall stew" of figs, sage, chestnut and pork belly. yes, that IS as good as it sounds.

Dessert: 7/10
amazingly enough, i was not all that excited about RHT's dessert menu, but we decided on the gingerbread cake. the flavor was nice but the cake was dense, which was probably the point but is still not my favorite texture. 

Drinks: * / 10
this one is a wild card, because i ordered a classic cocktail that was adequately crafted and my boyfriend ordered a creative cocktail which, it turned out, just wasn't his thing. no harm no foul. 

Service: 7/10
our waitress seemed a little distracted but she was friendly, and she gave me a million olives in my dirty martini so it's aiight. 

so, roosell hoose. you are a winner.

I love this place. The food is inventive and delectable, and the wine on tap is highly recommended and inexpensive.  

It is worth noting, however, that the portions are quite small, but the food is rich so in that sense I think the portions are sufficient.  Also, I wouldn't recommend this place to vegetarians.  Definitely great for meat-lovers, though!

I would absolutely give zero stars if possible. I will never again patronize Russell House or any of their affiliated restaurants, including Temple Bar and Grafton Street. 

My husband and friend got together to plan a dinner party for my birthday. They chose RHT, in part, because I really liked the food last time we went and it has a nice vibe. The reservation was made last week for 15 people. Surprisingly, I am actually more popular than I anticipated and the guest list ended up being more like 20 people. My husband called RHT as soon as possible (on Monday or Tuesday when the last burst of RSVPs came) to notify them and was told that we would no longer fit into their private room and would now need to sit in the regular restaurant. OK fine, no big deal. They then told him we would have to have a limited menu. Again, not a problem. We understand that they don't want to have to potentially prepare any given item off the menu. 

When we contacted RHT to set the limited menu, we were then informed that it had to be a prix fixe menu. Jigga wha? That's entirely different than limited menu. And on top of that, it was going to be $45 per person for a 3 course meal. Now, I'm not objecting to prix fixe menus generally, but springing that news on someone the day before their event is completely unacceptable. Ericka, the event coordinator, told my husband that they had to have a prix fixe menu because the restaurant wanted to guarantee a certain amount of revenue -- which, of course, we probably would have hit just with drinks and food alone, but being restricted to 2 courses to hit the mark doesn't work for our crowd. 

Calls to Ian, the general manager, went unreturned for quite some time. Again, not a problem if we weren't 24 hours away from the event and we wouldn't possibly have to find another restaurant to hold 20 people on a Friday evening. 

Ian, after dodging our phone calls for a couple of hours, was obviously super helpful (sarcasm) and said that it was the restaurant group's policy that there be a prix fixe menu for any large groups of 15 people or more...which is apparently not true since our initial reservation was for 15 and the restaurant was told at that time that there was a real possibility that we would add more people.

In short, don't waste your time with the circus at RHT unless you really like dealing with idiots. Save yourself the trouble and book any large parties at Daedalus, where the management is not inept and they actually welcome your business.

I have heard very, very good things about Russell House Tavern, mostly focused on their drinks and brunch. And I will say that when I went for drinks and dinner, I was not disappointed. The atmosphere is a little corporate, but that's something that plagues pretty much any nice restaurant/bar in Harvard Square. It is pleasant, and spacious, and though Russell House is often packed on the weekend, it isn't overwhelming once one is seated. The service was excellent, as our waiter was very attentive and friendly. Russell House also gets bonus points for the complimentary sparkling water, which is one of those oh-I'm-not-in-New-York moments for me. It's a nice gesture, and gives Russell House a little bonus point for classiness.
As for the drinks, I tried two different cocktails, and had a sip of my friend's two drinks. Each and every one was  a little different, but they all were excellent in flavor, yet packed a serious punch. I didn't get to try any of the beers on the list, but that list was lengthy and promising, plentiful enough to encourage me to return for more sampling.
We both ordered the chicken sandwich with 1/2 fries, 1/2 salad. That 1/2 sides option is nice, and the sandwich was excellent. It wasn't exactly the most original flavor I've had, but it was certainly good and something I'd be happy to eat again. I've heard good things about the burger, and about their cheap oyster happy hour, something I would very much like to attend. However, this is where I get to the not-so-good part of the review, which is that their average entree price seems pretty steep for a tavern/pub, even in Harvard Square. From the offerings listed, the pricing seemed like a bit much, and definitely limited my ordering options.
All in all, I would say that I'd be happy to hit up Russell House for more drinks and perhaps those oysters, but their dinner options beyond the sandwiches are pricier than they might be worth. I would like to try their brunch options, but when it comes to dinner, I'll come back to Russell House only when I want a burger or delicious but rich grilled chicken sandwich.
Very eclectic cocktail menu and fun appetizers/tapas style food.  Cute waitresses too! (That never hurts)  I prefer upstairs to down, but that is just me.  Very nice bathrooms too!

I have only been here on Sunday mornings for brunch. Eggs Benedict were delectable and our waitress was quick and courteous. Recommend to anyone wanting an enjoyable Sunday brunch, and there never has been a wait.

Ok such a cool, Bostony feeling place for Harvard Sq. Downstairs was super cozy for a cold day and somewhere you could stay all afternoon. Bartender was sooo funny and nice - all of them actually. Let us taste like 4 wines each before we chose a bottle. Cheese plate was generous for the price. Lobster sliders were a little dry but a good price. I would def go back. Yummy drinks and great service! Other pub-ish food all looked super yummy too!

Well, we went here on a Saturday evening. It was, to say the least, bustling. We had to wait 15 minutes for a table, but only because we wanted to sit outside on a beautiful evening (who wouldn't), and we were content to sample the cocktail menu while we waited at the bar. 

The drinks are what separate this place from an otherwise typical mid/upscale Harvard Sq establishment. A great variety of original cocktails comprise the selection, from classics (whiskey/rye combinations, martinis) to colorful and worldly conceptions that are part of a rotating menu (not sure on what basis, seasonal, maybe, or whenever they feel like changing). She had a Dutch Summer, which was really fruity but delicious; I had a Trafalgar, an odd mix of liquors (I usually take a simpler drink) but good and strong. 

Don't discount the food. While not their strong point, we're still talking about a pretty upscale place here, and the food meets this standard. We had a spinach based dip with some pita-esque slices, which was great and came in a large enough portion to be a meal in itself. She had a 'dirty' Caesar salad, which was good but came adorned with anchovy infused croutons (I guess that's the dirty part?), which neither of us were brave enough to try. I had the roasted Giannone farm chicken, which I must say was incredibly tasty and perfectly cooked, though not terrible inventive. 

The atmosphere (on a Saturday night) was busy but not overcrowded, speaking in a medium tone of voice, outside was nice as you are in a sort of alleyway where you may watch people walk past, look up at the ivy overhanging your table, etc. 

Recommended, particularly for the drinks.

"the food was great, but the service sucked."  

those words were resonating through my head, reminiscent of the operations management course i was enrolled in.  maybe it was the time we arrived at the russell house tavern, situated conveniently right in the heart of harvard square.  it was much later, and the bruins playoffs were preoccupying many of the patrons who seem to know many of  the staff who worked there.  

we were seated at one of the high tops by the window, which featured an outstanding people-watching vantage point.  this was part of the smaller upstairs with its storefront, supplemented by an enormous downstairs with another bar, similar to the old z square interiors.  the lighting was pleasant and really set the mood.  

the menu consisted of high-class bar food, such as oysters on the half shell and the charcuterie plate, items that make regular appearances on our table when we do get out to the bars.  the beer selection was equally impressive, with beers that were not well-known.  they also had a cask-conditioned ale, which was unfortunately kicked five minutes prior to our visit.  

what irked us was when we were seated and provided menus to muse over, the server appeared quickly and just stood there.  my boyfriend did not even know she was there as he was too busy going over the menu.  we needed a little more time, so she disappeared to get our water.  in fact, she never came back with the sparking water she offered, and my boyfriend had to get someone from the bar to provide us with some regular water.  she was apparently serving the whole top floor, while two hostesses stood around chatting with each other.  

when the food arrived, we thought the food was outstanding.  in fact, we kept needing more bread for the charcuterie plate that we were trying to finish off.  asking for more bread was challenging, especially for someone as impatient as i.  our server would put the order in for more bread, and someone else from the kitchen would come out with the bread perfectly laid out on a trendy rectangular plate about ten minutes later.  we really just wanted more bread.  

our server disappeared for a long time.  we wanted the bill.  we were there for probably two hours for a late dinner on a school night.  we will go back for the food, drink and atmosphere, but be warned of slow service.

Came here for restaurant week. Best eatery around Harvard Square. 

- Ambiance: 5
   Conveniently located in the busiest area of Harvard Square, it has outdoor sitting a as well as two floors inside. 

- Food: 5 
   I order the oyster and chicken and my friend ordered the pasta. Portions are huge and every single dish is absolutely delish! 

- Sevice: 4
   Waiter is friendly and helpful, except a little slow with the check. 

Due to restaurant week, we got super full of yummy food for a great price. HIGHLY RECOMMEND

Russel House is succeeds and fails on different dimensions...
1. Drinks: success! Cocktails are delicious and wines (on tap!) are affordable. 
2. Food: Tastes great but they seem to be always out of something on the menu. What is available is inventive without being intimidating.
3. Service: friendly but slow, especially for brunch.
* Extra: great for groups!

We came based purely on the recommendation that Russell House has one of Boston's 12 best burgers. You know the article by now. Does it stand up to the hype? Yes. It was a superb burger. Read on for a more in-depth review.

We had the lamb's belly and marrow bone small plates and the grass fed burger.  The lamb's belly was quite wonderful as an appetizer-like course. It especially paired well with the jelly spread that came with it. The bone marrow is one large bone sliced down the middle with a saw and cooked up in a delicious kind of manner. I could hardly get this one away from the wife. One criticism of the small plates is that, while delicious, they were incredibly greasy. We loved them while eating, but after the dinner had that queasy, too-much-grease feeling.

Finally, the burger. It's simple: english muffin, caramelized onions, bacon, cheese. I ordered it medium, and it came out perfectly medium. The taste, just to reiterate, was wonderful. 

The atmosphere and service as Russell House was very good. Our drinks were refilled regularly, and the place was quiet and well lit. Strangely to the place though, there was a big screen TV showing baseball games. What's up with that? Anyways, Russell House is demoted to four stars because of the incredible amounts of grease.

Pretty good...nothing innovative but a solid New England style cusine. 

The pizza was horrible but the salads are delish and vino selections is great too!!

Great service and if you go downstairs you have a better chance of avoiding the hipsters.

Disappointed. I really wanted to like this place. It's in a great location, it has a stylish interior and good service. The only problem is the food. During my last visit, I ordered the braised lamb shoulder with potato gnocchi. Lamb? Gnocchi? What's not to like? Unfortunately the plate was so salty it was nearly inedible. The gnocchi was so mushy and overcooked it was unrecognizable. I've had better meals at restaurants with half the price.

Sorry Russell House Tavern...I'm just not that into you.

I stopped into Russell House Tavern by accident today, as the place we had wanted to go (Bartley's Burgers) was, unbeknownst to us, closed on Sundays. We quickly found this place, and had a very nice brunch. The service was quick and courteous, and we were seated immediately. I had a traditional egg platter with scrambled eggs, bacon, toast, and hash browns. It was a very good meal for a reasonable price. I would definitely return to this gem in the heart of Harvard Square.

Nick the bartender is pretty damn swell, so is John (the baptist).  Drinks are great, bartenders know what they are talking about and give great suggestions, the music is fun, but some of the patrons are snobs and get mad when you drink their drinks.  Those snobs are from Texas.

Went there with a large group and they did a solid job of handling the 30 or so of us that were there, but on the downside we were split across 3 tables.

My wife's chicken was really good, but my pork trio was not.  When I order a "trio" of anything for over $20 I'm expecting a decent amount of food, but the portion was small and only one of the trio was tasty.  Overall I would say not worth the pretty penny you'll be paying.

I had a very enjoyable evening at Russell House last week. The oysters were fresh and delicious and the service was wonderful. The sauvingon blanc was great too!
I have been here a few times before and have always enjoyed myself. My three guests were extremely impressed by the quality of the food and the fun atmosphere. I highly recommend Russell House if you are ever in Harvard Square!

My friends and I went here for a late dinner and were grateful they had a full menu at 10pm at night. We picked out on crab cakes, pizza, and shrimp. All were prepared well and presented gorgeously. We found the mixed drinks creative and delicious. We also had a bottle of wine. The wine menu is extensive and our server was surprising knowledgeable about the wines. I find it rare for a server to know about more than one or two types of wine, but he was accurate in his description albeit a little too elaborate.
Went for lunch. Over-priced, under-serviced, decor is tired in downstairs back corners. Better off getting a deluxe sandwich at Crema for lunch. Preferred atmosphere and value at Grafton Street.

I have been here a few times and it is always a pleasant experience.

One thing I don't like is that the bathroom is down the stairs and after a few, I have to use it frequently and my footing falters a bit.  They have some creative cocktails and a diverse wine list.  We ordered one of those organic/bio-sustainable wines for $40, which was TERRIBLE.  Don't waste your money.

I love the thought they put in their dishes and almost everything has been delicious.  Although, I did have a pumpkin appetizer that was cold, undercooked, and the flavours did not work.  If you want to get adventurous, you can try the bone marrow.  

It is a great spot in Harvard Square and easily accessible sans car.  I'm totally on the gastro-pub bandwagon and this place does justice to the movement.

An Ode to an Egg

Soft orb of poached perfection
Enrobed in a crispy mantle of panko
And perched upon a a nest of toasty brioche & frisee.
A swirl of pecorino aioli and sprinkling of pancetta 
Add depth to a symphony of flavors.

At the touch of my knife the golden yoke flows forth.
It ensnares the pancetta and mingles with the aioli
While the brioche drinks it in...

Okay, that's enough.  Get it though, seriously.  What are you waiting for?

Even better, go downstairs, sit at the bar and get Lou to mix you up a few libations such as the ever-refreshing Sleepy Hollow or an elegant St. Germain cocktail (also by the pitcher! $35).  You won't be disappointed.

And BONUS: $1 Island Creek oysters after 11p, always and forever.

so earlier i only wrote review for the bar. i actually ate there last night, and here is my experience:

(btw i still stand with my previous review on the bar!! only one of them was friendly)

anyway...so our waiter was super nice to us, got our orders and such pretty quickly. friendly and very sweet. i ordered the Dirty Ceasar which, wasnt actually worth all that money but whatever, ill let it slide. the salad was room-temperature, i wish it was ice cold :/ 

my friend ordered the classic burger and that was SOOO good!! the garlic dipping sauce was sooo good!!! my other friend also ordered this meat dish, but that was just ok...he didnt seem satisfied with the $24 value, either.

but the 4 stars REALLY comes from...after 11PM, oysters are $1...we ordered 20, (lol), and ate among the 3 of us (the other two didnt like oysters in our party). it was yummy :)

overall, def a 4/5 and i will return again. but this time id go earlier for lunch and just eat the burger! maybe after 11 just for the oysters ;)

Dear Russell House Tavern,

Please move closer to me.  I want to be able to breeze in and grab a Moscow Mule and Fig and Mozzarella pizza again without driving out to Harvard Square.  I will get over it though and make a mission out there yet again.  Service warmed up eventually (surprisingly the bartender didn't know a location I was looking for that was literally two streets down and told me to use my iPhone..oops!), the patrons at the bar were hilarious, and I got a lovely sampling of some fancy scotch and whiskeys.  Splendid.

Regards,

Lindsay M

P.S. I love the thin crust.

randomly stumbled into this place while walking around cambridge.  i thought everything was great, the service, the food, the ambiance.  i ordered the steak tartare and my husband ordered the chicken pot pie.  the steak tartare was great!  in the past i've had it where it's basically meat paste, or where there's too many cornichons and this one was perfect.  they only include two toasts with the tartare which is far too few...however, our waitress (i *THINK* her name was Sarah) came up on her own without me saying anything and said "let me get some more toasts for you" which to me, was super courteous.  my first thought when seeing the chicken pot pie was that it was on the small side, but it included a small salad, and honestly, it ended up being the perfect amount.  my ONLY complaint (which does not affect the star amount) was the farty dubstep music they were playing but it wasn't too loud so i could deal.  i would return 100%.

I bet you thought English Muffins were only for breakfast. Silly Yelper, nooks are for crooks. 

Well not today my friend. Russell House Tavern, the place responsible for commandeering the former Z-square locale in Harvard Square and turning it into a gastro-pub-meets-bistro culinary love-fest, has developed an incredibly juicy burger topped with caramelized onions and bacon sandwiched between - yes - the nooks and crannies only typical to the english muffin. Simply brilliant.

My first visit here was more "dinner with the lady" inspired, and featured wine, arctic char, and quiet conversation in a corner. The meal got pricey real fast, and although I enjoyed my dish, it had too much going on...too many textures to wrap my head around - including wheat and pancetta bits. 

Most recent visit was more "oysters, burgers, and beers with a buddy" inspired and quite frankly made me pretty damn happy. Island Creek Oysters were fresh as hell, burger was tantalizing as previously described, and the beer spread here is quite lovely. I discovered Six Point Bengali Tiger IPA - which was essentially better than my first sexual experience (TMI). 

So hop on down to the new "new" spot in Harvard Square for a revolutionary use of the English Muffin, good beers, and good times with the buds.

An oasis of calm, impeccable service and great food on the well-visited Harvard Square. 

Given that the main food choices in the area vary between student-cheap and touristy-rip-off, the Russell House Tavern seems to be able to find its own niche amongst those that are seeking a high-quality experience with food, service, and setting. 

Since visiting on my own, I took a seat at the bar and enjoyed some recommendations on the draft-beer list and specials of the day from the highly capable bartender, who treated me well on my visit. She had a great balance between engaging but not being overbearing. 

Surprised by the pancetta / honey-roasted brussel-sprouts pizza. Yes, you read that right. Went very well with the well-balanced dunkel I had ordered to start off with; I had to leave after finishing my lunch for fear of being tempted by the many other fine taps they had on offer, as well as a nicely targeted list of single-malt scotches.

This would be on my regular go-to list if I lived in Cambridge but alas I do not.

As for those who have commented on the price - I found it very reasonable in comparison to other quality locations in greater Boston, and given the tourist-trap joints in the area, I didn't spend any more to experience local ingredients and committed service.

I usually go here for good service and ok food.  Tonight was a huge disappointment!  My friend and I sat at the bar and had a hard time getting the bartenders attention,  I think maybe the two bartenders had friends at the bar, and weren't really paying attention to us?  We had to flag them down to get them to take our food order, and when it arrived (a burger and a steak frites) we didn't get ketchup.   I had to get their attention and ask for it.  Then had to flag someone down to get salt.  No one asked us how our food was (I was hoping to ask for salad dressing, because my greens came naked).  After dinner we flagged the bartender down for desert and drinks.  They were out of the sherry I ordered, so the bartender suggested another.  Turns out it was 50% more expensive.  Would have been nice to warn us...  I've never had a drink substituted and been charged more than what I asked for.  All in all a really disappointing experience.  I'll avoid going in the future.  And I definitely won't send visiting coworkers in anymore.

I decided to check this place out with my sis for a Thursday night dinner.  It was PACKED when we got there and super loud.  I was unaware there was a downstairs where the reserved tables are, and the upstairs hostess just stared at me when I told her we had a reservation.  Finally, she gestured toward the stairs and I told the next hostess that we were there for dinner.

The tables are super close together and, since it's so loud in there, it was impossible not to hear the other guest's conversation, and have them hear yours.  

I was also slightly disappointed that the they didn't have a lot of options for wine by the glass.  The one I had was fine, but I was hoping for more selection.

I am on a steak tartare kick these days, so I was sure to order that.  And, I was not let down.  It was one of the best steak tartares I've had in  months.  Super flavorful and the egg was fresh and I was very happy.  Unfortunately, they only gave us 2 toast points and it took almost 15 minutes to get another 2, which still weren't enough.  We also ordered the beef wellington, which was rich and flavorful and amazing.  I was super happy..and should have stopped there.

The next dish to come out was the flash fried Soft-Poached Farm egg, which I had heard great things about.  I was really let down, as it was cold, greasy, and overcooked.  I almost sent it back, but our waitress was nowhere to be found for the next 30 minutes.  It took forever to get the check and, at that point, my good feelings for this place started to wear off.

Quite yummy. Only been once for dinner, and they have quite the vast menu, so I don't have much to say about it nor much weight to say it. 

Fresh oysters, nice crab cakes, pretty good food in general. Not as good as the price here would demand, but I will be sure to come back a few more times before I make up my mind about this.

A star and a half deducted because it is WAY TOO DARK in here. A hip joint, and I think outside seating on a warm day would be nice, but the indoor dimly lit, hazy atmosphere... I'm not trying to be a romance killer and I understand that it's a pub, but I like to see what I'm eating, thanks!

The meal I had here was, by far, the best I had during my month staying in Harvard Square. The atmosphere was lovely, the cocktail and beer lists extensive, and the food was fantastic. Though pricey, the portions were large, and items can definitely be shared.
i have been here many many times and always have a consistently good experience. good food, drinks, atmosphere, service. there is something for everyone on the menu!

Good cocktails, great beer and wine list and super-friendly staff. Great place to pop into for a drink while around Harvard Square. Looking at the food menu I wished I hadn't just had dinner. Next time I guess.

I had never been before but after reading reviews decided it was the spot to take an out of town foodie. I did make a reservation since there were going to be 3 of us on a Saturday night. Boy am I glad I did. When we got there it was a full house!

The atmosphere was very conducive for talking. The boys tried some beer they had never had before while I stuck with white wine.
