We opted to be adventurous and ordered 4 or 5 small plates and a pizza for us all to share. The Pato Loco pizza was  my favorite! The mix of the apple with stinky cheese and duck confit & liver was a genius combination. The crispy pig's head cake and the charcuterie board were also  hits with the table.

I will definitely bring more adventurous eaters here again!

I have a knee-jerk reaction to hate any place that designates itself a gastropub. I just think it's a really snobby way to say "bar that serves good food." But if the food is as good as it is at RHT, I'll eat there if they call themselves an outhouse.

Beer list is interesting and varied.

Things to try: fried pighead and bone marrow.

One note: we had a reservation for four. When we got there, the host first asked us if our entire party was there (we were standing in front of him). When we said yes, he said that our table was being prepared and it would be just a moment, as if they had a special table in mind just for us, and it wasn't just that they were waiting for a random four top to pay its bill and leave. Otherwise the service was good, our waiter knew the menu really well.

Overall: 4.2/5 stars.

Went here for Mother's Day dinner. First, the bread was good but the butter sucked. The Angry Queen pizza was 3/5, your average thin crust pizza w/ above average crust but "meh" cheese and VERY thin. 
Then came the grilled chicken sandwich (I ordered it p

Place was hopping when we arrived at 7:15 on Friday.  We were definitely older than the crowd there, but it didn't seem to make any difference.  We enjoyed being with the crowd of 20's 30's folks.  The menu is very interesting, and the food is what you expect from the descriptions.  Our waitress was very attentive even though she was out straight with many tables  Only downside was from the website pictures it seemed a bit more upscale, but it's comfortable nonetheless.  In addition the hostesses upstairs and down both added just the right touch.  Recommend this place for many types of diners/sippers..

Still think RHT is way overpriced.  Every time I walk out, I think to myself, "Holy shit, how did you spend $40 on 2 drinks and an app????"

The last straw came on Sunday.  Stopped in with the wife for a few nibbles since we were in Harvard Square.  A few nibbles is really all we got, even though we ordered 2 appetizers and a dessert.


"Mascarpone Stuffed Burratta"...interesting, Burratta itself is a stuffed cheese, so is this a stuffed stuffed cheese?  I asked the waitress.  When she realized I called their bluff, she became extremely condescending.  When it came out, it was the size of half an iPhone.  Hold up your iPhone.  Now imagine half of it.  This is what we got.  For $8.  One forkful of mozzarella for each of us (no, there was clearly no mascarpone, and clearly you lose the creamy inner portion of burratta when you slice it long and thin).  One forkful of mozzarella for $4 each.

Oxtail "Pierogies" were two half-sized pierogies on a bread plate.  Yes, exactly 2 half pierogies, aka one full-sized pierogi.  Again, for $8.  Making each half a pierogie $4.  You can't cut one pierogi into 2 halves and call it "pierogies" on the menu and charge $8.  I was so bewildered, I took a picture.  Have a look for yourself.


"Whoopie Pie Trio" - three HALF whoopie pies, each the size of half a golf ball.  Again, $8.  Took another picture.  Compare the size of the fork to the size of the whoopie pies.  At least there were 3 of them so we each got one and a half forkfuls of dessert.

So, if you've been keeping score at home, that's 3.5 forkfuls for each of us for $24.

What a joke.

Went to Russell House for the first time several months ago, but didn't come home in a state in which I could adequately review the experience, so had to wait until I went again yesterday evening. The verdict is: Stacy Approved!

We started with drinks. I had the Sleepy Hollow (Beefeater 24, apricot, lemon, mint), which was excellent! A little pricey, but worth it. Hoping I can figure out how to re-create it at home. 

Our waitress brought us a bowl of bread chunks and oil, which was appreciated, and we placed our orders. I had The Angry Queen pizza, with cheese, marinated and roasted tomatoes and basil. One of my companions is vegan, and they were able to make her an Angry Queen pizza without cheese and with mushrooms added on. Other members of our party had the burger and the crab cakes. Everything was great, and portion size was generous.

The atmosphere was chic, but still very relaxed. We (a part of five) were actually there for almost three hours, and everyone seemed fine with it (that might've gone differently if it hadn't been a Tuesday...). 

Upstairs quarters are a little cramped, but workable. Noise level was totally reasonable. Cost: definitely wasn't cheap, but wasn't super pricey either. 

Will be back, for sure!

I really liked the atmosphere. It was pretty crowded but the service was quick and the food was tasty. We got the burger and the crab cakes. They weren't anything special, but the prices were adequate and we were pleased after we were done. 

I'd recommend this place to friends, but I bet there are more impressive places to eat in harvard square.

Just because you have the cash to open a good looking tavern in harvard sq cambridge does not give you instant fame. In my eyes you should have been better prepared for this business long before you opened the doors. Dont keep your nose so high to the sky too soon. I say these things based apon my first visit to Russell House. Food just ok and over priced. service not good enough. I may try again in 90 days to see if it has improved.
Great restaurant in Harvard Square. Semi-local menu with a good brunch to boot.  Upscale tavern food with good variety and a raw bar.

I've been to Russell House a few times now.  The food and atmosphere is typically top notch.  It is priced highly versus your typical "tavern" but you get some great foodie influences that provide value.

I've enjoyed oysters and salad there and friends have gotten the burger and given high marks.  I imagine you can't go wrong with most anything that is on the menu.

This place was amazing. 

Great craft beers. Awesome Plates - Reasonable prices.  I had the Lamb Stomach and the Poached egg with some Fries to share.  My wife had 2 vegetarian plates and all was good. 

We were even given a free beer!

Sarah- waitress, great service. Delicious food, never had to wait to be seated. Sometimes when I pass by, it can look to be quite busy.

I live on the west coast and I still think about their anti-egg Benedict and their fig pizza.

Not the cheapest on the block, but definitely worth it. If I am ever in Boston again, I would probably try to come back to Russell House Tavern.

Been many times.
Food has always been solid
Service was above average

Bacon infused Bourbon Bloody Mary was UNREAL!!!!

Great spot for lunch.  We started with half a dozen $1 oysters.  For our entrees, we had the BLT cheesy sandwich and their soup of the day, which was a carrot puree with yogurt and dill.  Both were amazing, I definitely want to come back to try their beers and dinner.

Overpriced and over-pretentious, but if you read my other reviews, this really isn't really my type of place - so I'll admit that maybe I'm a tad biased against this type of place.  Wasn't a big fan of the ambience, and the food service was extremely slow! The waiter brought out the orders for the 3 other people I was with, but it took an additional 10 minutes to get mine - isn't a cardinal rule of serving to bring out everyone's food at once? With roughly 1 billion other dining establishments in Harvard Square, you're best to try something else, and you'll probably pay less as well.

Solid place to grab a beer but generally not impressed with the food. 

They have a wealth of beer options and the bartenders downstairs are knowledgeable. I asked for a recommendation and was very happy with it. 

When it comes to the food, I could take it or leave it. I could find something I like on the menu, but I wouldn't choose to come here. The grilled chicken sandwich was good and fit for a quick lunch, but honestly I'd recommend this as a place to grab drinks with friends after dinner elsewhere.

This has become one of my favorite places in the city. The menu is always changing, the cocktails are stiff and delicious, the decor is classic and cool, and the service is top-notch. This delightful little gastropub is only a few steps from the Harvard S

Man, I've been waiting for someone to finally come along and pick up this prime piece of real estate that lowly Z Square occupied for so long. Enter Russell House Tavern, the newest addition to the Square. I will headline this review by saying: Welcome to the neighborhood!

The bars are both beautiful - the upstairs more of a "step in and grab a drink, watch some of the game" kind of bar and downstairs the more "have a cocktail here while you're waiting for your table or people watching". As we had come here opening night, I thought we'd have to sit at either, but we got a table within a couple of minutes. 

While I would give the ambiance five stars, overall, the experience was a solid 3 stars. 

-Positive contributors aside from the atmosphere: drink list (extensive interesting cocktails and scotches/whiskeys, great draft beer selection), wine on tap (which I can't wait to try -- they didn't have it when I was there on the first night), salad portions (big enough for dinner!). 
-Extremely positive contributor? The almonds -- they are on the menu for a few bux, and totally worth it -- hot, spiced so well, deeeelish.
-Negative contributors: was a bit pricey, also vegetarian options are reeeeaaallly limited (not surprising when you consider it's a gastropub, but surprising when you consider the surrounding population). Service was quite slow actually...I would attribute most (but not all) of that to it being the first night, but reviews since the first night have pointed to that still being an issue. We were there for probably 2 hours, which was borderline ridiculous for dinner. 

Note: As far as I am concerned (a sympathetic who has had 8+ years experience in food service) they are still in the cleared zone for service; they're still figuring it out. If I go there mid-summer and still have that same lethargic service, then I'd be concerned.

All in all, I will definitely be back!!

Sup ninjas? Growing up just 2 miles from this joint across the Charles, I've only been twice, but each visit memorable. My date and I dined on a slow Tuesday night, but it was still pretty lively. The ground floor tavern decor consists of high top tables

A solid place for dinner and drinks. Some of the items on the menu can be a bit pricey so if I'm here for a meal, I usually get the Queen's Head pizza or the burger. They also have dollar oysters after 11:00 PM which makes for a good evening snack. The atmosphere is pretty chilled here. No need to dress up for this place. They  have a small outdoor patio seating area. I've never sat out there because there's not much of a view. Due to the location, this place attracts a lot of tourists, college students, and young professionals, which gives the restaurant a good mix.

I came here once for brunch because I heard their Bloody Marys were unique and worth trying. I decided to Mezcal Mary and my boyfriend got the one with the bacon. I just checked and I think they took off the back bloody mary, which was a good decision on their part because when we got the drink, it was as if they literally stuck two pieces of bacon into a regular bloody mary. The fat solidified as the drink sat on our table and when we got up to leave, the drink looked like it had been the byproduct of someone's liposuction procedure. Gross. The Mezcal Mary didn't do so well either. Bloody Marys should be simple: vodka, tomato juice, and hot sauce. If you want to be creative, experience around with the spiciness and not with the core ingredients of the drink.

Since this was voted best neighborhood (Harvard Square) restaurant in this year's Best of Improper Bostonian, I decided to check it out. The food was very good, but the service was mediocre at best. My date and I put our name on the list for an outside patio table and were told it would be about a 25 minute wait.  We waited it out at the upstairs bar, and after at least 30 minutes, went to check on our status. They floundered and said "oh, it'll be another 20 minutes..." meaning they had most likely forgotten about us.  (We went on the list downstairs and waited upstairs and clearly the 2 host stands were not communicating with each other.) At that point we took an inside table downstairs.  The waitress apologized for the long wait, saying it's not usually that busy on a Tuesday night.  Then she said she would bring bread, but informed us they were out of bread, and would try to find some from the back. The bread she brought out was very cold, but tasty with the oil. My date ordered and oyster, which the server placed in front of me (not a problem, but lack of attention on top of the wait made it stand out in my mind.)  He got the burger and I got the chicken and mashed potatoes.  Both of our meals were very good and mine provided leftovers.  I also had a St. Germain cocktail, which was made beautifully over crushed ice in a tall glass, and highly recommend it.  Overall, the food was good, but the young staff (probably in their 20's...I am 30, for a frame of reference) need to have a few more lessons in quality service and attention to detail.  Not that they weren't all nice, but the lack of experience, and mostly the forgetting about us for our patio seats left a sour taste in my mouth.  I would probably go back to try more of the menu, but with lowered expectations for the service.

Ventured out to Harvard Square on a random Wednesday night. It was rainy and a bit cold, probably around 11:30pm when we got there. We were there for some cold beers and raw bar ($1 oysters). Oysters were juicy meaning fresh. YES. Tried the poached egg. It was good but at the end of the day, it was just an egg. Thin crust sausage pizza was extremely tasty. Washed everything down with an IPA and that hit the spot. Extremely friendly and polite waiter. I felt very comfortable chillaxing there. Will be back soon.

Russell House Tavern was, in a word, flawless.

We've been meaning to scope this joint out ever since we heard about it from the outgoing bartender at Drink -months- ago.  From the moment we arrived for our OpenTable reservation to our final bite of the ridiculous chocolate cheesecake, there wasn't a single thing that could have gone more swimmingly.

My favorite things about our time at Russell House Tavern, in no particular order were...

- Pretty Things Baby Tree Quadruple: Honestly, when was the last time -you- saw a quadruple on a beer menu?  The last time for me was... hmmm... oh, yeah.  Never.  Think Nocturnum, but richer.  $20 for a 22oz, and it comes with serving directions (which our server followed to the letter).  Oh, and it's a local brew.  Want.  Someone find it for me retail so I can make the boy lug a case with him down to NYC for me.

- Steak frites: These were readily some of the damn finest frites I've had in awhile.  Oh-so-crispy and savory, served with some ridiculously decadent aioli.  Oh, and we asked to share the dish, which they thoughtfully served to us already pre-split on two perfectly portioned plates.  I considered stealing some of the boy's frites momentarily, but he finished his before I could finish mine.  Thwarted again!

- The girl at the table next to us getting shot down for trying to order tomatoes: The chef wouldn't serve them because they're out of season.  Need I say more about how awesome that is?  I think not.

- The Scottish Play: A cocktail with Laphroaig as the base.  Bold move, RHT.  But it delivers.  If you like your drinks smoky and strong, look no further.  If it were possible, it'd have put hair on my chest.  Instead, it gave me the happy bounces in my booth seat.

Considering the reasonable upscale price-point, the phenomenal location right in the heart of Cambridge, and the impeccable execution on everything from food to beverage to service, I expect RHT to build and maintain some serious staying power.  And that's a beautiful thing.

I've never had such a good experience at a restaurant.  Even on a busy night, we were seated very quickly.  The staff was very friendly and energetic.  Our waiter was fantastic - he was very knowledgeable about the menu and sold us on food we wouldn't have tried otherwise.  He also went out of his way to make sure our meals were perfect.  The prices were good, too.  We had appetizers, drinks, entres, and dessert for two for about $45.  I'll definitely go back.
Wonderful atmosphere and great drinks! Have not tried the food yet, but it looks amazing.

Russell House Tavern is a restaurant full of unique characteristics that make it unlike any other restaurant in Harvard Sq. To begin with- the layout of the restaurant itself is loft meets speakeasy. You walk by on the street to the open windows of what seems like a tight space to clink drinks and flirt with the good looking bartender- but what's hidden behind the first floor bar is outdoor seating and a large staircase leading to a beautiful, dark restaurant and bar with cushioned chairs circling the room and some of the friendliest service in an upscale (but casual) restaurant I've been to.  The service (from the hosts to the bar tenders to the manager) are incredibly warm and friendly- and the menu makes it difficult to just settle on one thing (so we settled on sharing everything we ordered with one another). I was digging the louder atmosphere and even more- the Island Creek Oysters.

A must-go in Harvard Sq- impress your friends by taking them to Russell House (it worked for me!).

The food here was very good but not outstanding.  I would return except that the level of noise downstairs is absolutely deafening.  You simply cannot carry on a conversation at any table.  We asked to be moved, which was accomodated but even the table in the corner behind a partial wall wasn't much of an improvement.  Likely will not return unless I don't want to speak to my fellow diners.

I am still drooling over this meal.  The service was top notch, the atmosphere was lively, the drinks were tasty, and the food was spot on.  Nothing else I could want on a Friday night.  

The bread that came out after we ordered is served with an amazing herb olive oil.  We ended up dipping into it with everything, fries, bread, you name it, it was great.  Our party ordered the Andria pizza as a starter.  This is a must order.  The thin pizza is perfectly cooked and the little figs are a perfect pairing to the garlic and burrata.  

For dinner, we were a little non-traditional, and ordered a bunch of items to share.  We got the special of the day fish which was fluke, and the char, as well as a charcuterie plate (the fig spread was the stand out pairing for the plate), gravlax, steak tartare, and some lobster sliders.  The fish were cooked perfectly, and the spaghetti squash on the char was something we were fighting over.  The tartare was some of the best that I've ever had, seasoned just right.  The lobster sliders were so delicious but too small for how delicious they were, I think next time I'm just going to order a bunch of them until I enter a lobster coma.

We finished dinner with some sorbet trios.  Incredible.  We were served a trio of pear, apple cider, and currant, and let me tell you, it had no time to even begin to melt.  Their other dessert options looked delicious too, but we just had no room for anything heavier than refreshing sorbet.

Our server was extremely well trained, and knew the answer to all of our questions. She was very pleasant and checked in on us at just the right times, despite a very busy evening and a few large tables.  I would say Russell House has some of the best head to tail options in Boston, which may turn some people off.  I say give it a shot!  You won't be disappointed.  It's definitely my new favorite Harvard Square destination.

I took my mom and future father in law here on a Saturday night. They were busy but not crowded and we were promptly greeted by a waitress offering bottled still and sparkling water. Well that was nice, but probably not necessary considering the environment, it didn't seem like that kind of place where everyone would turn their nose up at the thought of tap water, especially not me.

Ordered drinks, decent beer selection and cocktail menu was along the lines of a lot of gastropubs, mixing whiskey and serving up moscow mules. I ordered a lemon drop, and was a little disappointed at the lack of sugar on my rim, but the drink was strong and pretty yummy. We ordered the Charcucherie board which took a magnificently long time, about 30 minutes, so it was promptly take off of the bill, which was appreciated. When it arrived it was absolutely delicious, however.

The meal got much better from there. My fiancée ordered the grass fed burger which he called one of the best he's ever had. My mother loved the duck . I opted for a few small plates instead of a meal, the poached egg, which was nothing short of amazing, crispy on the outside and ooey-gooey yolky goodness in the middle; and the steak tartare. It was my first time having tartare, and it was quite tasty however it had a good amount of tarragon in it, which I am not a fan of. The egg I cannot rave about enough. The service was good, the prices were very fair, and the food was extremely tasty bordering on totally delicious.  All four of us got out of it for 114 dollars before the tip with each of us having a few drinks each. Definitely a bargain considering the amount and quality of food you receive.

We went to the Russell House Tavern with friends whose first experience there was amazing, but unfortunately this second experience was mediocre at best. Both burgers ordered were over-done, and the fries were burned in a uniformly brown and soggy pile. The Salt & Pepper Shrimp appetizer was bland and unremarkable. The best thing on the table was the Melted Cambazola Cheese.

The atmosphere was excellent and our hostess graciously called a cell phone number to inform us when our table was available.

Russell House Tavern has all the makings to be one of the hottest new gastro-pubs in Camberville, if not the Boston area.

Their beer selection is superb, running the gamut from Left Hand Brewery's awesome Milk Stout to a variety of lighter beers I didn't pay nearly as much attention to (I'm a dark beer kind of guy :) with each selection representing breweries and beers you don't often see in most pubs.

The cocktail menu is fascinating as well - apparently inspired by a veteran of Barbara Lynch's excellent _Drink_ which I'm also a huge fan of.

I chose the "Harvard Yard" a rye based cocktail with 'allspice dram' that gave the drink a positively delightful bouquet.  In the end analysis I think the mix was a bit too syrupy for my tastes but I suspect that might be my own predilections talking and doesn't reflect negatively on the drink itself.

My wife chose a margarita which was very nicely mixed and built on some really smooth tequilla.  I'd definitely get one in the future if I were in a margarita mood.

As for food, both our dinners were quite good.  I choose the Pork Trio which had a selection of 3 cuts cooked 3 different ways - loin, belly, and shoulder.  The pork was fantastic, and I appreciated each piece's different texture and seasonings quite a bit.  The pork came riding on a bed of creamy grits and a nice selection of wilted greens which were also both quite delicious.

My wife chose a thin crust pizza with home made sausage and other things I can't remember.  She gave me a bite and I found it to be unusually good with a much more complex flavor signature than you'll find in many other pizza offerings, especially in a pub.

We'll definitely be back to explore the menu a bit more, and I look forward to giving their beer selection a work out :)

Food was great; service was not.

I'm usually pretty forgiving when it comes to food service (I've been there before), but my experience at Russell House Tavern was especially egregious at certain points.

Let's start from the beginning- we walked in without reservations, expecting a wait. The wait itself wasn't long, but it was how the host handled us and other patrons that bothered me. There was a group of about 7 who had lost their reservation (probably for showing up late), so they took up most of the waiting area. The host looked at the computer (presumably at table availability) in between trying to keep the group of 7 calm and answering multiple phone calls. He did not seem like he had a good handle on the situation and walked away a few times to see if any tables were available (isn't that what computers are for?). He was apologetic, and since I was just with one friend, we were able to get a table on the first floor (we had to share one of the long 6-person tables with stools though). Sitting on stools for dinner is annoying, but we dealt with it.

Like I said, the food was a saving grace. We had the fried poach eggs (delicious, but not worth the price) as well as the crab cakes ($13 for two). The crab cakes were very rich and flavorful.

As a main course, I had the ale braised beef cheek. At $24, I expected a little more food, but it was nonetheless delicious. It was tender and the sauce was sweet and went very well with the meat and sides.

The beer selection provided a good variety (mostly domestic), as I had one of the rotating beers of the week(?), Victory Oktoberfest.

The food I give 4 stars, but the service gets 2, so this averages out at 3. Service was slow (it took a good 5-10 minutes before we first saw our waiter), and there were points throughout the meal where we were sans any potables. I also witnessed a few tables left uncleared for a considerable amount of time after patrons left, while other customers were at the entrance waiting to be seated.

I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and assume that they were a victim of circumstance that night (it was Hurricane Irene weekend, which was very mild in Boston/Cambridge). It also seemed as if they had random people clearing tables and bringing out food, so it's likely they were just short-staffed that one night.

This is neither here nor there, but to top off the whole experience, the table next to us was full of drunk girls, one of whom kept breaking into song at the top of her lungs (she did not have a Broadway-caliber voice). But what can you do?

Yelp Elite Event at Russell House Tavern:

Amazing time, amazing theme, great intro to this new gastropub. Kudos to Leighanne for organizing such a dapper evening, and most importantly, rocking one of the best "posh pub" ensembles of the night.

I had unfortunately never made it to ZSquare, but I really enjoyed myself at RHT for this event. The donwstairs bar/restaurant area is super romantic and cozy, and the upstairs was nice and lively. Definitely a jekyl and hyde depending on your mood, but something for everyone! 

They were kind enough to offer a signature cocktail, a delicious bit known as the Deco with gin, champagne and some sort of fruit. Grapefruit maybe? Who cares. CHAMPAAAAAAAAAGNE! Normally a beer drinker, this girl found a new home in this cocktail, curled right up in it, and drifted off to drunky land. So good, but so bad the next day if you had 46 of them like me.

Apps were wonderful - I mostly enjoyed the pate with fig jam, the serrano ham, and of course the sweet pickle-y oyster shots. Zing! Staff was super friendly and eager to please us all. Kudos!

For a tavern feel/menu restaurant, this is as good as it gets for Boston (in my opinion).  We were  seated promptly in the downstairs space (per our reservation), and the service was very prompt.  Loved our food - again, Tavern food - but very tasty nonetheless!  I would recommend this place and plan on returning back soon!

This is a review for the bar only. I have not sat down and had table service yet.

Sunday night, the bar is pretty full I see my friend I am meeting and join him on the corner of the bar by the kitchen. 

He orders a cocktail, a Manhattan I believe, I took a sip and it was good. I order a glass of the Riesling, not as sweet as my preference would have liked. They do have Kung Fu Girl Riesling on the menu (which I love) but only by the bottle not by the glass. They should consider offering that one too.

They have $1 oysters from 11-midnight so my buddy got about 15 of them. He loved them!! 

The bar tender was present but not friendly, and they kind of just throw the bill at you, no check presneter no "ill take care of this when ever your ready" more like a "whats this piece of trash in front of me? Oh its our check."

I will definitely come back for table service and see how that goes.

Made a trip to Harvard Square for dinner after my graduation at BU. It is amazing how the college vibe translates to different locations. Harvard Square feels a very upscale Berkeley and Russell House Tavern is great. Most of the staff is a bit disconnected, but our server was great (almost too attentive). The food was excellent and I love the various sections - patio, upstairs, downstairs - something for everyone!

I've been here for dinner, Drinks, and Brunch. They have great drinks! Make sure you sit at the bar downstairs, you can converse with the bartenders and watch them make your drinks. They have a unique collection of drinks for you to choose from! I like this place. For dinner, I've ordered their pizzas before, and its been delicious. Very very well made. (Definitely not like the dollar pizzas in NY; its incredibly delicious, well crafted, etc). 

Brunch - I ordered the strawberry toast, and my friends ordered sides of eggs, bacon, biscuits, and the pork sandwich. The toasts came out with like 4 large pieces of toast! Also drizzled with a little bit of white frosting with a small selection of thinly sliced strawberries in the middle of the plate. The only thing I would say about the dish was that I would've liked it to be slightly sweeter than it was, but besides that the dish was fine. The pork sandwich was HUGE! Portions were large. The biscuits I were however disappointed with, as was my party, but we are all from the deep south and I think we were expecting a southern style biscuit. The biscuit is definitely well made though, and unique. Just not our type of southern fatty buttery biscuity goodness that we're used to. :P

Overall, good brunch experience. Good overall experience for dinner and drinks as well! I would recommend if you're in the area and you want a classy , sit down dinner, or a classy place for catch up drinks with friends!

First of all, let me get the Executive Chef's name,  Michael Scelfo, out there so I gave credit where credit is due. He's not bringing gastro-pub to a new level but he is doing good food the RIGHT way. Most of the food is from a 20 mile radius of the restaurant and the wine list is all American. 

Honestly you should stop reading now and go straight to the Russell House and order the Charcuterie Board. 

Got there in a snow storm around 8pm on a Friday and it was Halloween weekend. A little wet when we arrived  and were seated right away. The server was knowledgeable of the menu and it was un-recited and suggested multiple menu items. I wasn't impressed with the entree list but I think that was because of the amazing appetizer and small plates menu that overshadowed it. 

We ordered the Tap Wine which was for the novelty and thank god because it was on the level of Rose Franzia...which I'm not knocking but it has it's time and place in another setting, such as squeezing the unboxed bag contents 10 feet into your half naked friend's mouth. The server was knowledgeable about the wine menu also but tried to up sell us the most expensive wine in the house which I caught quickly, applauded silently and ordered a Lagunitas IPA in spite but this review isn't about the server it's about the food.

We ordered the Charcuterie Board, Short Rib Wellington, Ox Tail Ravioli's (3), and Cambozola, mushroom, onion flatbread.

The cured meats included duck breast pancetta, rillette with a topping of creamy duckfat that melted beautifully on a room temp plate, hog cheeks, it also had a prune-honey jelly that added nice depth when needed after bites of pate. 

The short rib wellington was done perfectly with puff pastry and filled with chucks of tender short rib and juicy mushrooms. We were mixing combinations 20 different ways with our nice little spread of decadence. I scooped off the duck fat and let it melt into the demi from the Ox Tail Ravioli and it almost took my breath away at first bite. Which each breath the air dragged heavily along my tongue and cheeks. WOW !

Just an all around great atmosphere and decor. The place screams Nouvelle Americana which is what this menu should be called. I forgot to mention the cocktail list which was very tempting and filled heavy with Whiskey's. I even saw a 21 year High West Rocky Mountain Rye. I also saw one of the creations called a Wigglesworth which included Maker's Mark 46, Fernet Branca, Apple-cinnamon, and Maple Bitters and I am kicking myself in the ass now for not getting one. It hit me when we went for drinks at a local pub sipping on Harpoon which you can get anywhere in Boston. 

If you want out of the ordinary but classic and clean then this is the place to go. It was the best meal I've had in the last year and should be hard to beat. Hurry up !

We were trying to get a last minute reservation for restaurant week and this place was all we could find.  Most restaurants flub restaurant week -- Russell House Tavern did not, it was awesome.  I loved the food and the ambience.  More importantly I LOVED the wine by the glass.  $5 and delicious.  We'll be coming back some night for $1 oysters after 11PM.  Fun place, highly reccommend.

Went again. Yep. Two times in one month. It's just convenient. Sat at the bar this time with my buddy - we both ordered tasty cocktails. I went back to my standard Moscow Mule - so gingery, spicy and delicious. Bartender mentioned that they make the ginger beer in house which is awesome. I ordered the Queen pizza - very tasty. Good size. 

As Arnold once said - I'll be back.

A considerable improvement over Finagle a Bagel. 

Instant win for easy bar seats at 8pm on a Thursday night. Given the hype, I was pleasantly surprised.

Even so, though, it was busy -- and our bartender, though not overtly rude, made us aware of it. A stressed out bartender makes me feel guilty for contributing to his/her workload ... which is unfortunate at the tail end of a busy week when I'm dying for a cocktail. Yes, I got one (two, in fact), but the service felt almost begrudging.

The food, however, made me very happy! Highlights:

-- Jumbo shrimp with a honeydew-serrano-avocado salsa. Actually tasted healthy, and very refreshing.

-- TUNA CONSERVA. Best dish of the night. The fregola and radishes were punchy and very nicely textured, and the tuna was almost reminiscent of a good bacalao salad: firm, seasoned, and not too oily.

-- Steak tartare. Nothing unique, but perfect with a wee egg yolk (quail, I'm assuming) and a just-crisp-enough round of toast. We could've done with two toasts, actually, but we got the small plate vs. the app. Presumably the app would have more.

Not sure I'll order the roasted vegetables with herb pistou again -- the butter was overwhelming.

There were also a couple of service-related puzzlers that weren't deal breaking but worth working out:

-- I ended up with two knives and two napkins. After our appetizer, the bartender gave us another full set of napkin-wrapped silverware, rather than simply replacing what was already used. We awkwardly placed the second napkins on our laps for lack of a better solution. Weird.

-- And while I greatly appreciate a sense of urgency coming from the kitchen (our food came out in a flash), the waitstaff was flitting around that place like hummingbirds on speed. Getting out of my bar seat was like easing out of a NASCAR pit in the middle of a race (first and last NASCAR reference I'll ever use in a Yelp review, I imagine) -- and I almost got mowed down by three of them en route to the restroom. Afterwards, I couldn't help taking note of it for the rest of the time I was there. I mean, yeah, it's busy and people want their food ... but at that pace, someone's gonna get hurt! 

In sum, I'm very much looking forward to going back to Russell House -- with my game face on, so I can eat more, drink more, and work it off by dodging the high-octane waitstaff.

I like this place.  The food wasn't great, but good.  The deviled eggs are served with tiny shrimp, definitely not traditional, but tasty.  The local greens salad with figs and walnuts would be better at room temperature instead of cold, and the dressy was very garlicky.  The cheese/brussel sprout special was the weakest dish - the cheese was sort of bland and chewy.  The prices are quite reasonable.  I'd good back because it's convenient and the menu items are interesting.
Wow. I had one of  the best cocktails that I can remember. They make their own ginger beer- hard to beat that. Ambiance was terrific and the bartender's are spot-on talented.

I keep hitting the character limit. Maybe this place should be less awesome so that I have less praise to sing of it.

Working in the restaurant business, you'll sometimes hear the expression "It's sometimes better to make a good recovery after a bad customer experience than it is to get it right the first time."

I had just such an experience at Russell House Tavern. I'm not here to talk about my previous complaint, but rather about how Tyler Titherington, the General Manager of Russell House Tavern, and his exceptional staff managed to completely turn around my opinion of this restaurant.

In early March, I had written a negative review for RHT. To my great surprise, I received a personal email from Tyler a few days later. He acknowledged my complaints, and invited me to return so that he and his team could show me the hospitality he believed their team was capable of providing.

From the moment I read his email, my opinion of the place shot up about 20 notches. This kind of attention to the individual customer is something that I expect from places touting themselves as fine dining restaurants. Never before have I seen such dedication to customer service from an establishment with such a moderate price point.

Now, outreach is all well and good, but follow through is where you really win over a guest who has previously had a bad experience. Did Russell House win me over with their follow through?

Please turn up your speakers for a resounding YES!

During our email correspondence, Tyler went ahead and set up a reservation for Henry (my date) and me. When we arrived, he was waiting by the hostess stand, where he greeted us warmly before leading us to a great table they had set aside for us.

Once at our table, Tyler took our coats and checked them for us. He then proceeded to talk about the restaurant's operating philosophy, and how they strive to keep the food and wine as local as possible. After taking our drink order, he informed us that he was going to send out two complimentary small plates to give us a sense of what the restaurant was all about.

The first of the small plates was the Oxtail Pierogi, which is a type of dumpling made with unleavened dough. The second small plate was the Burrata, which is served with pistachios, currants, and crispy shallots. Both dishes tasted fresh and were extremely flavorful.

We were introduced to our server after we finished our first course. She was very nice, and incredibly knowledgeable about the menu. When Henry, who is a Wisconsonite, asked about the cheddar used on the grass fed burger, she not only knew that they use Cabot 6 month cheddar, but also took it upon herself to have the kitchen use a nicer, older cheddar instead. Talk about customized service! I ordered the Roasted Giannone Farm Chicken, which came with mashed potatoes and thyme roasted carrots. 

Both of our entrees were delicious, and very filling. Come the end of our meal, neither of us really had room for dessert, and we initially declined our server's offer because we didn't see any sense in paying for something that we weren't going to be able to finish. However, when our server gently pushed us by offering to bring us something on the house, we accepted. The surprise dessert was rather unconventional -- a plate of cheeses, fruit, and a few different types of spread. I stuck mostly to the blackberries (which are my favorite fruit), while Henry indulged his Wisconsin heritage by tasting and identifying each of the cheeses on the plate.

Throughout the meal, Henry and I were surprised and delighted by the quality of the service and the excellence of the food. The final surprise came at the end of the meal when Tyler informed us that our meal was on him. This was completely unexpected, and both Henry and I were completely floored by this generosity.

I will definitely return to Russell House Tavern, and would highly recommend it to friends and family. The staff and management have an exceptional grasp of what it means to provide great customer service, and this service is backed by an inspired menu and a fantastic culinary team.

Love it! I've been in to Russell House several times and it's been consistently excellent. I've been in for a casual dinner, just drinks, snacks and a beer, brunch, a Yelp event, and a big private party -- and it's worked wonderfully for all of them.

You're looking at a variety of delicious food options ranging from ~$5 snacks to ~$30 entrees, classic and original cocktails, an excellent beer and wine list, pleasant seating, and a lot of casual hang-out space. 

The fish of the day is not to be missed, the raw bar kicks ass, and the burger (especially in the "Harvard Square Happy Meal," where it's paired with a tallboy of Brooklyn lager and a shot of Fernet) ain't bad either. I'd be remiss if I were not to mention the $5 Westport Rivers wine on tap, which is also quite a draw. The charcuterie plate for just over $10 is a standout offering as well -- the pate and duck prosciutto are perfectly salty, buttery, and rich, pair amazingly with the fig jam, and the staff are great about bringing you more crostini that you'll inevitably need to get every last bit of cured meaty goodness into your mouth.

It's definitely worth stopping in for brunch, too; the brunch menu is filled with hearty, delicious options for very reasonable ($8-15) prices. (Also highly excellent: "The Quickening" brunch cocktail, consisting of Rogue Dead Guy with Amaro Meletti and Chartreuse, a shot of Fernet, and a plate of bacon. Good morning, the weekend!)

Similar to the food and drink options, the space is very varied -- there's an airy upstairs bar area with a couple large tables (perfect for brunch!), and an expansive basement space with a large marble bar, a couple large tables in a space that can be curtained off for private events.

On a side note, I hosted an alumni gathering here for my alma mater and the staff were really friendly and great to work with -- big ups to Maggie and Ian for putting together a great event and to everyone at Russell House for providing consistently great experiences every time I'm in!

This place rocks. 

The house made charcuterie plate is delicious and generously portioned and the crispy soft poached egg is insane (in the best possible way). The servers are friendly and really know their menu.

Plus, the first time I went they had Green Flash Hop Head Red on cask(!). Sold.
Nice atmosphere.  Great beer selection on tap. Awesome burger and fries.  Not overpriced at all and great location right in Harvard Square.  I always try to come here when I'm in town.

Thank you Yelp reviewers. While in town for a wedding, I found myself around Harvard and hungry for lunch. Enter my Yelp blackberry app and 5 minutes later I'm at a table. This place was huge inside and with the potential to be a rager at night with the huge bars. 

I got to order off of the Brunch menu and boy was I happy with my decision. The smokey 12 hour brisket melt is best thing I ever ate material. I'm a huge sucker for Reubens but this put them all to shame. The combination of meat, cole slaw and pickles just melted in my mouth. If I lived in the area, this would be a staple of my diet. What really put this place over the top was the fries that came with the meal. A huge mound of perfectly seasoned and crispy fries helped soak up excess slop from my sandwich. 

Unfortunately this are the only two things I tried. I was afraid if I asked for a bite of someone else at my tables meal, I would have to reciprocate and I was not about to let anyone of my sandwich get away.

Good food GREAT drinks - Gastropub/Tavern

In many ways I'm a fan of Russell House. The staff is usually pretty on top of things. The drinks are exceptionally well made, and somehow I can always manage to find something on the menu to satisfy a craving. 

This used to be my go to spot whenever I was in Harvard square, as I like the cozy little bar upstairs, and the nice spacious one down below. Haven't been here for quite some time, was nice to visit again.

Date Rating: 6
Pick up Scale: 6 (Everyone seems very friendly)

Strong Suggestion: Eat, drink, and be Merry.

I've heard a lot of positive hype about Russell House Tavern but only just had the opportunity to dine here and all in all, I think some of the hype is worth it. First off, the RHT is mostly underground. They have a small dining room/bar on the main level

Russel House Tavern knocked my socks off. I do not think my review can do it justice. 

Do not let the word "tavern" or its location smack in the middle of Harvard sq fool you. The food at Russell is spectacular, perfectly executed, and very flavorful. The food is complimented by an excellent selection of craft beers, wine, cocktails and liquors. (Lately I have been into tarty gin drinks and the Southside hit the spot.)

The menu reads like wish list for any meat or seafood lover. There are small plates, appetizers, a raw bar section and entrees. The entrees top out at about 25 though many are under 20. The quality however is on par with places that charge in the 30s. 

My group started with the charcuterie plate and the steak tartar with a quail egg (did I mention we love meat or what?) The charcuterie included the best chicken live pate I have had - very light and complemented by a honey grape chutney/jelly. It also included a rillete, trout pate, some smoked ham and duck perscuito. Many of these can be gotten separately form the small plates menu. The steak tartar was delicious. 

I had the pig three way, which came with grits and greens. The grits were creamy and wonderful, not "gritty" and were a perfect complement. The pork loin was the perfect balance of fatty and meaty, whereas the pork belly was a bit too much for me, but others enjoyed it tremendously. My friend's steak frite was a perfect medium rare and my husband's artic char was seared to perfection - very tender with the skin crispy and floating on top. 

After the meal I definitely needed an immediate nap - since I pretty much feasted on glorious pig and other animal fat. It was totally worth it. 
Oh and did I mention the service was delightful. Our waitress was knowledgeable, attentive but not overbearing. ...and sparkling water carbonated in house is free. 

Anyway - all carnivores must go here. Do not miss it.  Feast your heart out.

I would give it a four for food, 2 for service!
Loved the Wellington and the Serrano ham+manchego plates. The chicken Sandwich was decent. But service ruined the evening right from the beginning (Alison was serving us). Really upset cause we were celebrat

Great find!! We chose this place arbitrarily while in Harvard Square, and I'm certainly glad the culinary gods pointed us this way. We ordered at the bar, and the Grass Fed burgers were delicious! Juicy, cooked perfectly. Although the place was noisy, I love the atmosphere. The bartender was not amazing, but I'll def come back!

What a pleasant surprise. We took a chance on this eatery after reading some good reviews. The interior was warm and inviting and the lower level, where we dined, was quite. The food was better than I expected. I had the lamb belly pizza. My wife have beef wellington and a walnut vinegarette salad.  Everything was far very good. I would highly recommend this place.

That's it; I'm done with Russell House. After two underwhelming dinners, I decided to give them one last chance, this time for brunch. Bad decision.

I ordered the American Egg Plate: 2 eggs (scrambled for me), bacon or sausage (bacon for me), home fries, and wheat toast. The home fries didn't have much flavor on their own. At least they came with ketchup on the side. A couple of the bacon strips had char marks on them. I HATE charred food. The toast was fine, except that it wasn't served with any jelly or jam. The eggs were also fine, but I like my eggs with salt and pepper, and there wasn't any on the table.

The food was served by someone other than the waiter (a runner?), who promptly left the table after serving the food, so I waited for the waiter to come by to check on us. After about 3 or 4 minutes (way too long of a wait), the waiter came by, and I asked for salt and pepper, and jam or jelly. He brought a small salt grinder, and they didn't have any small available pepper grinders, so he brought a big grinder that he took away after dispensing some pepper. That's fine, but, really??, you don't have a salt and pepper grinder for every table when you serve eggs for brunch?? Wow. And the jam that came for the toast was some kind of berry jam that had no flavor whatsoever.

The only positive thing I have to say is that the "2 eggs" looked more like 3 or 4, so you'll definitely get enough food if you order this dish. I don't think I'll be back to Russell House.

I'd heard that the proprietor of Bukowski's in Inman had started this new restaurant in the heart of Harvard Square.  A group of friends and I tried it out last night, and I'd agree with other critical reviewers that this place is still working out kinks.

I noticed a few indicators of management problems during the visit.  The wait staff were frazzled and disorganized.  I especially noticed a communication disconnect between the kitchen and the waiters--on two occasions I had the wrong food item placed in front of me.  By the time we arrived at 7 pm they'd already run out of a few appetizer items. 

This place is clearly attempting to compete with Temple Bar and Grafton Street for the slightly upscale casual American dining/ happy hour crowd.  It still has some work to do.  I tried both the house salad and the house burger, and both seemed really marginal.  The burger was thick and not very flavorful.  However, others at the table seemed to enjoy the oysters and other items on the menu.

Convinced that RHT has the best cocktails in Cambridge.
And is a great place for a casual, reasonably priced, and deliciously prepared steak frites (or Rib Eye if you're lucky) ... while drinking said cocktail(s).

Russell House Tavern is like meeting a great looking person who doesn't have a great personality.  

This place has the location and the looks of the perfect restaurant.  It's got a great little area upstairs with a bar and a huge downstairs as well.  It's got everything nailed from furniture to the cool lightbulbs that hang from the ceiling.

But the food was just okay.  Prices were reasonable and the service was just okay.  I'll come back - but probably just for drinks and not for dinner.

Thumbs up for OpenTable.

Like I said, you can meet someone who's great looking, but you'll get bored if they can't hold a conversation.

A gastropub with a good beer menu and a mixture of traditional pub fare with slightly more adventurous options. Service was great, our waiter being very attentive and knowledgeable about the beers and food offerings. We ordered some small plates to start: Crispy Pigs Head Parmigiana, Redondo Black Serrano Ham, Brandt Farms Marrow Bone. All of these were delicious. The pigs head came out looking like an arrenchini ball, but with pigs head meat instead of rice. Crispy and savory and surprisingly light. The serrano ham was salty with just the right amount of sweetness. The bone marrow was straight buttery goodness. The only problem is that the bread that came with the bone marrow was buttered and overpowered the bone marrow at times. Switching the bread that came with the serrano ham fixed this problem for us. For out mains I got the burger that I've heard a lot about (which when I ordered, the waiter told me it's on an english muffin and alot of foodies have been slamming the chef about using the muffin) and Abby got the duck. Both were great, though my burger seemed to have been seasoned a little too much with pepper. The fries were plentiful too. Overall, this is a place I definitely want to come back to and eat everything else on the menu. Service was good, though slowed a little towards the end of the night, but we weren't in a hurry so no biggie there. I give Russel House Tavern a 4 out of 5.

If you're looking for a good place to meet some friends for drinks and food, and you must meet in Harvard Square, Russell House Tavern isn't a bad choice.  It's got a wide-ranging menu featuring competent if not masterful executions of culinary trends (right now:  bone marrow!).

I've been less impressed with their cocktails.  A few nights ago I had their "St. Germain cocktail" and immediately recognized that I shouldn't have allowed my love of St. Germain to override my skepticism about the appeal of sparkling white wine, St. Germain, and ... seltzer?  On ice?  I don't need my cocktails to pickle me in two gulps, but this tasted like fairy pee.  And since when is a cocktail served with a straw? (not a stirrer, a drinking straw)

Rendezvous in Central Square serves much better food at comparable prices.  Noir in the Charles Hotel has better cocktails.  It depends on what you're looking for - if your needs for food, drink and location lead you to Russell House Tavern, you'll probably be all right.  Although I'd suggest sticking to their wine and beer lists.

Great selection of interesting beers on tap and a decent wine by the glass list.. Menu very eclectic. Nice, bright and breezy bar.

However, I felt the service could have been more attentive at the bar - I sat with an empty glass and a finished plate longer than I would have liked.

I ordered the cheese, tomato and bacon sandwich and it was very good, served on brioche with a side of tasty fries.

I loved the food here. I had the dirty caesar and a fig white pizza. Absolutely delcious. The beer, wine, and cocktail list is very impressive and you can find anything to suit your palate. While there are many expensive options on the menu, I split the meal with a friend and there was plenty to eat and it was a very affordable dinner for the area and setting.

We sat upstairs, which was definitely on the loud and busy side. If you're looking for something more intimate and conversation, head downstairs to the dining room. The bar down there is beautiful. The decor upstairs reminds me of a french cafe (similar to L'Express in Montreal), the decor in the downstairs dining room reminds me of a classic bistro - dark woods and slate, delicate lighting. 

The service was also wonderful in my opinion. Our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, responsive, and overall very pleasant. The hostess staff was a little on the cold side, but they were accommodating and got the job done. 

I will definitely be back!

I've been to Russell House Tavern a handful of times, mostly just for drinks and light food. I hadn't been overly impressed with the food, but hadn't really given it a shot either until a couple of weeks ago. That's when everything changed...

I was dining with my fella (who is a enthusiastic eater), and we decided to order some small plates to share. This is my favorite way of dining, to be honest. I'd much rather taste a wider variety of things than settle on one entree. 

After much debate, we settled on the crab cakes, the steak tartare, and the pork trio. The crab cakes were probably my least favorite, but they were still pretty excellent. The tartare was AMAZING. Now, i don't really know what I'm talking about with tartare - it's not exactly in my usual rotation - but holy crap, this dish was delicious. Makes me wish I could have tartare once a week! 

The pork trio was the real stand-out, though. Three different cuts of pork, served over the creamiest, richest grits I've ever had. The shoulder cut could have been just a touch juicier, but the other cuts were pure porky heaven.

As for the drinks...well, they are always fantastic. I started with a Battle of Trafalgar - one of my standards here - and followed it up with something that may or may not have a name. All I know is that it involved St. Germain, rum, Allspice, and a big smile on my face. 

It's been a few weeks now, RHT. I'll be in soon.
The Food at Russell House Tavern is pretty average.  Maybe the best of Redline, Temple and Grafton St.  The location and and everything else beyond the food cannot be beat.  Service can be dodgy.

When you're stuck in a down pour and hungry in Harvard Square, where do you go?  Quickly pull up yelp and see a ton a great reviews for this gastropub, so you figure why not?  I'm glad I went.  Top notch beers on tap and a menu full of delicious sandwiches.  I opted to get the chickpea fritter, mostly because I had indulged the day before and wanted a non-meat/chicken option,  The salad that came with it was delicious with the perfect amount of dressing.  The sandwich itself was so flavorful and yummy!  I definitely will be back.

Pros: -excellent food and drinks, -lots of room, from the outside, the place does not look that large, -takes credit cards, -super easy location to meet people, it is right next to Harvard station, easy to walk/bus to and there are many garages around.

Cons:-service was a tad lackluster, -the "patio" is more of an alley that gets scant amounts of sunlight

I shall return

Brunchtime yo.  Not quite as good as breakfast, but I'll take it.  We had the anti-benedict and the pit master.  I fucking loved the anti-benedict - I had it with the fried poached eggs and I regret nothing.  Eggs, garlic spinach, and sausage, all put on an english muffin to make a little bread plate for the various ingredients.  The pit master was a brisket scrambled with eggs.  Underwhelming.

I took my wife out this Saturday night and decided to go to the Rusell House Tavern. I had been hearing good things and wanted to check it out. We decided to sample a few apps tapas style. We were not disappointed by this choice  We sat in the downstairs section and it was a little loud but, to be fair, it was a busy Saturday night. 

Russell House likes to mix up ingredients you would not expect. Some highlights were the fried poached egg (I know!) but it was delicious, a savory lamb on toast dish with huge flavor and fried oysters that melted in your mouth.  We then decided to get some pizza to top it off, I was in the mood to be a little adventurous so we ordered the white garlic pizza with fig. You would not think those flavors would go together but the sweet & salty combo really popped! I also had a great beer that was a recommendation of our server that I cannot remember the name but it was local and aged in barrels or something.  (I had three so the details are a little sketchy)

Wait staff was great, she must have been a stand-up comedian or something because she kept us laughing all night. A great experience, highly recommended!

Who knew that a burger tasted good on an english muffin?  It's the creativity that really makes me appreciate this place - which is perfect for a lunch date, work meeting, or a very casual dinner.

My favorite is the dirty caesar salad with beef (yes, not chicken!) - my friend kept stealing the chargrilled slices of steak they placed on my delicious salad.  

I tried their vegetarian pizza as well another night, and it was generously loaded with many delicious toppings, much unlike those other places that serve mostly bread with a tiny bit of "real" stuff. 

When they ask you "still or sparkling water?" definitely go for the sparkling water.  It's homemade and tastes a lot fresher than bottled Perrier - and it's free :)

I give it four stars not because it's outstanding, but relative to other restaurants within Harvard Square, it's much better.  I think it's a toss up between this and Cambridge One as my favorite go-to spot in the area.

So far, this place is my favorite place thus far while living in Boston. Okay, I've lived here for three days, but I'm still a fan.

The service is impeccable, the ambience is fun and casual, and the prices are great.

We had a bottle of the tap rose wine, and it was delicious. We then ordered some raw oysters, which are served with a delicious radish sauce instead of the traditional horseradish. The oysters were smooth and no sandy feeling at all. The raw yellowtail sashimi was served on top of a fried slice of sweet potato with a delicious batter. The local leaf salad was heaping tall, beautifully dressed with a light vinaigrette, and had walnuts and dried figs. Our favorite part of our late dinner was the meat charcuterie with duck prosciutto, pate, jam, and other meats served with crisped, flavored croutons. We were in heaven. Then the server brought out extra croutons without extra charge. 

We left this place super happy and hope to revisit this place again before I move next year.

Ok, I've had my share of burgers in my time but the one I had here was pretty fantastic. And it comes on sourdough...ohhhhhhhhhh yeah. Get one, you won't regret it. Some other reviews talk about the place being overpriced but I think the burger was only $12. I didn't get anything else besides that and a few beers, but I'd say that's reasonable. The ceasar salad that came with my burger wasn't all that (mostly just lettuce and dressing) but the burger was so good I didn't really care about the salad. Good beer selection also both in bottle and on tap.

This is a great addition to the harvard square eatery scene. I think they're owned by the same people as Grafton St. (another favorite) and this beats grafton in ambiance, service and drinks. My favorites include the burger (which comes on an english muffin, way more meat than burger) the oysters, thyme carrots, ceasar salad (the anchovies are INSIDE the croutons. genius!!) steak frites and the duck. You pretty much can't go wrong here. The staff is nice, and if you sit in the bar area in the lower level the bartenders are pretty flirtatious too (always helps!).

I had a "Spanish Sub", and an expertly crafted beverage made by perhaps the most patient person on the planet.  This time the bread encased its contents perfectly.  Sometimes one says "I'll be back", but, I mean it!

A standard girls-friday-night dinner turned into a marathon of eating and drinking. It happens. 

What made this night all the more special was the service at Russel House. My friend and I waited at the downstairs bar for a table, and we were lucky enough

My friend and I were in search for a good gastropub in the Cambridge and Boston area and Yelp took us here. Very conveniently located in the hub of Harvard Sq., it's a minute walk from the Harvard T station. The interior looked enormous with several floors, so it's not likely that you'd have to wait for service.

We ordered several things from the menu:
Lamb's Belly Toast: it was OK, nothing special. The meat was somewhat tender, but I expected a bit more tender considering it's belly.
Grass fed burger: the burger was good. It did not look like a 1/2 lb. patty, they must've mushed the patty so that it will exactly fit an English muffin.
Fresh pigs liver: I can't say whether or not I enjoyed it, all I can say is, it tasted funky. Definitely requires an acquired taste.
Sides of roasted brussels sprouts, grits, and frites. The grits were nice and creamy, the frites were deliciously crunchy. The sprouts, however, were a bit too roasted and tasted almost bitter.

Great food. I should check out more gastropubs. I've only eaten in the down stairs seating area for dinner.  Atmosphere was vibrant and casual. Didn't feel out of place with the kids in tow even though much of the crowd was a little younger. Had steak tartare and the steak frites which were both excellent. My wife swore the burger she had ranked among the best she ever had.  Looking forward to trying more off the menu!

Burger must be eaten with fork and knife, but go for the more exotic and you won't be disappointed. Food and service s were great. We split a large Dirty Caesar and they served it for us on 2 plates, then we shared the Beef Heart Ravioli and a roast lamb on toast with harissa and Marconia almonds? The ravioli had a nice tang to it and the texture of the filling was soft, but not mushy. The lamb isn't on their online menu, so I can't be specific on all the ingredients, but both were great. I had a hard time knowing which flavor to end on.

You know what? Since my original review, I've probably been here 20 times...And I live in NYC. But seriously, Russell House serves up flawless drinks, amazing food (get the breakfast pizza!), and has the most spot-on ambiance. 

This is, I think, as perfect as a bar/tavern/restaurant can get.

Seriously reasonable prices. Came here for brunch, got the anti-benedict (with fried poached eggs, garlicky spinach, sausage.. what else would you want in a breakfast?!) and the pit master (great brisket scrambled with lots of melty cheese). Both a little under seasoned though, and really I should stop ordering eggs because I don't like them enough to eat a whole dish of it.

I can't stop having unbelievable times at Russell House!  Never before have I experienced something like this, where every single time I visit, it gets better and better.  

When I first started going to Russell House, it was purely to try out the drinks.  There was so much chatter about the creative and extensive bar menu, I couldn't resist.  I was impressed;  impressed enough to return over and over again, even just for a quick drink stop while on my way to another venue.

Then I decided to try the menu.  GAMECHANGER!

I haven't always been the most adventurous with food, until very recently.  Let's just say that Russell House is the perfect place to try new things and to bask in the afterglow of your adventures!  Perhaps a pig's head parmigiana or some chicken liver pate is exactly what you need.  Russell House is the place to try it.   I urge anyone to at the very least try the charcuterie plate.  You will not be disappointed.  In fact, my guess is that you'll want to order it again and again.  

And again.

This is based on my second trip to Russel House Tavern. I had suggested this location to my friends for post b-day dinner drinks because they have a nice cocktail list, and the basement area space is quite nice and had the vibe we were going for. 

It was a Tuesday night, and while there were a fair amount of customers, it wasn't really hustling busy, considering there were two bartenders. The bartenders were not really very attentive to our party at all, and at one point my friend (the b-day girl) sat there with an empty drink for 10 minutes. Every single one in our party works in the service industry, so we are usually more than understanding when it comes to service glitches (they happen), but we all just felt like we got a cold attitude from the bar staff for the most part.

I have been to Russells House Tavern many times now and it has been consistenly good.

I prefer to sit downstairs, as it is a more intimate setting.  Make sure you call ahead for reservations.

This place has amazing cocktails.  My favorite is still the Sleepy Hallow, but everything I have tried has been really good.  I even enjoyed their Bloody Mary made with herb infused vodka (and I am not a Bloody Mary drinker).

They use fresh ingredients and season their dishes very well.
I love the crab cakes from the dinner appetizer menu.  The House Grass Fed Burger is delicious.  There specialty pizzas have been mouth watering good.  The farm chicken is amazing . . . the carrots where some of the best I have ever eaten.   The fish and chips are pretty tasty, too.

I like this place. It's got a cool interior and a fantastic location. The food, while a bit overpriced and underportioned, is actually really good. The service was good, but from what I remember their selection of beer wasn't what I thought it would be. I'd recommend checking it out as they do have some really interesting and unique dishes.

$5 wine on tap. 
Modern and comfortable atmosphere. 
Great area. 
Go here.

I was in boston for 4 days and came here twice.

My waitress was super rude. The food was well priced, but the menu was quite limited. Had a bloody mary that was delicious, and their bar was extensive. Also, great location and my food was really good. However, a really rude waitress is enough of a reason for me not to return here.

This place is a bit more upscale than my usual haunts, but I was determined to try the much-hyped burger, so I shaved, put on a clean shirt and headed over.  
We sat outside, which was a bit cramped but a nice spot on a hot day.  It was a bit late for lunch, but we were seated with no problem.  

I mostly just wanted to get to the burger, but the soup was a cold cucumber with yogurt, and I couldn't resist.  It was wonderful, and a great starter on a warm day.

Finally, the burger.  It was good, very good.  You could taste the quality of the meat, and the bacon on top was thick cut and flavorful.  It just had a good balance of flavor to it.

I went with the fries, my friend split her sides between fries and greens.  The fries were fresh and well cooked, I like it when they leave the skins on.  Not overly salted either.
And the pickle that came with it was quite tasty too.

Service was quick and friendly, although walking to the bathroom is quite a trek.

So I'm not breaking any new ground here, but I will report that the burger pretty much lives up to it's hype, and, overall, Russell House was one of the better lunch experiences I've had in a while.

Great atmosphere, excellent food, and a delicious beer selection.  

I am so happy to have found Russell House Tavern after paying Harvard a visit.   I started out our Sunday brunch with Goose Island Matilda on draft.   I even live in Chicago and cannot easily find this hometown brew on tap.  For my entree, I went with the crab cake sandwich.   I mean, you have to eat as much seafood as you can when only visiting the east coast, right!?  Well, it was absolutely delicious with the perfect amount of crab and cake.  

Our server was very friendly and knowledgeable.  We sat in the lower level of the restaurant, which was very comfortable.

Overall, a great choice when dining in Harvard Square.

Really cool vibe in the basement area. They have some good beers on tap that are worth a shot. I haven't had a full meal here, but their charcuterie is awesome. It's served on a board and includes rilletes, pate, and some cured meat. Insanely great.
Liked it a lot.  Strong pizza.   Very helpful beer reco from our server.  And a sharp space with good energy.  Solid casual date night with the wife kind of place.

Rosé: Knock, knock! 
Homeowner: Who's there? 
Rosé: Rosé! 
Homeowner: Blush wine...ha! Get your eff'in pink #@%$ off my property! You're nothing more than a White Zinfandel masquerading around as something you're not! Thelma, get me my shotgun! 

Confused? Don't be, because this IS a review of the Russell House Tavern, and a very positive one at that. However, if you will allow me the indulgence of pontificating for just one moment about a subject that is very important to me, and to our society of gourmands and oenophiles as a whole. Allow me to discuss the topic of wine relations. 

Sometimes considered taboo, wine relations is seldom discussed in public, but it is something we should not ignore. Many of you may be too young to remember when the rogue Rosé, White Zinfandel, emerged upon the American wine scene, and the subsequent damage it caused for decades to come. Scenes like the one illustrated above occurred on doorsteps and in restaurants across our great nation, and I remember them vividly as some of the darkest days in our country's young wine history. Sides were taken, lines were drawn, opinions and tempers flared...there was real threat of an all-out revolt against White Zinfandel, and legitimate blush wines were caught in the crossfire. 

Flash forward three decades, and time has healed many of our wounds. Our fragile wine culture has recovered, grown stronger, and moved beyond the days when we allowed ourselves to be force-fed inferior, overly-sweet wines, mass produced by large corporate agribusinesses. We have come to realize our prejudices, and we have recognized that the history of blush wines can be traced back to the traditional wine regions of France. We now appreciate that blush wine can be good wine. 

You may ask, "Why Steve? Why are you drudging up such an arcane subject matter from a bygone era?" The answer, my friends, is because the Russell House Tavern boldly chose to proudly display three American blush wines on their wine menu. This is foretelling of a day when blush wines will assume their rightful place among American wines, but this cannot happen without the cooperation of the American consumer. Now, I am not saying that blush wines will be the next big thing, because that would be foolish. After all, no winemaker intentionally sets out to make great blush wines, but rather it occurs as a fortuitous accident. Perhaps the climates and soils determine that a red varietal happens to make a really decent and drinkable Rosé, rather than the Pinot Noir that the winemaker had hoped for. Lucky for us, the true beauty of blush wines is that they pair well with just about everything. 

For example, a perfect complement to a Rosé is seafood and spice. So, under the Russell House Tavern's raw bar menu, you might select the Jonah Crab Claws with ginger & harissa aioli, which is a tremendous steal at six claws for $14. We ordered this, and the crab was cool and sweet, while the aioli had the perfect amount of peppery heat. Other natural Rosé pairings include pork and poultry. I've never hidden my love for charcuterie, so we ordered the House Charcuterie Board, which contained chicken liver paté, duck ham, Berkshire rillette, and Serrano ham. We fawned over this appetizer, savoring the sweet, silky richness of the paté, the smokiness of the rillette, and the delicately thin, cured hams. The portions were generous enough that we had to request additional crostinis in order to enjoy every last morsel of our charcuterie board. We rounded out our meal with the Dirty Caesar Salad with spicy anchovy croutons. The greens were fresh and crisp, the dressing was creamy and tart, and the croutons were delicious on their own. 

There is a quirky little thing that my wife and I do when we are enjoying a meal. We move our upper bodies as if we are dancing to music that only we can hear. This happens when our taste buds are overloaded with flavors beyond what our synapses and taste centers can process, and so we respond bodily. Weird yes, but both my wife and I caught each other in phantom dance as we consumed our food at Russell Street Tavern. It was REALLY that good, and inexpensive, and therefore a tremendous value. On the beverage front, the Russell Street Tavern has a wide selection of American wines and craft beers, and inventive cocktails. Russell Street Tavern occupies the space that previously housed Z-Square, and they did very little to change the décor. They really didn't have to, since it had been well decorated with marble bar tops, dark woods, and modern styling. In general, I found the cuisine and the beverage list at Russell House to be perfectly tailored to almost any palate or budget. I'll definitely return to continue my tour of the menu. And I thank the person who is responsible for including blush wines on the wine list for standing up for wine relations.

I really want to like Russell House... the second that I saw their menu I was excited to try out this fun looking restaurant that had menu items such as chicken liver pate, bone marrow, a charcuterie board and steak tartare. Yes, I like the "gross" dishes on menus! 

My first time walking into Russell House I loved the decor. Trendy yet still totally comfortable feeling. We were seated promptly and ordered all of our dishes without a hitch.

However, we had some problems with pacing. We ordered a variety of small plates and then one entree to share. And then despite the fact we tried to get them to course the food out...everything just came at once making us feel really rushed. Everything tasted fine, and during this visit, I felt like the quality of the food and effort that had gone into it was worth the price. 

Given my generally positive feelings I decided to return for a celebration dinner. Sadly, the same dishes I loved months before seemed a bit weaker and rushed in preparation. For example, the cut of the meat in the steak tartare. Additionally, same service problems of tons of food, then no food. And this time, everything seemed to be waaay to heavy on the butter (and I'm a butter lover). Even worse, this time I was seated on the banquette and was so close to other tables I could have been part of either of their conversations easily.

Also, the wine issues folks seemed to have were echoed in my experience. I don't remember what wine I ordered but when it arrived I felt like it tasted odd. Later when I got the bill, surprise I had been given the Benziger Pinot Noir which I really dislike. They were nice enough to take it off, but I wish I had been given the wine I wanted to begin with. 

After my second experience I don't think I'll be back again except maybe for a quick cocktail and small plate in between harvard square activities.

Russell House Tavern, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways:

1) Cocktails - Oh yes, they've got classics, they've got their own stuff going on, and they have got great bartenders coming from other awesome restaurants. Go, imbibe, rejoice.

2) Flexible food menu - Akin to Highland Kitchen, they have a huge variety of offerings that will satisfy many different needs. You've got your friend who only eats salad, one who wants a simple burger, and someone who wants a really great entree - and Russell House has them all. Plus there are the sides, apps, and little plates that mean that you can try a lot of stuff. Also, it's delicious.

3) Pork joy - that's right, this place is about taking the most delicious (most fatty) parts of animals eat making delectably rich dishes that make you feel like a sinner. Lamb belly, charcuterie, you can have it all.

4) Awesome drink options. Wine on tap? $4 shots of Fernet? Pitchers of St. Germain cocktail? That's right. They know what is fabulous, and they want to share.

5) Classiness - hells yeah. But maybe I'm not the best person to comment on this topic.
