All in all, I'm super excited for this restaurant, and I plan on going back a lot because there is so much to eat and it is all so good. This is a restaurant for my lifestyle.

I have been frequenting this place since it opened and I have always loved everything about it.  From the awesome burger to the poached egg to the fine selection of oysters the menu has always been affordable and imaginative.  My favorite part of the restaurant has always been the bartenders though.  Fun and thoughtful, they are always eager to make something special and unique for you.  As a regular I love that they always remember your name and make you feel right at home.  They are knowledgeable but more importantly they can always brighten your day with a funny story.  If you are in to Harvard Square make sure to drop by to say hi to Adam, Kyle, Vic, Sam, John, and Elizabeth.  You will be a regular before you know it.

Ok, I want to premise this with the fact that I work in the restaurant industry and I understand that there are kinks that always need to be worked out when you open, but there are also some kinks that just aren't really acceptable when you open. 

Lets start with the fact that while our server was extremely friendly and outgoing, he was not knowledgeable enough to be a server-not yet at least.  Lets start with the fact that me and a friend in our party of five arrived first, he took our drink orders before the other three and then did not bring us drinks until everyone had ordered. I'm sorry thats a no-go.  If I'm going out, I want my cocktail in a decent  time frame.  And while we're on the topic of drinks, for my second round, I ordered a glass of pinot blanc. After an extremely long time, he brought me a glass of prosecco and in what had become known at our table as his notorious enthusiasm exclaimed, "they even put it in a different glass for you!"  I realized it was prosecco by the bubbles rising within the champagne flute and informed him it was not wine, it took another 10 minutes to even get a glass of wine.   I'm sorry, but any knowledgeable server should be able to recognize at least the difference between wine and a sparking wine/champagne and the different glassware. 

Other qualms: someone in our party ordered an appetizer as an entree and it came out with the appetizer course so she was done by the time the entrees arrived.  Someone's entree salad came with nothing on it- it was supposed to have walnuts and figs on it and instead it was nothing but lettuce. The  Steak tartare came out as a small plate size instead of the appetizer size that we ordered.  My entree came out  between 5-10 minutes  later then the other entrees.  The food was decent, everything was pretty over salted though.  Oh and lastly we split the bill between two credit cards and it legit took about 25 minutes because they didn't know how to use their micros system.

I have to say that my biggest qualm amidst all these mistakes, many of which were totally forgivable-- was that never once did a manager come over to apologize or comp anything from our bill and our waiter was MIA for large periods of time.  

I might give it another chance, sometime, in the far far off future, but there's plenty of other great places opening or open that will bury Russell House Tavern if they don't work out their kinks ASAP.

Looking for some decent eats in Cambridge? stop by RHT.  Raw bar, modern menu and the decor to boot, pizza aaaand whiskey.  

You won't....

In Bean Town for a few days and made my way over to Harvard Square late on a Sunday evening needing nourishment. No other place open. The only downside was the noise. Felt like a pick bar for thirty-somethings. The food was outstanding and worth the blaring techno-pop drivel. I had a fig salad and a margarita pizza. Both were delicious and just the right portion.

I ate here with a friend last night. We sat upstairs at the bar for dinner and drinks. The decor 
was lovely, giving the impression that this was much more than a tavern. However, 
the ambience upstairs had the feel of a meat market and by ten some of the patrons 
were pretty drunk. Maybe things were more relaxed downstairs. Bartender was nice
but the beer menu was not impressive. One word to describe the food; SALT. The
menu had real potential but all 5 of the small dishes we ordered were extremely salty (even the salad which gave me chapped lips). Typically I prefer strong flavors but every other flavor was masked by salt. I would not return for this fact alone as the main reason to go to a restuarant is to eat good food.

Had lunch at Russell House Tavern and the ambiance was 4/5 and the food was 2/5.  The menu looked simple on the surface but was a little hard to decipher as there were many ingredients we did not recognize.  My friends and I shared an all-vegetarian meal:
- Creamy Spinach Gratin with flat bread
- Pizza with seasonal vegetables
-  Salad with Walnuts, Dried Figs, Mustard-Cider Vinaigrette
Overall, the food was very greasy and heavy.  The pizza was the most disappointing - the dough was dry and lacked crunchiness, and was sparsely sprinkled with vegetables.  
I might go back for drinks but wouldn't go for the food.  The service was great.

I was in town visiting some friends and three of us stopped be here for food on a Friday evening around 7:30pm.  The place was busy, but after being greeted promptly, we were eventually led to a table downstairs.

The decor is very well done and there are plenty of tables, but it did not feel cramped.  The menu items, including the drinks, were reasonable priced.  I had some house wine and my friend had what he described as a very strong Moscow Mule.  For my friend to say it is strong, it had to truly be strong--the alchy.

We ordered a large Caesar salad to split between the three of us.  We found the addition of parsley to the salad to be a bit strange and add (duh) a different flavor.  It wasn't bad, it was just...different.  I had the steak frites, medium.  It was done perfectly and overall was quite good.  My one friend had the roast chicken, which he enjoyed a lot.  The other friend had one of the pizzas (I forget which) that he said was just okay.

The service could have been a bit quicker, and had it been I would have added in another star.  Drinks were slow to get back to us, and the food took a bit to get to us.  We had to flag down our waiter a couple times (which I really hate having to do).

Went there last night, food was great!  Our server was great, knew a ton about the drink and food menu which sometimes you don't get.  Friend and I had some fun mixed drinks.  The wigglesworth was awesome.  Makers Mark and bitters and really good.  We also got the Cesar salad which was fantastic and 2 pizzas.  Really good food and drinks and ambiance.  Definitely worth checking out.

Love the Russell House!  I normally sit in the upstairs bar area in front of an airy open window.  Its fun to people watch and enjoy one of their beers on tap.  The food is good pub grub with a twist.  Sometimes I twinge at the price tag, but the combination of good service and fun atmosphere make up for it.  Check out their brunch too!

The downstairs at the Russell House Tavern is awesome:  a nice bar where you can fit multiple people, an atmosphere that makes it incredibly easy to interact with people, and just generally a great overall experience.

The upstairs itself is okay, but not really all that remarkable: it's not terrible, but it's definitely much more for either a meal or a quick sit-down.

The beer selection is excellent and decently priced, with a wide variety of cheap beers (Naragansett) as well as pricier wares (Arrogant Bastard Ale).  They also have a nice large selection of other spirits and wine, which is always a help.

I didn't eat anything, but the food does look good.

Overall, it's a nice place that I'd be willing to go back to for food.  A little pricey, but not too bad at all.
Solid all around. New Cambridge fave. Go there

Went to Russell House Tavern with some out of town guests on a weekday. The place was packed. I thought this place was too pricey for the type of food they offered. I was also not too impressed with their food or the menu. The customer service was good. The menu was quite short as well.

Delicious food, tasty cocktails, and an attentive waitstaff.  A reliable Harvard Square staple.

I come here as regularly as I can, considering it's on the pricey side. The menu changes (seasonal?) are always good to try, though my go-to is the Ozark Pork

Russell House Tavern is absolutely delicious!  It takes some real restraint to not try everything off of the French-accented American menu in one sitting.  (Although I did try.)  We were lucky to score two seats at the downstairs bar on a Saturday evening, and the service was awesome.  My favorite bar used to be Drink.  Russell House serves equally as good drinks --if not better-- at more favorable prices so I can confidently say that I like Russell House a tad better.  I was also quite impressed with their extensive beer list that they had on tap.  As for food, I loved how there was something for everyone.  You can get a $39 rib eye or $11 hamburger.  As for us, we had already had dinner before we went to Russell House but that didn't stop us from trying a few small plates.  The crispy soft poached chip-in farm egg, redondo black serrano ham, bacon wrapped figs, and house smoked Maine mussel salad were all delicious.

Ate here on Saturday at noon, so basically it was brunch.  I ordered 2 eggs, toast and bacon.  The bacon was forgotten, though they offered to get it.  I got one piece of tough toast, so asked for another piece of toast instead oh the bacon.  Two pieces of unbuttered toast finally arrived - accompanied by an ice cold piece of butter.  My knife couldn't pierce it!  My hands flew up in the air (this was $9.00 + tax) and I said forget it.  The eggs were freezing.  A manager happened to be standing there and didn't charge me - for which I am grateful.  But I still won't go back!

Russell House has a drink named the "Squishie"...nuff said.

So, I've been to this fine establishment on two separate occasions, once during restaurant week for dinner, and another this past week for a birthday lunch. 

Round 1: Dinner. Thursday. 7:30pm. Myself, Laura K, Caitlyn L & Erin

What was ordered:
- Caitlyn L went with the 3 course pre fixe (heirloom tomato salad, a HUGE pork chop with quinoa and something chocolate for dessert....for 33 bucks, she couldn't resist and according to her, all was fantastic.

-Laura K went rogue on the restaurant week menu (as did I and Erin) and  went straight for the kill, ordering the coveted "chip in egg"-a soft poached egg which is then lightly coated in a seasoned panko and then flash fried to a crisp. The end result, a crispy exterior encompassing a rich and luscious egg yolk, perfectly oozy. I could have stuck a fork in her, because she was doooooooooone....so good! Following the egg was the steak frites. She loved it as well.

-Erin went for the roast chicken which was such a great dish. Very comforting, very much like mama use to make. Roast chicken with roasted carrots and a decadent potato puree. 

-Myself, deciding on a small caesar, which ended up being tasty, HUGE, and not to mention perfectly dressed and not smothered in dressing...bonus. I also, like Laura K, went for the steak frites. I personally felt the portion of meat was a bit lacking, seeing as it was 2 thin slices of meat, and not actually a steak, but regardless, it had great flavor. 

Round 2: Birthday boy Damien S's "I added an extra year to your birthday card on accident, don't hate me" birthday lunch. Saturday. 2pm.

Ok, so this is where the "Squishie" comes into play.

What was ordered:

-Damien S did it up with a "Maria Basilico" bloody mary, featuring hints of fresh basil, horseradish, and cucumber. Refreshing, intriguing, manly...like an old spice commercial, minus the foul scent. His little birthday heart had fallen upon ordering some sort of chicken sandwich with fancy sauce on it. He liked, as did I, but we both agreed it may have been a tiny tiiiiiiiiiny bit dry, but barely. 

-Myself, the idiot who added a year to one of her best friends birthdays, had the almighty "Squishie", a fantastic concoction of champagne, orange juice, st. germain, and a splash of something else but damnnnnnnnnnnnn son, it was amazing. I then indulged myself in ordering the 16 hour brisket sandwich, topped with coleslaw and house made pickles. The train to flavor town had definitely pulled into the station.

*Service was better on the second visit than the first but that's to be expected when you're not in the middle of restaurant week. I can honestly say, I really like the atmosphere and the food. Wine, beer, and cocktails were equally good.

Excellent service!! Our servers were great, patiently explaining the specials and very attentive without being intrusive. I also love how there's free sparkling water. 

Smoked arctic char nicoise salad was so delicious, as well as the brussel sprout pancetta pizza. Was not crazy about the raw yellow fin tuna though...wasn't bad but just 3 tiny pieces of tuna for $13 is a bit unreasonable. 

Overall, a great place, and there's seating outside for a nice sunny day.

Made reservations for Thanksgiving. The downstairs area was perfect. I was upset to find out both desserts and one of the sides that were stated on the website for the holiday menu had been changed last minute. I can see if we were late arrivals and they ran out but we were amongst the first patrons. Unprofessional. The first bottle of water we were given was room temp. Yuck.  All 5 of us enjoyed our first courses. The presentation of the entree Turkey Duo was off balance, Way too much meat coupled with microscopic sides. My mom had the pork which I sampled and found delicious. They gave 2 of us substitute desserts as we did not like the last minute additions. Overall though: the atmosphere A, the food B to B plus, the service B.  I intend to try out their regular menu at some point, the back of the house shows promise.
Oh yeah-the Latin busboy had more personality than our waitress!

I guess if I had a hangover, this would be the place to go. My veggie omelet was super oily, cheesy and bland, the toast already too buttered, and after I ate half of it resignedly, I overheard our waitress tell the neighboring table about an eggs Benedict special with chard that sounded infinitely better. She couldn't have given us the information before we ordered? Meh, indeed.

Since opening, I have loved every meal at Russell House. A perfect blend of adventurous food and superb service. Whether it's stopping by the downstairs bar for a beer or enjoying a romantic meal, Russell House always provides the best atmosphere.

Highly recommend getting the lamb, no matter how it's prepared. Always delicious!

Russell House was the site of my first date and subsequent engagement night. This Harvard establishment has cemented itself in my heart and I cannot thank the staff enough for enhancing my special night even more with champagne and warm congratulations.

I came in for a few drinks with my friend early on a Saturday evening, the lights were nice and low, the small bar upstairs was full, and the downstairs bar was almost full. 

I like the bartenders uniforms and they were all generally nice and there for you. The drinks were good. But the best part...

THE MUSIC! I first paid attention while I was in the bathroom, and then realized the heavenly deities singing amazing beats and slower house music. While on the urinal, i pulled out my iphone and used the sound hound app for the remainder of the night clocking in those millions of butterflies and soft clouds. 

Who chooses the music?

Russell House Tavern has cornered the gastro-pub market in the Harvard Square area. It's much like The Gallows but with a more extensive menu including a raw bar. We came in as a group of 7 reservation-less folks and put our names in for a table. We were told that it was likely going to be an hour and a half (or more!!) but we found some space at the upstairs bar so we settled in to wait. I ordered the Sleepy Hollow cocktail which was tart and refreshing - a mix of gin, apricot and lemon. 

Surprisingly, a group didn't show and we were able to grab an upstairs table. I ordered the Short Rib Wellington for an appetizer. It's tasty, but I think that calling it Wellington is misleading. It's more like a stew with a puff pastry topper. The taste is amazing, but I wished for more short rib. I had lots of huge chunks of pepper and potatoes but very little short rib in my bowl. For my entree I went with the lobster from the raw bar menu. It's an appetizer portion for sure but it was brilliant. The lobster was tossed in some kind of mayo based sauce and was sweet and delicious. It is served with a side of diced beets and a couple homemade potato chips. Definitely satisfying.

The best part of the night...finding out that you can order a St Germaine cocktail...in a pitcher. Fab!!

Probably one of my favorite places to get drinks, at least on the slightly upscale side.  My fiancé really likes the drinks with their house made ginger beer.  We like the atmosphere downstairs and have always had nice service.  I've had their well-regarded burger twice.  The first time, my burger was overdone and dry.  Thus, I wasn't impressed.  The second time, they got it right and it was very delicious.  Haven't had a chance to experience much of the rest of the menu.

There are simply not enough stars in the sky (or on Yelp) for Russell House Tavern. I am totally enamored. I thought Stoddard's was going to be my new favorite but RHT has definitely stolen the show (and it's much closer to home). 

I had a fantastic night here on a lady date with a friend of mine. We started off with some classic St. Germain's and Moscow Mules while enjoying the COMPLIMENTARY bottled sparkling water (as a Perrier enthusiast, I was sold). We were having a casual night so we ordered a smattering of apps to nibble on though we ended up polishing off most. Our favorites were the Creamy Spinach Gratin and House Made Cotechino Sausage Pizza but the Short Rib Wellington and Dirty Caesar are hardly second tier selections. 

We ate in the quaint bistro area upstairs and enjoyed the people watching in Harvard Square and the lively din of the place without even realizing the existence of an entire dining room beneath us. This was likely the same setup from the days of Z on the Square however I'd never been to the space prior to that evening. I was pleasantly surprised on my trip to the restroom by the subterranean grandeur of the formal dining room. I was not-so-secretly jealous and almost asked our server to move us down there despite being more than halfway through. Speaking of the staff, they had clearly received the "let's go get 'em team!" pep talk at the beginning of the shift . Though their smiles and posture seemed a little forced, I could certainly appreciate the effort.

I am already gleefully planning my next visit back.

Don't believe the hype. 

Just because harvard square has gone WAY down over the years, doesn't mean that a mediocre restaurant should get all the hype that this one has. 

It's not bad, but certainly not as great as fellow yelpers have made it sound. Tried the following: cod, chicken, Caesar salad, tuna appetizer, oysters, fig pizza, steak tartare and 2 desserts, chocolate chili cake and bread pudding. There was 4 of us.  Tuna was smelly, had an odd texture for tuna, not tasty. The only standouts were the chocolate cake and the chicken. When you take into consideration the price and what you get these were the only 2 items that seemed "worth it". All other items were fine. That's it. Fine. Asked waitress for a menu to order a couple more items for the table. She didn't return for a LONG while, by that time we were over it. We had to flag her down a lot. She seemed to have a large section, so I'm sure she was busy, but we would've spent a lot more money on another bottle of wine and more food if we had a bit more of her attention. Back waiter/ busboy was great though. Completely on top of it... Give him a table or two! 
We drank wine and it was good. Prices seemed very fair and the cocktail menu looked interesting. We will be back and I'll be sitting at the bar and trying to like Russell house more....
But I'm in no rush.

Great choices of food, beer and wine.  

The menu here changes periodically but everything I've tried have been delicious.  My favorite so far is the roasted chicken which comes with mash potatoes and carrots.

THIS IS THE WORST PLACE. I HAD ONE OF THE WORST BRUNCHES EVER. The waiter was super rude. The food was lukewarm and generally gross. My friend spilled coffee and the waiter did not come over to help the situation - Our neighbors gave us their used napkins to stop the coffee from drenching us, then the napkins were left on the table and the waiter would not take them away or give us new napkins even though I notified him of the situation, and he disdainfully said "I know you spilled". ?! Doesnt that require the waiter to assuage the situation!!? I had to ask the host for new napkins and he was very rude about having to deal with the mess. We were never given new coffee or asked if things were ok. 

I AM NEVER NEVER GOING BACK TO THIS PLACE.

Was at Russell house for dinner the other night and had a lovely time.  Service was good, food was good, but the music was rather trite and hackneyed.  I've been in here enough times that I shouldn't have to hear the same four journey songs over and over again.  Also coldplay.  Seriously.  For a relatively modern bar, they certainly don't take their music seriously.

I had some problems with the food the service and the cleanliness of the glassware. The lamb belly pizza had no lamb belly that we could detect. The onions in the beef tartare were old and stinky. The menu read well, but was all around so so. The service at the bar was friendly enough, but we were in competition with the T.V. for the bartenders attention. It seemed that they were looking right at you and ignoring you. Not good. The big problem was the taste of sanitizer on the glasses. I don't know what to say?...rinse those glasses twice or something. I don't like the taste of sanitizer at all.

I go to this bar. A lot.  Way too more than I'm comfortable admitting on here.  I only hang out downstairs, usually in the same spot at the bar.  Not sure why.  Maybe it's so all of my stalkers know where to find me (you know who you are).  

The reason for all of this time spent in one location?  Great beer/wine selection, good food, and the drinks on the menu are great.  The bartenders can be a little hit or miss on off-menu cocktails though and I'm fairly sure they don't carry "flavors" so probably not the best place if you want one of those super fruity/sugary concoctions.  I say "fairly sure" because my friend's ordered apple martinis and that was a no-go.  I don't drink apple martinis so this isn't an issue for me.  If it is for you, go to Om  - they make them there.  

Anyways, back on topic:  the bar back downstairs is quite hot and a few of the bartenders are good looking too - always important!  Moreover, they are friendly and actually seem to care about the drinks they make.  

The big curved bar means that you can legitimately makes eyes with the person across the bar from you and it is great for people watching. And when there's no one to watch, you can focus on the TV or your amazingly delicious food.  The burger and the chicken sandwich are decently priced and  incredibly tasty.

Not the type of place that I'd frequent often but the lunch that I had here one weekend was good. Loved the lobster slides, the island creek oysters were fresh and awesome and my St. Germaine cocktail was refreshing. It was a nice day for the patio and not crowded in the late afternoon.

BUT AVOID $1 OYSTERS AT NIGHT.  They are served after 11 pm so that's a risk that you have to be willing to take. I've gone down that road before and come out unscathed but this time around, I wasn't so lucky.  We went for a late dinner and had a few small plates.  The farm eggs are quite good!  My BF ate his oysters all from one plate while my friend and I ate mostly from another plate.  BF was fine but my friend and I both got food poisoning the next day.  I noticed that with each oyster shell, there was a tiny piece of the shell that I had to spit out.  That should have been a tell tale sign that they weren't cleaned well when shucked. 

The oyster quality is significantly higher earlier in the day but that's what you get for wanting to save some $ at a place where the price point is too high.  I know there are people that get $1 oysters often but their stomachs are probably made out of steel. I would rather pay full price $2.50 at Island Creek Oyster Bar than be ill.

Food was good. Not great. But the price of the plate, compared to the portion size makes this place very overpriced. 3 peaces of Scallop for $25 that where just north of alright just doesn't seem worth it, especially being in Boston- where seafood is readily available.

I came here with my cousin and some of his friends for his birthday a few weeks back. It was pretty busy for a Thursday, but we still managed to find some space. While there I sampled the Cambazola Cheese appetizer, which was surprisingly unique and delicious, and the equally unique and delicious Kivik Apple Market cocktail. The food was great, and I wish I could give five stars, but I have to subtract one for the extra wait time after they got my appetizer order wrong the first time around. However, all things considered, I'd probably come back again.

Order the farm chip egg dish. Poached egg that is fried. How do they do it? Love this dish. Great at dinner time but also available for brunch. On the brunch menu it's called the Anti-Benedict. I also had the charcuterie board. Tasty and well executed. The hostess was nice during our visit in the Fall. One of the few places that would allow us to take our dog to their outdoor dining area. Definitely would go back.

Went there this weekend for brunch and sat at the bar, which based on some recent opentable.com reviews I've read might have been the real mistake. We sat for 1 hour, 15 minutes waiting for our food. We watched everyone around us get served, then even watched one party leave and the NEXT party be served, all before our food came. 
In all that time, our waiter/bartender never said a word to us -- in fact, did all he could to avoid eye contact and avoid helping us; even ignoring us the first time we said we were ready to order (we figured he wasn't our waiter and was going to get the correct person) -- and we only got helped when another bartender overheard us asking each other if perhaps our order hadn't been put in and helpfully checked on it. 
When the food finally came out, 2 of our 6 people had warm, tasty meals. The other four had cold eggs, missing side orders and, in the case of the two others, had cold, rock-hard toast for our melted cheese sandwhiches that the menu said would be served on "griddled brioche."
A manager showed up at one point, very briefly, and started with "I know you don't want to hear this, but our kitchen is really busy..." Looking around the room at all the other people eating, we couldn't help but point out -- politely -- that the busy kitchen didn't seem to have trouble getting anyone else served. When we asked about the (cold, toasted, rock-hard) sliced bread used instead of brioche for the sandwich, she said with a totally straight face "that is brioche." Really?! She said she'd sort things out, then disappeared.
We continued to wait (by this point, at least we'd eaten, even if most of the meals were served cold) with no more communication from anyone until we finally stopped the waiter in his tracks (as he tried to walk by again without making eye contact) and asked if we had a bill. After 2+ hours, we'd be hanging around the place long enough.
To their credit, they billed us about $13 for brunch for 6, which had included 2 alcoholic drinks. 
But the lack of communication from the staff -- never once did our waiter acknowledge that our food was late -- and the poor communication from the manager on duty won't have us coming back any time soon. What a bummer.

To start, I was *really, really psyched* to go here based on the recommendations.  I've wanted to go since it opened, since it's in a great location and about five minutes from my apartment.  I booked a reservation via OpenTable, and had dinner there tonight with my boyfriend.

Got seated, Thursday night at 7:30, upstairs was almost packed.  Server seemed pleasant and gave us our menus, we ordered cocktails, then took a few minutes to decide on a menu.  No bread.  Not a huge deal, but weird when the people sat after us were given bread immediately.

We decided to order two appetizers/"small plates" - got the crispy poached egg and the pork rillettes.   The egg was amazing.  The rillettes were way over seasoned, and a mush as opposed to the slightly more stringy texture I'm used to.  The bread it came with was terrible - far too brittle.

Drinks were fine.  The house rum was really nice, and the Moscow Mule was done well.

Next came dinner.  I had the steak frites medium rare, he had the burger medium.  Steak frites, which was supposed to be an 8oz cut, was two pieces of meat, maybe 6oz at best (with about 2 pounds worth of fries, likely to hide the fact there was so little of the steak - plating is also not a strong suit here).  It looked to be cooked perfectly, but upon actually tasting it, it was luke warm at best, as if it had been cooked first and sat out - OUT, not under any sort of heat lamp.  Not to mention I had to wait a few minutes to hail the waitress to ask for a steak knife.

The steak itself tasted like it had absolutely no seasoning, and the "demi", while a nice color, tasted nothing like a reduction.  It was more like a dark, watery sauce out of a bottle.  The combination was not pleasing.

Then the fries - they were cut like steak fries but were overall pretty limp.  These, like the rillettes, were overseasoned.  At this point it seems as though Russell House is suffering from Goldilocks Syndrome.

The BF's burger was - "Pretty much like Applebees" - not what I'd hoped to hear from a somewhat upscale restaurant, but not surprising given the incredibly lackluster entree I had.  I ate my steak and a handful of fries, he ate about 1/3 of his burger, we didn't take anything to go, nor did the waitress bother to inquire why.

We decided to give them the benefit of the doubt with dessert, and I'm glad we did.  He had the sorbet, I had the carrot cake bread pudding.  The bread pudding was out of this world and pretty much the reason for the second star.  The sorbet trio was okay, but the pink grapefruit sorbet was pretty much unpalateable. 

Overall, we were both really disappointed.  Service was lackluster, food was lackluster to poor, drinks were good.  I may try Russell House again in a few months when they've had a bit more time to get in the swing of things, but otherwise I would probably stick to grabbing a drink or two from their impressive selection of alcohol and share a small plate or two as opposed to plunking down $100 for below average food and service.

Usually, when I'm this excited to try a new place, I overlook a lot and genuinely want to like things.  Either I've matured from that phase, or Russell House disappointed me so badly I couldn't even go that far.

EDIT: It's now five hours later and I've been to the bathroom FOUR times, and not due to the drinks.  I honestly would assume I was right about the steak sitting out.  Ugh.

We checked in a got a free Gingerale :)

Really convenient location and a good lunch spot for sure!

Wow - this place is awesome. Everything about it - food, service, ambiance - gets 5 stars. It's a little on the pricey side, but your dining experience will be phenomenal.

We had a hard time ordering from the menu because everything looked so good. I ended up getting a House Charcuterie Board, which is an assortment of fine meats. DELICIOUS. It had the best pate I've ever had, along with some sliced meats and a dollop of local jam to cut the salt. We split a pizza with homemade cotechino sausage, which was bomb. It was crispy, generously sauced, and very flavorful. I kept on eating more of it, even though I was totally stuffed. The boyfriend also got the pig's head cake, which is basically all the meat from a pig's head put in a patty and topped with a poached egg. I know a lot of people would never think of ordering this dish, but for the gastronomically curious it is heaven on a plate. Lastly, our friend got the roasted chicken with mashed potatoes - it must have been good, because he all but licked the plate clean.

The service was good; our waitress was friendly and super patient with all our questions. I docked a star for a couple of reasons. First, the service was a little slow. It was decently crowed for a Tuesday night but we were definitely kept waiting at times. Second, they chose to seat all three of us at this tiny little table that was clearly meant for two. There were many larger tables that remained vacant for the rest of the night and plenty of downstairs seating so I don't understand why we got crammed in the corner.

Bottom line: incredible food, great ambiance, nice service. I definitely want to go back and try a bunch of other dishes.

we figured if we were going to a gastropub in harvard square, we'd be mingling amongst the yuppiest of harvard's finest. but we really wanted burgers and the menu sounded great.

to our expectation, us out-of-towners felt a bit out of place but it was a great place to people watch while grabbing a drink before dinner.

beer list and pours were good. the food was also great and hit the spot for our burger craving. salmon wasn't bad either. 

atmosphere was reminiscent of chicago's viagra triangle - for all those who've been.

This review deals with BRUNCH ONLY!

So I was utterly excited at the prospects of a brunch at Russel House Tavern. I've been there numerous times for cocktails, oysters, and dinner. All times the food and drinks have been pretty amazing. Waitstaff excellent.

But the other weekend we went for a early brunch with friends. Not alot of people in the restaurant. Server was awesome, but the food and drinks...

We tried several of their bloody mary's, the most interesting being the Red Sea. (A cocktail sauce type bloody mary with seafood in it), all of these cocktails, while strong, were not very good bloody marys. The seafood was room temp or warmer, and fishy.

Food wise, my girlfriend had a typical veggie/mushroom omelet with hashbrowns type affair. It arrived at room temp and was not bad, but nothing special in any way and did not make us want to order food their again. Likewise my breakfast of biscuit and gravy was one giant not too flaky, more on the greasy heavy side of things, biscuit, in a pool of gravy. Now biscuits and gravy don't need to be attractive to be amazing, but this presentation was worse than the usual biscuits covered in gravy. Also the gravy was flavored with wayyyyy too much maple syrup. It was painfully sweet.

TLDR: Basically I would have given this place 1 star for the brunch food except that the server was awesome and split our check 6 ways no problem. Also, this only applies to their brunch, I would definitely recommend them for dinner anytime.

Ended up at RHT this morning after too many drinks and not enough food last night. We were absolutely dying for something delicious, filling, boozy (and banana bready) to fill that terrible hole in our stomachs, and man, did RHT ever deliver.

This Piggly Wiggly (Bacon Bourbon Bloody Mary) is maybe the best I've had. YUM!

The banana bread and jam of the day started things off nicely, and the Breakfast pizza was to die for. It's hard to mess up eggy brunch dishes, but these were all done phenomenally well.

Oh yeah, the beer list rocks, too. Can't wait to come back for Cask Ale Thursday.

4 stars for slow (we were REALLY hungry) but friendly service.

This was our second try at the Russell House Tavern and this was our second disappointment. The appetizers on both occasions were passable, but nothing more. The entrees were mediocre, but lacking in balance and anything to make them special. The dessert on this occasion was terrible, described by one member of our party as sub-par for a Friendly's.

The drinks were excellent. Our waitress was outstanding, which took a little of the sting out.

Overall the problem seems to be that the Russell House is seriously overpriced for the quality of its offerings.

First off, this is the type of restaurant Harvard Sq desperately needed.  Had the food been better, It'd be a 5-star joint for me.  I like the layout/vibe/decor.  Huge basement dining room would be fun to check out sometime.  Other than our blase hostess, the service was really good (our waitress was very sweet).  I had the pork 3-ways, and the pork shoulder confit portion of the dish was rock-hard--a dense, thick, brick of pure meat, sans any marbling or flavor.  The crab cake lacked sufficient crab (always a pet peeve).  I'd give it another shot for dinner and would definitely come back for drinks and appetizers, since it seems like a nice place for a 30-something to throw back a few, and folks here are saying the cocktails are nicely done. 

Not 4 or 5 star material just yet, but there's potential, so I'll be back!

I'd give this 3.5 based on the limited selection of food I had on a Friday night.   We split the Chartucerie app, which was good.  Others loved the margarita pizza, but I thought it was just okay - not a great sauce.  I had steak tartare, which fine but not notable.

The vibe is fun both upstairs and downstairs.  Our party of walked right in around 5 on a Friday and sat at a long high top table upstairs. 

Loved the beer selection.  Goose Island Matilda made my night.  This is so hard to find outside of Chicago, let alone on draft.  It's delicious, try it.

When I go to Russell House I usually sit at the bar. I think this place has a good vibe, a pretty decent american beer selection and definately a good place for oysters. If you want a bargain on the oysters get there after 11 and get the oysters for a buck. I also really enjoy their food too!

Absolutely fantastic!  If you are in Cambridge, even if just for a day, you must go.  The menu is inventive and interesting and our server, Lee, was outstanding!  We started with the roasted bone marrow and the fried oysters.  The marrow was wonderful.  T

Finally had the chance to try RHT and I am impressed. This is what Eastern Standard could have been if they gave a crap about their kitchen. The decor is very well done with some great lighting choices.

Service: I think our waiter's name was Brian. He was everything I look for in a server. He was friendly, engaging and knowledgeable. If he didn't know the answer to a question he would find out and promptly return.

Food: I am a charcuterie whore. I go to places specifically for this and sadly they are usually pretty underwhelming. RHT had the best plate I have had so far. The best part was that they served duck ham on it. I love duck ham and so few places have it. The flavors were excellent. The rillette was like eating spreadable bacon. I even liked the chicken liver pate which I usually leave to the boyfriend to demolish. My only complaint would be that I'd like some sort of pickled item to cut through the fat. Everything else we had was also delicious (crabcakes, serrano ham, oysters) including our drinks.

Overall, I'm psyched that RHT opened. I'm tired of other places in the area like this that fail to deliver.

I just want to write a review about the downstairs bar--it's got a great vibe during the day on a weekend--of course, I don't often drink during the day, but when I am craving a bloody mary (sans tourists), this is the spot.
Good brunch.

This was the worst dining experience I have ever had in Harvard Square.

Things started off great - I was seated immediately (even a patio seat!) when I got there at 5 pm, even after telling the hostess that I was still waiting for the other half of my party of two.  I sat down and waited a few minutes before my friend came, then we had to wait another 5 minutes before anyone came over for the first time. Water was dropped off at the table, with no mention of taking a drink order or questions about the menu.  Finally, someone came back to take drink orders: a Harpoon Oktoberfest and Pinot Noir on tap.  *Another* five minutes later, and the server came back to ask us to show her Harpoon Oktoberfest on the actual menu because she couldn't find it on the computer screen.  *Another* five minutes later, and the drinks came from a new server (still no food order taken): a Harpoon Oktoberfest and Pinot Blanc.  I mentioned that I ordered the Pinot Noir to the newest server to come to our table (this was the third one we had seen in the 20 minutes we had been there, and we still hadn't had the opportunity to order) apologized and offered to take our order.  I asked what the daily terrine was and she had no idea, so she promptly left to find out.  *Another* five minutes later, she comes back with my wine and offers to take our order.  Again, I ask what the daily terrine is and still doesn't know.  FINALLY she comes back knowing what the terrine is - a foie gras, which sounds good and I order that and the crispy egg, and we split the spinach gratin starter.

The food came promptly, but it was highly disappointing.  The spinach gratin was overpowered with garlic (even for myself, a true garlic lover), and the terrine was incredibly salty.  After the main courses arrived, we were given the complimentary bread that should have came with the drinks we waited 20 minutes for.  The bright spot was the crispy egg, which was delicious.  Unfortunately, this one dish was nowhere near enough to save this disaster of an experience - I will not go back, and would encourage others to avoid this restaurant.

I've been to RHT for lunch, dinner, drinks, and dessert, and it never disappoints, in terms of quality. Both the menu items and the service have always been top-notch.

I was here most recently for a reunion dinner with some sorority sisters on a Saturday night; made reservations (always recommended as it gets very busy here) for 5 initially, then amended it to 6, with no issues whatsoever. It was nice that they called to confirm the morning of... definitely makes things easy if you need to change any of your plans.

We ordered a bunch of things to share: a white pizza, two orders of the lamb's belly toast, a side order of French fries, and the melted cheese app that came with that delicious flatbread. Everything was tasty and filling, to boot. Our drinks were also quite good... I had a St. Germain cocktail (comes in either a glass or a pitcher--good to know!), and the other ladies had beers (lots of good ones on tap) and other cocktails (Always Sunny is a big favourite). Whatever you order, it'll be delicious. And the bartenders have been known to concoct yummy drinks based on your preferences, if you don't know what you want to order.

The downstairs is more spacious than the upstairs, and the bar is an enormous horseshoe-shaped area that spans half the space, but doesn't feel too overwhelming. Plus, there are other booths and high tops and (more) private areas as well. Overall, a solid option in the Square for a meal or a drink; definitely a must if you're in the area.

In the heart on the Harvard campus. Nice place to get a weekend brunch or a drink in the area.

The ambiance is upscale but laid back just as I would expect on an Ivy League campus date spot type place.  The food and drinks are good, nothing out of this world though.  I did think it was a tad expensive.

I am a regular patron at this restaurant, especially during evening hours. This was my second brunch there and I was already disappointed since they got rid of the egg skillet dish that I loved from my last brunch. Well, the three of us ordered two Egg Benedict (one with the fried option, $2 extra) plates and a pulled pork sandwich. 
I would say the Egg Benedict was good (exactly what you would expect from an egg benedict) except for the greens that were served with it. It was a bit too salty for my liking. 
The pulled pork was not bad, but I wouldn't order it again. The flavors were too strong, especially the cheese, but for those who like a big chewy sandwich would probably appreciate it a lot more than I did. Although, I would recommend getting it without the bacon.
Since this is a brunch review, and priding myself as a somewhat of a coffee connoisseur (ex-barista), I must rate the coffee. The coffee at Russell House was fairly standard, with a touch of acid and mild flavor. It didn't feel too watery which is often the case in many restaurants. 
Our server was nice, friendly and fairly attentive. But, I think the hostess could have been nicer...(one of my friends came late and the hostess was completely oblivious to where our table was, even with the name on the reservation! My friend had to call.)
Overall, I would give it four stars, although I don't think I'll come back for brunch. Yet, considering my many visits here, I'll definitely be back for their Happy Hours and bar scene.

I'm definitely a huge fan.  Beautiful space in Harvard Square with stellar service, great drinks and some fine eats.

I know some people who come here mostly for drinks...but you really are missing out if you don't try the food.  I had two incredible dish

I hate to hold one crummy reservation snaffu against a restaurant, but hey, I had one, so I'm striking one star.

Russell House Tavern is a nice spot for a date, a night with friends, or brunch with your parents. The location is perfect for spending a day in the Square. Upstairs, you can grab an unbeatable people-watching seat by the windows. Downstairs, the atmosphere is cool and comfortable.

Food-wise, this place is pretty good. Great poached egg appetizer, and a nice selection of small plates. You can eat expensive here--some entrees in the mid-20 range, or more strategically by sharing the tapas or flatbreads. Weekend brunch was also pretty great--they were sadly out of the EBLT, but the simple chicken sandwich was tasty.

Russell House Tavern may not wow you--well, for some it may--but it won't disappoint either. I made my first visit to the Harvard Square favorite on a Sunday afternoon when everyone and their mother was out and about due to the warm spring weather. Luckily, the tavern didn't have too long of a wait (just 20 minutes), likely due to the ample space. Added bonus: We were seated on the ground level fairly close to an open window.

The brunch menu is a mix of breakfast and lunch. In fact, there aren't many traditional breakfast options, so be prepared. The selection, however, is interesting and gives you a reason to go here than an IHOP. I was fairly disappointed, however, that the menu wasn't more vegetarian friendly than it was. Or at least offer turkey bacon in place of pork. (*Hint, hint if the tavern's management is reading this!) 

I didn't have a Bloody Mary or anything alcoholic, but I'd be interested in coming back and trying something from their drink menu.

Perfectly enjoyable! Used to be Z-Square, I think. The downstairs atmosphere has a beautiful marble bar and cozy function room... outside patio is also fantastic. My friend and I lunched outside. Our oyster snack and meals were delicious, my friend even ordered a sandwich for her husband to go! Prices quite reasonable and service was mellow but attentive, we definitely be back.

Someone needs to tell these folks what hashbrowns are, because, what they're selling as hashbrowns are obviously home fries.   However, they're good homefries, so... there's that.

Speaking of potatoes, the french fries are also very good.   They give you an option of fries of green salad with sandwiches, which is nice, and if you ask, they'll give you a litttle of each.

The real winner here, though, is the Bloody Mary.  Well, Marys... you have options!  But I like the classic.   It looks very plain so you'll expect to be disappointed but the taste is spot on.  Rich with spices and horseradish and and and...  if you're a Bloody Mary fan, it's not to be missed.

The setting here is warm and inviting and the service seems to be spot on.  Overall, I'd say I'm a fan.

Russell House has remained pretty solid. The stay three stars this time because they were out of 3 things on the menu - the 20 oz Painted Hills ribeye steak, the lamb shoulder and I want to say the fish of the day. Friend had to substitute the steak frites instead, reportedly very good, cooked perfect med rare. I think we had an order of the roast chicken, good and a salad somewhere in there. I enjoyed the "Seared Gloucester Cod Loin with Creamed Fennel, Roasted Verrill Farms Celery root, Bacony Greens." The cod was juicy, melt in your mouth, just fatty enough for a loin but trimmed well. It was complimented very nicely by the creamed fennel, greens and roasted celery root done in French fry style on top of the cod. The fennel was certainly creamy and well textured, a hint of pepper. 
As always, the oysters were delicious and fresh, cold. Several Hendricks and tonics and goose and tonics laters, the ladies, my bud and I climbed up the stairs to the pouring rain on this Thursday evening adventure. A good, reliable standby.

Redefining the modern Tavern.

The entrance decor is moderately simple, but elegantly done. If you choose to head downstairs, you will be met with another level of elegance and an array of bar seating.

We took the simple, communal table approach. A fine choice.

Russell House offers a relatively short, but thoughtful cocktail menu. I chose the prohibition era classic: The Last Word. It was very well mixed, not watered down, not exceedingly limey, nor overwhelmingly Chartreusey. 

There is also a great selection of food, food any mood you might be in.  Pizza, Raw Bar, Small Plates, Entrees. I wasn't in need of a full meal, so I chose the Crispy Soft Poached Chip-In Farm Egg which was probably one of the most thoughtful and delicious egg dishes I've ever had.

Imagine the most perfectly poached egg, with a perfect oozey yolk inside. Now, imagine that egg breaded and perfectly crispy. And now, imagine that crispy poached egg placed on top of aioli, pancetta and brioche with perfect seasoning. 

Yeah, now stop imagining and go get it.

Russell house is a really nice dressed up Pub.  excellent assortment of appetizers and starter plates. a fun menu of interesting mixes. Pizza and raw bar are a cut above with great selection.  The Drink menu is what really stands out.  they have a great mixologist staff that make delicious mixed drinks with fresh ingredients.  Overall this is an excellent place to go for interesting food and fun drinks in a classy tavern feel. a great place to meet for drinks and a snack with friends.

great place to have drinks and food. the ambiance here is very nice with mostly young crowd. I had the spanish serrano ham and a sald as an appetizer and they were both great. I picked the pork trio after the waiter recommended it as an entre and it was simply amazing. Overall, I was very happy with both the service and food here and would highly recommend it.

Want lunch in Harvard Square?  May I suggest Russell House Tavern?

Had lunch with a couple of friends on a Friday afternoon and although I've made it for dinner here a few times over the past two years I'd never tried their lunch menu.

The Archer Farms meatloaf melt was fantastic.  Also, the greens had a light dressing.

I can't do 5-stars because the Oysters were sub-par.  I know it may not be the season, but the tartar sauce was lumpy and there was a zing missing.  In any case, there was a special ($1 an Oyster from 2-5).

High recommendation from this discerning customer.

I only ever eat at the bar here. It has a nice oyster menu often, for those who enjoy such things, and the flat bread is usually good. The location's great and the crowd is often chatty and pretty. That said, when it's crowded my review would drop to two

Fantastic!!!! Amazing food and a great waiter! His name is Adam, ask for him. He was super helpful and so friendly!!!! Definitely going back soon! 

P.s. Amazing oysters and the mussel salad is great!

Waiter was ok.
 The food was extremely overpriced and miniscule on our plates.
Eat downstairs if you can as the ambiance is better than the bar area.
There are better places to eat that aren't so trendy - try Citizen's Pub.

Ok, mostly good things to say. Really nice look at feel to the place, even though a considerable amount of it is in a basement. The atmosphere is ok, but there certainly is a little bit of that "try-hard" thing going on which I don't like. And this really is the only place where I find the cons...it's just a little too full of itself, the place, the atmosphere, not intolerable, but, I imagine there could be nights where it is OR they on the path to getting to that point. I'd like to ask them not to..because the food and the drink selections are top notch, the execution is pretty good and if they just eased off the pretension it would be a really wonderful place.

Good place to come with a group of friends.  The bar downstairs is always fun, I have come here on a tired day after work and I felt relaxed and at ease.

It gets very very very packed on the weekends, so make a reservation if you would like to come.

I am not a big fan of their brunch menu, but the dinner menu has a few things that are okay.  This is more for the atmosphere not for the quality of the food.

On my numerous visits to RHT, I've been struggling to figure out what I like or dislike about the place; it's very much been a love and hate relationship between myself and the establishment. Whether I went there for a Yelp Elite event, for drinks or for food I've noticed many inconsistencies in either the food, the service and/or the drinks.

While I think that Aaron Butler, their bar manager, is a phenomenal staff member, one who's expertise was finely crafted and tuned at Barbara Lynch's Drink before he moved to RHT to takeover their bar, I think that their drinks have been hit or miss a lot of times. While they've nailed some of my drinks, often times they haven't been nearly as good as what I've paid for. It's just been inconsistant; I'll order a Vieux Carré and it'll be excellent but then I'll get it again the following week and it won't taste nearly as good. I can't explain why but consistency is key in this case and I have yet to find it there. Another big disappointment in their wine on tap. While the concept is great, I've had two glasses of wine from their innovative, forward-thinking mechanism. One of Pinot Noir and the other of Pinot Blanc; Each time I could only have a couple of sips before discarding the rest because of a metallic-like aftertaste in each sip. While the glasses were only $5 each, it clearly wasn't worth it as the wine was mediocre at best.

On the upside most of their cocktails are affordable for the quality that you receive and will be worth it most of the time. 

As far as the food there goes, I've experienced both their regular dinner menu as well as their bar menu. The neat thing about their food is that the value is usually pretty great (except for one item, but I'll get to that a bit later) and they have all kinds of offerings, including  a raw bar. I've had their house burger which is a pretty solid meal in itself but when I ordered the roasted bone marrow dish from their bar menu I was extremely disappointed; while it tasted good, the portion was TINY! A half a bone. At $9. There's no way I'm doing that again, I felt like such a sucker. 

So despite my few complaints, why give it 4 stars? Well for one, the RHT fills a gigantic void within the neighborhood. Very few places offer a solid selection of cocktails, wines and beers and accompany them with worthwhile food options. And in this case, the place remains a neat, well decorated, casual but slightly upscale option where  you can go have a few drinks with friends or have a meal. Just be careful as to what you order as the value is not always there.

Inconsistencies aside, they do have some nice deals for the oyster loves in you. After 11PM, every single day, oysters are half-off and can be ordered at $1 each. Not bad at all. Oh and next time you're there hungover, you can always try the following: "The Quickening". - A Collins glass filled w/ Meletti Amaro, chartreuse green, & Rogue Dead Guy Ale, before being chased by a shot of Fernet & a plate of bacon. Or their secret burger, which is their regular burger topped with a fried egg.

Two stars looks bad, but the description "Meh" perfectly summarizes my evening here.  They had a lot of exciting looking small plates and appetizers, so my boyfriend and I ordered many of those and no entrees.  Deviled eggs and bone marrow were good, but nothing special.  Foie gras terrine with cherry gelee was awful, and I LOVE anything foie gras; it just tasted incredibly medicinal.  Steak tartare was okay, not a lot of taste and if the $10 portion is the larger size, I cannot imagine what the $8 portion looks like.  The charcuterie board was laughable; a single meager slice of three kinds of cured meat, two rillettes and pate (okay, the rillettes and pate were actually quite delicious, but an unevenly large portion for the poor turnout of the other meats).  Service, drinks, and $1 oysters were great, but not really enough to make up for how unsatisfying the food was.  I'm not sure, do they have a happy hour?  I can see this place making a good happy hour if the drinks were cheaper.

Russell House was my first love. Ever since I turned 21 (last year), and a bit before that, it has been my bar of choice. Yes, there are a few small things wrong with our relationship -- I do get jealous when its attentions are too set on others (no seats open EVER on Thursdays-Saturdays? Are you SERIOUS?), but I understand. 

Sometimes RH showers me with gifts, like the time there was a 1200 dollar open tab and only four of us to eat and drink to our heart's content. (3 Scottish plays, a bottle of red, a bottle of rose, and lots of RH towers please).

But most of the time we take it slow and steady. A dozen 1-dollar oysters to share, a Scottish play, and lots of heart to heart conversations.

I'm very sad to write this review. RHT has been a stalwart in our rotation for the last 2 yrs. We loved the ribeye. It was always done to perfection, and more than enough for my dc and me. Their version of a Moscow Mule was fabulous. So, what happened? They kept the price of the steak the same, and seriously cut the portion, almost in half. Literally - they even shaved the bone, so it was like the bottom half of our steak was missing, bone included. The chef had added a balsamic reduction on top of the steak. This wasn't mentioned in the menu. We would have elected to have it on the side. This is the first time I had to ask my dc for a little more steak, because the portion on the bone wasn't enough. My drink was very weak, I didn't even get a buzz. Sigh - goodbye RHT.

I have visited this establishment for only 3 reasons:

1) Used to work in Alewife. It was on way home and my co-corker/partner-in-crime lives in Harvard Sq.
2) They have a pretty damn good steak tartare
3) They also have a pretty good selection of beer, including Pretty Things. Granted seeing a bottle of it for $16 when I'm out always makes me cringe because I know I can grab it for half the price at my friendly neighborhood liquor store. So I usually go for a Harpoon IPA or something. This is also contingent on how much/what I've drank at whatever place I was at before getting to Russell House. 

So why only 3 stars when there's good beer and good steak tartare? Maybe its a question of my friend(s) and I getting too comfortable and not leaving sooner than we should but once you hit 9pm, this place turns into what I imagine would be the key place for all the action if the Bravo network decided to make a reality TV version of "The Social Network." That's what it looks like. Swarming with Harvard undergrads. Everywhere. Part of me wonders if David Fincher didn't spend some time at Russell House after 9pm. And what I also mean by this description is that this place makes you feel very old very quickly if you stay much past 9pm. I have no idea what sort of fake IDs the kids are getting these days but they really look young. Like real young. And there's so many of them. 

So I feel kind of guilty taking off stars because this place becomes "really young" after 9pm but its also just sort of your run-of-the-mill gastropub. Nothing you haven't seen before, nothing you won't see again. But I'm sure I'll be back here as they do have steak tartare.

Much to my misfortune, Russell House only moved into Harvard Square when I was on my way out of the Boston area, but it's always been a delight to go whenever I'm back in town. It's a restaurant that pivots for multiple needs incredibly well. I've had a light lunch by the windows with a carafe of on-tap rosé; I've had (always too many) shots of Fernet and High Life at the underground bar; I've had stellar burgers; I've watched two friends pound through 100 oysters in a sitting; I've known people who worked there; I've pierced my ear on the recommendation of a flirty waiter.

There are three things that go into any great restaurant: food, drink, atmosphere. Here, the beer selection is always good, the cocktails are even better, and the wine is on tap. The food moves well between incredible charcuterie and ($1 late-night) oysters and just-as-good sandwiches and burgers (I'm afraid I've never splurged on the more-expensive entrees, but I'm sure they're excellent as well). The atmosphere can be a little dim during the day if the patio is closed and you're not next to the windows, but as long as that's not the case, it's cozy, and the staff has always been friendly, chatty (in a good way), and welcoming.

Russell House is my cornerstone restaurant in Harvard Square; even now, writing this review across the country, I wish I could dial up a friend, head down, and put back a cocktail or two (or three or four) over oysters, make some bad decisions, and add another memory to the list.

It was my first time in to Russell House Tavern on Saturday night and thanks to the small plate design, I can say I had a really good cross section of their menu.  I loved the atmosphere, the drinks and the food.

There were some mixed reviews of the wine glasses since they are stemless and basically look like a juice glass.  Wine aficionados may not love it - I personally thought it was good that I was getting a bigger pour, so whatever.  

The food was pretty good.  I got the kale and pine nut salad which was a fairly typical salad, the tuna sashimi (VERY small portion) but it was fresh and the crispy yam patty on the side was awesome.  I also tried a piece of my friend's pizza with brussels sprouts on it which was great and my fiance and I split the pig's head small plate.  The pig's head tasted a lot like beef, which surprised me, but it was very flavorful.  I also had a bite of some of my fiance's pate off of the charcuterie plate and it was so good (and I'm not usually a pate fan).

I will definitely be back to try more small plates since they had a lot of exotic stuff on the menu.  It was pretty reasonably priced for upscale food.

I honestly don't know what to make of this place... I enjoy the salads here (especially the local leaf with figs and walnuts, topped with shrimp) but the pizzas are too small and thin-crust to get into. They definitely make quality drinks, but nothing that I'd say was terribly memorable. I do love that there is a robust bar menu and bar-like seats in the front and downstairs, but I also don't feel like the place has a lot of personality. I feel like Goldilocks reviewing RHT -- at the end of the day, if you live in the Cambridge area, you might as well check it out, just be warned that it's not cheap!

The Russell House Tavern was is an excellent choice for someone looking for a pub experience with a little something extra - aka a gastropub. The food selections are a tad more gourmet than your typical bar food and the beer / wine / liquor selections are particularly interesting. 

It does get crowded and the staff can be a tad confused about what to do with people when they run out of seats. 

They had Great Divide Brewing Company Hoss (Rye Lager) on draft along with some locals like Cambridge Brewing Company. The beer, wine, whisky and bourbon selections are excellent and will please swill and craft drinkers alike with more preference toward the discerning palate.

So yummy! We booked a large party (11 people) with less than 24-hours notice, and they were super accomodating. We were at a long table, and the waitress was super sweet, giving the specials at both ends and answering mutiple questions. The salads were delicious, and the artic char was fabulous. My dad got the steak, which was well cooked. The onion rings were a bit hard to eat, but good. The mashed potatoes were just okay. The cocktails were creative and good, and the waitstaff knowledgable. My one complaint would be that the restaurant was a bit loud, but we weren't screaming to talk to each other, which was nice. Overall, a wonderful meal!

I love this place.
No really, I LOVE this place. LOVE.

Back in the day, when this was just a crappy Z-Square restaurant, I hardly noticed this spot, squeezed as it is between Papyrus and Citizens Bank.

But then, one glorious glorious summer (2010), Russell House Tavern (hereafter, RHT) was established, and I began spending most of my evenings cosied up at the upstairs (i.e. ground floor) bar. Allow me to explain why...

Service is awesome. I am a big fan of the bartenders called Nick and "Sparkle Pony". There are a couple of Aarons and, I believe, a Chris. All these guys have consistently served me well. If I have ever ordered anything I didn't like here, my dish has been whipped away efficiently and replaced with something far more delicious, all at no cost to me. This is true both of drinks and of food.

Speaking of food I didn't like here: they do some crazy bone marrow dish that, quite frankly, I would give to a dog but not to a human. But no one forced me to order that dish -- I did it, on a whim, and when I disliked it, it was replaced immediately. I'm not removing one star from my review because I found a dish I didn't like: I'm not so monomaniacal to assume every restaurant should only offer on the menu that which I personally want to eat...
... especially because there is so much food here that I love.

The Charcuterie Board is divine. Unless you KNOW you love the rilette, ask for the Board without it. I often replace the rilette with a small spoonful of the Steak Tartare. MAN, the tartare is good. Other great things? You can never go wrong with their soup du jour (only served at lunch, alas), their Caesar salad, and my GOODNESS you *have* to try their crispy poached egg. And the lamb. And the duck. Beyond awesome.

The pizzas are totally delicious, but by far I love the oysters. Oysters oysters oysters. Shucked and served on ice in front of you at the bar. Did I mention that it's only $1 per oyster after 11pm? Yes, that's no typo: ONE DOLLAR PER OYSTER after 11.

Finalement, les beverages. They have pretty much every kind of wine and beer you could ever want... perhaps minus the most mediocre sort. The bar staff are great mixologists (I say PAH to you who prefer the overpriced, yet similarly delicious, cocktails at Drink) and if you're eager for something new... ask them for an "Anouska".

That's right, kids and kittens, they (unofficially) named a cocktail after me :) Do you see why I love this place?

I noticed the Russell House Tavern for the first time today (Sunday brunch) when running some errands in Harvard Sq. It looked nice from the outside, with large open windows into the restaurant and seating in an outdoor patio, so we decided to check it out.

I was pleasantly surprised to find that they have a raw bar (I love oysters!) and a really good beer selection (according to my husband, the bar tender). We ordered a E.B.L.T. sandwich (eggs + BLT) and an eggs benedict. The delivery was extremely quick, and both dishes were really delicious (the eggs were perfectly runny on the benedict). I agree with Heather G. that the waitstaff need a little work- they had run out of tomatoes for my BLT and failed to tell me until I noticed and asked, for example- but all were friendly and polite. I'm looking forward to going back for dinner to see how that menu fares. Until then, a solid 4 stars.

3, but only bc the food was fairly bomb. Service on the other hand, atrocious. The hostesses were lovely, directing my pal & I to the basement as it hosted a larger bar & we were only looking for drinks & apps. Thanks to them we lucked out and landed 2 se

Russell House Tavern is located in the heart of Harvard square on JFK Street. They have a great our door seating area for the beautiful summer days. This was not one of them with the heat and humidity. We opted to sit inside at one of the high-tops near the bar upstairs.

Their menu had lots of great entrees but not being overly hungry we decided to order two things and share them.  We settled on the R. House Grass Fed Burger and the Grilled Chicken Sandwich.  The burger was 8ounces of perfectly cook ground beef served on an English muffin with cheddar cheese, bacon and caramelized onions. It was very juicy and a tad messy but it was very tasty. The Grilled Chicken Sandwich with an edamame and pecorino spread, pickled red onions, fried shishito peppers and arugula on a focaccia was a bit different but equally tasty. I enjoyed the variety of flavors that both entrees offered. Both meals were served with an ample serving fresh cut French fries.

If I had to choose one I would go with the burger just because it was a classic burger and those always hit the spot. The chicken was a tad messier then the burger with the spread oozing out of it as your took a bite.

Given that it was a Friday I decided to get a cocktail and with the waiters recommendation I got the Cure-All-Fiz made of Oxley Gin, Rhubarb-Infused Lillet, strawberry, lemon, burlesque bitters and soda water. It was very unusual and a bit weird honestly. I am not sure if it was the variety of citrus flavors that just didn't seem to mesh well or if it was the less than ample serving. My biggest pet peeve with restaurants is that when you serve a drink the ice shouldn't make up 90% of the beverage. Its purpose is to keep the drink cool not to be so dominant that unless you drink it immediately it becomes so diluted with water that you don't taste anything especially when you're paying 10$ a drink.

3 Stars. - I had to take a star away for the poorly executed cocktail.

russell house tavern has potential, but given that it's reasonably popular already, don't know that they'll have the motivation to improve... 

the special soft-shell crab pizza was totally underwhelming.  the crab was a bit on the dry side, and the pizza dough was more like a cracker - thin and crispy, but not quite as crispy as a cracker.  no chewy texture at all.  in fact, it's the same "flatbread" (i.e., slightly chewy cracker) that comes with the spinach gratin.  we put them side by side, and they are definitely the same product.  

speaking of the spinach gratin, it was way too salty!  don't know if they added too much salt in addition to the blue cheese it comes with or what.  given it has blue cheese, the rest of the added salt needs to be moderated!  (this coming from someone who likes well seasoned food).

dirty caesar was good, but the croutons were similarly too salty.  my gf also points out that it was unevenly dressed - some portions had lots of dressing while others were more lightly dressed. (no, they were not extraordinarily busy - we were seated without a wait - so that's not an excuse for sloppy prep).

house charcuterie was the highlight.  the pates and ham were very tasty.  not enuf crostini to go with the amount of pate tho.  i suppose that was necessary to make it look artsy - throwing in a whole baguette on the board would not be as sexy, tho that amount of bread would be more proportionate to the amount of spread/cold cuts.

moscow mule, the lime, ginger, vodka mixed drink was good.  right amount of alkie and good ginger flavor.  drink selection in general is quite good (which i'm sure accounts for a good portion of the restaurant's popularity).

lastly, service was on the poor side.  we had to wait a good 15 minutes for the check after we asked, as the waiter kept forgetting.  also, he seemed to encourage over ordering - good short term strategy, i suppose, if he doesn't plan on staying at the restaurant for long anyway.  bad long term strategy for the restaurant tho.

also liked the decor.  

all in all, despite all the negative aspects, both my gf and i felt we'd like to come back and try this place again.  i'd like to see if they can step up their game in spite of the attention they've already garnered.

Got out of work early on a beautiful Friday afternoon, grabbed some drinks with a co-worker and headed to Russell House Tavern for dinner with my man. I could not have asked for a better day and the food at RHT fit right in.

Seriously, my boyfriend claimed the Ozark Heritage Pork Trio had too much salad (See pic. The pork and salad are served over grits.). That speaks to two things: 
1. All three cuts of pork - loin, belly and shoulder - were prepared expertly.  2. He loves him some pork.
And I tasted the grits. They alone would get 5 stars. That should be a side choice, seriously.

I just checked...it is! Gettin' it next time!

I opted for the Roasted Giannone Farm Chicken served over mashed potatoes. Having given up potatoes in favor of a better summer body, this was an indulgence - and worth the extra 10 min on a treadmill. The skin of the chicken was crispy and the potatoes were smooth as butter. Solid, if not safe, choice. But when I start drinking early, I just want what you want. (And I usually want comfort food.)

I'm not going to spend time on the cocktails. Seriously, ask for a suggestion from your server or bartender and go with it. The drinks are fabulous and probably enhanced by the speakeasy feel of the downstairs seating area. It just begs that you show up in a flapper outfit complete with jeweled head piece.

It's a little chaotic - but overall -  like it. Don't plan on bringing a group here and being able to hear anyone more that one seat away.

That said - they have great beers on tap and the Short Rib Wellington packs epic flavor into a small dish. Perfect food portioning at work.

Maybe I am just a simpleton and I "don't get it", but why should I get chastised by the rude bartender for asking for the best selling beer in the world.  Just say no, don't be a pompous douche.  I say this especially since their "only craft beer" list sorta sucks.  I ordered a Sleepy Hollow cocktail instead, it was not good.  Maybe you should stick with something that works versus tinkering with ingredients you can't handle (it had no enough mint, too much lemon, and I have no idea what they were using for apricot, but it was plain nasty).

Delicious food, great beer, awesome service.

We started with fresh sourdough ciabatta bread served with an olive oil dip that was so buttery and flavorful. I don't usually reach for the bread basket, but this bread was chewy, hearty and delicious.

We also had a glass of the just tapped cask beer, a Gritty McDuff's ale which was strongly flavored with citrus and hops and had a yeasty nose, almost like a really strong champagne.

We split the Dirty Caesar Salad with spicy anchovy croutons. It was the perfect blend of cold, crunchy, salty, nutty, and spicy all in one.

We also shared an unpictured  dozen of oysters with a cucumber mignonette and cocktail sauce. I figured you have seen enough oyster photos from me! Also unpictured, a little bit of heaven, also known as Crispy Soft Poached Chip-In Farm Egg with Pecorino Aioli, Toasted Brioche, House Pancetta. A breaded poached egg atop crispy, buttery brioche? Amazing.

I think my favorite dish, however, was the Crab Salad with Roasted Fennel Jam on top of Warmed Old Bay Biscuits. Each component of this dish was perfect by itself. The crab was sweet and fresh and tender, the biscuits flaky, and the fennel jam crunchy, slightly sweet, and very refreshing as fennel tends to be. Put together, this was just one of the best combinations I have ever had.

We finished the meal with the chocolate cheesecake which did not come out very pretty in the photo I took. It was amazingly dense and rich and chocolatey, and I am glad that we shared it!

Our server, Steven, was outstanding. He knew a lot about everything on the menu and especially knew about the very well developed beer list. He was super friendly and made us feel welcome. Even the manager stopped by to check in, and there was a genuine feeling of great hospitality on top of the great food.

The only drawback I could see were the TV's. From my seat I could see 3, and I think there may have been more, and I prefer restaurants, if they do have TV's to have parts of the restaurant where they can not be viewed.

I was skeptical at first, but Russell House has literally become my go-to place when I have friends coming from out of town and want to show them what Boston dining is all about. I've also been here for birthdays, grad school celebrations, or just when I need some amazing oysters and drinks. (The Wigglesworth? That's my drink. It's STRONG.) 

The menu does cater a little more to people like me, who like eating animals (and especially the parts that too often get passed over, like cheeks, liver, marrow). With that said, a vegetarian friend of mine still raves about the melted cambazola cheese flatbread. Ok, so maybe don't bring your vegan friends there, but everyone else will find plenty to sustain them. I love the charcuterie platter, which is always plenty to wrap up and take home, unlike some places which give you tiny schmears of paté on a board. The chip-in poached egg has to be tasted to be believed and is, quite rightly, what they're known for. 

I saw some people on here saying they had problems with the service, but my experience has been for the most part different. Our servers have been attentive and knowledgeable, and we've never waited too long for a table. It can get pretty loud, but it's spacious enough that it's not usually a problem. And I have to say I'm still blown away every time I walk in there by what they've done with the space, which has had some less-than-memorable places there in the past. Russell House Tavern has managed to create an atmosphere that fits right in with the vibe of the Square and makes it seem as if they've been there for years. Highly recommend.

I got to Russell House Tavern around 5:30 pm on a Thursday, as I entered to see if my friends were there yet the hostess gave me a warm greeting. She suggested that since my party wasn't there just yet that  I could be seated without them or I could take a seat at the bar.
