So I bellied up to the bar where I was promptly greeted by the bartender with a menu. I decided to try the Pinot Blanc on tap (admittedly mostly for the novelty of wine on tap). I know little about wine other than what tastes good to me, so I won't pretend to but I will say I liked this wine. The upstairs bar area was mostly full without being packed. There seems to be plenty of room on the first floor, but I can imagine that when it's busy in there it's sometimes hard to navigate through to get to the basement. 

Once my friends arrived we were seated right away. Our waiter was eccentric but very friendly. He was quick to offer suggestions, though some of his "help" wasn't really helpful. 

I had done my research prior to arriving- browsed the menu on their blog, read the Yelp reviews, read the local media reviews, and local foodie bloggers. I pretty much knew what I wanted before we even arrived. I ordered the Crab Cakes (appetizer portion - $10), Short Rib Wellington ($10), and the already infamous Crispy Soft Poached Chip-In Farm Egg ($7). Our waiter even asked how I'd like my 3 choices to come out; all at once, as their ready, or some other combination. I asked his suggestion and so we decided I'd have the Crab Cake as an appetizer and the other two plates would come with my dining companions' entrees. 

The Crab Cake was good but certainly not the standout dish of the night; served with a sweet pickle tartar and an apple slaw-like salad. The sweet pickle tartar was a great compliment to the crab cakes.

When my remaining two dishes arrived, I was so excited for and curious about this egg I'd heard so much about that I decided to eat that first. It looked good; still in an near perfect egg shape sitting on a nest that included toasted brioche and pancetta. The melding of flavors in my mouth was so good. Even deep fried the combination is light tasting with just enough crispiness and plenty of flavor. I now see why this has been the most talked about item on the menu. 

For me however the real standout of the night was the Short Rib Wellington. This dish was served in a small cast iron bowl. The chunks of braised short ribs were so tender they just about melted in my mouth, full of flavor. Along with the beef was small chunks of braised apple and mushrooms; the apple gave an almost sweet after taste that I think really positively contributed to the flavors in this dish. And to top it all off, there was a crispy, flaky puffed pastry sitting on top. I don't think I could eat more than this "small plate" of the Short Rib Wellington since it was so flavorful, but so long as it's on the menu I'll definitively order it again.

Throughout the meal our waiter was attentive, checking back to see how I liked the egg and to see if we needed more drinks or dessert. 

It's not an inexpensive restaurant but it certainly falls in the affordable mid-range category. For 3 meals and 3 alcoholic beverages our total bill came for $84. 

I can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu.

I want to give them a 3.5 and share 3 separate experiences with you. The first time we went, I just had a cocktail (the Always Sunny) and loved it. I didn't eat, but my gf got the crisp-in poached egg and raved about it.  We went back for a date night and I got the always sunny again and the steak frites. my steak frites were bomb. the lady got a bunch of small plates so she could try lots of stuff. she got the poached egg again and then some oysters, fried oysters, and some meat thing i cannot remember. and she seemed to love all of it. 

we went back last night and i tried this drink--the cure-all fizz--and was really excited because it was supposed to be a blend of rhubarb infused gin and strawberry. it was really light and refreshing but overall pretty bland. so i went back to the always sunny, which i love. this time, the gf and i shared an assortment of plates. the crispy poached crisp-in egg was bomb. the pigs head with a soft poached egg was bomb. and we should have stuck to the egg dishes because they do them right. but we felt weird ordering 4 different poached egg dishes so we got the mascarpone and strawberry burrata and the special daily terrine. both were bleh. the burrata was completely bland and they had warmed the mascarpone so it was almost eggy in consistency. it just wasn't for me. and the terrine was a more classic terrine so it was basically cold jellied mixed meat. i have had some more modern updated terrines recently and realized that the more classic version probably isn't for me.  but the things we liked, we loved!

I have to say for the first time the Yelp reviews worked for me. I guess you just have to go with a place that has more than a handful of reviews. ;-) 

Service was good, but probably because we went on a low-key Monday night. Drinks delectable. Food savory, especially the small plate of the crispy poach egg. I wish two had come out rather than the one we shared. The amount of food for the regular size meals were generous, I couldn't finish mine. 

Of all the gastropubs I've been to, this one definitely made a memorable impression. I would highly recommend it if visiting the Boston/Cambridge area.

I have been trying for ages to get to this place, you'd think that it was in another state...but sadly, for us people with toddlers, it might as well be...I was FINALLY able to meet a friend for lunch after a business trip, and was so excited to be "a hipster", even if it was only for a couple hours (and only in my mouth, sadly my business attire gave me away). 

Started lunch with a Moscow Mule - now that's how you start a Friday Lunch! Super delicious and wickedly potent, it was exactly what I needed to bring myself down from my hectic traveling schedule...so much so that I had two - and then had to walk around Harvard Square for two hours before I was capable of driving home :) 

Had the egg salad sandwich special, with sardines. I know I lost half the crowd, but for the other half - it was yummy. Very comforting yet sophisticated all at the same time. 

We ended the meal with a shared gingerbread cake with butter cream frosting and it was the perfect way to end the meal, great flavor, not to sweet and left a nice taste in the mouth. 

Can't wait to try RHT for dinner, that is when my children are capable of watching themselves!

If I were to ONLY rate this place after 11pm I would give it 5 stars purely for the osyters. My friends and I drank and were super tired and lazy and STILL managed to get to russells for those oysters. 

Now, if I were to rate this place BEFORE 11pm I would give it 3 stars. The food I have got to say is pretty tasty but a little over priced. Also, there service is sub-par. We walked in as a group of 9 and they seat us at a larger table with stools. Now, I came here in March when it was still pretty darn cold. When we got inside and of course I was going to take off my huge jacket, but where to put it... There were no coat racks, no place to put your scarf, or your purse for that matter. I had to hold everything on my lap. And as waitresses and waiters passed me they kept bumping into my back because there was no room. And even though it was winter for some reason the ac was on! And it was blowing right in my face! So luckily the no coat rack wasn't too much of a problem because I needed to keep my jacket on! 

I'd go back but only after 11pm. OYSTERS!

I came here for a working lunch and left hungry. 

The restaurant itself is very well appointed and interesting to look at. The ambiance certainly was the best part of the experience. This place is also much larger than it looks. The expansive basement ha

Perhaps it's just being home and realizing that I am unaccustomed to actual service in the bubble known as LA. When my  drinks buddy asked for a beer menu-as if the menus we had with 50+ beers suggested something of inadequacy-was met with an offhand "I'll get you the real beer menu" from the server I was shocked and confused. 

Where were we Toto? What fields of Elysium have we stumbled upon where the beers are reasonable and the selection vast?!? 

Late night 50% off oysters. Brilliantly paired with a wheat beer then followed by the Hell or Highwatermelon.

Rock star service, incredible selection of craft beers. I weep at the thought of leaving this all behind. I daresay I have found my new favorite bar.

I reviewed this place way back when for an event and promised I would re-review once I had a proper meal (just to ensure that the 5 star rating I gave them was worth it).. and I'm happy to report that Russell House Tavern did not disappoint. 

I love everything about this place. The atmosphere is lively, cool, and spacious (You wouldn't think so based on the outside), and the service is spot on. Our waiter was super friendly, and even though it was pretty packed she was really perfect. 

The food is on a whole other level. The menu is what you would see at a 5 star fancy shmancy restaurant, but somehow, the entrees are all under 25 bucks. Plus, they have a great selection of small plates and appetizers to choose from if you're not super hungry (my fav- the beef short rib wellington). 

Everyone should go here and enjoy this restaurant. It is, in my opinion, the best new restaurant in the city. I am definitely coming back.

So because it's in Harvard Square, I kind of assumed that RHT would be overpriced and subpar, but I have been so pleasantly surprised by the tastiness it consistently delivers to my tastebuds.

Large enough menu that you can be healthy or a fat ass -- I've hit up a few of the salads, all of which are delightful (though none are big enough for an entree if you  can eat an endless amnt of veg, as I can). The oysters were fresh and perfectly briny --  a lot more impressive than I was expecting -- though a few of my ladyfriends vetoed the accompanying sweet pickle mignonette, I was totally on board (they also come w/ banging Old Bay cocktail sauce.

Although I can't speak from personal noshing experience, apparently the secret burger is stuff of which dreams are made -- tonight it had not only a patty but some other meat stuff on top (?pork belly? short rib? brisket?) -- idk, but it was hoovered in minutes -- and the fries were crisp and thoroughly appreciated -- before I forget, the side of brussels is AWESOMMMME. Get them even if you aren't into cruciferous veg. The pizzas I've had are too cheesy for my lactard tum, but if you're into dairy, then they aren't a bad way to get your daily intake of carbs, sodium, and calcium. 

Din usually runs abt $30-40/pp, depending on the cocktail sitch -- oh, the beer and wine list is solid and fairly reasonable. Gets loud, but not too rowdy, or perhaps the wild ones see my ice bitch stare and retreat, who knows -- regardless, I don't know that I'd take a big group and expect to hear everyone at the table, but conversation is certainly possible. Overall, worth a visit.

I'm not going to lie...I hate Cambridge and their establishments. Any time I try to go out to eat it's an hour and a half wait. I don't care how good the food is, after I've waited for an hour and a half I can't enjoy it. 

Russell House Tavern right off the bat gets an extra star because we only waited for 15 minutes. I didn't think that was possible in Cambridge.

The only thing I had here was the pork sandwich off the brunch menu and that definitely earns the establishment another 3 stars. Tender pork, apples, crispy fried onions...amazing combination! They also let you substitute a salad for fries without even having to ask. 

This place is definitely worth checking out!

Restaurants like these are the reason I pine to live in a big city again.
Inventive, bold and always interesting, this place serves up a variety of atmospheres along with a substantial and diverse number of tastes and liquids.
The small plates are the stars for me - especially the really interesting items like the Crispy Pig's Head Cake and Lamb Belly Toast. Kudos as well to some well executed pizzas, especially the Pancetta, Brussel sprout and Marscapone version.
Add some salads and a dozen or so freshly plucked oysters, along with numerous libations and settle in!
This place was such a highlight during our last visit that we had to double back to Harvard Square the morning of the flight just to enjoy the brunch fare. And, it did not disappoint, especially the Anti-benedict and the Nutella Stuffed French Toast.
Best spot on Harvard Square by a mile.

3.5 stars -

Russell House had been in my bookmarks for far too long so I finally forced my boyfriend to go with me. It's a cute place for a date -- dark and cozy, lots of space between tables, polite waitstaff. They have a nice outdoor patio that I would have liked to sit at if it was warmer out.

They had a great drink menu but I decided to pass. We ordered a bunch of Island Creek oysters to start. I'm a huge fan of Island Creeks but for some reason these just weren't up to par and they were a bit gritty.

There were some really interesting items on the menu and I'd like to go back and try some, but for some reason we just weren't feeling like experimenting. I decided to order the local leaf salad (walnuts, dried figs, mustard-cider vinaigrette) and the cotechino sausage and ricotta pizza. The salad was a bit dry but the pizza was delicious! Everything was made in house and you could tell. It was all very fresh and I was happy to bring about half home as leftovers.

I love this place! I have been there about 5 times and every time the service has been great, the food a cut above (I adore the deviled eggs), and the environment is romantic outside and very hip inside. It's great for a date night, a night out with friends and it's child friendly. I'll definitely be back many times to come and recommend it highly!

Kinda love this place. They have an upstairs bar and dining area as well as a downstairs. It's best to make reservations if you want a table because the wait can be pretty long. That being said, I don't really mind waiting because they have SUPER delicious cocktails! The drinks are probably my favorite part of my visits here. Whether it's spicy good morning Bloody Mary with shrimp and homemade mix or a muddled cocktail shaken to perfection with fresh herbs, you CANNOT go wrong. 

The food is actually really good here. Besides the standard lunch/dinner menu they have a tavern menu, brunch menu and raw bar menu. If you are looking for a late night meal you are in luck because they serve till 12am Mon-Thurs. Weekends till 1am. 

They have a delicious crab cake appetizer that I have ordered upon every visit. They also have very flavorful pizzas if you are looking for a quick bite at the bar. Entree portions are very large here so you can always box it up and take it home for a second meal. 

I really dig the vibe of this place. It's usually pretty packed with mid 20s to late 30s peeps on weekend nights. It's also pretty loud downstairs but between the great drinks and food it would be an excellent place to meet friends and socialize. Right by the Red Line for easy access. 

The drinks are on the pricey side but the food prices are on point for quality and portion size.

I want to give Russell House Tavern two more stars. I really do. I like the interior and location. Harvard Square needs a good gastropub. I like the drink selection and menu. So I will make a deal with you, Russell House Tavern. I will give you one more s

Classy, upscale bar in Harvard Square. 

Not too expensive, I describe it as new york yuppie bar meets boston. 
Great for dinner or just camping out at the bar. 

Beer selection is amazing, no "filler" beers on tap - no coors, bud, not even guiness or Sam
Get drunk like a college loser here and enjoy the Russel in someone else's bushes !!!

Last time I was here it was Z Square.  We walked in yesterday and thought the new place looked great.  We got great seats at the bar and were immediately served drinks by a very friendly bartender.  We were thinking this would immediately become a regular place to go.  Unfortunately, the friendly bartender was replaced and things went downhill quickly.  

The new bartender introduced himself to another group at the bar.  I believe he said his name was Aaron and that he was the bar manager.  He was probably the rudest, most condescending bartender I've ever encountered.  Watching him interact with the staff was painful and the way he treated customers was just as bad.  We still loved the place, so decided we would stay for another drink.  Unfortunately, my empty pint glass remained empty for 15 minutes, even though he was standing right in front of us, but yet chose to ignore us.  It is very awkward being ignored when you're actually sitting right at the bar in the middle of the afternoon with the person ignoring you about 4 feet away.  We finally gave up and just left.  The team down at Grafton Street was a 180 from this experience - they were great.  

If the original bartender stayed, this is easily 4 stars.  If grading solely on the 2nd bartender, this is a 0 or 1 star place.  I will definitely go in again, but only after checking to see who is working.

My husband and I walked in for a quick bite before catching a movie. We had only 45 minutes so we thought a nice restaurant was out of question, so we decided to give Russell House a shot - our expectation was to get something simple to eat and a beer. We checked in with the hostess and told her about our time restriction - she assured us we had plenty of time and quickly got us a nice table by the window. What a surprise when we saw the menu - so many interesting options! We settled for a few small plates to share: Serrano Ham with Honey Torched Manchego, Pork Rilette with Apple, Torched Tuna and a Little Leaf Salad with Figs and Walnuts.

Everything came out pretty quickly and the service was great - however we did let our server know that we had to catch a movie.

And the food was great! Very interesting flavor combinations, very competently prepared, and served without any fuss. My husband was pretty happy with the beer selection, and I had a glass of Wineport Rivers rose wine on tap (has anyone ever heard of wine on tap?).  

So we were out of the door with 10 minutes to spare, with a budget friendly tab, and very happy stomachs. I can't wait to go back and try something else!

My cousin and I stopped by for lunch. She ordered grilled chicken sandwich w/ green salsa and I had a burger w/ beef and bacon. And That's the best burger ive ever had. Better than shake shack. 

Take one star off cos it was a loooooong wait after we placed our order.

I went to Russell House the other night for a late dinner and drinks and in terms of a dining and drinking experience, I was happy with the choice to go there. The Dirty Ceasar salad was a very tasty spin on the traditional ceasar and the beer selection was great. 

The reason I'm giving RHT 2.5 stars instead of 3 or 4 is because like many consumers these days, I'm trying my best to base my restaurant choices on how 'green' or environmentally friendly the establishment is. 
I would encourage any restaurant that is as popular and highly frequented as the Russel House Tavern to take steps, if it hasn't already, to become Green Certified. Any restaurant who has can testify to the success of doing so. 

I look forward to coming back, hopefully seeing the RHT a little bit 'greener'!

Ah, small plates. My favorites, by far, are the Crispy Soft Poached Chip-In Farm Egg (Pecorino Aioli, Toasted Brioche, House Pancetta) and the Crispy Pigs Head Cake (Soft Poached Egg, Ginger-Maple Aioli). Next time, I'll have 2 of each and call it my dinner. Both are so delicious and really different. 

My not so favorites were the Mascarpone Filled Burrata (Local Strawberry Panzanella, Basil, Chiles) and the House-Made Terrine. I personally wasn't feeling the mascarpone- the texture with the combination of strawberries, etc. was weird. It was a not so great paste.The terrine wasn't very flavorful. I don't recall what it was as it changes often but it was a very traditional terrine which would have been ok if Strip T's Terrine didn't blow it out of the water. 

On another note: The outdoor seating is great if you're able to get one. Even if my table wobbled.

I'd heard Russell House was big, so when a group of 6 friends and I decided to head there on a Wednesday night, I assumed we wouldn't need a reservation.  We arrived, went to check with the hostesses, and were met with dirty "can you believe these people just showed up?" looks.  Nevertheless, they put our names down for a table and told us to wait 15 minutes.  No prob, aside from the attitude, our bad.

Except 15 minutes was closer to 30, and when we were finally seated downstairs, it was apparent that the place was virtually empty.  What took 30 minutes, exactly?

Anyway, once seated, we were greeted cheerfully by our server, who I'm happy to say was kind and attentive throughout the meal.  But more on her in a minute.

As for the food, I've got two thoughts: one is that the menu is overpriced, but since I haven't tasted most of it, I'll demur.  The food we had, however, was delicious -- various pizzas and the fries, a pasta dish...all lovely.

Now, here's where I'm upset...I checked my bank account today and was surprised to see that I was charged for our entire meal, as opposed to the portion that I signed an authorization for.  We had split the bill onto two cards, something that most waitstaff can handle, but apparently not our waitress.  I called, left a message for the general manager, and 4 hours later had to call back because I still hadn't heard.  He admitted her mistake and said it was only a hold, and apologized profusely, but I'm still annoyed.  I've waitressed, and I really just don't see what's so hard about getting it right the first damn time.

What a great restaurant! Food is creative and delicious. Atmosphere is quite comfortable. A great crowd. The best of all was their ambassador/ server Steve Bowman. He elevated the whole experience. 
We are relatively well travelled restaurant go-ers, and this is as good as it gets! Of note, we had been there once before for brunch. Really delicious
We have been coming to Harvard Square for over 25 yrs, and this is the best dining experience we have encountered.

this place's vibe is great, the drinks are well-mixed, and the food was delicious. for starter i had Salt & Pepper Shrimp, which was like high-end popcorn shrimp. for entree i had Ozark Heritage Pork Trio, which was very savory (in particular the pork bel

I don't drink, so I wouldn't be able to comment on the quality of alcohol offered, but the food was surprisingly YUM!!  From first look, I thought a good bowl of baked nuts + greasy bar food were all they offered, however I was pleasantly surprised to find out that they had a fully functional restaurant downstairs.  And get this...the kitchen is open till 1am!!!  I ordered the Chicken Waldorf sandwich on multigrain brioche....GET IT!  It's phenomenal!  Their appetizers were pretty good as well: spinach and cheese with homemade bread...yummm.  Decent prices, and surprisingly good food at 12am...what more do you want :)  p.s the ambiance is pretty well maintained as well.  If you're here for a meal, I highly recommend you ask for downstairs seating rather than the kinda run down upstairs  :) Bon Apetite!!
I went back again, and was more impressed.  It's in a great location and has good food.  The drinks are good and has a nice bar area, I'll up my stars to 4.

We had a large group for a weekday holiday lunch and had a reservation. Everyone arrived on time. It took nearly 30 minutes for the waiter to take our order. Over an hour to get our food. The order was not complicated - salads and sandwiches. The server was flustered and got no help from management until someone at our table stepped in. A complimentary bread basket arrived minutes before the food. People who ordered sandwiches ended up with dry, over-toasted (stale) bread. No apologies by anyone. We were informed the manager "paid" for our drinks when the waiter dropped our bill - a few iced teas and coffees.  I guess that was the apology. They seemed unprepared for our group even though we had reservations. The food was o.k. The service terrible.

like it. awesome layout. the downstairs bar is great...very spacious and good for any kind of party; big groups, dates, parents in town...

sat at the bar (my thing to do these days) - they have a decent selection of beer and wine and a good looking cocktail menu. i wanted to try a LOT of the menu. Portions are small and delicious. the fried oysters are great. the brussel sprouts, divine honey seared goodness. the burratta was creamy and delicate. fries were perfect. 

good place to sample apps and small plates and spend the whole night talking and being comfortable. a little pricy but it's that kind of gastropub. 

good looking people go here. it's a big market for douchy-people unfortunately.

I wrote a little teaser on our Facebook page a couple days ago mentioning that I had a top-5 Boston burger. I might have jumped the gun a tad, and after thinking it over a few days, I'm not sure it's better than the one's ahead of it. Most of the burgers have received very mediocre scores from yours truly, but there are some standouts, and while my initial instinct was to go over the top, I kind of overlooked some past favorites. Which isn't to say the burger at Russell House isn't great, it is, but do I like it as much as Toro, Miracle of Science or Flat Patties? Close, but no cigar. I don't hand out high remarks easily, the top burgers have earned their place, in my opinion, and this is absolutely one burger I will be back for. Located right in the heart of Harvard Square in a stunning space, to me, this is what pub food and atmosphere is supposed to be about. It's modern, clean, and the menu is downright enticing, with something for everyone. The burger is priced at a very reasonable $10, served on a griddled English Muffin, with charcoal onions, bacon, and cheddar. I was pretty nervous about the English Muffin, which I don't normally enjoy and was worried it might be too thin for a burger. But, much to my delight, it actually holds up fairly well, a little hard to handle in spots (ie too hot in the middle because it's so thin) but griddling helps it form a crust which gives it much needed structure. The meat has good flavor, is noticeably beefy, but the bacon is a real afterthought, almost undetectable. And that beef, while tasty, is very overcooked in too many spots, as long as it's flavorful I'm happy, but overcooked meat dries out, and this burger just had too many overcooked spots. The homemade aioli was wonderful, a perfect foil to both the fries and the burger, and despite having only a handful of ingredients, there is a ton of flavor from start to finish. Also worth mentioning was the amount of char on the burger, I like some char, but for me, too many of the components (all of them really) had that charred flavor, to the point where things become bitter and consequently one note.The Russell House Tavern has a lot of things going for it, great location, great burgers and affordability, everything you could ask for in a casual restaurant. It may not be the best burger in Boston, but it's certainly right up there.

I hear over and over how Russell House Tavern is supposedly this amazing restaurant with wonderful service - but I have yet to experience this.

I went to breakfast several weeks ago at RHT - I found the service to be fine, but nothing fantastic.  My breakfast (breakfast pizza) was, again, fine but nothing special (and certainly not worth the price).  The rest of my group really enjoyed the meal, so I assumed I had just made a poor choice for my meal.

My parents were visiting this past weekend so my fiance and I decided to take them to brunch at Russell House Tavern.  The restaurant was almost totally empty, but that didn't stop the waitress from ignoring us and flirting with the other hipster employees while we waited for drinks, to order and to pay.  When our food was brought out, our toast was cold and stale.  We asked for new toast and were given luke-warm, yet still stale toast.  We had to ask four times for butter.  We had to literally walk over to her and interrupt her flirting in order to get a water refill.  On top of that, the food was nothing great.  I, nor the rest of my family, are very hard to please when it comes to food or service - but this completely unacceptable.

It will be a while before I go back to Russell House Tavern.

Gastropub, n. Brit. "A public house which specializes in serving high-quality food." See, Russell House Tavern.

It really is the definition of what a gastropub should be.  The fine selection of local brews, an impressive Scotch list, including Edradour (one of my favorites) along with excellent, and I mean excellent food, and prompt friendly service.

Started off the meal right with a Steak Tartar with Quail Egg and a Cassoulet.  The steak tartar melted in my mouth and the cassoulet, was a perfect medley of beans and meat and just darn right delicious.  The main dish, Ozark Heritage Pork Trio, was very well seasoned and prepared, consisting of the pork belly, shoulder and loin.  Served with creamy grits which balanced the salty meat taste nicely.  We also ordered three sides, thyme carrots, creamy spinach and pommes frittes all of which were delicious.  

My only regret was not having enough room to try the dessert, which I hope to have the opportunity to, the next time I am back in one of my favorite cities.

I came back for Brunch. Had the sausage and gravy on biscuit with a side of potatoes. Still good. The breakfast pizza my sister had was shared with Mum and they enjoyed it. Its very good.

Nothing to complain about...darn.

Russell House has become our go-to place for beer and good hearty fare at the end of a hard working week. Nothing tastes better than that first bite of crab cake with apple slaw and creamy dressing (make sure you get the appetizer portion with two crabcakes - $12 not the small plate with one - $8) chased down with cold draft beer. Although the steak and frites ($24) are a good following act. The puff pastry covered beef wellington ($10) is also tasty as is their duck confit ($22). We have also just had a side of their fries ($6) while sipping beers at the bar mid week. Their house-made mayo is a delicious accompaniment. And their wine on tap for $5 a glass is quite a bargain, although I do wish they'd get a red beside the pinot noir rose, which is rather bland. The charcuterie board is also definitely worth a try. Finally a place we can visit repeatedly without getting bored or tired!
Russell House has a nice, niche food menu. What they have, they do well. For drinks; Russell House sports a good beer and wine list.

There was a lot of rave about this place.. and  I was pretty stoked to finally try it.  

Pros:
-Lots of cocktails, beers, and a long wine list-- if you like drinks, this place will satisfy.
-huuuuuge lunch plates. you'll definitely be getting your money's worth
-wonderful atmosphere.  Love all the tiling, old school bar style look upstairs with the more classic dining room downstairs.

Cons:
-tuna sashimi.. tasted fishy.. maybe i'm biased b/c i work at legal sea foods, but still.. not acceptable
-not a an extensive menu, foodwise

Maybe i ordered the wrong things.. and would be willing to try again.. but as nice as Russel House Tavern is.. it should never disappoint.

Russell House! I love what you do. You deliver on so much for a girl on a budget who appreciates a good cocktail and something to snack on. Those fries -- addictive! The burger -- one of my favorites in the area! I love that you have the Left Hand Milk Stout on tap, and offer a side of sauteed veggies to keep it healthy when you're nibbling. Every brunch dish I've had has been absolutely fantastic. Try the EBLT. 

I know, I know, I can't really know what you're capable of if I'm too cheap to pony up for the 20$+ entrees, but forgive me, I'm young and if I'm going to pay that much for an entree, it's probably going to be somewhere a little more upscale. Plus if you could iron out the wrinkles of awkward service, that would be really great, thx, coz maybe it's the syntax or something, but it sometimes feels just a little bit off. But thank you for being there: the go-to place to meet up, a kick ass brunch destination and an easy late-night drinks place.

Last night our server rocked and helped up make small plate selections that were right on.  Good wine.  Good vibe.  Have been for brunch, lunch and dinner.  I recommend downstairs if it's cold out.  Distinctly different feels upstairs and down so choose the mood that works for you.  I ran into several people I know while there so the crowd was right on!  ;=)  Harvard Square needed a place like RHT.
Fantastic food, loved the menu and service. Decoration is a little pretentious.

This is my go to brunch location.  The food, while simple (think your basic ham and eggs), are superbly prepared.  Most remarkably, they've never overcooked my eggs (I like them runny). 

I've also been for dinner and sampled their pizza - nice thin crusts with flavorful cheese.  They also take the time to brush the crust (with olive oil?).  One of the best pizzas in town.

The tables are always clean and well dressed.  Servers always seem to be at hand when you need them, but don't hover (mark of a well trained staff).

Made reservations here on a Friday afternoon for that night & so glad we did. 
The outside & both levels inside were packed. 
The decor is dark wood homey feeling with really cool old filament light bulbs. The menu is amazing & unexpected on a college campus, then again it is Harvard darling!
5 star ambiance
4 star food
4 star service

Next time I'm in Cambridge I'm coming back here!

Drinks and Food = Amazing. I visited this restaurant for the first time Saturday night and was extremely impressed and satisfied. I had friends in from NYC that are "food snobs", so I was a bit worried. This place did not disappoint! Also, the menu is very fairly priced. We did have to wait for our reservation for about 10 min, but no big deal.

The drinks were creative, unique and delicious! Felt a bit like we were in a speakeasy... The waiter was very helpful with suggestions as well. 

The food, oh the food.... I can't wait to go back! They have a wonderful menu from small plates and apps, to entrees. We started with the beef tartare, short rib wellington and bone marrow. The tartare was phenomenal, great flavor and portion. But the bone marrow (my first time having it) was my fav! My friend and I both had the duck confit (large portion, and perfectly cooked). It came with a fig and pork belly side. My only complain is I wish the pork belly was separate and crispy. Our other friend had the pork trio - well, he didn't even let us try it, so I'm assuming it was good :)

My friends were happy and impressed with everything, and so was I. I will surely  be back....many times!

Nice place, fast service (if a little brisk/abrupt), chic but not fancy atmosphere.  We were seated in the dining area downstairs, which was cozy and comfortable.  I think I would have liked sitting at the bar more...our table was VERY close to the ones around us.  I felt like I was dining with strangers.

Herbed gnocchi with lamb and crispy poached egg- good lamb & cushy gnocchi but the overhyped poached egg, while tasty, is not the to-die-for item that the other Yelpers raved about.  "Butchers Choice" pizza (lamb, fontina cheese & mushroom) was VERY good with a crispy thin crust and flavorful toppings with herbs.  Even though the menu was a bit limited (lots of salads, but limited on other items), the beer and cocktail list is very extensive.

At the end of the meal, we got comment cards to let the restaurant know what they could improve on...I wonder if they take any of that into consideration.

Went here on a Wednesday evening with a work friend before heading home. The upstairs bar was full so we went downstairs. The bartenders (3) took some time to pay attention to us and then we had to listen to one bartender train a newbee who was sitting across the bar from him and 2 seats from us. From an educational standpoint, the bartender fails as a trainer. Boring and too much information at once and he asked the typical question which no student ever answers honestly,"Do you have any questions?" Of course his glazed-eyed student didn't have any. 
A few beers the pub offers are interesting. I had the IPA on tap. My colleague had Merlot. She ordered the kale salad which was outstanding. I wish I had ordered that but I like variety and ordered the other green salad-which was fine-just not as awesome as the kale. I also ordered the fois gras which was ruined by the lamphroag scotch-too strong and peety-but my bad since I didn't ask about lamphroag before ordering. A fine, hip joint for the young Harvard crowd but I found the bartender/servers a bit snotty for this 50 year old.

As other Yelpers have noted, this place is easy to miss, but once you enter, the ambience, smells, and feel totally take you in.

I had the Crispy Pigs Head Parmigiana and the Housemade Terrine, both excellent and DEFINITELY not for the vegetarian of heart. My friend had the Marrow Bone and something else- both of us were extremely content. For dessert, we had the chocolate bomb with pomegranate syrup. The prices are reasonable, and the portions are perfectly sized, so you leave feeling satiated but not stuffed.

What REALLY made the night was our amazing waiter, Steve. He was impeccably courteous, and his descriptions of food were to die for. In the end, we let him decide our dessert for us because he had described all of them down to the last crumb with his immense vocabulary and clear gusto for food. Thank you, Steve- honestly, no waiter will ever live up to this man.

Let's call a spade a spade. This is quality standard gastropub - probably what wikipedia could easily advertise as a example of gastropub but IT WAS NOTHING SPECIAL.

Good food (i had the chicken. my friends had the scallops) with very reasonable portions at an average price. The wine selection was quality but nothing super amazing. The host was friendly, but nothing too exciting to advertise.

Essentially, this is the stuff you would see in a romantic comedy with Scarlett Johanson. Delightful.. but nothing to memorable.

Great food for a great price. I always go to Russell house for the bone marrow and goat cheese and fig pizza which are amazing! you can rarely find a good restaurant in the square where you can pay $25 all in for a fantastic meal.

Definitely one of my go tos! Best part is they even have round tables on the lower floor for groups of six, making it perfect to catch up!

Great staff and affordable prices for a supper classy place.

The burger is great, the oyster bar pretty decent, and the atmosphere downstairs will set your mood to do Great Things with your evening!

I have been here two times for brunch...
Awesome food and great service

Breakfast pizza was very good just very greasy.
piggly wiggly bloody mary with bacon.. yummy
traditional mimosa
and my boyfriend has the benedict and he said it was delicious!

Great place for brunch... havent tried dinner there yet.
Best dinner in Harvard Sq. if you don't mind a loud environment. Service is good. I only wish it wasn't so packed all the time!
Great drinks!!!  The bar tenders will make you anything and they have the best ingredients.  Everything I've had here was perfection.

This review is nearly a year in the making...three lunches and four dinners...if that isn't the definition of a balanced restaurant review, what is ?  The chef is talented, the bartenders (upstairs) are masters of crafting unusual cocktails, the three spaces are comfortable  ( street level lounge, outside patio, large bar and dining room downstairs)...but the waitstaff is, at best, barely acceptable. The food and drink continually bring me back, only to have the waitstaff damage the dining experience. I have not returned since my last dinner in April...with three industry people from Dallas... an embarrassing fiasco because of the incompetence of the nevertheless chipper waitress...who repeatedly informed us that she was part of the opening staff. Courses not cleared..food runners arrive, juggle plates, change dishes...we flag down manager for SILVERWARE...then for more wine...then for missing dishes...only to have the waitress zoom by, gush, smile, and leave...drugs much ? So why do I return ?  The Cowboy ribeye with bone marrow butter, the great and unusual steak tartar...and the lamb shank soup...a wintry item only available twice, but one of my favorite dining experiences. Also, the street level mixologists are a marvel. Why can management not hire a good waitstaff?....really, I WANT to return.

Max from Cambridge

The place is a staple in our rotation. We've been here mostly for Saturday night drinks and dinners, but have stopped by recently for brunch which was equally as awesome. We always get the same waitress, who is super friendly and always available to get n

Russell House is a decent brewpub with a really interesting brunch menu. Prices aren't too bad and the food is good. The service isn't the greatest, but it's not so bad as to be detrimental to the experience.

I rate the burger a solid B, with positives going to the english muffin and the toppings, and negatives for being slightly overcooked and a surprising lack of flavor in the meat.

Although I didn't get to try it, they have an "anti-Benedict" on the menu that comes with poached eggs that are dipped in breadcrumbs and then flash-fried!

Beefy meal. Steak tartare was spiced nicely and the meat was fresh and melt in your mouth textured. Got my steak frites rare, great pink center. Red wine glaze was sweet and savory. Creamy, buttery garlic aioli and stellar fries. Potential to be a five star for me one day.

This place is a great addition to Harvard Square.  I was a little wary of the "posh pub" concept, but it totally works.  Russell House Tavern has an excellent and diverse wine list and the pinot blanc on tap is delicious and a great deal at $5 a glass.  

Food-wise, they have both small plates, apps, and entrees.  I sat at the bar and got the steak tartare small plate (smaller than the appetizer portion) and a side of fries.  Everything was tasty.  I can't wait to go back and try more.  The bartender was also very friendly.

We recently visited for Father's Day Brunch. Although the food is excellent, the service was far bellow average. I believe they were probably just not prepared to handle the large parties they had in that day. After waiting and waiting, even just to pay, I spoke with Andrew, the manager. He listened and was very thoughtful. I appreciated that. 

I would visit again for the food, but probably not with a large group again.
Meh. Service was somewhat lackluster and the food left much to be desired. The fried oysters were tiny and dry - and the Jonah crab claws butchered with half the meat missing.

I've been to Russell House a couple of times just for drinks, but decided to try them out for dinner recently.  I was a little hesitant -- being a vegetarian -- because RHT seems pretty meat-centric, but everything was sooooo good!  I had the Andria pizza and it was awesome!  Figs and burratta.....yum :)   I also tried the poached egg without the bacon on the plate....yum :)

On top of the food being awesome, we had great service.  I used to be a server back in college, so I'm pretty picky in what I expect from certain kinds of restaurants.  The atmosphere of this place is like a cross between fine dining and a pub -- which is cool and just the type of place that I like -- and our server was laid back and fun, but very professional and knowledgeable at the same time.  

I will definitely be going back!

Great food, excellent people. 

If you are 2 and if its busy in there then you might have to share a long table with other people but its still comfortable. Enjoy there beer collection.
Cheers!

We reserved via open table.  We were about 5 min late but that was okay,  DH and DS had the ribeye steak.  They loved it.  It says 18oz but it did not fill them up.  DD had a cheese pizza and she did not like it.  I had the pork trio and it was good.   We had the special of the day appetizer, which is basically prosciutto, mozzarella cheese and a piece of bread.   Definitely just for 1 person.   3 of us just had soda and one had water.  The sprite was watered down.  I could have complained but didn't bother.  A bit pricey for our weekly dinner.   Especially when you add the parking fee of $13 (that's with validation).

Very disappointed. There might have been some chanterelles in the gratin, because there were some soft filmy bits underneath. On the other hand, they might have been cauliflower or even rabbit placenta for all I could tell. All under a huge mound of stale-ish breadcrumbs. And I swear the honey-roasted Brussels sprouts tasted as if they'd been cooked in coca-cola. Two stars because the waitstaff was friendly and attentive.

We have gone here twice in the past 2 weeks.  We decided to go back for a second dinner here because we loved the food that much!
Food, 4 1/2 stars, absolutely delicious. All the food came out hot and well-timed. A couple of our favorite apps/small plates were: the pig's head, you CANT go wrong getting this! Also the tartare and short rib wellington. Also the pizza we highly recommend. Our main dish: We both got the pork trio. It had a generous portion of meat and was cooked perfectly. The desserts were good, but didn't stack up to the appetizers and entrees.
Service, 4 1/2 stars. Our waiters both times we went were amazing, very well-informed and very conscoius of when we needed refills, when to take plates. Some of the best service we've had. ONE downfall was on our 1st night upon our arrival we had a very rude host, we almost left because of him, but we are glad we decided to stay. 
Atmosphere, 3 1/2 stars, it was a bit basementy but very nice and good lighting. It didn't have that extra punch we like. It falls short when compared to other favorites of ours like Eastern Standard and Gaslight.

Aw man, I hate being that ONE bad review!

*disclaimer* 
I've only eaten here once, so maybe my experience was just an anomaly.

Okay, so here's the story:
Was in the Harvard Sq. area on a Wednesday night looking for somewhere to grab dinner with my boyfriend. We were debating between a few spots, but finally decided on RHT, because we hadn't eaten there before and we wanted to try somewhere new.

Sad to say, I totally regretted our decision.

First off, there was an problem with our IDs -- our waitress actually had to take ours inside to show her manager, explaining there was some sort of "server test" an agency or management was running at the restaurant, and she had to be EXTRA careful to not get in trouble. Weird excuse, huh? I have an under-21 MA-issued license, which was probably confusing to her. I mean, I wouldn't have minded so much if it didn't take 15 minutes for her to come back and say we were good to go, and another 10 minutes for drinks to actually come out. We also waited a whole 'nother 40 minutes for our food to come out, while watching the tables that were seated way after us get their orders first. I mean, if you want to test your servers or whatever, couldn't you do it in a way that doesn't effect your customers?

Secondly, the food was completely hit/miss when it did finally come out to us. We ordered four small plate/appetizer items off the menu. The first two dishes to get to our table were the crispy soft poached egg (miss: it was cold and *not* crispy) and the grilled prime rib knuckles (hit: perfectly seasoned and tender, loved the roasted pumpkin romesco!) After another strange lull in waiting, we got our third dish, citrust and juniper-cured gravlax (miss: epically). Now this was really the final straw: it was completely inedible, so much so that it felt like we were eating pure salt. Our palates were SO overwhelmed that we decided to cancel our final order, which was the beef tartare, and call it a night. Our waitress did take the gravlax off our check, which was appreciated (actually, I'd be very upset if it wasn't...)

At the end of the meal, the GM did come over and acknowledge the food/service was spotty. He explained there was a private event being held in the downstairs space, so restaurant flow was a bit off, and apologized for our terrible experience. He also said he tasted the gravlax and agreed with us, and pulled the item from the menu. I'm glad he came over and spoke to us, but I don't think I'll be going to RHT again. Overall, it was just an incredibly uncomfortable experience with the whole ID ordeal, long wait and the disappointing food.

I came in once for a birthday party.  I came in again this weekend.  Both visits were absolutely awesome.  The service was really fantastic both times; one visit was sitting at the downstairs bar, one seated in the downstairs dining room.  The most recent visit was sitting in the dining room, and it was lovely.

Steve was our server, and he was very nice and soft spoken.  I could hear him as I was sitting closest to him, but my friend sitting further away had a hard time hearing the specials.  I opted to go with the charcuterie plate, and the white wine on tap.  Yep, wine on tap. AND it's delicious and $5.  I was feeling like reigning in the spending, so I opted to go with the wine.  My parters in crime ordered cocktails, which were fantastic.  

The charcuterie plate is pure magic.  I can say with 100% certainty that it's the best plate of meat you can get in Boston.  The plate comes with chicken liver pate, port rillette with delicious duck fat, serrano ham, and  duck bacon.  It comes with an herbed jam, and lots of little toasted buttery crostini.  It was pure magic for $12, and Steve anticipated our needs and brought more crostinis for us before we needed them for smearing our delicious meat fats.

I highly suggest this place if you're wanting something delicious in Harvard Square.   The prices are also beyond reasonable and the portions are very generous.   I also suggest sitting downstairs, as the upstairs can be filled with a younger college crowd, unless that's your thing.

After a few hours of errands in and around Harvard Square, I dragged my fiance to Russell House for brunch, assuring him that yelp said it was good. He wanted to grab a slice from Pinocchio's around the corner, and I now wish I had listened to him.

Pros: option of flat or sparkling water for the table; decent service; fine ambiance. 

Despite his reservations, my fiance enjoyed his Ruben and fries, although he said he was in no hurry to return. My brunch, however, was completely inedible. I ordered "The Pit Master" (a mistake in the first place, I don't know what possessed me to think that yankees could pull off any sort of bbq). It was described, "Hardwood 16 Hour Smoked Brisket scrambled with Three Eggs, Grilled Scallions, Fontina & Roasted Potatoes. Toast." 

Problems: there was no brisket in the dish, only huge cubes of squishy beef fat that I initially mistook for the above mentioned roasted potatoes. So already I'm paying $11 for a dish that doesn't actually contain any meat. In addition, the scallions were raw, not grilled, and I was unable to find any roasted potatoes in the "scramble." The toast, far from being anything interesting, was the plainest, slightly burnt wheat bread imaginable (worse than anything I would purchase from a grocery store for my family). All of that would have been bad enough, but the eggs pushed this dish from unappetizing to inedible. They were so undercooked that completely raw egg was pooling up in the bottom of the skillet the dish was served in, making the bottom of the toast unpleasantly moist. Unfortunately for me, I didn't discover the raw egg until several bites in, and I have a medical condition that precludes me from consuming any type of undercooked/unpasteurized animal products. Needless to say, I've been absolutely sick to my stomach since I left RHT and paid for a lunch I did not remotely enjoy.

I'm sure Russell House serves better dishes than this one, and they seem to be doing some interesting things on their menus, but I doubt I will be returning for more of their "raw" selections...

In the future, I will go with my gut and stick to Pinocchio's.

Burger was OK, it was served on an un-toasted English muffin that took away from the actual burger.

Tried an Oyster.  It was good.  

The worst thing was the plate of Mixed Greens:  it was coated with an excessive amount of Sea Salt.  A sprinkle is fine, but this was just gross.  When I asked the waiter about it, he said "oh, we get that a lot.  The chef thinks this how it should be done, and believes that he knows better.  He doesn't really listen to the feedback...".  Nice, eh???

This place has a great atmosphere.  I'll keep it on my list as a great pub, but eat elsewhere....

Before I begin let me say that I am a (very proudly) born and bred Bostonian that now resides in sunny south Florida. I have lived in Cambridge amongst many other Ma cities. Recently I was "home" and was lucky enough to have my gorgeous GF(brownie pts) with me and wanted to show her how we get down in the bean with some serious grub(that I tell her about ad nauseum) . Rather than taking her to my old haunts I asked a trusted friend to recommend a new place for us both to experience. This is my FIRST Yelp review.

Russell House Tavern is a pretty cool New American gastropub in the space that formerly housed Z Square in historic Harvard sq. The menu created by Executive Chef Michael Scelfo has something for everybody,from a finicky kid(burgers,pizza) to a seasoned foodie(charcuterie,gravlax),and truly has multiple gems on it. I truly enjoyed everything I ate and would've had seconds(if my belly allowed) of each dish. If it wasn't entirely clear so far, I had a bonafide 5 star experience here for sure and would highly recommend it to everyone. I am happy to have popped my "yelp review cherry" on an extremely positive note! 

For starters RHT achieves a style incorporating both modern and traditional american elements very much like it's city and neighborhood. Yet it isn't at all pretentious and has a wonderfully light and energetic ambiance. It occupies 2 levels. Up has a cozy bar(W/friendly funny bartender Vic) and even a little outdoor patio. Down is the main dining room with a lively bar and restrooms. Where the old tenants (Z sq.) couldn't  quite make this space work, RHT  did and it has a hip buzz in the air that the former was aiming for. 

The menu is large but you don't get lost reading it and is very well rounded.Included are , assorted Appetizers,Soups, Salads, Sandwiches, Pizza, Burgers, Raw Bar, Small Plates, Entrees,  and Desserts . 
As far as beverages go, aside from in house filtered flat/sparkling h2o(nice bottles too) and the usual suspects of non alcoholic drinks it boasts an above average and extensive signature cocktail list,has a refreshing exclusively domestic Wine list(many sustainable), plus local and domestic Craft Beer in both draught and bottles. 

Let me tell you what I ate now in no particular order of course(and very briefly explained for lengths sake):Seared Scallops w/Beans & Pork Belly,Oxtail Peirogis,Beef Heart Ravioli,Lamb's Belly Toast,Lobster Sliders,Beef Tongue Meatballs,Crispy Pigs Head Cake,Crsipy Soft Poached Egg w/pancetta,Warm Burrata Slad w/Brussels Sprouts,New England Cheese Board,Carrot Bread...Phew! 
To not bore you with too many more details everything was SPOT on delicious. Standouts where Lamb,Oxtail,Lobster,Beefheart,Pigs Head,& Carrot Bread. 

To sum it all up, Mission Accomplished! We hit the Trifecta, great food/drink in a great atmosphere and had great service too(Kate Penner who was informative,attentive, & charming). All this without being pretentious or stupid expensive. The only downside(omnivores disagree) are extremely limited vegetarian options. 
Oh and l almost forgot to mention they have $1 Oysters 2-5 pm & 11-Close WOW!!!! The cherry on top certainly was the classic hip hop playing. 
Reservation recommended.

p.s. I hear Chef makes a kick-ass chili that isn't available 

Until next time.
R

Stumbled across this place when walking around Cambridge.  We were a little scared to sit down for lunch at Russell House Tavern because it was completely empty at 1pm, but my fellow Yelpers and their rave reviews convinced us to stay.

And we are SO GLAD we did.

The deviled eggs were absolutely delicious--smooth and bursting with flavor.  But the star of the meal was the pork loin sandwich.  This was HANDS DOWN the best sandwich I have ever had in my life.  It had incredibly bold flavors and was stuffed with meat, cheese, and greens.  I'm not usually a fan of pork, but I will crave this sandwich until the next time I get to return to Boston and sink my teeth into it.  

The service was attentive and friendly, and this was overall an extremely satisfying lunch.
Great French Toast w/ Nutella, and really good Egg Benedict.

$6 wine on tap, great cocktails and beer selection.  Gastro-pub decor and friendly staff.  I'm usually intrigued by anything that's not your stereotypical Boston irish or english pub which this did the trick.  

I only give it 3 stars because I don't particularly care for the crowd that gets drawn in on weekend nights, kind of snub and pretentious.  Also too packed to deal.  Perfect for a nice afternoon lunch/drink.

Russell House may be just a tad too classy for me, but I love it.

Oysters abound ($1 after 10 pm, I think), charcuterie rocks, and I've heard the burger is to die for. I came during restaurant week, too, and the portions were ginormous and the service delightful.

Russell House Tavern, you coy little devil, you. 

I've walked past this place dozens of times and haven't tried it out until recently upon the suggestions of my local Yelpers, and it was one of the best meals I've had in awhile. Their poached egg that's

Harvard Square needs more bars IMO.  This space has been a revolving door of restaurants for several years.  I came here with some friends after stops at other bars were either crickets (restaurants with bar areas that were winding down) or were packed (Grendel's Den).  Although a bit shiny and glossy, the bar was pretty lively without being nutso.

We ordered a couple of rounds of drinks and the bartender quickly knocked out our orders and no eye rolling when we paid with separate credit cards.  I did like how the upstairs bar was on street level right where JFK and Mass Ave meet.  There was plenty to look at out the big windows.  The one weird thing was that you can't walk in the door that was meant to be the storefront door - that is an emergency exit.  You have to walk down a quasi alleyway and into what seems to be an office building or something, then enter the bar.  kind of weird, but oh well, the booze was good.

Upgrading a star in honor of excellent servers and hostesses. 

Last visit we had a delicious dirty ceasar, steak frites, froie gras, and fried oysters.  It was a salty, fatty meal - just what the doctor ordered.

I also discovered that I can request a wine glass if I want one (thank you manager for private messaging me).

Wine glass + upstairs table by window = happy me.

I travel a lot, and I usually try to sample to highly-Yelped spots near where I am.  I almost never go back to a place twice, but the Russell House Tavern warranted a second trip.  Both visits were really impressive. 

I had a delicious pumpkin and corn pizza and a couple well-recommended local beers on one visit.  Second visit was a light, generous, and tasty salad with an Ali's Ideal pizza -- my first experience with brussels sprouts on a pie, and a great one at that.  The staff were attentive, knowledgeable, and genuinely interested that we have a good meal.  I wish this restaurant was in MY town, but Cambridge residents and visitors are blessed to have this gem in a neighborhood dominated (understandably) by college-kid-focused spots.

Russell House Tavern is a nice balance between fancy-pants and comfortable, at least for getting a drink and a snack. They have a good beer and wine selection and an interesting list of dishes. My husband and I split the spinach and blue cheese dip which was not as creamy as I would have expected but oddly satisfying. Service was friendly and prompt. We got to sit right by the big picture window which was great for people-watching.

All in all, it was a refreshing change from Grendel's or John Harvard's which can be ridiculously loud and claustrophobic. I'll reserve total judgment until I try more of their dishes.

Been here for drinks a couple of times; delightful. Tonight we came for Restaurant Week and to actually try the food. It doesn't disappoint.

The raw bar appetizer selection was excellent. I told our server that I would like the accompanying house herb aioli to be smeared on, well, everything, if possible.

The lamb leg was good, not the best I've ever had, but good, and had a great smoky tomato mixture on top. His steak was underdone and my lamb was a bit over, so we'll keep that in mind next time -- because yes; there will be a next time.

The best part, though, aside from the Crimson Crow, was the dessert. I almost never order dessert anywhere. (Because really, can you improve on a couple of scoops of gelato while walking off dinner? No, usually you cannot.)  I chose the chocolate cheesecake with salted caramel swirl and almond crust... and we both threatened to lick the plate after that thing; good heavens. Barely-sweet and barely-cheesy chocolate cheesecake with a delightfully crisp almond crust, and the salted caramel sauce to smear on it, and fresh minted whipped cream... I could go on.

Anyway, go for drinks, go for dinner, go for dessert. You won't regret it. And get a Crimson Crow.

I was excited to discover the Russell House Tavern, a refined yet affortable gastro pub that had me oooing and awwing over the menu. Our dinner started out with a bang with fresh crab cakes nestled in an indescribably delicious dipping sauce. Wow, I could have trippled our order. I wasn't wowed by the crab claws I had next and wished that my lobster slider had warm lobster rather than cold but I get what they're going for. I wish there were more vegetarian options and more fresh fish options to choose from - I would have LOVED steamed crab legs or lobster and would have paid good money for that to be on the menu. Could the restaurant consider adding a seasonal or special menu to show case all of the amazing ingredients summer has to offer? They already choose to select local ingredients so why not raise the bar and offer certian local ingredients when they are at their best - in season!?!?!?!

I will definitly return, yet might be drawn in sooner with more options and a menu which highlights the offerings of the seasons.

Walking into this place for the first time, I couldn't help but label this place as your typical first-date restaurant haha.  Casual yet classy sit-down restaurant/bar.  Conversationally-friendly but loud enough that your neighbors can't eavesdrop.

* Oysters = So fresh! and consistently fresh!

* Pork trio = one of the few dishes that always keeps me entertained.  3 porks cooked in its own style.  Pork belly is my fav, but that's just cause it hits home to my affinity for chinese food.  My friends have digged the other two as well.  You can't go wrong with this dish, unless of course you can't eat pork.

* Cocktails are delicious and options are plentiful, but I think they're a tad overhyped.  Just go by your intuition when navigating the menu.

* Request to be seated downstairs if you want that sit-down, intimate dining ambience.  Otherwise, grab a table in the upstairs bar-ish area for drinks/snacks and a chill hang-out.

Mediocrity defined. I once had one truly well-prepared dish here, which is no longer on the menu. On every subsequent visit, I've had:

1) miserable service-- every time.
2) food that barely peaks at "average," and the charcuterie often falls below.
3) wine served in rocks glasses. Pathetic.
4) ok at best drinks... for a place that supposedly has such an advanced bar program, I felt nothing above a "meh."

If your expectations and standards are fairly low, then this place will be adequate to keep you from starvation. Otherwise, grab a burrito from Felipe's and a drink... well, anywhere. And definitely stay away if you enjoy wine. They treat it like a red-headed stepchild.

An interesting first experience. Food tasty and well prepared. Service was warm but slow at times. When I felt symptoms my food allergy I was surprised since I had given them a heads up. They did a good job of getting me a new entree pretty quickly. Will give it another try again.

This review is for drinks only. 

I like to ask bartenders to make their fave drinks and try to get the more "seasonal" cocktails. They seem like the kind of people to appreciate taking their own creative liberties, but what's on the menu has so far been good. I have preferred the whiskey cocktails to the gin/vodka so far. Order the Wigglesworth, you will not regret it. 

The bartenders are extremely knowledgeable, and we had a nice talk once about places I should try for food & drinks in Boston when I told them I just moved back here. Thanks guys! 

Overall I really like the place, but prefer the downstairs bar.. Though what's with every drinking establishment  in Boston being required to play sports all the time? The decor inside is really nice and it's got a way more upscale look than a sports bar, but there are like 3 flat screens down there stuck on ESPN at all times. Arg.

Cocktail: 
- Last Word (gin, lime juice, maraschino, chartreuse): A little too sweet and lime-y for me.
- Moscow Mule (vodka, lime, ginger beer): Awesome combination.

Appetizer:
- Crab Cake Salad: Refreshing and great on top of the latkes.

Entree:
- Seared Gloucester Cod Loin (with fennel, celery root, and greens w/ bacon): Delicious and cooked perfectly. Love the onion strings on top

I like the look and feel. Eat upstairs or outside to enjoy the sun or downstairs for the style. Brunch sandwich of cheese, bacon, and tomato was delicious, especially with an added egg. My wife disliked the greasy, boring farmstand omelette though. Also, the waitress forgot several little things, like stirring spoons for tea.

(Update: Manager Tyler responded with appreciation for our review and apology for the things which weren't perfect, which I think is much to their credit.)

A nice find for a tavern in Harvard Square. It's not touristy like John Harvard's and has a more upscale vibe. There's a small bar upstairs with rows of high tops, and a larger bar downstairs with more seating. The hostesses were a bit snotty, but the rest of the staff was A-OK.

I came here before going to a concert at Harvard and was so impressed with the whole place.  the food was amazing. mi novio and i split a lot of the small places: the charcuterie, a lamb flatbread, a salad, some other lamb special, and some other things that I can't remember.  everything was amazing, and the amount of food was perfect.  one thing that stuck out to me was our server.  he was incredibly helpful with recommendations brought our food out sporadically in a logical order (salad first), which you would think would happen at every restaurant.  reasonably priced, good service, and good food, will definitely be back!

Oh Russell House Tavern... it's like the stars aligned for us to meet.

I never go into Harvard Square. Let me repeat... I NEVER go into Harvard Square. It seems like it's always something. Parking is a disaster. I can never just walk into a place an get seated in less than 40 minutes. And I saw a guy pee in the street once and let's just say it, where I live you don't really see that every day. It just seems like I always choose the wrong time for a date with Harvard. 

So how did I find the Russell House Tavern? I was kidnapped. BIg Love kidnapped me and said "just trust me". Hmph. It never really works out. Usually that phrase, from his lips, equals failure. Though I do love him dearly. So I trusted & he paid for parking :)
(um, just keep reading, the story counts as a review because at some point, I really do review this establishment)
Okay... So...

We happened upon the Russell House Tavern. It was between RHT and some other place across the street. I couldn't decide so my husband said "pick a hand". Unlike "just trust me"... this phrase usually works out for the best :)

I looked at the menu on the side of the building and "grass fed beef" caught my eye. It was a sign. I told Big Love and we frolicked in together.

We were greeted by two women who seated us right away. (could I have been wrong about Harvard?) Moments later our waiter - a very polite, witty & handsome in a different sort of way fella - came over and asked us if we wanted water. Still or sparkling. I love water choices. LOVE. I don't like MAKING choices. But I LOVE having choices to make. We chose sparkling and looked through the menu. I can't remember the waiters name. I'm going to call him Smiles. He didn't smile a ton, but I did like his smile. It was very warm.

The atmosphere was really something. Beautiful leather bar stools, romantic lighting and pictures from the 20s and 30s lining the walls. I loved the old photos of Cambridge and Harvard Square.

The menu was very unique. Everything from the appetizers to the side salads just looked interesting and delicious. We couldn't decide, it all looked too good. In the mean time the waiter and I discussed the drink menu and we decided I should have the St-Germain Cocktail. I'm absolutely obsessing over Elderflower Liqueur right now. He told me it would be "refreshing" and it was! My best friend had made the same drink at her Birthwarming celebration a few months prior. (Birthday/Housewarming... creepy huh? I love it.)

Anyhow, we decided on the Grass Fed Beef Burger (medium-well) and the Steak Frites. Any burger with bacon and an English muffin needs to be mine. 
Smiles came back with some bread and olive oil. Usually I don't love olive oil for dipping. But THIS olive oil was ridiculous. Smiles said it was infused with rosemary and garlic. We were starving so we inhaled it.

Our food came and let me tell you, I ate more than I could handle. Simple because the meat was so sinful and the fries were perfection. Seriously, if I ever gave birth to a pile of french fries, these would be them. I've never loved fries as dearly as I loved these. I asked Smiles about the fries and he told us with a laugh "it's actually a very complex french fry process"!

The food came quick and the service was outstanding. Smiles seemed like a real charmer and not some hungry scenester who couldn't be bothered. He came over just enough to keep the drinks flowing, but not enough that he interrupted our conversation.

We found out that RHT uses as much local product as possible, which I appreciate. Local stimulates our economy and keeps our little communities afloat. I love local!

The receipt came on a postcard, which was thoughtful as the next day I passed it around work and told everyone how amazing the tavern was. We thanked Smiles and paid. We too were all Smiles when we walked out :) I had experienced a pretty lame day, but Russell House Tavern turned it all around. 

Thank you to Big Love for such a nice date. I take back what I said about the "just trust me".

Even if it means taking on the parking garages and urinating strangers... I think I will venture back to Harvard Square to visit my favorite little Cambridge Tavern.
Food was great and the service was good. Looks like a great place to watch sports at the bar with friends too.

Good menu. I have only ordered seafood here.
Good selection of cocktails/wine/beer.
The downstairs is a cool hangout and the outdoor seating is a good people watching spot in the summer.
Excellent service.

Great atmosphere and delicious food! Here is my breakdown:

Get this:
Pig's head cake: absolutely delicious! Definitely try it, even if you're squeamish. It's fried like a crab cake and has a poached egg on top. The sauce is amazing and the consistency is

Let me begin by saying that I am so incredibly happy that there is no longer a Finagle-A-Bagel occupying the space that is now Russell House; it makes the very best of this location.

With that said, Russell House wins on several accounts.  The beer selection is mostly local and, when it's not, the beer is from a smaller brewery, as opposed to a major one.  There will be no Bud Light here.  There is actually wine one tap (allow me to say it again: "Wine on tap!"), which is often local, as well.  I even spotted whiskey from New York State.  

The food is very good, the raw bar is reasonably priced, and there is outdoor seating in the summer.  Moreover, the bartenders know their cocktails.  And they are very accommodating.  For example, I had difficulty connecting to their wireless network, and they went out of their way to reset the router and do what it took to get me connected.  Not too shabby.  And since I went there last on a snow day, they offered a free cup of soup to anyone who ordered anything.  Good form.  Good form indeed.  Added props to Chris, one of many excellent staff.   

My only qualms are the following: with such a gourmet menu they should have (my favorite) truffle fries.  Second, the first three times I ordered the same drink, the price was different.  I like when it's less expensive, but not when it's more expensive.  

Overall, go here.  Good atmosphere, good food, good drink, good service, and no good reasons to miss any of it.

Pros: good food, reasonably priced, great wine and beer selection, friendly service, and pleasant atmosphere

Cons: sometimes hard to walk in and get a table-- make a reservation if possible!

Russell House Tavern is my go-to restaurant in Cambridge.  I love the pizza selections, particularly the Andria, a delight made of burrata, black mission fig, and sweet garlic.  I can always count on this place for a variety of occasions, from grabbing a drink with my girlfriends to entertaining out-of-town visitors for happy hour $1 oysters.

Closest thing to a true gastropub that I've been to in Boston area.

Much better food than the other parts of their empire (e.g. Grafton).  Service a little slow because it's opening night, but they were friendly.

The steak frites and crab salad mini sandwiches were outstanding.

I've been here twice so far, once for drinks and oysters and another time for brunch. I haven't had a dinner here but their dishes do look superb and sound quite interesting.

Firstly, their drinks are superb. I haven't ordered a drink here yet that I didn't like. Delicious! 

The oysters are great, but I really didn't like the sweet pickle mignonette it came with.

For brunch, I ordered the breakfast pizza and my friend ordered the nutella stuffed french toast. The breakfast pizza was delicious and HUGE, but maybe a tad bit too salty. My friend loved raved about the nutella-stuffed french toast. We also ordered the biscuit and jam, which our neighbors had ordered and looked delicious but the server forgot to put it into the system so it never made it to the table.

I will say, despite the great food and drinks, the service was quite lacking. When I came here for brunch it wasn't very busy (despite being Mother's Day) and yet we had to flag down our server to get our order...and she also forgot to put our biscuit order into the system. Disappointing, but I suppose everything else makes for that.

Hubby took me to Russell House Tavern for my birthday. Even though we were running 20 minutes late on a Saturday night, we were greeted by friendly hosts/hostesses and immediately taken to our seats. 

Champagne and some oysters arrived soon after, which was very impressive. We had some clams (the green herb aioli and sweet pickle mignonette were superb), torched tuna from the raw bar, both very delicious.

Shared the short dirty Caesar and our entrees arrived. My husband had the grilled market fish, which was mahi mahi. This dish was made to perfection. Perfectly charred, came with a nice citrus salad that complemented the fish very well. I had the seared Gloucester cod loin, which came with very delicious creamed fennel and even more delicious roasted celery root, the bacony greens were too salty for me. The fish was covered with crunchy potato strings, which made the plate look very theatrical. 

We shared a frozen orange bomb, which was so yummy. At this point we were stuffed to the brims.

I need to single out our server Katie P in a good way. She was so attentive, nice and showed up right when we needed her. A+ service. Thanks Katie P.

The restaurant is nicely decorated, the scene is vibrant and you can't beat the location. We were so lucky, found parking in front of the restaurant. All in all, we had an awesome dining experience at Russell House Tavern, will be returning many more times and recommending it to all our friends too.

Great cocktails and delicious food. I went there with a handful of friends on a Saturday night and had a great time. The small plates were great for sharing. We had a duck pizza, small lobster pot, swordfish, haddock, shrimp ceviche, and some roasted vegetables. Aside from the duck pizza being a bit heavy on the mushrooms and little light on the duck, there were no major food complaints.

The cocktail list is fantastic. The bar staff is very knowledgeable and should be able to make any obscure cocktail that comes to mind. There is one bartender, specifically, that has just moved over from Drink and is great at helping to craft cocktails based on your flavor preferences. I'm a big gin and bitter cocktail fan (think negroni), and this bartender was able to mix me a citrus / campari / gin concoction that was absolutely delicious. Had it not been a Monday night, I probably would have ordered a few more. 

After chatting with the manager, I learned that they switch up their menu on a seasonal basis, so I'm excited to see what comes next. I encourage everyone to make the trip to Russell Tavern and experience it for yourself. 

Good luck!

Came in on a Wednesday night for their $1 oyster after 11 pm night deal. The oysters were fresh and delicious, though they came served with two mediocre and bland sauces. Service was very slow, though, and we watched a couple tables around us order, receive their food (which looked OK), and eat before we received our dozen oysters. Will come back for oysters.

We came here for an oyster event and had a great time.  We hung out at the bar and snagged some seats as soon as they opened up.  On top of the oysters we had the charcuterie plate (a little skimpy if you ask me), sirloin knuckles, and the sausage pizza.  Everything was tasty and the wine appears to be a generous pour.

My only upset was a grouchy bartender who slowed down the service and kept hucking bottles into the trash underneath the bar in front of me, and I kept thinking he was going  to hit me.

Overall, a swank place that I would love to go back to for dinner!

Had a reservation for four at nine o'clock, but we weren't seated until 9:45. It was very busy, and the hostess was very apologetic, but, y'know...
