Four glasses of sparkling wine were brought to our table as a sign of good faith, and they were appreciate

Ok. Haven't even eaten there yet but this is a first:  When I called to make a reservation for 7 people I was told that if we didn't show and didn't cancel 5 hours before our time, they would charge us a "small fee" and so needed my credit card number.  I asked how much the "small fee" was and the guy on the phone didn't know so had to ask the manager.  He came back and said $10 per person!  That's $70!  I don't call that a small fee.

Then when I called back to change the reservation to 8 people the guy said they would only charge that fee if we didn't show up at all. Not if we didn't cancel.

That's a bit better but still, the food and the service better be good!

My first experience with Russell House was subpar. The food seemed average and overpriced, the service wasn't stellar, and the overall atmosphere was too boisterous for a nice meal.  As we live nearby (and love oysters), we decided to give it another shot.

Walked in around 9pm. It was busy upstairs, but there were at least two open tables. I asked if we could grab one next to the bar for drinks and snacks. The hostess smirked at me that there was a "wait list", and that her co-conspirator would have to check for availability. After a few minutes she decided that they "might" have a table available in 15 minutes, downstairs. 

So we left. I'd rather have a grilled cheese at Charlie's Kitchen than put up with that kind of crap.

i went to russell house tavern on tuesday for my birthday dinner. i was with my boyfriend, parents, sister, and her boyfriend. when i first walked in, i liked the ambiance - they have outdoor seating, an upstairs area, and then the seated tables downstairs. overall, i liked the interesting choices on the menu, but the food itself had some hits and misses.

i was the first to arrive, and the waitress let me sit at the table and answered the questions that i had about the menu. i started out with a chardonnay, and she was very right when she told me it was on the sweeter side and i appreciated her accuracy.

for starters, i ordered the lamb terrine special that came with a dijon sauce, served on crostini. the flavor was very good, although it was very dense and the texture didn't quite do it for me. my boyfriend ordered the torched tuna, which was overcooked and bland. the beef ravioli was incredibly rich, and while the flavor was very good, the one bite i had was completely sufficient for me. we also had the lobster salad, which had good flavor but didn't really let the lobster stand out as a star ingredient.

for dinner, 3 of us ordered the arctic char. this was by far the standout of the meal - the char was cooked perfectly, moist, and had a nice crispy skin on it. it was served over a parsnip puree, which was sweet, creamy, delicious, and paired perfectly. the blackberries and asparagus rounded out he dish quite nicely. my dad and sister both ordered the roasted chicken, which came with nicely cooked carrots and mashed potatoes. the dish was not a standout, but was made well and had nice flavors to it. my boyfriend ordered the burger which ended up being boring and a complete disappointment. it was not served on an english muffin as advertised and had very little flavor. 

for dessert we ordered the cheesecake and the sorbet. the sorbet was another favorite, with a scoop each of pineapple, mango, and a berry flavor. the cheesecake was a little heavy but not too large of a portion, and it was served with real whipped cream that was very nice.

overall, i would recommend russell house tavern to those that like to try interesting dishes, but with the caveat that not every dish stands up to the menu description. i would like to go back and try the pizzas during a casual night out, and it seems like it would be a fun hangout place.

I went to Russel House the other day to sit at the bar, study, and grab some lunch. Besides the lunatic that sat down next to me throughout my time there I had a great experience. The lady was drunk out of her mind and insisted on talking to me even after I put both my headphones in to try to politely give her a hint. 

Anyway the burger I odered was delicious and cooked perfectly. I wasn't sure about how they put it on an english muffin but it worked. They have an good selection of high quality beers here too and and oyster bar ($2 each). Looking around upstairs you wouldn't realize it but they have a dining area downstairs that is almost triple the size.

Nom is all I have to say.

Just went this afternoon for lunch and it happened to be restaurant week (how was I unaware that it was restaurant week? What a travesty!). Decided to go with the prix fixe lunch menu for $20 per person. Soooooo good.

Upon walk

Love Russell House Tavern! I'm so pleased with how well its done since its opening in Harvard Square.  Its a Square favorite among locals and its always my first watering hole spot when I cross the river. Although it gets alot of visitors for its touristy location and although its a bit of a chaotic atmosphere, its fun, and the food/drink isn't compromised like that of its overpriced and underwhelming neighbor, John Harvard's.  The beer and spirit menu is vast and carefully selected, the menu has a perfect amount of offerings that cater to more sophisticated pub palettes but still has a few traditional menu items for folks that can't swallow the oysters or charchuterie.  Its got an equal parts-mix of groups of Harvard grad student-drinkers, date-night folk, and out-of-town diners that have exhausted a day in the Square. The bartenders that know how to mix a great drink and know their liquor, and and the dishes are well presented, hearty(but not huge) , which is good for those of us counting our calories after that 12% Otter Creek draught.  I highly recommend all of the items I've consumed in my visits- the crab cakes, caesar salad, salt & pepper shrimp, and my friend loves the oysters.    Great drinking spot, great dining spot, go there.

Update on my previous review as I was recently at the bar with an old friend, and had a stellar experience. We ordered a plate of fries, which came out late, and were comped as a result. Crispy and delicious. She ordered a beer whose keg was nearing its end, so she got 70% of a glass for free, and another beer of her choosing, also for free. Later in the night, they made an extra sidecar by accident and asked us if we'd like to have it. Obviously, we did. In the end, we had five delicious drinks, a plate of fries, and a new best friend behind the bar for a grand total of 15 bucks. A rare excellent evening in the heart of Harvard Square.

REVIEW IS JUST FOR $1 oysters..

At a buck an oyster, you cant possibly expect to have them all expertly shucked.. i had a noticeable number of shell pieces in mine, but still, ITS ONLY A BUCK and they all tasted fresh and delicious!

Service was really good (and it BETTER be.. they were practically empty at 11pm on a Sunday night!) AND they offer complimentary sparkling water if you so desire. oh that's fancy, huh?

Gotta come back here and try some real food next time!

came here for brunch early on this year.  they serve your classic brunch fare, toad in the hole, cuban sandwiches, but each with a more classy and richer twist.

bloody mary with the lobster and shrimp is a MUST. its stronger than you think, so make sure you eat first!

will definitely come here everytime im in boston!

I was a little wary after hearing mixed thoughts from a fellow Yelper, but dinner here turned out to be one tasty meal!  

The family and I had a chance to try out a number of apps, small plates and entrees and they were strong performances all around.  Highlights included the Brandt Farms Beef Heart Ravioli and Ozark Heritage Pork Trio - both were pretty fantastic with tender meats and loaded with robust flavors.  Even the accompanying salad on the pork trio was delicious.  The Seared Arctic Char and Grilled Bluefish special deserve honorable mention as well with great preparation on both dishes.  

Conversely, I wouldn't recommend the pizza.  The Andria was overly greasy and the almost nutmeggy flavor I noticed really didn't jive with the rest of the toppings.  I'd pass on the Deviled Local Farm Eggs too - refreshing notes from the chilled shrimp and cantaloupe, but otherwise bland.

The ambiance and service are both notable too with ample seating and walking space as well as surprisingly modest noise levels considering how lively it was that Saturday night.  Great food, atmosphere and prices...can't complain =D

Let me be clear, I blame management for this, not our unfortunate though attractive waiter. But we were there for an hour and a half, and all we got were 2 drinks, an appetizer and our main course. WTF! 

The only time I have had worse service was when I went to a Mexican restaurant in P town, and didn't get any service at all. Our waiter had the attention span of a toddler, the waiting skills of a circus monkey, and must have lied in his interview because I don't think he had ever waited a table in his life. 

Now I can understand that if you are new to the industry, it takes a little bit to get your bearings, your routine, etc. But you do that at Denny's or Friendly's or IHOP, NOT at a restaurant where a 2 top can easily  hit $50 before ordering the main course. 

The food was fine, but I think a little too cerebral, like the art of the dish had been lost in translation from inception to kitchen. It seemed...distilled for high volume? Fancy, but too salty, and over seasoned. This may get better with time, but right now, it's overpriced, and overcompensating. 

The hostess was very nice and i think well aware of how incompitant our waiter was, as she checked on us two or three times. And the hostess for the down stairs had this great look reminicent of those 20's style absenth ads, with her fierce haircut and the green light of her podium glowing up at her from below. 

Be that as it may, I won't be going back any time soon. And I hope they get their sh!t figured out because I love the location and décor.

Pork trio (awesome), plenty whiskey cocktails to choose from and a friendly staff, what else could you want? anytime i find myself in the area, i'll be tempted to stop in for a drink, gotta try that burger too. 

The girlfriend and i didn't hold back and the end tab wasn't too bad:
 simple leaf salad- mustard vinaigrette, walnuts, figs,
Salt & pepper shrimp - nice thin breading, great flavors
2 glasses of wine
2 cocktails - seelbach and vieux carre(my favorite of the two)
pork trio
steak frites

$103 before tip

This review is for brunch only. So far we have had...
-nutella-stuffed french toast- very tasty (though I do have a nutella problem which results in me loving everything that has nutella on it, but whatever)
-biscuits and gravy- very little gravy so it was a pretty dry meal and I wouldn't recommend this one
-breakfast pizza- very good and covered in runny eggs which, again, gives it an unfair advantage over other foods

Ummm THANK YOU RUSSELL HOUSE!! 

Finally, finally, finally. A delicious and semi-affordable restaurant in Harvard Square with an *excellent* beer listing (including listed alcohol percentages), totally delicious appetizers, and really juicy burgers.  

First - the wait staff is AMAZING.  I walked in on a Thursday at around 7PM and was asked by two hostesses if I needed help.  One asked if I wanted to sit outside - an option I didn't know existed. PERFECT!!  A seat for two in the back of the side alleyway was perfect - and the bench seat was pretty comfortable and allowed for extra room when my buddy and BF got there and joined us later.

The waitress kept the drink coming to me and my girlfriend, had solid opinions and suggestions on the food, didn't kick us out after we'd eaten and wanted to keep drinking, and was super kind when I got a little too drunk and started speaking quite loudly about (a) how much I loved this place and (b) how much I loved this place.  Instead, they brought us what I like to refer to as "we know you're hammered so he's some bread so tomorrow won't be as painful" bread basket.  Thanks Russell House buddies!

The oysters were delicious, the cheeseburger was super juicy and yummy, the fries are excellent (skinny and flavorful), and the bread was also delicious.  The tuna tartar-ish dish was ok, but a warning that the anchovy oil on it is slightly overpowering.  

There is also a HUGE downstairs area with a nice wraparound bar,  booths, and seemed perfect for gatherings of 7 - 10 friends wanting to grab drinks.  The bathroom was clean and modern.

Approximately 7 beers, a burger, three oysters, and the tuna appetizer set us back about $105 + tip.

I was here last week and I'm going back this week - five stars!

Came here for brunch on Sunday. We were seated downstairs (read: in the dungeon) which I think detracted a lot from the meal. It certainly didn't help you forget that you were starting your day in a bar.

Our waiter was nice, but I felt like he really pushed adding sides to the orders.

However, I cannot complain about the food. I really enjoyed the yogurt and granola with caramelized bananas. I imagine this is what banana creme brûlée would taste like. The fruit with mint was also great. Top it all off with a mimosa of course!

to go from a ghetto Finagle a Bagel to this, you have to be impressed.  Even Z Sqaure was OK, but this place got the vibe down like Z never could.

And while the sign says Tavern, it really is trying to be a bit more foodie than a typical tavern in these parts - kudos for that.

the food was great - and the price was right.  the service pretty solid, though got spottier as the place filled up.

might be a new regular spot, frankly.  if for no other reason than featuring a pizza with essentially lamb bacon on it.

This is one of those places which really disappoints me. Not necessarily because it's terrible all around but because this pub has so much potential and yet, still manages to suck.

Starting with the positive: (most) of the food was delicious. I went with two friends, and we ordered an assortment of dishes (the menu has since varied slightly but it involved a beef dish, some scallops, a pizza and pork belly) and everything (except the pork belly) was fantastically seasoned and prepared. The pork belly was just a block of fat. Now, I know that pork belly has a lot of fat -- that's what makes the meat so delicious. But there was no meat in this dish, which seems unacceptable. Since the rest of the meal was so good, I'm chocking that up to a mistake in the kitchen. Either way, we tried to mention this issue to the waitress but encountered some difficulties. See below.

The negatives start and end with the service. But man, the service was really neglectful. We were seated on time and our drink order was taken by a seemingly friendly waitress. We ordered a bottle of wine and she promptly brought us three dirty glasses. We mentioned this to her and asked for bread. 10 minutes later she returns with glasses. Still no bread. We asked again and she said she'd bring it right away and she took our order. 20 minutes later she brings our food. STILL NO BREAD. Oh well, on to meal time. The waitress came by our table exactly once to ask how the food was and was nowhere to be found when we wanted to complain about the pork belly. She returned long after our plates were clean and asked if we wanted dessert.

I should say that the waitress wasn't bad, per se, at what she was doing. She had just been instructed to follow a very strict script: seat customers, take drink order, take food order and ask exactly once how it is. I understand that the place is busy but if the waitress is nowhere to be found for an entire meal, I think the restaurant is too busy. They've obviously chosen volume of customers over service and it's too bad. Otherwise, Russel House Tavern could have been a really cool place.
Good crab cakes and fries. Liked the deep fried egg. But wasn't blown away. Very good drinks. What you'd expect from a gastro pub.

Russell House has a lovely, old timey feel to it, with interesting decor that includes old lightbulbs and lots of curtains. I went here with friends for cocktails, and I was very happy with my experience. We sat at the downstairs bar. I started with the crab cakes appetizer, which were juicy on the inside, crisp on the outside, and deliciously flavored. Even the greens on top were more than decoration - they were yummy!
I tried the Champs Elysees, Battle of Trafalgar, and a cocktail called the Crimson Crow I believe? (three drinks, guess I forgot.) They were all delicious and different, but my favorite was the Battle of Trafalgar, which was made with Pimm's but tasted like honey wine.
The bartender was very patient with our group of five who kept ordering different elaborate cocktails for three hours. 
This is a great place to go with friends for after-work drinks and appetizers. It's not too loud or crowded to talk, even at the bar the atmosphere is relaxed. 
And it took me until the next morning to even remember that this place used to be a dingy bagel cafe! I completely forgot, the transformation is so complete.

I tried out Russell House as soon as I moved to the area almost a year ago, and I have kept coming back ever since.  

It doesn't matter if I'm on the patio, upstairs, or downstairs.  Every part of the tavern has such a great vibe.  It doesn't matter if I'm there for brunch, dessert, dinner, happy hour, or late night appetizers.  Everyone I take here ends up having a good time.  This place is especially memorable among all the out-of-town guests that come with me.  Whenever my boyfriend visits me, he is always asking if we could go back to Russell House, and he's not happy until we do.

It has a very chill, relaxed, yet classy ambience.  I would feel comfortable going here whether I'm in jeans or a nice dress.  Last time I went here was late at night.  There were some people decked out in their best dresses and suits (looked like they came from a formal occasion), but the people at the table next to mine came in wearing casual clothes and backpacks (looked like they came from the library). 

I usually list dishes that I like at restaurants, but I've gone here so many times that I can't single any dish out.  Try them all, and you'll be satisfied somehow.  I'm also pleased with their selection of drinks.  I don't fall in love with every drink I try, but I appreciate being able to come back here and try something new each time.

This review is based on a failed attempt to have dinner at the Russell House, not actual dinner. We didn't bother after our experience with their staff in trying to set up.

We were planning to have a nice dinner with out of town guests the night before our wedding. It was meant to be a nice meal where our families could meet and we could spend a little more time with guests who traveled far (and some from abroad) to celebrate with us.

We very rashly decided on Russell House because of its location and feel just as the invitations were going out the door. BIG MISTAKE. Neither of us had eaten there and we hadn't experienced the service. Now we know better.

We signed a contract with Russell House to do a private dinner. The woman who is supposed to be their events coordinator would not respond to our emails or calls. Two weeks before our dinner when we were trying to adjust the head count and settle on a pre fixed menu, it took 5 days for the events coordinator to return our calls and emails. At that point she promised us a draft of the pre fixed menu, which we didn't see until calling her multiple times a few days later. 

The minimum we had to reach was so high that with a 4 course meal and raw bar at the table to "nibble on," as they told us, we still weren't getting anywhere near the minimum. They refused to include the tax, administrative fee (whatever that is), and gratuity in the minimum and gave me attitude when I told them it was ridiculous that we couldn't even get close to the minimum with all of this food. Who on earth can even eat that much?!

We cut our loses, decided that it was entirely worth losing the $250 deposit (although because of their complete lack of responsiveness in this process, I firmly believe that they should be reimbursing us for our pain and suffering), I WILL NEVER, EVER GO BACK TO RUSSELL HOUSE TAVERN.

We had a fantastic meal at the Foundry on Elm, who was nice enough to accommodate us at the last minute with a large party on a Friday night. The food was excellent, the service superb (they had at least 3 servers working our table for the full evening, including one of the managers), and it was HALF THE PRICE (even when you factor in the deposit we had to eat). 

We are very loyal restaurant goers in the Cambridge and Somerville area and all I have to say is WOW. Never again.
fun place to visit. Love the blonde beer!

Today was the second day they were opened.  Given the timing, I'm ready to forgive peccadilloes.

Their menu was pretty flexible, but not too crazy.  There are "small plates," appetizers (which are larger than the small plates), a raw bar, a small charcuterie selection, a few pizzas, entrees, and sides a la carte.  About 8-10 options in each of the small plates, appetizers, and entrees, with some overlap between small plates and appetizers.

The overall approach of the chef is to focus on seasonal, local ingredients.  This wasn't immediately obvious from the menu; the only very seasonal thing I saw were ramps.  But hey... my palate isn't so refined as to be able to distinguish local red onions from AGAR red onions.  

I had an appetizer-sized Caesar salad, and a trio of pork (pork belly, pork loin, and pork shoulder, drizzled with a sweet vinegar sauce) that usually comes with grits but I subbed out for mushroom gratin, and a bit of a mizuna salad.  (Mizuna tastes like a slightly spicy arugula.)  

The Caesar salad was perfect.  Anchovies were available, so I indulged.  The lettuce was crisp and uniformly cut into bite sized pieces.  (I don't know why this is so hard for some restaurants to do, but it doesn't happen as much as it should.)  The salad was perfectly dressed, and the dressing itself had an excellent balance of lemon, pepper, and rich salinity.  A nice touch they do is to add a bit of rough-cut parsley in their Caesar salad.  It's enough of a finesse to make it interesting, without going so far as to be trying too hard.

The appetizer-sized salad was pretty big, so I ended up splitting it with my wife.

The entree was a nice size.  Probably about 6-8 oz. of pork all told.  Each cut was cooked perfectly:  the loin was moist, the shoulder was tender and smoky, and the belly melted in my mouth without being gristly or chewy.   Really, no room for improvement here.

The mizuna salad included some red onions and was dressed with a simple vinaigrette.  Its brightness made a nice contrast to the rich pork dishes.

There was a little mix-up with the mushroom gratin.  The waitress mentioned it included fontina cheese, but it came out as simply mushrooms cooked in olive oil topped with bread crumbs.  It was tasty, to be sure, but not what I was expecting.  I'm sure these kinks will be worked out in time though.

During the meal, someone brought over a small complimentary dish of smoked almonds (which go for $5 as a small plate).  They were tasty, if you like smoked things.  (I do).  Better yet, they were served warm.  Perfect for the rainy day we were having.

Like its predecessor Z-Square, the restaurant occupies two levels.  Although I'm sure there were renovations, the decor is generally the same both upstairs and downstairs.   (I might be wrong on this... my recollection of Z-Square is somewhat sketchy.)  Notably, the "lunch counter" upstairs was replaced by a bar... a step in the right direction.

The service was reasonably attentive.  Our waitress wasn't able to answer all our questions right away, but she was very quick to ask the kitchen and come back.   One nice thing they do is to leave each table with a large bottle of "house-filtered" water, rather than trying to keep refilling each glass from a pitcher.  I'm sure this will streamline service when it gets busy.

All in all, a solid debut.  I'll keep coming back for as long as they keep this level of quality up.

I have been here twice, and each time I was impressed. Their menu is exceptional, and I noticed that there was a lot of care taken in choosing each item, including their extensive cocktail and wine and beer list. They have tons of craft beers! The food was great, and the oysters were very fresh. You get what you pay for here! It is moderate to high priced but not bad for what you get!
I will be back!
 
My only gripe: they have pate. EW

I really liked the range of options and the cozy vibe upstairs at the Russell House Tavern.  The wine pours are generous, and the house pinot blanc (straight off the tap) was very drinkable.  The appetizer of Serrano ham and manchego was quite good, although I didn't really dig the pickled pears that came on top.  My husband had the roasted chicken, which had ultra delicious crispy skin and buttery mashed potatoes.  I had the pork three ways, which was OK.  The sauce was flavored well, but it just became too much of the same thing for three different pork parts.  Based on the meal, I'd give it close to four stars, but when I got the dessert menu and couldn't find anything I wanted, come on!

Every time I come here the food is always good.

The last time I went, I had the grilled cheese sandwich with a cup of soup.  It was really delicious.  The sandwich is just a regular grilled cheese sandwich, which I had with a slice of tomato and no bacon.  You also get a side salad, which was very fresh and the dressing was very nice and complimented the greens.
The soup, a carrot and ginger soup was fresh and tasty.
This little combination totally hit the spot.  It's comfort food.

I've had a martini here also, impressive.

I'll be back sweetie darling!

Those of you who love Drink will remember Aaron B, the young bartender with glasses. He's now the bar manager at Russell House, which has replaced the old Z Square in Harvard.  So expect that same selection of esoteric but tasty cocktails, that same attention to little details (garnishing each glass, napkins and water just so).  It's like Drink, but north of the river.

Protip: if you're a whiskey sort, the Vieux Carre or the Scottish Play are good choices.  The Scottish Play does taste a little smoky, but that's how I like my whiskey (AND MY WOMEN, GET IT, I'LL EXPLAIN IT LATER, PM ME) so it works out.

We went for Restaurant Week and I'd have to say it was the BEST we've had at a "tavern" in a while! This is a real "upscale" feel but our server was not by any means "stiff" which I love! It was crowded but we made a reservation ahead of time and were sat immediately.
I had beef cheek for the first time in my life and it was so delicious. Very very tender and came with a parsnip puree that blew me away! (Later that week my boyfriend had an entree with parsnip puree and wow it was TERRIBLE after having the Russell House's)
The beer selection was also great!

I visited Russell House for the first time last night - met some girlfriends for drinks at the bar.  Our bartender, Lou, was adorable, hilarious, really friendly, and attentive - dealing with our indecisiveness with patience and humor.  LOVE him.  Probably my favorite bartender of all time, actually.  The drinks were delicious, the food was amazing, and the atmosphere was fun and inviting.  For these reasons, I would probably come back.  Add Lou to the mix and I'll definitely come back!

Love this place. Excellent food for a bar and some unusual dishes. Their burger is really good too. Friendly and attentive staff and generally a good vibe. Decent selection of draft beers and a few more unusual ones on bottle. By far my favorite place nea

love this place. Probably my favorit place in Boston.
Take your pick - small plates, appetizers or entree. I usually get a few small plates with my bf and share, or if there's a few of us, we'd get 1 entree and couple more small plates to share. That way you get the best of everything.
Great food, great drinks, love the bar upstairs... oh, and great service. Once when we went for brunch and the kitchen had some printing problem, the manager came to apologize twice for making us wait 20-30min and took care of our bill. I mean, I think everyone else's was late too but I guess ours got lost so it was especially late, but still - they never forget to provide the best service to make you happy, even after becoming so popular. I hope you stay this way Russell House!

Absolutely fabulous food and drinks.  Stopped in here wandering around Harvard campus for a drink.  Top-notch cocktail menu made by knowledgable bartenders.  Then we got a glimpse of the dinner menu.  Lots of house-made charcuterie, pates, terrines.  Loads of pork and fresh seafood.  After having lived in the UK (birthplace of the gastropub) and eaten at many gastropubs there, this is the ONLY place I've eaten at here in the States that even compares and/or deserves the moniker. We cancelled our existing dinner reservation and came back for dinner.  It was amazing.  Check out the trio of pork and the smoked pork rillettes.

i was a little hesitant to go to russell house, since i read a bunch of reviews on here about the terrible customer service. i have to say, they must read yelp because hands down the service was pretty awesome. everyone greeted us, and was polite; we barely had to wait for anything and when it took our waitress maybe 2 mins to get us our check she apologized and thanked us for our patience (!). so..keep that in mind if you're considering checking this place out. 

the drinks here are pretty delicious. we were sitting near the downstairs bar and i saw the bartender pouring way more than one shot into each and i knew that we would get a Serious Drink, which we did. my husband had a martini type thing with chartreuse and i had a vodka + ginger beer drink - both were delicious and SUPER strong. 

the food was..okay. it was fine, it just wasn't anything special. my husband felt his burger was overly salty and i just had a pizza and a salad, no big deal. i would be super excited if they introduced a veggie burger, since right now, the only thing veg people can eat are the pizzas (2 of them), a salad, and a pasta dish. the fries are crazy salty addictive...mmmm.

all in all i thought this was a pretty solid spot, especially considering that harvard square tends to be d-bag central and i despise most other restaurants in the square. this was a pretty low key place, definitely skewing younger, and i'd definitely love to come back. probably more for drinks and to work my way through their excellent beer list, though. 

p.s. make a reservation on opentable! we did this maybe an hour or two before we went and had no problems getting a table, but there are a ton of people waiting by the time we left.

I was super psyched when I saw that a new gastropub style restaurant was opening up in Harvard Square. I think it was a welcome addition to the neighborhood.. there doesn't seem to be much middle ground to choose from when it comes to restaurant selection in that area, in my opinion.

I met up for lunch with a friend and was not impressed by his seat selection (he chose the high top with the stools...really?) but nevertheless the restaurant layout is pretty pleasing overall. I like that they have the outside terrace and the big windows open up right to the street (which can be a blessing and a curse when you're trying to eat). Still, overall, nice ambiance.

We ordered and the server definitely had a bunch of small touches that were aimed toward good customer service which did not go unnoticed. Sparkling water was no extra charge. Who doesn't like a little effervesence? 

However the thing that got me was that the food was just OK. I ordered the burger, which at $10 was a steal but it didn't really do much for me. It was just sort of lack luster in every way. The English muffin was sort of soggy on the bottom, the meat was too greasy and it was just sorta meh. To me, I'd rather have really good food than ambiance - hence the 3 star rating.

If I come perhaps I will just stick to drinks at this place or try something else.

While most of my classmates ventured to New York and Leisureworld--I mean Florida!--for spring break, I took advantage of some fantastic Jet Blue discounts and made my way to Boston to visit my genius bureaucrat of a sister. Russell House turned out to be the perfect spot for a) a break from pretending to be an Ivy League student (vs. one from the largest Virginia state school--womp), b) people watching, and c) a scrumptious lunch.

The Sister had a little pizza with figs and local burrata cheese. I was skeptical about figs on pizza, too, but the sweetness was balanced so nicely with the tangy cheese. I had the braised short rib, which was served with mashed potatoes and roasted carrots. Every bit of it was delicious, which is saying something, because normally I'll only eat carrots raw. But no, they were perfectly seasoned, the potatoes lovely and creamy, and the short rib almost ridiculously tender.

You can keep your retirement condos by the swamp and your tiny studio apartments in Hell's Kitchen. (I might be kidding about that last one...) I'll take a medium sized townhouse in Davis and lunch at Russell House Tavern.
Great people who work there. Mainly go for that. Good beers on tap, too. Yum, yum.

Lunch today, outside, pretty nice little area and inside looks pleasant and inviting.....martini was good, nothing special, bacon bourbon bloody was great, the smoked brisket reuben was excellent and the pork loin sandwich ok , we both had the salads as sides, one had dressing (decent) the other didn't (not decent)......service was good, nice place, pretty good beer selection and a very interesting and different menu!!

My friend and I went to RH for dinner Saturday night, and I couldn't have asked for a better experience. The hostess staff was super friendly and accommodating when we walked in, asking whether we'd like to sit up or downstairs. We decided on downstairs and were seated at a high pub table near the bar. The atmosphere downstairs was a good mix of bar goers, diners, and larger groups of people -- ranging from Harvard Square hipsters to older couples looking for a romantic night out. 

I immediately asked our waitress for a beer recommendation from the extensive list of craft beers from all over the country. She was very knowledgeable about the menu and told me to try the Dead Guy Ale if I was in the mood for something not too heavy but rich in flavor, and it was by far my favorite beer choice of the night. The drink list is phenomenal AND they have wine on tap... righteous!  

Even though you could make a meal out of all the delicious beer, the food is not something you want to miss out on. Being a vegetarian, it's sometimes hard to find options that look appetizing on the menu, but I had several to choose from here. My friend and I split the creamy spinach gratin for an app -- better than any spinach dip you'll ever eat anywhere! For an entree, I ordered the "Farmer's Pie" pizza, which was a flatbread covered in green goodness (pesto, zucchini, peas, fontina cheese) ...yum! Big enough to take some home and enjoy the next day. My friend ordered the burger and couldn't have been happier. 

Our bill wasn't too expensive for what we ordered, and for the excellent service and overall good vibes that came from this place, I would be willing to pay more. My last note goes out to the fab choice in music that played at just the right volume all night... definitely topped off my A+ encounter with the Russell House Tavern. I will be back for sure!!!

Awesome. Been here at least 5 times and it has yet to disappoint.

The bartenders are some of the best in all of the Boston metro area (stiff competition to those at Green St. and Aldo at Corner Tavern). They can make a mean drink using any flavor or description you have, their regular cocktail menu is amazing, and they have a pretty rockin' beer & wine list (all their beer is also domestic).

The food is incredible. I've had their regular salad with bacon, buttermilk dressing, etc. so many times- it's HUGE and SO good. Their crabcakes and their steak are potentially life changing... gosh, so good. Oh, and their chicken is top-notch. I've also had their brunch, including some of their raw bar-- also lived up to everything else I've had there.

The service is also great- super friendly, helpful. Their ambiance is very chill. The upstairs areas can get kind of loud, so if you're looking for something a bit more low-key, head downstairs. 

I'll definitely, without hesitation, be heading back.
Had the braised lamb shoulder w/ gnocci. Seafood tower. Awesome service. Excellent value would go back soon.

Eh.  Not bad, but not great.  I was fairly disappointed because the Russell House Tavern looks like it has so much potential!  I'm sure that with a little more work it could be a really great place.  The staff just seemed unorganized and apathetic.  The service was extremely slow -  Granted, it was Sunday at 1pm, but it took about 10 minutes for our server to finally wander over and bring us water and then about another 10 minutes to bring us the coffee we ordered (after a reminder). On the plus side, the dishes we ordered were pretty tasty... Not amazing, but good.  I might return to Russell House at some point, but only when it's not a busy time.

"Oh Drink, if you were in any more of a convenient location, I would probably develop a severe drinking problem." A quote taken directly from my review of Drink a few months ago.  Let the substance abuse begin...

We went to Russell Square Tavern a few days after the opening.  Just there for drinks, we bellied up to the bar and asked the gentleman behind the counter if he had a recommendation for a spicy cocktail.  "Tabasco spicy or ginger spicy?" the man replied.  Deja vu.  This is the exact response I had heard the last time I was at Drink.  Hesitantly, I replied, "...Tabasco."  The barkeep then suggested the Ball Crusher - my favorite libation at Drink.  I had to investigate the situation.  It turns out the bar manager at Russell House had worked at Drink and was well versed on all the wonderfully delicious cocktail recipes served there.

Unfortunately the bar manager is the only bartender with such knowledge, so from now on, I will be placing my orders with him.

This review is more about the food than the drinks. Although the drink menu is great and the bartenders will be happy to concoct something to your liking, what stood out yesterday at dinner was the PHENOMENAL burger. This was the best burger I have ever had in my life. Thick cut bacon; perfectly melted cheddar; carmelized onions; and a nice, thick, grass-fed patty, all on an english muffin. 

No kidding! An english muffin! They don't screw around filling you up with carbs. It's not about the bread is it? It's about the meat and the delicate flavors mixing together to achieve perfection.

Instead of fries or a side of greens I got a side of Brussels sprouts. They were also perfect. Crispy, a little sweet, not over cooked.

There was so much food, I could not finish it. Burger and a drink, less than $20.

In a sentence: Beautiful space, interesting food, prices that are a little on the high side, and inattentive service.

My boyfriend and I went here for my birthday and had a great time. We got a beautiful outdoor seat on a really lovely night, and we ordered a lot of things. We ordered the crab pizza special, but the waitress delivered the crabcakes instead. It actually took us awhile to realize, because we'd been considering the crabcakes, too. The waitress was mortified and brought us a free crab pizza, so between that, the oysters, the dirty Caesar salad, and the steak frites, we were buried in food!

The food was delicious. They have really great fries, and the crab pizza was wonderful even when I reheated it in my toaster oven four days later. 

The service, not so much. Our waitress was very sweet, and started out on the right foot, but eventually disappeared, leaving us waiting for things like our check for far too long. Granted, it was a fairly busy Friday night, but our meal turned into a two-and-a-half hour affair.

The prices are fairly high - but hey, it's Harvard Square. I would definitely go back!

I went here recently with two of my girlfriends and it was incredible! The service is great, drinks are wonderful, and the food is amazing. Plus there is a lot of seating so there doesn't seem to ever be that long of a wait. We went there on a Wednesday night and when we first arrived the hostess told us it would be about 15 minutes for a table and showed us to the two bars (a small one on the first floor and a bigger one on the bottom floor). After ordering our drinks we were pretty much seated immediately and they were able to transfer our drink orders to our server so we didn't have to wait to pay our tab. 

Our server (Steve) was awesome, he was very helpful with helping us figure out what to order, made sure we had enough water, and that our drinks were never empty. We ended up getting the Creamy Spinach Gratin for an appetizer and then three pizzas to split between all of us for the main course - it was way too much food in the end, but definitely worth it and worth the price. If you're ever in the area, I would definitely stop by.
What a sweet find in the middle of Harvard Sq! This is a must visit for those who love great food and a well equipped bar that serves up a delectable menu of outstanding food! Don't miss it!

Heard some good things about this newcomer, so I decided to give it a try for lunch.  While I really wanted to go hog wild on the raw bar offerings, I decided to stick with a sandwich since that seemed an appropriate choice for 1pm on a weekday.

I had the steak sandwich, and they actually cooked the meat how I had ordered it - medium rare.  Many places ask you how you want the steak cooked, but then it comes out as well done.  I even saw pink this time!  Gooey cheese, sauteed mushrooms and caramelized onions rounded out the sandwich.  

One suggestion though - my sandwich came with a pickle on top, and I can't stand pickles.  I maintain that they're one of the most polarizing foods out there - there's no middle ground, either you love these things or you hate them.  I wish the menu would disclose such things, as anything that a pickle touches immediately becomes a pickle itself (in taste, at least).  It's kind of like a bad Midas touch. 

The table next to me had ordered a pizza that looked mouth watering - that will probably be the next thing I order.  

Though I didn't order any this time, they had an impressive beer list.  Not huge, but full of interesting brews that went beyond the pedestrian Sam-Harpoon-Stella-Heiney selection. 

This place could easily be 5 stars with a few tweaks.  For one, the non-alcoholic drinks are too expensive.  $3 for an iced tea or diet coke?  Service was ok - nothing wrong with it but not reaching 25% tip territory either.  One of our water glasses was dirty, but beyond that and the unwanted pickle, no complaints here.

Russell House Tavern is popular for brunch and cocktails and is located right in Harvard Square. The main bar area is warm with luxurious looking black bar stools.


The downstairs area is spacious and can accommodate large parties and a great cocktail hour.

I had the Anti-Benedict:  Garlic Spinach & Breakfast Sausage, Hollandaise, Hash Browns with Two Crispy Fried Poached Eggs $14


My friend had the Pit Master was 16 Hour Smoked Brisket scrambled with Three Eggs, Scallions, Fontina, Potatoes and Toast $11

My other friend had the E.B.L.T on a Croissant: 2 Eggs over easy, Cheddar, Lettuce, Tomato, Bacon, Mayo, Hash Browns for $9

I will have to come back for cocktails and dinner since they serve a nice variety of updated American classics such as pizzas, sandwiches, salads and appetizers.

So disappointing!  Having had lovely meals in the past at RHT, my boyfriend and I decided to finish a delicious fall day with another trip to RHT.  

Our experience soured quickly:  
1.  The hostesses seemed annoyed to have to seat us.  Sorry, isn't that part of the job?  
2.  We were seated, crammed between 2 other parties - spacious is not a word used to describe RHT and couldn't even hear each other across the tiny table.  
3.  We sat for 10-15 minutes without anyone coming over to see if we wanted a drink, to place an order, to even offer us water.  Finally, I couldn't take it anymore - multiple wait-staff had passed us, made eye contact and walked away.  
4.  We left.  As we walked past the hostess, I explained why we were leaving and she hastily attempted to get us to stay by asking where we were sitting and who had been helping us.  NO ONE, that was the issue.  

Sorry RHT, but if you can't even get a waiter to the table to offer water 15 minutes after being huffily seated, we'll take our business (and generous tips) elsewhere.

Drink: 5 stars!
Food: 5 stars!
Service: 2 stars.

I've been here twice.  

First time, I sat downstairs at the bar area.  Such a nice area!  I like the downstairs area so much more than the upstairs bar.  Bartender was extremely knowledgeable.  I loved my gin drinks ("British Bee" and "Last Word").  The boyfriend likes whiskey, bourbon and such, so he really enjoyed the "Fedora" and "Vieux Carré."  We ordered a bunch of small plates- the steak tartare and marrow bone stick out in my mind.  Only negative the first time is even after giving them a 20+% tip, I ended up getting charged a 30+% tip and didn't notice until I checked my credit card statement, so be careful!  I suppose mistakes happen.

Second time, I went last night with a few friends.  We sat in the upstairs bar area.  The waitress came by and took our drink order (once again, AMAZING- I loved my "Battle of Trafalgar").  However, she gave us a weird look and was visibly annoyed when only 1 person in our party of 5 ordered food.  Mind you, it was 9:30pm and we were meeting up for drinks in the bar area.  After sitting around for over an hour and trying to hunt our waitress down, we were finally able to order a second round of drinks.  Not sure if she was having a bad day, but she was rude (rolling her eyes) and MIA the whole time.  To make it worse, she charged the 18% gratuity to our check.  I understand places do that if your party is on the larger side, but after the horrible service, it left all of us in a sour mood toward her and the restaurant.

I normally feel pretty bad giving two stars unless it was absolutely terrible.. but seeing as the average rating is 4 stars right now I don't feel bad. 

This place has a lot of potential, its nice inside but the atmosphere is relatively casual, not too stiff.

Unfortunately the service was horrendous.. well the server did ok once we were finally seated but the hostesses were clueless, unfriendly, pretentious...  

On top of that the food was pretty much mediocre. 

Maybe this place is a 3-4 stars IF YOU HAVE A RESERVATION. 

Without reservation, you are treated like an unwelcome burden.. this is a horrible business & customer service strategy.

We waited 40 minutes, just to be sat at a table in the bar area (not even restaurant) that had been OPEN the entire time we were there. There were 6-7 other open tables around the restaurant that were being 'held for reservations' but weren't filled for 30-50 minutes.

My group had just arrived in Boston and we were hungry. We were heading to the Harvard area and decided to look on yelp for a place to eat. We found Russel House Tavern, which was very close to the red line station. We didn't have reservations but they let us sit at the bar area. We went around noon and it filled up fast.

I had a hard time deciding between the Pork Loin sandwich and the Meatloaf melt. The waitress told me that she preferred the pork loin sandwich, so I went with that. I am glad I did because it was delicious! I could taste the sweet apples and onions in every bite. It was definitely one of the best sandwiches I've had. The fries were good too. Looking around, I see other people ordering unique and tasty dishes. Looking back, I wish I could have went back another day during my Boston trip. It was definitely my favorite restaurant and it wasn't very expensive. I would be cautious however, because it could set high expectations for dining in Boston, especially if this is the first restaurant you go to there.

I don't usually write reviews, but Russell House deserves a shout out. This place is foodie heaven- try the charcuterie board, or the poached egg. I've never disliked a single thing I've ordered, and the staff is incredibly knowledgeable about the food. My friends and I come here almost every week, for the atmosphere as well as the great food. Great drinks too! The Sleepy Hollow is my favorite. A lot of things can be made gluten-free too (ex- they'll give you celery sticks instead of bread for the charcuterie), so just ask!

I ate at this joke on 12/26/11 for an early lunch.  Place is nasty.  my girl's lettuce was all wilted and gross.  We asked for a new side salad, and the kitchen obviously just went thorugh the existing salad and manually removed the lettuce pieces that had "turned".   
The restaurant was mostly empty (not suprised) and yet they were stacking overweight customers all around us.  How about some space, when you have an entire empty restaurant?  

I would never go back.

Sit on the patio. Admire the ambiance. Get whatever you want - Ali's Ideal was satisfying, yet light enough to avoid a food coma. The mascarpone tasted more like parmesan...but good nonetheless. The fried oysters are uniquely complemented by the pickled watermelon rinds. I wish it came with 6 instead of 5, because cutting an oyster in half to share is just...not necessary! :)

I heard about this place through my friend, super yelper Jaimie F. 

I went there the first time during warmer weather and sat outside. 
The atmosphere was pretty great considering how crowded Harvard Sq is. It's like your own nook with which you can observe the zaniness of Harvard Sq. (Actually during my first brunch the Harvard University marching band came through)  The second brunch, I was seated in the lower level, and despite the darkness it was still pleasant. 

The service is fantastic, young attentive waitstaff. 

The best part of Russell Tavern House is of course the most important. The food. i have tried the following:
* The pit master- Basic, not that exciting. It's pretty much protein/carb heaven, so if you're looking to indulge that what you're really looking for. 

* Toads in the hole- Egg in bread, again basic, but it comes w/ hash browns and they have seriously the best hash browns. yummmmm I am drooling on my keyboard, ah crap.... 

* French Toast- Delicious, if you prefer sweets in the morning. Not overwhelmingly sweet. it won't cost you a couple hundos to fill a cavity. 
The best part is that there's no powdered sugar all over it. Just simple wonderful french toast.

* Anti-Benedict- now for the pinnacle of nom nom nom. 
I have a soft spot for well made benedicts to begin with, but they took it to another level. I mean they kicked it up a notch, BLAM!  They panko breaded the egg and then flash fried it. O_O forreals. 
So, now imagine with me for a second a buttery english muffin topped with spinach and a fried egg that still maintains it's over easy egg yolk, drizzled with hollandaise.. uggghhh so good. It comes with the hash browns I gushed about earlier. So, these things are not good for your waistline, but I'm resigned to being content with an anti-benedict shaped extra pound tacked onto my butt just so I can eat this.

We visited Russell House Tavern last night, and was I surprised! The atmosphere was vibrant, the servers were attentive, the food was great. But what really seems to set RHT apart from other gastropubs is the favorable balance between the amount of effort and prices of the dishes. Everything we ordered - the crispy-soft poached farm egg, the steak tartare, the chicken liver crostini, and the torched tuna with anchovy oil - was thoughtfully conceived, perfectly plated, and accessibly priced. My Moscow Mules were not only blended well, but the ginger beer was housemade, and each was a mere $8. I plan to return, often, and recommend you do as well.

One of my favorite places for dinner in Harvard Square.  It is difficult to get in, so try to make a reservation, or come after 9 and the wait is much more reasonable.  The melted cambozola cheese appetizer is phenomenal!  I always want to try different things here, but keep coming back to the burger.  One of the best I have had in a long time.  Good selection of beer and wine.

Russell House is one of my favorite places in Boston, hands down.

I remember first stumbling upon this gastropub the first weekend I moved to Boston.  I was out with a couple of my friends, and we were barhopping in Harvard Square.  We happened to walk into Russell House, and never having been to this place before, we ventured downstairs.  Now, if you're not a regular at Russell House, you may not have realized that there is a downstairs, and if so, you'd really be missing out.  The ground floor seating area and bar is generally crowded and noisy, so I always walk straight downstairs, where the atmosphere is more refined and more intimate, with its leather booths, ambient lighting, dark woods, and vintage photographs.  Some of my most memorable nights out in Boston have been at Russell House - sitting downstairs in the leather booths, drinking wine, and having deep conversations with close friends all night long.  I could spend hours upon hours here.

It's obvious that I adore this place, but I must admit that I've never been blown away by anything on the menu.  Everything I've had (including the roasted giannone farm chicken, the pt. judith bluefish, the jonah crab cakes, and the melted cambozola cheese appetizer, among other things) has been good - even great - but nothing has ever been extraordinary.  However, their extensive wine, beer, and cocktail menu alone is worth coming here.  This is, after all, a tavern by name.

It's not often that I care more about an establishment's ambiance than I care about the food; in fact, I've been quoted saying that I would go just about anywhere for good food, regardless of atmosphere.  There are a number of places I could go to in Boston that serve better versions of what's on the menu here, but I simply don't care.  There are some places I go to in order to eat and run, but Russell House is a place I go to in order to eat and sit - it's the whole experience.

I came here with my girlfriend and my parents for an early lunch in a packed Harvard Square on our first day in Boston. The only reason we stopped here was because we were starving and it was the first place we saw that we all agreed on. Everyone else was satisfied with their meal except me. So lets break it down:

The atmosphere:  Pretty standard American tavern/restaurant, maybe a little more upscale. I could really care less about the decor as long as the food is good.

The service: By far THE creepiest waiter I've ever had. One line that became an inside joke for the rest of the weekend: "May I tempt you with some sweets?", spoken in a really creepy I'm not a stranger I have some candy in my car if you would just follow me sort of way. Not that it detracted from the experience it was just weird. In fact, now that i think about it, i should give this place an extra star just for making us laugh. 

The food: I ordered the crab cakes, which came two on a plate in between french bread. There was a tabasco aioli spread on the bread along with some greens and some fries. The crab cakes had no trace of crab in them , and were very greasy. The tabasco aioli just tasted like someone had mixed mayo and tabasco sauce and did not fit with the overall dish. At least there were fries. Thats about all there is to say.

Maybe I'm being harsh, but all i wanted was a decent, edible lunch. I guess that's too much to ask from this place.

VEGETARIANS BEWARE!

This place pulled one of the sleaziest moves. My girlfriend ordered the EBLT without bacon. It showed up with bacon, so we politely asked them to take it back and prepare a new one. I should have been suspicious when a new sandwich appeared within 5 minutes. When she opened up the "new" sandwich there was a half a strip of bacon still stuck to the bread. All they did was pull the bacon out and flip the sandwich over so it would look different.

For a place that tries to pass itself off as somewhat classy, a move like this is despicable and shows they have no respect for vegetarians.Really, really lame.

The manager came over and apologized profusely but offered no explanation for what they had done. The gesture of removing the charge for that sandwich from the bill was meaningless, as any rational person would expect that as a minimum, and also because by that point we were so angry and disgusted my girlfriend had no appetite.

First impression of RHT: Casually elegant. I did not realize that the restaurant was down stairs. The patio was gorgeous and in-bloom. Would be a great spot to enjoy a cocktail during the warmer months. 

I ordered the 'Angry Queen' pizza and it was DELICIOUS! Thin crust loaded with tomatoes and fresh basil. It was light and filling. I ended up needing a doggy bag! My friend went with the Short Rib Wellington. A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!!!! 

Upon my next visit, I will DEF be partaking in the 'Raw Bar' and ordering one of the tasty looking beverages on their drink menu. 

Russell House Tavern, you have whet my appetite and I'll be seeing you again this fall!

After receiving a message from the General Manager, we decided to give Russell House another shot.

We arrive on time for our reservation and were told to go downstairs. Which was weird, because I requested to sit outside. We were seated in a corner table. Same glasses with etch marks - one would think since I specifically mentioned this incident in my prior review they might have tried to avoid this, but they did not. My boyfriend and I both shrugged to one another and decided then that we should maybe count this place out.

And then comes our waiter. He was a lot of personality. At first, I was wairy, he was a little much to take in. I thought maybe he was trying too hard since I had previously commented on the service, but later decided that was his personality. I ended up loving our waiter, he was super attentive, informative without being condescending, and made us laugh.

One thing I noticed which was odd, people who I assume were hostesses and managers would kind of just slowly saunter around the dining room, some of them looking at us awkwardly. One woman who I assume was an assistant manager actually pointed at us and asked the hostess who we were. It made us feel really awkward. The General Manager came over to us and explained that he had a table opening up outside, but we decided to stay at the table we were seated at. Wish we had known prior to being sat at the table downstairs. He was a nice guy - asked us a few different times how things were and if we needed anything.

As far as the food and drink goes - I started with the City of Eternal Spring, which was light, sweet and bitter all at the same time. It was perfect. They really know how to make their cocktails here.

We got 4 oysters to start, followed by their steak tartare. It was savory, and melted in your mouth. My only comment is they only give two of the grilled pieces of brioche, but about a half cup of tartare, and could use at least four, if not six. We also ordered the Fiore Di Nonna Burrata, which was accompanied with purple shiso, house cured lonza, pickled raisins. The dish was so well balanced, and the presentation was great. We ordered four more oysters, which were perfect. I have never been disappointed with their raw bar.

For our entries, I ordered the steak frites again, since it was so perfect the prior time. I was a bit let down. I asked for the steak medium rare, but it was super rare, on the side of being blue. I ate what I could of it, but ended up leaving about 3 ounces of it for my boyfriend to eat because it was so rare. Fries were crispy and well seasoned, and their garlic aioli is awesome - savory and yet not too overpowering with the garlic. My boyfriend got the pork trio, and he was pleased. His cheesy grits were outstanding. I hate grits, but I loved these, they were creamy and salty and the perfect compliment for the dish. I could eat a bowl of just those grits.

We got the chocolate mouse cake with strawberry rhubarb compote and a chocolate ganache poured over the top. This was delicious, and satisfied my sweet tooth.

They were generous when it came to the bill, which was nice. Would I come back again? Maybe, I was impressed by a few things, and disappointed by a few as well. A list of about fifteen other places I want to try before coming back awaits.

Came here for a late (1 PM) lunch with friends while visiting the east coast. 

Friendly service: we were seated quickly and had a great waitress who was knowledgeable about the menu and happy to answer any questions we had. She also offered to split our check by what we each ordered at the end of the meal--super easy and nice.

Complementary sparkling and still water is provided.

We all ordered very different things, but each of us was happy with our dish. I had the daily flatbread special, which on that day had a corn puree as the sauce, and was topped with cheese and seasonal cherry tomatoes. It was so fresh and tasted like summer, not to mention an unconventional choice of flavors. It was perfectly crisp and a nice size for lunch. One friend loved the burger, which came on an English Muffin, and the other had a few pieces of fresh seafood from the raw bar, followed by the cast iron cambozola, which came in a cast iron pot, with flatbread for dipping.

We were seated at a communal hightop, but not crowded in with others. Hooks underneath are great for those with bags.

I just looked at the menu and saw other things I'd like to try, but I live across the country, so a return visit will have to wait for another day. I look forward to trying more on my next Boston-area visit!

I recently made reservations to this place on a Sunday night for my boyfriend and I. The hostess was a nice and directed us downstairs to be seated. Place was empty, except a few people at the bar and the hostesses downstairs weren't  paying attention and were chitchatting with each other until they noticed us waiting. Oh well. Eventually, they gave us a seat that was good and away from the bar TV. Which is a plus.

We ordered a bunch of food. Started out with the oysters and clams. Nice and fresh, so a huge plus. We had the steak tartare, house terrine, raw tuna, and crab cakes. Presentation was quite lacking and a little messy, but maybe they were having an off night. Regardless, steak tartare, tuna and crab cakes were excellent. We also had a few glasses of the house wine on tap which was a great pairing. 

We ended the night with dessert. I had the chocolate hazelnut torte and my boyfriend had the carrot bread pudding. Both good and a nice end to the evening. 

Overall, a decent dining experience.
A bit too upscale for my taste, but a nice date spot. Food and drink were near impeccable, I'd found.

I bet that this is the sort of place that will earn more stars for me the more I go here, but my early impressions have left me in the middle of the road.

Everything that people are raving about - the raw bar, the beer/wine and cocktail selection - this didn't really do much for me. The beer list was certainly impressive, and the organic ale both the hubster and I had was delicious, and reasonably priced.

Had we come here for drinks, we probably would have been very happy. But we came for dinner, and the food was just a bit overpriced for what it was. I had a burger, which quadrupled my caloric intake for the day, and hubs had the hearth-baked pasta gratin, which tasted like it had been roasted in a smokehouse, not baked on a hearth. I was really turned off by the fact that extra side dishes cost $6 each - we're talking a side of spinach, fries, etc. Maybe my blue-collar roots are showing (gasp!), but my feeling is that sides should be $3-4. This disappointed me.

Seating was cozy, in the midst of a communal table, but the waitstaff were a bit slow and awkward. They were inches away from splattering us with a dropped tub of ketchup, and several other items went cascading to the floor throughout the night, just behind our backs.

I'll come back here for drinks and oysters with the girls sometime, and undoubtedly my impression of the place will rise, as it does when delicious drinks and foggy, laughter-infused memories are involved.

I love coming to the bar for lunch on my day off.  I am in the service industry myself, and I would like to think I know a little about service. Marshall, the upstairs bartender, is the man! He is knowledgeable, polite and entertaining.  Thanks to Marshall's hospitality, I continue to go to Russell House for a nice lunch. (And I bring my friends and family!)

Avoid this place. They ran out of cetchup, all salad dressings, med-well burger was extremely rare. They also ran out of 2 of the 5 specials by noon but it couldn't have been due to the high demand, they place was not busy. The food they did have was decent  but they try to put a high class spin on their entrees but they dont pull it off. The staff was very nice and good decor but definitely won't be going back.

Up until my dinner trip to Russell House Tavern, if you said "Pigface" to me, I would have thought you were talking about the industrial rock superband. This place has forever changed that association for me. 

I was a little nervous when my dinner companion suggested we share the pig head appetizer. I can be a little timid about food, so I tried to talk him out of it, but with no success. I agreed to at least try it. After all, it wouldn't come in full noggen form, just pulled pork fashion.

It arrived in a breaded sphere topped with a tomato sauce and grated cheese, which almost made me forget about its origin. I ate pig face. And it was really good! 

We also had some really spectacular drinks from their cocktail menu. My burger and fries were definitely above-average quality (what can I say? I really wanted a burger that night)! 

The atmosphere was nice, the service pretty good, and the location next to the Harvard Square T stop can't be beat. I'd definitely be interested in sampling some other items from the menu.

The truth is, Russell House is probably even cooler than I even know, but I'm really looking forward to my pending investigation.
I came here on a weekday, it was much more chill. They also have $1 oyster specials after 11pm on weekdays, they were delish!

I don't often Yelp after my first visit somewhere, but I am smitten.

My wife and I went there for an early bite on New Year's Eve, and we sat at the (curiously uncrowded, but it was early) bar in the pub upstairs, so I don't have anything on the downstai

I went here for lunch-so yummy!  The appetizers were the winners for me: cauliflower and veal cheek soup and a smoked mozzarella salad.  
For entrees, I had the short rib wellington and my boyfriend had the fish and chips (which were homemade waffle potat

In my experience, you can get a much cheaper, better meal elsewhere in Boston. Yes, the ambience was excellent (very intimate and classic), but the food was mediocre and the service was a bit lacking.

I love eating here for brunch, dinner and lunch. My go-tos are always the burger with bacon and cheese on the english muffin, the soft poached egg, the pizza and the pork trio. The dessert and cocktail menus have something for everyone whether you want something sweet or tangy. For brunch, get the benedict or the breakfast pizza. The anti-bendict is awesome since is the crispy soft poached egg and eggs benedict combined. 

Sit downstairs if you want to take your date here and definitely make a reservation! The bar is great as well for watching games.

After attending a concert in the area, ended up here  and was wonderfully surprised. I'm a (recovering?) french fry addict and the fries here are tasty and crispy--homemade greatness! The pizza with ricotta was very good, as was the crab cake. The salad with house-made smoked almonds hooked my attention, but the greens needed more dressing (and I usually complain about too much dressing). Server was a doll and coursed our meal of small plates perfectly.

Only suggestion: the outside bricked patio needs something... plants, flowers? Nice small spot, but felt like an alley between two tall brick buildings.

Russell House is my favorite "classy" bar in the Cambridge area. The drink selection is impeccable, but be prepared to pay $10 for that lovely cocktail (plus tip). They can charge that much while bringing in the crowds because this place has the perfect location: right around the corner from the Harvard Square T-stop.

Try to get a seat upstairs if you can--it's quieter, and you're likely to get faster service, especially at the small bar. But the larger downstairs area isn't bad either. (Plus, that's where the restrooms are...)

Favorite cocktail: "The Last Word" (unless I'm trying to impress someone with my manliness, in which case, "Moscow Mule").

Here is my problem with restaurants in Harvard Square:  When you have restaurants in college towns, especially one where people have more money than common sense, you tend to get mediocrity. Lets face it, there will be plenty of others who will readily take your seat once you take your disappointed tookas out the door. And, the servers are usually young, inexperienced college students who will work for low wages and, lets face it, usually door a less than stellar job. This detracts from your dining/drinking experience, while the owners reap large profits. RHT is "good." It could be great, but that would mean owners reinvesting in their employees, and seeking customer feedback to drive satisfaction.  Go for the drinks if anything.

Pretty good, but I wasn't super wowed. 

Had a bunch of the small plates (and boy do they mean SMALL! like two dumplings small), which were all tasty but overpriced. Bone marrow was good. Also tried a few veggie sides which were hits for us. And a special blue fish terrine, which was kind of meh.

Oysters were fresh and so were clams. If I'm in the area again, I'd probably stick to the booze and the raw bar.

Nice space, I love the way they use the courtyard for outdoor seating.
We hosted a party at RHT and it could not have been better.  Tyler and the team went far above and beyond anything we could have expected, and we're really grateful for all of their efforts!

Sorry for being a mean bitch, but seriously if you want to call yourself "gastropub" you have to bring out some gourmet dishes.

1. Local leaf salad: terrible presentation, way too oily. I can make this at home with a more beautiful look and a much more balanced taste.
2. Crispy pig's head: it is a piece of lukewarm meat patty. Period. I almost feel like i was sitting in McDonald.
3. Seared arctic char: The fish is cooked very well, but the sauce is so creamy that it ruins the whole dish.
4. Pork trio: gosh why does this dish get so many rave reviews? All the compliments for four or five pieces of meat of mediocre texture and flavor under a bunch of leaves? It is horrible to look at and boring to taste.

HUGE LETDOWN. Maybe I expected too much "gastro" from a pub. Oh did i mention the table has leftover oil on it and the waitress is acting like she hates her job? Yes, definitely one star.

I love dinner here. The menu is chock-full of tasty and creative dishes and drinks. Particularly love the chip-in-egg, which is great even without the pancetta for the vegetarians.

I discovered Pimm's No 1., a liqueur at Russel House through the Battle of Trafalgar drink. Recommended. 

Service - good - the right balance of inattentive and over-attentive. I had to flag our waitress a couple times, but she was easy to find as she'd often be one table or two away from us.

Ambiance - it does get loud, so try to be seated in a corner or cut off area.

Food: 
The best:
Chip in Egg: Try it. basically a poached egg with a fried surface.
Battle of Trafalgar (drink) - the right combo of sweet and astringent, for those who like an alcohol-y kick to a drink
The Andria - a slightly sweet and nicely rich pizza
Chocolate Chunk Bread Pudding - If you like chocolate, vanilla ice cream, and bread pudding, this is made for you.

The good:
House-Made Cotechino Sausage pizza: Well made sausage makes a tasty but simple pizza
Honey & Chili Roasted Brussels Sprouts - I love this vegetable, especially roasted with garlic, which is how they did it. only thing was, I couldn't taste the honey or chili
Carrots - good and well seasoned with thyme
Pommes Frites - Like for the most part but ~30% of the fries had a poor crispy outside to soft inside ratio, namely, too much crispy outside, not enough soft inside
Orange Panna Cotta - I have not had much panna cotta so this may mostly be personal preference. It just tasted like a sweet, slightly spiced rasgula (an indian milkfat-based dessert) or a thicker creme of a creme-brûlée.

We split everything 3 ways (and everyone got 1 drink each) and came out to $40 each with tax and tip included.

And now we know we never have to come here again...

We were debating places to go for brunch/lunch today and looked up some menus for Harvard Square. Andy was craving fish and chips and his craving was stronger than my craving for steak and egg tacos from Tory Row so we went to RHT.

Apparently, RHT's lunch menu isn't available during brunch on Sunday, despite their online menu stating that lunch starts at 11, but whatever.

So niether Andy nor I got to indulge our cravings for lunch. 

I got a rather uninspired grilled cheese with tomatoes and bacon. It came with soggy oily french fries, a wimpy pickle that was past it's prime, ketchup, and a little container of mayo that was crusted over on top (appetizing, no?). If I'm going to spend $9 on a grilled cheese, it better be special, like come on artisan bread or have something better than generic cheese on it.

Andy got a cuban-like "Spanish" sandwich. He found it to be very bland, despite claiming to have harissa on it. I tried it and found it to taste like liquid smoke and nothing more. His greens looked fresh though.

$3 for a sprite? WTF is that?

The waitress was friendly enough and the space is pretty cool, but I don't know that we will come back here based on the food alone.

A refreshing new wind is blowing into Cambridge. The former z-square cafe spot had its doors closed for so long, but I went to the opening night where Michael Scelfo (Temple Bar) as executive chef. I would say it's best described as contemporary American. They try to honor the communal Harvard square philosophy by sourcing locally.  

Prices range from cheap small plates at $5 a piece to pricier entrees getting close to $30. The lamb belly & steak frites are a must. 

I will say that service was a bit slow and sporadic, but i'm writing that off to the fact that it was opening night. I look forward to going back soon.

BRUNCH was incredible.  I've  been here twice now for brunch and both times it was flawless.  

The most important thing to know:  get the Anti-Benedict.  It's a twist on your classic eggs benedict but the egg is flash-fried in a crispy golden brown shell...still fresh and runny on the inside, but crispy and delicious on the outside.  Add some delicious spinach and the whole thing comes together to make the best breakfast plate I've ever had.

I'd also recommend the Daily Buns.  Apparently they're different all the time but on the one occasion I had them they were awesome.  Nothing like cina-buns are anything like that.  I honestly wouldn't know how to describe but that in itself sort of describes them.  

All in all the Brunch menu isn't huge but it's packed with delicious treats.  Every plate on there has the potential to be somebody's favorite plate.

I've officially become a fan of Russell House Tavern. On several occasions I've gathered large groups of friends, had a small intimate dinner, and just met for a few rounds of drinks. Each time I was pleased with the service and the food.

You can't go wrong with any of the delish cocktails they whip up and the wine on tap is perfect for those that want to support their local winemakers (get the Rose!).

I'm happy to report that their mashed potatoes are what dreams are made of, the Dirty Ceasar salad could be a meal in itself, and the torched tuna is delectable.
Solid brunch choice!  I like to sit at the bar upstairs - great place to un-hangover your self.

I really like this space. You have three different places that you can sit, depending on your mood/demeanor. There's an indoor pub area, or the downstairs area that is more upscale and "swanky". 

We chose outdoor seating for our particular afternoon lunch, and were given the lunch/brunch menu.

We ordered the grilled cheese, tomato and bacon on brioche, the bacon on the side (my 6 year old requested to just eat bacon for lunch) and a local green salad. 

Everything was amazing and fresh, but what I loved the most were the fries, and the aioli that is served with them.  Very tasty and fresh.

And I also loved the use of real cheese on my sandwich. A lovely Cabot cheddar. What's with the New England obsession with processed "American" cheese?  Do New Englanders enjoy putting poison orange squares in their bodies? Yuck.

I'd like to go back to try some of the breakfast items, which all sounded amazing from the menu descriptions. I'm also going to go back for a "date" night for the downstairs area. I hope it will take me into a 1940's era of nostalgia, like the decor suggests.

And of course I will go to the pub. I am human, therefore I do drink beer.

the first time i've been to russell house was when i was visiting someone from harvard. we wanted to go out to eat and we came across russell house. the environment of the restaurant is very different from the restaurant in california (where i am from). there were a bunch of people crowded around the bar area and the restaurant was a bit noisy. the lighting is dim but the feel of the place is lively. great place for socializing.

all the food is tasty and the service is not bad. the one thing i suggest is the volcano lava dessert as it have drip of spice which gives an interesting flavor.

the only thing i wish for is that the restaurant is a little bit bigger so it can accommodate the amount of people there but i am from california so i'm used to open area/space.

Had an early dinner here last week to catch a show at Regattabar. Sat upstairs and watched the room fill up and the noise level increase to the point where no "inside voice" could be heard. While  the food presentation was creative and attractive, it just did not taste that good to me.
