(except the oysters, esp. the Island Creeks) My companion and I shared the lamb cassoulet (off-tasting and "spare me the lamb belly from now on") the figs in a blanket (pretty tiny and a bit overcooked) a salad (underdressed), the charceuterie platter (some things better than others) and a cheeseburger (served on a toasted english muffin, which seemed to enhance the overall dryness of the meat) I was impressed with the drink menu and liked the wine on tap selections from Westport Winery in SE MA. Service was great....Kevyn was attentive and knowledgeable about food and drink menus. But overall, I will think of this place as less "gastro" and more "PUB."

Outstanding!  I totally love this place!!!!

The menu is awesome!  The small plates are crazy!  We had bone marrow, beef heart ravioli, lamb bellies - everything was amazing!

We waited for an outside table (too cute - in the courtyard-ish area, so you're outside, not not on the sidewalk) in the downstairs bar area....the bartenders were amazing - helpful, courteous - its like they were from another era.  

Actually all the staff was amazing - from the hostesses to bartenders to our waitress - they were polite and helpful incarnations of the JCrew catalogue - loved them!

And did I mention the food?  In addition to the funky small plates we ordered, we had the lobster sliders, deviled eggs and some amazing "pome frites" .  Everything was delish!  Five stars for this place - I can't wait to go back.

It was love at first sight for me at Russell House Tavern.  Or maybe I should say first sip or bite?  I am seriously enamored of this place, and see no signs of the fire dying in the foreseeable future.

Why?  Because I love everything about this place, duh.  I sort of view Russell House as the bar equivalent of a Create Your Own Adventure book.  You can hang out upstairs or downstairs (or even outside?!), you can drink beer, wine (on TAP), or cocktails (pitchers of St. Germain cocktail, anyone?), and your meal can consist of simple fare (burger / salad)  or something slightly more adventurous (oysters/charcuterie plate/lamb stomach pizza).  However you play it, one thing is certain: it will be delightful and you will be a winner.

I would be remiss if I failed to praise the staff of Russell House.  Scott, one of the waiters, takes service seriously.  He is charming, witty, has great facial recognition, and is attentive even when the house is packed (which is often).  He once entertained three of my girls and me while we were seated next to a table of twenty Harvard Business School bros...yikes.  Everyone behind the bar is exceptionally skilled at slinging cocktails; Lou and Aaron, the Bar Manager, definitely deserve mad props and major shout-outs.  I could continue this valentine, but I think you get my drift...

This place is perpetually alive on a weekend, and probably most non-weekends too.  LOVE the vibe here and the beer list, cocktail list, and food list all totally hit the spot.  5 of us with multiple rounds of drinks came out to a grand total of ... $250 with tip!  Not at all bad, considering the number of oysters that were sacrificed that night, empty beer bottles, and empty hamburger bun bags that hit Cambridge garbage pails city-wide.  We had:
- the oysters (@ $2.50, a little pricey ... ?$1 oysters all the time would be a much better move, considering there's probably a tonne of profit that comes in from all the drinks that go with the oysters)
- the Andria pizza (which was really tasty, albeit a little on the sweet side)
- the Pan Seared Blue Fish with beans (which was apparently AMAZING... the beans led to some gastrointestinal madness later, but I digress)
- the R. House Grass Fed Burger (which my friends cleaned off their plates, which is indicative of something good I think)
The food was awesome and we've been back here with friends a few times already.  Good spot to impress, and eat + drink like Harvard kings.  Reservations are also a MUST for weekends.

Food is well prepared and well executed. Downstairs dining room keeps you away from the potential busy upstairs bar area.

Good selection in beer and a good range of different types of food.

Unlike the pompous "poor" reviews we are seeing from some of these so-called "foodies" -- this restaurant is bringing some much needed class and character to tired Cambridge scene.  And as a side note to the reviewers who call the food uninspired, the head and sous chef from Upstairs on The Square frequent this classic and flavorful spot -- a testament to the unique, Europe-esque cuisine found at Russell House Tavern.  

I am constantly wishing there was a place in Cambridge where I felt comfortable trying anything on the menu, something like a Franklin Cafe but without the hassle of driving to Boston's empirical South End.  Tonight I had a special dinner here, sat by the window on a cool summer evening, and enjoyed literally every bite of food I tasted.  We started with a Torched Tuna -- a delicious, sashimi grade plate of tuna with basil, olive oil and generous flavors that was gone within seconds.  We were so impressed with the tuna we chose to almost double our order, having a Short Dirty Caesar with spicy anchovy croutons: a dish I would describe as flavorful but not heavy -- a terrific second course.

For Entrees, we enjoyed a Hearth Baked Pasta and Steak Frites, my personal favorite.  The pasta again combined a medley of flavors without being too heavy, but the real award winner was the side sauce served with the Frites -- a Garlic Aioli that was decadent and unmatched as a Frite dipping sauce.  I asked our waiter for the recipe.  We paired these entree's with a Mushroom Gratin side; simply unique and flavorful.  

Although the food was above my expectations for a restaurant that took over the uninspired Z-Square Cafe, the real show stealer was our waiter, Peter H.  Peter was calm, confident, and well informed about every item on the menu.  His demeanor and professionalism echoed that of the restaurant itself.  

Simply put, Cambridge is generally peddling shit as classy food.  Tory Row, Grafton Street, Om, Upstairs on the Square; all these places are charging Boston prices for suburban food.  They are ok places if the prices were more reasonable but generally nothing above your average higher-end chain spot.  Cambridge is not Boston and the restaurants solidify this dichotomy.  

Russell is a great place to relax, enjoy a mindfully created meal and world-class service.  Until Franklin Cafe relocates to Cambridge (hopefully in place of some uninspired, overpriced generic spot) I will frequent the RHT for a meal that opens my mind to new flavors at an appropriate price.  I hope they are here to stay.

My daughter and I went here today for brunch. Simply put: 100% bad. We thought we'd take a break from our low carb and indulge. Boy, did we make a huge mistake. The "french toast" with nutella and bananas came out looking like soggy toast. I didn't even bother to look in between the yuk. Totally unappealing. My daughter tasted it but we left it pretty much uneaten. We also ordered the omelet, and my daughter wanted to try the biscuit instead of toast. The biscuit was a huge yellow mount of paste. The omelet...barely edible. We ate half of the omelet but did not touch the biscuit. The coffee was a thick bottom-of-the-pot murky mud. Not drinkable. The woman next to us ordered salad...but the plate of field greens looked monotonous and she also gave up half way, with a dissatisfied expression on her face. Yelp gives this place an overall 4 stars?? Really?? I am telling everyone I know not to go here. Even Z-Sq was better than this and only the soup and one or 2 other thing were ok then. We wished we could have asked for 100% of our money back. Save yours and go elsewhere.

My friends and I were planning our weekend trip to Boston and I told them I would find us a place to dine.  As luck would have it, my dear Queens Community Manager, Leighann, had filled the role of Boston Community Manager in the past.  So one afternoon while we and a group of other Yelpers lunched on dosas in the canteen of a Hindu temple in Flushing, I asked her to recommend a restaurant where four people could go for a nice dinner in Boston that's not going to poke a hole in our wallets.  Russell House Tavern, she said.  Ok, Russell House Tavern it was to be.

Russell House Tavern is located in Harvard Square, which was perfect for us because my friends had wanted to visit Harvard.  So we spent a couple of hours touring the neighbourhood and arrived at the restaurant for our 9pm reservation.  We made our way downstairs and were led to a table for four that was ready for us.  A Celtics play-off game was on TV so guys at the bar were watching and talking about the game over beer, getting excited whenever someone scored.  Together with the classy decor and low lighting, it created such a warm and friendly environment that at the same time felt upscale.  

A quick glance over the entrees on the menu and the Ozark Heritage Pork Trio immediately popped out at me.  Grilled loin?  Yes.  Confit belly?  Yes!  Smoked shoulder!  YES!  For an appetiser I decided on the Jonah Crab Cakes, which consisted of sweet pickle tartar, candy beet, and apple salad.  And I also ordered a Peak Organic Nut Brown Ale for refreshment.  

The crab cakes were soft and tasty, and the beer was delicious as well.  But I was truly impressed with the Ozark Heritage Pork Trio.  When I bit into the pork shoulder for the first time, I thought to myself: holy shit are you shitting me?  I mean, this was awesomely delicious.  It was so very tender and juicy, like it had been cooking in a slow cooker all day.  And the flavours were so full, savoury, and satisfying.  Seriously, I couldn't get enough.  I probably could have ordered a second plate.  

I am definitely going back to Russell House Tavern the next time I am in Cambridge, and I can't thank Leighann enough for the recommendation.

I would have given Russell House Tavern four stars but for the service.  Let me begin with a list of what was bad and then I'll get into what's pretty good.

--I inquired about availability while waiting to meet a friend.  The hostess was very snooty about not having a reservation.  She suggested we could try downstairs, and the extremely clear unspoken message was "as that is where the worthless plebians eat."

--When my friend arrived 30 minutes later, all the tables that were empty when I first went in were still empty.  I *do* believe that they had reservations, but they obviously are having severe growing pains about how to allocate them.  There were roughly 15 spots in the upstairs section sitting empty in the 30 minute span of time I was waiting and other non-reservation people were coming in and inquiring.

--Neither the hostess upstairs nor downstairs suggested we could eat at the bar instead of waiting, which I thought was odd.

--Our waitress was pathetically amateurish at upselling.  She tried to tell me the small plates "Little Local Salad" was tiny and not enough to share.  When it arrived, it was *clearly* plenty for one (not on its own of course, but as part of the whole meal) and perfect for sharing amongst other small plates.  

--Our waitress was AGRESSIVELY trying to turn and burn us.  She tried to clear our plates, I am not kidding, *eight times* before we were actually done.  We stayed for two hours but it was annoying to have to fight off the waitress every fifteen minutes.  

--Along the turn-and-burn lines, all of what we ordered arrived at once.  Granted, we ordered some random things, but I don't think it's my job to set the pace of how orders come out.  

The generally unpleasant and uncaring service was a real downfall for me.  The total cost of our meal before tip was $45/person, which is no small chunk of change.  For god's sake people, if you want to promote yourself as an upscale gastropub where people spend money, then let them linger and enjoy themselves.  


OK, now here's what's good.  Despite the shittay service, the atmosphere is fantastic.  We did sit downstairs and even though it wasn't as breezy as upstairs, it was extremely welcoming and cozy.  It's easy to relax and wile away the hours here (well, theoretically).

The drinks are out of this world.  First we split a pitcher of the St. Germain cocktail, which was splendid.  I could have drank that for the rest of my life.  However, I would not recommend getting the pitcher, despite it's refreshingness.  It seems like a good deal, but if you're looking to actually get intoxicated, it's a better deal to order one cocktail at a time.  I suspect the St. Germain pitcher has a lot more soda water and ice than wonderful booze.

For "dessert," I had the Champs Elysee (sorry if spelling is off...I thought their drinks menu would be online but it's not) and my friend had the Moscow Mule.  Shazam!  Those bitches were strong and tasted fantastic.  

The menu is quite eclectic and fun.  There's a raw bar, appetizers, small plates, pizzas and fancypants entrees.  We had a hodgepodge of things:

--1. Two oysters apiece
--2. The aforementioned Little Local Leaf Salad
--2a. The small plates Jonah crab cake
--3. The butcher's choice pizza

...and that is the order in which those things would have come out if I'd had my druthers/been the waitress.  But I digress.  The point is, there is an assortment of options here for sharing, indulging, and just plain enjoying.  The oysters were fresh and their accompanying sauces were perfectly piquant.  The "little" salad was very refreshing with just the right balance of flavors between the figs, walnut and mustard.  The crab cake on its own was too salty but eaten with the greens and sauce (which is surely how its intended) its great.  The butcher's choice pizza also walked the line of being almost too salty, but juuuust managed to keep it light and tasty.

So...I don't know.  The food and atmosphere is wonderful and the restaurant fills a long empty niche in Harvard Square (both in terms of the defunct Z-Square and the need for some upscale casual dining).  But the attitude of the service is just bad and pretty off-putting, as well as their incompetence at managing reservations.  I guess I would recommend always having a reservation if you go here, and if you are ordering small items to share, order them one or two at a time to counter the server's attempt to turn and burn you.

So I went here for lunch to see if I liked it. Wowza!!! Loved the grilled cheese with tomato and bacon. The fries are delish too! I am definitely going to come with my boyfriend to do dinner and drinks. I am dying to try the crispy fried egg!

Topline: Interesting menu with delicious and unique dishes, as well as some standards for less adventurous eaters. Thoughtful and unusual beer list. Appealing French gastropub decor (though becoming commonplace in Boston).

Details:

The bar: It gets crowded, but if you can find a seat (or a patch of floor to stand on), Russell House is a good place to drink beer. The bartenders know the beers on draft well and can make educated recommendations. They have Left Hand Milk Stout on draft, and were offering a "pre-mixed black and tan" beer called Shabbadoo by BBC last time we were here that I thought was pretty awesome.

The restaurant: You know how I described the Shabbadoo as "awesome"? That's because it was one of only a few adjectives our server knew. Don't get me wrong, he was a good waiter, but as one of my friends pointed out: It would be helpful to get a better description of a dish than "awesome" or "really good." He wasn't really able to provide vivid descriptions of tastes or textures to help us decide on a choice (though we did opt against the burger when he was unable to christen it "awesome"). Aside from the awesome issue, service was excellent.

So what did we order? As one friend put it, "the menu." We shared several plates to start:

-Deep fried poached egg. This was pretty cool. I don't really like egg yolks but was willing to give this a try. There wasn't much yolk in my portion, but damn was this delicious (and weird). This was texturally confusing in a good way, like something you'd see on Top Chef. 

-Bone marrow. Meh. It needed salt, in my opinion. I loved the little toast squares it was served with, though.

-Pig head. Nommin'. I liked this pig head dish better than the one at Coppa; it was topped with yet another egg and sat in a puddle of a delicious sweet sauce.

-Fried oysters (on special). Another meh. It was supposedly served with a "slab" of bacon, but this amounted to about half a strip. Oysters have such a delicate flavor that I think they're wasted on frying. 

-Short rib Wellington. Served in a ramekin, and looks more like a pot pie. Tasty, but weird to share among the table. Probably the least memorable dish we had.

-Liverwurst (the "special pate"). I'm not a huge liverwurst fan, but this was pretty good. It didn't have that overwhelming coppery taste liver sometimes can. The liverwurst lovers among us gave this a thumbs up.

For an entree, I had the roast chicken. It was nothing special, though I would have licked those mashed potatoes off the plate if I'd been alone. Of the other entrees our table ordered, the winner seemed to be the pork trio, which featured three distinct pork dishes. 

The dessert menu looked awesome, but I didn't want to strain the integrity of my intestines any further. I had to say no.

Next time I come to Russell House, I'd like to try a different set of items to explore the other menu options. I'll probably get the egg and/or the pig head again since those are the two dishes that keep coming back to me in delicious daydreams.

The folks at cardullo's told me that this place was superb and i was anxious already to give it a try, so my friend and i had dinner here. She tried one of the small plates, which was in fact quite small (think tapas) but delicious. I ordered the steak for dinner and that too was excellent. I will say that I didnt think the portion was quite as large as i would have expected for the price, but it was delicious. the service was perfect for an upscale restaurant and nobody seemed to mind that we weren't really dressed for the upscale appearance.  The dessert menu wasn't as exciting as we'd hoped, so we passed on it. I'd love to see them add more dessert items, it seems only natural considering the HUGE list of alcoholic beverages. All in all, a great place to try for lunch or a cozy dinner.

A great selection of beers on tap.  Newfangled cocktails which are pretty good, but generally on the sweet side.  The food was surprisingly good (since I figured the upstairs and downstairs bars were the main draw).  Oysters with pickle mignionette, slow lamb shank (excellent), carrot cake+ice cream dessert.

I read about this place in an issue of Improper Bostonian and have been dying to try it. First off, I was really impressed by the atmosphere. The space is much bigger than I anticipated, and boasts 2 floors and 2 bars. The upstairs looks like a great place to hang out with friends or colleagues after work. and they have a great beer list, wine list, and cocktail offering.

I made my reservation on Open Table, but considering it was midweek I probably didn't have to. The staff were very friendly, sometimes bordering on theatrical though. They may have been overly trained to avoid the usual Boston-speak and cater to the intellectual crowd, but that's totally my assumption.

We got the steak tar tar (really good, definitely needs the crostinis to bring out the flavors), the burger, the chicken (the one with carrots and mash) and the softshell crab (was the fish market special for that day). The crab was so-so for me. The batter was interesting, had a slight cinnamon flavor that really complemented the crab), but I noticed under better lighting that my toasted bread thingy was a bit charred. The burger went down well, though the bacon wasn't omitted as requested, maybe upon better judgment, and the chicken was much enjoyed by my boyfriend (and dog) when I finally got home that evening.

I would definitely dine here again. Love the atmosphere, really excited about the menu. Love that it's a lot of local ingredients and daring. AND very affordable.

UPDATE
6/14/10
I tried to hold off on this update, hoping the situation would be resolved quickly. When my friend and I had dinner I gave her $100 cash towards the bill (which was about $100). She gave the waitress $80 and asked her to put the rest on her card, where she would leave the tip. She failed to notice until the next day that she had been charged the full bill on her card, so the waitress pocketed the cash. Granted, she did sign the receipt, but an $80 tip on a $96 bill? Who assumes that? We don't even look like ballers. Anyways, she did call the restaurant and they told her they would refund her the overpaid amount. Today the charge went through and they charged her the full amount. She will be calling again tomorrow. Hopefully it was just a timing thing and it will be resolved ASAP. Removing a couple stars while I wait...

Woot! All resolved! The manager (I think it was the manager) called my friend to make sure everything went through (took a while to get updated in the banking system.

Got a great window seat, had the hamburger, and my husband had the pork sandwich.  Each was excellent.  As much as I loved my hamburger (would have preferred a ciabatta bun instead of English muffin, as the muffin was just too small), I really loved the salad, which was simply mixed greens and a light olive oil, barely garlicky dressing -- not overly garlicky at all.  My husband didn't think there was any dressing on it, but it was just very light and refreshing.  Great atmosphere, pleasant, quick service.

I'd actually been looking forward to trying this place for a while, but had never made it in.  I've been feeling particularly disappointed by options in Harvard Square these days, and so on our way home we decided - hey - it's about time.  Some sweet parking karma aided us in our hunger adventure, and in we went.

The atmosphere is fine - it feels slightly schizo, reminding me a little of Neptune Oyster, but also an old Italian place, but then again a Tavern-type (i assume this is the goal hence the name) via some of the seating.  Our hostess attempted to sit us at one of the small two person tables squished in between a bunch of other folks, but I asked for seats at the near-empty tall tables instead.  She was quite accommodating - good choice for privacy, maybe not so much for comfort as the stools have no backs and rock either side to side or back and forth depending on how it's situated (not just mine - my boyfriend's did too).

I was surprised to find there actually wasn't a ton on the menu I was excited to order - maybe this is cause of the prices...I'll get to that.

I was particularly intrigued by the Crispy Soft Poached Chip in Farm Egg, so I ordered that and the Roasted Chicken.  The first time our waitress came to take our order I wasn't quite ready, though my boyfriend had decided on the RIbeye from the moment he picked up the menu - love at first sight.  The second time round I was ready and placed my order.  My boyfriend ordered his steak, only to be told they didn't have it tonight and he should try the steak frites instead.  I'm sorry, but I feel like this is one of the biggest mistakes servers/restaurants make these days, ESPECIALLY when your prices are this high.  WHY DIDN'T YOU TELL US WHEN WE ARRIVED??  Sorry for the caps, this just really frustrates me.  Also, it's the most expensive thing on your menu - why wouldn't you tell us.  And you're suggesting the steak frites instead of a Rib Eye?  I'm sorry, that's just sacrilegious.  Whatever, he ordered the pork trio (which I had actually been excited about anyways).

An aside - our waitress turned out to be super duper spacey.  The food came out really slowly, and instead of playing it off tactfully, she came over, kind of stared at our empty table blankly, looked at us and was like, "Oh, um, that's weird - I'll check with the kitchen I'm sure your food is coming right out."   Something to keep in mind is that the restaurant was not very busy at this time.   A few minutes later our food came.  Our waitress came over about 30 seconds later and started to ask how it was, but instead said, "Oh, you just got it didn't you?"  She looked sheepish and walked away.  Then she came back a few minutes later, briefly didn't remember why she was there, and said, "Okay, so how is it now?"  The whole thing was just weird, and mildly uncomfortable.

But, lets get down to business. 
-There was no bread basket.  If your appetizers are all basically $9 and up, your small plates are tiny and around the same price range, and it takes longer than is normal for food to hit the table...sorry, but you should have a bread basket.
-The egg was good.  Didn't blow my mind, but it was worth ordering.  Maybe not worth it's price since it's not super shareable, but whatever.  Also, if many of the other small plates are really that small, don't bother.
-The chicken was dry.  Like, really dry.  Like, I had made better chicken at my house a few days earlier (not kidding).  The potatoes were also dry.  The carrots were...gross.  I left much of each part of my meal on the plate.
-The grits that came under the pork trio were really good, though there was probably an 1/8 of a cup total on the plate, spread out, and covered in salad.  
-The pork belly tasted like spare ribs with no flavor (see Citizen Public House for some pork belly that'll knock your socks off with flavor).  The smoked pork tasted like...smoked pork - points there I guess.  The pork loin was crazy dry.

So, RHT, you make me sad - I really really REALLY wanted to like you, but in the end you made Tory Row (which I wasn't a huge fan of in the first place) the better option for the square.  

If you're trying to be what I think you're trying to be, either make better food, or lower your prices.  Or, better yet, both!

Love this place. Awesome fish, really good pizza, the pork trio was yummy. Great bourbon / whiskey cocktails. Some of their appetizers seem pretty novel and seem legitimately interesting to foodies. If you like gastropubs, you'll probably love this place!

BEST LAMB I HAVE EVER HAD.

The place is fairly new and the waitress noted that they were short staffed which is why we gave her leeway when it took a little while to get drinks and also to place our order. We mentioned bread (as we saw other people getting it) and with an apology we got bread all night long, all night (as sung by Lionel Richie). For the mistakes that were made, they made up for it full force in the absolutely yummilicious food. I said multiple times throughout my meal, that I was eating the best lamb I had ever had. It was so good. We got comped some coffee for the "trouble" which there wasn't really any detrimental to speak of. Our waitress was friendly and attentive as she could be, the food was delicious and the setting was nice.

Let them work out their kinks and this place will be awesome!

Awww man! I wish I had a bad experience so I could write a funny review. Alas, all I got out of it was a great meal and some fine tasty beers. That'll have to do.

We started with the Foie Gras and Laphroig Terrine, which is apparently French for delicious. It comes with cherry gelee, which is exciting because I feel like Marcel from Top Chef would have made it. All in all, a delicious little dish, creamy and salty in all of the right ways (okay, gay boys... stop snickering... even I can't deny that sentence sounds really inappropriate).

For entrees, I got The Andria flatbread pizza, a delicious little pizza with lots of cheese, sweet garlic and figs. Figs. Garlic. Perfect. So good. My date tried the White Clam flatbread, which smelled delightful. I didn't quite try it as I didn't want to go into anaphylactic shock, but it apparently tastes great. We'll take his word for it.

The beer list runs pretty deep. It also includes one of my favorites, Left Hand Milk Stout. We were certainly happy with the options of beer. Our server, while clearly swamped, was still kind enough to talk to us about her favorite beers and what she likes to drink them with...

The place was super packed. It was a Wednesday night at the peak of dinner time. We didn't have to wait for a seat, but the line probably started as soon as we were seated.

All in all, a good experience. I can see how servers get slammed here. It could get quite busy there.

I'll be back and I'll bring the double entendre with me.

Ah, I hate to be harsh, but this place really isn't quite a 4 star stop in my book.  We first walked in and had to mill around quite a bit before we were taken care of in any way.  We then sat at one of the big high top tables, which was fine by me.  It took some more time waiting for a server to appear.  I ended up going with her suggestion of a "seasonal" drink with the Wigglesworth.  The cocktail was pretty great, seriously boozy with a smooth finish, and I liked the little glass it was served in.  My companion got a beer from their decent list of draughts on tap.  We did not indulge in wine on tap, but I am happy to see that the selection is a very local vineyard.  On to the food...  My burger was cooked perfectly but it is served with a giant pickle spear draped across the top which is seriously unappetizing for a girl with a pickle aversion.  I understand many establishments add pickle to their sandwich plates but when it is not listed in the description I really don't think it should end up dripping disgustingness all over my main course.  It came with a huge pile of pretty sub-par fries.  They seemed overdone and a little cold as well as under-salted.  My companion got the chicken waldorf sandwish and said it was "just OK" with slightly messy sandwich prep.  

The decor in here is decent, and the downstair is definitely more appealing.  THe bar seats look nice and comfy and at any subsequent visit I know where I'll be headed for a seat.  It is hard to go into this place without comparing it to the other fairly new wood ceilinged gastro-pub The Gallows and in each and every category, decor, ambience, service, drinks and food The Gallows takes the cake.

I hope i return and am impressed in the future because this is a solid 3.5 stars but I believe they can do better.

My bf and I were wandering around Harvard Square looking for a brunch spot and stumbled upon the Russell House Tavern. We had no idea how lucky we were! When we walked in, it seemed tiny, but we were seated downstairs, which is gorgeous. Then we read through the menu and got even more excited. Toads in the hole? EBLT on a croissant? Sold. My bf was so excited he asked to see a dinner menu so he could scope it out for future dining adventures. We both cleaned our plates, and basically it was brunch magic.

I went here with a veggie  friend of mine who happens to know one of the bartenders. I wasn't sure what to expect but I had a pretty good experience and I'll be back. Most likely I'll be back with my carnivorous fiance as the range and combinations of meat dishes you can get looks amazing. As it was we had the Andria- a cheesy, figgy, galic-y dream. I could have easily eaten another as was rather sad when there was no more on the plate.

We also had a side of pomme frites and while it may be hard to mess up french fries these were perfect- golden brown crunchy on the outside,warm fluffy goodness on the inside. I would go back just for them. Our bartender Nick was witty and conversant - the gentlemen sitting next to us was from England and they got into a good-natured repartee about the guy's use of the word "puddings" when ordering dessert. He ended up with some amazing looking carrot cake,tho. The cider was good too. It did get a little loud but that's understandable.I feel like this is a place I could go to several times and still not have everything on the menu. I look forward to my next trip there.

I happened to stop by on a Sunday afternoon during a break. It was pretty busy and seemed like it had a lot of people for brunch. I managed to get seated at a common high top table. While it took awhile before anyone took my order, after that initial wait (and they were busy) my waiter was excellent and very attentive. Due to my time constraint, I ordered the melted cheese with tomato and bacon served on brioche with a side green salad. The iced tea was very, very good. The sandwich itself was fairly tasty with thick cuts of bacon (and that's saying something because I'll admit it, usually I loathe bacon). The brioche definitely provided a different experience. My complaint- the salad dressing. It had a lot of potential, I could taste that it would be good, except it was so incredibly salty I didn't really eat any of the salad. All I could taste was salt; no thank you. I did like the atmosphere, though if you hate being cramped it probably won't suit you all that well. However, I'd be willing to go back a different day and time to try it again. I think it has potential to please me.

Try to avoid the patio/courtyard seating with the "drama queen never smile and unfriendly" waiter who has a pretty bad attitude.  Oysters were not that great and fresh (duh, they waited until 11pm to serve u the leftovers that people didn't buy).  The cocktails were not bad  but the 1-liquor drinks were so weak my grandma could've handled 4 of them and still walk a straight line.  The appetizers were good but overpriced for what it's worth.

Best cocktails in Harvard Square, hands down. 

Get the Last Word, the Moscow Mule, or a good old-fashioned Dirty Martini. You won't be sorry.

Oysters are also fresh and delicious.

Entrees are good, though a bit heavy. The fish is usually fresh-tasting and light. The pork trio is delicious, but plan to go directly to bed after eating it. The steak is tough, not nearly as tender as it should be. Get the brussels sprouts side: honey-buttery and heavenly.

Well worth a  visit -- WONDERFUL cocktails, very good food; and a nice, clean, lively ambiance.

We only ordered fries and the melted cambazola appetizer but both were incredible. The fries came with ketchup and a white sauce (maybe garlic aoli) which was to die for! Just reading the menu of what else they served made my mouth water. Try it yourself: http://www.russellhousecambridge.com/?page_id=16

It was excuisit gourmet food at standard dining prices. I'd recommend this place to anyone. The food is wonderful, the atmosphere is classy but still pub style - fancy bar atmosphere but the game's always on. I'm so excited to go back!

business.full_address:
4607 Madison St
Riverdale, MD 20737
business.name: G & S Auto Dynamics

reviews.text: The best, honest, reasonably priced

I used to come here to get work done for my car when I was in College Park because I knew a guy that knew the guys at G & S. It's difficult to get to but the guys here will do a quality job that won't send you to the poor house. They give it to you straight and do all sorts of work. I like that they don't give you the typical upsell bullshit. They've been here for a loooong time so they know what they're doing. 

They'll also give you good prices on service and parts.

Not open on Saturdays so try to find time during the week to get an appointment. I don't understand them a lot of times but I usually get it through Gil or Sabino's(sp?) hand gestures.

One of the few trustworthy mechanics out there.  Always prompt and charges you reasonable amounts while trying to explain to you the problem in broken english with a heavy italian accent.  Knowledgable and experienced.

The best mechanics.  Gildo and Sabino ( G & S) are great.  Always the best priced (regularly 50% the cost of other shops), fastest, and nicest. In addition to servicing my car here for over ten years, I have referred no less than 7 friends who have all raved about their experiences.  Really special. I wouldn't take my car anywhere else. Recently replaced my Lexus precision sensors here for $400 parts and labor.

You will never find an auto shop with these types of people. Honest, reliable and trustworthy.  Sabino and Gildo, excellent people who enjoy fixing cars, and make money legitimately by educating you about the nature of the problem with your vehicle, while

This place is the shit. Everyone in my department has been going here for years, and they just don't make people like these anymore. Sabino and Gillano (sp?) are gruff, but they have always given it to me straight. There have been times I took my car in and they're like "this doesn't need to be fixed, no charge, go home". I mean, who does that?!?!? I feel like most car shops will be like "oh you need to replace ***** that'll be $5000". 

Tips: call early in the morning and ask if you can come in. They will usually grunt something that probably means "yes". Have someone pick you up, cause they don't really have a waiting room and it's not near anything interesting, and it can take a while, but these guys are sooo worth it.

If you're tired of being scammed by car shops, come to G&S.  It might not look like much, but it's seriously the best decision you could make when you have to get anything done on your car.  Bottom line-- their prices are fair and they don't jack anything up, even for women.  I brought my friend's car in for new brake pads and rotors, and they called me to say that they could just machine the rotors instead of replacing them.  Let me repeat: they took the initiative to save me almost $100.  I will never go anywhere else as long as I live around here, and I'm recommending it to all my friends with cars.

I have been coming here for years for service on my SUV, my husband's van, my mother's Camry, etc. and they are always dependable, get the job done, and are quite fair with the rates they charge.  Yes, they have the accents and I've had a hard time understanding them at times especially since I wear a hearing aide on top of the accents but I just keep asking till I get the answer and they are good about explaining what you need done.  Trustworthy is the main adjective I would apply - and fair prices.

I've been using G&S for about 9 years now for everything from basic oil changes to some semi-custom fuel system repair work. They've always been honest, thorough, and reasonable with their pricing. It's nice to have a place to go where you don't have to worry about getting a second opinion.

business.full_address:
6530 Adelphi Rd
Hyattsville, MD 20782
business.name: Hyattsville Library

reviews.text: This library is so old and so huge - I just love it here. This library always has exactly what I need. I have to disagree with the other reviewer, though, I found the staff members quite amicable.

None of the staff members are friendly.  

The only plus for me is, this is a huge library, and it's well stocked.  

Make sure you have your own computer, waiting to use a public one, takes forever.

business.full_address:
216 S 1st St
Champaign, IL 61820
business.name: Fiesta Cafe

reviews.text:
This place has been very hit-or-miss with me.  The setting is always nice, especially with shady outdoor seating during the summer.

I have had a couple of the vegetarian combination plates that were pretty sub-par, even compared to Dos Reales or a similar American Mexican place.  Most of the meat dishes I've had, though, (burritos, tacos, nachos) were pretty good.  And they do chiles rellenos well.

I'd give it 4 stars for the margaritas and the service. Our server was really nice and attentive. 

The food though, has much to be desired. Last night we went there and I got chicken tacos. They were so horrible that I only took one bite. My friend got the same thing and she also didn't eat more than one bite. They were that bad. The chicken tasted like it was canned. 

The chips are good and the salsa isn't too bad either. They're generous with the chips and keep them coming, good thing too since that's what I ate for dinner since my tacos stunk. 

Good place to go if you're just looking for 'ritas and chips.

This place was poppin! We had to park in the Dallas and Co. Parking lot cause the Parking Lot was full. The entire structure is pretty cool- they've been pretty successful with an attempt to 'Go Adobe'. 

Overall, the food though wasn't that great. I guess I might just have really high expectations for mexican food because I love it. I ordered their 'Mexican Combo Dinner' and got a beef tamale, chile con queso, chorizo enchilada and the enchilada was my fave..
I always enjoy the chipolte steak soft tacos and the black beans!

I agree with many of the criticisms listed by other reviewers (chips not great, some dishes can be bland, etc), but Fiesta is still my favorite Mexican place in CU. I am a vegetarian, and I love that they have such a good variety of dishes available without meat. I particularly love the chimichangas. I also am not a fan of refried beans, so I love that Fiesta has the option of black beans for all their dishes.  It is definitely a "comfort food" type of restaurant for me, cheap and cozy and consistent.

I picked 4 stars, which means, according to Yelp, "yay! I'm a fan."  And I am, because this is one of my go-to restaurants. It doesn't close at 7:30 pm, like every other place in town, so I think it gets a lot of business because it can cater to the crowd that doesn't eat dinner at 5 and then get all tuckered out around 8.

I considered writing a long review, but it really boils down to this: this place will stuff you with food, mostly chips and salsa if you're at my table, and they won't stop refilling everything until you tell them you can't eat any more.  Which you will do in a kind of thick, goopy voice because you're actually so full of food your body is storing it in your chest and throat.  I secretly think that the staff likes the spectacle of gluttony, but I don't care. When I go there, it's because I want to get fat and happy and that's what happens.

Very casual, comfortable place, a little further off campus.  Laid back.  AWESOME vegetarian burritos and chimichangas, good guac, and I like them Margaritas man!  Huevos rancheros is another favorite of mine.  The vegetarian food there is truly so, you don't have to ask if it's made with clam sauce, chicken broth, lard, etc.  Small place with an expanded dining room in back, and sometimes gets rather busy, but some of the best Mexican in Champaign.

I went to Fiesta Café because they were the only Mexican establishment, at the time, serving pork tacos. I was disappointed. The pork tacos were made sweet with some sort of pineapple concoction, and the tortillas were store-bought. I much prefer tortillas that restaurants make themselves.

On the plus side, this is one of the Mexican restaurants that tends to offer coupons via the mail. When I dined on a Monday night, Fiesta Cafe had a lot of older couples taking advantage of the discount.

Champaign, IL is a place in which I've learned many tragic truths in this thing called life. One of the more prominent ones, specifically in relation to the central-Illinois locale, is that there is no good Mexican food here. You may recieve recommendations and you may choose to believe them, but remember this: it's all relative.

During my 3 year stay in this small midwestern town, I was duped into trying the fare at a variety of Mexican eateries. Always hoping to replicate my Pilsen, Clark Street or the lady that sells tamales out of a cooler experience I never turned down an invite. On a recent trip back in search of gainful employment (in the form of a university sponsored job fair) I was implored to try Fiesta Cafe. It was the straw that broke the camel's back.

Quantity over quality appears to be the motto here, as it is at many C-U establishments. I ordered tamales and was greeted with rubbery and unpleasant masa wrapped around a minimal amount of chicken. The sour cream did indeed come in a school lunch single serving container as mentioned in another review, and the rice and beans were sorely lacking in positive qualities. 

I gave two stars, however, because the service was good and they carried tamarind Jarritos. Tamarindo! The food was edible, but it just wasn't quite what I'd expected.

This was awful.  Base on the reviews from this site we decided to check it out.  I reallly wanted to like it, it's close to home, has awesome architecture, great outside seating and good atmosphere.  Howerver that's when the good times stopped.  The chips showed up and were so stale they had to have been out of the bag since early last week.  The salsa was not tasty at all and the sour cream came in cafeteria packets or "in baked potato packets from Golden Corrall" as Jessie says.

When the food showed up it was just as bland as the chips.  Jessie will eat just about any Mexican food on the planet but this was TERRIBLE.  I haven't a clue what other people enjoyed, maybe we managed t order the two things on the menu that are awful.

To top it all off there weren't any entertaining people in the whole place to pay attention to.  Just unacceptable.  

Needless to say we will not be visiting the Fiesta Cafe again, unless there is a Fiesta with lots of free booze.

Ah, Fiesta Cafe.

You do not deserve all five stars on food alone, but there are so many additional factors.

First off, Fiesta Cafe is a flagrantly ridiculous adobe structure, looking as if it was transplanted straight from the American Southwest into the midst of First Street in Champaign.  Ridiculous.  Awesome.  Hilarious.

Next, the service is fast, friendly, and the food delicious.  I ordered the chilequiles, which I'm a bit particular about.  I also wanted them with scrambled eggs, which seemed odd and self-indulgent, but they did it PERFECTLY.  And I was delighted.  The food was great, and i was pleasantly surprised as I thought it'd suck or be midwesternly bland.

Finally, as I left the patio, full and happy, i stopped and looked about.  There are a plethora of flags, American, Mexican, Peace, LGBT Rainbow, a whole plethora of flagtasticness.  'Twas nice to see a cool, friendly environment.

So, in conclusion: Ridiculous pueblo, frighteningly good chilequiles, flagtasticness, wondrous service.  I was delighted.

Fiesta Cafe has the best Mexican in Champaign/Urbana. Everything isn't made with the same ground beef, there are choices. Ordered a beef taco and had 4 choices of beef from ground to a chipotle marinade. On a nice night, outdoor seating is fun. Great Mexi

Te amo, Fiesta Cafe!  Having grown up in C-U, I've heard my fair share of how great Dos Reales is supposed to be, but everytime I eat there, I feel like I am being rushed out the door.  Fiesta on the other hand....well, there are few places I'd rather sit on the patio and have margaritas.  That, and the staff always recognize my husband and I and remember what we like, right down to the extra sour cream (no longer in those little paper wedges) and Island Margaritas.  Oh, man.  I'm making myself want to go there right now just thinking about it.

Why I Like the Fiesta Cafe...

1.)  The decor is extra funky.  Plenty of Tecate Ads and scantily-clad Mayan princesses.

2.)  The Tacos Mexicanos are the best, especially the tacos al pastor (deliciously marinated, spicy, tender pork w/ pineapple).

3.)  Utilizing the food and drink specials (or not) allows you to get a very reasonably priced meal.

4.)  The service is friendly and fast.

5.)  I'm not certain, but it might be nearly as good as El Charro.

6.)  You have about 5 or 6 different salsas at your table, which really allows you some variety of flavor.

The only drawback is that if you don't get the Tacos Mexicanos, you're probably not getting anything really exceptional.  Also, I might've encountered a moldy chip once.

It's always interesting how everyone has their go-to mexican restaurant...mine, hands down, is Fiesta Cafe. I've been going here since I was a little kid and it's difficult to find another restaurant that can compete. I love how their salsa is always fresh, service is AWESOME, their margaritas are great (get the don julio blanco and you won't be disappointed) My favorite dish is Tacos Mexicanos with chicken and a side of rice with white cheese sauce...mhmmm, delicioso!

As the saying goes:  I've got 99 problems.  Unfortunately the flavor and heat level at Fiesta ain't even close to being one.  FC was so crowded that ye olde boy friend and I  held out hope for a Mexican experience that would put the culinary and GI horror that was El Toro out of mind.  We're still waiting for the GI results, but at this point I think we're ready to call it:  unless you want to be depressed and wallow in milquetoast mexican food, don't go here.  The ambience was fine.  It was bright and kitschy in ways I find endearing.  

Getting the order wrong and forgetting a side?  Forgivable.  
Ruining tequila with a syrupy excuse of a marguerita? bad news.  
Swapping the meats on my BFs platter? worse news.  
Unflavorful and rubbery fish tacos smothered in soggy slaw and served on a plate where everything was white:  death.  
A soggy fry job on a cimichanga: death warmed over.  

I feel like mexican food is easy to get right:  it is my go-to for home meals when I have nothing on hand.  With beans, cheese, lime juice, salt, something in the pepper family, a tomato and a tortilla -- it is easy to be great.  If you start there and possible add cumin then there is nothing you can do wrong.  I'd be happy to assist FC if they would like to develop this concept.  Until then, I'll just be over here soaking some beans and making my delicious oyster mushroom fajitas.

Based on the bland, tasteless chicken verde enchiladas I ate here tonight, I am never going back.  The chicken was dry, the verde sauce definitely canned, and the price for three of these horrible enchiladas was nearly $13!

The chips were stale, the sour cream was delivered to the table in horrible squeeze-out packets, and the mild salsa was more onion than tomato and also very watery.

The service was also lacking--our very distracted server took several minutes to even bring us menus.  She later cluttered up the table by dropping extra baskets of chips and salsa with us without clearing away the as-yet-unfinished ones already in front of us.  Drinks, including water, were not replenished frequently, and when we received our check, there was a charge for a Coke we hadn't ordered on the tab.

We ate outside in the patio area next to the parking lot.  It was a pleasant evening but flies were everywhere and we spent much of the meal swatting them away.

I recently moved to Champaign-Urbana from California and some might say my standards for quality Mexican food are too high, but service and ambiance aside, the food should at least *taste* good, shouldn't it?

Laid back place. I had the best carnitas tacos ("mexicano style" soft corn tortillas, lime & cilantro) but honestly, some of the worse rice & beans I've ever had....skip those. And the sour cream comes in the little packages like you would get at Wendy's or something....The complimentary chips and salsa were great, and the staff friendly and attentive. Pretty decent food overall. We had a party of 8 for lunch and surprisingly they accommodated us immediately, but the place filled up quickly, and not all with just college students. FYI-The lunch specials are yummy and a great price-check them out.

This rating is inflated because of the location: I"m coming from the Bay Area where there are tons of great Mexican joints and Fiesta doesn't really compete with them, but it's by far the best we have here in C-U. In fact, it may be my favorite restaurant in town.
They actually have carnitas, which is a godsend, and all their dishes are executed well. The burritos don't have rice, which is weird and makes them messy, but I actually enjoy the result; more beans and meat is not a bad thing. They give you free chips with two salsas, one spicy and one mild. All the meat I've had there has been top quality and the beef isn't stringy like at so many other places. Also the margarita menu is intense, they have like 20 types of tequila, which I appreciate though it's not really my style.

Kelsey Keyes reviews Fiesta Cafe: "It took me a while to come around to Fiesta Cafe, and I still don't think their chips and salsa are as good as those you get at Dos Reales.  Still, the food is reliably good.  And the fish tacos alone make it worth a visit.  Service has always been remarkably friendly, and generally fast. Plus, the building is painted bright pink!  What more could you want?"

I had a craving for Mexican food tonight... which happens rarely enough that I should I should indulge. I had no idea where to get good Mexican food in Champaign, but a quick Yelp search brought up Fiesta Cafe, which is conveniently located just a few blocks from my apartment, and also stays open everyday until 12am (an oddity in Champaign where a lot of restaurants are closed by 10pm). 

So I decided to check it out: I didn't actually eat there, only got food to go, but the restaurant seems pleasant enough that I will probably go back soon. I ordered the chicken mole, and it turned out to be quite good... in fact, surprisingly good and quite better than most Mexican food I had while I was in NYC. It's also very reasonably priced, and the service was very friendly. Nice place!

business.full_address:
3325 S Hoover St
South Los Angeles
Los Angeles, CA 90007
business.name: 365 Laptop Repair

reviews.text: My laptop wasn't holding a charge anymore, so I went to this place (closest to me since I am a USC student) at around 11am on a Thursday. The guy at the shop told me the computer repairman wouldn't be in until 3. I came back at 3:30, guy still wasn't there. I waited until 4:15 - 45 min!! For him to show up. When he did there were about 5 angry people waiting for him, several of whom he had told their laptops would be ready by 2pm that day, and he told them to come back at 6. When it was my turn, we figured out I just needed a new charger. I should not have bought this from him. He charged me $50 for what you can find online anywhere from $18-$33. I was totally taken advantage of because I couldn't go online and shop around. Don't go here if you can afford to travel farther for better service.

First of all, I would note that the other 5-star reviews are all written with the same month by yelpers who have only written one review so far....for this company, which I find to be shady and misleading. If you read them carefully, it's almost as if the business is advertising their services through these reviews (oh what specific prices and services!)

My problem with this company is that they don't state their shady-a$$ business practices (no refunds?) when purchasing. And because if you don't ask at the time of purchase, this accidental purchase will be "your fault", according to the business owner. I had a receipt and it was within one week of purchase. 

Their business phone seems like it's the guy's cell phone, which isn't a big deal unless you're trying to make a complaint and he asks for you to call him back because he's busy.

The company is a shared space with the photo developers.

Other than it's convenient location, I would avoid this business. 0 customer service.

business.full_address:
DownCity
Providence, RI
business.name: Providence Roller Derby

reviews.text:
I went to a bout at Thayer Arena earlier this year on May 5th which was a double header. The RI Riveters battled the Dominion Derby Girls All-Stars (from Virginia,) and the Providence Pigeons took on the Shoreline Roller Derby women (from Connecticut,) at Thayer Ice Arena in Warwick. 
This is the second Roller Derby bout I've gone to, the first one was actually in a roller skating arena. Thayer is an ice rink but the ice was gone leaving a court clear for the skaters to compete in. It was wild! Spectators were seated close to the ring and outside in the seats. Watching in Thayer afforded better seating because of the bleachers. The crowd was entertained by a DJ but Girl Haggard played as well! It was an excellent night. 
I had to leave early unfortunately, the big man can't last for very long. 
I always think of that movie from the 70's, "Rollerball" and think of cheesy theatrics and major pain when I think of Roller Derby. This is not at all like what I was expecting when I first went. Families, couples old and young and kids too, enjoyed the bouts, the music and the fun. I still haven't figured out the rules to the game yet but I didn't need to really. The game is fast paced but not ultra-violent, the players are colorful but not crude. I will be supporting the Mob Squad this year! Go out and have a blast! Make it a night! You can even join in and become a Referee with some training! They're on facebook and Twitter so you can follow them easily.

Are you ready for fierce women on 8 wheels?

Roller Derby is an action packed sport that never disappoints. It might take you a few jams to understand what is going on, but once you realize how the game works, you will be hooked! The feisty names, and col

I went to see a providence roller derby bout at the RI Convention Center and was surprised by how BIG the crowd is and to see that it is a 'real' production. They have colorful announcers, live music, a merch table, half time events, program books with pics of all the girls and a section for autographs, photographers, reporters, they have an after party that is open to all the ticket holders, and more.  

You might think it wouldn't be a family friendly environment, but it is! There are so many families with kids there, and the kids go around asking the skaters for autographs. Really cute. The skaters are real athletes and it isn't some wwf rehearsed show. You can tell the girls are VERY aggressive and take the sport seriously but they aren't rolling around punching each other, it is nothing like that. They have refs that call minor and major penalties.

They serve beer/liquor, have a concession stand with food and soft drinks.

Also, the ticket prices are VERY reasonable at only $10 a pop. 

Rhode Island has a total of 3 home teams that only play each other: The Old Money Honey's, Sakonnet River Roller Rats, and Mob Squad. 

They also have an A team called the Riveters that competes against other states team and a B team called the Killah Bees. 

The Old Money Honeys are my FAVORITE team. Those girls are all awesome to watch.

Something you should know: I love roller derby. When you meet me and you find out I love roller derby, you'll probably ask why I'm not a derby girl. I'm kind of, sort of brutally honest, a bit rough on the edges and a girly girl at heart. So why am I not a derby girl? I can't skate to save my life. So I watch instead.

The first bout I ever went to was after my college graduation, and to be honest I totally fell asleep. I had been up for hours, so it was completely justified. Next, a group of friends went to see another friend (she plays for the Cosmonaughties/Boston Derby Dames league). It was a ton of fun. It was easy to understand and really fun to watch. Then I moved to Providence and decided to check out PRD.

My first reaction was that the venue, and crowd, was much smaller than the BDD venue/crowd. It's probably understandable, but it bothered me that roller derby didn't seem to have as big of a following in Providence as it did in Boston. So I was hesitant at first. But then the bout started, and these girls are just as tough as I'd hoped.

Admittedly, I've only been to two PRD bouts, but have every intention of attending as many as I can for next season. I'm a fan of the Riveters and the Mob Squad, and you can expect to see me there wearing one of those two shirts and cheering on Rhode Kill who is absolutely, without a doubt my favorite derby girl. Is it weird I'm her biggest fan and don't know her? Whatevs.

Check it out next season! I hope to see you there :)

business.full_address:
320 Atwood St
Oakland
Pittsburgh, PA 15213
business.name: Saigon Tokyo

reviews.text: This little Vietnamese place is OK. They're Vietnamese, but make Japanese cuisine like sushi as well. Although the owners are very friendly, the food isn't anything special. I've had better Vietnamese, and if you want sushi, Oishii Bento or Sushi Boat, which are both nearby, are better.

No, not cool. Not good. Stay away from sushi. Staff didn't know difference between various types of sushi and it made me sick. Got sick after 2nd visit. 1st visit was OK. Pretty decent pho and spring rolls. Stay away from here like you would a wet, gross Oakland porch couch.

business.full_address:
South Los Angeles
Los Angeles, CA 90007
business.name: Gamas Painting

reviews.text:
Gamas helped us with our project to paint our 3-unit building and they did a fantastic job.

From the start, Linda was on top of it, helping us with the permits (getting permits with the City of Beverly Hills can be painful). She also interfaced with the scaffolding company.

The project was beautifully done on time and within budget.

I would highly recommend Gamas painting! Professional and affordable.

Gamas Painting ROCKS! They are a family run business that works together. They provided a highly competitive bid, and all of their references checked out. They just painted our family room, and are about to paint the exterior of our house. They are above board, and do not over-price their bids. I hope you use them.

I found out about Gamas Painting by Reference, that ALWAYS good! :-) So I decided to give them a call and within 48 hours I had an estimate on hand. I am super happy with the finished product, my bathroom and bedroom looks AMAZING, and there pricing's are very reasonable. Great Job Gamas Painting! :-)

After getting a lot of pricey estimates from different painting companies, I was pleasantly surprised by the quote Linda Gamas gave me. Her team did great work. They painted my entire 1 bedroom condo (minus the bathroom) and removed the acoustic ceilings from 2 rooms in just 1.5 days. I was floored at how fast and efficiently they moved while still doing a fantastic job. I also prior to starting the work, I had to frequently request a different start date as my closing date kept shifting. Linda was very understanding and accomodated me. It took off a lot of the stress of being a first time homeowner. I highly recommend them.

business.full_address:
210 N Columbia St
Chapel Hill, NC 27517
business.name: Tarheel Take-Out

reviews.text:
Ten meals later and I am still loving this service.  The employees are very professional, the drivers on time and food from some of my favorite restaurants.  They recently added Sandwhich to their line up and the last two times we ordered our food (from Sandwhich)it  got here in 30 minutes.

I like that the employees will call me to double check something if they aren't sure about my order and not just chance it.  The one time they were over an hour delivering they called and told me they were refunding me the delivery charge.  That is outstanding customer service.  I didn't even have to ask.  

This place has been a life saver since I have been recovering from surgery and don't want to eat pizza every night.  Like I said earlier, the $4.99 delivery charge is worth it to me.  I don't have to drive downtown and pay for parking and brave the cold and the crowds.  I think we're pretty lucky to have this service!

This service got me through my first two years of undergrad (when I was car-less) and through graduate school (when I was house-bound with literary theory tomes). They will order, pick-up, and deliver takeout from a variety of restaurants throughout Chapel Hill. And if your hubby wants wings, but you're craving Italian, you can even opt to order from more than one restaurant. Browse all the restaurant menus on the Tarheel Takeout website and submit your order online or by phone. If ordering online, there's a notes field for tweaking orders (hold the mayo!). You can also place your order in advance, if you require it on a specific day at a specific time. There's a fee for delivery and a nominal fee for each additional restaurant per order placed.

They bring you your food in relatively good time, but they charge your first born for it.

On top of the $7 delivery charge (which does not include tip), they take a 15%-35% mark-up on EACH dish.  

If you are hungry and really want delivery, then they are worth it.  Not that you have many other choices!

Update: $5 is still to steep of a price for delivery, but I appreciate that some businesses have been running free delivery coupons.  It has influenced our decisions on where to order from.  With a newborn at home, we sometimes don't have much of a choice but to have our food delivered.

I was going to raise them up a star because of the coupons, but one of our recent orders came from a delivery person that reeked of cigarette smoke, and it had gotten to the bag the food came in, and we had to take it to the garbage can outside to stop smelling it.  (Fortunately, the food was not effected.)  I don't understand why you hire smokers to deliver your food... especially when it costs so much to have said food delivered.  This only happened once, and hopefully it won't happen again.

I love IP3's pizza, and Tarheel Takeout is the only way to get it delivered. With a toddler at home and a baby on the way, picking up just isn't an option for us. 

Long story short, our order was incorrect. The manager we spoke to at the time only gave us a credit for delivery when we expected the entire pizza to be covered. I called to complain and was directed to write Wes (the owner) an email. He was very professional and handled my complaint wonderfully. 

What could have turned into a very bad customer service experience ended up being a great one! Wes and his company obviously care about the quality of their service, which is more than I can say about most restaurants.

I used Tarheel Takeout all the time when I was in school, mostly because I rarely had access to a car or cash. The name is kind of misleading, since they pretty much only do delivery, but they do take OneCards as payment (expense, not flex dollars). I loved the convenience of being able to order a burger from one restaurant and a burrito from another and having them both brought to me at the same time. 

It's a great service but it's not perfect, and I do have some gripes. First, there's a delivery fee AND a service charge. I think the last time I placed an order I totaled the fees and it was something like $7. So you definitely pay for the convenience. Also, it usually takes at least 45 minutes to get your food, and I once waited almost 2 hours. And I realize that the closing time of 9:30 or 10 pm (depending on the day) is based on the schedules of the participating restaurants, but I really wish they were open a little later.

Tarheel Takeout is one of those staple services around Chapel Hill that helps the city run... It oils the machinery of the local academic body in such a way that, were the service suspended, rioting and mass hysteria would surely take place.

It really is a great system all around, and I challenge anybody to refute that.  For those pedestrian masses wandering around Carrboro or South Campus, Tarheel Takeout is a beacon in the dark that has been followed many times, always ending deliciously.

The only thing that prevents me from giving this service five stars is their occasionally slow service.  After all, delivery drivers are not chosen for their grit and determination under pressure, so things don't always arrive as quickly as you'd like.

Tarheel Takeout Express is a godsend if you're studying, or don't want to trudge from your dorm to Franklin Street in the rain, or just lazy (hey, I'm not judging.)

Plenty of restaurants participate, so you're pretty much assured to find something you like once you get over the initial confusion of ordering delivery that isn't pizza. There's a delivery fee but it's nothing too severe, and they take OneCards.

Unfortunately my first experience with Tarheel Take-Out was horrible. My food was an hour late and when I called the answering service was unapologetic. I ended up canceling my order and doing something else.

business.full_address:
200 W 106th St
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: New York Dry Cleaners

reviews.text: I was looking for a new tailor after my favorite one on 103rd closed. New York Dry Cleaners are across the street. It's not very noticeable from the outside. A permanent scaffold in front of a run-down building doesn't do much to recommend businesses on the south side of 106th, but this place is a gem. The tailor always takes time to double-check my measurements, reminding me that a 32" inseam doesn't mean anything if the pant rise is different from jeans to jeans. I've had him hem all my jeans (he painstakingly matches the thread) and work pants and dry clean my shirts and jackets. He cares, he's sweet, he's fast, and he doesn't charge as much as the other guys in the neighborhood, some of whom are asking $15-18 to hem pants. New York Dry Cleaners charges around $12.

business.full_address:
4732 Brooklyn Ave NE
University District
Seattle, WA 98105
business.name: Safeway

reviews.text:
I actually like most Safeways, but will never do a big trip at this store again.  

It's pretty small with a limited selection of many items.  It reminds me more of the Queen Anne stores (http://www.yelp.com/biz/safeway-seattle-8#hrid:MXL-IQGz6abRhQHb7TK85A/src:self) than the nice big one in Ballard (http://www.yelp.com/biz/safeway-seattle-14#hrid:e11OhfbPNkoc2v8-IaO-2A/src:self).  There is no pharmacy but they do have a (smallish) parking lot.

I was surprised at how many things felt slimy.  I had to wipe my hands off repeatedly as everything that came out of a refrigerated case felt wet!?!  I hope the temps were set correctly cause I have never experienced that before.  The produce wasn't bad though. Organic peppers were on sale for cheaper than the other ones.

The staff was in my way several times because they were stocking many areas.  It was early evening, a time when most people do their shopping, so most stores wait to do stocking until late night or earlier in the day. Apparently not here.

And the guy that rung me up was kind of a dick.  When he started I cheerily asked him if he could wrap my eggs in their own plastic bag.  He didn't respond at all (though he did do it).  Then, after I spent $140 he questioned me about a 35 cents off coupon.  What a jerk.  

This Safeway may be close to our apartment but makes the sorta ghetto Capt Hill location look downright fabulous and inviting.

I have known about this store since the early 1990's and the only thing that really changes is the pan handlers out front. Located on the corner of Brooklyn and 50th NE (next to everyone's favorite post-drinking Jack in the Box) this is one of north Seattle's smallest Safeway's. It's cramped and tightly packed shelves make it an adventure to find anything and its meat and produce is edible but not my first choose. If I were a staving college student or limited to just University Way for my shopping it's the best on the block, otherwise I'll walk the extra 5 blocks to Trader Joe's on Roosevelt.

There is a reason they call it "The Ghetto Safeway."  The only thing this safeway has going for it is the Real Change Guy (Edward).  There is somethign very comferting in his cadence: "Uh Real Change Sir? -- Have a good day sir.  Uh Real Change Ma'am? Have a good day Ma'am."  Other than that, expect long lines, terrible service, no bakery or pharmacy, normal to bad prices and a bunch of drunk college students looking for the beer section.

Definitely don't come late night unless you have some time to kill waiting in line.

Easily the worst Safeway in the entire United States of America. Or ANYWHERE really. I went to one in Canada that was just so classy.

But seriously? When was this store built? Just walking in there is enough to make you depressed. It's like an instant dose of SAD, Safeway Affective Disorder. The lighting. The way things are laid out. The pathetic produce section. The seemingly never-ending long lines.

Then why the 2 stars?, you ask.
If you're looking for an 'experience', shoot-em-up-comedy-movie type of experience, this is the place. It feels like one of those grocery stores in movies where gunfights could break out at any moment.

The people there = actually the awesomest. Total characters.

+ The Real Change Man: Greets you with his signature line "Reeeal Change. Have a Good (time of day) Ma'am. Have A Good (time of day) Sir."  HE IS SOOO COOL. Take a minute to chat him up sometime, and buy a Real Change from him. If you don't know what that is, it's a newspaper project that gives people jobs and it's all for good cause.

+ Flash-lightning Fingers Cashier. Jai is his name. When he asks if you would like to make a donation. JUST DO IT. Because apparently when you do, he then needs to punch in some numbers or something. Whatever it is, he has to type 100 characters in 2 seconds. It's mind-blowing to see it in action.

+ Occasional Transients Hanging Outside Asking For Change Or Food. It's always awkward with these folks. They'll ask you for change, but when you decline they can still see that you have just bought food, so they'll just ask for your food straight up. What do you do?
Sometimes they would also ask you to buy them booze in exchange for food stamps..... Refuse. politely.

Having said all that, if you need to buy groceries, I suggest going somewhere else.

Whenever I reach the midpoint between Safeway and my place, which is about only a mile away, I have this feeling that my heart is shriveling up and just sunk into the bottom of my gut. Then my knees lock and my palms get sweaty, and all of a sudden, I become irrationally worrisome.

The closer I get to the Safeway entrance, I become increasingly paranoid that some animal or wild creature is resting on the rooftop waiting to take a shit on me. How else can you explain the different trails of birds' poops, cigarette butts, and spit that leads to the doorway of Safeway? This place is seriously bad. 

The meats here are always discolored every single time. It looks like it is afflicted with gangrene. It is as if someone took the liberty to punch and kick the crap out of the beef flanks after it was already cut and packaged.

I GO HERE FAR TOO OFTEN.  It's on the way to school, so I go there without thinking or knowing of where else I could get anything.  

HOTTIES?:  
Yes, this is the major food store in the U-District, so there are hotties walking around indoors and out, from the campus all the time.  :)   And, on occasion, they have a couple of cuties who work there at the cash register.  

LOCATION:  
Hey...the U-District with its own parking lot.  Ever notice how all Safeways are very much alike?  I do take them for granted.  

PARKING:  
Unusual for the U-District, but this store is a good place to get parking for a quick shopping trip.  

SERVICE:  
I'm glad that, even though this is a smaller super-market, it has "self-check-out."  The service is good too, if  you need to go through the cashier lines.

The only good thing about this store is the real change guy. He always makes my day better after walking in and finding that anything I need or came for is either out of stock or isn't carried. The produce section is better than it was, but I still see sorry-looking bruised fruit every time I go. If I had a choice, I'd shop at the QFC in U Village.

This Safeway was recently remodeled, and they've made efforts to clean up the area outside. Its not a model store for the chain, but its about 5 times better than it was before. They did an excellent job with the new construction. Selection is about the same, although they did add some freshly baked breads and goods. Prices are a little more expensive than normal Safeways.

These reviews crack me up. I guess this Safeway used to be a lot worse. It's not so bad now. The alpha-male college students buying their barbecue supplies are annoying, but they're annoying all over this neighborhood. I kinda like the Go Huskies sign, it makes me smile. Have none of you ever lived in San Francisco? Those are some ghetto Safeways down there. Prices are better than QFC any day, and I don't usually have a problem finding what I'm looking for. That said, I wish I lived closer to the Fred Meyer in Ballard, that place is the shiz.

This Safeway is among the worst out there, and I think they only get away with it because they realize that students (most of their clientele) don't really care. Impossible to enter without being hit up to buy a copy of Real Change or someone begging you for spare change or a cigarette while playing guitar badly.  It's the only Safeway I've ever been in with a security guard posted inside, also they have no public restrooms there (for very good reasons, as I imagine such a place would quickly become a "shooting gallery" and not of the gun variety). 

Their selection is horrible, and often times they run out of things that you wouldn't expect them to run out of (regular coca-cola, what?) .

 I'm trying to imagine their good points, which are precious few, but they do have okay chinese-like food and cheap subs. They also have decent jalapeno cheese bread for 1.29$.  There are also usually always some good looking women here. (Vegetable section anyone?)

If you want to buy alcohol there, make sure everyone in your party has their ID or they will oftentimes refuse you. Also, expect it to take forever if you're trying to get cigarettes or a lighter (just go to J's mart  or the Chevron instead). 

The hours kind of suck, they close at like 1:50 am, which also makes sense considering the amount of miscreants in the area roaming the streets. 

In short, I recommend taking a walk down Brooklyn to the QFC or the other Safeway if you need food, don't waste your time/money here.

Since this store is walking distance from the UW campus the majority of the shoppers here were college students.
That should be a motivator for the store to update it's look, stock and clean up.
To start off, as we neared the store, there was a homeless lady sitting right in front of the entrance panhandling.  Then, walking into the store, I thought I entered a time warp with this being a store from the 1970's.  It wasn't dirty but, it wasn't clean.
Prices were comparable to other grocery stores and selection was limited.  If it's just the basics you need this store will fill your needs.
The workers here were very nice and helpful.

this place is pretty much the worst grocery store ever.  they hardly ever have anything.  i wouldn't go there to buy meat or produce, only frozen foods or candy.

one time the checker insulted me for not donating an extra dollar towards a charity.  

thanks.

This Safeway is so ghetto....

Sad selection.
Not very clean.
The staff is okay, I guess.
The produce is pretty much a fail.

Just go somewhere else. Trader Joe's is only a couple blocks away.

Well, I have good news and I have bad news. 

The good news is that they DID remodel, and it now looks like all other normal Safeways. You'll also now find self-checkout stands so you don't necessarily have to stand in the horrendous lines at 5:30 pm. And, best of all, the "Real Change, Ma'am?" Man is still sitting outside nine out of ten times. 

The bad news? They kept the "Go-o-o-o-o- Huskies!" neon lights up.

Worst Safeway ever.
