Today I arrived at the shop after brunch with a few friends (and yes, brunch included a couple of mimosas to help with the nerves!) and was greeted by Jenn, another artist at the shop. I filled out some paperwork, and then Adam popped out to show me his concept: perfect!

We talked a little about color and then he finished setting up. He talked me through the process (I don't know if this was because my tough-guy act wasn't working or because he does it with everyone but it helped to know what he was doing) and then started. 

We chit-chatted throughout and he was efficient and focused. He checked in at a few points toward the end and kind of kept me apprised of what he was doing.

The process was organized, chill and I liked that Adam checked in regularly if we had stopped chatting. I also liked that he told stories throughout, peppering the silence but not being too talkative. 

I will definitely return to Name Brand for another tattoo.

i've been getting a full sleeve at name brand, and they are among the best in the business. i'm in the industry myself, and have never worked with or for anyone there, and i can STILL highly recommend them. any of the artists at name brand would be the "big dog" at any other studio- there just happens to be like five of them. a large portion of their clientele is other tattoo artists and piercers- people who know. that should tell you something. not cheap but quality never is. they just moved to ground floor space on washington and the new shop is large, clean and comfortable. if you are in SE Michigan, you would be hard pressed to find a better place to get a tattoo.

First tattoo, long story short:
1" X 5" rib tattoo
Done by Adam
Put me completely at ease
Did an amazing job
Virtually no pain/maintenance required after 
Will definitely get all my future ink done here

I'm actually pretty happy with my tattoo. I just wasn't happy with the artist I worked with.  I asked Jen what she thought about adding shading to a  small part of my tattoo and she took offense.  She said that I obviously wasn't happy with the tattoo and that even if she did add it she could intuitively tell that I still wouldn't be happy with it.  Basically, I should have  taken other reviewers seriously when they said this girl can be unpleasant to work with. I have several tats and I've never experienced an artist getting disgruntled over revising an area the size of a thumbtack. Anyway, this isn't to say Jen doesn't have skills,  but I definitely would not  come back here.

I got amazing work done there several years back, I was told when I got the work done that name brand does free touch ups for life. come to find out that, they have since changed their policy and refuse to honor the agreement they made. I will not go back. nor will I continue to recommend them to others.

I walked into Name Brand when I first moved to Ann Arbor for a tiny memorial piece and was struck by how clean and gorgeous the shop is inside... I had initially been very wary of the first tattoo shop I'd walk into in a college town. Everyone there is professional, ultra-friendly, and, of course, a phenomenal artist.

I received my favorite tattoo (Out of over 20) from Chad Hunt my second visit. I initially wanted a small traditional portrait of Chief Joseph, about the size of a CD. After emailing him I went in for my appointment and not only did he completely exceed my expectations, he had a drawing ready that left me absolutely awestruck. The experience was highly pleasant, to say the least--the studio is ultra comfortable, he was chatty and personable, and he worked quickly (My entire leg from the knee to the ankle tattooed in about 3.5 hours, with no quality sacrificed). It healed beautifully and I now have a stunning work of art on my leg that I am constantly complimented on--I wish it was somewhere on my body where I could show it off year-round!

My only regret is that I am moving soon and won't be able to get tattooed by the other artists there anytime in the near future, all of whom have brilliant (Brilliant being a total understatement) portfolios. A coworker of mine had a half-sleeve done by Jeff Zuck that actually made me gasp when I saw it. 

Even if you aren't a tattoo "collector," I'd recommend Name Brand for your first/only tattoo. Too many people who just want one tattoo end up going to awful scratch shops because they don't know any better. I wish all tattoo shops held themselves to the same standards that Name Brand does.

I grew up around Detroit and when the time came to start getting tattoos I thank my lucky stars that Name Brand was there to guide me on my path.. Not only do you find world class talent but informative, friendly artists who provide the finest custom tattoos.
 
With a full staff of professionals you can find the perfect tattooer to suit the type of work you are looking to receive. I have been worked on by several of the names @ name brand all of which did incredible work.

I'm extremely happy with my experience at Name Brand. This was my first tattoo -- a six-inch oval piece on my forearm. Cole did the work. I wasn't particularly nervous, but I wasn't completely calm either, and the entire vibe of NB put me at ease. The dude who does scheduling, etc. was super nice. Cole was super nice. I was into the music they were playing (which happened to be Dinosaur, Jr.). The tattoo came out exactly as I'd hoped (if not a bit better than I'd imagined). I'm so happy I went to Name Brand. Happy I went local.

I had three pieces done at Name Brand.  They have the requisite cleanliness (just ask to see the autoclave) and professionalism.  As of my last visit, they have a receptionist to greet you and answer questions, which means that walk-ins aren't ignored by artists tattooing and artists don't get up in the middle of a piece to talk to walk-ins.  
Jeff Zuck, the owner, does world-class work.  If Bill Falsetta is there, I can also recommend him.  Dawn Cooke and Mike Emmett have since started their own shop in Ypsilanti called Depot Town Tattoo, and Name Brand no longer offers piercing since moving to their address on State Street.
Staffed by reputable guest artists, you won't meet warmer tattooed people than there are here. Scheduling usually happens within a couple of days. Be warned that metal is the only music played in this shop- I suspect it's all that can cut through the sound of 4 tattoo guns buzzing simultaneously.

business.full_address:
206 N 4th Ave
Kerrytown Ann Arbor
Ann Arbor, MI 48104
business.name: Dogma Catmantoo

reviews.text: Dogma Catmantoo is a great addition to Ann Arbor. Like the previous reviewer mentioned, it's not the place to get an item you can easily pick up at Petco or Target, but it is a great place to find unique and fun items for the pet enthusiast. It's also definitely not cheap. However, everytime I've stopped there, I've found either a great gift (cat themed nail files/fur remover), a health aid for my pet (malt flavored hairball remover) or a new accessory (cat litter mat that I adore!) The owner is a veterinarian, so if you have questions about your pet, she's a definite expert. I've encouraged her to increase the cat items in her store, and she has done so in the new, larger Dogma Catmantoo space.

Ever since my cat had to go on kitty Atkins (she's obese) , we've had to upgrade and buy cat food with *actual* meat in it, as opposed to pigtails, twist ties and melamine that most pet food brands like to slip in when we're not looking. So, considering 90% of food you can buy for your pet that's sold at big box retailers isn't actually food, Dogma Catmantoo fills a pretty important need in my life now. Granted, I am paying almost $1 a day to feed my cat, but on the other hand, she won't be fucking dying of kidney failure because of the shit that she eats. Just like Bobby Brown, it's  my prerogative. (And seriously, I've only been able to find one actual recommended brand of food for my cat, and that's at the lame Pet Supplies Plus. Dogma has all three brands that she can eat...)

So I'll proudly support the lame yuppie hell that is the local boutique pet shop. Though I will take away a star purely because of the over-the-top pun that is its name, and which really annoys me.
FYI, they canceled the frequent buyer program.

This place is so charming.  They offer a lot of cutesy pet accessories and gifts, leashes/collars/clothing, TOYS galore, specialty pet beds, and food.

They are very knowledgeable about their products and quite friendly also.

The location is convenient and the wide variety of products they carry makes it well worth a visit.

Only downfall is that, as would be expected from a "boutique" pet store, they are a bit pricey.  Some of their items are definitely worth the penny you pay, but a few others I would save for petco or a bit cheaper of a pet supplier.
Their website says that they are open on Sunday.   Not the case!  Made the hike out here and it was closed.   Not a happy camper.

I am completely torn about whether to hate or love this shop. Like Margot F's review, I agree that many "useful" items are not available there, and I too am anti-gentrification, anti-yuppie- but then again, that's what this shop is going for and they're doing a great job.   

They do, however, get big kudos for bringing in items that are rare that you want to try.  And they really research and know the products they bring in.  

 I bought an expensive argyle doggie sweater for my family Pit Bull, and although I felt a little guilty and silly, Dogma was the only place that had a variety of sweaters that fit his broad, snuggly body type and Logan (the dog) has gotten NUMEROUS complements  on his sweater, leading me to resolve that it was worth every penny.  They let me bring him in and try on many sweaters, and didn't discriminate against him b/c of his breed. (BTW he one of the best-behaved dogs I have ever seen, calm, listens, friendly, putty in my arms for hours)   He feels quite handsome in it.

And-- the customer service is not to be overlooked- the staff are attentive and courteous.

This is the A2 equivalent of those Upper East Side pet stores that sell designer duds to distinguish Vuitton-worthy pugs from the rest of the pack.  

Not only does Dogma Catmantoo ("the store for discerning pets and the people who love them," I kid you not) refuse to carry the Fancy Feast tier of pet foods, they also refuse to carry the two most widely vet-recommended brands, Iams and Science Diet, because you can get them at the box stores on the edge of town.  

When I first moved to town, they carried the brand of litter I used, but a few months ago stopped stocking it.  Why?  Because people liked it so much it had become widely available.  Straight from the cashier's mouth: "We don't like to sell things you can get at other stores."  

Like your dog's favorite treats.  Or cat collars, of any variety.  Or refills for those ubiquitous cardboard scratching posts.  Or ANY OF THE OTHER USEFUL SUPPLIES PET OWNERS NEED REGULARLY.   

But you can get a polka-dotted doggie bed that says "If my dreams would come true, bones will rain from the sky."  Or a chew toy shaped like a black stilleto.  Or a microsuede puppy raincoat and matching hat.  Or a plastic change purse shaped like a golden retriever's head.

They sometimes post a little sign outside that claims, "We love cats, too!"  The lady doth protest too much.  The occasional hemp cat toy might accidentally make its way onto their shelves, but by and large the store caters specifically to the dog who already has everything it actually needs but might be in the market for an ergonomic water dish.

So what's a pet owner who would prefer to patronize a locally-owned business in the walkable downtown but isn't about to switch to cat litter made of recycled khakis to do?  Suck it up and hitch a ride to Petco.  The only pet store downtown is bound and determined to be completely useless.

Surprised at all of the bad reviews. I'm purely in it for the better-than-average dog food selection (it's not extensive, as the store is very tiny, just a few holistic brands that boast better ingredients than most brands you'll find at big-box pet stores) and it serves that purpose quite well. My only reason for not giving a 5th star is that now my dog is hooked on this particular kind of food & I can't find it at any mainstream pet store.

Most natural brands of food will run $10-16 for a 5lb bag & the store clerk suggested that I try Fromm's brand, because of the good ingredient & it being a family-owned company based out of Wisconsin. She gave me a handful of single serving bags of different varieties to take home before I made my final selection. The 5lb bag is a mere $12 and you'll save about that amount of money by volume if you level up & buy the 33lb bag. She hooked me up with a frequent buyer card that they hang onto at the desk so I don't need to remember to bring it in.

Sure some of their non-food items are priced rather high but that's expected from any boutique store, which this clearly is. I stop in frequently just to browse and the owner & other employees have never been anything but jovial and informative. And sure they're not quick to jump when you walk in the door but the store is about the size of a large bedroom so it's not difficult to find a clerk if you've got a question. I almost prefer to be left to my own devices & if I need a hand I'll ask for one, so this is a non-issue for me.

Dogma Catmantoo is my favorite place to buy toys for Brewer.  They are all made in the U.S. and hold up really well with my chewer of a puppy.  They are on the expensive side, which my husband hates, but as long as I am buying Brewer a new toy every once in awhile and not every week, it's ok.  New toys help keep curious, active puppies out of trouble :-)

The owner is usually there and very approachable and friendly.  I haven't ventured much into her food line, but can guess that it's very good.  

They have an extensive stock of fun collars, which many of them I like, but ended up finding another one I liked better online.  Most of them are printed, and I wanted a solid color, which she doesn't have very many of.  

Here would also be my place to buy a "pet gift" for someone, as there are so many unique items.

Open early for Farmer's Market Saturdays.

As a speciality pet shop this place has a lot of stuff and some things I wouldn't imagine anyone had ever thought of, but frankly it could get more disorganized and froo froo than this place. The woman who runs the shop clearly knows a lot, but even she didn't know what she has in stock. The place is always a disaster and I feel like you have to be in some sort of club just to shop there. I appreciate that I can bring my dog in, but with her and I walking around all we do is knock things over. 

I love my dog, but spending money here seems like a waste of my time and hers.

While I think the products that are sold at Dogma Catmantoo are adorable and great, I am turned off by the customer service that they offer. Nobody ever greets me when I enter the store nor do they ever ask if I require assistance or have questions about the products. I prefer to take my business to a pet store that appreciates it.

business.full_address:
1213 Hermann Dr
Ste 350
Museum District
Houston, TX 77004
business.name: Houston Headache Clinic

reviews.text:
The positive aspects of Doctor Mathew;
I chose him because he was within walking distance from my house.

I went in blindly to this appointment as I am new to Houston.  I have always suffered from Migraines but I seem to be having more attacks because of the constant air condition and air pressure which changes often in this area.

Dr. Mathew was curt from the get go, tried to change many of the medications I had been on for 10 years though I had already found another doctor I was very comfortable with.  In the end, he tried to prescribe Pristiq an (SNRI) and Treximet (a Triptipan) these medications when taken together cause a sometimes fatal drug/drug interaction which I know from college they should never be taken together.  When I said something I was treated like a third world citizen because apparently women are not allowed to talk in his clinic.

Also, he tried to talk me into $5000 worth of Botox.

He only prescribed or attempted to prescribe me "brand" medication along with the botox which leaves me to believe this 72 year old man may be lining his pockets with pharma money before he retires.

He has no business practicing medicine.  I really feel sorry for the women working in his office....

When I started having chronic daily migraines, friends and family started looking around.  Who is the best in the treatment of headaches?, they would ask.  Finally, a doctor recommended I see Dr. Mathew at the Houston Headache Clinic.

I should have seen

I've gone to Dr. Mathew for about 25 years now and have been pleased.  When In my late teens, I had regular migraines that I at first thought were sinus headaches.  I later learned that many on my mother's side had them various points in their lives...thanks gene pool.  I tried a number of doctors, but most focused on their specialty alone.  A neurologist would say that I should be able to eat anything and not have headaches while a allergist-type wanted solely to look at the foods I ate.  Dr. Mathew provided the most balanced, comprehensive view.  He is a neurologist, but seems more multi-discipline.

He accurately diagnosed me and predicted the pattern of my headaches over the next 20 years or so.  They are now a non-issue except that I avoid a number of foods.  Over the course of those years, I have varied on taking some mild daily medication or none at all as needed.  He always looked for the basic solution first and has adjusted or eliminated medications gradually as new ones became available.  He was also the one of the first to be aware of the new triptan-based medications as they became available such as Imitrex (years ago), Relpax, etc.

Dr. Mathew is a reflective, quiet man that I have always found to be very kind and caring.  A person could misread him at first since he tends to use fewer words.  I've recommended him to my wife and my friends (mostly female) and every single one had glowing praise.  Most were long-term sufferers who had failed with other doctors.  My wife's were controlled quickly.  She no longer sees him and transitioned back to our primary care doctor for the now rare headache.

Solving migraines and headaches can frankly be like detective work since there can be multiple triggers and complex interactions.  These include stress, food, hormone changes, lights, sound, weather, etc.  Dr. Mathew is like a detective, both in solving migraines and in his style.  He's a bit quiet and thoughtful, but happy to answer questions and explain the alternatives.

One earlier reviewer commented that Dr. Mathew should learn US culture and that women are allowed to ask questions here.  I'm sorry that person had a negative experience and side effects of a drug, but I can say that knowing Dr. Mathew that this comment does not represent him.  In fact, the reviewer's comment could come across as a bit racist (i.e. quickly assuming the root cause of a problem is the other person's difference in culture.   Well then, I guess that reviewer must be from outside Texas so anything she says cannot be right!)

Two final thoughts... I am local to Houston as are the friends I have recommended.  To my knowledge, all the treatments have been on an out-patient basis.  I did encounter a physician assistant a while ago that was not very helpful and seemed a bit rude.  She did some of the background discussions before seeing the doctor.  She is no longer there.

The Good  
Um, well he looks good for being 70 years old.  

The Bad  
His bedside manner lacks severely if you question him about anything. He will take it personally.  

Full Review  
Long story short: After admitting my hubby to the hospital for treatment of his NDPH, I questioned Dr. Mathew on the amount of Topamax he had raised my husbands dosage overnight. I was berated for questioning him and made to feel like I was to blame for his headache. My husband ended up getting 2 kidney stones and was immediately pulled off the Topamax 2 days after my questioning him. He may be good at treating some headaches, but he needs 2 lessons: 1) in US culture (yes women are allowed to ask questions here) and 2) bedside manner. Unfortunately my husband had to suffer for many days with the kidney stones, probably caused by the Topamax. Shame on you Dr. Mathew.

He's since been fired as my hubby's neurologist.

business.full_address:
226 W. Foothill Blvd.
Ste. E
Claremont, CA 91711
business.name: Balanced Therapies

reviews.text:
I had a great experience with this massage therapist. He came and did a group event for many people and did a wonderful job. He was kind, reasonably priced, created a relaxed atmosphere and was great to work with.

In addition you can now pay online at his website www.balancedtherapies.com which is so convenient.

I would highly recommend Balanced Therapies.

I have to say Balanced Therapies is as good as it gets! If you live in or are ever in the area, I seriously encourage you to make an appointment and check it out. It's the best massage i've ever had. Super professional, great prices and lots of helpful advice on how to stay balanced. You can't beat it!

business.full_address:
5608 Walnut St
Shadyside
Pittsburgh, PA 15232
business.name: X Shadyside

reviews.text: I used to go to this gym 6 years ago before I moved from Pittsburgh.  I came back for a short period and I went there first.  I took a spin class and after getting completely drenched from sweating, I wanted to use one of their amenities, a shower only to find out that this gym DOES NOT PROVIDE TOWELS.  I have been to gyms all around the world and a towel is a basic amenity that should be provided (especially if im paying $70 a month).  While I love the location, I would not join this gym because of this one factor.

This is a great gym! It is pricey - consider the area, etc.. its going to be more expensive. 

They have great operating hours, a cardio room downstairs that is a decent size. Upstairs, you have weight machines, free weights, and a room for yoga, spin classes, etc... 

I found the staff to be very helpful, the gym was clean and well maintained, I few machines would break down and it would take a while for them to get fixed, but that isn't uncommon in high traffic gyms and it never interfered with my ability to get in a good work out. No harm, no foul. 

My only real complaint is the utter lack of parking. There were times when I would drive over to work out, spend 20 minutes circling for parking and give up. Not sure where they could possible get a lot, even if they wanted to. Its a crowded area and thats not going to change.

I've had a big change of opinion after spending more time in that gym. The equipment would often break down and never get fixed. Considering how small the gym is, it's inexcusable that two treadmills would be out of service for at least a month. I also had problems with the individual TVs on machines; sometimes they wouldn't work properly or would be completely broken.

The gym was generally quiet enough in the mornings, but it would be pretty packed after work. It was hard to find a machine. The staff also didn't really enforce the 30 min time-limit policy, which caused people to have to wait for equipment longer than necessary.

I was told on the phone I needed to let them know before the 25th of a given month to cancel my membership moving forward (and not be charged for the next month). I wasn't told that I had to give 30 days notice (aka pay for an extra month). Though they're technically right (it IS in the contract), I feel that their staff mislead me.

If you live in Shadyside (or nearby)... GO TO URBAN ACTIVE INSTEAD. It's cheaper and the facilities are unbelievably better than XShadyside... although I apparently have a membership at XShadyside for another month now, I am 100% done with that place.

Overall an excellent gym that is moderately busy. The biggest elements in a good gym are being kept clean, having good hours and being expensive enough to keep out the riff-raff while being affordable enough to be inclusive to most yuppies. Walking that fine price line is critical. As a former Gold's member, I saw the clientele get trashy once prices dropped below $40/month. And, subsequently, all the "nice" people left.

Urban Active, with its shady billing practices and low-low prices mean the gym is always packed and classes inaccessible. Club One is both expensive AND in the ghetto and doesn't provide security like Target does late at night.

XShadyside provides all classes for free, a huge boon -- considering that many gyms are shifting to a pay-for-class model for yoga and/or Pilates.

Negatives are lack of parking and no towels. 

All class instructors are competent. The facilities are always clean and the machines are modern and well taken care of. 

Until (or if?) the LA Fitness opens at the corner of Baum and Liberty (with proposed parking garage), XShadyside will remain the best gym in the East End area.

I have been a member for about 9 months. I have no gripes about the gym, except that it is significantly more expensive than other gyms in the area.

The gym is clean, very friendly staff, well organized. This is definetly a tiny gym though, and when it gets crowded at 4-6 you can find yourself waiting for free weights/benches. Same things downstairs with the cardio machines, they could definetly use a few more (but space is so limited).


I like this gym, but once my contract is up I am going to Urban Fitness which is 20 bucks a month cheaper, brand new, nicer equipment, lots more equipment (they have bball court and pool!). But I would recommend checking it out if you like a small gym.

This review is based on the spin class I just tried over here.  First time ever at spin and the trainer, Courtney helped me set up properly on the spin bike, made sure I was comfortable and made me feel like I could do it even though I thought I would pass out at certain points during the class.  All I know is Courtney teaches the class 7:30p on Thursday.  The class in an hour long which I don't like because that just seems so long.  The thing is it goes by so quick and it may have to do with the music sets.   I will be back for sure.  

The rumor is that Katie Holmes tried this class out too!  The girl has got some good taste.  Still love TOM!
I love this gym everybody there is soooooo nice and helpful

X Shadyside is a no frills type of gym (no pool, sauna and hot tub) but gets the job done. They just revamped the entire first floor with more workout machines and weights. A downside of the renovation is that there are less tv channels to choose from (no more Bravo). The staff is incredibly friendly and helpful; and the bathrooms are kept clean (what more can you ask for?).

The convenience of being able to walk to X Shadyside especially in the winter and their flexible hours are huge pluses so I'm okay with the monthly price that I am paying.

I am looking forward to Planet Smoothie opening next door.

business.full_address:
119 S Cayuga St Ste 301
Ithaca, NY 14850
business.name: Sunrise Yoga Center

reviews.text: Steven is a great teacher and his style of teaching is calming and invigorating.  He'll get you in good shape, too!  The studio is beautiful and serene.

I've taken yoga with Steven for a little over two years and I really enjoy his style.  He's supportive, encouraging folks to leave their competitive spirits on the sidewalk and do the yoga that's right for them.

business.full_address:
10 Schalks Crossing Rd
Plainsboro, NJ 08536
business.name: Lotus Garden

reviews.text: I am sorry to give this such a bad rating--but I have to say, the food was not great and definitely not worth the price. First off, our order got completely screwed up. No appetizer came, and for the entree we clearly asked for tofu but got chicken. When the chicken came (fried General Tso's) we were surprised because it did not look like tofu and didn't look veg yet the waitress insisted that it was. It was just the she didn't understand our question, nor our order--not that she was being uncaring. Nevertheless, don't go here if you want to eat vegetarian. My impression is that it is very authentic Chinese food because there were a lot of Chinese patrons there, so if you are going for an authentic meat dish this place might be just the ticket. Otherwise you should head to a local Indian place. The veg options were definitely NOT great here. Too fried, little vegetables. I'm giving this two stars instead of one because the wait staff was very apologetic about the order mix-up, and they seemed quite nice.
I've had better. It was edible but I wasn't really enjoying my food here.

A friend of ours lives in Plainsboro so we decided to go here after a movie one night. I see mixed reviews for this place based on the food and it's service. Let me give you my opinion:

Food: The food was slightly above average. I went there with a Chinese girl who knows her authentic food and she said that it was pretty good and had some menu items that are usually not seen in other Chinese restaurants. We would give it a solid 7 on the taste scale.

Service: here is where they out shined other restaurants. I don't know if it's because they're aware of the negative feedback on Yelp, or they just have genuinely nice servers, but our guy was very attentive and friendly during the course of our dinner. He even recommended some of the dishes. Kudos for that. 

Bottom line: When we're in the area again, we'll go back.
I love coming here! I've have great authentic Chinese food here every time.

The minute you walk into this restaurant, you'll know it's a old fashion canto-style Chinese restaurant. The environment can use some updates!!! There are complimentary  homemade duck sauce with fried wonton noodles on the table:) the severs' English not good, so don't expect them to answer much questions...
The food is okay. There's the real Chinese and the Americanized Chinese. I ordered black bean beef, tastes good but very oily.  If I have to dine in, i would come back, but if not, I prefer getting the real Chinese food at the Asian market five minutes away.

We went for a quick lunch from work.
Food is good but portions are small covered with a large portion of rice.
Service was so rushed that the bill was placed on the table when the meals were served.
Why not put the bill on the table after the ordering is done!

I haven't been to this place in years and was decently surprised with the braised beef  noodle soup for lunch. You can't beat a warm and satisfying bowl of soup on a cold day for $10 bucks including tax and tip!

After having read the reviews, I decided to go here for lunch today. 

I was quite indecisive on what to order. I asked some questions about items on the lunch menu and the man and woman up front were friendly. However, when the man asked if I spoke Chinese, I said no. I do speak Chinese but not conversationally so I didn't even want to bother explaining, though I ended up explaining for whatever reason. He was nice enough to make some recommendations and alternatives which was great, but what he said next was like a slap in the face. He noted that a section of the lunch menu was more authentic Chinese and that "I probably didn't know that." Excuse me? How dare you judge me? A customer. A first time customer? I sucked it up and explained I knew what the items were and that I've had it before. Anyway...

The food came out super quick and I was out of there in no time. But still that comment left a sour note in my mind.  

Despite all of that, I ended up with the family style tofu with brown rice and hot and sour soup. I love the fact that they had brown rice available. You rarely, if not ever, see that in Chinese restaurants in Boston. The food was good but the sauce for the tofu was super oily. The hot and sour soup had everything but the hot and sour. That was a bit disappointing.

Despite being insulted, the food was good. For under $10, you get a decent amount of food (definitely not enough for an average male) for the entree and the soup was generously portioned.

Will I be back? I don't know.

Okay, I'm from Jersey. Land of big hair and strip malls. 
  And generally, I get nervous when I visit a Chinese restaurant in a strip mall. Especially a restaurant where the patrons seemed to upset the yellow-white balance (although, granted, the Indian customers weren't quite white or yellow). 

But man, I was impressed by the quality of the food. 

   I promised myself I would stop the gorging after this week of gluttony. Unfortunately, I wasn't expecting such a good meal. Especially, as I said, from a restaurant tucked away in a strip mall next to an Italian restaurant with cheesy Italian opera blaring away. But I guess with the Plainsboro population growing, they know their Chinese food. 

The tastiness we ordered included:
- Stir-fried crab w/ egg
- Lotus root with squid
- Tofu with golden mushrooms
- Homestyle duck

I was busy licking my plate clean. 
My only beef with the place was their rice was dry. Not sticky. Just dry. How do you mess up rice? Sad times. 

But still, for central Jersey, I'll give it a five-star rating. 
  My taste buds are rejoicing, but my stomach is hating me. Actually, probably more like the scale is hating me right about now. 
    Thank goodness for my metabolism.

I grew up in Princeton Junction, and Lotus Garden is the best and most authentic Chinese restaurant in the area. The service is always friendly and the food is terrific. My favorite is the spicy beef with dry bean curd. I don't even like tofu but they hav

There are not many reasons to come to Plainsboro but Lotus Garden is one of them. I ordered the eggdrop soup (best ever) with steamed pork dumplings (amazing) with a steam chicken and veggie dish (simply wonderful.) 
Nice dine-in experience with speedy service and it was very crowded. Oh, this is important, we were the only ones in the restuarant who were not Asian. So where do people go for real Chinese food--Lotus Garden.

For those who need reviews by Chinese people for Chinese restaurants, I'm Chinese (American-born) and am happy to say that I've been coming to this restaurant since I was in middle school (and I'm 34 now).  

The people are very nice and the food is great.  Like any place, some dishes are better than others, but I recommend the following:

1.  Pan-fried noodles
2.  Popcorn chicken
3.  Shrimp-stuffed tofu
4.  Sauteed fish

Give it a try - you won't be disappointed!  It's my husband's favorite local restaurant and a real treat.

My boyfriend and I have only gone here for lunch, so the prices are decent for the portion of food you get (plus the soup or eggroll).

I like the wonton chips they give you when you first sit down.  Everything we've ordered here has been pretty good.  The fried rice is very bland.

The service could be a lot better.  Every time I've been here, I've always felt really rushed by the waiter/waitress.  They always seem to want my order the second I sit down, and ask things like, "soup? eggroll? rice?" when all s/he needs to do is wait like 15 seconds for me to say my complete order.

I think the real reason we go here is because it's close to where we live.
We really like Lotus Garden - order dinner from here regularly.  Their lunch special is a great deal too - and they're quick!

After reading the other reviews, I have to wonder if we're talking about the same place. The food here is very good, IMO, especially for those who are a bit tired of the super-huge and greasy portions that usually pass for Chinese food in the US.

The 'Authentic Chinese' menu is awesome, and I usually get some scallion pancakes to go with every order. The lunch menu is cheap but good, even though the portions are a bit smaller, and the hot and sour soup tastes, well, the way hot and sour soup ought to taste.

I've always found the employees very nice and helpful as well, although I am Chinese and do speak Chinese pretty decently, so that might have had an effect; I can't say.

In any case, I consider this one of the best Chinese restaurants in the area.

SO Much MSG!!! I  was very thirsty for the rest of the day.  It was a relatively big and nicely decorated restaurant. There are very few Chinese restaurant to choose from in this neighborhood. So there are definitely people who come here for what they think is authentic chinese food. The authentic part of chinese meals are located in the back of the menu book(1 page only). The daily specials are posted on the board as you walk in. The selections are very limited. Unfortunately , despite the nice looking restaurant with very friendly staffs, the food just wasn't good enough for me to make another trip here.

With limited Asian food options in the Plainsboro area, I was excited when my friends mentioned grabbing a quick lunch at a Chinese place nearby.  The meal started nicely, with won ton chips and their special dipping sauce waiting for us at the table; would go nicely with some beer and sunday night football...I digress.

Their lunch specials are reasonably priced ($9 with tax/tip), and their service is quick.  However, our waitress was horrible...I don't know if that was her "indoor voice" but I swear she was yelling at us while asking us what we wanted.  As I asked for the chow mein, she told me that what I really wanted was another noodle dish.  I informed her politely that I wanted the chow mein, and she had the audacity to tell me that that was NOT what I wanted.  Last I checked, I was still half Chinese and I knew what chow mein was...

To add another note on our waitress, typically you get the bill at the end of the meal.  We got the bill (with fortune cookies) a few minutes after we were served our meal.  The place wasn't even close to half way packed, and our group felt like she wanted to get us out ASAP.

Anyway, my dish was oily enough to deep fry some egg rolls if I ever had the need...yes, the noodles were more than edible, but it just wasn't good Chinese at all.  However, with limited options in the area, I'm likely to come back...
The teriyaki chicken is the best thing there. Everything else is so-so.
The worst experience I ever had! The boss was very rude when I asked why our dishes took so long, and he acted like an asshole.

I had an awful experience at this restaurant. 

The service was horrific. It took nearly half an hour to place my order. I then spent the entire meal trying to get the waitresses attention, practically waving my hands over my head, while she wiped tables and folded silverware near by. 

The food was mediocre, at best.

I've since ordered takeout, going in late I discovered there was no one in the restaurant an hour before closing. I wondered if the food was bad the first time because I was so annoyed about the service. Turns out no, it was bad al the time, no matter my mood.

This is a local chinese restaurant at the Super Fresh mall where you can either dine or take out.  It may be just a chinese restaurant, but I think they offer dishes with good quality and generous portion.  

I never had any favorite dish,having different dish every time, and they were all good.  My wife's favorite was pork chop.  If you are looking for a decent dining option at Plainsboro, this could be a good one.

My parents are probably more of a fan of this place bc of its convenient location.  Yes, despite its location in a "strip mall" (I don't know if it's still considered a strip mall if most of the store fronts are empty), the interior reminds me of any other chinese restaurant (this is not one of your strip mall takeout joints).  The food is actually authentic and tastes pretty good.  The reason I only give it 3-stars is bc I haven't had anything that has been SUPER, but most of the food items are a safe bet.  A go-to item is always the salt-and-pepper pork.  I also like the sea bass with black bean sauce.  My dad is a big fan of the sliced pork with chili peppers (it's really spicy!!!).

Just as a note - even when my parents have guests, we DO occasionally take them here for dinner, so I think it's safe to say that the food really is not bad.

business.full_address:
317 W State St
West Lafayette, IN 47906
business.name: Von's Gifts

reviews.text:
One of my all time favorite places to go crazy shopping. They pretty much carry everything that I love. Books, cds, posters, beads, rocks, cards, stickers, stuffed animals, posters and jewelry.

The book part is well stocked and staffed by some very helpful people. I recommend the discount card as it will save you a bundle of money. As an English major, several of my books for classes were carried here so the savings went far. 

The CD part can be a little less friendly at times, but if your feelings get hurt,  just take a spin around the stuffed animal room and you'll feel better again. I bought countless posters there. Some, like the HUGE Miles Davis one I had framed and mounted, still with me years later.

This place was great. A big bookstore, and gift shop, used bookstore.. but my favorite part about this store was the bead shop area. They have so many beads and supplies for making jewelry there- I have never seen so many beads! There is a variety of every single color, shape and size bead you could want. They sell them by the bead or by the strand. So much fun can be had in here. Their staff who I talked with were extremely helpful and friendly.  This is a great place to go for a little trinket, too.  Have fun!

Great place to just look around. Buying books is great there too. They have it set up so that each class has it's own section of books which makes getting books very easy. Very helpful and friendly staff with an overall relaxed atmosphere.

Fun fun fun! I love Von's. Pretty much three stores rolled into one. They all connect together. A bookstore on one end, jewelry/bead shop in the middle and finally a cd/record store. 

If you're a student at Purdue searching for books sometimes it's cheaper to head over to Von's rather than Follet's across the street. They have a 10% discount card (you have to purchase it for 5 bucks, but in the end you save money always- since textbooks cost so much). 

If you're a bored Purdue student or just like making crafts, check out the jewelry shop. I spent many hours in here purchasing beads and then making funky necklaces back in my dorm room. 

The music shop is superb as well. They always have the latest indie titles in the window, plenty of used and new cds, dvds and even fun tshirts and posters to clutter your college dorm walls in the back. 

Von's is a fun place to spend an afternoon with friends if you have some down time between studying at Purdue.

business.full_address:
981 Howell Mill Rd NW
Westside / Home Park
Atlanta, GA 30318
business.name: Atlanta Humane Society Clinic

reviews.text:
The Atlanta Humane Society Clinic is the only place in the entire metro area where proceeds are donated back to the shelter for animals.  I recently adopted Cochise, a small rottweiler mix puppy from the Atlanta Humane Society and I had to pick him up from the clinic.  At the Clinic, Cochise was neutered and they also embedded an identification chip between his shoulder blades.  

When I picked up Cochise for the first time, the veterinarian was very helpful.  She told me everything I needed to know explaining my dog's condition in full detail as well as upcoming vaccination requirements, etc. If you adopt a pet from the Atlanta Humane Society you get one free pet visit, within seven days of adoption, to one of the society's acceptable clinics.  Luckily they have at least one hundred across the metro area. In addition, whenever you bring your pet back to one of the Atlanta Humane Society participating clinics. If you adopt from the Atlanta Humane Society and bring your pet back to the clinic you will receive a 10 percent discount.   

For more information regarding vet services and hours call (404) 875-6420 or visit www.atlantahumane.org.

I recently adopted a 3 month old puppy and have mixed feelings about AHS. On the plus side, they were pretty nice and helped me find the right pet. Staff were personable and friendly and the process for adopting was pretty fast and easy - there was minimal paperwork involved and no formal interview. I love my puppy and she has been happy and energetic since I got her.

On the other hand, the volunteers that work in the dog rooms aren't very knowledgeable about breeds...they were completely uninformed about different breeds what breeds mixes specific dogs there were. I wouldve expected volunteers and staff to be more knowledgeable. they also didnt interview me to see if my pup was an appropriate fit for me or my living situation, which made me feel like they were just trying to get rid of their dogs. they also left out a lot of information and guidance about taking my puppy home (ie. that I shouldnt take her outside or around other dogs until she's done her vaccinations...) and really just shoved a few pamphlets in my face before sending me to the in-house pet shop with a $2 coupon.  My pup is due for another shot and I have called their vet 3 times now and left messages...they do not answer that phone or return calls. Ive since made an appt at another vet and wont be returning except for obedience classes...

 All in all, it was a pretty good experience and I would recommend AHS to friends but do your homework on breeds and pet care before you go and dont expect them to provide much there.  Also, I wouldnt count on them for vet services - if they cant return my call, I'm not trusting them with my new friend! AHS staff should really ake more time to make sure adoptions are a good fit and let clients know they are there to assist with information and medical needs, if needed.

The staff at the clinic is great.  But, keep in mind that being an at cost clinic, they are always very busy.  It took us a while to get used to Dr. Dorsey but now we adore her.  She isn't a touchy, feely vet.  She is a matter of fact type of person and won't talk you into getting things that are not necessary for the animals.  She saved our dogs life when we found out at her first appointment that she had Parvo.  The support from the staff through that process was so wonderful.

We left to take our animals to a vet closer to home, but have learned our lesson.  Once you have a clinic that is so dedicated to the well-being of animals and not fattening their paychecks by giving unneccesary recommendations you can't ever leave! :)  

Be patient, leave a message and the staff will get back to you and fit you in.  The only thing I miss is them being open on Saturday.  But, it is good that they get to enjoy their weekends now.

I'm not sure what to say. But at the front desk I was treated with one of the best customer service around. It helps to have a love for what you do, I found out that he is also a petsitter outside of work. He does little things that make me feel welcomed, checking on me when I was waiting for the vet, and showing genuine care for me and kitty. 

Granted, I visited without an appointment, I had a long wait. Arrived at 11am, was told to come back after lunch (1pm) although there wasn't any other patients at that time, it was an empty room. 

Anyway, when the vet? came in to see us, I did not feel like she was a vet. It felt like she was fresh out of school, like the first day of internship without supervision. Now, I know that young professionals gotta start from somewhere. 

Asthma is a pretty common condition among cats and I'm pretty sure she would know from the symptoms and could let me know what is wrong with my cat. 

I went in knowing that my cat must have developed asthma. I honestly just wanted some medication for my cat. She inspected kitty and told me she doesn't know what's wrong with her and decided to run a radiology exam. I said ok. Test done and showed nothing. I told her it seemed like asthma. And then only she started telling me that it might be asthma. Gave me some antibiotics and sent us home. Few days later my kitty is doing better. Thanks for the medication but that bill was too expensive for not knowing what is going on.

business.full_address:
998 Amsterdam Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Sip

reviews.text:
Cute place, reasonably priced. I had a BLTA (bacon, lettuce, tomato, avocado) sandwich for $10 that was pretty much perfect. And it came with a side of candied yams, which were unexpected and super yummy.

For some reason I decided it would be a great idea to order an alcoholic milkshake in the middle of winter. It had cranberry vanilla infused vodka in it, which sounded promising, but really it ended up being extremely alcoholic tasting and sickeningly sweet. My date got the havarti sandwich and some sort of German pilsner that came in a huge glass.

Three stars, mostly because the waiter should have warned me about that milkshake thing, and because I was pretty much sitting on top of the party next to us, one of whom kept staring at me. I will probably be back though if I'm in that neighborhood. That sandwich was seriously good.

bad form! 

went there for lunch with a friend recently--the waitress entered my order completely wrong, I was so hungry I would've eaten it except for the wretched havarti and butter slathered all over it (see my "latest discovery"). Honest mistake on homegirl's part, but the mandatory 18% tip on the bill was in poor taste considering all she had to do was point and click on a little handheld-order-taking-machine. 

also irritating that the whole time she talked to me as if I were a twelve-year-old... "oh i'm soooorrry sweetie, i entered it wrong." oh no, heather, i am not your sweetie.
how common.

Sip is the epitome of an establishment that tries way too hard to be something that it's not. The real question is, "what is it?"

As Heather H. points out, it used to attempt a more Gothic, pseudo-Turkish approach to the typical Columbia bar. The moody l

Sip is definitely cool...cant take that away from them...but, I found the food overpriced for the portion size...I had the BLTA sandwich, it was good...I will prob go back, but during happy hour or Mondays when food is half price.

I've put off reviewing SIP because I don't want more people going there. There I said it. 

On the other hand, I would like it to stay in business, and while I've struggled long and hard with the dichotomy of my feelings, here I am. 

What a great break from my usual Columbia University food crawl. The music is always good, and by good I mean good if you were born before 1985 and partied to real music; I'm not being ageist... Well, ok fine, I am. The music is even better if you happen to be in the neighborhood at night because they have DJs who spin the aforementioned good music nightly. The food is on point and if you come Mondays, it's half off. Tuesdays, wine is half off with 2 food orders. You get free tapas if you come for after-work-drinks for happy hour (5-7). See where I'm going with this? Cheap food, cheap liquor, and free tapas... What's not to love? Well... The space isn't big, the tables are small, tips are automatically added to your bill... And that puts some people off. I, personally, don't care. I prefer not to do math when I've been drinking, to completely be honest, and the service is ALWAYS impeccable, so they deserve it, thankyouverymuch!

The one thing I love about NYC is that you can stumble on amazing places like Sip.  

I was looking for a bar on a late night that had good music, a chill vibe, and good drinks.  Luckily I strolled by Sip with the bff because it was exactly what we were looking for.  

The music was chill and eclectic-tunes included records from Beyonce, RadioHead, Kanye West, and my all time favorite: classic 80s r&b.

The drinks were delish.  I opted for a few glasses of the "cheap" red wine (It's really called "Cheap Red" but its a good mix of a couple of reds).  It also didn't taste cheap at all...and at $6/glass it was a great deal. My friend had a cold and ordered a hot toddy--this drink was the real deal:  Jameson, lemon, cloves, honey and a tea pot of hot water to knock that Cold out!

The atmosphere was super chill.  I guess I would describe it as a hip coffeeshop type of vibe that happened to have a fully stocked bar.  

I can't wait to come back for 1. Brunch with endless mimosas/bloody marys 2. The late night happy hour 2-4am...craziness and 3) 1/2 off food on Mondays.  With all of these deals how can you not try this place????

i like the decor and the location (very close to columbia).  the food is pretty expensive for what you get though.  i've had a bunch of things and have never been impressed with the food (the split pea soup is really salty).  however, they do have free tapas between 5-7 though.  it's a nice place to get some work done in the morning-afternoon periods, and there are plenty of outlets to plug in your computer at the counters on the side.  it's a pretty small place though, so i'm sure i can fill up.  the one thing i really hate about this place is that one of the guys that works there (i don't know if he owns it or manages or what but he seems to exercise some power over the rest of the staff) is really rude and aggressive.  i've been to sip a bunch of times and every time i've heard him yell at his staff really loudly in front of everyone.  i just don't agree with that kind of behavior and feel terrible for the staff members that have to work under him.  he also yelled at a patron once and after she left he kept on ranting about how she was crazy and weird.  my friend and i were sitting nearby the whole time and did not notice anything weird about her.  it was just a very strange situation and he makes me uncomfortable.

We walked into sip and this is exactly what happened. I was so appauled I wrote out the conversation as soon as we left. 

Me: Hi, are those couches up there? (they are like elevator over some speakers)
Waitress: yes they are.
Friend: can we sit up there (jokingly)
Waitress: no, that's a dj booth, are you a dj?
Friend: yes I also know jiujitsu (also jokingly haha i mean wasn't it obvious!) 
Waitress: wow, you're really cool.
  We left
Bartender: Pleasure having you.
Friend: Yeah you too

The workers here are not friendly, dont bother wasting your time or money here.
crappy food, crappy place, crappy manager. thats all

Reasons to like this place:

-  It's open pretty much 24 hours, it's only closed from 4 am - 7 am.

- The atmosphere was surprisingly cute and cozy--and not in an overbearing downtown way, but in a reasonable uptown way.  

- During good weather, they open the windows and doors...so it can be a really pleasant atmosphere.

-  The sandwiches are surprisingly tasty.  I tried a BLT and Avocado sandwich and the bread was toasted just right, the bacon was crispy and didn't have gristle, the avocado was ripe, and it came with a side of vinegar/green pea salad, which tasted great.

- The cocktails are inventive and strong.  I had a particularly potent pineapple tequila cocktail that gave me a totally bitching vertigo episode!

-  The free wi-fi.  Decent internet speeds.  

Reasons to dislike this place:

- Price.  As a Manhattan cafe geared toward Americans with too much money, they feel completely comfortable charging $10 for a BLT sandwich and $10 for a cocktail.  I'm used to going to little deli convenience stores and getting an even better sandwich for $4-$5. If they want the price to justify what you get, they ought to think about making the sandwiches much bigger.  I was still hungry after my $10 BLT sandwich which just makes the whole thing an illogical meal.  Why would I come up here and pay $10 for a smaller sandwich if I can walk 1 block and get a huge and delicious sandwich for $4-$5 at Andy's Deli?  I expected that the price would be a little higher because of the arrogant yuppie factor, but come on, there's no way this BLT sandwich is worth $10.  

- Automatic gratuity.  I'm a pretty good tipper.  Having worked for years as a server, I understand that good service should always get at least 20-25%, but at the same time, I frown upon places that slap an automatic 18%.  The only thing this policy does is removes the incentives for the service to actually be good.  It was a somewhat obvious symptom here because although the server was friendly and lively, she wasn't very attentive nor reachable.  I was still planning on giving her about 20% regardless, but I think automatic gratuity is a sleazy concept.  It's a gesture of hostility to the guests and implicitly states that customers can't be trusted.  I ended up leaving less money (the obligatory 18%) than I would have left (I was thinking 20-22% in this case) because I felt insulted.  

 So, one pineapple cocktail and a BLT sat me back $25 when you take into account the tax and mandatory tip.  The lunch was definitely not worth $25 in my opinion.  I would have much rather had a $4.95 falafel sandwich from Soom Soom or Maoz instead of paying $25 for the lunch I had here.  

- Comfort.  Although I said earlier that the atmosphere is cozy, the seats aren't!  People are sat close together and in rigid chairs.  I ended up sitting at the elevated bar stools so I can have my personal space, but the chairs were too uncomfortable to sit there and get some serious writing done like I had originally planned.  Also, there are no power outlets for laptops.

- The hipster and yuppie factor. Tables with glued pennies underneath the glass in an attempt to be postmodern. Nuff said.

Went here to meet a girlfriend the other night at around 7. Not only were they out of 50% of the wines on the list, they were also out of all the boozy "infusions" they are famous for. I settled on a vodka cranberry which was OK and has the bacon wrapped prunes which were tasty but a little too cloyingly sweet for my taste. My girlfriend ordered a glass of chard (the only white they had in stock), it was pretty horrid-worse than the stuff we used to consume copious amounts of during college. Her brie and eggplant sandwich was OK, but not great. Don't think I will be heading back anytime soon.
The Bacon changed my life. And I'm a sausage girl.

I work remotely, so the world is my office; my tools: my trusty laptop. My search for free wifi led me to Sip. Nursing a hangover from the previous night of rooftop debauchery, a bar was not what I had in mind, but I was drawn in by the low-key, friendly atmosphere. Although I only ordered iced coffee, the waitress brought over a generous heaping of free tapas, a spread that included olives, bruschetta, and garlic, and never was I under any pressure to vacate my table. The DJ kept the vibe going spinning downtempo hip-hop. I'll definitely be back for drinks when I don't have to work.

With deals so hot the definitely need to get AC. 

Came by for the free internet. Stayed for the half off food. Everything on mondays is half off. Rib dinner for $10 boom!. 

sandwich dinner for $5 bam 

How do you go wrong? It's a little too hot when it's in the high 90s outside. 
Also they put 18% tip on everything so don't be suprised when you see the bill.

I just ate here, the service was terrible. I odered iced tea, when I needed a refil my server wasn't available to get me another one. The salad wasn't good either. 
They add 20% tip to the check for the service which is terrible. The prices for the food is way overpriced.

My new favorite place to waste the day away over a book and multiple glasses of coffee, or wine, depending on how saucy I'm feeling :) 

Sip is great--really small, but it's perfect. They have a great menu and surprisingly delicious food. I love the salads and they make a killer latte. I was jazzed for hours! 

The staff is super friendly and this is one of those places where if you become a regular, the staff will be your new best friends. I love it! I went in on a Saturday afternoon to do some reading/writing and immediately was told "you need a glass of wine." Not only do they categorize the wine by "cheap" and "not cheap", they give a ton of recommendations and i love that. 

Also, how gorgeous is this neighborhood?! I had no idea as this was my first time frequenting "Manhatan Valley" but i love it! I just wish i could transplant this location further down, but it really is gorgeous. Central Park North is truly a little bit of heaven and a breath of fresh air from tourist infested Central Park South that has a Mickey Mantle's (ew) and the abused horses being forced to tote around tourists all.day.long. 

Anyway, i love Sip!

Feeling tired of the bars around Columbia I decided to give Sip a chance. At first it seemed great- some of us wanted food, others coffee and dessert, still others booze. Sip accommodated us all. The music and atmosphere was conducive to friends gathering and talking, which was what we wanted. 

Then came the problems. When it was time to leave, the server came over and apologetically said that their computer system was down. He then said that he could compute the bill manually but that he preferred not to- could we just remember how much we paid and then pay in cash? 

I found it odd that he couldn't compute the bill manually- do they not have a backup calcuator in the place?- and that somehow this became our responsibility. Nonetheless, because we were anxious to leave we started working backward and came up with a total. In the middle of this, though, the server reappeared and asked us for our patience- the computer would start working again soon.

So we waited about 40 more minutes for the computer to work. Didn't happen. Then the server came over and said that we owed about 20 dollars more than we thought, unnecessarily adding "there was a lot of booze" (which there wasn't- maybe a total of five glasses of wine among six people). When we asked for an itemized list, he again groaned and said that it was too hard to remember. Are we that dependent on computers nowadays that we can't keep track of a few glasses of wine and desserts? 

As it turned out, the extra money came on two extra glasses of wine I had ordered. I ordered a "cheap" glass (their words) for $6, and when I ordered two additional ones I expected them to bring me more of the cheap. Instead, they brought me the more expensive $9 glasses without being asked! Realizing this, I protested but was told that I had to specify that I wanted to continue drinking the cheap wine. Like there's a default setting on wine, or whatever.

So sorry, Sip. Gave you a shot, and you blew it. Back to 1020 and the local dives, where at least they're honest.

So after two years of basically living a couple blocks away from SIP, I decided to give it a try and was totally disappointed.

First, I tried ordering two things on the menu (both were associated with the happy hour) and they were "out" of both of them. Really? you are out of the two random things I pick that are the cheapest on the menu? Of course, a more expensive item was recommended to replace what I had asked for.

Second, We also had to repeatedly ask for our free tapas that went along with happy hour, that came out really late afterward. Although I did enjoy my beverage (third choice was a charm) my experience was disrupted by constantly trying to get the waiter's attention.

Third, The AUTOMATIC SURCHARGE of 18%, sealed the deal for me that this place was a one-timer. Honestly, we just had two drinks and had an 18% charge on our bill. The bill also gives you advice on what more you can tip below (different percentages with different prices). If I didn't look close enough I would not have realized I was already charged for the tip. I have never been to a restaurant that does this anywhere else ever (there was only 2 of us and we just had drinks). NICE TRY SIP--never again. Full stop.

I came here to meet a few friends for drinks. The place is small, but there is a good atmosphere and they have free tapas during happy hour! The tapas were ok and the happy hours drink were $7, which I guess is okay. 

I actually showed up a few minutes after happy hour, but because we had such a large group the waiter let us have a couple more rounds at happy hour prices. Unfortunately as soon as you stop drinking they kick you out.

Hm. They have 1/2 off monday meals w/ order of drink. And other assorted great deals.

Small place; decor is kind of "leopard print legging momma"--lots of padded red and black leather, stainless steel bar chairs, candle light, and small glass colored tiles. 

food is reasonably priced without deals too, and vary around a theme of spanish tapas, small sandwiches and panini, bar food, and odds and ends. 

Logically it has all the bits and pieces that could make a good occasional dinner, but I think I prefer it as a late night snack location with a small group of friends. It's also likely a good candidate for a place for a couple that has been together a while, and doesn't need to indulge in viewing-gallery pompous shows of affection--i'm thinking something like indecent acts performed on nightclub speaker stacks. It's great if you just want to have a lively conversation and drinks. The place won't impress, and I think it's probably best for a couple that is already impressed with each other. 

Good thing I'm writing this on Valentine's day!

** 1,200 review **

Massive props to Sip and Ciris, the owner, with big shout outs to the awesome DJ booth built over the stairs, the Lincoln pennies meticulously placed, the infused orange and vanilla bean vodka, the scrumptious mushroom side, the delectable Brussels sprout salad, and the awesome soul/funk vibe. It feels good to have a real neighborhood joint.
Great food, great service. Good hours, too. Come for 5-7 and 2-4 (am) happy hours.

Where should I start....awesome food (Havarti Sandwich with a side of Bacon), drinks (fav place for Sangria) , coffee and its salute to old-school and underground music.  

I've been coming to SIP for over a year now and I am completely addicted to pretty much everything about it, while I kinda want to keep it to myself I also want to tell the word about it.  That being said stop by and enjoy one of the last NY gems.

Oh did i mention the bacon.  ;)

Sip is cute, cozy and delicious! It's a place you could easily walk by and not even notice. The service is always friendly and on point. The coffee is from a french press, which makes it 100x better than drip coffee that has been sitting forever. And of course, there is the Sipwich. It's actually not even on the menu anymore, but still totally available to order. The Sipwich is a delicious egg sandwich topped with all sorts of little delights. Personally, I get a Sipwich with an extra egg, cheese, ham and avocado. My friend gets an extra egg and chorizo. Of course you must also order a side of Billionaire Bacon...because everyone knows no Sipwich is complete without Billionaire Bacon. Sip has become my go-to spot for a comforting breakfast after a late night. I will also admit that I haven't ordered anything else off the menu. I have friends who have ordered the french toast and it was pretty good, but very sweet. It's more like a dessert than a breakfast. 

You must feel comfortable sitting very close to people and having a lack of table privacy to come to Sip. Normally, that would bother me, but Sip rocks it with service and food. So with that, I'm forgiving of my lack of personal space. This is not a place for groups. Normally, I only come here with one or two other people and it's perfect.
Decent German beer on tap, like Weihenstephan.  Pretty good snack food, especially tiny  hot dogs wrapped in  tiny croissants.  Not to pricey.   Probably a good place to hit starting at 1am...

Sip appears to be an awesome, awesome place for writers and workers with a few caveats.  The place is small/cozy but not cramped, has many different seating options, outlets and wifi for the laptop luggers, decent prices on food and drink, and serves food, coffee/tea, and liquor!  Also, the whole Open 'Til 4am thing makes me squeal with delight.

The caveats are as follows:

Outlets - there are only outlets along the wall with the bar-height seating and in the back.  So laptop people are limited to those spaces.

Busy Times - Weekends they serve brunch until about 4pm, which means a lot of people coming in and perhaps less tolerance for people taking up a table forever.  Happy Hour begins at 5 and goes until 7 each day, and the woman behind the counter informed me that it's a pretty busy time.  So, for weekdays, it looks like before 5 is best.  For weekends, after 7.  But, again, open until 4 am...

For writers - If you have a small group of writers (no more than 5) you should be fine sitting in the area in the back.  But if, when you arrive, that is taken, you're totally SOL.  I would suggest writing dates with one or two other people at the most.  The again, if you show up at 10PM on a Thursday night, you may find the place yours for the taking.

I think SIP is a great place and I cannot but approve of their wifi and late hours.
My friend lives really close by so we went here a few times for an afterparty. Then she ran out and thought she spotted a love interest! It was a scene in a movie! So hilarious, she is so adorable!

A very fun cute place - so close to being a five star, but it loses one for its own identity crisis.  I came this weekend with my favorite UWS fellow bruncher in search of sustenance and a new place.  We found it on Yelp, natch, and were very pleasantly surprised.  Seems like a great place to chill if you live in the neighborhood - free wifi, great coffee (bonus points for the french press), fun music.  And the food was quite yummy.  I had some kind of egg + chorizo + potato yumminess.

But here's the rub - it's trying to be all things to all people: a wifi cafe, a bar, a restaurant, and it doesn't have the ability (or the space) to be any more than one at a time.  The tables aren't really big enough to hold food, coffee, utensils, etc. for two people.  And if you come with a laptop, aren't you taking up a table for someone who might want to eat?  There's only about 12 tables in the place.  Also, it's long and narrow, so I can only imagine the bottle neck at the bar on a crowded night.  I'm being nitpicky, I guess, but it's worth noting.

Also, I have to call out the decor - weirdly Abraham Lincoln/Penny themed.  Whoever glued all those pennies in a row to EVERY surface deserves a medal.  Love the local art on the walls too.  All in all a good place to try in a very up and coming part of town.  I know too many people who live up here not to come back at some point.

Whatever you do you MUST go to the Sunday brunch. They serve the best beacon I've ever had.  Sip is a really really small spot and will get crowded extremely quick. So if your going to plan on going then you need to make sure to get there early and plan to wait during the brunch. 

But the food here is good...however if you go for brunch they will not put cheese on your eggs. They seem to have troubles making scrambled eggs with cheese. But otherwise its an enjoyable spot and the food is good.
Super friendly place.  Defines neighborhood joint.

I'm approaching Sip as a work cafe, not a club or restaurant. It's a little awkward as a work space, as it is cramped and about 1/3 of the seating is on stools along a wall bar. The staff was very friendly: I asked if I could squat and work (mid-afternoon), and they were good with that. There is a bit of a menu with smaller items (like baguette and jam: the jam was pretty ordinary). It's a decent alternative to Hungarian Pastry Shop and an upgrade over Cafe Fresh further down Amsterdam (though less physically spacious).

Had to come back to SIP (was there twice actually on this NYC trip)!  The 3 course brunch with the all you can drink option was amazing!  And for only $25!  You just can't beat that.  The food was great, the drinks were great, the service was great.  Perfection.

I've been to Sip multiple times, for dinner (usually on Mondays when it is half price), drinks, and tapas. Here's my take:

GOOD: 
-Some of the dishes are tasty. I particularly like the roasted chicken, the field greens salad, and the macaroni and cheese. Salmon was also good but is no longer on the menu.  
-They use fresh squeezed grapefruit juice in their drinks. 
-The imported pastries are good, love the macaroons. 
-The vibe is chill, and nice eclectic tunes, as others have noted. The art on the walls changes often. 
-The servers and other staff have been really friendly and helpful.
-Good place to hang out with a laptop or book, a cocktail or coffee
-They recently revamped their cocktail menu with some interesting options.

NOT SO GOOD: 
-Some of the dishes are not as good. The sea bass came very overcooked, the bananas foster needed more rum or liqueur to cut the overpowering sweetness of dish, and although the components in the ceasar salad were tasty (fresh romaine, parmesan tuile), it was so awkward to eat, served vertically, with whole pieces of romaine that already have dressing on them. You can't eat it with your hands and dip the dressing without getting dressing all over your hands, and you can't eat it with a fork because the romaine hearts are 8 inches long, and you can't cut it up because the plate is too small. 
-I love that the grapefruit juice is squeezed there, but the seeds need to be strained out. 
-Service can be reaaalllyy sslllooow with only one server for the entire place
-the seating is awkward, since the hard chairs are about 6 inches higher than the vinyl seats, which are much too low for the tables. And then you end up being ridiculously higher or lower than your date/friend.
-the menu has barely changed in 3 years and does not change with the seasons. cabbage soup is still monday's soup. some of the entrees have changed, but not much.
-Mondays at 1/2 off is a good deal (18% gratuity included), but I don't feel it's worth it to pay full price

My biggest gripe about this place is the automatic 18% gratuity. Perhaps they instituted this rule b/c of the free wi-fi and some people who spend endless hours at cafes but never order anything. But really, that only gave this waitress ZERO motivation to actually care about service. She only got our order and delivered our drinks. Everything else we had to flag down her attention. 

I don't even know what the point of having a waitress is. I could totally bus my own table. It's so freakin' small anyway, it's like let me just order at the counter, get a number, and wait for my food to come out. 

Also, someone mentioned that the place was uncomfortable. Yeah, that would be b/c they use outdoor metal folding chairs and try to squeeze in as many people as possible. I was practically sitting at the same table as the next person, but not. 

I got a cappuccino, and was disappointed at how small it was for $4. It was also extremely bitter, which I wasn't a fan of. I usually put like 2-3 sugars, but this I had to put like 5-6 sugars, and it was smaller than "regular" cappuccinos.

Usually, I tip 20% anyway (15% min for sub par) but I made sure to leave EXACT change b/c this place did not deserve a penny more.

The vibe and decor of this small place draw you in, myself on multiple occasions (there's not a lot of nice looking places like this in the area). But the food is just not good, especially for the price. Last time I had a caesar salad which was frankly ridiculous - the presentation of the dish was so elaborate that it was almost imposible to eat it (besides the fact that it had very little flavor). On top of that, the service is sometimes lazy, like the servers are fed up being there and are more interested in talking with their friends. The 18% mandatory gratuity is off-putting too. I find this place is best as a place to come by in the afternoon for a coffee and work on your laptop for an hour or two.

Side note: the place feels very cramped the way it's organized at the moment. A few friends sat at the table closest to the bathroom and my friend was asked to move to another chair because his chair was in the way of the server. Why are there chairs in this area if they're not meant to be sat on?

Sip is an awesome place for brunch on Sundays. It is trendy, the food is not that fancy but it is classic and good, and the bartender is friendly and pays good attention to when you need a refill.

Get there early to get a seat (it really seems to start filling up around 11) or you might have to wait a while because it is small. 

I will definitely go back to try out their evening dinner and drink specials!

Discovered this place thanks to MJ (Thanks MJ) and it has officially been added to my favorite list.  

Did you know that tapas are free with drinks during their happy hour?  Garlic shrimp is to die for and so is their swine in a quilt.  I know, the word swine makes me wanna puke (since I had a swine flu) but it's still good.  Their beer selection is limited but they are from a local brewery and so f'ing good.

This place is tiny.  I don't think you can fit more than 25 people here but that's why I like it.  A small hidden gem.

I highly recommend this place.  (Com'on, I even go all the way up there from where I live) :D

Finally tried sip after living in the area for 5 months. I was super excited because it seemed like a very cool spot. I have mixed emotions. 

 everyone is right. Amazing playlist. Old school hip hop, black sabbath, ramones, MJ, MIA, even cumbia! Awesome. It's a cozy place, just comfy. Fun decor. Music low enough to converse and loud enough to seat dance.  service was.. Unremarkable. Thats all I can say. Not friendly and not rude. 

The Cappuccinos we ordered were teensy, table next to us had huge mugs! Mustve been lattes! No worries. 

Towards the end music got turned up to club level which was inappropriate and made chatting difficult. It happened so quickly randomly.

Over all it's ok. Will try it for hh and give it another go.

Meh. Second time I went there and still not impressed. Yes, Mondays is half  off food menu- I might go back to that...
But the space is very tiny, the drinks are overpriced, $4.00 for a cup of tea and the music completely overwhelms the space. 
My friends and I grabbed a table and chairs by the sliding open doors, and spent most of our time there- yelling to be heard.
The bartender kept running out to smoke cigs and flirt.
Go there with someone you don't like.
Cozy atmosphere and yummy breakfast!  They never rush their customers here and are super friendly and down-to-earth.

A good friend of mine lives around the corner from here, and generally when we're done singing 1-2 hours of opera, we're in need of a drink.  Sip fits the bill very well - the drinks here are quite good (just be careful of the Bees' Knees if gin lays you out like it does me.  However, the barkeep WILL do it with vodka as well on request!).  The food isn't bad, although I think there's better for less in the hood.  

The space is tiny and a bit cramped - you want to be here on a night when it's not too busy!!

Food at brunch came out cold, and when I tried to complain it took the waiter so long to get back to us that I was looked at like I was crazy.  Well, it came out cold.
