Don't look at me like 'i gave you that 20 minutes ago of course it's cold now' when it took me that long to get your attention.  Then tack on an 18% gratuity to deal with that kind of service.  Not recommended at all!

I recently went here on a date. We did not have food, so I cannot comment on that. The drinks that we did have however were well done. We had the grown up shirley temple and the something wench. I particularly enjoyed that the shirley temple came with the sprite separately so that the drink gradually got weaker as you added more sprite and drank it down. It was an interesting progression.

The atmosphere was nice...slightly loud due to the volume of music being spun by the DJ. I would have appreciated it more on a weekend, but this was a Monday night, so I expected something a bit more serene.

Overall I'd go back.

I will never go here again. I gave it 2 chances. The waiters are rude and don't listen.  My order always gets messed up. The waiter refused to give me change the second time I went and actually said he thought he DESERVED a better tip. It's tiny and loud. The food is overpriced for what it is, and its not that good. The coffee tasted like water. 
They try way too hard to be "hipster and eclectic" and quite frankly this place is highly overrated. I'd rather go to the Mc Donalds a few blocks away, and trust me I rarely, if ever, say that.

me: went to this cafe and they had HORRIBLE service
me: the waitress was so rude
me:  and we ordered a lot of stuff too
me:  and i  left early but i heard that they (my friends) got kicked out after  because they weren't ordering additional stuff
friend: wth?!!? where is this?
me: sip on 110th and amsterdam
me:  when we were waiting for a seat, the bartender asked us if he could make us a drink
me: and i didn't feel like drinking but i was really dehydrated
me:  so i asked for a glass of water instead
friend: wth! that aggravates me with restaurants
me:  and he gave me a grimace before giving me water
friend: i hope it closes ASAP
me:  and A had ordered coffee in the beginning while we were choosing which food to order
me:  and BEFORE the waitress took our order, she said  "oh i'm not going to give you the 50% off food if all you order is a cup of coffee"
me:  cuz on the menu it says 50% off all food on mondays
me:  and she just straight up threatened us that she wouldnt
me: so C ordered a drink, R ordered a drink, A had coffee, we ALL ordered food
friend: wth?!!!!
me:  but at the end the waitress didn't give us half off all the food
me:  cuz we didn't all order drinks
me: even though they didn't specify that we had to on the menu
friend: wtf?1?!
me:  im so pissed
friend: that's bullshit
friend: i would've walked out or not paid enough
me: they also include 18% tip
me:  and it's a freakin cafe with wifi, you're not supposed to kick people out
friend:wtf!
friend:sip?
me:  yeah

*edit*
Oh yeah, forgot to add that they were out of half the food we tried to order.

I guess I'll keep the 4 stars....although I'd really like to bumb it down to a 3.5. 

My 2nd visit here was a bit off par...1st off...this establishment needs to be given a lesson in technology and the new age. The waiter uses a touch screen pad to enter in all the orders (yes, very tech savvvy...but)...we were ordering, my friend first, then me, then my other friend...when before we were done ordering my first friend wanted to change her order. No biggie right? We hadn't even finished ordering. The waiter jokes around like, oh no, you can't change your order, I've already put it in the system...it's already at the kitchen...blah, blah, blah. Apparently he wasn't kidding though. He said there was just no possible way to change it. NOTHING he could do. Even though we were in the middle of ordering...WTF??? 30 min later after going back and forth from our table back to the bar...discussing the issue with the bartender (no manager to be in sight), and refusing to give us water, he finally comps my friend $10 to compensate for the change she wanted. Why couldn't that have been done in the first place??? 

2nd...the food is usually very good here. Fresh fruit with more than just melon and cantelope...delicious mac & cheese and the most amazing broccoli au grautin you'll ever have. One of us got what was supposed to be the chicken omelet with a side of sausage. Sausage...pretty questionable texture...not so great on taste. The omelet? Well....it was supposed to be a chicken omelet...the 'chicken' also had very questionable texture...turns out...it's chicken liver. The waiter failed to mention that we wouldn't be getting chicken breast...but instead chicken LIVER...in an omelet.

We were all hungover and just wanted some carbs to soak up the alcohol in our stomachs...so you can imagine how these ridiculous issues were kinda tuggin' on our nerves.

The rest of the food was good. Juice - fresh squeezed...but watch out for seeds in your cup. 

Another thing to watch out for...which really is totally sketchy and again goes back to being behind in the times...they don't give copies of receipts if you're paying with a CC. So...they could very well change all the numbers you write down and you'd have no record and hence no say in the matter and could get screwed. Not that that happened...but really...who doesn't ALLOW copies to be given out with CC receipts?? 

Not sure I'll be back...really just wasn't WOWed this time. And service both times has been flaky.

Sip is a great place to go for amazing drinks, food, and coffee. They've pretty much got all of it--cheap brunch for lazy Sunday mornings, delicious infusions for a Saturday night out (be it at 10PM or 4AM), and really good coffee made on really good machines for a wonderful kick-start to your work day. Free wi-fi and a glass of the cheap red makes for an easy study spot. Friendly owner and staff, great music, sweet spot.

Our waitress was probably up there on my list of worst dining experiences. Not only did she take over 30 minutes to bring us our drinks (because she was drinking herself at the bar), she forgot my order when she brought everyone's food out - at least an hour after we had ordered. And I only ordered a toasted English muffin, which took another 30 minutes to finally get to the table.

The atmosphere is hip and the interior is cozy for a small group of friends, but set aside a lot of time if you really want to try out this bar.

Okay, I'm biased because I had been DJing at Sip every other Saturday night (how's that for promotion?) since September 2006. However, as a life long NYer who has observed and experienced a lot of significant change in the city over more than a decade, it's nice to know a place like Sip exists in Northern Manhattan.  

As many folks in New York City are aware of most lounges, bars and clubs in Manhattan that are located away from the central nightlife areas don't really address the interests of folks who fall out of line with mainstream culture. Then factor in that there has been a mainstreaming of lower Manhattan's nightlife. In other words local neighborhoods are increasingly starved for quality nightlife. 

For folks Uptown or the on Upper West Side the options have been slim other than the typical bar with 10 flat screen TVs playing 5 different sports, and a few hip looking lounges and clubs here and there that have DJs spinning top 40 and a little dance music (if you're lucky). 

Fortunately, Sip is a great space, albeit small, for local "downtown/bohemian" types, but isn't pretentious enough to scare off folks who are not into that scene. Sure, they also serve bistro food, have Wi-Fi, an all-you-can drink brunch on weekends, and the vibe at night is on point. 

You could ask why have DJs in such a narrow space, but Sip is clearly a haven for Uptowners that want something different. It's part lounge, bar, coffee shop, bistro, art gallery. With new artists work displayed on its walls constantly changing, and resident DJs spinning eclectic mixes of music ranging from electronica, funk, hip-hop (often old school and mash-ups), electro, baile funk, house and reggae (more dancehall) it provides a much needed alternative for those in the area.

Those wondering why they don't see DJ's all of the time is because they play at night, mostly, although DJ Dan plays during Brunch on Sunday (I believe).

Fridays are now with DJ Know1 who spins more hip-hop, afro-beat, reggae, funk/soul

When I played there I used to spin a bit more of a electronic music set with house, electro, detroit techno, baile funk/mash-ups and nudisco, but I always played hip-hop, soul, re-edits, afro-beat, and reggae.

They also have happy hour from 2-4am which is great for the late night crowd.

It can get pretty crowded some weekends, but not always. The crowd is often very mixed, which is often why we play to so many music types, and there are local heads who come in all of the time that constantly come through. Also, when the weather gets warm the entire front of the place is open which is very cool. The fact is that there are few spots like it in the area, so if you do live nearby it's worth coming either for a meal or a night out.

Tasty food and drinks, but a little expensive and crowded.  Also the DJ has to climb over a table to get into the booth which is mildly amusing, but potentially dangerous and/or annoying.  Good happy hour on Sunday though and cool atmosphere.

Let's see....went alone, ordered the chicken pot pie and a glass of "cheap wine" for $6 a glass. The wine was definitely cheap, and the pot pie was initially tasty, but I think the chef stuck a whole stick of butter in there. While I love butter, I think I felt a little queasy by the end. It was very fresh at least- fresh and from a whole chicken- as I found some unexpected thin bones in there, too. A good dish if you like it rich.

They include 18% gratuity in the check regardless of party size. While I don't mind it too much if they include gratuity, I do get annoyed when the first bill comes and says it includes gratuity- I put my credit card down- and then they come back with the second charged slip and have an empty line that says "GRATUITY"- in which case you have to remember that they've already included tip. Feels scammy. I think 18% gratuity is quite alright for our time in the century.

The best part of the place is that all the workers appear to make efforts to be friendly, and the atmosphere is generally cozy. The waiter I got was some new guy on the job who was really hot. Now I'm pretty straight, but damn.
A gem.  I love the vibe and the decor here.  Certainly one of the best places for a late night cocktail in this neighborhood.
Only reason to go here is the dates appetizer. Beer selection is limited.

Sip is a "coffeebar and lounge" located on Amsterdam Ave, between 110th and 111th. They are open almost 24 hours a day, and there always seems to be a decent crowd. 

Although the drinks can sometimes get expensive (I once paid around $10 for a well vodka lemonade), the happy hour drink specials, combined with the delicious free tapas, are a great bargain. In general, the food is fantastic, and I highly recommend the apple and brie sandwich with a glass of Bulls Blood. For a full menu, see Sip's web site.

They claim to have live DJs regularly, although I've never seen one (I don't come every day though). However, don't let that discourage you, because their playlist is usually spot on, and includes everything from old school rock and hip hop to contemporary electronic producers such as RJD2. 

Sip has become my go-to spot while waiting for my clothes at the laundromat, conveniently located next door. Sip also has free wifi, and on several occasions I've brought my laptop and sat down for a productive work session. Tip: there are power outlets conveniently located under the table at each station across from the bar.

If you're looking for a fun place to relax, study, work, or even wait for your laundry to dry, Sip is a great place to be.
Great service, great drinks, great little spot near Columbia. Happy hour is awesome, free Tapas! and good menu! Check it out.

Forget Starbucks, Peet or whatever ... this place is non-generic - is has a character. Very nice ambience, not mainstream, interesting diverse and kind people, great service, good wifi, good coffee, wine, food ... just everything you need. good music too: Rolling Stones, Led Zeppelin, world music. Not dead-cheap, but worth it!
I sat here with my laptop all day only ordering coffee and wine. the waiter brought me one complimentary snack after the next... very sweet!
The interior has white, red, black and a counter of 1-cent-coins. Looks pretty cool!

So this is a great little spot for a snack and some good sangria. They actually make it right here with liquor mixed into the wine and fruit goodness.

There service is ok, but I don't come there for the service. I come for a good drink and some good food. Their menu is pretty good, with some nice options for most palates. 

They menu and and most dishes show this place has a chef and not just a line cook putting up some solid plates. Be weary of dishes with chunks of beef, as you can rarely expect a great piece of beef at such cheap prices. 

The space is small, so if you're tall or large in any sense of the word this space will not be comfortable for you most likely. 

I like Monday evenings since I'm usually in the area on Mondays. It gets fairly packed this day,  so I'd recommend choosing another evening since there are no reservations. 

Don't be surprised by the included 18% gratuity on all checks. Do expect some decent music to be played from time to time, even if it's from someone's ipod.

Like Schiller's on the LES, they sell wine by the glass by 3 choices - cheap, medium and expensive.  The cheap is not bad.

And they have delcious chocolate covered macaroons.

I've only been here for brunch, as dinner seems kind of expensive. We got the $25 brunch with unlimited bloody marys and mimosas. 

The food was very good, in a fattening sort of way. Ample quantity. The ingredients seemed to be of good quality. Unfortunately, the drinks were both small and weak. I must have had at least six and I wasn't buzzed at all.

Honestly, the best thing about this place is its decor - very funky and fun to look at. It is a bit cramped, so maybe not good for kids or very large people. 

If you go, get the $15 brunch sans alcohol.

Wanted to avoid being the biggest lame-o in the world by going to the library on a Friday night during WINTER BREAK, so instead, I decided to be a lesser lame-o and go to this bar/lounge/coffee shop, alone, to drink water and pretend to be productive on a Friday night (think I officially reached my pinnacle of lameness). 

A bit cramped for space with regard to availability & proximity of seating and the size of the tables, but the waitress was nice, attentive, and sociable. I finally started to work when I got my food not much after ordering (roasted eggplant sandwich with a beet salad or some sort). It was then that I had a moment of self-realization. As I began to recognize this new feeling I was experiencing as fear of nearly self-inducing a seizure, it dawned on me that this place is way too dimly lit at night to even pretend you're going to a) see anything well enough to get work done or b) not go blind alternating between an incredibly bright laptop screen and the romantic/cool/lounge-y ambient lighting.

That being said, my intention was not to stay long because it really started getting to me. So much for my plan to work. The sandwich was quite alright and the salad intriguingly weird but tasty, but I booked it as soon as I could for fear for my ocular well-being. Probably totally cool during the day, but not really a spot for productivity at night. My bad.

Real-time Yelp: I'm sitting in Sip at this very moment, enjoying a small pot of coffee (french press) and a selection of tasty (free!) tapas.  The place is tiny, as many have already attested, but charming.  Friendly service, pleasant music, and quirky decor.  And wifi, of course, or I wouldn't be writing this.

When to go: 5-7pm for free tapas; 2-4am for happy hour.
Wine isn't terribly good, but the service is nice.

Nice staff, fun atmosphere - I thought they were more of a coffee shop but are really just a sit-down restaurant. They let me order coffee to go anyways though and it tasted great. The chairs outside were great too to sit in and smoke a cigarette while drinking said tasty coffee. I'd happily go back.

Just came home from one of the worst brunch experience ever!  First thing- they add 18% gratuity to all checks, and it doesn't say it on the brunch menu (it does on the regular menu but that wasn't presented to me).  Secondly- my french toast came out cold and just was a thick mess.  It was made from unidentifiable old dry bread/cake filled with cream cheese covered in syrup (prob to disguise the actual taste of the bread) and on top on some sort of creamy overly sweet sauce and jelly....the menu just says french toast.  All of that other stuff isn't listed at all.  I had one bite and sent it back. Was still charged for it and treated very poorly and in a curt dismissive tone by the barista/manager.   I've worked in restaurants for years.  I regularly tip 20-30% (esp on brunch because it's cheap and usually amazing).  I found the automatic gratuity for a party of 2 insulting, and being charged for food I didn't eat beyond over the top.

I moved into the neighborhood as most of the bars on Amsterdam in this stretch were changing hands and reopening with new concepts, and Sip seemed the most promising.  I sitll think it's worth a stop in -- on weekends it's packed with all sorts of people, and on any given night there are a bunch of regulars who will chat you up -- including the neighborhood druglords and bar owners.  Sip doesn't have the best liquor selection, but they have creative mixed drinks and a decent wine list.  I tried the soup off the limited food menu and it was surprisingly good.  Earlier in the day (much earlier) Sip functions as a coffeeshop and looks inviting for those who want a quiet place to sit and use free wifi.  I don't know what to make of the place though, but I guess that's not bad -- they have good music, a somewhat hip vibe, and you really never known who will take the stool next to you.  (And the place gets points for providing the hooks under the bar so you can hang your stuff!)

Where do I begin? Everything about my experience here with my friends was the worst nightmare anyone could imagine. Overpriced beer that the bartender could not pour correctly even though it took him 10 minutes to do so. 1 server for the entire place who had no idea about anything she was selling(except the most expensive and unappealing items) they auto grat %18 for everyone. Yeah my food was good but so is the food at Ihop. $6 for a shot of well vodka at this piece of shit hole in the wall? DJs spinning awful music and constantly climbing up and down behind your booth while you're trying to enjoy what you can out of this train wreck of an establishment. Tables so close together that you're constantly being elbowed by everyone in the building. I have never had such a terrible experience in my life. I feel like there are no words to properly justify how much of an awful place this it. avoid it. avoid it. avoid it.

Sip was my anthropological "third place."  A home away from home, with a second happy hour that ran from 2-4 am.  Sip got me through law school.  

Sadly, this magical little bar is now CLOSED.
half price on mondays! but super crowded on mondays...

Eggs in a Basket: This is Rocky Mountain toast with bacon on the side.  They do it perfectly. It was happy hour so I got a $4 pint of stout and it came with a free tapas dish. 

Sip WINS.

Tight quarters, Food is good, worth squeezing in for a seat.

Went here on a Thursday night to see my friend who DJ's at the after hours when it turns into a lounge.  This place is incredibly tiny.  When my friend said cozy he meant intimately cozy.  Arrived close to 1am, and the place was jam packed.  You seriously had to crawl over people to walk through.   The crowd is your collage age range.  Music that night was great!  The food was surprising delish.  Plus I know they run a special 2 for 1 I think after 1am to 4am.  The workers were pretty awesome.  Oh and I'll make note that the Mojito is pretty good.  The waiter challenged me to try it or I'd get it for free plus whatever drink I wanted to replace it with since I'm a pretty great Mojito maker myself.  He passed!

I'm sure it is hit or miss with the crowd during the Lounge nights, but I'd recommend going during the day to try the food.

Still great food and uber-friendly staff. 

The only bad thing is that they automatically add 18% gratuity onto your bill.

Today is the day I started Yelping again, as a New Yorker, and started filling in the gaps between my experiences here and my reviews thereof.  This is my fourth review today, and the first written at one of my subjects.  Yes, the place has free wireless, so that feature is checked off.

I know this is a nearly-always-open bar.  I've only been here once as a booze patron, on a night of bar hopping during orientation week at school.  I had nothing bad to say about Sip-as-bar, but I admit I was already in good company, ethanol-happy, and seated at the edge of the patio area.  No complaints.

That having been said, I can see where the experience might have been less than stellar for the dedicated bar hopper, at least in respect of the size of the place.  No other boozer data to share.

Instead, the few times I've been here, I've been attracted by the signs offering off-peak cheap(er) food and coffee combos.  Just now, I had not one, but two of the "Sipwich" $4 sandwich and coffee combos.  They were fabulous, even factoring in the fact that I was starving when I stepped through the door: the "billionaire bacon" followed by the chorizo version.  Both were generous and mouthwatering.

Seating when I've done the off-peak thing has always been comfortable.  Cheerful environment, and genuinely friendly service.  Music has never been overwhelming when I've been here, but then I've not been here when a DJ has been working. I tend to avoid times busy enough to merit a DJ.

I've never felt more at home than when I'm at SIP. Not many places where the owners will actually welcome you like a regular even if it's your time. Happy 2x a day and good prices during non-happy hour. In a way I hate giving it a good review in fear that it will get crowded.

I don't get all the love for this place, although I haven't been here for brunch. I've eaten lunch there several times and the food has always been well below average. If you don't eat anything and treat this place as  a coffee house or a bar, it's probably just fine. The do have free internet which is a big plus.

Seriously delicious food. Lots of fresh vegetables and good, quality ingredients-- I've had the lobster ravioli, field greens salad, and a few sandwiches that come with a daily veggie side. All impressive and worth coming back for. Mondays are half off food (!) otherwise it is a bit pricey.

The decor is a bit confused- feels like a 50's bowling alley alchemy lounge- and the wifi is really slow, but service is friendly and there is not much else in the neighborhood so this place is one of my new favorite spots!

Sip is one of those places that makes you question the entire concept of brunch. You're tired, hungover and hungry, and you just want some damn food. At Sip last Sunday, it was not worth the wait. The place is cute but tiny, and three of us were crammed into what would be a tight fit for two. 

It took us a good 20 minutes to get water and about 45 minutes before my friend's soup arrived. It was another 15 minutes before the rest of the food showed up. It wasn't even overly crowded, but there was only one waiter working. The frazzled newb kept forgetting our juice and coffee, and the "quiche of the day" was a cold frittata. Um, no.

Best Mac & Cheese. EVER. 

And their DIY Caesar salad is truly a work of art. 

I'd recommend the half-price Mondays but too many people already know about so go on a different night!

My one beef is with the name. Sip. I am so over these pithy one-word restaurant names. Considering the entire place is decked out in pennies and other Abraham Lincoln decor, why not call the place "The Abe Lincoln"? 

Also, the waiters take your order on a Palm Pilot-type gadget which seems high-tech but the service is actually kinda slow. Not sure why they need the gadget.

Baby it's cold out there.  Must warm up.  Sip is a good place to do just that.

A friend lives in the neighborhood.  Has lived here for a while.  Previous to yesterday, she had never been here.  Today was her second day in a row.  Who knows what tomorrow might bring for her?

By day this place is more of a coffee and pastry shop.  By night it becomes more of a bar/lounge type of a place.  We specifically came here to get out of the cold and get something warm to drink.

We both ordered tea ($3.50) and a rugelach ($1).  Their rugelach were interesting.  I had a NY Cheesecake rugelach and she had a Black Forest rugelach.  I had never had such fancy rugelach before and might never have one again, but the one I had was really good.

They also had hamentashen on the menu.  Impressive.  I haven't had one of those in years and didn't on this day either.

This was a good find.

On this balmy Sunday night I went uptown with Brittany to meet her friends in this loungey bar/cafe. Everyone was friendly and familiar.

This small narrow place has local artist's work on the walls and good music to distract you as you sit in the snug at the back. If you sit in the front you can watch the neighborhood pass by. On this night I met a local art teacher (with his fake Nike Jordan IIIs bought on eBay for $45), a whole bunch of ecletic Columbia students and L-Train (introduced to me as the local crackhead).

A nice neighborhood vibe, but too small to grow into a popular social watering hole, but being open till 4am on Sunday is something to be thankful for, I guess. Yes, we did stay till 4am. Where the time went , I don't know...!

Dear Sip, I really wanted to like you - I even gave you a second chance. I like the  concept and the deals sound good..but the execution left something to be desired. 2 1/2 stars might be more appropriate, but not this time.

I've been here twice - once for half-off food Mondays and free tapas from 5-7 on a weekday.  Yes, I am a cheap college student.  I can only afford so much at once..

Monday was fun, the food was too little for the portions. You also have to get a drink for the half-off special.. Didn't know that before going, and it is not mentioned on ANY of their ads. Not cool I think that's called false advertising. :( The food was fine though. Don't get the french toast unless you're in the mood for cream cheese and bricks.

When I went for free tapas, I knew we'd be getting drinks. And since it was happy hour, all the drinks were under $10. Yay!  I liked most of the mixes, and the alcohol was strong. The tapas did take a while to come, and when we finally were served, the bites were tiny (1/4 of a sandwich.. for 4 people??) The food did come in rounds though, so we eventually got more food.

Service is a bit distant. They are always talking to the bar tender or someone in the back. It's nice that they are so friendly, but it was hard to get their attention (both times).

Everything at sip sounds really good, but I feel like the people working there are just too cool/miserly to make it happen.

This place would have gotten a better review from me if not for the lousy service.  Its a shame b/c the vibe and look of the place is really cool and intriguing, especially for the area.   But at each stage, the server (I think might be an owner as well) walked past 5 times without doing a damn thing.  Here's the part where you give a menu, here's the part where you take a drink order, here's where you take a food order, etc...  He just kept walking by without even so much as a glance!  It took so long for him to get my food order, I was about 2 minutes away from plunking down money for my drink (that would be $3.50 for an 8 oz coke) when he finally came back by.
Then unfortunately it was after I ordered my food that I noticed the "grade pending" sign in the window from the health dept.  (as I was recently informed, thats code for they got a bad grade and are disputing it).  
I had eggs with potatoes and smoked salmon and it was very average.
I *may* go back for the 1/2 price wine on Monday, but I wont go on an empty stomach, thats for sure

Nice coffeshop and nice decor. Small place...but they have enough space to seat maybe 10 to 15 people comfortably. 

I paid almost $5 for an espresso after tax & tip (it's a sit down coffeeshop).

The espresso was good...but nothing special. I wasn't impressed at all.

Great atmosphere... Awful service. The entire waitstaff was drunk/high and totally neglected us. There's an 18% gratuity added to your check, so they definitely don't work for tips...

Also a bit overpriced for quality. I don't mind spending money, but cafe Amrita on 110th and bistro ten 18 on the corner of 110th and Amsterdam are MUCH better choices.

Eh. Not bad. I'm not going to blame them for the not giving me their fantastic and legendary brunch because my schedule means that my "weekend" is Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Thus when I came here for brunch it was a Friday morning and therefore was unable to get it. Understandable.

The cobb salad that I had was tasty, if over priced, and Shea's food looked good. The ambiance was cool, as was the music selection and the servers. The biggest con about the place was the price. An 8 oz bottle of coke is $3, the food portions were disproportionately small (despite their tastiness), and they insta-grat you 18%. I didn't mind the last part too much because they did warn us in the menu and before we got the check. The only time I don't like it is when a waitress slaps it on a table of two without telling. 

All in all I think I'll be back for brunch, but probably not otherwise.

Words that come to mind: tiny, cool and versatile.  No matter the time of day or mood you're in, chances are they'll have something for you: coffee/tea, wine/beer/cocktail, tapas, entree, dessert, breakfast.  You name it.

I ate dinner there the other night (venison) and it was pretty decent, however, it seemed like the effort put into plating was slightly disproportionate to the dish itself.  Can't complain (much) though.  Our waitress was friendly and chill (read: unpretentious).  Not a place to go out of your way for, but it's in my 'hood and I'll definitely be frequenting from now on.

Bartenders etiquette 101
1) Be quick
2) Be courteous
3) Know your drinks
4) Don't rob the customer - unless it is deserved
5) Pour what is paid for - unless you really don't want customers


Sips cafe gets scale of A-F (because it's a Colombia bar
1)F - 20 minutes for a martini and with only ONE drink order ahead of me
2)F - waitress was nice but the bartender acted like i just walked into her living room and took a dump
3)C - "Kettle Martini, up, olives" this took clarification
4)F - short watery pour (at $13 in a not so swanky location)
5)FFF - despite the mediocre first martini, i was only half finished with my food and ordered a second.  Having noted the weak Kettle the first time and the fact that she poured the bottle out, i was excited to get a new (undiluted) pour. no luck - instead of opening a new bottle, or just asking if i wouldn't mind another top shelf, the bartender tried (despite the fact that i was sitting 5 feet away) to replace Kettle One with POPOV!!!! and, wait for it, and to charge me for a second kettle.  OK i get it - this happens in bars at 3:50 am when the clients are drooling drunk and the bartender/owner is a cheap bastard, but at 6:30 pm with a client who is (literally) reading quietly and having dinner??  Well Done Sips, well done!

i have to amend this a little bit - i went here for brunch last Sunday and they offer what may be the best house-made olives in town as a 'course' in the brunch...good stuff.  Just go and get a bowl of olives and a Popov martini and you're golden

Great find - definitely think after a few more visits I would bump this up to a four-star review.  I only had their Monday soup (basque cabbage), which was generous in size and even more generous in flavor!  I took a sip of my friend's cocktail, Orange Wallbanger, which is reminiscent of a cream-cyle (yum!).    Although our waitress was super nice and chill, we did have to flag her down to order and get our check.

The Business is permanently closed. Went by there for lunch, and the door broken, with a sign that the business is closed.  The owner's Facebook page announced that they had permanently closed on New Years Day, 2012.  Very sad to hear this.  We loved the place!

I'm commenting on SIP as a daytime venue.
Do you hate Hungarian Pastry Shop? Go here instead. They serve coffee in a bodum, they have wifi. So what is the down side, it's a bit small and it's a bit darker. The food is pretty decent quality and decently priced. What more could a student want?

Some friends and I ate here for brunch yesterday afternoon.

Initially we were just walking past to look at the menu, when our waiter Matthew (I prefer to call him "Charlie" though) informed us that they had the best food in town and that he had a table ready for us, we went on inside and sat down.

They offer a prix fixe menu for Sunday brunch.  For $25 you can get a three course brunch, plus all you can drink mimosas, bloody marys, coffee, tea and juice (the fresh squeezed orange juice is AMAZING!).  For $15, you can get the same thing, just without the liquor.  Well, since gas is up to like $35 a gallon, and since I'd had plenty to drink the night before celebrating my birthday, I opted for the liquor-free brunch.

Before I forget, the music was great!  On Sundays they have a DJ there, who broadcasts on some satellite radio station.  The musical selections were smooth and soulful, and perfect for a lazy, beautiful Sunday afternoon.

Ok, now on to the food.  I ordered the banana chocolate chip bread (DE-LICIOUS!), the broccoli and cheddar omlette and the "billionaire bacon."  When asked what made the bacon "billionaire" Charlie informed me that it's actually soaked in molasses.  Honey, that was enough to get me to try it, so that's what I ordered.  Charlie kept the orange juice coming, and a few of my friends ordered coffee and tea (the tea smelled amazing!).   All of my food was delicious, and everyone with me enjoyed theirs also.

The place is very small, and it was busy so it took Charlie a while to bring us the check - even with us signaling to him.   I didn't mind though, because I was rocking along with the music.

This place CLEARLY loves Abe Lincoln, as there are pictures of him everywhere.  There's even a penny wall in the main dining room, and the walls in the restrooms are decorated with pennies as well. I asked Charlie how many pennies there are, and he told me an exact number, which I forget.  I just know he said there are over 84,000, and each penny is facing the exact same direction!

I loved the food and the atmosphere, and I'll definitely go back when I'm in the area!

After a long day at school (I am a graduate student) I thought I'd stop off at Sip, across the street from my apartment, and treat myself to a drink. Now I did enjoy my drink. I'd agree with the owner that it was probably a bit on the big side (not that this says anything about actual alcohol content). But the mood was spoiled as follows:

I get a bill back for $16 and change. After reviewing the bill I see $13 for a drink (sticker shock right there), a dollar and change for tax...and 18% automatic gratuity, adding another $2.50 or so to the bill; I'd had no intention of treating myself for $16, and if I had I could have gone to 1020 and had 3 beers (including tip) for that price. Now if the $13 was the end of it I would have left feeling a bit grumpy for unwittingly ordered a $13 drink, but I wold have gotten over it and probably wouldn't be writing this review. But the sleaze factor of their gratuity system is what inspired this review.

So I called the server over, and told him that while I can accept that I probably ought to have asked how much the drink was and that I'm not complaining about that, I've never heard of having automatic gratuity tacked on just for sitting down and having a drink. He shows me the menu with this policy (which I never saw because I just ordered my drink directly), so seeing that it would be more trouble that it was worth to make a case, I sign my bill. (And to add insult to injury, there is still a gratuity line on the bill.)

At this point I am greeted by someone who asks me what the problem is. I kindly explain to him, too, that it's my fault for not asking for the price but that I really don't appreciate this business of 18% gratuity and I've never heard of this for just sitting down and ordering A drink. He says it's on the menu too, and that's how the computer system works; as I pointed out to him, someone had to make the decision for the computer system to work that way.

So anyways in all of this I ask him if he's the owner; he is. He tells me that the servers tell you when they bring you the check about the 18% thing...which I actually wasn't, but anyways, it's kind of too late at that point now isn't it? I explained that maybe you should make that a little more obvious, post a sign or something, instead of hiding it in small print at the bottom of the menu, where someone just ordering a drink probably won't even see it. He said "suggestion taken" in a tone of voice that suggested to me "please go away now."

To his credit he did eventually agree to void my original check and just have me pay the drink + tax. But again, I kind of feel like it was only because it was pretty obvious I wasn't going away until I got an answer that didn't sound like him trying to excuse ripping me off. It really is rather hard to not feel like this is a rather underhanded business tactic--like I said, prices is one thing and it's your fault for just blindly ordering; and you expect to pay automatic gratuity on say a party of 5 or 6; but come on, this is just sticking their hands in people's pockets.

From the other reviews I'm apparently not the only one who feels like they're trying to be sleazy about it, either; another review says the brunch menu straight up does not mention the auto gratuity, yet they charge it anyways. Tip to the owner: the business I go back (and insist that other people join me in going to) to are the ones that treat me well, not the ones that make me leave feeling ripped off.

I MIGHT come back for say the happy hours with free tapas (then I might feel like all the gratuity and what-not was justified), but not just for a drink. And trust me, I'll be scrutinizing the price of every last thing before I agree to have it brought to me. It's probably more enjoyable too (three or four stars, which I felt up until the bill fiasco) if you know that you're looking at having this 18% tacked on instead of having it surprise you at the end.

So yeah, buyer beware.

I've only visited at night when it's a bar.  They have a DJ playing pretty good music, but I think it's funny to have a DJ for such a tiny place. I bet the max capacity is 30 people. It's fine, seems to have a lot of regulars. So many in fact, that I was standing right in front of the bartender trying to get her attention for 15 minutes while she ignored us/greeted her friends.

The first time I went to Sip was years ago, in its previous incarnation as solely a bar.  Now it serves food and has a totally different attitude, less blue mood lighting and more neighborhood hangout.

Their mac and cheese was recommended to me as was their Monday special of all food half-off.  Finding myself in a position to check it out today, I headed over in the company of a nine-year-old.  We were greeted with free tapas (bruschetta and a potato leek frittata that was rather tasty) and an explanation of the happy hour special ($2 off of beer and wine, $4 mixed drinks).  

Since, you know, I had a smallish child under my care, I declined the booze and hit the food.  We both got the mac and it was really good with a nice bread crumb crust.  Then I had an espresso.  The bill?  Nine bucks.  The menu is actually pretty extensive, considering that the space is itsy-bitsy, and they serve everything on it all day, so breakfast for dinner or dinner for breakfast.  What ever you desire.

The next step is to check out their brunch special:  $25 - three course brunch - all you can drink mimosas or bloody marys ($15 without the booze).

Wouldn't be able to bring a big crowd here as the place is pretty tiny.  But the ambience is really cool and it was a perfect place to grab a drink with my gf on a Friday night.  Waitstaff was really pleasant and they had a DJ in the back.  We're hoping to go back sometime to try the food.

6 months ago, a good friend of mine told me that he'd be DJing at Sip every Friday night from now on.  while i was happy for him, i was secretly a little annoyed - would i be obliged to go to the same bar every friday night now?  would i be the obnoxious one out of my group of friends known for dragging their poor drunk asses all the way up town each weekend?

good news is, it's worked out great - sip is fabulous - it's tiny, intimate, and only gets really packed at the height of the night.  the bar and bathroom walls are covered completely in pennies (this still fascinates me) and there is really cool art displayed throughout.  comfy & cozy booths & chairs allow for nice conversation and late night hookups (of course there have been a few).

drink prices are reasonable and they also serve food - really, really good food - bar stuff like sandwiches and burgers as well as chicken and veggie skewers with a pretty good selection of desserts including cupcakes from crumbs, yummm.

while i would never consider myself a regular (no, it never became a situation where i was obligated to go everrry friday, phew), i truly love the vibe at Sip.  it's comfortable and both the crowd and the music are eclectic and welcoming.

This used to be my spot every Mondays when I was looking for a job and needed free internet.  Everything on Monday is half off.  I would order this amazing sandwich called the Sipwich with egg,cheese and tomato for $4 ($2 on Mondays!).  I think you could

OK, I feel a little guilty about doing this, but I'm going to do it anyway. I'll review Sip, even though I haven't eaten there in almost two years.

The reason I feel compelled to review it? Because it was, hands down, the WORST service I have ever experienced in over twenty years of eating in NYC.

The waitress was very nice and friendly and polite- no problems there. The place was empty, except for about two others. It was lunchtime on a Monday, when they have a half price deal. When I ordered, the waitress apologetically told me that it would be a little slow today, because the kitchen was backed up, or something. (What? There are two of us here.) Then I proceeded to wait an hour for a sandwich. An HOUR? Seriously? Did I mention I was one of two people there?

I decided to give them another chance a few weeks later. Again, a friendly waitperson. Again, an empty place. Again, lunchtime. Again, I was told it might be a "few extra minutes because of computer problems." And again, it was an hour wait for food, this time a salad. (I could have walked to West Side Market and bought the ingredients, made the salad, and eaten it, all within that time.) 

Was the food good? Yeah, but not all that freaking good. I still get mad when I think about this place. Maybe they've shaped up, but I don't know if I want to give them another chance.

Unfortunately the adorable ambiance and creative menu do not justify the obscenely high prices and lazy service with attitude to boot. But somehow it is always crowded with hipper-than-thou Columbians who scorn the more mainstream digs on Broadway. The mac n cheese (which I've ordered twice) is very good but I could probably make a similar version at home and save the $18. Neighborhood regulars cozy up to the spare bar and ignore the lax service standards. Part of the sticker shock comes from the fact that gratuties are included for all parties, a detail the staff will not be quick to point out. 

Looks deceive - skip it unless it's late and you're desperate.

Dear Everyone:

We came here one Sunday afternoon in pursuit of accomplishing work and a delicious beverage.  While we did accomplish some work, our beverages were not everything we hoped for.  I had jasmine pearl green tea and it was sort of like drinking a flower bed--I do not recommend it (unless you enjoy drinking flowers).  My partner had the lemon/lime aid which was, um, a little on the sour side.  She quickly followed it up by ordering a Sprite to mix with it and even that did little to quell the sour level of this beverage.  If you order it, don't bring your litmus paper.

Additionally, the service tends to be a little on the slow side.  I'm completely fine with this most of the time, but only if I've got a few spare 5 hours.  

We highly recommend the broccoli gratin.  It's cheesy.  It's broccoli.  It's completely delicious.

I really like this place, it's such a great change to all the dive bars this far up on the UWS. There really (and sadly) is nothing else like this. Great lounge atmosphere and full food menu. Good wine and beer selection. Beers on tap aren't any you are likely to know, so just let them know the general kind of beer you like and they'll serve that to you! 

I haven't gone here yet for food, just for drinks out at night. It gets really crowded, which is the downsize, the super small size of this place. Don't have your party here, there's no room! I originally went here thinking it was a wine bar, it's not, but you will find wine and seating and you can hear each other to talk even though there's a DJ. 

They have great brunch deals, i'll have to come back for brunch or check it out when it's more coffee shop during the day.

Went here for drinks at midnight. It was okay. For a Friday night, it was pretty dead, and I found the drinks a little over priced. Fun decor. Might go back to try coffee during the daytime as recommended by a girl I met there....

This place isn't half bad. I stopped by with some friends Thursday night for drinks and it was packed. There were some cute girls but they must have been college girls 'cause they were giggling and were totally wasted. One girl kept coming round and was all over me and one of my friends. So wasted and totally not my type. 

I think Sip is better for people who like cocktails and the scene. It's really, really small too so don't go with a big group. I'm thinking of coming back here for brunch 'cause I've heard it's pretty good.

If I lived in New York, I would most definitely visit this place again. I went on a Thursday, so I missed the half-off menu Monday and other deals they have during the week. I got the macaroni and cheese - recommended by the waitress. I added chicken to the top for some protein. It was pretty delicious - and I am really picky about my mac & cheese. While it was not the best I have ever had, it was worth the price. My friend got the apply & brie sandwich that came with a side of beets. She did not like the beets and I was too scared to try them. The menu seemed to have a lot of really tasty options, including breakfast items that you can get at any time of the day. Major points for me!
Overall, the place was cute and it would be a good place to chill and have a few drinks with a friend. It did not seem too trendy and the prices were reasonable. 
One thing that I did not like was the water. Granted, I got it straight from the tap, but it did not taste clean at all. If possible, I would give this place 3.5 stars, but I do not think it is deserving (yet) of rounding up.

Not bad. Even if I came here on a Friday morning and was therefore ineligible for the $25/$15 brunch special on Saturdays and Sundays. If you prefer unlimited bloody mary and mimosa style drinks, then go for the $25. If you're okay with unlimited coffee, tea, and juice, go for the $15. But only on the weekends. If not, you're stuck with the regular menu like we were.

I came here for my first breakfast post-acquisition of freedom (read: finally finished with school for the rest of my life), and I had the $6 menu item of 2 eggs anyway I wanted them, 4 slices of wheat toast, and a big cup of coffee. My girlfriend had the overpriced Cobb Salad, but according to her it was tasty. So here's the pro's:

- the decor is pretty fabulous (including some nice pieces of art on the wall and a random penny holding shelve fixture on the right side of this largely hole in the wall abode)

- the music selection (though it was a bid loud)

- the food was pretty tasty, and the coffee was decent

Now for the con's:

- pretty small portions for what you pay for

- you pay $3 EACH per tiny little 8 oz. bottle of Coke. I know because my girlfriend ordered 2 and I had 1, and it came out to $9

- a lot of the items on the menu looked pretty steep in price without even seeing the portion size. Considering the size of what we got, I'd assume the portion size is pretty small.

- we had a hell of a time getting our check. After we finished eating, the waitress seemed to forget we were there. A feat no doubt considering the fact that we were one of three people there and I was wearing a bright purple shirt with the word "LGBTerrific!" prominently displayed on my chest. I was in a protesting type of mood today. ;-)

P.S. They insta-grat you with 18% and they at least say so on the menu and told us when we were getting our check. I only mind this when it gets sprung on me by surprise. They made several attempts to let us know in advance. Just FYI.

P.P.S. This place is small, so I can see why some bar-goers have had some problems with this place. When I walked by it later today it was pretty busy, so it seems like a place where you gotta hit it during the off hours.

I'm not gonna lie. I judged Sip very rapidly when I first walked in. But this was probably because I had been walking in the rain 15 blocks because a friend gave me the wrong directions. But as I dried off, I started to notice the small details that made Sip good. The laid-back atmosphere, the music, the menu. I don't know if I would make an effort to go just because, well, it's so far from where I usually am but it's good to know of this place. If you're around the area, you could (and should) test this place out.

ehhhhhhh Sip....... you made me want to gulp down my drink and leave.

if it wasn't for my cute date, i probably would have.

No AC, not even a fan so there was very little air movement. Stuffy.

Tables and chairs are like out of a food court. Super uncom

business.full_address:
600 N Main St
Blacksburg, VA 24060
business.name: Campus Exxon Servicenter

reviews.text: I took my car here for an oil change and brake service. I had a rude experience involving being hung up on twice. The owner found out and performed the brake service for free. I appreciate his effort, but his mechanics just don't seem to care.
Good place to get ripped off, especially if you are a college student.  Take your vehicle to Bugshop or Long Shop.

business.full_address:
278 Wickenden St
Fox Point
Providence, RI 02903
business.name: Round Again Records

reviews.text: This is my favorite record store in Providence. The records are cheap, they are in good condition and are well organized. You find stuff here that you have been searching for for years and instead of it being priced up insanely it'll often turn out to be like six bucks. For eg. I got the Rolling Stones, "Exile on Main Street," here for $3.00. The only objection I have at all is that often you don't find that much vinyl from after, say, 1982.

"Record store steve" has been around for years....if you have a record player, his store is the place to go-- Steve also, buys your old records....if you need quick cash, go to round again records--

I have been told you get a "special sound", a unique sound (analog), with 45's and 33's....you cannot get that sound with cd's--

I stopped by based on the 1st review of this little shop. There is a decent selection of vinyl and used cd's, and the vintage speakers, receivers and turntables on sale are a cool plus.  

If you're into vinyl and 45's, stop by. you might not find everything, but there are surely a few good ones floating about.

Low-Fi meets low cost
They even sell new needles!
Vinyl: not a myth

There's a ton of reasons to go to Round again. Let me detail:

1. To prove to your hipster friends how cool you are
2. To see what the hell your parents are talking about
3. Because you absolutely MUST find (insert rare vinyl-only recording) and have been digging for AGES

According to Steve the owner, most of his business is now done through mail order and the internet. That doesn't mean you can't spend a good hour or two 'round the brick and mortar store. The place is perfectly organized, and everything is in moderately good to brand new condition. It's truly a trove of music, with all genre's represented, from Bad Religion to the Clancy Brothers.

If you're an audiophile and actually listen to vinyl, you can also pick up hardware here like needles and players. It's a hell of a lot better than scavenging the dregs at Goodwill and Salvation Army.

Flipping brilliant. If you visit only one place on a day or weekend trip to Providence, you must hit Round Again. Not only is it one of the CLEANEST record stores on the planet, it's also impeccably organized, has Lupo's tickets for sale, and, for vinyl lovers, is a bargain hunter's paradise.

I wish I'd taken more advantage of this place while I lived in the area. A recent stop on a daytime adventure back to my beloved former home yielded six fantastic finds. Among them:

A Johnny Cash album
Fleetwood Mac's Rumors
A Boston album for the gentleman
A Sonny and Cher album for a not to be named Yelper (ok it was Peter W.)
Mommas and the Poppas greatest hits (monday, monday...)

I also found, in the bargain bin no less, tons of Led Zeppelin, Streisand (well, that's to be expected, I mean really), Prince and The Revolution's 1999, one of Prince's first efforts from the 70s (before the hair straightening), loads of Neil Diamond, some Frank, and more Johnny Mathis than I'd ever like to see again in my life.

If you're looking at CDs, check out the soundtracks and international stuff. Most albums are $7.95.

This store is amazing!  Not only is the quality top-notch, the selection and layout of the store make for great browsing.  The owner is knowledgeable and the prices are fair.  I would not hesitate to recommend this store to anyone who is into vinyl.  

Definitely worth the trip!

This is not the place to go if you just want to pick up the latest thing you heard on the radio. The owner (who is very nice and eagerly discussed Annette Funicello with me during my most recent visit to the store) stocks a small, eclectic collection of used CDs (divided into country, blues, soul, and a few groupings that I have yet to decipher) and a larger, equally eclectic, and much more interesting collection of records. Most of the titles are at least fifteen years old. Beautiful but expensive mint-edition albums line the walls, and much more reasonably-priced records fill the bins. Bargains abound if you know what you're looking for. Turntables and a few other pieces of electronic equipment are also available. If I were a true vinyl enthusiast, I would come here all the time and eventually be very, very broke. Worth a visit.

Like any other record store the rating is effected by the selection of stuff I actually collect (will pay for), vs stuff I buy if the prices are right. I don't go in this place much but when I do I usually leave empty handed. In fact I can only remember buying 1 record here back in the early-mid90s for $4. (checking discogs.com I see the only copy for sale there is $38, so I guess I owe these guys a thank you)

Anyway I think this place is a bit overpriced, but I am looking for listener copies (some ringwear on cover? fine. some dirty vinyl but no major scratches? fine too I didn't buy a Nitty Gritty record cleaner because I only buy mint records) of fairly mainstream stuff at a place like this, and I can find it in one of the area's other 5 record stores (we really are spoiled in the Providence area) cheaper. 

If I collected the genres this store specializes in I'd rate it higher, does that make me a bad person?

Round Again Records has been in continual business since 1979...you don't stay in business that long by cheating people or being a devious merchant unless you are the Federal Government. The store is full of history, lots of great photos including original Rock Photography by Providence local, Richard McCaffrey, original Rock Artwork by the Rhode Island's Mad Peck, many other pieces of music ephemera and of course the BEST selection of COLLECTIBLE and desirable music available on vinyl in Providence. If you're looking for the new, hip, of the moment record by that favorite band of yours that no one will know about in three weeks...you won't find it at Round Again. If you are looking for great music that stands the test of time...this is where to go. This is a USED record store...you can't order used records. Additionally, all records are MINT or VERY CLOSE...(This does not include the budget bin records located on the sidewalk during the warmer months...50 cents each or 3/$1). The stereo equipment there is all fully refurbished, cleaned and comes with a guarantee (my entire system was supplied by them). Steve, the proprietor and only employee is a fountain of knowledge about music and is generally quick with a humorous quip. Steve specializes in Classic Pop, ALL JAZZ especially Be-Bop & 50-60s Rock and Roll but has MANY great records from the 70s and 80s as well, covering all musical genres.

Meh, I've got mixed feelings on this shop.

On the one hand, it's a classic record shop with a large volume, particularly in the rock/classic rock category, but also decent offerings in jazz, soul, and blues.  As mentioned, they do have some offerings of mint, unopened, newer indie releases.  Prices are generally reasonable on their used stuff, though I wouldn't go so far as to say cheap (at least not for any good albums in decent shape).  That said, I've certainly broadened my collection with a few good finds here and have appreciated its presence.  Finding a gem or two is a usual occurrence here if you look hard enough.

On the other hand, for me this shop lacks personality.  It reminds me of the music shop in Low Fidelity, except there are no witty debates over what qualifies as "good music", and there's often not even any music being played in the shop.  Recently when I brought some out of town music-head friends in for them to scour a bit, the owner was overheard talking shit about the customers.

All in all, in a world of struggling or dying record shops (one that I preferred on Wickenden closed down about 2 years ago), its certainly a blessing that Round Again is still around.

With it's lack of offerings in alternative genre's however, I often prefer some of the other record shops PVD has to offer:

-SDC Audio and Video on Angell St. has a surprising volume of records and the owner is friendly and flexible.
-Analog Underground and Armageddon on the West End are smaller, but cater to more indie and metal/punk respectively.  
All of these shops will be happy to throw on an album that you are debating about, or to put in an order for a request you haven't been able to find

business.full_address:
2937 Broadway
Morningside Heights
Manhattan, NY 10025
business.name: UniCafé

reviews.text:
I had lunch here 2 days ago and I didn't leave satisfied at all. I ordered the avocado chicken panini but it took soo long. The way to order is confusing for a newbie. Ordering is just like a deli or a restaurant where they have different kinds of cuisine - pizza, salads, wraps, etc. I think you order at the counter that has the menu above. My friend ordered a salad and I promptly ordered a panini at the same place. It literally took 15 to make and my friend was already half way through. We only had a 30 min lunch break. The sandwich itself was meh. The avocado kept slipping off. It wasn't a well made panini. They put in a ton of avocado in though. The grilled chicken was lemony. It came with chips in the plastic container. Not a bog fan of then but whatever. To wrap it up, food - meh, decor - okay, seating - good, staff - nice

Ps. Someone behind me ordered a chicken cutlet hero. To make it, the took a chickencutlet in a plastic blaggy and microwaved it. In. A. Plastic. Bag. No me gusta. I mean, I don't expect them to bread the chicken then and there but the plastic bag was too much. Maybe I'll come back if I'm truly desperate.

I came here on a Thursday night with a friend, and the service left much to be desired. She ordered a slice of pizza, which they were very prompt to fill. I ordered a sandwich, which required them to come out from behind the pizza counter, and then make it. I'm happy the food was freshly made, but by the time they finished and I paid, my friend had finished her pizza! The sandwich (Chicken Mexico) was okay, but based on the sogginess of the wrapper, it seemed like it had way too much oil. I felt slightly bloated/disgusting after eating here, and I don't know why.

I'm gonna get this outta the way right now and just tell you;

I had a really bad experience here the first time. I had just come to the upper west side of Manhattan, New york, for probably the first time in my life. I had finished moving my stuff from a hotel in queens to my friends house, about a block away from here. I was hungry, but happy. 

I needed to find the closest place that would provide coffee and food. 
I saw a noodle shop, but did not get a good "vibe" and passed it.
 This is the 2nd place this way, so I walked in. It's filled with foodstuffs, menu boards, deli cases, hot food and long lines of people.
 I did not even know which line to get into, or where the line ended.
 I messed up, and asked at the wrong line for the wrong thing, and I guess the girl was having a bad day, or was just used to dealing with people who know what's going on.
'Cause she got all impatient. 
I was like "Hey.., I don't...know, it's my first time..' 
an she was like "FINE" and rung me up. 
SO yeah, even tho they have tofu cream cheese and awesome bagels and $1 coffee and a good 2nd level with nice windows...I did not come back. FOR A MONTH.
My hostess even kept buying the creme cheese for me cause i'm trying to be all vegan, and it's really good, but I would not come by. 

You know, I probably came back because I'm lazy. See, there is a Starbucks nearby me, and it kinda sucks it's overpriced, its overcrowded, its got crazies and homeless people, and I got sick of waiting 10 minutes for them to remember to get me my plain cup o' coffee. ANd I don't wanna walk uo 5 blocks to the next one.
 So yesterday, I came back here. And everyone was REAL nice. And they had a bagel can eat, and it took 2 minutes, and they have free wifi. I love it here. I would have check ins here, if I had anything other then a ghetto phone.

I have had the calzone here...sausage I believe, and the roll, which is basically a smaller calzone I guess. Both times I was disappointed. Over cooked bread with a lot of flour or something all over it just giving it an overwhelming flourery burnt taste. After a long wait to heat it up, and I say long because there was no one else there to be taking up their time, the inside was still sort of cold, as was the marinera sauce, which I hate. I hear bad things about the pizza as well so I'be never tried it...doesn't look appetizing either. They do have other assorted goodies like pastries and cookies but I've never ventured as far as to try that either when Morton Williams a block away sells the same thing for less. The cashier was nice though...I will not be returning.

I stopped by the gelato window which I will not do again. The guy was very friendly, but, it was $3.50ish for the teeniest tiny scoop of gelato, which was flavorless and freezer burned. He was nice so I might try it again in a pinch for a cup of coffee or 24 hour place, but, say no to the gelato.

People that have been around this neighborhood for more than a year would remember this place used to be called "Pinnacle".
The only thing that has changed from Pinnacle--its former name--is the interior. Other than that--the staff, the food, stayed exactly the same.
After 2 failed attempts to pass the health code and a forced closure, the revamped restaurant still doesn't look very appealing to me.
About a year ago in December, it had received a score of 97 for the health violation. 0 being perfect, and 1 point is given per violation, and the maximum passing score being 27. After that, the re-inspection gave them a 52, still too many.
There came the forced closure of the restaurant until early January of 2011.
One of the first violations it listed on Department of Heath website was,
"evidence of, or live mice in facility's food and/or non-food areas."
Although they eventually were able to pass the inspection, I'm still disgusted.
I try to tell this to all my friends, but for some reason, many people don't know this fact. 
Personally, I wouldn't eat at a restaurant that has rats in them.
It's fine for breakfast sandwiches and bland calzone/pizza. They do have good tea selection in the case. Good when you're in a rush and hungry, otherwise there are other places to eat.

I've used this place as a place to study for the last six or so months. 

What I like about Uni:
+It's open 24 hours a day
+The cupcakes are pretty good. My favorite is the carrot cake cupcake
+The soup is pretty good
+Free wifi
+$1 house coffee

What I dislike about Uni:
-The pizza is awful. I ordered a plain cheese pizza and it had a bland taste.
-$10 minimum in order to use a credit card
Great turkey club sandwich! Probably the best sandwich I have had in the area when I needed a quick meal. Cheap prices and convenient location.

Honestly, the food here doesn't look too great (I've never actually tried it).

But this review is more on the niceness of the cashier, who let me use the bathroom even though I wasn't a paying customer.

I'll be back to try out the food, but frankly, I a

business.full_address:
515 S Water St
Fox Point
Providence, RI 02903
business.name: Fish Co Bar & Grill

reviews.text:
I have never seen so many broken bottles on the ground by the end of the night.

Anyways, there were a lot of people dancing, drinking, playing pool and some weird punching bag game having a good time. A few people got kicked out by the bouncers, but don't know why. The poles were interesting, but a lot of those women should not have been up on them.

A good place to go if you want to dance and have a lot of people to watch and talk to. Great view of the Biltmore.

The minute i walked in.. I needed a drink lol
5 dollar cover and cheap "fish piss" drinks..wait FISH PISS! still trying to figure out what the heck that is....Back to my much needed drink.  It cost me about 7 bucks and it had ice in it..A shot with ice? really?? i wish that was the worst part...the crowd was just awful....people dont ask you to dance anymore? just come up to you and hump...is that how it is now!  Music was same ol..i swear i have been hearing the same music for the past 10 years in every club i go into..This atmosphere is definitely for the younger crowd who just want to get drunk and grind on Who-ever..or whatever lol this place was just a big NO!

A fixture of my trips home from college was the inevitable night out or two at the Fish Co.  And my most recent trip last month was no exception.  

Its almost like a security blanket for me, how much this place has not changed in the slightest bit in the last five or six years.

But enough waxing reminiscences.  This place is college-age-y.  Note I did not say college-y.  Once you are even slightly past college age, you will feel slightly embarrassed and slightly dirty to be there.  I experienced this feeling at the Fish Co. for the first time at age 24.

However, if you are in that age 21-23 wheelhouse, this place is for you.  You'll have a blast.

This place totally blows. It is always empty, has terrible music (some dj playing top twenty,) there is a stripper pole in it, and they have the audacity to charge cover when the superior, more crowded hot club is right next door. Worst.

if you are a girl and you walk in there are about 5 dudes in there, all disgusting, that just stare at you as you walk across the bar. waiting for you to go over to that stripper pole i guess.

All the bartenders are hired because they are 'attractive' and they are too stupid to even make drinks or collect money. 

They have 'fish piss shots' that are some gimicy mixture of cheap crap, shocker, these suck too. 

The ONLY i repeat ONLY redeeming quality of this bar is there dollar corona/landshark night. In which all you should do is go and drink them as quickly as you can and then go immediately to hot club. i barely recommend doing this, as your experience will undoubtedly be wack. 

this place is pathetic filth, i anticipate it will close shortly.

This club is pretty trashy. The bathrooms are disgusting and you may need a body condom just to breathe the air in there. If happens to be just one of those nights post break up and you are out with your girlfriends you CAN get your dance on here. They have cheap shots and you can get hammered without breaking the bank. The average age is 21.

Had a great time at the Fish Co. last night.  The DJ definitely knew what he was doing- the dancefloor was packed by 11:30, and there were quite a few girls on the stages dancing around the poles and having a great time.  They had 4 bartenders on the main bar, which was where we were, so we rarely waited more than 2 or 3 minutes for a beer,even when the place was completely hoppin'.  Agree with previous posters though, it is definitely a younger crowd.

I've always had a good time at Fish Co.  Once you're out of college though you'll feel a little bit out of place--if you're in college check it out though--great drink specials and nice atmosphere when the weather's nice.

Bar near the water...cool concept, right? Unfortunately, it rarely worked out as 'cool' whenever I tried to come here. I definitely should have given it more of a chance but my time at PC rarely brought me over here. $1 Corona Thursdays is a great concept...except they always run out REALLY fast. That makes the cover that guys only pay completely worthless. 

Be ready to dance if you come, but realize that you don't have to. There is plenty of room outside to just chill by the water and that can be fun...but it is more of a club than a bar once the hour gets late. Beware of the meatheads punching the shit out of that boxing machine...they will quickly get angry at everyone around them if they are out-scored. 

Go with girls because 9/10 ladies here are prissy bitches. 

Man this review sounds negative. Listen, if you go with friends it can be a nice Providence treat. Go there unprepared...well, get their early and get wasted on $10.
This place is a gong show.

This area of Providence is a big attraction in the summer, primarily for the outdoor decks and marina that this street and bar sits on. The place is a big draw for locals and college kids all year round, but in the summer the biggest thing is that it has a very large seating area right on the water near the famous hurricane barrier in downtown. The bar and grill that it is called is much more a bar than a restaurant, although it has bar food, the actual food is terrible and pub like. The bar inside is very good with quick service and then there is even an outside/covered porch area with anothr bar open in the busy times. The wait staff is very good and helpful and friendly. BVe carefull visiting on weekend nights or Thursday nights when this place turns into a college nightmare of scantiy clad girls and drunk students! Worth a visit though!
avoid at all costs...stay home first, or go to church, or crossroads ri, anyplace else!!

This club is always crowded!  They play really good music and they've got an awesome outdoor patio overlooking the water!  Girls can dance on stage which is really fun if your favorite song is playing!  They've always got contests going on here where you can win money.. its just a really fun place!

business.full_address:
P.O Box 390152
Central Square
Cambridge, MA 02139
business.name: Carolina Recycled Glass Jewelry

reviews.text: Beautiful glass jewelry. Great website too!

business.full_address:
458 Russell St
Ste 11
Hadley, MA 01035
business.name: Route 9 Diner

reviews.text: Cheeseburger supreme lives up to its name. Wife liked fish & chips. Jr. Liked his chicken strips & fries.

We ordered hot wings and mozzarella sticks to start - both were average, nothing special.  I ordered a Turkey Club and my husband ordered a Chicken Cordon Bleu sandwich.  Large portions with lots of fries.  He said his was delicious - mine was not.  The bacon was half-cooked and definitely old.  The toast  was scorched - and it appeared that they tried to trick me into eating it anyway by flipping the blackened side plate-side down.  I tried a bite and it tasted like charcoal.  I would have sent it back and ordered something else...but our aloof waitress disappeared after the food was delivered.  I munched on my fries, waiting for her to come back - when she finally did, I was too annoyed to order anything else.  I will say that the guy at the counter by the door was friendly enough, but unfortunately we did not get the same friendly face at our table.  Luckily they just charged me for the fries, not the gross inedible sandwich.

I realize this is "just a diner" but if they won't even re-toast 3 fresh pieces of toast so the customer doesn't have to eat charcoal, I wonder what else they are skimping on.  I will not be going back.

I like the idea of a diner but I try to avoid them at all costs. 

The decor is fitting right up to the actual mini jukeboxes. Too cute! The selection is decent and you'll find people picking some interesting things. 

I come here if everything else is closed and I'm starving. I feel bad because diners usually mean annoying 17 to 20 year olds who can't quite drink yet, or chose not to drink so the cool thing to do is go to a diner. Or you're just starving and will eat anything. :)

On a positive note, their food is surprisingly better that one would expect and there is variety. Their selection for beer is silly. 

But seriously, diners must be our modern translation of the circus. I think this diner might even serve popcorn!

I agree, this place isn't really anything special.  It is good if you're with a lot of people, or it's late at night.  (I've definitely come here at midnight when I was craving some fries and a milkshake.)

Breakfast is decent.  Lunch/dinner is decent.  I think the burger I had was pretty good.  But if you have the option, there are better places to go in Amherst.

I've been eating at the Route 9 Diner since it first opened in 2003.  Originally, my friends and I went there because it was open late (typically 24-hours) and served great food.  Now I stop in for lunch on the weekend or for a quick dinner when I'm in the area.

The diner's menu is pretty diverse, as they offer breakfast, typical diner food, and fancier stuff.  We usually stick with the classic-diner fare though, and are never disappointed.  A few of our favorite appetizers are the Cheese Fries, waffle fries, and Disco Fries (fries with melted American cheese and brown gravy).  Perfect diner stuff.

Salads are good, though some of my friends think the Cesar salad is a little heavy-handed with the dressing.  The sandwiches are hearty and can be served with fries or waffle fries (go for the waffle!).  The breakfast food is also good.  You get pretty big portions and there's a good mix of classic and more inventive breakfast items.

Two other things that my friends like about the Route 9 Diner: they do serve beer/wine, and there's a glass case with rotating desserts.  ;o)  

Waitstaff is typically nice enough -- not too absent, not too in-your-business.  Jukeboxes and 50s-style diner decorations are a nice touch.
Very spacious and clean  inside. Food are ok. Very big menu with tons of choices. Waitress is very friendly.

What can I say.  It's a diner.  But being that I am a BIG fan of diners (see review of Boulevard Diner in Worcester, MA), this one has a nice ambiance.  It seems that almost every patron is a regular by the way that the wait staff greeted them.  The naughty items on the menu are  extensive, but offers selections for the calorie conscious.

I had the opportunity to dine here twice during an overnight stay in Amherst.  My first meal was not so great - a plate consisting of cottage cheese, questionably fresh fruit, and melting jello.  The next morning, having perused the breakfast menu the evening before, I decided to give this place a second chance.  Glad I did.  I had a delicious custom omelet with cheddar cheese and spinach.  It was supposed to come with home fries, but I opted for the sweet potato fries that were being advertised as a substitute for a dollar more.  Well worth the additional dollar.  Great fun, good prices, and what a great place for the local UMASS Amherst students to hang out at any hour.

1) They are open really late.
2) They have jukeboxes!

I have some quality memories of ordering a 3 am cheeseburger here with friends while forcing, erm, sharing my musical taste with other diners. 

Every college town needs at least one open-late diner, and this is the one for UMassers.  And damn, I love their cheeseburgers.

We were visiting Amherst for a Convention at the Mullins Center @ UMass - and had to find a place close enough and open 24 hours - Route 9 turned out to be a good pick.  Let me tell you, I was concerned about going to ANY place that is open 24 hours, you never know what you are gonna get, seriously.

But the Route 9 Diner was clean and bright.  Not only did they display gorgeous, scrumptious desserts in a rotating cabinet as we walked right in - but the booths were roomy and some of them had jukeboxes (sweet)

The first night, I was stahhving...so I wanted MEAT (I had saw many cows on the way and all I could think of were burgers & steaks!)  So I ordered their steak with extra coleslaw - it came with a greek salad and that was more than enough.

Hubbie ordered a salad that had no lettuce - he said it started with an "x" - don't ask me but look for it under the salads, it was AWESOME!  you could add meat to it - he added chicken (you know me - it would have been beef all the way!) but it was a gorgeous salad, lots of different color peppers and chunks of feta and red onions --ooooh yum!  

My friend, Jodi ordered a Chicken Cordon Blu sandwich which came with seasone waffle fries and a pickle - equally yummiefiable
