We also had breakfast there on the way back to Stoneham (I ate dessert first - Chocolate mousse cake (kinda dry but I think it's because it was old)  Then I had the Route 9 Diner Breakfast special - 2 eggs, 2 slices of bacon, 2 sausage links, 2 french toasts or pancakes (no homefries)  I ordered the french toast - large slices of thick bread, moist and crisp in the right places...eggs were ok, the bacon and links were good. 

Skip the homefries, fully loaded and otherwise - it was flavorless (I make it better and think some more onions and garlic would do wonders)  

Hubbie had the Mediterranean Omelette - he liked it.

Liz, was our awesome waitress - we went Monday early afternoon, you should def. ask for her!

I've always had a pretty good experience while dining at the Route 9 Diner. The service is quick, and friendly, and the food is fresh and consistent. From my experiences of eating here, (maybe it's just the type I food I order) this place luckily lacks the greasiness you'd expect from a diner!

By far the best thing about this place is its hours. That's not to say the food is bad, because it is quite the opposite. The food is excellent, albeit typical of a diner. However, the names they give some of burgers is more than enough to start a conversation on a date gone sour. The late night aspect allows munchie-driven college students and after-hours movie goers (and anyone in between) to drive down their hunger without spending too much or searching too hard.

Traditional diner food, reasonable prices.  The biggest draw to the Route 9 diner is that they're open 24 hours on Fridays and Saturdays, and until 2am on most nights.  So if you get a craving for pancakes at midnight, this is the place to go.
Good solid food, and service. Always hot and fresh.

Winner of the quickest kitchen ever, hands down. I don't know how they do it... with a combination of senior citizens and hungover college students, families and kids, all hungry. This place is always packed, and by some miracle, they always manage to stun me with the speed of their service. There are obviously elves working in this magical kitchen.

I am a fan! It's one of the very, very limited things open 24 hours (if not the only thing) in Amherst, and it's a great hit with the 5 College area.

HUGE PORTIONS.

I usually come here after 11PM with my boyfriend to get some late night food. I had the Reuben once, which was okay. I also had the onion crock soup, which was good but a bit too cheesy.

The time after that I ordered their nachos grande supreme with chili. It had wayyyy too much chips, and not enough cheese/chili/etc...on top. But in terms of flavor, it's better than Applebee's/Chili's because they give you large portions.

Their patty melt is also good, but kinda greasy. Fries were nice and crispy, just the way I like them!!

Definitely a place to come check out because they have such a huge menu, it'll take a while for you to become bored of this place.

Their strawberry cheesecake is better than ok but not great, but I wouldn't recommend spending ~$5.00 on it (Stop&Shop is right in the same lot).

P.S. I've had the same waitress twice (not college-aged), and she's my favorite so far because she's chill and doesn't rush my boyfriend and I when we're chilling, and is good on giving us refills without us asking!

While it feels about as authentic and personal as a drive-thru, there isn't much the Diner doesn't do well. The menu is massive, and everything is tasty. You're certainly not going to get anything gourmet, but the greasy spoon and meat-and-potatoes menu is well executed. Of course, breakfast is the specialty, and they do it well. I enjoy the eggs benedict at the Diner and the Huevos Rancheros is delicious. The Route 9 Diner is open 24/7, which is a plus, but the late night menu is smaller and more expensive. It isn't too surprising, given the cost of staying open 24/7, and everything being 5o cents to a dollar more isn't really that big of a deal. The service is often surprisingly quick given how busy it is. Just because the Diner is the stereotypical college eatery doesn't mean that it should be overlooked.

My boyfriend and I go here often for breakfast even if it's generally afternoon by the time we arrive.  I love the loaded homefries. Normally I order those with a bacon, egg, and cheese sandwich. When I had a craving for something sweet I preferred the french toast with bananas, nuts, whipped cream, and syrup. The portions are huge and the price is reasonable. I have never ordered from anything but the breakfast menu but that I can easily recommend.

Isn't it true? You can eat a great meal at dinner, but nothing starts the day off like a great breakfast. Anytime I get crap for breakfast when I eat out, I'm usually in a pissy mood for the better part of the morning. Fortunately, this was not one of those times. I'll say one thing for this place, at least as breakfast is concerned, their food is very consistent. I probably haven't been here for at least 2 months, and I order the Irish Eggs Benedict, and it tastes exactly as it did the last time I consumed it. Even the service was fast and friendly. One thing that's weird though, I have a hard time ordering anything else off the menu. It's like I'm stuck in some sort of Breakfast Twilite Zone.
I'm giving them 5 stars because they have homemade corned beef hash, and use homemade challah for their French toast. You can't get better than that!

We had lunch there yesterday with four others and we all really liked it.  The food was very good, the portions were *huge*, the prices were great when considering the portion sizes and our server was very friendly & attentive (she also had a good sense of humor, for an extra bonus).
Route 9 Diner is decent, but if your out late this is your only option. Service is great and food is decent. There's really nothing there that they specialize.

I think I've been here numerous times only after 2am for late night cravings with a huge group of people only to feed my hunger after a night of drinking to sober up!

I tried many things on this menu but nothing that impresses me at all especially since I'm from New Jersey, the capital of diners but it is 24 hours!

Great gathering place for large groups. Not a quiet place. Great fries fast service although this past Sunday the waitress forgot to come back after getting her money. I've had a variety of dishes from her. Good burgers, Gyro's, Salads, Fish and Chips, ho

Has anyone ever been to the diner sober? Doubtful.

As far as drunken feasts, the diner rates at the top of my list. Wicked cheap prices but with more character than any IHOP, what's not to love? Like Kris said, the place has a huge menu, although the cheeseburgers and waffles are my personal favorites. 

"This place isn't anything special"? Brook are you serious? Possibly I'm viewing the diner through beer goggles (beer dentures?), but as far as late night satisfaction in Amherst goes, the diner is tops.

Lets be honest with each other. You aren't going here if other things are open. Thats not to say that the Rt 9 Diner is bad. It isn't, by any stretch, but it isn't fine dining and would frankly be an afterthought if it wasn't open 24 hours. But hell, if you're hungry at 1 am, don't hesitate to come here. Noting is great, few things are bad. Its a little more pricy than the things are worth, but thats the price you pay for 3am cheese steaks.

I love this place. It's got a menu that goes on and on and on for pages and a dessert case. How can you not love a dessert case?!?! I'm a big fan of the Honey Mustard Chicken wrap with waffle fries. Yum! The mac and cheese was a bit too yellow cheesy and under-flavored. It's sort of a hit or slight miss menu but you can never go wrong with the greek specials or breakfast at any hour of the day. Also, don't forget to check out the dessert case- I'm a big fan of the German Chocolate Cake but it all looks delicious! Definitely a good place for the family that cannot decide on any other restaurant because it has something for everyone!
i have nothing nice to say about this place. if it's so late that you can't get food anywhere else, i recommend you just go to sleep. really.

I wouldn't say this diner is a MUST see in the Happy Valley, but it won't be a mistake either!  The omelettes are huge and tasty and the coffee was just right.  Quality of food is good, service is cheerful, and the place is CLEAN and throws  the notion of "greasy spoon" on its head.  I was super impressed when we asked for directives on Northampton and our waitress pulled up a new sheet on her waitress pad and wrote out specific instructions on where to park, what to see.

I'm a big fan of Route 9 Diner. The food isn't always fantastic, but it's never bad, and the price is good. Their buffalo chicken fingers are juicy, the chicken pot pie is great, and you can't go wrong with the burgers and chicken sandwiches. I'm really into the disco fries and the matzo ball soup! And you gotta love that they are open 24/7. Nothing like a big diner style breakfast at 3 in the morning!

This place is garbage. I had a friend who worked there. She told me not to eat there. Prior to this knowledge, I had eaten there.

Typical but sub par diner fare. Too expensive but massive portions. I have never finished a meal here, not lacking in drunken hunger. Not a real diner because its only 24-7 Thurs-Sat. Crummy service, awful food, but good drunk times with a juke box is your best bet. Try a bar instead.

For a real diner, go to the Whately Diner. Its 24-7 year round and way cheaper. You'll save half the bills, its 15 minutes away, and has the real diner necessities, which includes but is not limited to truckers.

Jukebox?  Check.
Homemade pies and cakes? Check.
Huge quantities of comfort food?  Check.

The Route 9 Diner has all the ingredients to make it the perfect Western Mass pit stop.  My friends and I used to go here at 10 am, 2 am, and everywhere in between.

I had a recent experience at the Rt. 9 that pretty much sums up my feelings about the place:

I ordered an omelet, was asked by the server if I wanted cheese.  I said "Doesn't it come with cheese?".  Turns out, no, cheese is not included, and you have to pay extra.  Seems silly that this is the case, but I say yes and ask for cheddar.  Omelet comes out and it turns out my extra dollar has netted me some neon-orange squares of processed "cheese-food".  

If you are going to serve crap like that (and you shouldn't) you can't charge extra for it.  And, if you are going to charge extra for cheese (on an omelet, of all things) there is no way in hell it should be this cheese.  

That story should make clear pretty much everything wrong about the Route 9 "Diner".

A very disappointing day at the Route 9 Diner.

I opted for the Shepherds Pie special. It came with soup and pudding.

The Matzoh Ball Soup was not good. The broth had no hint of chicken, just kind of yellow mildly salty broth, but the matzoh ball was bizarre. It had no taste, no texture, no presence of any kind, but there it sat in the middle of the bowl. You could take a spoonful, put it in your mouth and swallow... like it wasn't there. It could have been made from very weak unflavored gelatin... I don't know.

The Shepherds Pie was, I thought,  OK. Seasoned ground meat, corn and "homemade mashed potatoes." The GF is certain that the potatoes were instant. I'm certain that I've had better shepherds pie... everywhere.

The tapioca pudding? Strangest most processed, oddest colored tapioca pudding I've ever had. And the tapioca balls? Refer back to the matzoh ball. I think it was made from the same stuff. I could see it, but there was no sign of its presence once in the mouth.

And the kicker? That shepherds pie burned through me quicker than Sherman through Atlanta.

Eh, this is just a place I go to get breakfast when I can't afford to eat elsewhere.  It's easy and fast.  The breakfasts aren't particularly amazing, but it's hearty and the portions are big.  Everything is pretty mediocre, but it is convenient.  I usually get the Route 9 special with pancakes.  
  Besides breakfasts, they also have sandwiches, burgers, and early bird specials.  I am not a big fan of anything besides their breakfast menu.  The sandwiches look like something that a 7 year old can make at home by him/herself.

The 5 of us had breakfast there this morning, & everything was great!  The menu is vast.  Between us we had chocolate chip pancakes, banana pancakes, a Florentine omelet, & Eggs Benedict.  All choices were delicious, large portions.  Friendly staff, very child-friendly, clean, totally pleasant experience.
Great for a late night feast, definitely head over here after a good night out in Amherst.  Can't beat the food and the classic diner feel.  Huge menu and friendly staff.

24/7 Diner. what else needs to be said?

I love their eggs bennedict. I swap out the homefries (just ok in my opinion) for waffle fries.

Buffalo chicken wrap is good too and milkshakes...

business.full_address:
391 Stanford Shoppng Ctr
Palo Alto, CA 94304
business.name: The Cobbler Shop

reviews.text:
Good selection of flip flops for the summer. 

As for actual cobbler work, the prices are a bit higher then I'd like and I know I can get work done cheaper elsewhere, but the workmanship/quality is high.

I have actually never had shoes repaired here.... But, this is my favorite place to buy sandals on the Peninsula! The Cobbler Shop always carries cute Rainbows and other great sandal brands such as Reef. I have a bit of a flip flop fetish though so this place can be very dangerous for me!

business.full_address:
405 Fulton St
Troy, NY 12180
business.name: Shalimar Restaurant

reviews.text: The place is not too great for quality indian food, but its proximity to RPI makes it nearly the only choice within a walkable distance. The lunch buffet is ok, but considering its just like $7 it is a good VFM option.
Really really yummy! Everything was great....Best Indian food!!!

Service was good considering there was one front of the house staffer and about 20 customers.  However, when comparing Shalimar to myriad other cheap Indian buffets I do have to say that it is too spicy and I probably won't return.
Great food, super helpful staff, decent prices! My new favorite indian place :)

Sorry but I have to edit my origional review. Around here, its ok, the food is good, but its not as good as some of the authentic food that I've had. I like it, the people are great, and the food suffices when you have a hankering for it. The truly definitive flavors that you look for in traditional Indidan cuisine are not as pronounced as they could be though. But I still like the place

It's decent. The seating inside is kinda cramped. I liked my buffet experience, and would go back, yet not setting my world on fire. Sometimes the buffet would look like it needed "freshening." Food was tasty, but if asked where to go for Indian, would not be in the first 5 places in the Capital District I'd mention.

My go-to place when I have a craving for Indian food while I'm at school.

I usually call ahead and pick-up my food for a weekend dinner. Each dish comes with a container packed with rice. Usually, I order a naan with my meal as well. They redesigned their menu and there's a new 15% discount for students (pick up only) - score!

Pretty standard fare, although I've had better back home in the city. So far, I've had the Lamb Curry, Chana Masala, and Aloo Gobi. All were pretty good. My only gripe with the Lamb Curry is that it can sometimes be a little bland - it's a hit or miss sometimes. Price, with naan, averages to about $10-$12 a meal. Alright pricing, not great.

Went here with M. last week for a weekday lunch at the buffet. Waitress greeted us and got our drinks. M. got a mango lassi - it was good according to him.

You just go up to get your food. They had plenty of naan that was better than usual. I got myself some naan, cabbage, chick peas, and rice and peas. The chicken dishes looked alright, although the tandoori chicken looked a bit dry.

The meal was delicious and was very filling. Standard fair, nothing spectacular.

The decor is a bit lacking, although the place looks a lot better during the day than it does at night. M. and I sat at a table next to the wall, near the entrance to the buffet. Not much privacy between tables.

Will go back again.
Tasty food, friendly

My dad and I have been loyal patrons to this restaurant for several years. I no longer live in the area and I usually look forward to their lunch-buffets when I am in town (great value for the food). But I was extremely disappointed today when I attempted to call in a take-out order and ask for dishes to be made with low salt  or no-salt (for my dad who is craving chicken biryani while in the hospital). They told me that nothing could be done to accomodate me. As a South Asian who occassionally cooks, I know that I was given a faulty answer. For a small family-run buisness, that unsympathetic answer definitely ruined my appetite.

Was here recently with my cousin and her husband and it was a solid 3 stars and overall experience pretty good.

Inside: It's in an older building, store front type setting which could really lend it's way to a really trendy appearance and cozy atmosphere

What a surprise treat! We were traveling in the area on vacation from San Francisco, where we have lots of really good Indian restaurants, and were really craving something with some taste. We didn't saw a good review for this in upcoming Troy, pulled off the throughway, and just loved everything they had in their buffet. It's a little hole in the wall, which we knew from back home could be the real find. Sure enough, all the items were tasty, just enough spice, and we walked away happy. Thanks to Shalimar.

I really love the naan.  I really love that they deliver.
I appreciate the buffet.
I think the food is decent.
The decor there sucks and going down there to the bathroom is creppy.
The service there is pretty good.  I went toward the end of the buffet and they were out of chicken tikka masala and the woman who was serving us had them make up an extra batch just for me.
I will go back because of the convenience and the fact that the chinese around here sucks.

I live in the area, and I'm a fan of Indian food. Thank god (or Vishnu or whoever) for Shalamar. Go here for lunch on weekdays 11:30 AM-2:30 PM. They do an all-you-can-eat buffet that only costs like $5.55.
Very laid back atmosphere, if the buffets on just grab a plate and sit down. Pay at the register afterwards.
The vegetarian dishes are amazing, if thats your thing.
I'll probably be there, the lonely guy in the corner scarfing a heaping plate full of colorful orangy mush. But so good!

I'm torn about how to review this place.  I'm basing it on only on their lunch buffet since I've never order off the menu.  It use to be very good.  But lately they seem to fear spice and always have nothing but chicken or vegetarian dishes. Ihelios the vegetarian options when they are properly spiced but they skimp on favors here.In the past the food was better spiced and there was a variety of dishes including beef and lamb and sometimes goat  in addition to chicken. Now it's everything chicken and nothing is spicy.    The lunch buffet price is inexpensive.  Something like $7 for all you can eat.  It is good but everything tastes bland.  The buffet includes nan and pakora but they always run out in minutes and take a long time to replenish.  There is a nice rice pudding dessert.  Not to sweet.  Salad with a cucumber yogurt sauce on the side.  A green mint dressing and a red onion dressing.  They both use to be spicy.  These too are no longer spicy. Always tandoori chicken.  Always  their version of chicken tiki masala which I usually love but here it's made with dry chicken breast cubes in a flavorless yet unusually bright orange cream sauce.  It's mostly the bland day glow cream sauce with no chicken pieces to be found  They have plain rice and a meat and rice dish but again usually made with sparse pieces of dry chicken breasts.  They always have about 4 vegetarian dishes from lentils, to spinach,  cauliflower, chick peas but these all are bland, runny and seriously lacking in the Indian spices I have grown to love.  It's been very Americanized as far as flavor.  I wish they would season their food as it should be seasoned, the way they use to season it.  They are Definately skimping on spice and quality which is why I wont be going back

Cheap and good. Shalimar's strong point is the lunch buffet, which is cheap and plentiful. The price for the buffet is about 7-8, and unlike some other eateries, Shalimar restocks their containers on a regular basis. The actual food is adequate, the selection is limited and not overly tasty. The quality of the buffet is a step down from regular service.

Outside of the buffet, the quality and price go up. I have yet to have buy a bad meal, but likewise I always feel a bit gipped.

bad food, worse service. the place seems to be staffed by a bunch of high school students that roll their eyes at you when you walk in the door. there are much better options in the area. don't go here.

Three of us enjoyed the buffet today, Saturday, for lunch. Contrary to other posts here, the buffet was fully stocked and we never wanted for anything. For example, the naan was replenished every few minutes - nice because it was warm when we took it. 

The atmosphere is what it is: a storefront in downtown Troy - neat and very un-chain like. 

The food had good flavor and the six or seven hot items provided something for all of us to savor. I like the idea of a buffet because I get to try items I would not otherwise order. 

Tandoori chicken was not to my liking - actually it didn't have that clay oven taste, more like it was colored orange??? 

But the chickpea dish was awesome - too spicy for my wife and son but they both had their favorites and went back for seconds. 

Our first visit was good, we will be back.

Eh.

It's a buffet.  There were some things that were pretty good.  Some things that were adequate.  Some things that were lousy/scary.  

Pretty Good:  Cabbage Dish - Chaat
Adequate: Chicken Tikka - Peas
Lousy/Scary: Rice Pudding - Tandoori Chicken

It would have been nice if the naan were replenished more frequently.  If you are in the mood for Indian buffet, it scratches the itch.  Glad I went, because I was in the mood for overeating comforting Indian goo.

But really otherwise, I'd rather go to Oliver's a few doors down.
Lunch buffet (weekday) price is reasonable.  Buffet is usually pretty good but sometimes inconsistent in terms of flavorful.  Buffet selection is little plain compared to other Indian restaurants.

I got takeout here about a week ago, first night in town, and what a mistake. I ordered Chicken Tikka Masala and some Onion Pakora.

The Chicken Tikka Masala was simply terrible. I've had better microwave-frozen-entree versions of this dish. The sauce had next to no apparent spices in it. It simply tasted sweet and fatty. Furthermore it was a nearly radioactive orange color, which leads me to believe there's something in it that adds plenty of color, and no flavor whatsoever. The actual chicken in the dish was dry and had next to no flavor of its own.

The Pakora were alright, but you can't really screw those up.

Will CERTAINLY not try again.

Delicious Indian food. I've only been to the lunch buffets, which aren't generally spicy (probably due to the fact its for many people), but the food is always great. The naan is awesome. Friendly people, too.

Lunch Buffet is the best deal. For $8 you can you can eat all you want and sample new things. They usually have the most popular things from the menu and its always hot and replenished quite often. Everyone that works here are friendly and its one of the best Indian restaurants in the area.

Shalimar's food i is tasty, but this location is not the best.  If going in the middle of the day, you have a hard time with parking. The service was very speeding but the young at the counter didn't seem to know much about the dishes i inquired about.  I would probably go there again since I don't live that far but Id Recommend Aashinini(spelled wrong) in downtown albany if there was an option between the two.

When I craved Indian food in college, Shalimar was my first choice (in Troy, that is because it's the only one, haha). Food here was delicious. It didn't go as spicy as I wanted but it does the job. They even have a lunch buffet here for cheap and I thought it was well worth the 7 bucks. If you're near RPI, this IS the only Indian restaurant in town. The best part about this restaurant is that they deliver. I miss that!

I was a bit skeptical, since the Albany location has gone a little downhill in food quality, and majorly downhill in service.
But, I think with my stomach, and the 'Lunch Buffet - $6.99' sign pulled it in after walking around the Farmers Market. What can I say? My stomach likes to follow up food with more food.

It was a good thing, too!
There was one guy running everything in the front of the house. He was efficient and really good about keeping the kitchen informed. The food items were replaced many times while I was there, which meant I ate a ton of pakoras. 

The food here tasted like they'd made everything that morning - very fresh and light. Much better than other Indian lunch buffets (COUGHtandoorpalaceCOUGH), which often have dry and old tasting food on their buffets.

Avoid.  Go to ANY other Indian restaurant in the area, except Gandhi.
It depends on your point of view. Would you rather have a terrifying bathroom experience from food poisoning (Gandhi) or because it's like a haunted Halloween experience (Shalimar)* ?

I've been here a couple of times, both for the buffet and for dinner. The buffet is the better deal, but prices have jumped. It's just what I refer to as 'McIndian' - the food will fill you up, but it's below average.

The last time for dinner was just awful, though. Service was amazingly sloppy and rude and the food was pretty bad. The place is dingy and dirty and I just don't enjoy eating here.

Hop across the street to First Choice Jamaican Restaurant instead if you're on Fulton - now THAT is a good, soulful and delicious place to eat.

* (Seriously, the bathroom is in the scary, dimly lit basement. Watch out you don't get eaten by a grue or something...)

I like to eat my words, particularly when it involves delicious Indian food.  I had not been to Shalimar in probably 8 years and that was because the last time I was there it was gross.  Really gross.  But my gentlman friend suggested it and I was in the mood for Indian food so...

This time, it was delicious (except for the naan which was entirely unremarkable).  I had my standard chicken vindaloo, which was made with mostly dark meat chicken.  It was great and my only complaint about it was that the usual potatoes were absent.  My gentleman friend had Punjabi Lamb (I think), which was also really good.  I should knock them down to a 3 stars because the vegetable samosas were not made in-house (frozen food section of the local halal grocer I suspect), but the dinners totally made up for it.  I would also like so see them offer papadums and chutney upon being seated for no extra charge (that always wins brownie points in my book).

The decor is a little busted and the bathroom in the basement is downright scary, but all-in-all I was happy with my dinner and experience.  Is it the best Indian food in the Capital Region?  Not by a long shot.  But it is decent and really close to my home.

I have not yet eaten at the restaurant but I give their catering service a 5 star. I had placed an order for catering for my sister's 30th birthday since she really likes this place. When I initially called, the woman I spoke with said the manager would call me back and discuss what I needed and how much I was willing to spend. She let me know that often they will make you a deal from there to make it something affordable for you. 
The manager called me back promptly when the woman told me he would call, which is much more than I can say about other places I called for catering who said I would receive a call back. When he called, he asked how many people I was looking to feed. I only anticipated about half of my party guests eating Indian food so I told him around 15 people, and we went from there. He gave me about $80 off what the initial price would have been, and upon arriving for the food, there was significantly more food than I had even ordered! The food was delicious, hot, and more than enough to feed all the people I had over. They were very professional, and accommodating. I would use them again for catering in a second!

I have to say that I am appalled by the owners cavalier attitude towards his buffet and his loyal customers. If I'd have known he was such a jerk, I'd have stopped going here a long time ago. 

 The buffet is $6.99, You expect there to be FOOD in the buffet trays when you walk in and sit down. 

There have been times in the past where I've had to ask for a certain dish to be refilled because it's completely empty. A customer shouldn't have to ask for a buffet item to be refilled. It's a buffet for gods sake! There's supposed to be food in the trays... not just a little rice and some cold nan bread. 

Today we went in for the buffet at 1 PM (it ends at 2:30pm). The tables were roughly 1/4 full. It wasn't busy. 

We go up to the buffet and notice there's no entrees! Well, OK there was one... there was tandori chicken that had obviously been sitting there for hours... all dried out. 

I asked the waitress to refill the tikki marsala and she passed that on to the owner. My friend swears he heard the owner say though the curtain that divides the kitchen and the dining area... "let them wait".

The owner came out 5 minutes later and stirred the empty buffet trays again (why does he keep stirring empty trays?). I asked him about the tikki marsala and he said it would be "a long while". I said.. "a long while?!"

After about 15 minutes of absolutely no food coming out of the kitchen we walk to the register to cash out. My friend doesn't want to to ask for a discount but I do. If he wants to pay full price for dry rice and old, dry tandori chicken, that's his choice. 

I ask for a discount and the waitress calls in the manager/owner. He's the old, Indian guy with the glasses, a perpetually filthy apron and the Tom Selleck mustache. He comes over and I politely ask for a discount because there's no entrees available and hasn't been since we came in 20 minutes ago. He gets all belligerent with me and starts yelling. He's creating a scene in his restaurant. I guess he assumes that I'll back down and just pay if he yells really loud and causes a scene. 

He says that it's our fault because we didn't check to see if there was any food in the trays BEFORE sitting down and ordering drinks! I swear to god he said that. We're supposed to make sure a buffet has food before we sit down and order drinks?! Are you kidding me?! It's a buffet! It's supposed to have food all the time!!! LOL!!!!

When he refuses even a small discount, I refuse to pay at all. He threatens to call the police and I tell him to go ahead. I'm sure the cops will come and see that there's no food and side with me. 

He won't call the cops but continues to yell louder and louder... until finally the restaurant is dead quiet and everyone is focused on our conversation. 

I offer to show him that there's no food but he won't budge. He says no discount and I can't leave without paying full price OR he'll call the cops. But, he won't really call the cops because he knows I'm right.. 

Eventually, my extremely non-confrontational S/O insists on paying for both our "lunches" on his credit card and we leave. I tell the rude belligerent unappreciative owner that we're never coming back again and he just lost 2 good customers. As we're walking toward the door, he yells that if I'm going to cry about $6.99 he doesn't want our business anyway.

I didn't even mention the hideous bathroom they have at the Shalimar. Using the bathroom is a scary experience. You have to walk down to the basement through a storage area and look for the bathroom. If you're lucky enough to find it without help, you'll be astounded at how filthy it is. Yuck. If you do go to the shalimar in troy, avoid the bathroom at all costs.

I would not recommend patronizing the shalimar because the owner is such a belligerent, rude and unappreciative person, the bathroom is scary and the food is non-existent.
A steal of the century is here. Weekday all you can eat buffet with delicious food. $7

The lunch buffet is really good! $6.99 on weekdays for delicious Indian food, and staff there was friendly too. And if you love tea, definitely try the Chai tea there, it tastes so much better than the ones I had from tea bags.
great for a quick lunch (buffet from 1130-230) and good take out too. not too expensive, and thats great for standard indian food.

I haven't made it to the buffet yet. I've had two sit-down meals here, both in the late afternoon when, each time, there was only one other couple in the restaurant.

Shalimar is completely uninspired. The decor is bland, at best. The service squeaks into the "passable" range, but not by a lot. Both times we've gone there, we've heard the guys back in the kitchen shouting loudly to each other. Last time, the "host" was on the phone loudly discussing his plans to get KFC for dinner. This time, the "hostess" was wearing an oversized t-shirt, sweatpants, and flip-flops. She also deemed it appropriate to vacuum a few feet away from us while we ate our appetizers, and to stand and hover at the table while I signed the credit card receipt.

The food is adequate. I wouldn't call it GOOD Indian food, but it's certainly edible, and I've definitely had worse. It hasn't made me queasy, which is always a good thing. The prices and portions are reasonable.

I would definitely suggest coming for the buffet if you're thinking about eating here. Like I said, I haven't done that yet, but I'm assuming the food is of equal quality, and therefore the significantly lower price will make the whole experience a more palatable value.

business.full_address:
Harvard/Holyoke Gate
Dudley Staton via Mass. Ave
Central Square
Cambridge, MA 02139
business.name: MBTA Bus Route 1

reviews.text:
Every single negative review of this bus is true. It's dirty, crowded, stops too often, and is generally packed with people I do not like (I'm looking at you, dude with his backpack on a seat during rush hour, and you, lady fighting with the bus driver about how close to the line you can stand). Also, it would be great if they could run the buses close enough to schedule to avoid two of them coming literally right behind each other.

HOWEVER. The #1 bus is the cheapest, most convenient way for my car-free self to get from home in the Back Bay to Central and Harvard Squares and the South End. Moreover, it's an easy walk from the #1's stops to Kendall Square. When I have to get to that area and time is of the essence, there's no better solution than the #1. 

If you have a smart phone, I highly, highly recommend you download the CatchTheBus app to track the #1. It's pretty accurate and will help you minimize your time hanging at bus stops.

Three stars because I live close to Dudley Station and travel to foreign lands on the other side of the Charles often and this is by far the most direct way there and is convenient for me. I win. But I also lose, because this bus route blows goat ass. It is a mine field of stops, red lights, crazies, little old folks counting pennies etc. I'm pretty desensitized to the T at this point but this line still manages to irk me a bit.

Running down Mass Ave from Dudley Square to Harvard, the #1 bus is seemingly one of the T's most important routes.  It services the red, orange, green, and silver lines.  It services multiple colleges and important city hubs.

And yet, it sorta sucks.

This opinion stems from many hundreds of rides.  I understand that sometimes during rush hour there's just nothing that the T can really do: it's going to take 45 minutes to get from MIT to Hynes, and really, you should just walk, because you're going to go insane otherwise.

But oftentimes, there are totally inexplicable gaps in service.  I've never seen another bus line that "bunches" buses quite as badly as the #1 does: you'll wait 23 minutes for a bus that was supposed to show up in 8 minutes, only to see 2-3 (sometimes even 4: I kid you not, I have seen 4) buses show up at the same time.  I have no background in transportation management and cannot fathom an explanation for this.  It is mind-boggling and unbelievably frustrating.

There's also a lot of inconsistency in drivers.  Mrs. Operator #64457, must you really sit there, door open, waiting for that last straggler to shove his crinkled dollar bill into the slot while you squander away another green light?  Can't you, you know, drive the thing while he pays?  Please?  Just... can you just drive?

Oh, look.  There's a red light.  And you've decided to drive now.  Lovely.

For a bus that mostly just goes in a long straight line, service is just not reliable enough.  Lifeline though it may often be, the #1 bus will make you hate the MBTA.

Let me just state that I HATE taking the bus.  Never was a fan and still not.  However when I was living in Cambridge I had to sometimes suck it up and take the bus.  It wasn't as bad as people make out to be.  It did smell, and was slow.  However it got me where I needed to be.  Though I still avoid taking the bus as much as I can.

This is/was my primary mode of transportation when I first moved to Cambridge. It conveniently got me between  work school and home while I had all 3. Now I have a different job, and I'm not in school anymore so I'm not as fortunate to take the bus as often as I used to. However, compared to the trains, I'm looking at you RED LINE, this bus isn't so bad. 

The service has gotten a bit better in the past year which is a great improvement, especially for weekend service when I used to be able to walk from Boylston street to Central Square in an hour and still make it before any bus ever got to the stop. That happened oh so frequently last year. Don't get my wrong though, the trip along Mass Ave. is beautiful at the right time of the year. During the blistering cold of the winter months, not so much.

But this weekend #1 was old reliable. I checked my phone for the schedule and each bus came right on time. Even better the buses were only about 11 minutes apart when I missed one and had to wait for the next. Now if they could only transfer that improved efficiency to their trains the MBTA might actually deserve that fair hike we're all paying more for the same crap service. Good for you Route #1, may you be a shining example of improvement to the rest of your oh so shitty fleet.

Erratic and questionable - sums up the 1 line pretty well.  It's vital to check NextBus and be ready to adjust accordingly b/c the bus often comes way ahead of schedule.  As for the ride itself, it can be a complete sh*t show during peak hours with tons of people coming on/off at nearly every stop and oftentimes being (for the lack of a better word) dicks about moving in and making room for others.  As for the questionable part, shady characters get on here pretty regularly so just be aware.

Jeffrey doesn't do buses alone. He can't. He won't. 

But unfortch Jenna C. (my bus "buddy") was busy and I had to suck it up and ride the steel cage of trash all by my lonesome to MIT. 

I really didn't mind this bus and I don't see why the #1 gets so many bad reviews. Maybe I caught it on a good day? 

Right away I found a couple of open seats where I was able to plop my butt down along with the 3 giant bags of Yelp schwag I was carrying with me to ROFLcon. The ride was fine and there weren't any crazies around which is a plus.

The ride back was a little heartwarming as there was an old woman next to me with a walker. I'm going to call her Faye. When it was time for Faye to depart at the Hynes stop, she darted up in the air with a big "EXCUSE ME!" and shuffled her way to the door. A nice stranger hopped off the bus in front of her, grabbed her walker to set it on the sidewalk, and took her hand to help her off the bus. When he got back on, a random woman commented, "You're a very nice man for helping that woman. I don't know how she does it, but relying on the kindness of strangers like you must make it possible for her to get around."

I smiled and thought the same thing.

My only criticism (which applies to all bus routes) is that there are too many stops. Are people really not capable of walking a couple of blocks to a stop? If it stopped less often, we'd get to places faster. Obvy.

I won't be afraid to ride buses anymore. If Faye can do it, I can do it.
Walk.

A fine system for testing the efficacy of a bus: If you can walk the distance of your commute without even seeing a bus traveling along that route, that bus line is not efficient.

That said, I have made the walk down Mass Ave a few times without seeing a bus. A couple times, I've managed to get really lucky and have the bus magically appear right when I got to my stop. 

However there is one remaining problem with the #1 Bus. It seems to make EVERY DESIGNATED STOP AT EVERY INTERSECTION, and pretty much is about as fast as walking....

This should be one of the most convenient routes on the MBTA but it turns into one of the biggest headaches. The busses never travel on schedule, and the MBTA's worst and rudest tend to drive these busses. On the plus side, thanks to one of these sunshiney ladies, I did discover that chivalry is not dead--one of them flew by me this summer and a handsome construction worker actually chased her down, knocked on the back, and got her to stop for me. Of course she proceeded to curse me out because I was too short for her to see (WTF???) but still, a nice story to tell. Now if only I'd gotten that chivalrous gentelman's name...

The person responsible for scheduling the #1 bus appears to have mental capacities equivalent to an infected pustule resected from Sarah Palin's anus. 

There is no other explanation for the fact that one can walk along Mass Ave, during peak hours, from Harrison Ave in the South End clear across the Charles River (over 1.5 miles) without being passed by one single measly bus. But you'll probably see over a dozen buses passing in the opposite direction. In fact, it's not uncommon to see caravans of 3-4 buses at a time. They must be going to some bus drivers rally.

I don't understand the diatribes against this bus line.  Yes, it was late when I took it from Columbus and Mass all the way back to Harvard after an evening with old friends in the South End.  But it went fast, the bus driver was courteous, and the trip was totally uneventful.

As to the clientele, it was a mix.  College kids, graduate students, adults, and a few bums.  Hey, it's a bus.  If you want a private limo, hire one.  I can't complain at all about this trip.  And yes, I sanitize my hands every time I leap off a bus.  Whether the 1, the 3, or the sterile DC Metro, riding in public transportation is taking a trip inside a Petri Dish.  Still more responsible than driving, though.

Everyday after work I make the choice to either wait for the #1 or try and race it home to Central Square on foot.

You know what's sad? I usually win - walking.

You're like the best bus route ever, #1. But you totally suck and a wet rock could do a better job at dispatching. It's not freaking hard, wait every 10-15 minutes to send out another bus. Sheesh. 

If you have the patience to take the bus expect to become very intimate with your fellow passengers and enjoy the on-bus entertainment provided by the crazy homeless people.

Often late, often crowded, frequently full of drama and sketchiness... still, it's a necessary evil to get from Cambridge to the South End, and parts in between, without having to ride in town then out again.

It may be kind of a moot point to review a bus line, but I think it's funny.  People say- then walk, or get a limo, or pay to drive, etc.  Sometimes, you don't have an option.

Then again, I have found myself searching for other options after taking this bus fairly regularly.  I thought the T was bad until I took the bus. I thought the 66 was bad, until I took the 1.  From Harvard square, I have started taking the Red, to the Orange, and walking.  There are far fewer crackheads this way.

It's a very slow bus route with a lot of stops.  Because it's travelling down Mass. Ave, it is constantly subject to traffic.  The worst thing about the bus is that you still sit in traffic.  

The only plus side is that there are entertaining people on the 1 route.  Scary, entertaining people.

In the beginning there was heaven and Earth, and people had to walk everywhere, or ride donkeys.  Then God said "let there be railways"; he created the red line, the blue line, the orange line, and the green line, and to a lesser degree the silver line (think that cousin that no one talks about) and it was good.  The next day God took one of the red line cars and created the bus system, and it was good.  The bus system quickly became Gods favorite among public transportation since it could not only go backwards and forwards, but could also change lanes.  All of the T lines were obedient and they too loved the bus system...except for the blue line.  The blue line was a proud line and believed himself better than the bus system.  He accused the bus system of being slow and useless and convinced the orange line to revolt against God.  God, and all of the really cool lines, ganged up and laid the smack down on the Blue and Orange lines and cast them out of the Heaven (Park Street).  Similarly God punished the blue line by making it the shittiest of all the lines, followed closely by the orange.  Eventually, it was prophesied that the blue line would give rise to a bus, a bus that was late and full of dirty drunk winos who ramble on and on about stupid crap really loud.  It is called the #1.

Ok,  first off I HATE buses!  I think they are useless, overcrowded, toasters-on-wheels that only exist to serve those too lazy to walk or too cheap to drive (or too cheap to pay that extra 55 cents to take the subway for that matter).  I have had a car since I was old enough to drive (seeing that I live in the suburbs it was necessary) but yet I do think it can be economical and (sometimes) faster to take public transportation when going downtown.  I have loathed the bus system for a long time but I went against everything I believe in and took the #1 to Harvard from Hynes a few weeks ago to please a friend who didn't feel like going out of the way to transfer at Park St (understandable since we all know the subway system here never works properly either).  Not only did the bus that was supposed to come every 10-12 minutes make us wait for 20 minutes but once we got on it was unbearably packed, and of course had to stop at EVERY corner along Mass. Ave.!!!  Most of the time people are, unfortunately, standing intimately close to one another so when a seat up front FINALLY became available (3 stops before the end of the route) I took it, only to be belittled by a guy who was likely homeless and definately ignorant, sitting behind me.  The next part will (hopefully) appall you and take you by surprise!  The convo went something like this:

Ignorant Homeless Guy: "Why are you sitting there?  It is for disabled and elderly people?"

Me: "I beg your pardon?  There are no disabled or elderly people here so I'm allowed to sit"

I.H.G.: "That guy over there (pointing to a 50 year old guy who was standing 5 people away from me accross the aisle, happily chatting to a friend) looks over 65. You should offer him your seat."

Me: "That guy does not look 65 to me. And he is in the middle of talking with someone.  If he wants my seat, he can come ask me to sit and I will gladly get up for him.  Besides, I don't feel it is really any of your concern"

I.H.G.: "Do you think you are disabled because you are heavy?  It's amazing what heavy people try to get away with...acting as if their weight makes them disabled!  It's digusting."

Me: "Excuse me?  I'm not THAT big.  Sure I could stand to lose a few but I'm not morbidly obese!!  Who are YOU anyways, to talk to me that way?  That is not very polite to insult people you don't even know."

I.H.G. : Gets of bus at next stop, staring at me with an evil smirk.

So THIS is why I don't take the bus.  I am fortunate enough to have a car but when I try to save a little money AND do something good for the environment I get verbally assaulted by homeless people with no social ettiquite who don't know how to mind their own business.  Next time I'll just drive my nice airconditioned car to my destination...or better yet, just walk and maybe I won't be considered 'heavy' for much longer
The most terrified I've ever been that a crazy person was actually going to cause real bodily harm was on the #1 bus.

I'm a little biased since I am near Harvard Square and for me the bus comes with regularity (not to mention cost efficient) to bring me to my mecca, Newbury Street (with good food! great shops!!). And, ahem, for my manly Red Sox games as you can get off near the Convention Center and walk there. 

 I really don't mind the #1 bus at all! Then again, I am a shopper (and game attendee) and not a commuter so that may be why I am not too stressed out about delays. It is affordable and it's public transportation, so maybe my bar is relatively low too.

Hell on wheels and I'm not talking about the roller derby/sons of anarchy/railroad boys/tour de France fun kind of hell on wheels. No, I imagine that the deepest and darkest level of hell might be akin to riding the number 1 bus all the time. It's always crowded, loud, and obnoxious. Baby carriages fly everywhere and you need to listen to that annoying dude proclaim "Route 1-Dudley Station" over and over again. 

The worst part? The bus stops every single block. Every. single. block. Boston is a city facing a very serious obesity epidemic and I do not understand why the good folk of Boston can't walk just one more block. Ridiculous. Stop and go. Stop and go. There goes my lunch. 

My bus ride is always full of loud drunks hollering about complete nonsense-it sort of reminds me the after party to a yelp elite event only it's 8:10am. Speaking of yelp elite events, I take it back. The deepest and darkest level of hell is not riding the 1. It's riding the 1 with a hangover. I do give props to the drivers of the good ol' proletariat chariot-they may be in purgatory but they are handling it with a smile. 

I dare you to search my reviews and find one review with toilet humor. I am way too high brow for that sort of thing, but I assure you the number 1 bus is appropriately named-it is downright pissy. (and smells like it too)

In addition to my 'open letter' review, I want to say this about the #1:

Whyyy does it have SO MANY STOPS? Central Square, Sydney St, Landsdowne St, Albany Street... REALLY? (and it does this from Harvard to DUDLEY?)

FYI- traffic on Mass Ave SUCKS BALLS at evening rush hour, so if you really just want to get to Hynes (from Central or EVEN Harvard....probably even the opposite way from the Mass Ave station area on the orange line)-- WALK. 

As for unreliability, i've learned Nextbus.com (unless you can download the mbta app on your phone- I can't!) IS YOUR BEST BEST BEST BEST BEST BEST BEST FRIEND EVER.

If this was "The One", we would be stuck in the Matrix. Or are we already and MBTA is actually an Agent? SHOCK! 

It runs around Mass Ave from Harvard Sq to South End and back and in theory should be faster than taking the T. However, even during rush hour when they run two buses side-by-side, it might not despite its route avoiding downtown because of traffic. 

I guess don't ride it that often to see the sketchy people and it's a nice route during the night when taking it down to Hynes to the T to Brookline.

Apparently stopping at bus stops is optional . . . I decided to walk to MIT this morning and catch the bus from there, and it just didn't stop. It wasn't crowded either, but I think the driver had been stuck in traffic, and was afraid of being too off schedule. Of course they only care about the schedule when it's convenient for them.

Taking the #1 bus is like a crap shoot. Sometimes you're really lucky and you get one AND it's not hella crowded. Unfortunately this doesn't happen 99% of the time. Warning to people who take this bus: if you stomp on my foot with your big clogs on, and don't acknowledge it, I will push you on my way off the bus.

There will be a bus.  Don't be surprised if you wait 30 minutes for it and don't be surprised if 4 busses arrive within 2 minutes of each other.  There's a pretty good chance a bus will stop for you, but occasionally it won't.  If it does, you might be deafened by the brakes as it pulls up to the curb.  There are a couple of shithead commuters and raving lunatics that travel this route regularly and sometimes the raving lunatic is the driver.  You might exit the bus with some muscle soreness or full blown whiplash, but most of the time you'll arrive at your destination without mental or physical scars.  Most of the time.

The #1 Bus has a purpose:  if you are at Berklee and you need to get up to Harvard, it's probably more convenient than taking the Green to the Red.  Beyond that... 

One of the major problems of the #1 bus is that it's on a high traffic road.  Massachusetts Avenue doesn't lend itself well to traffic.  It's small and it's a major roadway.  The Mass Ave bridge, while nice to walk across, is terrible when it comes to traffic.  Hence, major delays on the #1, overcrowded buses of people trying to get from Hynes to Harvard or Central (or vice versa), and just utter chaos.  Buses immediately follow other buses, and it becomes harder and harder to get on.

Then, there's the colorful people.  My personal favorite was a gentleman who continued to inform me of his interest in John Grisham simply because I was reading a book.  And he's just one of the many colorful characters you may encounter.

So if you're looking for an interesting experience, the #1 is fascinating.    If you're looking to get somewhere, well, um, yeah.

The watched bus never comes. 

Now that I no longer live or work in the South End.. the bus usually comes the moment I step next to the little sign that says '1'. The longest I've had to wait in the past several months has been about 5 minutes. It's kind of ridiculous. Such is life.* 

The passengers however, can be somewhat annoying. People tend to be pushier than on other buses. The moment they scan their Charlie cards to get on, 'excuse me' and 'please' get erased from their vocabs. Or maybe they weren't there in the first place? Dare I say.. the B line of the bus circle? Oh.. and of course there's the "Dr." that likes to ride the '1' bus and proclaim his love for the Black Panthers. We can't forget him! "The man is watching youuuuuuu."

*And now that I've told y'all that.. you know I'm screwed. lol

Sometimes there are sketchy people, or a crazy talking to you.
Sometimes it smells like fish or other strange unpleasant odours.
Sometimes a bum will ask you for money for their starving children the whole way somewhere even when you insist you don't have cash.
Sometimes you notice that everyone else on the bus likes to keep to themselves because they don't want to get involved with any weirdness.
Sometimes it takes absolutely forever to arrive.
Sometimes there are hordes of people cramming in to get on so you don't know how to fight your way in, to totter sideways grasping for an unreachable pole or something. 
Sometimes although the ride may be actually alright (depending on the circumstance), I still relish the sweet smell of freedom when the doors open and I tumble out.

Still, I take it when I need to because it's just so convenient to pop down Mass Ave from the Back Bay to Cambridge and vice versa.

I'd love to write more, but Tom's review pretty much said it all. How could I ever come close to a Metallica-themed review?

I won't spend any time ranting about the 1 bus.

Can somebody PLEASE tell me WHY ON EARTH the bus stops on the railroad tracks and opens its doors at Albany Street?? I've been meaning to ask one of the drivers...

There's a lot of responsibility that comes with being named #1, but one bus has got to start it off.

This is the simplest route for me to many places from Cambridge to the Back Bay.
It comes pretty frequently.

Depending on time of day/road traffic/people traffic your experience can vary significantly on this bus. There are a lot of stops, which is a plus if you're trying to pick it up somewhere but a minus when you're already on and stopping frequently.

During rush hour in the morning, the Pearl St stop is your biggest obstacle since a billion people get on there and as such there is significant lag.

Overall, it's pretty OK.

This is a very central and important bus line, I just cant figure out why oh why MBTA cant it come on time, or at least every 10 min or so? Why MBTA, why??? Why do they come in threes and then you got to wait for at least 20 min.  

Sometimes there are seats, sometimes none.  Air conditioning usually works, and so does the street announcing thing.  Some bus drivers are a bit rude, but not too rude. 

Service needs to be a consistent and on time.

Welcome to where time stands still
No-one leaves and no-one will
Moon is full, never seems to change
Just labelled metally deranged

Dream the same thing every night
I see my freedom in my sight
No locked doors, no windows barred
No things to make my brain seem scarred

Sleep my friend and you will see
That dream is my reality
They keep me locked up in this cage
Can't they see that why my brain says rage

Sanatarium
Leave me be
Sanatarium
Just leave me alone

The Number 1 bus is the most statistically robust vector for the transmission of tuberbulosis in the City of  Boston. I have this on good authority from the Public Health Commission.

Now a good friend has contracted H1N1 influenza from the same bus because some highly irresponsible sick person was coughing and sneezing in that urban American way, and the bus ride inched along for 30 minutes longer than it should. People, didn't any of you see 'Outbreak'?

Don't take that bus if you can avoid it. Bring an N95 rated respirator. And alcohol wipes. 

FAIL.

If this bus did its job properly, it would be AWESOME.

I took this bus from Symphony Hall up to MIT for a concert. Got on the bus - got there easily and quickly (10 minutes! hooray!)

When it was time to leave, it was cold. Deathly cold. "Exhale-and-your-breath-hurls-ice-pellets-at someone's-face" cold. I really really wished the bus would come quickly, because I was afraid I might die.

Ten minutes: "Ffffuuuuuuck, it's cold."
Twenty minutes: "I can't feel my fingers."
Thirty minutes: "I can't feel my toes."
Forty minutes: "Whoever said hell was hot was lying. Hey look, a #1 bus in the opposite direction!"
Forty-five minutes: "Fuck it, I'm walking home."

I then trudged all the way home in the bitter cold in less time than it took the bus not to come.

Fail.

A Day in the Life of the MBTA Bus 1:

Me and Joe: ::walking onto the 1 bus at Hynes, among the clusterfuck of people.  Takes a seat::
Crazy guy in the back of the bus: ::People getting on:: Please don't step on my sneakers.  These are brand new.  If you step on my sneakers I'm gonna have to take it outchya wallet.  Don't step on my sneakers or else I'ma have to rob you.
Me:  O_O ::stares back at Joe, mumbles under breath:: Please move faster.....
Girl standing in front of crazy guy listening to him ramble about his sneakers to her: ....Those are nice sneakers
Crazy guy: Thanks, but if you step on it I'ma have to take it outchya wallet, and I don't want to have to take it outchya wallet but I will.  You got any other questions Miss Lady? Can I call you Miss Lady?
Me: ::trying not to burst out laughing praising God Almighty she is NOT that girl::
Girl: ....Um...No  ::moves to front of bus::

Kind of  reminds me of the Bill Cosby skit, "Nut in Every Car"

I've never had an experience quite like that.  He also went on to tell some guy to stop looking at him......

I like how the 1 takes me where I need to go, but god damnit there are a lot of people on this damn bus.  They need to run like 3 or 4 buses in a row to accommodate all the damn people.  And even then, it would still be a clusterfuck.  But at least there's entertainment.

Let's talk about the ONE for a minute. About how there are a gazillion stops and you could walk the route faster on most days. Walking that route is something I urge most of you to do in fact, when it's not a windy or rainy frozen nightmare outside and you're not wearing a super great outfit. Anyhow, this route is a disaster. It amazes me how short it is, but how late I always am because of it. Maybe I should just take the green line *GASP*

business.full_address:
1515 Holcombe Blvd
Medical Center
Houston, TX 77030
business.name: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

reviews.text:
If I ever get cancer or if I ever become an oncologist, I would want to receive treatment/work at UTMDACC. Hands down, I am always humbled when I am surrounded by these smart and compassionate doctors, nurses, technicians, staff, and volunteers. I had some of the best volunteering memories and neurosurgery shadowing experiences at this wonderful teaching hospital

Dr. Mendelsohn has been at the reigns of this internationally reknowned cancer center since I was in elementary school, which was more than 2 decade ago, and he has done a superb job of always promoting the leading edge of oncology treatments. The doctors relieve grim diagnosis with positive prognosis, just because they are darn excellent at making cancer history (with both double meanings of history). And best of all, the doctors are helping my dear friend beat prostate cancer at the tender age of 26.

I just can't say enough good things about this place. My dad has had lung cancer being treated over the last year and the podunk northside hospital he was at had declared him cured. As a favor, he went to MD Anderson to see a doc a neighbor worked for. That awesome guy had a third of my dad's colon pulled out after finding polyps, discovering cancer hanging out there. If he had stopped treatment on the northside, this would be festering. He is in such a good position to heal, and it would have been borrowed time otherwise.

The point is that these guys are driven to succeed. They want to cure cancer because they are a research institute and so they don't stop until they're sure. They are also just darn good people. My dad celebrated his bday there and we came in and they had cake and balloons waiting for him. So nice. Every single person associated with this hospital is amazing, receiving treatment anywhere else is simply settling. This is the only place to be. (but duuuude, parking gets expensive. Dad was in for 30 days, cost about $10 each time to park. Ka-ching!

Update on my initial review from January.  The comments are based on both first-hand experience and from other family members.  

Positives:  some of the friendliest staff I've encountered in a medical setting.  The nurses in the clinics are helpful and they didn't act like we were intruding when we had questions.  The hospital staff (from the floor nurses to the residents) made us feel like my sister was being taken care of while she was there.  

Negatives:  Some of the doctors needed better bed-side manners (the residents are much better - it seems the more experienced and teaching doctors have somehow gotten detached from their patients).  Social workers - I had a good experience with MD Anderson until I had to deal with the social workers.  They were non-responsive - their job was to coordinate my sister's discharge to hospice care.  I ended up going onto the internet and searching for hospice care companies to followup on who can take her.  It's a tough time for families at this point and their attitudes and performance does not help with the situation.

The treatments at MD Anderson were not successful for my sister and she passed away this past June.  Overall, the experience had more positives than negatives.  It did give us hope for a short period of time.  Though knowing what we know now, I don't know if we would have continued treatment if we had to do it all over again.

This hospital does amazing things everyday. From the moment I got there I knew that I was going to be taken care of. Btw the hospital food is amazing too. Actual legitimate menus and taste. Very satisfied with a home away from home
I am alive because of this hospital, so I give it five stars!
Can someone recommend a health plan for an elderly that is accepted in the MD Anderson Center
This place is phenomenal! The staff is amazing and they are all dedicated to the patient. They are passionate and caring!

I have been a Chinese interpreter for this hospital for almost 2 years now! The staff is very nice, polite, professional with great attitude. The facility is very huge and I get lost number of times! Nevertheless, the staff has been very helpful giving me good directions. :) I totally enjoy working with them as a contractor and always looking forward to it!

This is probably the most serious, heartfelt review you will ever see from the likes of my sarcastic ass.

About three years ago, my dad came down with a serious tumor that resulted in radiation, chemo and a major operation with 5 weeks in intensive care. This was at a different hospital with different doctors. The end result was him being cancer free - worse for wear - but supposedly cancer free. 

Not so fast.

A couple years later, he went back for a checkup to those same doctors who told him he was fine. But something wasn't right. So, we signed him up at MD Anderson for a second opinion. Thank God we did. Because they found a major recurrence of the same cancer he was supposedly healed from. At stage 4. Before he had the chance to die from it.

Before we could blink an eye, he was already in treatment. And in the hands of the leading expert on his type of cancer, no less. Dr. Jaffer Ajani, our somewhat introverted doctor, had our entire faith in his hands. And for good reason.

It paid off. 

Although my dad will never be free of this cancer (at least, not in the near term), they shrunk that stuff down to size. He feels great again and will continue to be in periodic care/management at MD Anderson. And that will make us breathe easier.

The entire experience of cancer sucks for everyone involved. If there is one major, MAJOR part of it that makes it somewhat bearable, it's the care of the people, the technology and the process at MD Anderson. The entire process was so unbelievably efficient - even in such a huge facility - it made us wonder over and over again on how they are able to do it. The technology is the absolute latest and greatest. And the people? Well, they have a sincere passion for what they do (I'm leaving out the exception of one nurse we had issues with that were soon "resolved"). Passion drives greatness. This place is full of it.

You cannot put a price on the ones you love. And you cannot put a price on the services MD Anderson can offer.

What can you say?  MD Anderson is fantastic. 

It sucks to have a family member dealing with cancer, but I can't think of a better place for them to be treated.   We're dealing with a re-occurence of metastic melanoma that was supposedly removed by other doctors over 18 months ago. 

It was removed from the foot and lower leg, only to resurface in the liver and lungs 18 months later.  The old docs didn't find this, and the only reason we found it was because we got a second opinion from MD Anderson.  These docs know what they're doing.  

In the last 4 months they have been able to reduce the tumor's by over 60%, and are making continuous progress.  They just got my family member approved for a new drug that was recently released by Bristol Myers Squibb (called Urvoy).  

We are the first to be treated with it outside of clinical trials, and I don't think we would have been able to get our hands on the drug at a lesser known hospital.  

While we're not in the clear yet, we're making great progress and I feel ad good as possible about a bad situation.  It's very reassuring to know that Phil Mickelson had his family treated here, and based on our experience, 

I can't think of a better place to fight this horrible disease.  High marks to the team of doctors at MD Anderson!

What can you say about MD Anderson? It's a place to love and hate. Hate due to the simple reason it must exist, and love because the people here are doing their dadgum best to end cancer.

My Dad was diagnosed with lymphoma, and MDACC did everything they could to help him, including trial treatments. Unfortunately, there was a spot in his lung that just wouldn't respond, and with his asbestosis issues, there wasn't too much of a chance. He passed away peacefully, at home,  in 2009 after a 9 month battle.

Later that year, I was diagnosed with a granular cell tumor and had to have my right great/big toe amputated.

In the above situations, to date, I've spent almost 2 years going up to MDACC once a week or more, and every time, the staff makes "everything better." All of the people I've come in contact with, be they schedulers, nurses, Doctors, janitorial staff, errand runners, etc. -- they are all caring and compassionate, and outwardly so.

The Doctors and the staff of the Lymphoma and the Melanoma clinics are outstanding. Dr. Nathan Fowler (my Dad's Dr.) was just an awesome and caring guy. Very down to Earth, very honest, and very helpful. My Doc, Dr. Merrick Ross, is just amazing. Great bedside manner, and he did an excellent job with the amputation. He's known as the best surgical oncologist in the US, and I believe it.

All in all, MDACC is a great institution, and I can't image going anywhere else for any cancer-related issues.

Absolutely amazing place.  The people are wonderful.  Things run rather efficiently although not always quickly.  I enjoy the place of wellness and the classes they offer.  The different sections are designated by pieces of art or interest...from waterfalls to tree sculptures to gazebos and beyond !

I work here as a nurse and I can tell you, it's the best hospital I've ever worked for. They really, really, really care about their patients and that is something you unfortunately don't see at many hospitals. I am proud to work for such a great institution.

Let me start off by saying that I am NOT an employee of MD Anderson or any of it's entities nor do I or my immediate family work in any other medical or insurance related industry. This review is purely from a member of a patient's family's standpoint and will provide tips that will hopefully help you around your way at MD Anderson.

If you're reading this review, you're probably looking for some insight from others whom have had experience with this facility and I hope this information I provide could help.

MD Anderson is the epitome of world class service. The phrase "You pay for what you get" is certainly true, however, given the high cost of medical fees and high degree of care and services offered, there are always certain areas that can be improved to make MD Anderson an even better Cancer Center. 

CHOOSING THE RIGHT DOCTOR

To begin, I would like to stress the importance of choosing the right doctor. Like any medical facility, there are doctors who tend to focus more on a clinical approach while others are more interested in experimental approaches. Make sure you find out which approach works best for you and your family before choosing a doctor. I say this because it is often very difficult to switch doctors after you've made a choice. Also keep in mind the doctor's reputation. You will need to do a lot of research on this and probably visit the facility yourself. Like any caring family member, I was making phone calls left to right, searching online etc, to find the best oncologist at MD Anderson. Let me save you the time and say that no one at MD Anderson will tell you. What you need to be asking instead is "which doctor has the busiest schedule?". The "busy-ness" factor represents his/her popularity/demand and this will be the proxy for a doctor's ranking. As far as oncologists goes, I found out there are 2 breast cancer oncologists with very busy schedules currently at MD Anderson. To find out which doctors have the busiest schedules, you'll need to contact each doctor's assistant. Each doctor has an assistant whom does all the scheduling for patients so it's best to contact them directly.

INSURANCE

Secondly, make sure you have insurance and that your insurance company approves your treatment at MD Anderson. Luckily, we had insurance and they cover 90% of the cost. But for the sake of simplicity, I'll list all costs without insurance. If you do not have insurance, then there is an initial fee of ~$21000 USD paid up front which does not include any medical scans or procedures. Medical scans such as CT scans, ultrasound, x-rays cost about $2400-$3000 per scan. If your cancer treatment requires surgery, you will most likely have to stay in the hospital for at least 5 days. Surgery cost differs for each type of surgery, so I won't get in to that as I have no idea what the costs are for other surgeries other than the one my family member had. However, hospital stays are about $2000 per night, with the first night of in the range of $5000-$6000.

GET A MAP

Yes, get a map. No matter how abundant the signs are inside the buildings, you will still need a map for your first few visits. MD Anderson has several buildings and you will most likely be visiting the Mays Clinic and/or Main Building the most. These 2 buildings are connected via a LONG and enclosed bridge. You can walk it, but MD Anderson also offers free shuttle (more like golf carts) every 2-3 minutes, so people with problems walking can use those instead. Both buildings are huge and appear as if they're made like a maze. This is particularly the case with the Main Building where one can easily get lost by making a wrong turn. There are also numerous entrances and parking garages at MD Anderson. When you are making an appointment for the first time, remember to as which entrance and garage you should use. On a related note, if you are visiting the facility the first time, you are entitled for free valet parking. Make sure you get it validated. 

SURGERY

During surgery, family members will be waiting at a designated waiting area on the same floor as the operating room. Also during surgery, your surgeon will contact any family members via a phone at the reception desk of the waiting room for updates regarding the status of the surgery. After the surgery, the surgeon will come out to talk to the family members about the surgery in a private room. 

HOSPITAL ROOMS

Regarding the hospital rooms, you are allowed 1 person to stay  with the patient during the nights. Each room has a 1-person couch which folds out into a bed. Patients are free to order food from a limited menu via phone (very much like room service at a hotel). All costs associated with food and drinks are included, so eat and drink up! Nurses comes about every 30min to an hour to check on the patients vital signs, so if someone is staying with the patient overnight, let them be warned that he/she may not get a good night's rest.

I have been coming to MD Anderson since 2009.  I have spent  few months inpatient and many months outpatient.  Overall the hospital is the best at what they do, hands down.  Everyone I encounter is professional and compassionate, and I really appreciate the volunteers.  What a wonderful program and it is so helpful to patients.

One of the best things about the hospital is the available services when you need it.  MRI, CT scans, x-rays, etc. are available quickly if not immediately.  This goes a long way to alleviating worry because you don't have to wait days/weeks for a test and results.

I'm still fighting cancer, but I whole-heartedly believe I am in the best place to do so, surrounded by the best doctors for my disease.  One of the doctor's I see literally wrote the textbook on my disease.  Seriously.

Easiest 5 Stars you could ever give when they place patient care, welfare, health, and convenience first.

  We needed to bring a family member here many times, and each time the stellar performance of the hospital never changed. There was always a friendly staff, HIPPA information and security, and a volunteer to get you what you may need.

 For a hospital that moves a city of people daily while saving lives.. you cannot complain. We are blessed and grateful that such good people pride themselves on taking care of others.

MD Anderson was a great place to work.  The staff are friendly, talented, and reasonable.  They work well together (IMHO, this is uncommon).  I was treated well from the beginning all the way until my last day.  My experience was with the non-clinical, research side of the institution.  The employees conduct themselves with uncommon dedication, competence, and professionalism.
I need help for my mom.  It's a frinday night in Reno, NV and need to talk to someone at this hospitial.  She has high grade ESS. Please call me, we don't want to lose her. (775) 848-4552

I can't put into words the gratitude I feel towards this hospital.  They are amazing.  People said to me before I came here that the hospital is too big - you'll feel like a number.  Even though the hospital is huge and they see patients that travel there from all over the world - each time I went I felt I received very personalized treatment.  

The staff there is truly different from other hospitals.  I heard from the nurses that MD Anderson has the highest rate of staff staying there until retirement, or if they leave they come back and stay until they retire.  As a patient I never felt like I got treatment from someone punching a time card.  Everyone seems to truly believe in what they are doing.  That brought me a lot of peace of mind and comfort during my struggle with cancer. 

They saved my life and I'm grateful.  I would recommend this hospital to anyone that can make the trip here - it's worth it.

business.full_address:
782 Route 518
Skillman, NJ 08558
business.name: Calhoun's Garage

reviews.text:
We had an old car that was making too many different noises to even try to describe on CarTalk.  The check engine light had been stuck on for years (except, luckily, whenever it needed to pass inspections).  Then it started having major issues.  Finally we ended up at Calhoun's, after having tried out half the auto repair shops in the area.  Mr. Calhoun himself gave us a diagnosis of the things that were wrong with the car, in order of priority, with no pressure at all to fix more than we could afford.  We decided to deal with just a couple of items first.

When we finally picked it up after the repairs were done, the engine ran so much better that we sat dumbfounded in silence for several minutes, listening to all the little noises that weren't there.
