I went back for more, despite being turned off by my first plate. I was going to get my money's worth either way. Despite being called "Tokyo Sushi", there sure wasn't much of that. There was some itty bitty california rolls and shrimp tempura rolls, but the rice was hard and they weren't very good. I'm not sure if sushi is more prominent during lunch, but with a look at their menu, it's expensive as hell anyways. I'm talking 15 bucks for a specialty roll order. I could go to Bethesda for sushi twice the quality at half the price, according to a fellow sushi enthusiast. 

I took a few rolls anyways, with some general tso's chicken and white rice. I could tell by looking at the rice that it was overcooked, and when I tasted it, I knew I should have trusted my instincts. The general tsos was soggy, like it'd been left there all day, and again, tasted like nothing. 

By that point, my friend and I were grumbling about the crappiness of the food but were still hungry, so we went for salad and fruit. Not trusting the ranch dressing, I had my salad with warm italian dressing, and was again turned off. I recall my friend joking and remarking "They can't mess up watermelon, can they?" and then spitting it out saying it was warm and dry. 

Perhaps my standards are too high because I'm an asian cuisine fanatic, and can make most of their selections at home by myself. But If I, an amateur, can make it a hundred times better, then I might as well have saved the money and done just that. I mean, even the orange crush I ordered tasted watered down. I'm giving this place two stars, because the waitress was very sweet, but I really recommend fellow yelpers to save themselves a night of food poisoning and get their fill of Chinese food elsewhere.

I do not understand the hate that this place gets. I have ordered food from every chinese place in Hyattsville and none compare to Tokyo Sushi. The place is clean (dining area, plates, forks, buffet tables, and the bathroom) and the service is always good too. They refill the buffet tables often when you are eating there which is a plus. They also have decent sushi for a Chinese buffet. I love this place and my family and I eat there once a week with no complaints :)

This place gets 2 stars because of how ridiculously cheap it is, although it probably only deserves 1. It's even cheaper for UMD students on Thursdays... so, unless you're a UMD student, stay away on Thursdays. The food was not memorable, and kind of gross at times. The service was ok. Check out China Buffet instead. Much better selection of food and equally cheap.

Disclaimer: the sushi menu is also offered at the (terrible) bar next door.  

We ordered some dumplings and sushi as appetizers for our meal. Dumplings appeared to be from a bargain bin and perhaps microwaved within the last four hours. The sushi (spicy salmon) seemed like it was some kind of paste rather than fish. Ive eaten cheap sushi before, but this wins the award for the worst Ive ever had. Congrats.

I'm eating it as I type at my desk (dire food emergency).

It's ok but entirely too greasy (I will seriously need to detox via lots of water and plain green tea shortly). I have only eaten here two other times.

It's semi-tolerable, but I'd only pack a box full of food. Only stick to certain seafoods, pepper chicken (only when it's visibly hot), veggies, and veggie lo-mein. I wouldn't touch anything else, especially the desserts and sushi.

And packing your own box is cheaper than the buffet price (unless you just eat THAT ridiculously much lol).

Another thing: The coconut shrimp tastes nothing like coconut, but instead cheap, fried, store bought! :-/

I was in Hyattsville to pick up an item from the Metro Lost & Found when I walked across this. There were a ton of warning signs (mainly: it's a Chinese buffet called Tokyo Sushi), all of which I ignored for the "$5.75 lunch buffet" sign. In I go!

The food wasn't anything spectacular, but pretty darn good for what I paid for it. The calamari and seafood delight were perfectly enjoyable. I guess I'm a little more forgiving (and amazed) because there's really no such thing as a $6 lunch buffet in Alexandria. I'd come back here frequently if only the cost of the commute didn't negate the low price for the food.

I totally agree with the other reviewer, this place has serious problems. I took a bite of the shumai dumpling and it was so disgusting my tongue pushed it out back onto the plate before I could even mentally process what it was. It didn't even taste bad, it tasted like disease. 

All the rest of the items involving meat were similarly inedible. 

However, it works for me on price. 6.35 for all you can eat vegetables and fresh orange slices is a pretty good deal.

I switched to the salad. The fresh lettuce, red peppers cucumbers and onions were fine. 

Agree that the best dressing option, Italian, was not so great. If I come here again i would just ask for some oil and rice wine vinegar.

nice staff. horrible buffet. I left there feeling sick and ashamed. all the food is very oily. there's only about 40 food items. 2 kinds of sushi. not worth it. pictures outside are a complete fabrication

business.full_address:
350 S Lake Ave
# 107
Pasadena
Pasadena, CA 91101
business.name: Frank's Shoe Repair

reviews.text:
I'm fascinated by shoe repair. It's fun to watch, and the end product is even better. My work heels are mostly Cole Haan Nike Airs, so fairly expensive and I love them too much to just toss when the heels wear down. At Franks, he'll replace the heels, polish & shine, and your shoes are as good as new for just $12.  He's quick; I'm actually just watching him finish as I draft this review. 

I trust Frank because I brought in a pair of Cole Haan NAs to fix previously.  The padding on the inside of both shoes had thinned out and was providing little support. He replaced at a very reasonable price, and they were comfortable again.

He's friendly, but be sure to specify what it is you want. Also, he prefers cash.

K, shoes are done; gotta run.

This review is not about their shoe repair service, but rather their warm customer service. I had two belts that needed some extra holes, so I took them into Frank's. I asked how much it would cost, but he just waved his hand around and said there would be no charge and to come back in a few minutes. Voila! But... oops. Only one hole when I asked for two each. I went back and he punched in the additional holes, even though he had started working on something.

I took my almost 40-year-old high end vintage leather jacket to Frank to have a lining placed in it because the original lining was tattered.  I had not worn this jacket in many years but had preserved it in the best conditions.  Last Christmas I gifted the jacket to my daughter and I took it to Frank to have the lining repaired.  I was devasted when I saw that someone in this business damaged the leather on the back of my jacket and has totally devalued the jacket. To exacerbate matters, when I returned to Frank, early the next day to discuss the damage of my jacket with Frank, he refused to return the $100.00 I paid him to my credit card, accused me of being a con artist--and told me to sue him!
I trust frank completely! Best tailor in town!
Super nice. Took care of my Kenneth Cole wedges & Franco Sarto sandals~ Definitely reccommend

First time to try this shop out. Been to Very good shoe repair places in LA proper that promise a good job for a fair price. This is not one of them.

So-so work. No concept of delivering on time. Heels and shines for my wife's shoes were done on time, but a pair of boots that required side gussets to be replaced needed 3 trips and 4 weeks to complete. Wha??
Work was sloppy at best. 

Will not go again and I should have not done so many pairs for a first go.

He did a great job fixing up a pair of my terribly scuffed shoes. But even better, he fixed my favorite purse! He had to open up the lining to do it and you can't even tell. Seemed like a good price too. Another time I stopped by and wanted him to add a couple of extra holes to a belt. He did it right then and there and didn't charge. 
The only drawback might be the hours.

Frank's is the epitome of good old fashioned service. Frank is very sweet, helpful and professional. I was very pleased with the customization of my soles. The shop is clean and quaint. It is also a tailor shop and I would most definitely take my garments there when necessary.

business.full_address:
126 Yale Ave
Claremont, CA 91711
business.name: Claremont Books & Prints

reviews.text:
Beauty.  Nestled in the downtown of the Claremont colleges, this is as lovely as it gets.  The door from the street opens up to a narrow, wooden staircase which leads to the upstairs loft which is the bookstore.  Bookcases to the ceiling, lining corners and tiny hallways.  Out of print books, all sorts of eclectic old texts, beautiful first editions under glass throughout the store.  A gem of a place.

Note: Has changed owner, so now is called Second Story books.  One unfortunate side of this is that the new owner has taken down the old magazine and newspaper prints of other bookstores and libraries that used to be hung up all around the store.  It was a bit shabby of course, but really charming.  Ah well.

business.full_address:
95 King Street S
Waterloo, ON N2J 5A2
business.name: Starbucks Coffee Company

reviews.text:
This place is consistently busy, and I have often met people I know while standing in line here.  I figure they are here for the same reason I am: for the tasty beverages, good service and cozy environment.

They are, at this store, at peak times, often overwhelmingly busy, but I find the line moves fast and the servers are happy to serve you (and maybe make a little small talk as well).  In the wintertime, I love their Salted Carmel Hot Chocolate (which I have dubbed the SCHC) and often come here to get my fix when I am in the area.

I don't know why someone else give this place such low rating (maybe they were here on a bad day), but I heartily give my recommendation to this location.

The staff is nice, but their product is consistently terrible and watery for whatever reason.

The seating looks like a nice enough place to chill, but given the alternatives I've never been particularly driven to do so.

business.full_address:
5611 Morningside Dr
West University
Houston, TX 77005
business.name: Little Woodrow's

reviews.text:
The establishment itself, which has consistently been a great place for me to sit and enjoy a beer with my fellow grad students (weekdays only) gets a  4. This 2-rating is for the bartender who was working last Thursday night.

Dear bartender,
Perhaps you were having a bad night. Perhaps most people don't tip. But I tip really well. When I gave you exact change for my beer, you stood there and stared me down, until, uncomfortable, I asked if I had the correct amount. You said, in reply, THANKS A LOT, apparently not noticing, in my other hand, the dollar I was about to put down on the bar as a tip. 

You see, in all of my years frequenting bars, I've never given my tip in the same wad of cash as I use to pay for my drink, because it seems easier for the bartender to tell that they don''t need to make change if I leave it on the bar separately. And friends of mine who have tended bar have done the same. In fact, I copied this technique from someone who tends bar. 

Also, you didn't pour my beer. The nice guy working with you did. It was for him that I still put down the dollar tip, on a three dollar beer. For you, I could only muster a look of shock, because I've never been treated that way before in a bar. 

I stood there for a moment, hurt, wanting to say something back, but I didn't, because I'm generally the kind of conflict-adverse person who is so eager to please that I tip more than I should most of the time. 

Making me feel that awful and confused means if you ever serve me again, I will not be tipping. But it should all work out fine, because if I see you behind the bar I'll wait until someone else is free.

Went here one night with a group of friends because Bronx wouldn't let us in due to their private party they got going on. It was semi-packed but a decent place to go to enjoy some beer and they have the typical bar games like darts and golden tee. Very chill environment.

Sometimes you just need a cold beer, and if that's the case, then Little Woodrows is a good place.  They have a great selection of both draft and bottled beer.  It's a really calm place to sit and hang out with your friends and even your four-legged friends.  I love a dog-friendly establishment.

Overall, not a typical place I hang out, nothing special, but a good place to people watch and relax with friends.

Just as the three star rating says "A-OK"...fun place to pregame, I suppose?

Drinks were strong-ish, cheap-ish and the crowd was freaking young. Miller lites, house vodka and jager bombs abound!

Forgive me, but I'm over hanging out with my age group (under 25). Give me a nice lounge, good martinis and attractive patrons. 

Ugh, I'm old.

Happy hour is 2-7pm. From 8-10pm there is a special on domestic longnecks for $1.50. There is a dart board and a pool table. The music is too loud and the tables outside are too large. One of the bartenders was nice and friendly.

If you're looking for a chill place to have a few beers and play some darts, Little Woodrow's is for you. I'll often come here when we have nothing else in mind. It's not necessarily my most favorite place to go, but it's a safe spot and this place never disappoints.

The only drawback is that their selection of beer is pretty poor when compared to Gingerman, which is right next door. But still a more than decent selection, and I'm sure you will find something to your liking.

You know some places just hold a special place in your heart. Its not that they are super nice places or that they are hip and cool, it just that they are comfortable and familiar. When you walk in the door you feel like you never really left, that is what I love about Little Woodrows. This use to be a very frequented spot of mine especially on Sat night's $3 You-call-it bigass mug- AND IT TRULY IS BIGASS!! And on Sun nights when they also have great drink specials. I got to know some of the bartenders really well and I felt as if I was right at home. The bartenders played games such as Jenga with the bar patrons and you had yourself just an old-fashion good time. Then several months went by when I did not visit the bar and when I finally decided to go back I felt as if I had never left. The bar looked exactly the same, the staff were pretty much all still there, and environment was just as comfortable as I remembered it. 

Little Woodrows has a great selection of various beers at a good price. Inside you can play photo hunt, pool, darts, or a selection of board games. They have a great patio which makes this place good for large groups of people, assuming that you get there early enough. Also, they have what is called the "Big 50 Club", where you have to finish there selection of 50 beers in a certain order and when you are done you get you name on a plaque to put on the bar wall and ceiling. 

The only negatives are that sometimes the bar can get packed and it takes a while to get a bartender because typically the most they have are two. Also, because the bar is very opened up to the outside patio, it can get very muggy and slightly uncomfortable. But despite these things, this is a great neighborhood bar and I was feel right at home when I am there.

Having recently just started grad school this bar is one of the spots that the collective has been frequenting the most. Tuesdays are their Big Ass Beer nights in conjecture with their Geeks who Drink trivia night. This occasion means that you get one of their specified beers (i always choose Shiner) in one of their big mugs for $4.25. 

The cool thing about this Woodrows is that they finally got their liquor license so if you have a friend who doesnt like beer. Simple. They can drink all the liquor they want. 

The Geeks who Drink is pretty awesome, they do 8 rounds of 8 questions each and they usually run through it pretty quickly. The only problem is that the volume on the stereo is painstakingly low so the place either has to be completely quiet or you just miss the question. 

Im still a big fan. 2 thumbs up.

It's a bar, it's in the village, and it's ok.  The drink prices are ok, the crowd is ok.  If there was such a thing as a perfect example of a mediocre place, this would be it.  With so many other options in the village, I'm not sure why you would end up here.  Thats probably why I don't too often!

I stopped by woodrows for a couple beers last night. Mostly uninteresting. 
I talked to two group of girls. They were both pretty fun none of them really my type though. I like Woodrows cool place.

Little Woodrows is a decent joint. They have a good amount of beer, decent happy hour prices, darts, TVs for sporting events and ample indoor and outdoor seating. 

However, the service is typically slow and a little frustrating. It has more of a college vibe than other bars in the area and it can get quite loud and crowded. 

On a recent evening, they were supporting the opening of a new brewery - Karbach Brewing and you could get $3.25 pints of their beer. For an extra $9  you could get a tshirt and pint glass too. I appreciate their support of local brews. The hubs and I played a littlle darts, drank a few beers and caught some football. Standard bar. A-OK in my book.
Great place to drink some beer and relax on the patio and open air bar. Especially on Tuesday night with $4 mega mugs!

Being the beer snob that I am, I frequented Ginger Man when I first moved to Houston-- then I started checking my bank statements.

Why not move next door where there are actual specials? Super friendly bar staff. Dog-friendly too! 

Fun trivia Tuesdays=bonus!
Pretty good.

This is not a good place for happy hour. They don't serve food and the drink specials are for domestics. I came at 5pm once and it was only old men hunched over a small bar in a dark little room. They do have a huge patio, but it was bare. I can't imagine this place being popular since it's hot in Houston for the summer so I certainly don't want to drink and sweat out on the patio with no A/C.

Beer. Ya know, there are bars out there that try to come off so smart and sophisticated, and uppity with their great selection, ambiance etc... I prefer the K.I.S.S. method to drinking sometimes.  Just give me the basics. This place is great at being basic. 

My buddy and I started our Saturday beerfest here. It was great. I mean, when you name all my requirements for drinking beer and running my mouth, this place had just about everything. Outdoor seating, a deck, golden tee, darts, pool, and a pretty good beer selection are the things I simply require when I just want to grab a beer. Also, I don't need any special beer made by a one legged Belgian with the gout and a secret recipe. No, just a pitcher of cold bud light will do me fine. This is a good basic bar. Cheap, cheap beer, great specials if you happen to catch one (Tues day big ass beer day is awesome), and plenty of seating. They've got the basics covered. 

They got docked a star because the times we've gone in there, it's been a total sausage fest. Saturday was no exception. They've started selling frozen Bellini's and margaritas to attract female customers the bartender said. It would really be wise for them to think of ways to entice female clients because as we all know, if there's girls, the guys will come. Wait....Um, I mean if there's females, then the guys will stop by. ;-)

Its Friday night and I am trolling Rice village. Of course my first stop was Little woodrows. This place has a huge front patio. And thats whats so enticing about it. I love the fact that you can grab a cold beer on a warm day and simply chill outside. uhhh..OK so its summer and it was hot and humid. But most of the nights are cool.  

Happy hour is 2-7pm and 8-10pm a special on domestic long necks for $1.50. The bathrooms are OK... I mean its a basic bar. The bartenders are friendly and they are quick to get to you. 

There are a couple of dart boards and a pool table if you want to play. Usually there is someone playing pool. Which brings me to the clientele. Very friendly. You can go and pick a conversation with just about anyone and are bound to get a friendly response.  The music is not too loud and so you can actually hear others speak. 

This is a great male bonding spot and I would recommended this as such. I wont recommend this as a first date spot unless she is a jeans and t-shirt kinda gal. But great for the 3rd date onward. 

Overall I its a great spot and I would definitely go there again.

This is a neighborhood favorite. It's always been a nice, laid-back atmosphere to complement the Rice Village vibe. They recently started serving liquor, which has introduced a slightly different crowd on the weekends.

I love all of the little Woodrow's in general, but this one is not my favorite. I used to go to it more, but now I find myself avoiding the rice village area. For one, it used to be a more dead atmosphere, but parking sucks no matter how you slice it.

They now offer liquor but before it was only beer. I guess that makes it easier to bring out my friends who claim to not be beer drinkers.

It is definitely a more casual place, but it has a lot of big tables so it is good for groups.

I am a fan!

I like this whole little area (when parking is decent). Little Woodrows is always fun, although if it's not a week night sometimes it's a little too crowded for my taste. The other night we were at Ginger Man's next door and hard they had Saint Arnold's Divine Reserve 10 on tap, jumped next door and had a half pint, that was definitely a pleasant surprise! (Any other St. Arnold fans understand how big of a deal this is!) Pretty cool little joint with a good selection and nice patio.

I find it amusing that I've been in Houston for over two years, find myself at the Ginger Man (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-ginger-man-houston) more often than not, and yet I only made it to Little Woodrow's a few weeks ago.

Truthfully, they're pretty similar bars.  The clientele is a lot more laid back than most of the bars in The Village and lot less frat daddy/douche baggy.  Yes, there are darts and pool.  (Ginger Man does not have a pool table.)  Yes, they have a huge selection of beer.  Yes, it is much more spacious than most places in The Village.

And while I liked it a lot, it is just one of those places that doesn't leave a strong impression on you.  Which I find amusing since I enjoy the Ginger Man so much and they're so similar in patrons, vibe, and service.  Nevertheless, it is a solid bar and you can see plenty of dogs on any given night.

Appears to be a very local scene with Texan memorabilia and local offerings of beer.  The taps cover the walls as they do at the Avenue in Allston, MA.  Another great place just to chill with friends and chit chat.  Divey: my kind of place.

I can't complain about a place that days after the hurricane had ice brought in so that they could serve cold beer by candle light since they still had no power. 
That is brilliant. 

They had live (obviously acoustic) music outside that day and I really enjoyed it. 

Call it withdrawl, call it whatever you like. All I know is that I got cold beer at a welcoming little place in the Village at a time when I needed it the most.

There's nowhere in Houston I'd rather hang out with some friends and grab a few beers. When the weather is nice, the patio is great, and even has great metal cheers rather than the typical flimsy ass plastic chairs. 

It can get a little crowded on Friday or Saturday nights but it's a great place to spend a weeknight or an afternoon.

This review is based on a one time so it stands at 4 stars but could be bumped up next time I go.

I was only here for about an hour late saturday night but I loved this place once inside. My first impression was it kind of looked dumpy but it kind of is in a good way. his place is great for a group of friends, or just two, to go grab a drink or 7 and watch a game and just hang out for cheap drinks. 

In the hour I was there I was already chatting with a few people, just seems like a friendly place. The people that go and hangout and drink here appreciate it, and I think I shall too.

Can't lose!  Little Woodrow's is a nice looking place with a lot of beer on tap-- and it's pretty darn cheap too!  Lots of friendly people and very crowded on weekends.  Nice place to go.  Recommended.

Whenever i felt like getting out of Katy and having some beers, I would tell my friends to meet me at Lil Woodrows as i call it.  The beer selection is great and they have a fair amounts of wine as well.  Fun atmosphere inside and out on the patio.  
The people there are friendly and usually have no problems with splitting a table if there is no where else to sit.  
The service can be slow at times just because of the amount of people that are usually there.  So if you go, find a strategy for getting a drink quickly.  
Oh and they have board games in case you feel like kickin it ol school kid style. Plus its in Rice Village and you can hop around to three other bars that are right next door.
Would have given it 5 stars if drink service was faster

Update: They have liquor now!

There is nothing really special about Little Woodrows. It is a good place to chill with friends, but I feel like it is just there, with nothing really that great to offer. It is relatively quiet so you can hear each other. 

They have a good selection of beers on tap, but not extensive. They don't have liquor. The inside is very small, so if it gets crowded expect to sit outside in the brutal Houston weather. 

The main reason we go is for trivia night every Tuesday which can be fun. The prices for a beer are decent but not great. 

Parking can be annoying as they don't validate for the parking garage, but just stop in at Baker Street for a few beers

Cheap beer, nice bartenders.  This is a great place to go if you're hanging out with friends and want to take over one of their outside patio tables.  It's not really much of a pick-up place (which I really like) although I'm sure a fair number of people get hit on there because, well, it's a *bar.*  We hang out here quite a lot, but if you're a non-smoker like me, the smoky outdoors can be a little overwhelming.

I have been going to this place for a while and i must say that every time I'm here its a blast the people here are awesome. They just hang out no problems just to hang out and have some beers. They have a great variety of beer and make you favorite mixed drinks too. Snake bite, Black and Tan you name it. The juke box is cool too cause you can listen to your own mix of music but if you get to it make sure you load it up cause if you don't someone will. Great place to chillax and have a few..

I love the Gingerman next door, and this place is a pretty nice place to hang out as well.  The beer selection is good, and the bartenders do a good job of taking care of everybody.  The manager knows what he is doing as well.  A really chill place with a great patio out front, and a good atmosphere to watch the Texans play.  I usually come in the afternoon because it is a different crowd at night.  Overall good alternative to the Gman when they are crowded or you don't want to spend as much cash.

Well given I have only been here once my review is not completely scientific. I was invited by my classmate to watch a bloody MMA game, which I did enjoy. The place was not hard to find, just right by the rice village shopping center on Mornigside. I ordered one drink only since I did not have a designated driver. It's just sad that you go out and can't even enjoy more than one drink. But it's always better safe than sorry. I am totally against DUI.

I am not an alcohol person. My typical drinks are Gin Tonic, Margarita or the recently acquired Midori Sour. I went for the Midori Sour but they ran out of whatever that made it and said they had blue or whatever-I-couldn't-hear Sour. I went for the Blue Sour. Imagine walking back with a blue drink to a table of macho guys who were into martial arts and drinking brown beer...

Anyway overall I had fun (guessed the alcohol totally kicked in) and the game was actually enjoyable (not so bloody in the end). The decor was like a regular dive bar and music was not loud so you could have a conversation. The drink was inexpensive too, $4 for a cocktail. I don't know if it was the right price since I barely ever paid for my own drinks.

Cheap beers on Sundays. Nice bartender.

I was with two friends. One friend bought first round; I bought next round; and the bartender gave my other friend his round for free (we worked it out). They had a good beer selection and nice outdoor seating area.
The hood itself is douchey, but that can't hate on the place for that.

Out of all the village bars I probably go to this one the least just because it's at the end of the street.  I always park in the lot on the other side of the street and by the time I get to this bar I'm already too drunk or too tired.  Honestly this is the worst just because there's nothing special about this place.  It has less selection than the gingerman and there's no music.  The only thing is there's not a bouncer a lot of times so people can just walk in.

Another Village bar, but one of the more tolerable ones.  Parking sucks.  The staff is nice and the patrons aren't too loud and frat-boyish.  This feels a little different because the patio is bigger than the indoor area, which can be a downside in the Houston summer/humidity.  As a native Houstonian, I am accustomed to central air everywhere.  The idea of sitting on a patio in Houston in August is beyond me.  And our air quality is so bad, why would you want voluntarily subject your lungs and skin to it, unless you're looking for a free spa?

Great student hangout in the village! Can we say GOLDEN T? Pints and Pints of Beer with fast table service. The patio is where it's at at Woodys. There's a "backyard" type atmosphere here with all of the huge wood panels. A great place for hanging out with friends. This is a great place to kick back after work for a couple of beers. The only suggestion that I have is stop by BW3s for your food before you go, because your next options is ordering a pizza for insane prices. Sometimes on the weekends they will have someone grilling burgers and fajitas.

Been going here for years and it's my bar of choice in the Rice Village.  Can get a little overcrowded some nights, but it is a great bar to hang out with friends.  Good beer selection and a full bar.

Little Woodrows was sort of what I expected. I mean, I've been to a lot of the bars in this area and they all have the same vibe. Big wood panels, outdoors, great beer selection and a generally young and yuppy crowd. Lots of people here were either in the tech industry, medical grads or Rice students. 

There were plenty of places to sit, huge pic nic tables, no loud annoying music. I don't even know how many beers were on tap but I know it was a lot. They had massive cheap 20 oz drafts of Lone Star for $2.50 a piece. I couldn't believe how cheap! 

The bartender was great, she remembered what I wanted every time I came to the bar, and knew what beers they had without having to check. Although I'm a loser when it comes to Megatouch machines and I was a little disappointed that they didn't have more games on it. Although they did have some other cool games there. 

I went during the week so it wasn't as crowded as I've seen it be when I walk by on the weekends. I saw that they have Geeks Who Drink on Tuesday nights at 8 and that is a lot of fun. I haven't done it there but I've played it elsewhere and it's always a good time. I definitely recommend this place.

A lot of times I find when my boyfriend and I or a group of friends can't figure out where to go drink, this is a safe, dependable spot. The atmosphere is casual - it's usually buzzing with conversation, there's darts, pool, the electronic jukebox, and occasionally I like to play with the photo hunt game at the bar. They've also got a nice patio.

As for the service and beer itself, every night of the week they've got a drink special, besides the Happy Hour, which is from 2-7pm.  I usually end up going from 7-10pm Saturday night for their $3 You-call-it mug - IT'S HUUUUUGE!!! The bartenders are always nice and friendly and do their best to get to you. It sometimes can get pretty crowded at the bar and if you're a small, short woman like myself, it can take them awhile to notice you. =\

If you're in for a challenge, they have the "Big 50 Club" where you go through their list of beers in order over the course of several visits. Once you finish, you get a t-shirt and a wooden plackard with your name on it and nailed to the wall/ceiling for all to admire your amazing feat, along with the other 23909052430680396 names (it still looks cool altogether) and after spending quite a bit towards the end (they've got Chimay and Lambic on the list), which kind of sucks, but it is what it is.

After cycling around downtown Houston, my brother and I were ready for some food and a beer.  It was 11am on a Saturday morning.  We parked in the parking garage, crossed the street to the Gingerman, and... it wasn't open  yet.  

Luckily for us, just a few doors down was Little Woodrows.  The beer selection was more than adequate, the bartender was pretty, and the sun was shining.  I don't remember whether they serve food at Little Woodrows, but there were takeout restaurants on the same street.  We ended up having Greek food with our beer.

This bar has a very chill atmosphere. Good selection of beers which is always nice, although they can be pricey depending on what you select. They have plenty of seating both indoor and outdoor. It's in a good location if you want to bar hop, but parking can be a hassle. Overall it's a great place if you're looking for a laid back evening with friends.

I prefer Gingerman, but that hasn't stopped me from going to Woodrow's a time or three before. Don't let that stop you, either.

If your girl doesn't imbibe beer, you can get a $9 Lambic Framboise at Gingerman or a $2 frozen mimosa at Woodrow's. Your choice.

I think they have a full bar now, so I bumped it up a star. Stellar.
Underrated. Most little woodrows give me the big heeby jeebys, but this one is the most palatable. Staff is nice, good beers on tap, and relatively low on meatheads. I give you props, little woody

Absolutely love this place.  It seems that this is one of the few places in Rice Village that really doesn't get overpowering on the weekends.  They've got a decent amount of beer on tap and the prices are average.  They also have darts and pool tables so they've A-okay in my book!
Cool place to hang out and chill. Big patio outside. Pool table and darts. But the women's bathroom smells like wet dog...
